headline: Mixed Opening Lines in Knicks’ Courtship of Anthony
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It didn’t take long for Steve Mills to address his primary mission in assuming the Knicks’ top executive position last week, courtesy of his former and once again benefactor, James L. Dolan. On N.B.A. media day, Mills explained how the job opportunity appeared suddenly, announced the exercising of an option year for Coach Mike Woodson and then got down to the business of what promises to be a season of breathtaking pandering to Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Greece: A Vow to Erase a ‘Shame’
text: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece suggested on Monday that he wanted to eradicate Golden Dawn, the neo-fascist xenophobic political party that is now facing a major government crackdown on charges it is a criminal organization involved in murder, attempted murder, blackmail and other crimes. Mr. Samaras, who was visiting New York for the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, said in a reception sponsored by the American Jewish Committee that his government had no tolerance for the party’s anti-immigrant intimidation tactics and other fascist behavior. “We are dedicated in completely eradicating such a shame,” he said. “We must do it within the context of our democratic Constitution. But we have to go all the way and do whatever it takes.” His remarks appeared to go beyond previous statements about trying to curb the power of Golden Dawn, which has 18 members in Parliament. Over the weekend, the police arrested six of them, including the party’s leader.

headline: Coming Soon? An Occupy Wall Street Debit Card
text: To mark the second anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement last month, an assortment of protests, marches and rallies were held, to support or oppose mostly predictable causes.

headline: Sugar Industry Highlights Conflicts Over Trade Pacts and Land
text: OMLIANG COMMUNE, Cambodia — Yim Lon nurses bitter memories of how three years ago the local authorities forced her and her family to dismantle their small home and move it to make way for a sugar plantation.

headline: City Unveils Campaign to Improve Girls’ Self-Esteem
text: The fashion industry and Madison Avenue are not anathema to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in the same way that soda companies and big tobacco are. But they are, in a sense, the impetus for City Hall’s latest public health campaign.

headline: Markets Assess the Impact of a Federal Shutdown
text: Updated, 10:04 a.m. | As investors cautiously pulled back from the markets, economists were grappling with how much a government shutdown could dent confidence in an already fragile economy.

headline: Durability of Stoudemire, Once a Star, Is in Question
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Only after Amar’e Stoudemire climbed onto the dais and took a seat on a folding chair did he begin the painstaking process of figuring out how to position his legs underneath a table that was not designed for especially large human beings. Then again, what was one more challenge?

headline: Senate Democrats Ready to Reject House Bill Immediately
text: Though they have yet to receive any budget bill at all from the House, which has yet to vote on one, Senate Democrats said Monday evening that they would vote immediately to reject whatever legislation they received, assuming it contained any policy prescriptions.

headline: James Street Dies at 65; Led Texas to Title
text: The showdown between Texas and Arkansas, both undefeated after nine games, was hailed as the biggest game of the 1969 college football season. The Rev. Billy Graham gave the invocation. President Richard M. Nixon, who arrived in a helicopter, promised to award the victor a plaque as national champion.

headline: Christie Wants State’s Top Court to Block Gay Marriage Ruling
text: Gov. Chris Christie moved on Monday to block same-sex marriages that would otherwise be allowed in late October after a judge’s ruling last week that the New Jersey Constitution requires the state to allow them.

headline: Jobs Report May Be a Shutdown Casualty
text: Updated, 10/1/13 12:57 p.m. | with Bureau of Labor Statistics announcement.

headline: Doubts Raised on Value of Investment Consultants to Pensions
text: Here’s a brainteaser: Would you invest $10,000 in a mutual fund without knowing its past performance? Probably not. Yet, if you were in charge of $13 trillion of pension money, would you accept the recommendation of an investment consultant without knowing its performance record? The answer is yes. It happens every day.

headline: Bob Kurland, 88, Pioneer for Basketball’s Big Men, Dies
text: Bob Kurland, a forerunner of basketball’s dominant “big man,” who led Oklahoma A&M to two consecutive N.C.A.A. championships in the mid-1940s, then starred for two gold-medal-winning United States Olympic teams, died on Sunday at his home on Sanibel Island, Fla. He was 88.

headline: House Passes Another Budget Bill Delaying Health Law
text: With hours to go before the federal government runs out of money, the House on Monday night passed its latest bill to link further government financing to a weakening of President Obama‘s health care law.

headline: L. C. Greenwood, Member of ‘Steel Curtain,’ Dies at 67
text: L. C. Greenwood, a 6-foot-6 blend of power, speed and style who as a member of the Pittsburgh Steelers’ “Steel Curtain” defense in the 1970s helped lead his team to four Super Bowl victories, died on Sunday in Pittsburgh. He was 67.

headline: Man Who Aided Al Qaeda Gets 18-Year Prison Sentence
text: A former Brooklyn man who was accused of conducting surveillance of the New York Stock Exchange for a possible terrorist attack was sentenced on Monday to 18 years in prison, 2 years less than the maximum term that prosecutors had sought.

headline: Israel: Egyptian Rescuer Is Honored
text: An Egyptian doctor who hid a Jewish woman in a cabin he owned in Berlin during World War II has become the first Arab honored as part of the “Righteous Among the Nations” by Yad Vashem, Israel’s Holocaust memorial. Starting in 1942, the doctor, Mohamed Helmy, provided the cabin to one of his patients, Anna Boros, then 21, and also helped her mother, stepfather and grandfather survive the war, according to a news release Yad Vashem issued Monday. He was aided by a German woman, Frieda Szturmann, who also has been added to the “Righteous” group, now more than 24,800 people from nearly 50 countries. “I will be grateful to him for eternity,” Ms. Boros wrote of Dr. Helmy after the war. She moved to Brooklyn and died in the 1980s, according to Yad Vashem. Dr. Helmy died in 1982.

headline: Federal Official at Center of the Health Care Tumult Has Gone Against the Grain
text: WASHINGTON — The federal official in charge of health insurance shopping malls, which open Tuesday under President Obama’s health care law, has been challenging conventional wisdom since he came to Washington from California three and a half years ago.

headline: Indonesia: Australian Leader Aims to Halt Flow of Asylum Seekers
text: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia pledged Monday to work with Indonesia to stop the flow of people traveling by boat to Australia to seek asylum, even as his new government pursued a tough policy of turning back vessels that has created diplomatic tension between the countries. Mr. Abbott, who traveled to Indonesia for talks, has come under fire for continuing a policy that ships asylum seekers arriving by boat to third countries for processing and denies them the right to ever settle in Australia. Mr. Abbott’s own plans for combating people smuggling — including forcing boats packed with asylum seekers back into Indonesian waters, buying up boats and gathering intelligence in Indonesian villages — have been heavily criticized by Indonesia. Migrants from the Middle East and South Asia pay smugglers to get them into Indonesia and then onto rickety boats that make the perilous voyage to the Australian territory of Christmas Island, where the migrants can apply for asylum. On Friday, a vessel carrying about 100 people from Lebanon, Pakistan and Iraq sank off West Java, killing at least 36 people.

headline: Going Long. Going Short.
text: I’ve always wanted to go long, as in writing that big behemoth of a saga called the “Great American Novel,” no matter the absurdity of questing after such a holy grail. I thought the best way to understand the endless ribbons of America’s highways, the oozing boundaries of our suburbia and the rhythms of life they induce in us, resided in an ever expansive aesthetic of maximalist comprehensiveness, full of crisscrossing tentacles of story lines and sentences bursting with syntactic curlicues. Our souls sprawl with this land, after all. Think of the labyrinthine universe of David Foster Wallace, the dense weight of William Faulkner’s past (which I share only literarily, not genetically) or Saul Bellow’s overflowing, burbling prose.

headline: Vacation-Averse as Mayor, Bloomberg Says He Will Take One on Jan. 2
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a self-described workaholic who has ascribed his success partly to not leaving his desk to go to the bathroom, is planning a vacation.

headline: Miller Seeks Fresh Start Following Hardships
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Just in time to try to make his fifth Winter Olympics, Bode Miller is back: as fit, refreshed and interesting as ever.

headline: Iran Staggers as Sanctions Hit Economy
text: TEHRAN — The owner of a bus manufacturing company here admits that he is a man who likes his routines, and so every day he continues to commute to his downtown office. There he orders cups of tea, barks orders to his factory foremen over the phone and signs a steady flow of papers his employees put on his desk.

headline: Beyond Berlusconi
text: ROME — FOR those outside Italy who assumed that the era of Silvio Berlusconi was over, the latest crisis — in which he ordered five of his party’s ministers in the coalition government to resign — must come as a rude awakening to the realities of Italian politics. But to Italians, the situation is sadly predictable, and it speaks volumes about the sorry state of the country’s political landscape.

headline: Financial Watchdog With Bite to Depart His Agency
text: David Meister is waging legal battles against some of the biggest names in finance.

headline: Keep Farmland for Farmers
text: CLERMONT, N.Y. — WHEN we went looking in upstate New York for a home for our farm, we feared competition from deep-pocketed developers, a new subdivision or a big-box store. These turned out to be the least of our problems.

headline: The Rut We Can’t Get Out Of
text: THE Federal Reserve confounded the bond markets last month by clinging to its easy-money policies. The federal government has shut down today because of an impasse over the budget. And in two weeks, the nation is set to hit its borrowing limit.

headline: Obama Selects Romney Adviser for Social Security Commission
text: President Obama announced on Monday that he planned to nominate Lanhee J. Chen, the top policy adviser to Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential campaign, to fill an opening on an independent federal panel whose task is to recommend improvements to Social Security.

headline: Government Workers Get a Self-Esteem Boost, or Blow, as Shutdown Approaches
text: As the prospect of a government shutdown loomed closer, government agencies have been briefing their employees and contractors over whether they are deemed to provide an essential service that will continue as Congress fights over the budget. Those declared essential will report to work on Tuesday. Those considered nonessential will be furloughed while the politics are worked out on Capitol Hill. A guide to who is and who isn’t furloughed is available here.

headline: Vote Tuesday in Runoff Election
text: Because no Democratic candidate for New York City public advocate received 40 percent of the vote in the primary election on Sept. 10, a runoff between the two top vote-getters is Tuesday. Our choice is State Senator Daniel Squadron. The polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

headline: Conservatives With a Cause: ‘We’re Right’
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, was the first to take to the Senate floor to publicly pose a question gnawing at an increasing number of lawmakers and ordinary citizens alike as the deadline for a government shutdown neared: Has Congress gone completely crazy?

headline: A Football Match Where Hooligans Take a Back Seat to Vikings
text: LONDON — Olaf Orywall and his family came from Berlin. Graham and Erica Smith came from Scotland. Jim Kennelly came from Melbourne, Australia, and a considerable number, like Rondell and Deborah Hannah, came from the United States.

headline: A Historic Fair Housing Decision Reaffirmed
text: The New Jersey Supreme Court has wisely rejected an attempt by Gov. Chris Christie to undermine its 30-year-old-ruling in the Mount Laurel fair housing case, one of the more important civil rights decisions of the modern era. In last week’s strongly worded decision, the court made clear that it would be keeping a close eye on both the Christie administration and wealthy communities that might be inclined to flout the law, which limits the use of exclusionary zoning as a means of preventing the construction of affordable housing.

headline: Containing the Conventional Arms Trade
text: Efforts to control the $70 billion a year global market in conventional weapons got a big boost when the United States signed the United Nations arms trade treaty, joining more than 100 other countries in affirming the need to keep these weapons out of the hands of unscrupulous regimes, militants and criminals.

headline: Pirates and Reds Renew a Rivalry
text: PITTSBURGH — It is only natural for the Cincinnati Reds to be here for the first playoff game at PNC Park. They were here for the opener, in 2001, and for decades they have risen and fallen in tandem with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: The Dishonesty of Voter ID Laws
text: The Justice Department on Monday sued North Carolina over the state’s restrictive new voting law, which requires photo identification for in-person voting and cuts back on early voting and same-day registration — all of which will disproportionately affect black voters. The suit, which follows similar litigation against Texas, is the latest effort by the department to go after voting discrimination in the wake of the Supreme Court’s ruling in June striking down part of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: The Fight Against Bullying in Schools Expands to Store Shelves
text: AMONG 12- to 17-year-olds, 47 percent of girls and 34 percent of boys report having been bullied either face-to-face or online, according to a survey by Mintel, a market research firm. And prominent cases of teenagers committing suicide after being harassed on social media networks have, along with strengthening the resolve of antibullying organizations, prompted brands to take up the issue.

headline: Those Banana Republicans
text: They say that the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result. Why is it that the Republicans in Congress seem so determined to prove this maxim?

headline: Football Gains Toehold in Nation of Soccer Fans
text: At Wembley stadium in London, a sold-out crowd of 83,500 people watched as the Minnesota Vikings defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers.

headline: Cubs Fire Manager, Leading to Talk About Girardi
text: CHICAGO — In the Cubs’ 137-year history, no two-season stretch has been worse, mathematically, than 2012 and 2013. After suffering 101 defeats a year ago, the Cubs lost another 96 games this season, and on Monday, the president for baseball operations, Theo Epstein, fired Manager Dale Sveum.

headline: Con Edison May Have Caused Metro-North Line’s Power Loss
text: Consolidated Edison acknowledged on Monday that the power loss that has left travelers on Metro-North Railroad’s New Haven line hamstrung since Wednesday was most likely related to the utility’s work disconnecting a feeder cable that was previously taken out of service for equipment upgrades.

headline: Mergers Holding Steady
text: The third quarter was by far dominated by one of the largest deals in history: Verizon Communications’ $130 billion deal to take full control of its enormous wireless unit by buying out its partner, Vodafone. That deal catapulted the telecommunications sector to being the leading industry for deals this year.

headline: Unrest in Central Sudan Leads to Arrests of 700
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The worst week of violent unrest that central Sudan has seen in years has resulted in the arrests of 700 people, the government said on Monday, along with many deaths and an unprecedented crackdown on the news media.

headline: Senate Rejects House Bill and Sends It Back
text: The Senate voted swiftly Monday night to kill new House legislation tying further government funding to the Republicans’ latest hit on President Obama’s health care law, sending a spending bill free of policy prescriptions back to the House less than an hour after the House approved it.

headline: Patricia Blair Dies at 80; Starred in Television’s  ‘Daniel Boone’
text: Patricia Blair, an actress who played resourceful women in 1960s television westerns like “Daniel Boone” and “The Rifleman,” died on Sept. 9 at her home in North Wildwood, N.J. She was 80.

Collins wore a dress shirt for the occasion. He was thrilled to be kept on, to see, as he put it, the light at the end of the tunnel.

headline: A Monument to the West That Many Pass By
text: KEARNEY, Neb. — When the three-million-pound Great Platte River Road Archway, as long as a football field, was suspended over Interstate 80 here nearly a decade and a half ago, promoters hailed it as a singular monument to westward expansion that would draw at least a million visitors a year.

headline: Obama Signs Bill to Ensure Military Will Be Paid During Shutdown
text: In an overnight message to troops and Defense Department personnel as the government shut down on Tuesday, the president said he would work to get Congress to reopen it as soon as possible.President Obama signed a law late Monday night that ensures United States military personnel will continue to be paid even if the government is forced to shut down at midnight.

headline: Time for Smith to Learn, Quickly
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It was last Tuesday, a day off for the Jets, and the quarterbacks had a brief break in their meeting room between film sessions. So, naturally, during those five free minutes, they chose to watch more film. In awe, they watched some of Peyton Manning’s dissection of the Giants from Sept. 15, another brilliant game in a brilliant season.

headline: Tenant’s Fine for Renting to Tourist Is Overturned

headline: Reid Rejects Negotiation on Budget Bill

But before the early morning vote was even called, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, dismissed the House maneuver as game playing.

headline: Poll Shows Major Shift in Identity of U.S. Jews
text: The first major survey of American Jews in more than 10 years finds a significant rise in those who are not religious, marry outside the faith and are not raising their children Jewish — resulting in rapid assimilation that is sweeping through every branch of Judaism except the Orthodox.

headline: Japan Sales Tax to Increase Next Year, Abe Says

headline: Boom, Bust, Flip

So they took out a 30-year mortgage and bought a fixer-upper on a quiet street in Seattle’s Roxhill neighborhood for $309,900. That was in the spring of 2007.

headline: Is It Principled, or Irresponsible, for Politicians to Threaten a Shutdown?
text: Budget crises, fiscal cliffs and debt ceiling emergencies might feel so common in Congress that they’re hard to take seriously, but government shutdowns — like the last one in 1995-96 — do affect millions of people. Also, they end up costing the government more money, not less.

headline: Revisiting Minamata, and a Storied Mentor
text: W. Eugene Smith was impassioned in covering the deadly effects of industrial mercury pollution in Minamata, Japan, during the early 1970s. The photo essay dramatically revealed the poisoning’s human toll and brought Mr. Smith even further acclaim.

headline: Aftermath of the Mumbai Building Collapse
text: MUMBAI—As buildings in Mumbai fall down with an alarming frequency, much of the blame has been placed on construction companies that used shoddy techniques or owners who neglected to make the necessary repairs. In the latest accident near the Mazgaon dockyard, the owner of the building is the city government itself.

headline: China Is Said to Be Holding a Professor Based in Japan

headline: Daily Report: F.A.A. Supports Easing Rules for Electronic Devices
text: Airline passengers should be allowed to use their personal electronic devices to read, play games or enjoy movies and music, even when planes are on the ground or flying below 10,000 feet, according to recommendations an advisory panel sent to the Federal Aviation Administration on Monday, Jad Mouawad reports.

headline: The Many Job Descriptions of a Business Owner
text: Consider the story of Brian Schutt and Jesse Cross, two classmates at Purdue, where they studied business. Mr. Cross began a career investing in real estate, and along the way he figured out that real estate required a lot of maintenance work. Instead of outsourcing the work, he decided to learn what it would take to repair and keep up the real estate he owned himself. That experience convinced him that he had stumbled upon a business opportunity, and the result was Homesense Heating and Cooling.

headline: In Performance:  A Yiddish ‘Waiting for Godot’
text: This week’s In Performance video features a scene from Samuel Beckett’s existential play “Waiting for Godot,” presented by the New Yiddish Rep and the Castillo Theater in what they are calling the play’s first-ever production in Yiddish. (It is being staged with English and Russian supertitles. ) The work has been translated into Yiddish from the play’s French and English versions by Shane Baker, who stars in the production as Vladimir. In this scene, a young boy (Nicholas Jenkins) tells Vladimir that Godot won’t be coming that day after all. The production, directed by Moshe Yassur, continues at the Castillo Theater through Oct. 13.

headline: Wariness as Government Shuts Down
text: Investors cautiously pulled back from the markets as a flurry of political moves in Washington on Monday evening failed to end a budget standoff, setting up the first government shutdown in nearly two decades, The New York Times reports. Stock markets around the world fell on Monday, though the declines were relatively modest in the United States while negotiations in Congress remained stalled, Nathaniel Popper writes in DealBook. Markets in Europe were higher on Tuesday, while stock index futures in the United States pointed to a higher opening Tuesday morning in New York.

headline: Hagel Says National Security Will Not Be Compromised
text: SEOUL — Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel said Tuesday that 400,000 civilian employees in the Defense Department would be furloughed, though legislation signed by President Obama would ensure that uniformed members of the military would be paid in full and on time. Department lawyers were combing the legislative language to see if “there’s any margin or widening of the interpretation of the law regarding exempt” employees who could possibly be called back to work, Mr. Hagel said.

headline: Federal Workers Arrive to Uncertainty
text: The crowds were lighter than normal early Tuesday at L’Enfant Plaza in Washington, where there are a number of federal agencies. Phillip Davenport, a management analyst at the Federal Aviation Administration, who is considered an essential employee, said he was expecting a heavier workload.

headline: On Day 1, Parks Close, Workers Stay Home and ‘Panda Cam’ Goes Dark

headline: Vietnam’s Trade of Underaged Species
text: HO CHI MINH CITY — “It’s basic police work,” said Michael Brosowski describing his activities with the Blue Dragon Children’s Foundation, a nongovernmental agency that rescues children working in sweatshops in Vietnam. When it learns about a case of child labor, workers for the agency scout out suspected factories, snoop around posing as, say, electricians, and keep getaway cars on hand.

headline: Favorites? Broncos, by a Wide Margin
text: Twenty months ago, Eli Manning and the Giants won the Super Bowl at Lucas Oil Field in Indianapolis, then the home stadium of his All-Pro brother, Peyton. This year, Peyton Manning seems poised to return the favor. No team is hotter through four weeks than the Denver Broncos. Although five teams are undefeated, the Broncos’ scorched-earth pace makes them the front-runners for the Super Bowl at MetLife Stadium.

headline: The Politics of Religious Conversions in Jharkhand
text: ARA, Jharkhand— Early on an idle Sunday morning in late August, Ram Singh Kujur perched on the solitary broken wooden chair outside his mud hut, sipping tea from a disfigured steel tumbler. Sundays never used to be such in the Kujur residence. Seven years ago, the Kujurs would have excitedly woken up early, put on their best clothes and head toward the village church. Now, the family of seven bathes and duly assembles in front of Lord Ram’s idol, positioned in the corner of their single-room house.

headline: Art Collector’s Diary: Me, My Mouse and I

headline: Bookshelf | A Big Book of Architectural Entertainment
text: Publications devoted to architecture typically follow a narrow blueprint. There are shelter magazines, like the now-defunct Nest and The World of Interiors, that chronicle the in-good-taste décor of worldly aesthetes; scholarly journals that treat buildings in abstract theoretical terms; and quaint Martha Stewart-esque titles chock-full of how-tos for painting bedroom walls the just-so shade of robin’s-egg blue. So when Pin-Up, a self-described “magazine for architectural entertainment,” first came out in 2006, its low-key tête-à-tête format, antidesign typography and droll intellectual tenor was as subversive as it was groundbreaking. “The one thing that has always been consistent from Issue 1 was to have a more conversational tone within the context of broader architectural discourse and not have everything be so serious or jargony,” said Felix Burrichter, Pin-Up’s editor and founder (and a T contributor). “Pin-Up: Interviews” (powerHouse Books, $30), a new collection of 57 interviews that have appeared in the magazine’s past 16 issues, demonstrates just that.

headline: Beware Financial Comparisons With Others
text: When it comes to money, we like to think that we’d treat one dollar the same as the next. After all, a dollar is a dollar, right? And if someone offers us two dollars instead of one dollar, who wouldn’t jump at the chance? It will probably surprise you to learn that how we make that decision depends on whether someone else is involved.

headline: Becoming ‘Pen Pals’ With the K.K.K.
text: Christy Chan was around 8, the child of Chinese immigrants and living in a rural part of Virginia, when her family began receiving mysterious letters. As the sole English speaker in her household, Chan routinely translated everything that came her family’s way — pamphlets in the mail, notes from teachers and dentists. Then some new letters began arriving. They were formal, typed, with crosses on them. At the bottom they were signed, “The Wizard.”

headline: Qaeda Branch in Syria Pursues Its Own Agenda

headline: Three’s a Trend | Evening Wear Gets Some Disco Shine
text: For several seasons, designers have fixated on comfort and classics, trying to create the best knit turtleneck and the most functional day coat. But for spring, the emphasis has turned to shiny evening attire. From New York to Paris, crystals, metallics and lamé have dominated runways. At Lanvin, almost the entire collection of disco-ready amethyst and teal separates, dresses and jumpsuits featured bronze or chrome. At Givenchy, Riccardo Tisci sent out pleated evening dresses with reflective materials that glistened under the spotlight. At Haider Ackermann, the evening-focused collection included a gold-pleated dress draped over trousers for a night on the town.

headline: Tourists Find Washington Monuments Closed

headline: Walter White’s Dream

Nothing could be further from the truth: I’ve been writing about “Breaking Bad” so much in order to avoid staking out a clear position in the debates about Pope Francis’s recent interviews! But now the show has ended, so the blogging of evasion must as well — after this one last post, in which I explain why the show’s finale left me somewhat disappointed.

headline: Dividing Up the Job of Legal Counsel
text: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase have managed to get at least one job split right. Neither bank will cleave the chairman and chief executive roles, but they’ve figured out that allowing the general counsel to also run regulatory compliance invites trouble. Interpreting the rules and ensuring they’re followed too often conflict. Rival financial institutions — and companies in other industries, too — should follow suit.

headline: Bivouac and Bushwhackers
text: Five days after the Battle of Chickamauga, trainloads of Union wounded continued to rumble through Murfreesboro, Tenn., on their way to Nashville hospitals. Cpl. Joseph W. Ely of the 19th Michigan Infantry, who was stationed in Murfreesboro, a town in middle Tennessee, wrote in his diary about one wounded soldier who “fell off the cars at 12 o’clock and was picked up this morning. The cars had run over his legs. The feet were taken off this morning.” Judson Austin, one of Ely’s comrades, wrote to his wife that “the cars are loaded so full that the boys that are not too bad off ride on top of the cars & often riding all day they get tiard & sleepy. This is the way they get tumbled off & run over.”

headline: Health Care Coverage Business Is Bustling at New York City Hospital

Blue Cross Blue Shield of North Carolina reported that it was experiencing higher volumes of calls and online queries regarding coverage than usual, as well as more visits to its retail stores.

headline: After Being Denied Access, Veterans’ Group Allowed to Tour Memorial
text: WASHINGTON — When a large contingent of older veterans and their caregivers showed up at the World War II Memorial on Tuesday, they were blocked from entering by metal barricades with signs warning that the park was closed because of the government shutdown.

headline: The G.O.P. Definition of ‘Negotiation’
text: There were outbursts of disbelieving laughter from Democrats on Capitol Hill last night when the final demand from House Republicans arrived shortly before the midnight shutdown: a conference to negotiate their differences.

headline: Wasting No Time, Cashman Tries to Keep Girardi With the Yankees
text: Brian Cashman spoke for 50 minutes 31 seconds at his annual end-of-season news conference Tuesday, an unusually long dialogue. But after a disappointing 2013 season, in which the Yankees failed to make the playoffs for only the second time in 19 years, there were many topics to discuss.

headline: What Does the Affordable Care Act Mean for Your Business?
text: It’s been three and a half years since the Affordable Care Act became the law of the land, and the enormous changes it will bring to the American health insurance market are upon us. As of Tuesday — glitches and delays aside — small-business owners and individuals are able to begin shopping for health insurance policies on online exchanges, and in many cases receive tax credits to offset the cost.

headline: ‘Your Money’ Columnist Is Answering Health Care Questions
text: The Times is answering readers’ questions about the new health care exchanges in the Your Money column. The latest  one covered many of the basics. If you’re still not sure how the law affects you and your family, please e-mail your questions to tsbernard@nytimes.com.

headline: In Paris, a New Breed of Wine Bar
text: For many tourists in Paris, ordering a glass of wine can often be intimidating, an embarrassing collision with a heavy, leather-bound menu and the haughty gaze of the sommelier.

headline: Cycling and Sipping Between Germany and France
text: The man, in his 60s, emerged from a side street in the small town of  Oberrotweil, Germany. He didn’t say much, but we heard his message, which was printed on his T-shirt: “Wine improves with age. I improve with wine.”

headline: South by Southwest to Add Sports Component
text: LOS ANGELES — Music. Film. Interactive. Sports?

headline: Tribes Lose Battle to Shield Payday Sites From New York  State Crackdown
text: A federal judge has denied a request by two American Indian tribes to stop New York State’s top financial regulator from cracking down on their online lending businesses.

headline: Shutdown Implications Extend to Food and Product Safety
text: As large portions of the federal government shut down on Tuesday, some agencies felt the impact more than others.

headline: A Google Glass Alternative in Japan
text: TOKYO — Foreign tourists visiting this city have long encountered translation help. But the methods are not perfect, including at restaurants, where sign language, photographs and plastic models of sushi and sashimi have been used.

headline: What ‘Connected Education’ Looks Like: 28 Examples From Teachers All Over
text: A video created by Esther Wojcicki’s journalism students at Palo Alto High School to encourage other students to “impact the world” with new ways of learning.

headline: Making a Stand-Up Meal of the Sit-Down Taco
text: Talking about the best taco you’ve ever had in a restaurant is like talking about the best kiss you’ve ever had in a hospital. No matter how good it was, it would have been better somewhere else.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: 2013 N.L. Wildcard — Pirates 6, Reds 2
text: Anyone who has even casually followed the Pittsburgh Pirates this season is probably familiar with one particular number: 21. That’s how many years it had been since the Pirates have made the postseason, let alone had a winning season.

headline: As J.C. Penney Flounders, a Lack of Control Becomes Evident
text: The latest events at J. C. Penney provide a hard lesson: With today’s public company, it is sometimes difficult to be sure who is in control.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Spring 2014 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Justices to Hear ‘Raging Bull’ Copyright Appeal
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear an appeal in a copyright dispute arising from the movie “Raging Bull,” and it added seven other cases to its docket.

headline: George Will to Leave ABC News for Fox News
text: George Will, who has been a conservative presence on ABC News for more than three decades, is leaving for the Fox News Channel, the cable news network announced on Tuesday.

headline: Betting on a Nobel Winner
text: Compared with, say, the Academy Awards or the Booker Prize, the Nobel Prize for Literature is shrouded in mystery. There is no list of nominees. Even the date of the announcement is kept secret. So how do bookmakers every year confidently put forward a list of odds for who will win the prize?

headline: The Cecil Opens in Harlem, Michelin Star Rankings and More
text: Headliner

headline: With Grand Canyon Closed, Cancellations Pour In for Arizona
text: PHOENIX — Train trips from Northern Arizona to Grand Canyon National Park have been canceled. Rafting expeditions along the Colorado River have been suspended. Hotels have relaxed refund policies for travelers who have booked rooms near one of the 24 national parks in the state that were closed on Tuesday.

headline: Citing Efforts to Prevent Attack on Syria, Group Nominates Putin for Peace Prize
text: MOSCOW — He is credited with commanding a war to crush separatism in Chechnya, approving a full-scale attack on Georgia over a minor border dispute and complaining when NATO led an air war in Libya to stop Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from killing thousands of Libyans. And he is still selling weapons to the murderous government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: A Campaign to Make Route 66 Hip Once More
text: What better way to revitalize a stretch of Route 66, the historic highway stretching from Chicago to Los Angeles, than with a filling station and a motor-court cottage? The city of Springfield, Mo., has plans to turn both into the visitors’ center of a new roadside park it is building as part of an effort to help bring new life to run-down areas of the 12-mile stretch of highway that runs through the city.

headline: When Writing Well Is Part of the Problem
text: The author of this past weekend’s Lives essay reflects on the most useful feedback she has received about writing fiction.

headline: Internal Dissent Imperils Berlusconi’s Long Reign Atop His Party
text: ROME — For two decades, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has not just led Italy’s powerful center-right political movement; he has practically owned it. A billionaire media mogul, he has bankrolled campaigns and vetted his party’s candidates. His power has been so absolute that even at age 77, he still has not truly groomed a successor.

headline: The Courts and the Shutdown
text: The opening of a new Supreme Court term on the statutorily prescribed first Monday in October is always surrounded by a fair amount of drama having to do with the momentous legal issue the justices will be taking up. The government shutdown has imbued the start of the 2013-2014 term this coming Monday, Oct. 7, with a different sort of suspense.

headline: Utah Senator Causes Uproar Among House Republicans
text: Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, may have only been trying to support House Republicans, but some comments from Mr. Lee — one of the captains of the effort to defund the health care law — are upsetting the Republican ranks.

headline: Roots of Current Impasse Go Back to 1974
text: WASHINGTON — Congress, at odds with the president, was struggling to assert more control over the federal government through the budget process but could not seem to wrap up its work on deadline. So the House and Senate voted to change the budget-making process, and lawmakers gave themselves a deadline extension to get their fiscal house in order.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 5: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
text: Welcome to the fantasy football quarter turn. Philip Rivers is a top five fantasy quarterback, Joique Bell has almost tripled C. J. Spiller’s fantasy output and Roddy White has one eighth of the fantasy points that Eddie Royal has. Just what was expected (or not).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, Kenya, Afghanistan and the West Bank.

headline: Lawyer Contests Casino Referendum’s Wording
text: ALBANY — Seeking to stop a November referendum that would allow more casinos across the state, a Brooklyn lawyer filed a suit here on Tuesday arguing that the ballot measure’s language is improperly slanted in favor of its passage.

headline: Rio's Chicken Wings at Home
text: Melissa Clark recreates the spicy chicken wings from Ganso, a Japanese restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn, in the comfort of her kitchen.

headline: Dreaming of Spicy, Crunchy Chicken Wings
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Austin, Tex., Stands Out in Hotel Recovery That Has Hugged Coasts
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Skittish developers have delayed new hotels across much of the country until the economy returns to health, and financing does, too. But in Austin, developers aren’t that wary.

headline: Effects of Shutdown Felt in the Final Frontier
text: One agency that has been particularly idled by the shutdown is NASA — the astronauts on the International Space Station and mission control are working, but relatively few other people are. NASA’s popular television channel has gone dark, no longer showing feeds from space missions, and its various Twitter accounts are silent.

headline: Vows Column Angers Readers With Mention of Child’s Death as a Spiritual Milestone
text: With the government shutting down and Marine generals being forced out for negligence, the subject of a weddings-oriented column in The Times is, no doubt, relatively unimportant. But because it has been the subject of plenty of angry reader e-mail, I am taking it up here.

headline: John Armleder, the Artist Who Believes in Everything
text: “My dream is to go to a show and wonder, ‘Who is that artist?’ and find out it’s my work,” said John Armleder, the Swiss painter, sculptor and performance artist who spent the past few years recovering from the removal of a brain tumor. “Before I got ill, I did wall paintings with models of brains,” he said. “Both myself and the guy who published those paintings landed up with brain problems.” Now, the 66-year-old is back on the scene with an untitled, unthematic show at Nahmad Contemporary, on the Upper East Side. Unlike most artists, Armleder didn’t oversee the installation. “I consider the artwork to exist as itself,” he said. “It’s the person who looks at it who gives its meaning.” In fact this show was conceptualized and curated by Joe Nahmad, the 23-year-old art dealer and gallery owner whose older brother was implicated in an F.B.I. poker raid last April.

headline: From a Tortilla, the Feeling of a Warm Embrace
text: My grandmother was working the day she met my grandfather on a garlic patch outside Mendota, Calif., in the flat fields of the San Joaquin Valley in the center of the state. It was 1942, and they were both 16. She liked to say — years later, standing in the kitchen of the house where she helped raise and feed us — that it was love at first smell. He was clipping garlic tops. She had just delivered lunch to some men in a nearby field.

headline: Employees Without Health Care Coverage Looking to Exchanges
text: AURORA, Colo. — Angela Graham, 51, has not had health insurance for years, and is not covered by her job conducting telephone surveys.

headline: An iPhone Case That Sharpens Your Photography Skills
text: Technology companies are rapidly improving camera functions and apps for smartphones, but one is focusing instead on how a smartphone case can improve photos.

headline: Untangle Your Cords
text: Recoil, a company in Park City, Utah, has developed a way to keep the cords attached to technology devices from becoming a knotted mess.

headline: Study of Hormone Use in Menopause Reaffirms Complex Mix of Risks and Benefits
text: Hormone therapy for menopause is one of the most divisive subjects in medicine, hailed by some as a boon to women’s comfort and well-being, vilified by others as a threat to health.

headline: The Softness, the Crunch, the Nostalgia of the Fish Taco
text: Some people get a faraway look in their eyes when they talk about fish tacos.

headline: National Zoo’s Panda Cam Goes Dark
text: WASHINGTON — One casualty of the impasse in Washington is the public’s look at the newborn panda at the Smithsonian National Zoo on the “Giant Panda Cam.”

headline: In a Public Offering, a Symbol of New York Gains a Symbol: ESRT
text: King Kong swung from it. Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr planned to meet at its top in “An Affair to Remember.” And now, the Empire State Building has a new claim to fame: it has gone public.

headline: But What Does the Shutdown Mean for Travelers?
text: If you’re about to board a plane, take the Acela or go camping, you’re probably wondering if the government shutdown means you’re out of luck. The answer: only if your itinerary includes a visit to a destination entirely run by the government, Stephanie Rosenbloom reports in The Times’s live blog on the fiscal crisis.

headline: What’s In It | Doritos Locos Tacos
text: Taco Bell’s Doritos Locos Taco is a marriage made in processed-food heaven. It joins a perfectly engineered snack with a proven fast-food colossus. Michael Moss asks: what’s in it?

headline: That Nacho Dorito Taste
text: THE INVENTOR OF DORITOS, a longtime Madison Avenue executive named Arch West, first envisioned this snack in 1964 as more than a golden-hued chip. He saw it as a marketing powerhouse, a vehicle for delivering endless varieties of new flavors.

headline: Into the Heart (and Other Assorted Body Parts) of Old Russia
text: “A Young Doctor’s Notebook” stands out on American television simply for being a serious adaptation of serious literature. Shakespeare aside, where have we seen that this year? Perhaps only in HBO’s “Parade’s End,” an adaptation of the novels by Ford Madox Ford, unless you count “Game of Thrones” or “Under the Dome.”

headline: Dropping In on Tragedy, as if You Were There
text: “Films Beget Films” is the title of Jay Leyda’s 1964 book about compilation films: new works stitched together out of old footage. In the case of “Let the Fire Burn,” it’s video that begets a riveting chronicle of the radical group Move’s clash with Philadelphia authorities and a catastrophic siege of its headquarters in 1985. Seamlessly fashioned from television news footage, public hearings and other sources, the movie relives an incredible chapter in American history.

headline: No Escape to Alcatraz
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The tourists arrived by the dozens carrying cameras and wearing sun hats only to be told that there would be no boats to the historic prison on Alcatraz Island.

headline: Disabled, but Still Dangerous
text: The new “Ironside” really should have added a suffix rather than simply borrowing the title of the old series starring Raymond Burr. Something like “Ironside on Steroids” or “Ironside: Angry and Annoying.”

headline: Comedies of Sensitivity and Squirms
text: “Super Fun Night,” an ABC comedy that stars Rebel Wilson as a loser looking for love, should be an easy sell. Everyone likes a Cinderella story, and, as Kimmie Boubier, a lawyer with a video diary and a weakness for jelly doughnuts, Ms. Wilson must be endearing.

headline: At Valentino, Leather Espadrilles Fit for Wanderers
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Plucky Opera’s Poignant Death Rattle
text: After 70 years, New York City Opera has folded, and people are furious about it — not just the choristers, orchestra players and other dedicated company personnel, but countless fans who have depended upon the “people’s opera” for decades.

headline: Netanyahu's U.N. Speech in 3 Minutes
text: Highlights from the speech by Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, at the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Video of Israel and Iran Sparring at U.N.
text: Following an extended attack on the credibility of Iran’s new president by Israel’s prime minister in an address to the United Nations on Tuesday, an Iranian diplomat exercised his country’s right to reply with scathing remarks of his own, as my colleagues Somini Sengupta and Rick Gladstone report.

headline: Missing Out on History in Boston
text: BOSTON — Vern Bengston, a retired teacher who made a pilgrimage from Idaho to Boston’s historic Faneuil Hall, was hopping mad. The storied building, where the likes of Samuel Adams, Daniel Webster and Frederick Douglass once held forth, is collateral damage in the government shutdown.

headline: Museum Celebrates an Artist Who Still Produces
text: When the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles asked Gere Kavanaugh to be an honoree Sunday at its annual fund-raiser, the 84-year-old designer had one stipulation: “She said, ‘Fine, but people need to understand that I’m not retiring,’ ” said Suzanne Isken, the museum’s executive director.

headline: Living in Irvington, N.Y.
text: A riverfront community in Westchester with abundant greenery and an attractive commute.

headline: Irvington, N.Y., Nature, Near the Upper West Side
text: The point of no return for Dr. Alton Barron, a Manhattan hand surgeon, came one day in the late 1990s. He was pushing his 3-year-old daughter, Chloe, in her stroller across Lincoln Park Plaza when the child spied a large grouping of leafless saplings in concrete containers and exclaimed, “Look, Daddy, a forest!”

headline: Ally of Ivory Coast Strongman Sought by International Court
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Charles Blé Goudé, a crucial ally of Laurent Gbagbo, the Ivory Coast strongman indicted on charges of crimes against humanity, is being sought on similar charges, the International Criminal Court said Tuesday.

headline: Where Indie Game Producers Come Out to Play
text: Digital distribution has been driving sales of independent video games for nearly a decade. But the rise of the indies can be traced in no small part to IndieCade, a quirky, artful gathering that attracts people from around the world to an event that’s known as the Sundance of games.

headline: F.D.A. Bans Three Arsenic Drugs Used in Poultry and Pig Feeds
text: In resolving a longstanding dispute, the Food and Drug Administration has announced that it will rescind approval for three of the four arsenic drugs that had been used in animal feeds at the request of the companies that market them.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | A Real-Life Look for Stella McCartney’s Lady on the Go
text: Stella McCartney’s models were aglow with simple, soft makeup and hair. To make sure the eyes weren’t lost in otherwise neutral faces, Pat McGrath used a taupe brown eye liner to draw a pseudo-cat-eye, which popped under subtle but full eyebrows. The hairstylist Eugene Souleiman ditched styling products altogether to focus instead on a clean head of hair. “Texturally, the hair is very light,” he explained. “It’s freshly washed, blown out straight with a round brush. The hair is literally draped over one ear, and pulled into a very taut ponytail.” The slightly messed tresses were in line with the show’s celebration of the chic, ever-on-the-go woman. Souleiman achieved the humble detail by lightly massaging the scalp, “just to bring out these little imperfections,” he said.

headline: Restaurant Report: Girasol in Los Angeles
text: When Alice Waters opened Chez Panisse in 1971, her philosophy was simple yet, for the time, radical: use seasonal, local ingredients whenever possible. The idea transformed eating in California and, eventually, the rest of the country. So what exactly is California cuisine these days?

headline: It’s No Longer on His Face, and It’s Got Ambitions
text: William Kentridge’s 2010 staging of Shostakovich’s first opera, “The Nose,” was one of the Metropolitan Opera’s most acclaimed productions of recent seasons, and for a critic just catching up with it when it was revived on Saturday afternoon, it was easy to see why. With unflagging energy and unfettered imagination, it powerfully seconds both the irreverent zaniness of the Gogol story on which the opera is based and the teeming exuberance of Shostakovich’s music.

headline: Like People You Know, Driven Yet Exhilarated
text: SEATTLE — The happily galvanized look of Pacific Northwest Ballet’s artists in “Air Twyla,” a triple bill of pieces by Twyla Tharp, is a marvel — and a sure sign of the inspirational effect this choreographer has upon dancers. Since its three works span 31 years, from “Nine Sinatra Songs” (1982) to “Waiting at the Station” (a world premiere), the program demonstrates much of the amazing diversity of Ms. Tharp, one of the very few living choreographers to whom the word “great” should be applied.

headline: Ex-Employees Allege Sexual Harassment at Women’s Networking Group
text: Four former employees of the National Association of Professional Women, a women’s networking group, have sued the organization and three of its executives, claiming that a manager had sexually harassed them and that their paychecks had been docked in violation of New York State labor law.

headline: Salsa Down the Decades
text: The great Puerto Rican salsa orchestra El Gran Combo has been around for 50 years, as the projected visuals of its current stage show tell you, or 51, as history tells you. Some of its songs have been in Spanish-speaking consciousness for so long that they’re bigger than the band, or bigger than what the band is now. And so El Gran Combo has a duty toward pageantry.

headline: Hopes for a Street Resistant to Rebirth
text: For decades, it’s been a retail version of a hard-to-crack whodunit: What is wrong with West Eighth Street?

headline: Movement Made for Listening
text: In the near darkness, it takes eyes awhile to adjust. Aural information dominates at first: rhythmic exhalations that sound human. As your pupils dilate, and the light very slowly brightens, four shapes, white and pulsing, grow discernible. The pace of the brightening doesn’t quicken, but recognition, when it comes, dawns instantly. The shapes are heads, bobbing like derricks. The blacknesses below the heads are bodies.

headline: Taco Crawl
text: The Aieee!!! taco is filled with a sautéed andouille sausage, onions and chiles, mixed with black beans and rice and topped by picante salsa, crema and scallions.

headline: Ziggy Stardust’s Reading Habits
text: Plenty of music fans could have guessed that David Bowie was a fan of George Orwell’s “Nineteen Eighty-Four,” since Mr. Bowie once aspired to produce a musical based on the novel. Now we have 99 other book recommendations from the Thin White Duke.

headline: A City in Limbo After the Shutdown
text: What happens to the nation’s capital when the government is shut down?

headline: Home Kits for Tortillas, Purple Tomatillos and More
text: To Chop: Purple Tomatillos Inspire Stunning Shades of Salsa

headline: Shutdown Q. and A.
text: The shutdown of the federal government has created widespread confusion. Here are some questions and answers about some of its specific and practical effects.

headline: She’s 16, but Not Thinking of Sweet
text: What is “Royals,” by Lorde, the New Zealand songwriter who performed at Webster Hall on Monday night, doing in the Top 10 alongside Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball” and Katy Perry’s “Roar”? Most of all, it’s insisting that pop listeners don’t have to settle for clichés.

headline: Ryan Links Budget Impasse to Debt Ceiling Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Budget Committee, suggested on Tuesday that the government shutdown may not be resolved for more than two weeks.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,264 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: For Your iPhone 5, a Personal Photo and Extra Juice
text: Battery cases and phone cases customized with photos you have taken are both staples of the phone accessory world. But not a battery case featuring a photo you have taken.

headline: Banksy Announces a Monthlong Show on the Streets of New York
text: “Hello, and welcome to Lower Manhattan,” the message begins, as elevator music plays. “Before you, you will see a ‘spray art’ by the artist Ban-sky. Or maybe not; it’s probably been painted over by now.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Alexander McQueen Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: New York to Sue Wells Fargo Over Mortgage Settlement
text: Fielding complaints from borrowers struggling to save their homes, New York’s top prosecutor is preparing a lawsuit against Wells Fargo, accusing the bank, the nation’s largest home lender, of flouting the terms of a multibillion-dollar settlement aimed at stanching foreclosure abuses.

headline: With Lagerfeld, No Need to Look Below the Surface
text: PARIS — Fashion designers including Miuccia Prada and Marc Jacobs have collaborated with artists, and artists frequently sit in the front row. The other day Jeff Koons attended Stella McCartney’s show. And sometimes the commercial trade-offs are as blunt as a handbag: in 2008, Louis Vuitton installed a shop at the Murakami retrospective at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Facebook Now Allows Users to Search Timelines
text: Facebook clearly has some Google envy. Yet after Facebook’s latest search additions to its Web site, Google probably has some Facebook envy, too.

headline: Performances Canceled at Ford’s Theater
text: The Ford’s Theater Society receives no federal financing and employs no federal workers, but the site where President Abraham Lincoln was shot has been barred from hosting any shows or performances during the government shutdown.

headline: What They Say Versus What They Mean
text: Over at Wonkblog, Lydia DePillis asks, “Remember when Republicans were worried about ‘economic uncertainty’?”

headline: Federal Data Reveals Variety of Health Care Plans
text: As the much-anticipated health care exchanges opened amid bitter partisan debate and technical problems, the federal government released data late Tuesday showing that about 100 insurers were participating in the federally run marketplaces, offering more than 1,700 varieties of health insurance plans.

headline: Closer Look at Polls Finds Views of Health Law a Bit Less Negative
text: On opening day of the new federal and state health insurance exchanges, a deeper look at how Americans view the Affordable Care Act shows that public opinion is not as negative as has been reported.

headline: The Nacho Dorito
text: Michael Moss explains the psychology of what makes Nacho Cheese Doritos so alluring.

headline: YES Viewers Say Their Goodbyes
text: The Yankees’ 85-77 record prevented them from making the American League playoffs. A disappointment, yes, but grounds to shun them? No.

headline: Worried About Land Grabs, Group Presses 3 Corporations to Disclose Sugar Purchases
text: HONG KONG — Oxfam accused three big international food companies on Tuesday of buying sugar from what the advocacy group described as plantations that had unfairly taken land from farmers in Cambodia and Brazil without proper compensation.

headline: Restricted Group Speaks Up, Saying Sex Crime Measures Go Too Far
text: LOS ANGELES — Larry Neely looked out across the expanse of an airport hotel conference room that usually holds conventions of labor unions, political groups or business executives.

headline: Surviving Spouses With Reverse Mortgages Win Case
text: It’s a jarring situation: Your spouse dies, and you end up facing the possible loss of your home through foreclosure--just because you aren’t listed as a borrower on a reverse mortgage on your home.

headline: Dodgers Don’t View Injuries as Obstacle
text: LOS ANGELES — As the Dodgers were put through their final workout Tuesday morning before leaving for Atlanta, much of the attention was focused on who will not be in the lineup when their National League division series begins Thursday.

headline: Staunch Group of Republicans Outflanks House Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — They have had their fleeting moments on cable television. Their closed-door run-ins with Speaker John A. Boehner spill occasionally into the pages of Capitol Hill newspapers. But outside their districts, and sometimes even within them, few have heard of the conservative cadre of House Republicans who have led the charge to shut down the government.

headline: For Federal Workers, Anxiety and Anger
text: Federal workers across the country staged protests on Tuesday to express their anger and frustration over the shutdown.

headline: Hollywood Advancing Clinton Film
text: LOS ANGELES — Two television projects about Hillary Rodham Clinton collapsed under political pressure this week, but she may yet get her close-up on screen, this time from Hollywood.

headline: Texas Governor’s Trips to Lure Jobs Stir Skepticism Over Motive
text: HOUSTON — Rick Perry is not the first governor to try to lure jobs from other states. Others have done it for decades, often with discretion, sometimes with gimmicks, like the time Arnold Schwarzenegger drove a moving truck down the Las Vegas Strip in 2004 while trying to woo businesses to California.

headline: Rematch for Nassau Executive Could Be Bellwether of National Trend
text: A fair question to ask about the race for executive of Nassau County is: Why would anyone want the job?

headline: Ministering on Death Row, and Feeling a New Confidence in Rome
text: This week, trailing a group of men walking through a prison, Sister Helen Prejean overheard bits of what they were discussing. “I heard one saying, ‘He is so honest,’ but I didn’t catch who they were talking about at first,” said Sister Prejean, a member of the Congregation of St. Joseph, an order of Roman Catholic sisters.

headline: Groceries Are Cleaning Up in Store-Brand Aisles
text: Grocery store brands once carried a stigma. With no-frills white packaging that telegraphed bargain basement and low quality, they were a last resort for consumers on tight budgets.

headline: Jellyfish Invasion Paralyzes Swedish Reactor
text: In an episode that evokes B-grade sci-fi movie plots from the 1950s, but actually reflects a continuing global problem, nuclear engineers in southeastern Sweden have been wrestling with a giant swarm of jellyfish that forced the shutdown of the world’s largest boiling-water reactor.

headline: Well-Traveled Guard Offers the Knicks Direction
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When Beno Udrih made his N.B.A. debut with the San Antonio Spurs in 2004, it quickly became apparent to his teammates that he was a different type of player. It had nothing to do with his passing skills or his dependable jump shot. It had everything to do with how he thought about the game.

headline: Early Interest for Online Health Markets
text: On the day that health care exchanges went live, millions of Americans tried to go online to see how affordable their health care could be.

headline: Spain Is Expected to Extradite Ex-Trader in JPMorgan Case
text: Federal authorities expect that one of the former JPMorgan Chase employees facing criminal charges in connection with the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss in London will eventually be extradited to the United States, a senior prosecutor said on Tuesday.

headline: Losing Hope in Fukushima
text: More than two years after the nuclear meltdown in Fukushima Prefecture, thousands of refugees, desperate to return home, are losing confidence in the Japanese government’s cleanup efforts.

headline: Insider Trading Trial of Mavericks’ Owner Is Under Way
text: DALLAS — Mark Cuban is a “righteous man” whose stock trading practices are “inconsistent with someone who’s done something wrong.” Or he’s a brazen billionaire whose trading ran afoul of securities laws.

headline: It’s Not Citizens United
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — ON Tuesday the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments in McCutcheon v. Federal Election Commission, potentially the most significant federal campaign finance case since Citizens United in 2010.

headline: Tax Cuts in the Mayor’s Race
text: On Friday, without many people noticing, Joseph Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor of New York, slipped a little substance into the campaign.

headline: Netanyahu Pushes Back on Iran
text: During an aggressive speech at the United Nations on Tuesday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel used sarcasm and combative words to portray Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, as a smooth-talking charlatan, one who is determined to continue building a nuclear weapons arsenal.

headline: Our Democracy Is at Stake
text: This time is different. What is at stake in this government shutdown forced by a radical Tea Party minority is nothing less than the principle upon which our democracy is based: majority rule. President Obama must not give in to this hostage taking — not just because Obamacare is at stake, but because the future of how we govern ourselves is at stake.

headline: Dartmouth in the Glare of Scrutiny on Drinking
text: HANOVER, N.H. — It is a new school year, and there is a new president, Philip J. Hanlon, who no doubt would prefer to begin his tenure as the 18th president of Dartmouth College dealing with issues more lofty than binge drinking, sexual harassment and fraternity hazing.

headline: Scenes From the de Blasio-McCray Wedding
text: A selection of scenes from the wedding of Chirlane McCray and Bill de Blasio.

headline: Effort to Finance Veterans’ Programs Fails in the House
text: WASHINGTON — A bill to finance veterans’ programs failed in the House on Tuesday night. It was one of three measures from Republicans aimed at alleviating some of the effects of a government shutdown and forcing Democrats into negotiating.

headline: Near Fukushima, a Human Crisis Quietly Unfolds
text: The 83,000 refugees evacuated from the worst-hit areas around the nuclear power plant are still unable to go home, two and a half years after the disaster.

headline: Pope Assails Bureaucracy of Church as Insular
text: As Pope Francis convened a closed meeting on Tuesday with eight cardinals he appointed to overhaul the Vatican, he used his second revealing interview in two weeks to make a barbed indictment of the failings of the Roman Catholic Church, calling it overly clerical and insular, interested in temporal power and often led by “narcissists.”

headline: Once Alienated, and Now a Force in Her Husband’s Bid for Mayor
text: She was the seventh-grader too frightened to stand in front of the room because her white classmates would mock her, contorting their mouths to make their lips look big. She was the smoldering teenager who took to writing poems every day to wrestle with her isolation and anger. She was the eldest daughter of one of the only black families in Longmeadow, Mass., who arrived home to see their new house scrawled with racist graffiti.

text: Would government-owned banks distort the free market, or complement private lending?

headline: A Campaign Urges Listening to Those Torn by Mental Illness
text: ONLY 61 percent of Americans think it appropriate to tell family members about a mental illness diagnosis, according to a recent study commissioned by the New York City Metro chapter of the National Alliance on Mental Illness. Just 43 percent approve of telling friends about a diagnosis, and just 13 percent of telling co-workers.

headline: That’s Not Amore
text: WASHINGTON — John Boehner wakes up in his English basement apartment on Capitol Hill, his head still in a merlot fog.

headline: Japan’s Nuclear Refugees, Still Stuck in Limbo
text: NAMIE, Japan — Every month, Hiroko Watabe, 74, returns for a few hours to her abandoned house near the damaged Fukushima nuclear plant to engage in her own small act of defiance against fate. She dons a surgical mask, hangs two radiation-measuring devices around her neck and crouches down to pull weeds.

headline: Concern for Accused Army Sergeant’s ‘Emotional Health’
text: The former Army sergeant known as Rambo, who has been charged with conspiracy to kill a federal drug agent, looked as if he was on the verge of tears before a court hearing on Tuesday, his lawyer said after the proceeding ended.

headline: Woes Continue for Giants as Snee Considers Surgery
text: The Giants’ battered offensive line is not becoming any healthier, with the four-time Pro Bowl guard Chris Snee now considering season-ending hip surgery. Because two other starting linemen are injured as well, the Giants on Tuesday signed the former Philadelphia Eagles center Dallas Reynolds.

headline: Google Accused of Wiretapping in Gmail Scans
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Wiretapping is typically the stuff of spy dramas and shady criminal escapades. But now, one of the world’s biggest Web companies, Google, must defend itself against accusations that it is illegally wiretapping in the course of its everyday business — gathering data about Internet users and showing them related ads.

headline: Fixing Penn Station Without Rebuilding It
text: FOR commuters and travelers, New York City’s Pennsylvania Station is a disaster, as almost anyone who passes through it will tell you. The nation’s busiest transit hub is cramped, crowded, confusing and depressing. But now that the New York City Council has told Madison Square Garden that it has 10 years to vacate and find a new home, there is talk of rebuilding the rail station that lies beneath it.

headline: Growth Forecast Is Trimmed for Developing Nations in Asia
text: HONG KONG — The Asian Development Bank lowered its growth forecasts for emerging nations in the region on Wednesday and called for more structural changes to support the local economies.

headline: Shutdown Felt Far Beyond Washington
text: Tourists from Valley Forge to San Francisco were turned away from parks and monuments that were closed in the first government shutdown in nearly two decades.

headline: In a Divided Country, a Teacher Seeks Escape in the World of Movies
text: Breathe deep and smell the rot. The signs of decay are everywhere — and I mean everywhere — at the Blenheim School in Durban, South Africa, the setting for Jon Robin Baitz’s early play “The Film Society,” which opened in a welcome if slightly ponderous revival on Sunday night in a Keen Company production on Theater Row.

headline: Puzzles As Gifts
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to go ahead and guess that 27 Across was the seed entry for Paula Gamache’s fun, near-soundalike puzzle.

headline: Harold M. Agnew, Physicist Present at Birth of the Nuclear Age, Dies at 92
text: Harold M. Agnew, the last surviving major figure to have been present at the birth of the nuclear age — a physicist who helped build the world’s first reactor and atomic bombs, flew on the first atomic strike against Japan, filmed the mushroom cloud, helped perfect the hydrogen bomb and led the Los Alamos National Laboratory at the height of the cold war — died on Sunday at his home in Solana Beach, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Court Upholds a Settlement Affecting 20,000 City Renters
text: A federal appeals court has upheld a settlement affecting more than 20,000 rent-regulated tenants in New York City, clearing the way for them to seek individual compensation from their landlord for rent overcharges and other complaints.

headline: Michael Shvo
text: Mr. Shvo, 40, is the chief executive of Shvo, a luxury residential development company that he founded in New York in 2004 after several years as a top-grossing broker for Douglas Elliman Real Estate. Mr. Shvo’s first major development project, in partnership with Victor Homes, is a condominium at 239 10th Avenue in West Chelsea, the site of a former Getty gas station near the High Line. He is an avid art collector.

headline: Small Markets Find Ways to Compete
text: PITTSBURGH — From his crouch behind the plate at PNC Park on Tuesday, Russell Martin called for the first pitch of the baseball postseason. On Wednesday, some 130 miles away, the playoffs will continue at Progressive Field, with Nick Swisher taking part.

headline: To Venezuelans, Heir of Chávez Is a Poor Copy
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The start of the season for two premier teams in this baseball-loving nation was thrown into doubt after thieves stripped vast amounts of copper wire from the lights in this city’s main stadium. Basic items are often so hard to find that when a truck driver slumped dead at the wheel after a highway accident last week, motorcycle-riding looters swarmed in to grab the cargo: tons of red meat.

headline: 5 Members of a Family Die in a Colorado Rock Slide
text: DENVER — What started as a carefree family hike along a rustic mountain trail ended in tragedy on Monday, as two popular Colorado high school coaches, their daughter and two nephews were killed by a crush of falling boulders.

headline: Justices to Weigh Key Limit on Political Donors
text: McCALLA, Ala. — The Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision reshaped American politics by striking down limits on independent campaign spending by corporations and unions. But it did nothing to disturb the other main form of campaign finance regulation: caps on individuals’ direct contributions to candidates.

headline: City Councilwoman Is Chosen in the Democratic Runoff for Public Advocate
text: Letitia James, a New York City councilwoman from Brooklyn with strong ties to labor unions, won a Democratic primary runoff for public advocate on Tuesday, a victory that makes her all but certain to become the first African-American woman to hold citywide office.

headline: Northern Spy Lifts Cloak on Koreas’ Deadly Rivalry
text: SEOUL, South Korea — On Oct. 24, 1995, as a man now known as Kim Dong-sik hiked up a rain-slick mountain road in Buyeo, about 95 miles south of Seoul, he could not shake off a foreboding. He and another North Korean agent had sneaked into South Korea by boat 52 days earlier on a mission to bring home a Communist spy who had been working in the South for 15 years. The latest message from their superiors said the spy had been instructed to wait for Mr. Kim in a temple in Buyeo, disguised as a Buddhist monk named Jawoon.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Catsimatidis Spent $419 for Each Vote in Primary
text: John A. Catsimatidis spent $419 a vote in losing the Republican mayoral nomination last month, more than double what Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent per vote in his 2009 re-election race, according to figures released this week.

headline: Nets, Before Taking a Shot, Share a Kumbaya Moment at Training Camp
text: DURHAM, N.C. — The scene at the Nets’ team dinner late Monday night, hours after they arrived on the campus of Duke University to begin their weeklong training camp, resembled a support group or an intervention.

headline: Practicing Self-Defense When Motorcyclists Make a Drive Dangerous
text: An uneventful — by New York City standards, anyway — sunny Sunday in your family sport utility vehicle turns instantly into something out of “Mad Max” when a group of motorcyclists surrounds and overtakes the vehicle, forcing it to stop on a West Side highway.

headline: Wisconsin: Judge in Abuse Case Won’t Step Down
text: A federal judge has refused to recuse himself from a case in which he ruled in favor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee in bankruptcy proceedings, and against creditors, who include hundreds of sexual abuse victims. Judge Rudolph T. Randa denied the creditors’ motion suggesting that he had a conflict of interest because his family members are buried in archdiocesan cemeteries. Judge Randa had ruled in late July that the archdiocese did not have to turn over millions of dollars in its cemetery trust fund to the abuse victims and other creditors, because it would “substantially burden” the church’s free exercise of religion. In denying the recusal motion on Tuesday, Judge Randa wrote that the care and maintenance of his parents’ burial crypts will not be substantially affected by his decision.

headline: Arizona: Court Upholds School Funding Program
text: The state Court of Appeals on Tuesday unanimously upheld a lower court ruling affirming the constitutionality of a program that directs public money to private bank accounts to pay for private school tuition and educational services for some students. The Arizona School Boards Association and other groups sued to block the program, saying that it violated the state’s Constitution because it directed private funding to religious schools, among other arguments. The appeals court ruled that the program, designed by the Goldwater Institute, a conservative group, “expands the options to meet the individual needs of children.” Open to special-needs students at first, the program is available to one in five public school students in the state.

headline: Tesco Plans Venture With Leading Chinese Grocery Chain
text: LONDON — Nine years after it first tried to crack the Chinese market, Tesco, the British grocery store chain, said on Wednesday that it would abandon its solo approach and form a partnership with a state-run supermarket operator in hopes of a stronger expansion in the country.

headline: During Siege at Kenyan Mall, Government Forces Seemed Slow to Respond
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — When the first shots of automatic gunfire burst out, Raju, a member of a local gun club, was waiting in line in a bank at the Westgate shopping mall. He crouched down, pulled out his phone and feverishly pecked out a text message: “I am inside and I can confirm this is not a robbery.”

headline: A Perk for Furloughed Employees (ID Required)
text: WASHINGTON — It was only a matter of time before somebody tried to commercialize the government shutdown that is playing havoc with the lives — and pocketbooks — of federal workers.

headline: Airport in Florida Is Evacuated
text: Jacksonville International Airport in Florida reopened late Tuesday after it was evacuated for several hours because the authorities received reports of suspicious packages there.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Republicans Standing Their Ground
text: Conservative House Republicans have led the push to tie the dismantling of President Obama’s health care law to the passage of a budget resolution.

headline: Big Ten Network Makes Investment in College Hockey
text: ST. PAUL — Information about American college hockey was scarce in British Columbia when Curtis Gedig, a senior defenseman at Ohio State, grew up and played junior hockey there. Local news media did not cover it. Few college games were televised. Michigan State and Boston College might as well have been in a different solar system.

headline: Quotation of the day for Wednesday October 2, 2013
text: “I am patient. That’s how you get stuff done. You are patient.”
