headline: Petke Sobered by Club’s Checkered Past
text: The rookie coach Mike Petke has been with the Red Bulls/MetroStars through bad times, worse times and sheer debacles. That is why he is guardedly sanguine about his team’s current state.

headline: Are Our Political Beliefs Encoded in Our DNA?
text: In December 2008, The New York Times Magazine reported on the emerging science of “genopolitics.”

headline: Howard University President Is Retiring
text: Sidney A. Ribeau, president of Howard University since 2008, announced on Tuesday that he will retire at the end of the year. The university’s board of trustees appointed Wayne A. I. Frederick, who previously served as provost, as interim president and said it would conduct a national search for a new president.

headline: Israel Gutman, Who Survived and Documented Holocaust, Dies at 90
text: JERUSALEM — Israel Gutman, who took part in the Warsaw ghetto uprising, survived three Nazi concentration camps and became a prominent historian of the Holocaust, died on Tuesday at his home here. He was 90.

headline: Arnold Burns, Who Left Justice Dept. in Protest, Dies at 83
text: Arnold I. Burns, a top Justice Department official under President Ronald Reagan who resigned in protest of what he and others viewed as improper acts by Attorney General Edwin Meese III, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Claims That Google Violates Gmail User Privacy
text: A federal judge last week refused to dismiss most of a lawsuit against Google over accusations that it improperly scanned the contents of e-mails in order to target ads.

headline: Oscar de la Renta Comes to a Hotel Bathroom Near You
text: On Monday evening, minutes before stepping into the Peninsula New York’s lavish 25th anniversary party, Oscar de la Renta was seated comfortably in a sprawling suite 15 floors above the booming street performance that kicked off the night’s festivities, admiring the new amenity line he just created for the hotel group. The collection consists of shampoo, conditioner, body and shower gel, body lotion, and soap, all laced with his newest scent, a unisex blend of citrusy mandarin with warm bergamot and bright jasmine. When asked how long it took to create this particular smell, the designer, who has been making fragrances since 1977, said cheekily, “a lifetime and a few years.”

headline: Blackout for Reds, as Pirates Move On
text: PITTSBURGH — It was everything the Pittsburgh Pirates could have dreamed, and the best part, for them, is that now there is more to come. The Pirates, after two decades of losing seasons, have stormed into the National League division series.

headline: District of Columbia Says It Can Meet Payroll for Two Weeks
text: A bill to continue the financing of Washington’s city government went down to defeat in the House on Tuesday night, but the District of Columbia Council vowed to continue operating despite the financial obstacles.

headline: How Intense Study May Harm Our Workouts
text: Tire your brain and your body may follow, a remarkable new study of mental fatigue finds. Strenuous mental exertion may lessen endurance and lead to shortened workouts, even if, in strict physiological terms, your body still has plenty of energy reserves.

headline: The Tax Equation in the Health Care Law
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Shutdown Could Worsen Budget Deficit, Analysis Says
text: At first blush, it might seem that a government shutdown would have a positive effect on the budget deficit, reducing its growth by constraining spending. But not so fast.

headline: Home Sales Rose in Tighter Manhattan Market, Report Says
text: As Manhattan’s residential sales inventory continued to plunge in the past three months, dropping to its lowest level in 13 years, sales took off in the opposite direction, with buyers determined to make their move before mortgage rates and home prices commence the inevitable tandem escalation experts have predicted.

headline: How to Improve a Statue That’s Been Made to Dazzle? Tone It Down
text: No one has ever accused New York City of understatement.

headline: BlackBerry Filing Describes a Global Slide
text: OTTAWA — In a delayed regulatory filing issued on Tuesday evening, the smartphone maker BlackBerry revealed that customers are turning against its products in what had been its one remaining bright spot, the developing world.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 2 P.M. (HBO) IN GOOD COMPANY (2004) A 51-year-old advertising executive (Dennis Quaid) finds his life turned upside down when a young shark (Topher Grace, above right, with Mr. Quaid) arrives on the scene to take over his department and his office — and sleep with his daughter (Scarlett Johansson). This “engagingly lightweight drama,” written and directed by Paul Weitz, “is a gently revisionist fairy tale about good versus evil set on the battlefield of contemporary corporate culture, a site of our leading blood sport,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mostly, though, the movie is about men. Men without fathers, men without sons, men with wives who work and make them feel like less than a man and men with wives who, like Dan’s wife, Ann (Marg Helgenberger), give them the gift of both an exquisitely preserved figure and a fertile womb.” She added, “I don’t believe for a single second how Mr. Weitz ends his fairy tale, but I mean it as a compliment to say that I wish I did.”

headline: News Quiz | October 2, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: U.S. and South Korea Set Defense Strategy for North Korean Threat
text: SEOUL — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said Wednesday that the United States had devised a strategy with South Korea to deter the growing threat of North Korea’s nuclear and chemical weapons programs.

headline: Reports Say Obama Scraps Malaysia Trip Because of Crisis
text: Malaysian news media reported Wednesday that President Obama had decided to cancel his trip to that country next week because of the fiscal crisis back in the United States, quoting the nation’s leader as saying Secretary of State John Kerry would be representing the president.

headline: Former Japanese Leader Declares Opposition to Nuclear Power
text: TOKYO — Japan’s flagging antinuclear movement received an unexpected new recruit this week when one of the nation’s most popular figures, former Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, made a very public about-face from his previous embrace of atomic power.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Government Shutdown Begins as Health Insurance Exchanges Open
text: In “House G.O.P. Stands Firm on Shutdown, but Dissent Grows,” Jeremy W. Peters writes about the politics of the first day of the government shutdown.

headline: The Type Who Takes Her Time
text: Melissa Cacciola speaks slowly, deliberating over each word, sometimes going back to tweak a phrase or clarify a thought. It’s like her photographic medium — the tintype — which produces a single, unique image in the time you could shoot hundreds with a digital camera.

headline: Should Colleges Use Admissions Criteria Other Than SAT Scores and Grades?
text: Bard College, a prestigious liberal arts college in upstate New York, will offer students admission if they can write four 2,500-word research papers that earn a B+ or better by the college’s standards. That means no need to worry about low grades or SAT scores.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe’s Next Trick Is to Make Harry Potter Disappear
text: Before Daniel Radcliffe became the most famous child actor in history, he was just a child: an only child, a poor sleeper, a nonstop talker, a picky eater. He was also disarmingly sweet. In the screen test he took at age 10, in 2000, for the first Harry Potter film, “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone,” he smiles brightly, ebullient, his delight in being there apparent; he is concentrating, concentrating so hard at one point that he mouths words under his breath while waiting to deliver a line, but even still, when he does finally speak, he is all natural sincerity. His face is a flawless little-boy face, his eyes huge and cerulean blue. One eye occasionally blinks more slowly than the other, but no matter. He turns, compliantly, this way and that when asked. About four minutes into the footage, someone places the iconic round glasses on him, and there he is: Harry Potter, boy wizard, the chosen one. The adult voice on the video says: “Those look good.”

headline: New York Today: A Day at the Races
text: With the Democratic runoff on Tuesday, New York City woke today to a presumed new public advocate, Letitia James.

headline: Ah, There’s Nothing Like New Baby Smell
text: Nature provides plenty of reasons for parents to adore their newborns. The giant eyes, the adorable coos, the flawless skin.

headline: SAP Ventures Raises $650 Million Fund
text: Seventeen years ago, SAP created a venture arm with the aim of gaining a toehold in promising new start-ups. Now that business is aiming to continue branching out from its parent company.

headline: Obama Cancels Trip to Philippines and Malaysia
text: The White House announced on Wednesday that President Obama had canceled his trip next week to the Philippines and Malaysia because of the budget standoff in Washington. Secretary of State John Kerry will lead delegations to both countries, instead of Mr. Obama.

headline: Citizen Journalism Grows in India’s War-Torn Tribal Belt
text: On an August afternoon, Mastram Ghosh, a lanky young man from Tikamgarh in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, stood on Jantar Mantar Street near the Indian parliament in central Delhi. A huge crowd protesting an Indian government move to amend the country’s revolutionary Right to Information Act (R.T.I.) filled the street. Mr. Ghosh was reporting on the protests, shouting his dispatch on the phone to Central Gondwana Net Swara (CGNet Swara), a phone-based, rural community news provider in the tribal areas of central India.

headline: Obama Sets Conditions for Talks: Pass Funding and Raise Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — In their first meeting since a budget impasse shuttered many federal operations, President Obama told Republican leaders on Wednesday that he would negotiate with them only after they agreed to the funding needed to reopen the government and also to an essential increase in the nation’s debt limit, without add-ons.

headline: Marc Jacobs to Leave Louis Vuitton
text: PARIS — The fashion designer Marc Jacobs is leaving Louis Vuitton after 16 years to concentrate on his namesake line, according to Bernard Arnault, the chairman and chief executive of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, which has a majority stake in Mr. Jacobs’s company.

headline: Never Mind. I’ll Find Someone Else.
text: I’m not sure exactly what tipped me over the edge. Maybe it was the traffic on the way into work. Maybe it was the hour I wasted trying to get my printer to complete a scan over the wireless network. Or maybe it was just residual anger after receiving some shabby treatment from a colleague, a sales person and a job applicant — all of which led me to write a few honest e-mails to these malefactors. My first honesty-gram was directed at someone who owns a used furniture outfit nearby. He had asked me whether I could take a look at a damaged table that he had acquired and possibly repair and refinish it. Which led to the following exchange:

headline: Daily Report: Lawsuit Accuses Google of Wiretapping in Gmail Scans
text: Wiretapping is typically the stuff of spy dramas and shady criminal escapades. But now one of the world’s biggest Web companies, Google, must defend itself against accusations that it is illegally wiretapping in the course of its everyday business – gathering data about Internet users and showing them related ads, Claire Cain Miller reports.

headline: Russia Accuses Greenpeace Activists of Piracy
text: MOSCOW — Defying complaints from international human rights and environmental organizations, as well as the apparent wishes of President Vladimir V. Putin, Russian prosecutors brought piracy charges on Wednesday against 13 Greenpeace activists and a journalist who covered their protest.

headline: Live Stream | Miu Miu Spring 2014 Collection at Paris Fashion Week
text: A live stream of the latest women’s collection from Miu Miu at Paris fashion week, scheduled to go live at 2 p.m. local time, 8 a.m. Eastern Standard Time.

headline: With Inflation Low, the European Central Bank Holds Rates Steady
text: PARIS — The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low on Wednesday, but indicated it was ready to take steps if needed to protect the euro zone from political turmoil in the United States.

headline: Doctoroffs to Give University of Chicago Law School $5 Million
text: The University of Chicago Law School is expected to announce on Wednesday a $5 million gift to create a business leadership program.

headline: Advice About  Sleep Deficiency in Midlife, Part 2
text: Orfeu Marcello Buxton, a neuroscientist, has been answering reader questions about sleep deficiency. More than 200 people sent questions (most can be read here).  Part 1 of his answers is here. [Update: Part 3 can be found here.] Because of the volume of questions, not all may be answered.

headline: Shutdown Savings and the Debt Ceiling

headline: Wells Fargo Braces for Suit on Foreclosures
text: New York’s attorney general is preparing a lawsuit against the nation’s largest home lender, Wells Fargo, accusing the bank of flouting the terms of a multibillion-dollar settlement aimed at stopping foreclosure abuses, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. The lawsuit, which claims Wells Fargo violated the guidelines of last year’s agreement between five big banks and 49 state attorneys general, is expected to be filed as early as Wednesday.

headline: Do These Pants Make My Rear End Look Flat?
text: Some of you may accuse me of navel-gazing with my latest problem, but as you will shortly see that is an anatomical impossibility: my behind has flattened out.

headline: Back in Asia, Hagel Pursues Shift to Counter China’s Goals in Pacific
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In the four years since he announced a shift in American foreign policy and defense strategy to counter China’s ambitions in Asia, President Obama has found himself perpetually sidelined from his goals by a series of escalating conflicts in the Middle East and budget crises at home. A long-planned trip to the area has been cut back because of the government shutdown that began Tuesday.

headline: Mark Hurd, Oracle’s Master Salesman, Wants Your Business
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Hurd, co-president of the Oracle Corporation, has a big Starbucks coffee in a cold room in the Moscone Center. That’s how he likes a room, cold. He’s focused that way.

headline: New York’s Biggest Costume Party
text: Comic-book fans nearly cracked the Internet in half with reactions to the news that Ben Affleck would play the masked crusader in a forthcoming Superman/Batman film. Many of the impassioned, no matter their favorite Dark Knight (West, Keaton, Kilmer, Clooney or Bale), can be found at New York Comic Con. The four-day festival, which runs Oct. 10-13 in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, celebrates the dedicated writers and artists, passionate fans and, yes, the commerce of comics. The showroom gets densely packed and the lines for events extremely long, but the vibe remains upbeat and nerdily earnest, with double-takes from passers-by as Supermen, Captain Americas and Doctor Whos roam the nearby streets.

headline: Image of the Day: October 2
text: A function in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, to mark the 144th anniversary of the birth of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Elements | Character

headline: Who Will Heal the Doctors?
text: In my previous column, I reported on the problem of widespread burnout among doctors and medical students — and I described a response that, in recent years, has spread to half the nation’s medical schools: a course called The Healer’s Art, created by a physician, Rachel Naomi Remen, to help doctors and students discover and reconnect to the deep meaning of their work and maintain their commitment for it. The article touched a sore spot. Hundreds of readers — patients, medical students, doctors and spouses and children of doctors among them — contributed comments describing their personal experiences, many of them raw with emotion. Some of the most poignant notes came from doctors themselves, and their words revealed a deep sense of betrayal.

headline: In Test Project, N.S.A. Tracked Cellphone Locations
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency conducted a secret pilot project in 2010 and 2011 to test the collection of bulk data about the location of Americans’ cellphones, but the agency never moved ahead with such a program, according to intelligence officials.

headline: Case Against Greek Far-Right Party Draws Critics
text: NIKAIA, Greece — For over a year, 30 Kaisareias Street bustled with activity. Burly, black-clad members of the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party converted part of the nondescript white building into a headquarters, holding frequent meetings and fanning out for military-style neighborhood patrols armed with batons and heavy poles wrapped in the Greek flag.

headline: Disappointment and Disarray in Venezuela
text: With food shortages mounting and inflation running high, some of the most ardent supporters of former president Hugo Chávez are voicing their discontent with his successor, Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Tom Clancy, Best-Selling Master of Military Thrillers, Dies at 66

headline: Buy Low, Sell High
text: My It’s the Economy column for the next issue of The New York Times Magazine looks at one venue through which the financial crisis helped the rich get richer and simultaneously wounded the middle class: real estate.

headline: Iceland’s Romance With Electric Cars on Display at a Wedding
text: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Newlyweds may choose to depart the marriage ceremony in a horse-drawn carriage, a limousine or a classic car, but none of those seemed quite right to Tomas Kristjansson and his new wife, Berglind Anna Zoega, electric-car enthusiasts who exchanged vows at Reykjavik’s postcard-worthy Hallgrimskirkja Church on Sept. 7.

headline: Sea Change
text: “Something Big,” written by the Swiss author Sylvie Neeman and illustrated by Ingrid Godon, is an unusual book, both in look and content. Godon, a Belgian illustrator, uses oil pastels, mostly loden green, persimmon red and a pale teal, to sketch simple figures on a white background. Where a broader expanse of color is called for, she rubs the oils across the page. The effect is almost like something drawn by a child, but on a second look, far from artless.

headline: Today in Small Business: When Your Biggest Client Disappears
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

text: Seth Green and Giovanni Ribisi play men whose fathers move in with them in this new Fox sitcom.

headline: What You Get For ... $1,000,000
text: SOLANA BEACH, CALIF.

headline: The Gun Report: October 2, 2013

headline: House to Vote on Bills to Finance Parts of Government
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday will vote on bills to reopen national parks and museums, restart veterans’ programs, fund medical research, pay the National Guard and Reserves, and finance services in the District of Columbia.

headline: The Landscape of Small-Business Health Insurance
text: Five years ago, a start-up called Liazon began offering businesses a new way to provide health insurance to employees. On Liazon’s Bright Choices, an online marketplace, a company can specify how much money it wants to spend on each employee’s benefits, and employees can use that contribution to buy the plan of their choice.

headline: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 1
text: In the first episode of a four-part series, "Mud" traces the roots of the residential highrise, from the biblical Tower of Babel to New York's tenement buildings.

headline: Re/Max Rises in Debut, While Empire State Trust Is Subdued
text: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | Stock market investors are showing an appetite for real estate – and discount coats.

headline: Furloughed Employees Hold Shutdown Parties
text: On Tuesday evening, approximately 15 furloughed government employees gathered in the Port Tobacco, Md., home of Ashley Brincefield, a 29-year-old federal employee who works for Customs and Border Protection, for what Ms. Brincefield called a “survive the government shutdown party.”

headline: Lew Renews Warning to Lawmakers About Default
text: WASHINGTON – With Congress engaged in an all-consuming fight over financing the government, Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has implored legislators not to forget about the country’s debt ceiling, which needs to be raised in a matter of weeks to avoid what might be a financial market calamity.

headline: Carnegie Hall Opening Gala Canceled Because of Stagehand Strike
text: They are among the highest-paid performers at Carnegie Hall, even though they do not play a note: they are the stagehands of Local 1, whose average total compensation of more than $400,000 a year is more than some of the hall’s top executives earn. Little happens on Carnegie’s stages without them.

headline: Man Charged With False Report After Airport Closing
text: The Jacksonville International Airport in Florida was closed for several hours Tuesday evening after a man told an airport official he had a bomb in his bag. On Wednesday the man was charged with making a false report about planting a bomb, the authorities said.

headline: Obama to Meet With Congressional Leaders at White House
text: WASHINGTON — On Wednesday, the second day of the government shutdown, President Obama summoned the Republican and Democratic leaders of Congress to the White House for an afternoon meeting to urge the passage of measures financing the government and increasing the nation’s borrowing limit — without extraneous add-ons like limiting his health care law.

headline: Loeb Raises Stake in Sotheby’s and Seeks Board Seat
text: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb said on Wednesday that he wanted to join the board of the auction house Sotheby’s and called for the chief executive to step down.

headline: A Child Shocked by the Shutdown, and a Parent Who Would Like to Be
text: The federal government has blown my 12-year-old’s mind.

headline: Why Labeling Health Plans Gold, Silver or Bronze Doesn’t Help
text: This week marks the somewhat limited debut of the health insurance exchanges established by the Affordable Care Act to help small businesses buy insurance for their employees. The Small Business Health Options exchanges, as they are known, went live on Tuesday, and businesses that go browsing – they won’t be able to buy online until November — are discovering a new concept for comparing the offerings: metal levels.

headline: Some Head Start Programs Close, and Others May Soon
text: The National Head Start Association estimates that nearly 19,000 children from low-income families have lost or are at risk of losing services in 11 states because of the government shutdown, according to its analysis  of the impact of the shutdown.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: ‘More Patriotic Than Scrupulous’
text: Today, many Civil War battlefields resemble sculpture gardens. Where soldiers once fought and died, monuments commemorate their battle-tested regiments. But what about those regiments that failed the test? No elaborate memorials celebrate the deeds of the 11th New York Heavy Artillery–and the reason is clear. In the summer and fall of 1863, the promising new unit fell apart, largely thanks to the ambitions of its officers.

headline: The Nomads’ No Man’s Land
text: FREE ZONE, Western Sahara — Some parts of the Sahara are more of a no man’s land than others. The most extreme example is the so-called Free Zone, a strip in the Western Sahara, with territory occupied by Morocco to the west and Algeria to the east. Strewn with mines and inhabited by just a smattering of nomads, the area is controlled by the Polisario Front, a state in exile that has been based in refugee camps in southwestern Algeria since 1976, when Morocco annexed Western Sahara after Spain’s colonial forces withdrew.

headline: James Whiteside Promoted to Principal Dancer at American Ballet Theater
text: James Whiteside — who created a stir dancing the roles of Romeo in “Romeo and Juliet,” Prince Siegfried in “Swan Lake” and Prince Désiré in “The Sleeping Beauty” since joining American Ballet Theater as a soloist last fall — is being promoted to principal dancer with the company, its artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, announced on Wednesday. Mr. Whiteside, who danced previously with Boston Ballet, was praised this year in The New York Times by the newspaper’s chief dance critic, Alastair Macaulay, who asked, “What newcomer to New York has ever invaded a repertory more surely than James Whiteside?” The promotion will take effect on Oct. 30 — the night he is scheduled to dance the male lead of George Balanchine’s “Theme and Variations” at a gala to kick off the company’s fall season at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

headline: Readers Ask About Subsidies and Other Health Care Law Provisions
text: The Times is answering readers’ questions about the new health care exchanges in the Your Money column. The latest one covered many of the basics. You can find earlier installments on In Practice.If you’re still not sure how the law affects you and your family, please e-mail your questions to tsbernard@nytimes.com.

headline: Second Banksy Work Appears in New York After First Is Painted Over

headline: Tom Clancy Dies at 66

text: WASHINGTON  — Representative Mick Mulvaney, Republican of South Carolina and one of the House’s most ardent conservatives, released a statement to his constituents this morning. Cutting through the Washington clutter, we offer an annotated version:

headline: Like This Jacket, Honey?
text: LOVE MEANS NEVER having to get dressed alone. It means an eye you trust. It means the acceptance of a worldview and aesthetic other than your own. It means moving through life with the confidence that at least one other person cares as much about how you look as you do.

text: Nearly everything about Silk Road was shrouded in secrecy.

headline: Missed Opportunity in Syria Haunts U.N. Official
text: UNITED NATIONS — Locked in a disagreement with the Syrian government over access, the United Nations missed an opportunity six months ago to investigate the first suspected chemical weapons attack in that country’s civil war, the organization’s top disarmament official said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: The Icing on the Cake
text: My mother lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., so packing for a summer 90th birthday visit was easy: Loose linen clothes, a sheet of baking parchment, and a three-ounce bar of Scharffen Berger bittersweet chocolate because my sister wasn’t sure she’d bought enough.

headline: Updates Work, Except When They Don’t
text: Your responses to the question of whether Shakespeare is best appreciated in productions that dress up the original plays in modern settings, or hew more closely to “classical” tradition, contained almost as many viewpoints as you’d get if you gathered a hundred theater directors in a room and started them arguing.

headline: A Hotel Rewards Program for College Towns
text: Many families of college students will be heading to college towns across the country for visits during homecoming and parents’ weekends (not to mention four years of pickups and drop-offs), but choosing a hotel often involves a trade-off.

headline: In Vienna, New Energy Amid Old-World Charm
text: In Vienna’s bohemian Seventh District, craftspeople, artists and shopkeepers are breathing new life into a handful of old cobblestone streets known as Spittelberg. Steps from the MuseumsQuartier, the city’s museum district, the neighborhood overflows with Old World charm and hidden garden restaurants. It wasn’t always picturesque. Named after a hospital built here in the 1500s, the hill filled in over the centuries with low-rent housing, taverns and brothels. By the 1970s, the red light district was headed for demolition, but locals insisted on preservation instead. Restored Biedermeier buildings on pedestrian lanes now house galleries, boutiques, bars and restaurants. With summer tourists gone, Viennese enjoy strolling and dining outside on pleasant autumn evenings.

headline: Finding Inspiration Through Exploration
text: “He was a rebel — no question about that,” Sven-Olof Lindblad, founder of Lindblad Expeditions, said of his father, Lars-Eric.

text: The NBC series stars Mr. Fox as a news anchor with Parkinson's disease returning from a medical hiatus.

headline: For Sale: Brownstone Tied to the Revival of Brooklyn
text: The beginning of the end for the brownstone at 272 Berkeley Place in Park Slope — as far as the legions of admirers it welcomed for decades are concerned — came in 2006, when Evelyn Ortner, its co-owner and chief preserver, died of breast cancer. The house’s other owner, her husband, Everett, died last year. And two weeks ago, after being denuded of many of the Ortners’ books, knickknacks and papers from five decades of Brooklyn boosterism, their house was put up for sale.

headline: White House Enlists Business Leaders to Pressure Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration mounted a full-court press on Wednesday to enlist the nation’s business leaders to pressure Congressional Republicans to agree to finance the government and increase the nation’s borrowing limit without demanding other measures in exchange.

headline: Get Back, and Just Let Miley Cyrus Grow Up
text: Enough already. Enough with the nose-in-the-air repudiations and the false moral panics. Enough of the finger pointing and the slut shaming. Enough with the using of Miley Cyrus as a punching bag.

headline: As Demand Stays High, Officials Try to Address Problems in Exchanges
text: Federal and state officials moved Wednesday to strengthen the computer underpinnings of the new online health exchanges, which proved inadequate to handle a flood of consumer inquiries that began as soon as the system opened on Tuesday and continued into the next day.

headline: 1890: Commuter Rage
text: On Feb. 16, 1890, The New York Herald reported on the accident-ridden journey of a certain Mrs. Lanarkshire and her daughter, who:

text: The cookies were laid out on paper plates, a 70-year-old print of “The Chimp” was threaded into the aging film projector, and the Sons of the Desert were filing into the Players Club on Gramercy Park South on a recent weeknight.

headline: Technology Firm From India Will Be New York Marathon Title Sponsor
text: The New York City Marathon sponsor ING will end its decade-long relationship with the race and be replaced by Tata Consultancy Services, the Indian technology giant, race organizers said Wednesday.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Getting a Party Started With D.J. Apps
text: At my university, a friend decided to learn to be a disc jockey, for fun. She was talented, learned fast and became one of my university’s most popular D.J.’s. If I had tried to learn that skill, it would have taken me a long time, I know. But the world has advanced and your smartphone and tablet can manage a lot of the tasks of mixing music for you — whether you’re a real D.J. or just a musical amateur keen to liven up a party.

headline: Health Care Panic, Again
text: Eduardo Porter is getting a lot of attention for his piece in today’s paper suggesting that what Republicans fear most is that Obamacare might succeed. He deserves it: it’s a very good piece. But I guess I’m surprised that so many people seem to find this a surprising and new insight. I thought it was obvious. Here’s a column I wrote back in July predicting more or less what is now happening, for exactly the reason Porter gives: GOP panic over the prospect of successful health reform.

headline: ‘Like a Tom Clancy Novel’
text: Tom Clancy, who died on Tuesday, was so popular — 17 of his novels were No. 1 New York Times best sellers—that his name meant something even to people who had never read a word of his work, a rare achievement for a contemporary writer. His name was a byword signifying spies, military equipment and covert plots against the American government.

headline: In San Francisco, 3 Days of Shopping for $106
text: San Francisco is not, generally speaking, known for its egg coddlers.

headline: Reid Says He’ll Negotiate Once House Drops Demands
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, called House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio on Wednesday to commit to negotiations on a long-term deficit reduction deal, but only after the House passes the Senate’s bill to reopen the federal government without policy strings attached.

headline: Criminal Complaint and Protective Order Related to the Silk Road
text: Read the criminal complaint and other court documents related to the F.B.I. seizure of Silk Road, an online drug market.

headline: CEOs All At Sea
text: Lydia DePillis continues her informative series of blog posts on the political haplessness of big business, which with all its money and connections finds itself not only unable to stop the slide into chaos but unable even to exert any appreciable influence. But I still don’t think the businesspeople understand their problem.

headline: A Poet Reckons With Her Inheritance
text: In her recently published collection of poems, “The Forage House” (Red Hen Press), Tess Taylor, a descendant of the white branch of Thomas Jefferson’s family, explores her personal history, sifting through not just records but the very dirt of her ancestors’ property and the bones buried there. She saw “unearthed remains of slave cabins — cracked pipes, a few buttons” and witnessed how archaeologists use these bits to recreate the past. In a recent e-mail interview she talked about her ancestors, including Appalachian forebears “who kept Scottish ballads alive for centuries” in remote parts of North Carolina, about slavery and about the role of poetry.

headline: Shrimp Is Having Its 15 Minutes
text: A dozen fast ways to cook the new king of seafood.

text: Alfonso Cuarón narrates a scene from his film, featuring Sandra Bullock and George Clooney.

text: The unlikely trajectory of the Modernist furniture designed for Le Corbusier’s utopian Indian city of Chandigarh.

headline: Three Greek Golden Dawn MPs Freed
text: The Golden Dawn lawmakers stormed past journalists — one a hitting a video camera and another shouting at them — after their unexpected release on pending criminal charges.

headline: In Face of Shutdown, Foreign Aid Continues
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government may have ground to a halt because of the budget standoff in Washington, but at least one part of the government continues to operate as usual: foreign aid agencies.

headline: Another ‘Angola 3’ Prisoner, With Cancer, Is Released
text: Human rights groups, supporters and legal teams who have worked for the rights of the so-called Angola 3 prisoners over the years welcomed on Wednesday the release of one of the men, Herman Wallace, who has advanced liver cancer. He had served decades in solitary confinement in Louisiana prisons.

headline: Races End Fees to Top Runners, Drawing Outcry
text: The sport of road running, from small-town 10-kilometer races to big-city marathons, has long supported its top athletes with appearance fees. Come run our race, and you will be paid something regardless of your performance — that’s the model. The fees are a crucial source of revenue for those swift runners who have gotten a massage and are napping by the time the main pack approaches the finish line.

headline: Fallout for G.O.P. Candidate Where Shutdown Pain Is Acute
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — With 170,000 federal employees in Virginia and 30 percent of the economy of Northern Virginia dependent on government spending, no state has more to lose from a government shutdown than this one.

headline: Acclaimed New Conor McPherson Work Coming to New York
text: A critically acclaimed London production of “The Night Alive,” a new play by Tony Award nominee Conor McPherson (“The Seafarer,” “Shining City”) will transfer to Atlantic Theater Company this fall with the British cast intact, the Off Broadway theater announced on Wednesday.

headline: Why Big Ag Likes Big Data
text: Big Data’s push to remake the industrial economy took a big step forward Wednesday, when Monsanto announced it had bought the Climate Corporation.

headline: Drake Tops the Album Chart
text: The biggest winners on the Billboard charts this week are all one-namers: Drake, Cher, Lorde and Badfinger.

headline: Nature in Focus: Using Short Videos to Teach Science
text: Science teachers frequently scour the Web for short videos, knowing they can be powerful tools for demonstrating hard-to-explain concepts and piquing students’ interest in their subject.

headline: 3 London Portfolio Managers Leave SAC Capital
text: Updated, 8:24 p.m. | Three portfolio managers with an SAC Capital Advisors unit in London have left the firm, according to documents filed with a British agency that tracks corporate registrations.

headline: A Park Slope Mom Raises a Hunter
text: When I was growing up, my grandfather kept a rifle cabinet, and his bird dogs had the run of the house. There were hunting motifs on the pillows and cocktail glasses, and duck calls on the mantel. It would have come as no surprise to him (or probably anyone of his generation) that my 14-year-old son Booker’s proudest possession is his newly acquired hunting license, and that he fully intends to take down a deer this fall.

headline: Greenhill Expands Into Brazil Despite Nation’s Woes
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company has opened an office in Brazil and hired the former Goldman Sachs executive Daniel Wainstein to run it, a move that comes as several Wall Street players have been retrenching amid Brazil’s economic woes.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Gravity’
text: When making his science fiction thriller about an astronaut stranded in space, the director Alfonso Cuarón was met with several challenges. One was how to shoot a feature that takes place in an environment where everything is in constant motion. In this video, Mr. Cuarón narrates an early sequence from “Gravity” with Sandra Bullock and George Clooney, and discusses some of his ideas behind the structure and layout of the scene.

headline: Statins May Reduce Gum Disease Risk
text: Statins may have a beneficial side effect: reducing gum inflammation, or periodontitis.

text: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders seem to have found a new strategy on the government shutdown: If it grabs a headline, open it.

text: The endgame for the rue21 buyout is all about Apax Partners vs. Apax Partners, with one of them losing.

headline: A’s Follow Crisp’s Lead Back Into the Playoffs
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Sitting with his father in the upper reaches of the decrepit Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena and watching the dreadful Clippers play, Coco Crisp learned growing up what it meant to develop a bond with a team. The building might have been crumbling, the crowd was often sparse and the expectations low, but if the Clippers were not the Lakers, then they were at least his team.

text: A look at some memorable runway shows by Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton.

headline: Marc Jacobs Packing His Louis Vuitton Bags After 16 Years
text: PARIS — Marc Jacobs, one of the greatest American talents to conquer the perilous stage of French fashion with a 16-year career as the designer of Louis Vuitton, during which he produced megahit accessories and elaborate runway spectacles, is leaving the company to focus on his signature business in New York.

headline: Risk-Averse Gandhi’s Move Rattles Indian Election
text: NEW DELHI — As India’s ruling dynasty hurtles toward an important and unpredictable election season, many of its pressing questions have converged into one: Can its heir apparent, Rahul Gandhi, project the message of political change that this country seems to crave?

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Museum Gets $5 Million for Renovation
text: While the Smithsonian Institution’s other museums were shutting down on Tuesday, the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York was celebrating a new $5 million allocation from the city that would be put toward its $79 million renovation. This latest allocation comes on top of another $9.3 million that the city has already contributed.

headline: Depression Tied to Parkinson’s Risk
text: Depression may be an independent risk factor for Parkinson’s disease, a new study has found.
