headline: At Paris Fashion Week Parties, Air-Kissing Wanes for Now
text: PARIS — Elisabeth von Thurn und Taxis, the globe-trotting princess who is a columnist for Vogue, arrived at her own dinner party at the Hôtel Prince de Galles on Tuesday night on the back of a motorcycle. To beat the traffic, Parisians gad about on motorbikes these days, ever since Uber introduced the bike option here last year.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe: Prankster, Trivia Nerd, Laundry-Sorter
text: There’s a lot about Daniel Radcliffe that didn’t show up in his portrayal of Harry Potter all those years: the consummately British school boy turns out to be a huge fan of American football, he is frequently profane (although apologetic about it) and he has an unexpectedly deep sense of humor that is both dark and quick-witted.

headline: Chinese Activist Joins Conservative Research Group
text: BEIJING — Chen Guangcheng, the blind legal activist whose headline-grabbing odyssey included an improbable escape from house arrest in China, a mad dash for refuge inside the United States Embassy in Beijing and several rocky months as a visiting scholar at New York University, has found a new job with a conservative research institute in New Jersey.

headline: Changes Slowly Coming to FIFA as Problems Put It on the Defensive
text: ZURICH — The decision by FIFA’s executive committee three years ago to award the 2022 World Cup to the tiny, gas-rich emirate of Qatar was to many outsiders the perfect example of the secretive and insular way major decisions are made at the top levels of world soccer’s governing body.

headline: When the Government Shuts, Even Web Sites Go Down
text: When the federal government last shutdown in 1995, most agencies and departments had either no presence on the Internet or a very basic Web site. Since then, agency Web sites have become the primary public face of the government for most Americans who do not live in or near Washington. So it’s perhaps not surprising that the decision by agencies such as NASA and the Library of Congress to take down their sites this week has gotten a lot of attention.

headline: For Haim, Rinse, Repeat and Rock ’n’ Roll
text: The first thing you spot when the band Haim comes on stage is their hair. It falls over their shoulders in long pleats, parted at the center, layered just enough to move with them as they begin to dance.

headline: Praying to the Moon, While Lashing Out at Fate
text: As the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky sang “Casta Diva” at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening, she drew listeners in with her expressive shadings and heartfelt delivery. She earned a thunderous ovation after the cavatina, in which the druid priestess Norma prays to the moon goddess for peace.

headline: Finding Talking Points Among the Underdogs
text: The world becomes less complicated with a Malcolm Gladwell book in hand. Mr. Gladwell raises questions — should David have won his fight with Goliath? — that are reassuringly clear even before they are answered. His answers are just tricky enough to suggest that the reader has learned something, regardless of whether that’s true. A recent posting on Goodreads, a Web site that bolsters enthusiasm for books and reveals no-baloney reasons readers like them, lauds the power of Mr. Gladwell’s entertaining insights into the not quite obvious. “Do you really want to be surprised all the time?” a commenter identified as Dr. A. Taubman asked this week about Mr. Gladwell’s latest, “David and Goliath.” “The world is disconcerting enough already.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Myanmar, Italy and Ukraine.

headline: New Hunt for Head of Energy Regulator After Candidate Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is once again looking for someone to head the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, following the decision by Ronald J. Binz to withdraw his name from consideration.

headline: Yvonne Strahovski’s Beauty Regimen
text: Known for her roles on “Dexter” and “Chuck,” Yvonne Strahovski, 31, plays a scientist in the film “I, Frankenstein,” opening next year. Raised in Sydney, Australia, she lives in Los Angeles and maintains her blond good looks with a beauty routine that emphasizes natural products, notwithstanding highlights and the occasional spritz of Chanel. She explains here.

headline: The Pro-Miley Backlash
text: Last February, Joanna Coles, the new editor of Cosmopolitan, spent much of Fashion Week squiring around the magazine’s cover girl, Miley Cyrus. There was Ms. Cyrus front row at Rachel Zoe’s show rocking a fire-engine-red jumpsuit. There she was again in an off-white peplum dress at Marchesa. One night, at a party in her honor, as paparazzi hovered, Ms. Cyrus dismissed shock at her budding sexuality as largely a media fabrication. “I think it’s fun to read about,” she said, before adding that she didn’t think the public at large actually cares.

headline: New Hires Suggest Apple’s Interest in TV Continues
text: Apple is not saying much publicly about its plans for television, other than that it is an area of “intense interest.” But it appears that movement is still happening inside the company.

headline: Lois Duncan: Revisiting the Classics of an Earlier Generation
text: At 7 p.m. on a recent crisp September day, the powerHouse Arena bookstore in Dumbo, Brooklyn, was set up for a party celebrating the writer Lois Duncan and the reissue of her young-adult classic, “Debutante Hill.”

headline: For Browns Passer, Comeback Trail Leads Back Home
text: CLEVELAND — The coach’s phone rang at St. Ignatius High School, a longtime football powerhouse here.

headline: Lodge Owner Offers $25,000 to Reopen Grand Canyon
text: The federal government’s shutdown on Tuesday may have closed national parks and museums, but a few groups are working to find alternatives for travelers who don’t want to cancel their vacations.

headline: Surrounding Art With the Sounds of 60
text: One of the most noteworthy aspects of Zorn@60, the extensive concert series with which the composer, bandleader and DIY impresario John Zorn has celebrated his 60th birthday, is the diversity of institutions where those concerts have taken place. While Mr. Zorn spent his 40th birthday at the Knitting Factory and his 50th at Tonic, this year he has taken over some of the city’s most significant bastions of high culture: Lincoln Center, the Guggenheim Museum, the Miller Theater and more.

headline: At Louis Vuitton, Tough Boots for Showgirls
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Celebrating an Elder Statesman of Jazz
text: Jazz regionalism isn’t what it used to be. In an age of instant, endless connectedness, there are fewer compelling reasons for a scene to develop in isolation. Whether you choose to mourn or celebrate that fact, one thing it highlights is the rare intrinsic value of someone like the trumpeter Marcus Belgrave, who received an award of recognition from the Festival of New Trumpet Music at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night.

headline: Brazilian Officers Will Face Charges of Torture and Murder
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Homicide investigators said Wednesday that they would charge 10 police officers with torture and murder in the disappearance of an impoverished construction worker from Rocinha, one of Rio de Janeiro’s largest slums, the latest development in a case that has been a festering source of tension here for months.

headline: At the European Shows, Transcontinental Trends
text: Next Thing You Know, Parisians Will Love Starbucks

headline: Van Gogh’s Copies
text: A new show examines the artist’s copies of his own work.

headline: Seeing Double: Van Gogh the Tweaker
text: For a long time, it’s been something of a dirty secret, violating ideas about great artistic originality: Vincent van Gogh frequently made copies of his own work. Now, in an about-face, what is seemingly the least original aspect of van Gogh’s method is offering a close-up glimpse into the strange, obsessive intensity of his creative process.

headline: A Charm Offensive to Lure Banking Customers in Britain
text: Vernon W. Hill II shook up American retail banking more than a decade ago, and now he’s bringing the same model to Britain.

headline: Plane Crash Investigation Is Delayed
text: Updated, 10:47 a.m. | WASHINGTON — National Transportation Safety Board investigators at the scene of a jet crash that killed four people on Sunday have apparently postponed the investigation because of the government shutdown.

headline: The Art of Work, Hard-Core Edition
text: BERLIN — Along an elegant street here, through a stylish fashion showroom, then into a messy back office, Omer Fast, 41, sits watching pornography on his computer — a smacking, thwacking foursome that’s barely describable.

headline: Peter Schlessel to Lead Universal’s Focus Features
text: LOS ANGELES — In a surprise leadership change at Universal’s Focus Features unit, James Schamus will be replaced by Peter Schlessel.

headline: Clip: 'A Touch of Sin'
text: A clip from “A Touch of Sin,” directed by Jia Zhangke.

headline: Shopping Highlights in New York Starting Oct. 3
text: Openings and Events

headline: Parks and Lodges Try to Deal With Shutdown
text: The state tourism division in North Carolina is suggesting alternative destinations for visitors who wanted to experience the vistors’ center at the Blue Ridge Parkway, which is closed because of the government shutdown. A lodge in Arizona is offering a donation to keep the Grand Canyon National Park open. And the Navajo Nation is reminding visitors that the tribe’s parks and recreation areas–including Lake Powell, Monument Valley and the Four Corners Monument–are open. Rachel Harris’s report is here.

headline: 100 Seconds With Pogue: Galaxy Gear
text: The Times’s David Pogue tests out Samsung’s new smartwatch.

headline: Problems at Health Care Web Site Not From Online Attack, Experts Say
text: As the federal government struggled on Wednesday to explain the technical problems experienced by would-be users of the health exchange Web site, www.healthcare.gov, computer security specialists say they had ruled out a cyberattack known as a denial of service, or DDoS, attack. Those occur when attackers fire huge amounts of traffic at a Web site until it collapses under the load.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Hermès Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Watch That Sinks Under Its Features
text: In the beginning, computers were the size of buildings. To use one, you walked into it.

headline: San Francisco Ballet in Dispute With Dancers
text: The San Francisco Ballet said that it had made “emergency contingency plans” that could result in the cancellation of a planned New York tour, including performances at Lincoln Center, if the union representing its dancers does not meet a deadline for accepting what the ballet called its “last, best and final offer.”

headline: Cuomo Enlists Pataki and McCall to Help With Tax-Cut Plans
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday that he wanted to reduce taxes next year, when he will be seeking re-election, and he named a commission led by a pair of his onetime rivals to develop proposals for New York State lawmakers to consider.

headline: Shutdown Provides Material for Late Night
text: While few people may be laughing on Capitol Hill, the government shutdown is irresistible fodder for late-night comedy. The subject has been at the top of every monologue, and the inspiration for several much-viewed comedy bits.

headline: Shutdown Hurting Intelligence Efforts, Director Says
text: WASHINGTON — At a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday where the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., was testifying, senators of both parties expressed alarm about the impact of the government shutdown on intelligence gathering. Roughly 70 percent of the intelligence agencies’ civilian employees have been furloughed.

headline: In Myanmar, Revival of Attacks on Muslims
text: BANGKOK — A resurgence of religious violence in western Myanmar this week has left six Muslims dead and dozens of homes destroyed, a senior police officer said Wednesday.

headline: Why The Right Fights
text: To understand how we ended up in this strange political moment, with the federal government shuttered in pursuit of a political goal that most elected Republicans concede is well-nigh-impossible to achieve, it’s worth talking not only about polarization and redistricting and the conservative media landscape and anti-Obama sentiment and the weakening of institutional party power, but also about a more basic, often-underappreciated element in how many movement conservatives regard the history of the last forty years. To explain this point, I’ll start with a quote from David Frum’s great book “Dead Right,” which was written in the early 1990s, in what seemed like a period of exhaustion and defeat for limited-government conservatism, just before the 1994 congressional sweep gave that movement new political life. Here’s how the Frum of that era — who was much more of a small-government rigorist than he is today — depicted the Reagan years and their implications for the right:

headline: A Sampling of Old and New, Side by Side
text: The aim of the Fall for Dance Festival is introductory. Its sampler programs are selected for variety, yet there are lessons, intended or not, to be gleaned from the juxtapositions. In this year’s third program, on Monday at City Center, the lessons were about old and new.

headline: Next Time, Libraries Could Be Our Shelters From the Storm
text: Two big storms and a major blackout have battered New York City since the Sept. 11 attacks. Climate change threatens higher tides and more extreme heat. Architects and engineers look for ways to respond.

headline: Family Trees of Familiar Scions
text: Pedigree matters.

headline: The Afro as a Natural Expression of Self
text: Dante de Blasio’s towering Afro, a supporting player in his father’s mayoral campaign, riveted attention once more last week when it caught the eye of President Obama. Introducing Bill de Blasio at a Democratic fund-raiser in Midtown, Mr. Obama digressed to point out, “Dante has the same hairdo as I had in 1978. Although I have to confess my Afro was never that good.”

headline: There’s Bad Blood on Bourbon Street
text: Like practically any television show or movie set in New Orleans, “The Originals” works in a reference to gumbo within the first 10 minutes in an effort to establish its bayou bona fides. For this show, the wearying device is particularly apt because the series itself is a sort of gumbo. The creators tossed everything they could think of — vampires, witches, werewolves, an extra-human pregnancy, New Orleans itself — into a pot and hoped that something would bubble up that matched “The Vampire Diaries,” of which this show is a spinoff.

headline: Food Matters | An Italian Town Says Yes, Please, to Cheese
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: BlackBerry Said to Be of Interest to Cerberus
text: Cerberus Capital Management is seeking a confidentiality agreement that would allow it to examine the books and internal operations of BlackBerry, a person briefed on Cerberus’s plans said on Wednesday.

headline: Jakob Arjouni: Excerpts From His Work
text: The German crime novelist Jakob Arjouni died of pancreatic cancer on Jan. 17. He was 48. Melville House in Brooklyn has just published an English translation of his “Brother Kemal,” the first novel featuring his Frankfurt-based private eye Kayankaya in more than a decade, and the last in the series. Below are excerpts from two of Mr. Arjouni’s previous novels, which were translated from the German by Anselm Hollo. The excerpts appear courtesy of Melville House.

headline: A Master of Crime Fiction in a Nation Lacking Them
text: George Bernard Shaw once remarked that there were two things that Germans have no talent for: revolution and crime novels. Jakob Arjouni proved him half wrong, at any rate.

headline: Mama’s Molotov Cocktails
text: WASHINGTON — Going gently into that good night, or going gently anywhere at all, is obviously not an option for Alexandra, the heroine of “The Velocity of Autumn,” a slight but genial new play by Eric Coble at the Arena Stage here. Although we first see her slumped comfortably in an armchair, wearing a festively colored dress and listening to a little Berlioz, the 79-year-old Alexandra, played with wonderful grit and wit by the great actress Estelle Parsons, is armed for bear.

headline: Another Shutdown Victim: U.S. Efforts to Offset China
text: WASHINGTON — Debate over the federal government shutdown has tended to focus on those it hurts: veterans, tourists barred from the Lincoln Memorial and Yellowstone National Park, and giant-panda enthusiasts deprived of their publicly funded panda cam.

headline: The Agony of Suspense in Detroit
text: DETROIT — It would have been hard to think of a better metaphor: A fire-breathing dragon was bearing down on the Detroit Institute of Arts.

headline: Dragon Rally
text: While reporting on the threats facing the Detroit Institute of Arts' collection, reporter Randy Kennedy encountered a mobile protest in the form of a fire-breathing metal dragon.

headline: For the Price of a SoHo Studio
text: An architect and his wife spent $586,000 on a light-filled New Jersey house, land included.

headline: Oaks in Their Midst
text: As a city couple searching for a place to put down roots, Jeff Jordan and his wife, Sally Librera, had made several predictable stops, including San Francisco and Manhattan. But they ended up someplace totally unexpected.

headline: Domino 3.0
text: It certainly looked like a magazine start up. There was the eager — and tiny — young staff in a scruffy office on West 38th Street decorated with Blu Dot furniture, a couple of Moroccan rugs and their own artwork. Elaina Sullivan, the market editor, had painted canvases à la Rothko. On a wall blackened with chalkboard paint, someone had drawn a medley of picture frames. With no real budget for photography, Michelle Adams, the new magazine’s editor in chief; Brittany Ambridge, the photo director; and Robert Leleux, the creative director, had shot, styled and written nearly every feature. Ms. Ambridge was also responsible for retouching the photos, and Ms. Adams had been making sales calls.

headline: Germans Win d’Orsi Senior Trophy
text: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, which ended on Sunday, the 96-board d’Orsi Senior Trophy final was between Germany (Michael Elinescu, Entscho Wladow, Ulrich Kratz, Bernhard Strater, Reiner Marsal and Ulrich Wenning) and USA-2 (Carolyn Lynch, Mike Passell, Roger Bates, Garey Hayden, Marc Jacobus and Eddie Wold). The Americans lost a heartbreaking match by 11 international match points, primarily because they conceded 24 imps on the four slam deals in the final 16-board session.

headline: A Poetic Rebel Full of Salt and Vinegar
text: “Life is a bitch, full of hangups, full of hurt/First love makes you itch, then it dishes you to the dirt.” No, it’s not Dorothy Parker. Those words belong to Fran Landesman, a hard-living outspoken cynic, who might be described as the Dorothy Parker of jazz lyrics.

headline: Should I Replace Outdated Ceiling Lighting Fixtures?
text: Q. Should I replace my outdated ceiling light fixtures before listing my home for sale?

headline: Cleansing the Palette: Black & White Accessories
text: As an architect who favors modern interiors that are free of clutter, West Chin admits to a preference for the absence of color as well.

headline: Nick Offerman’s Sawdust Vies With Stardust
text: Nick Offerman is a lucky guy, as he humbly and repeatedly submits in his new memoir, “Paddle Your Own Canoe” (Dutton, $26.95). He is married to the actress Megan Mullally, and after years of being passed over for roles, he has come into his prime as a character actor (what a casting agent once told him would be his “sheriff years”), starring as the bacon-loving, whiskey-drinking, sawdust-sniffing Ron Swanson on “Parks and Recreation.”

headline: There Is Nothing Like This Dame
text: It was probably inevitable. There are many pillars of gay culture, but among the sturdiest are an affection for musical theater and a love for the great dames of cinema and the sometimes gloriously melodramatic vehicles that the studio system built to accommodate them. And here it is: “Mildred Fierce.” This show, making its New York premiere, is a loving musical parody of the movie that won Joan Crawford her Oscar and cemented her as a tough, suffering Warner Brothers heroine after her ignominious release from her MGM contract.

headline: Scrutinizing Nature, Sorrow and Oneself With a Subjective Lens
text: This year’s New York Film Festival has been notable for, among other qualities, the number of jumbo offerings, including selections weighing in at three hours or more. The embrace of the cinema of duration continues to somewhat overwhelming effect in “Views From the Avant-Garde,” the festival’s annual lineup of experimental work that this year includes a mind-bending, back-challenging 202 works (17 features, 185 shorts).

headline: No Seat at Table for Soccer Players’ Union
text: As the members of FIFA’s executive committee gather in Zurich this week to discuss — among other things — when to play the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, one of world soccer’s powerful figures is already thinking ahead.

headline: A Tea Tray Inspired by Istanbul Mosques
text: Zeynep Fadillioglu’s Kubbe tray looks like a modern version of the metal tea trays seen in Moroccan and Egyptian markets, but its inspiration is narrower: “kubbe” is Turkish for “dome,” and the designer was thinking of the mosques in her home city, Istanbul. Ms. Fadillioglu knows something about mosques: she led the team that designed the interiors of the strikingly modern Sakirin mosque on the Asian side of the city, whose dome is 130 feet in diameter and trickles glass raindrops from a chandelier suspended there. The tea tray, part of her first collection of furniture and accessories, was introduced at the Maison et Objet show in Paris last month. It is handmade in Turkey of walnut, oak or maple, and costs about $893. Information: (90-212) 287-0936 or zfdesign.com.

headline: Discounts at Broadway Panhandler, Roubini Rugs, Y Lighting and Kartell
text: Some items are up to 60 percent off at Broadway Panhandler, through Sunday (a Wüsthof Classic 8-inch bread knife with bamboo cutting board, usually $150, is about $60); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: John Derian Pulls Up a Chair
text: John Derian introduced furniture four years ago, but don’t feel bad if you didn’t notice: the pieces were often hidden amid decorative pillows and antiques in the designer’s two East Village stores. They finally stepped into the limelight last week with the opening of John Derian Furniture on 8 East Second Street. All the chairs, chaises, sofas, benches and ottomans in the 900-square-foot storefront are influenced by furniture Mr. Derian found during his travels. “Most are 17th-, 18th- and 19th-century European and American designs that we tweaked,” he said. Though the shop is more sparsely decorated than his other stores, it does have a wall of antique oil paintings and a life-size cloth horse that was once in a saddlery. Upholstery fabrics include hand-dyed velvets and Belgian linen from Libeco Lagae. Prices start at $1,185 for a Mignonette chaise. Information: (212) 677-3917 or johnderian.com.

headline: Cabinets of Curiosity
text: For the London Design Festival, which ended last week, Mint, one of the city’s leading design stores, presented Cabinets of Curiosity, cupboards that took everyday storage to poetic heights.

headline: A Quartet Gets Loopy
text: Studio Four NYC, which produces custom rugs for interior designers, has partnered with four of its frequent collaborators to introduce its first rug collection. Amanda Nisbet Design, Carrier and Company, Katie Ridder and Tilton Fenwick each designed two patterns in three color schemes, which are available to regular consumers and the trade.

headline: After the Deluge, This
text: In Long Beach, N.Y., reconstruction is prolonged and painful, with decisions guided by a single, unanswerable question: When will it happen again?

headline: Dark Water: A Year After Hurricane Sandy
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — In lines at the grocery store and the post office here, the usual pleasantries are still squeezed out by talk of the slow pace of reconstruction, spiking flood insurance premiums and whether the hospital, movie theater or sports club will ever reopen. Nearly a year after Sandy, you hear the same refrain everywhere: “Hey, how are you doing? Are you guys back home yet?” About a quarter, possibly more, are not.

headline: Improving Your Home Network
text: NETGEAR is best known as a company that makes the routers that direct Wi-Fi traffic on home computer networks, but its fastest growing product isn’t a router. It’s a device called a network extender, which is meant to improve — and extend — a home’s balky Wi-Fi signal.

headline: Jury Clears Promoter in Death of Michael Jackson
text: A California jury decided on Wednesday that Michael Jackson’s final concert promoter, A.E.G. Live, was not responsible for the pop star’s death.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Tracks Raw Bar & Grill
text: Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan is a hectic place. But the Tracks bar near the Long island Railroad ticket window is a sanctuary of sorts there.

headline: Obama on the Government Shutdown
text: John Harwood of CNBC and The Times interviewed President Obama, who said he was not prepared to negotiate until he was presented with a “clean bill.”

headline: Cameron Rallies Tories as Labour Attacks Pile Up
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron delivered a blistering attack on the Labour Party leader, Ed Miliband, for his left-wing policies on Wednesday. But it was nothing compared with the Conservative-leaning Daily Mail’s description of Mr. Miliband’s father as an unreconstructed Marxist “who hated Britain.”

headline: A Fitting Conclusion in Black and White
text: PARIS — The last day of the spring 2014 collections began in majestic black as Marc Jacobs closed a significant chapter at Louis Vuitton, and ended a few hours later with a plain white cotton shirt and pair of trousers at Hermès.

headline: World War II Memorial Will Stay Open to Veterans
text: WASHINGTON — Veterans will be able to visit the World War II Memorial while the government is shut down, Carol Johnson, a spokeswoman for the National Park Service, said in a Twitter message on Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Why Women Leave Tech, and a Guide to Twitter’s I.P.O. Filing
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Lee Thornton, Ex-White House Reporter, Dies at 71
text: Lee Thornton, a radio and television journalist who covered the White House for CBS News during the Carter administration, became a host of “All Things Considered” on NPR and produced “Both Sides With Jesse Jackson” for CNN, died on Sept. 25 at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 71.

headline: At Airport Hotel, the Runway Is Part of the Show
text: Accommodations near the airport make sense for layovers and business trips, but for weekend getaways, too? Marriott thinks so, and hopes to prove it by attracting more leisure travelers — and aviation enthusiasts — to its Renaissance Concourse Hotel in Atlanta.

headline: Weapons Inspection Team Begins Work in Syria
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — After weeks of threats and negotiations over Syria’s chemical weapons stockpile, an advance team of international weapons inspectors has begun to take the first steps toward dismantling the arsenal. Early indications suggest that they are in for a long, hard slog.

headline: In Surprise Move, President of Howard University Resigns as Budget Troubles Loom
text: After months of internal rifts and a trustee meeting last weekend, Sidney A. Ribeau, the president of Howard University, announced Tuesday that he would resign at the end of the year.

headline: Mixed News on Giants’ Injuries
text: The Giants’ injury report Wednesday was lengthy, a list of 15 players, but it was not all bad news. As expected, there was nothing encouraging to report on the starting offensive linemen Chris Snee (hip) and David Baas (neck), who have been sidelined with injuries.

headline: Someone Had Better Figure Out What He’s Talking About (Trivial)
text: How did it get to be October already?

headline: Stabbing Victim Says Attacker Had ‘a Dead, Methodical Look’
text: The attacker never said a word as he marched toward James Fayette and his child, a pair of bloody scissors in hand.

headline: New York Finally Dresses Down
text: When it comes to everyday clothing, Priscila McCalley, a corporate lawyer in Manhattan, loves a bargain. She’ll pay “up to $100 for a going-out kind of dress, and about the same for a work dress,” she said, but only if the items are on sale.

headline: Obama Says He Won’t Negotiate Until Government Reopens
text: In their first meeting since a budget impasse shuttered many federal operations, President Obama told Republican leaders on Wednesday that he would negotiate with them only after they agreed to the financing needed to reopen the government and also to an essential increase in the nation’s debt limit, without add-ons.

headline: As F.B.I. Pursued Snowden, an E-Mail Service Stood Firm
text: DALLAS — One day last May, Ladar Levison returned home to find an F.B.I. agent’s business card on his Dallas doorstep. So began a four-month tangle with law enforcement officials that would end with Mr. Levison’s shutting the business he had spent a decade building and becoming an unlikely hero of privacy advocates in their escalating battle with the government over Internet security.

headline: Despite Criticisms, Health Care Law’s Impact on Jobs Is Still Unclear
text: WASHINGTON — To Speaker John A. Boehner, it is “job-killing.” To Senator Ted Cruz, it is “hurting the American people.” To Senator Mitch McConnell, it is a “big reason we are turning into a nation of part-time workers.”

headline: Where Rush Hour and Happy Hour Overlap
text: In the eyes of its detractors — which is to say, most people — Pennsylvania Station has all the charm of a hospital.

headline: Braves’ Free Swingers Face Dodgers’ Staff of Aces
text: In the mid-1990s, when baseball added the division series to be played before the league championship series, nobody said much about the randomness of the postseason. The Atlanta Braves ruled the National League and simply owned the new round.

headline: Yankees Begin Negotiations to Bring Back Girardi
text: Brian Cashman met with Steve Mandell, the agent for Joe Girardi, as planned on Wednesday and began negotiations for a new contract for Girardi. The meeting was said to be a good one and the sides will continue talking.

headline: France: Court Throws Out Cases Claiming Racial Profiling by Police
text: A court in Paris on Wednesday threw out lawsuits that claimed illegal racial profiling by the police engaged in public identity checks and pat-downs. The decisions will be appealed, said Lanna Hollo, a legal officer for the Open Society Justice Initiative, an advocacy organization that supported the lawsuits. In linked but separate civil cases, 13 black and Arab men requested 10,000 euros, about $13,600, in damages from the state after being stopped and in some cases frisked by the police; none of the stops were followed by further police action or charges. The court found that the men had been unable to prove racial motives for the identity checks, which are widely viewed in France as a legitimate policing tactic. A 2009 study conducted by French researchers and the Open Society Justice Initiative found that Arabs and blacks were as much as eight times more likely to be stopped than whites.

headline: Social Networks in a Battle for the Second Screen
text: After “Breaking Bad” drew 10.3 million viewers to one of the most crowd-satisfying finales in television history on Sunday, Twitter and Facebook raced to tell the news media about the throngs who shared their instant reactions to the show on the social networks.

headline: UBS Brokers in Puerto Rico Create Headache for the Bank
text: Over the years, Puerto Rico has attracted the very wealthy, who come for the postcard-perfect beaches and the promise of a tax-free life.

headline: Finally Secure in the Desert, the Coyotes Devote Their Focus to the Ice
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Just three months ago, the Phoenix Coyotes were less than five days from moving to Seattle. Yet that was not the closest call during the team’s long period of instability. At one point in 2010, they came within 15 minutes of moving to Winnipeg.

headline: Fish or Cut Bait
text: It was the most important military commission case to come before any court in the more than seven years since the Supreme Court invalidated the Bush administration’s first effort to set up military commissions to try Guantánamo detainees for war crimes.

headline: Iran’s President Responds to Netanyahu
text: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Wednesday dismissed the verbal assault on his credibility by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel the day before, during a speech at the United Nations General Assembly. Mr. Rouhani was quoted by Iranian news agencies as saying Mr. Netanyahu’s speech reflected what the Iranian leader called Israeli alarm at the signs of rapprochement between Iran and the United States. “Israel is upset to see that its sword has gone blunt and Iran grows more powerful by the day,” the Fars News Agency quoted Mr. Rouhani as saying. Mr. Netanyahu, who considers Iran his country’s most dangerous enemy, said in his speech that the Iranian leader was seeking to deceive the world by asserting an earnest desire to resolve the impasse over Iran’s disputed nuclear program. Mr. Rouhani, who visited the United Nations last week, spoke by telephone with President Obama on Friday, the first such contact between the leaders of Iran and the United States in 34 years.

headline: Does Scotland Want Independence?
text: GLASGOW, Scotland — IN just under a year, Scotland will hold a referendum on whether to become an independent country. The issue is already so divisive that the comedian Susan Calman had to call for an end to the “name-calling, swearing and death threats” she received after making jokes about it on a radio show. It’s so controversial that it would be bad manners to bring it up with anyone who doesn’t agree with you already.

headline: America Mustn’t Be Naïve About Iran
text: WASHINGTON — THE international agreement to destroy Syria’s stockpile of chemical weapons has put diplomacy back at center stage of American foreign policy. But enforcing America’s “red line” in Syria is only a prelude to dealing with the thicker, redder line around Iran’s nuclear program. Last week’s charm offensive by Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, and his seeming show of flexibility augurs well for a diplomatic resolution.

headline: Brooklyn Inquiry Finds Witness Who Says Police Coached Him to Lie
text: A sweeping investigation into cases handled years ago by a retired Brooklyn homicide detective has turned up a witness to a 1995 murder who says the police coached him into giving false testimony.

headline: Excuses, Excuses, Excuses
text: As our National Zoo closes while the Congressional zoo remains open and (infuriatingly!) pays itself, House Republicans are making a series of arguments about Why It’s Not Our Fault:

headline: Minority Rules
text: So, the House Republicans have shut down the government. Now what? What is their end goal? What is the principle at play? What do they hope to gain?

headline: Congress Breaks Bad
text: As the government shutdown dragged on, gloom mounted. James Clapper, the director of national intelligence, warned that foreign intelligence services might swoop in and recruit furloughed C.I.A. workers. That seemed a little paranoid, but then we’re talking about spies.

headline: A Blind Spot on Rearview Cameras
text: Safety is a big issue for Americans, but many dangers persist simply for lack of political will to confront them.

headline: Mercy at the End of a Life
text: On Tuesday, a federal judge in Louisiana ordered the immediate release of Herman Wallace, a 71-year-old man who has spent more than 40 years in solitary confinement conditions for the murder of a prison guard. Mr. Wallace, who maintains his innocence, was wheeled out on a stretcher and taken to a local hospital because he is dying of advanced liver cancer. Prosecutors fought his release up to the moment of his departure.

headline: The Cost of the Shutdown
text: Many Republicans seem to be celebrating the government shutdown as an opportunity to show that less spending isn’t really so bad. “People are probably going to realize they can live with a lot less government than what they thought they needed,” said Representative Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee on Fox News. Her upbeat attitude helps explain why so many in her party thought nothing of shutting down a government they distrust, all to dismantle a health care law they oppose.

headline: Learning the Wrong Lessons About Austerity
text: After a deep, three-year recession, the economy of the 28 countries that make up the European Union collectively grew 0.4 percent in the three months that ended in June, the best quarterly figure since early 2011. That is hardly a cause for celebration for most Europeans who have experienced little to no discernible change in their lives in recent months. The union’s unemployment rate, for instance, was 10.9 percent in August, and has not budged since May.

headline: Two Media Mainstays Expand Their Video Presence
text: TWO companies that are mainstays in legacy media are expanding their presence in online video, producing more original Web series as they follow consumer eyeballs and advertiser dollars.

headline: Partial Victory for BP in Dispute Over Settlement
text: HOUSTON — A federal appeals court gave BP a partial victory on Wednesday by ordering a lower court judge to reconsider his interpretation of a settlement with claimants who filed billions of dollars of claims against the oil company after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster.

headline: Can Obama Ignore the Debt Ceiling?
text: Can President Obama exceed the debt without Congressional approval in order to keep the government running?

headline: New York: Two Cities?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Politics Behind the Government Shutdown
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preparing Teachers for the Urban Classroom
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Fashion Runway, South Sudan Takes Steps Toward a National Identity
text: JUBA, South Sudan — Even by the standards of fashion models, the women teetering in their high heels on the dirt catwalk here were remarkably tall and slender. But judging by South Sudan’s many towering inhabitants, they were hardly out of the ordinary in the young nation’s capital.

headline: Where Poor and Uninsured Americans Live
text: The 26 Republican-dominated states not participating in an expansion of Medicaid are home to a disproportionate share of the nation’s poorest uninsured residents. Eight million will be stranded without insurance.

headline: Wall St. Fears Go Beyond Shutdown
text: With Washington preoccupied by the government shutdown, Wall Street is shifting its attention to an even more worrisome situation: the possibility that the government could run out of money within the next few weeks, forcing an unprecedented default on its debt.

headline: War and Baked Beans

headline: As Government Slugs It Out, Government Workers Take It on the Chin
text: PHILADELPHIA — Lyn Kirshenbaum understands why President Obama and Congressional Republicans keep exchanging roundhouse swings over health care and federal spending. Politics is a brutal business.

headline: At 20 and in the Spotlight, Whether He Likes It or Not
text: DUBLIN, OHIO — Jordan Spieth’s mother had just finished telling a reporter about her son’s unease with being the center of attention at this week’s Presidents Cup when Spieth’s practice group arrived at the par-3 12th tee at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

headline: Obama ‘Hugely Impressed’ by Pope Francis
text: President Obama said in an interview on Wednesday that he had been “hugely impressed” with Pope Francis, “not because of any particular issue” but because he seemed to be “thinking about how to embrace people as opposed to push them away.”

headline: Fuel From Landfill Methane Goes on Sale
text: Farmers, waste management companies and the energy industries have long experimented with converting methane, a byproduct of decomposing organic matter, into transportation fuel.

headline: Senator Harry Reid on the Shutdown
text: Highlights from the Senate majority leader’s frequent comments about the government shutdown illustrate his acerbic side.

headline: In Showdown With G.O.P., a Scrappy Reid Plays Hardball
text: WASHINGTON — It was not enough for Senator Harry Reid to just dismiss Republican offers as “vexatious” or “kid’s stuff” or “one cockamamie, can’t-pass idea after another.” He called the White House and asked it to issue a veto threat, which it promptly did.

headline: Corrections: October 3, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: For a Jig or a Tale of Bawdry
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., I’ll admit this: the theme for Evan Birnholz’s very clever double rebus puzzle was spoiled for me earlier in the week because of technical issues that were encountered in trying to produce this puzzle for the Web. It didn’t change my feelings about the puzzle, though; I thought it was a great idea, even when I knew what was coming. Then I saw it being solved again in the final round of the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament. I can only imagine what this was like for those of you solving it for the first time.

headline: After Fighting Off Urge to Rebuild, Pirates Will Battle Cardinals
text: A year ago, it would have been hard to imagine Pittsburgh in a division series in 2013. As if 20 losing seasons in a row were not bad enough, the Pirates had made a habit of raising fans’ hopes and then falling flat in the final few weeks of the season. The front office recognized the unrest.

headline: Bonus Day at the Beach, if Not for That Shutdown
text: The air was warm, with just the right amount of breeze. The waves flashed translucent green before breaking on the beach at Jacob Riis Park in Queens. And there was not a cloud in sight. In other words, it was a perfect beach day, and despite the calendar, a rare opportunity to sneak in some sand and surf before the leaves start to fall.

headline: Eight Are Killed in Tennessee After Tire Blows Out on Bus
text: ATLANTA — At least eight people died after a front tire of a chartered bus blew out along Interstate 40 in Tennessee on Wednesday, sending the vehicle across a grassy median and into a tractor-trailer and a sport utility vehicle, the state authorities said.

headline: Ruth Maleczech, Beacon of Stage Avant-Garde, Dies at 74
text: Ruth Maleczech, a reigning figure of the New York avant-garde theater for more than four decades, died on Monday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 74.

headline: In TV Ad, Lhota Cites Common Ground, and Differences, With de Blasio
text: Joseph J. Lhota, lagging in the polls in the race for mayor of New York City, on Wednesday released the first television advertisement of the general election campaign, trumpeting his liberal stances on social issues but criticizing the tax-raising plan of his Democratic rival, Bill de Blasio.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Tom Clancy, Spinner of Suspense
text: Mr. Clancy’s military thrillers were blockbuster hits on the best-seller list, at the box office and even in the gaming world. He died at 66 in Baltimore.

headline: Chandler Seeking Progress With a Few Steps Back
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Tyson Chandler celebrated his 31st birthday Wednesday by retreating to a side basket at the Knicks’ training gym. As his teammates practiced on an adjacent court, Chandler launched dozens of midrange jump shots.

headline: Kidd’s Task: Show Stars the Rewards of Resting
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Jason Kidd logged 50,111 minutes on the court over 19 seasons as a professional basketball player. It is an impressive total, to be sure, but he probably would not have minded if he had clocked a couple of thousand fewer.

headline: Albert D. Wheelon, Architect of Aerial Spying, Dies at 84
text: Albert D. Wheelon, a physicist whose early work on satellites for the C.I.A. in the 1960s helped lay the groundwork for a vast American arsenal of aerial spying machines, died on Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Even With Allies Leading New York City, Unions Won’t Have It Easy
text: Organized labor is having somewhat of a moment in New York City.

headline: Leonard Kerpelman, Who Led School Prayer Case, Dies at 88
text: Leonard J. Kerpelman, a Baltimore lawyer and gadfly who successfully argued a landmark Supreme Court case in 1963 that led to a ban on state-supported prayer in public schools, died on Sept. 26 in Baltimore. He was 88.

headline: A Yellow Light for the Jets, but No Color-Coded System
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — At his 2 p.m. news conference Wednesday, Jets Coach Rex Ryan, perhaps thinking aloud, floated the idea of asking the rookie quarterback Geno Smith to wear a color-coded wristband Monday night against Atlanta.

headline: Millions of Poor Are Left Uncovered by Health Law
text: A sweeping national effort to extend health coverage to millions of Americans will leave out two-thirds of the poor blacks and single mothers and more than half of the low-wage workers who do not have insurance, the very kinds of people that the program was intended to help, according to an analysis of census data by The New York Times.

It also signaled its displeasure with the Police Department over the case.

headline: Faded Dreams of Riches Drive Pursuit of a Celebrated Fungus

With a resigned nod, the man shoved the gear knob into park.

headline: Still Playing on Road, the Rays Send Another Team Home for Good
text: CLEVELAND — In their brief time on land this week, the Tampa Bay Rays have won three games in three cities, with another trip to come. They do not mind the travel. Although they are unappreciated at home, their riveting road show has earned them a date in Boston for an American League division series.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) SCANDAL A third season begins as Olivia (Kerry Washington, above, in the role that earned her an Emmy nomination) deals with the repercussions of having been revealed as the mistress of the president (Tony Goldwyn). Meanwhile, her father (Joe Morton), the mysterious head of a top-secret black ops program financed by the C.I.A., is determined to fulfill his orders no matter what. “Scandal: The Secret Is Out,” at 8, presents highlights and story lines from the show’s first two seasons.

headline: 10 Questions for President Obama
text: President Obama remains stuck in a double-barreled showdown with Congressional Republicans — over the government shutdown and over the need to raise the government’s debt limit by mid-October to allow the United States Treasury to meet its obligations.

text: Every fall, Chemult, Ore., swells with pickers and buyers who flock to the forests to look for the prized matsutake mushroom.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Moody’s Gives Philippines Investment-Grade Rating
text: HONG KONG — The Philippines received an investment-grade rating from Moody’s Investors Service on Thursday, underscoring the rapid growth and political stability that the country — once seen as a “sick man of Asia” — has enjoyed in recent years.

headline: U.S. and Japan Agree to Broaden Military Alliance
text: TOKYO — The United States and Japan agreed on Thursday to broaden their security alliance, expanding Japan’s role while trying to show American determination to remain a dominant presence in the region.

headline: Kerry Says Talks With Iran Will Not Be Based on Trust
text: TOKYO — Secretary of State John Kerry, in his first remarks about Iran since Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel warned the United States to be wary of talks with the country, said on Thursday that the United States would negotiate with Tehran only if it provided proof that it would not pursue nuclear defense programs.

headline: Party Leader in Greece Is Returned to Custody
text: ATHENS — The leader of the extreme-right Golden Dawn party was returned to custody on Thursday after appearing before a Greek magistrate on charges of setting up a criminal organization, part of the government’s crackdown on a party described by Greek and European authorities as neo-Nazi and violent.

headline: Top Indonesian Judge Held in Corruption Case
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The chief justice of Indonesia’s Constitutional Court was arrested this week in a nighttime raid on his official residence by anticorruption investigators, who accused the justice of taking a bribe to issue a favorable verdict in an election dispute.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Science Behind Your Craving for Doritos
text: In the video above, and in a graphic called “The Nacho Dorito,” Michael Moss explains how food scientists have made this snack so compelling. Watch the video first, then read the graphic, using both to answer these questions.

headline: Q. and A. on the Government Shutdown in the U.S.
text: PARIS — The United States government is in a political and financial crisis that could reverberate around the globe.

headline: Why Are There Still So Few Women in Science?
text: Last summer, researchers at Yale published a study proving that physicists, chemists and biologists are likely to view a young male scientist more favorably than a woman with the same qualifications. Presented with identical summaries of the accomplishments of two imaginary applicants, professors at six major research institutions were significantly more willing to offer the man a job. If they did hire the woman, they set her salary, on average, nearly $4,000 lower than the man’s. Surprisingly, female scientists were as biased as their male counterparts.

headline: Open Eyes and Heart in Paris
text: In Peter Turnley’s Paris, there is no unruly traffic, no labor strikes and no waiting in lines.

headline: Is There Too Much Pressure on Girls to Have ‘Perfect’ Bodies?
text: New York City’s latest public health campaign takes on unattainable notions of beauty promoted by advertisers to tell girls that they are beautiful the way they are.

headline: Migrants Die as Burning Boat Capsizes Off Italy
text: ROME — Having floated for at least two days in the choppy Mediterranean Sea to reach Europe, a rickety trawler overstuffed with African migrants fleeing war and poverty was nearing a Sicilian island, not even a quarter-mile away. But it was still dark and no one had yet spotted them. So to signal their position, someone set a match to a blanket.

headline: New York Today: Hockey Weather
text: Updated 12:33 p.m. | It’s October. Leaves are turning, it gets dark by dinnertime and hockey season is starting.

headline: In Washington, Wedded Bliss Has to Wait
text: WASHINGTON — For couples who plan to get hitched at the courthouse here, marital bliss may be tempered by the government shutdown.

headline: Crunching Numbers on Lambrecht: Was Keeping Those Old Cars Worth It?
text: The sales numbers are in for last weekend’s Lambrecht auction – the liquidation of a retired Chevrolet dealer’s immense stock of leftover vehicles. According to Proxibid, based in Omaha, the company that fielded online bidding for the auction, total sales including on-site and online purchases was about $2.8 million.

headline: De Blasio Has Enormous Lead Over Lhota, Poll Finds
text: With five weeks until Election Day, the race for New York City mayor is shaping up to be a landslide, with Bill de Blasio holding a 50-point lead over his Republican opponent, Joseph J. Lhota, in a poll released on Thursday by Quinnipiac University.

headline: Signs Suggest North Korea Has Restarted Nuclear Reactor
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s main nuclear complex was discharging hot wastewater in a further sign that the country has restarted a Soviet-era nuclear reactor there that it had used to obtain plutonium fuel for atomic bombs, an American research institute said on Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Social Networks Battle to Be the Center of Talk About TV
text: When “Breaking Bad” concluded to an audience of 10.3 million viewers on Sunday, Facebook and Twitter raced to tell news media about the throngs who shared their reactions to the show on their social networks. But the companies were seeking more than just bragging rights, Vindu Goel and Brian Stelter report.

headline: Week 5 Probabilities: Why Offense Is More Important Than Defense
text: The original goal of building a model for football forecasting was to weigh the importance of each facet of the game. In particular, I wanted to know if offense was more important than defense or if defense really did win championships.

headline: Metro-North, Star of the Rails, Stumbles in a Rough Year
text: Among the largely unloved ranks of public transit systems, the Metro-North Railroad has long been the golden child.

headline: British Regulator Plans New Rules for Payday Lenders
text: British regulators announced plans on Thursday to impose stiff new rules next year for payday lenders, whose business has grown sharply since the financial crisis.

headline: Alibaba Invests in a Search Engine for Apps
text: The Chinese Internet company Alibaba Group wears a number of hats, with commerce sites, a payment system and a search engine.

headline: A New Kindle Fire, Just in Time for the Holiday Season
text: If it’s October, that must mean the holiday buying season has begun — and that means Amazon will offer a new color tablet.

headline: Obama Cancels Asia Visit
text: The U.S. shutdown cuts into Obama’s travel plans.

headline: The Mystery of Earth’s Oxygen
text: To Donald E. Canfield, there’s something astonishing in every breath we take. “People take oxygen for granted because it’s just there and we breathe it all the time,” said Dr. Canfield, a geochemist at the University of Southern Denmark. “But we have the only planet we know of anywhere that has oxygen on it.”

headline: First You Cry, Then You Marry a Prince
text: LONDON — Since the ’90s, the singer and songwriter Tori Amos has been an inspiration to sensitive young women everywhere through her deeply personal and angry songs about bleak subjects like masochism and lost love. So it came as a bit of a surprise when Ms. Amos and the playwright Samuel Adamson, also not known for easygoing fare, were told that their new musical, “The Light Princess,” just wasn’t dark enough for Nicholas Hytner, director of the National Theater here.

headline: Between Earth and Heaven
text: “Life in space is impossible.” That stark statement of scientific fact is one of the first things to appear on screen in “Gravity,” but before long, it is contradicted, or at least complicated. As our eyes (from behind 3-D glasses) adjust to the vast darkness, illuminated by streaks of sunlight refracted through the Earth’s atmosphere, we detect movement that is recognizably human and hear familiar voices. Those tiny figures bouncing around on that floating contraption — it looks like a mobile suspended from a child’s bedroom ceiling — are people. Scientists. Astronauts. Movie stars. (Sandra Bullock and George Clooney in spacesuits, as Mission Specialist Ryan Stone and Mission Commander Matt Kowalski; Ed Harris, unseen and unnamed, as “Houston” down below).

headline: More Companies to Call Emerging Markets Home
text: Emerging markets will be the headquarters to thousands more of the world’s largest companies — as many as half — in the next decade or two, a study published by the McKinsey Global Institute said Thursday.

headline: Rattled Congress Seeks Way Out of Its Standoff
text: WASHINGTON — Republican efforts to resolve the fiscal standoff that has closed much of the federal government heated up Thursday, the third day of the shutdown, with new talks over a broad budget deal and an effort by more moderate House members to break the logjam.

headline: Ackman Modifies Bet Against Herbalife
text: The activist investor William A. Ackman has pared down his $1 billion bet against the nutritional supplements company Herbalife, he told investors on Wednesday.

headline: Obama Warns Wall Street
text: Markets have had a muted response to the government shutdown that began on Tuesday. But President Obama, in an interview with CNBC, warned that the economic effects of political gridlock could grow far worse if Congress fails to raise the debt ceiling by Oct. 17, leaving the country at risk of defaulting on its borrowing. “This time is different,” he said, adding that Wall Street “should be concerned.”

headline: Karate-Chopping Trees in Central Park
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Fuss About India’s Oscar Entry
text: It is not every day that the heavyweights of Bollywood sulk over a prize. Sept. 21 was, however, one such day. On this day, the Film Federation of India, an autonomous trade body authorized by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to select India’s entry for the Oscars, announced “The Good Road” as its choice for 2014.

headline: ENI of Italy Considers Large Gas Project in Mozambique
text: LONDON — ENI, the Italian oil company, and its partners in Mozambique are strongly considering building a floating liquefied natural gas platform to export a portion of the gas they have discovered in the waters there.

headline: A Home Furnishings Visionary Takes On High Culture
text: After upending the home design market with his democratizing strategy of good taste for the masses, the Restoration Hardware guru Gary Friedman is now betting he can do the same in the rarefied world of art. Will he disrupt or be disrupted?

headline: 36 Hours in Antwerp, Belgium
text: Antwerp’s central railway station makes a grand first impression with its soaring glass ceiling, elegant hall and ornate turn-of-the-century architecture. And it’s a splendid entrance to this stylish city, the largest in the northern Belgian region of Flanders. Years ago, Antwerp established itself as a fashion hub following the international success of top designers like Dries van Noten, Ann Demeulemeester and fellow alumni from the local Royal Academy of Fine Arts, one of Europe’s premier design schools. But today, the imagination and innovation that initially spurred the cerebral fashions for which the city became known is now blooming in diverse forms — from comics to cuisine, and art to architecture.

headline: Former Bihar Chief Minister Gets Five Years in Jail
text: NEW DELHI— An Indian court on Thursday sentenced Lalu Prasad, a former chief minister of Bihar, to five years in jail after he was found guilty of participating in a scheme in which mid-ranking officials created false receipts and siphoned off $ 6 million worth of public funds earmarked for animal husbandry for more than a decade.

headline: Bibi’s Tired Iranian Lines
text: Never has it been more difficult for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to convince the world that, as he put it in 2006: “It’s 1938. Iran is Germany.” He tried again at the United Nations this week. In a speech that strained for effect, he likened Iran to a 20th-century “radical regime” of “awesome power.” That would be the Third Reich.

headline: The Accumulated Wisdom on Bribing Your Children
text: When it comes to teaching children about money, there are few tactics that draw more outright hostility from parenting experts than our amateurish attempts to bribe the little people.

headline: Next Act for Master of the Page-Turner
text: “A Time to Kill” was deep into technical rehearsals in late September when John Grisham arrived in New York. The day after his flight landed, he and his wife grabbed a bite before heading to the theater.

headline: 2014 Toyota Corolla Gets ‘Marginal’ Rating in Tougher Crash Test
text: The redesigned 2014 Toyota Corolla – one of the automaker’s most important models — earned a Marginal rating in the new and challenging small overlap frontal crash test, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety said on Thursday.

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for October 6, 2013

headline: An Unacceptable Headline Atop a Questionable Article
text: It’s hard to know where to start with the lead article in Monday’s Times. In it, anonymous government sources – described in the vaguest possible way (for example, “one United States official”) – are unquestioningly allowed to play their favorite press-bashing hand, featuring the national security card. In so doing, they seem to take a swipe at a news organization that competes with The Times.

headline: Aggressive Blunderers
text: Jonathan Chait argues that blame for what looks more and more like a shutdown merging with a debt ceiling crisis rests not with Tea Party radicasl but with the Republican leadership: “The House leadership has evinced every tic of classic aggressive blunderers.”

headline: Boehner Pledges to Avoid Default, Republicans Say
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner has privately told Republican lawmakers anxious about fallout from the government shutdown that he would not allow a potentially more crippling federal default as the atmosphere on Capitol Hill turned increasingly tense on Thursday.

headline: Shipwreck Survivors Saved Near Sicily
text: The Italian Coast Guard released video showing rescued migrants being helped to shore. On Thursday, a boat carrying 500 migrants sank just half a mile from the Sicilian coast.

headline: These Boots Are Made for Walking to the Bank: ‘Kinky’ Recoups Its $13.5 Million
text: “Kinky Boots,” the popular Broadway musical about a drag queen who saves the day at a struggling shoe factory, has recouped its $13.5 million capitalization in a relatively quick 30 weeks of performances, the lead producers, Daryl Roth and Hal Luftig, announced on Thursday.

headline: How the Shutdown May Hurt the Environment
text: It is far from clear how badly the country’s environment will be damaged by the government shutdown. But the immediate prospects are not promising.

headline: Egypt Back at Square One
text: CAIRO — Two police officers are on trial for beating to death a young Egyptian man, Khaled Said, in broad daylight. Outside the Alexandria courthouse where they are being tried, rows of riot police and a small band of protesters face off. The demonstrators chant anti-police slogans and are beaten and arrested.

headline: Braves’ Kimbrel Is King of Remaining Closers
text: Throughout his career, Mariano Rivera  had the distinction of being considered the game’s best relief pitcher, even though in almost any season you could point to a pitcher who had outperformed him statistically. From Trevor Hoffman to Eric Gagne to Koji Uehara, there has almost always been a player who had a better earned run average, or more saves, or a lower WHIP. But Rivera, based on his particularly incredible postseason record and the air of confidence he gave the Yankees, has been the king of closers since he assumed the role in 1997.

headline: Postscript on Rivera, Almost the 1.0000 and Only
text: In the end, Mariano Rivera pitched 1,283.2 innings and gave up 1,284 hits and walks combined. In other words, if Derek Jeter and Andy Pettitte had not gone out to the mound last week so they could dramatically remove Rivera from his final game as a Yankee, the greatest reliever in the history of baseball might have finished with an immaculate WHIP measurement of 1.0000.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘September Midnight’
text: At the start of autumn, we present a Poetry Pairing featuring “September Midnight,” a poem by Sara Teasdale that was published in 1914, and an article from 2012, “Finding Zen in a Patch of Nature.”

headline: Pressing Republicans, Obama Links Shutdown and Economy
text: WASHINGTON — An impassioned President Obama on Thursday kept up the pressure on House Republicans to end the three-day-old government shutdown, appearing at a small construction company outside the capital to challenge Speaker John A. Boehner to quit blocking a vote on the needed federal spending.

headline: Remembering City Opera: ‘We Will Miss it More than We Realize’
text: New York City Opera announced this week that it would close its doors and file for bankruptcy after 70 years of productions that included notable performers like Beverly Sills, Norman Treigle, Plácido Domingo, Catherine Malfitano and Samuel Ramey. Times readers, including many who performed or worked for the City Opera, shared their favorite memories of the company. Below are highlights, in some cases slightly edited for clarity.

text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban on Thursday staged a suicide attack on a rival militant commander in northwestern Pakistan that killed at least 15 people but was reported to have left the commander only lightly wounded, Pakistani officials said.

headline: The Gun Report: October 3, 2013
text: Maryland gun dealers have sold more firearms in the first nine months of this year than in all of 2011 and 2012 combined, as lawmakers debated and enacted some of the toughest new gun laws in the country. The Baltimore Sun reported that more than 15,000 gun-purchase applications were filed in the 10 days before a ban on assault rifle sales and a new handgun licensing requirement took effect Tuesday. More than 4,300 gun purchase applications were filed last weekend alone.

headline: When Mom’s Clicks Lead to Love First
text: When my mom started setting up her profile on a dating Web site called Ourtime.com, she was super pumped.

text: Every N.F.L. season has its share of surprise fantasy performers, and one could argue that 2013 has had more than usual.

headline: Republicans Say Boehner Has Offered Assurances on Default
text: WASHINGTON — With a budget deal still elusive and a deadline approaching on raising the debt ceiling, Speaker John A. Boehner has told colleagues that he is determined to prevent a federal default and is willing to pass a measure through a combination of Republican and Democratic votes, according to one House Republican.

headline: Malcolm Gladwell: By the Book
text: The author of “David and Goliath” compares Michael Lewis to Tiger Woods: “I’ll never play like that. But it’s good to be reminded every now and again what genius looks like.”

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor, in Reversal, Will Run as a Republican to Keep His Job
text: Last month, after losing the Democratic primary for Brooklyn district attorney by 10 points, Charles J. Hynes said he would give up his bid for a seventh term in the office he has occupied since 1990. His name remained on the ballot on the Republican Party line, but he promised a “smooth transition” for the man who defeated him, Kenneth P. Thompson.

headline: The Latest Fashion Accessory Is an I.P.O.
text: An initial public offering instead of a contract. LVMH may have found an original way to keep close the hot designers that made it worth 75 billion euros and created the world’s largest luxury group.

text: Philip Ettinger and Tracee Chimo in a scene from Joshua Harmon’s comedy at the Laura Pels Theater.

headline: SAC’s Forceful Ways Shown in Massachusetts Citi Case
text: The hedge fund was so desperate for an upper hand that four of its employees pleaded with a Wall Street analyst one morning to reveal private insights.

headline: Driver’s Wife Describes Fear of Angry ‘Mob’ of Bikers
text: For the first time since a weekend confrontation with a large group of motorcyclists led to the beating of the driver of a sport utility vehicle, the wife of the driver publicly addressed the episode on Thursday, saying she and her husband were terrified when a crowd surrounded their vehicle after it struck one of the riders.

headline: Skiing, the Next Generation
text: A cluster of Colorado ski resorts is playing the long game this year, opening new trails and adding perks for families in an effort to nurture the next generation of skiers and snowboarders.
