text: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the many tanking comedies that had their premiere this season.

headline: Chirlane McCray on Love, Politics and Bloomberg
text: Chirlane McCray, the wife of Bill de Blasio, sat down with me recently for a two-hour interview at Little Purity Diner in Park Slope, speaking openly about her personal life, her politics and her role in the campaign.

headline: Vanska to Conduct Two Farewell Concerts With Musicians of Minnesota Orchestra
text: MINNEAPOLIS — As had widely been expected here in recent days, Osmo Vanska, who resigned as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra on Tuesday, will conduct concerts on Friday and Saturday evenings presented by the orchestra’s locked-out players. The Musicians of the Minnesota Orchestra, as they call themselves in their independent activities, announced Mr. Vanska’s participation on Thursday, saying that the concerts will be his “thank you and farewell to Minnesota.”

headline: Lorde, Miley and the Different Flavors of Pop
text: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss different approaches to pop stardom, as embodied by Lorde and Miley Cyrus.

headline: Short and Sweet: Reading and Writing Flash Fiction
text: Overview | What are the essential elements of a story? How can writing flash fiction help us become better writers? In this lesson, students will consider the nature of stories and learn to write more concisely by reading and writing flash fiction.

headline: With the Jobs Report, No News Isn’t Good News
text: The monthly employment report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics is the most important source of information on how the economy is delivering (or not) for the American people.

headline: T FALL TRAVEL
text: With its last-frontier appeal and magical mixed bag of culture, New Orleans is quietly luring a circle of expats, who find an evolving city that’s just the right amount of undone.

headline: Document | A Photographer’s Pit Stops Along America’s Highways
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Some Economic Consequences of the Shutdown
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Samsung’s Mobile Chief Departs
text: Kevin Packingham, the chief product officer for the mobile division of Samsung Electronics, who was involved in introducing several of Samsung’s popular Galaxy devices, has left the company.

headline: Reuters Plans to Lay Off 5% of Newsroom Staff
text: Turmoil continues at Thomson Reuters after the company announced on Wednesday that it was laying off staff members.

headline: New York City Marathon to Have Tighter Security
text: All bags brought anywhere near the New York City Marathon will be searched. Family members heading to the finish line will go through a special screening. People marching in the kickoff parade will not be allowed to carry bags of any kind.

headline: Life, Interrupted: A Golden Opportunity
text: Earlier this week I found myself surrounded by journalism royalty. Many of the most-talented and most-courageous broadcast journalists, editors, producers and videographers had gathered at New York’s Lincoln Center for the News and Documentary Emmy Awards.

headline: Roth, in His Own Words
text: To the Editor:

headline: Not Shrews. Princes and Kings.
text: In Shakespeare’s plays, women put on men’s clothes so they can travel where they like, marry whom they like, and speak their minds. Actresses from the 1600s to the present have followed suit — literally — dressing as men in search of better parts and more lines. Here are some of the most famous examples of Shakespearean male drag. ALEXIS SOLOSKI

headline: France Moves to Shore Up African State in Turmoil
text: France is drafting a United Nations Security Council resolution aimed at stabilizing the Central African Republic, the chronically dysfunctional country in which a transitional government has failed to stop months of lawless rampaging, atrocities and dire shortages that are attracting extremist militants from neighboring states.

headline: Renaissance Woman
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Duplex’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Straight Sets Content Is On the Move
text: Thank you for visiting Straight Sets. This blog’s regular features, including live tournament analysis, news and notes from Christopher Clarey, Ben Rothenberg and others, and other coverage, can now be found on the tennis section front. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely tennis news.

headline: A Short History of the Morgue
text: Inside the New York Times photo archives, known as the "morgue," the filmmaker Katerina Cizek and the archivist Jeff Roth discuss the making of "A Short History of the Highrise."

headline: Show Is Back at Carnegie, but Without a Settlement
text: A concert at Carnegie Hall by the American Symphony Orchestra went on as scheduled Thursday night, a day after a strike by union stagehands caused the cancellation of the hall’s gala opening concert, which had been scheduled for Wednesday evening.

headline: Can You Read People’s Emotions?
text: Are you tuned in to the emotions of others? Or have you been accused of being insensitive?

headline: For Better Social Skills, Scientists Recommend a Little Chekhov
text: Say you are getting ready for a blind date or a job interview. What should you do? Besides shower and shave, of course, it turns out you should read — but not just anything. Something by Chekhov or Alice Munro will help you navigate new social territory better than a potboiler by Danielle Steel.

headline: Both Men and Women Should ‘Uncover’ Family Responsibilities at Work
text: Of course people cover up aspects of themselves on the job. The workplace is generally no place for a rehash of a drinking binge or to flaunt your Axl Rose tattoo (depending, of course, on the workplace). But when people cover up their families’ needs, they’re putting family responsibility in the category of “things we don’t talk about at work,” and the results are wide reaching.

headline: Manning Has Time to Hit Right Notes
text: Eli Manning might have made one too many rap videos in the offseason, but William C. Rhoden says Manning is the perfect quarterback to lead the Giants out of their early season funk.

headline: What to Do With Your Retirement Plan if You Change Jobs
text: Kya Gream, 25, recently started a new job as a medical office assistant in Champaign, Ill. Her old employer sent her a thick packet about her options for rolling over her retirement plan, but she has not taken the time yet to digest the information, since it looks a bit daunting.

headline: Novel by Michael Hastings to Be Published Posthumously
text: Michael Hastings, the journalist and author, had written a novel based on his own life before he was killed in a car crash in June.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: Manning Has Time to Hit Right Notes
text: Eli Manning might have made one too many rap videos in the off-season, but Manning is the perfect quarterback to lead the Giants out of their funk.

headline: ‘Streetcar’ From Another Era
text: That Blanche DuBois — what a cutup!

headline: California Institute of Technology Tops English Magazine’s University Rankings
text: The California Institute of Technology has been ranked the best university in the world by the Times Higher Education magazine of London for the third year in a row, leaving Harvard University and Oxford University tied in second place.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

headline: San Francisco Ballet Reaches Agreement With Dancers’ Union
text: The San Francisco Ballet has resolved its dispute with its dancers, the ballet company and the executive director of the dancers’ union confirmed on Thursday. On Wednesday, the dancers voted “significantly” in favor of accepting the Ballet’s offer, said Alan Gordon, the executive director of the American Guild of Musical Artists. The company’s planned New York tour, which includes performances at Lincoln Center, will go ahead as planned, he and Ballet officials said.

headline: Obama Will Not Unilaterally Raise Debt Limit
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will not invoke a constitutional amendment to unilaterally increase the nation’s debt limit if  an  impasse with House Republicans causes that ceiling to be breached Oct. 17, his spokesman said.

headline: Papa’s Kitchen
text: Inside the tiny Filipino restaurant in Woodside, Queens, where it’s karaoke night every night.

headline: Listen Up | The Fiery, Fashion-Forward Stylings of Iggy Azalea
text: The trash-talking Australian MC Iggy Azalea knows that her modelesque, fashion-forward appearance is at odds with her persona. “It’s just easier to be aggressive than to play nice,” she said with a laugh. The 23-year-old, who dropped out of high school and moved from the small town of Mallumbimby, New South Wales, to Miami when she was 16, broke out in 2011 with a pair of explicit videos that caught the attention of the rapper T.I., now her mentor, who appears on Azalea’s new EP, “Change Your Life” (out Oct. 8 from Island Def Jam). A remix of the title track by DJ Shift Key has its premiere here. Azalea says she’s still getting used to the experience of being remixed. “It’s like changing a hair color,” she said. “It’s nice, but it takes some getting used to.”

headline: Closing the Government to Save Face
text: Marlin Stutzman was, until today, a little-known Republican back-bencher, representing northeast Indiana in the House. But with just one off-message statement that he was quickly forced to retract, he became the prominent public face of the House Republicans who are refusing to re-open the United States government.

headline: Sing for Your Dinner
text: “Purple Haze” crashes from the speakers as stingrays flap languidly across the flat-screen TV. The singer, leaning over the rubble of his dinner (monumental pig hooves, broken crab shells), nails every throwaway whoop. The crowd, if that’s what you can call three tables, erupts.

headline: Exploring the Challenges and Opportunities in the New Communication Climate
text: I just returned from my first visit to Japan, which was limited to a small slice of Tokyo, a megacity offering a dizzying mix of ancient and modern, exuberant consumption and reflective modesty. I was there to speak at an annual forum on the environment organized by the Asahi Shimbun newspaper.*

headline: Car Chase, White House to Capitol, Has Fatal End
text: WASHINGTON — A woman with a young child was shot to death after turning her vehicle into a weapon on Thursday afternoon, ramming her way through barriers outside the White House and on Capitol Hill.

headline: A Tortilla Trove Inspired by Street Food
text: Homemade corn tortillas — supple, tender, pleasantly chewy and with a deeply satisfying flavor — bear little resemblance to the packaged discs sold in supermarkets. Fortunately for those of us without a tortilla maker, they are being served seven days a week, hot off the press, at Fresco, a Mexican restaurant in the Savin Rock area of West Haven.

headline: Warhol Death and Disaster Work to Be Sold by Sotheby’s
text: After Christie’s announced that “Balloon Dog (Orange),” Jeff Koons’s 10-foot-high sculpture resembling a child’s giant party favor, would be the star of its Nov. 12 postwar and contemporary-art auction, it started an international advertising campaign featuring the lovable pooch. The auction house also sent gushing e-mails to its top clients that read, “The Stage Is Set to Make History.”

headline: For Med Students, Love From the Drug Rep
text: In the social and culinary wasteland that was residency training, it had been easy for Cheryl, a bubbly brunette in her mid-30s, to become our den mother. She never tired of listening to our grousing, had unerring taste in take-out, made it a point to come to our parties when invited and every so often brought in a plate of her homemade brownies.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: In the latest installment of “Before and After,” four book designers discuss recent examples of their work. Each designer shared early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

headline: In Louisiana, a Craft Brew Tour
text: Louisiana recently introduced a new craft brewery trail, aimed to complement the state’s rich culinary and music tourism.

headline: Trimmings: Paris Fashion Week
text: Accessories from the Chanel, Hermès, Valentino, Chloé spring shows, and more.

headline: A Hotel Room With 140 Characters
text: First there was vacation.

headline: When Israel Stepped Back From the Brink
text: NEXT week is the 40th anniversary of the Yom Kippur War, perhaps the most traumatic moment in Israel’s history. On Oct. 7, 1973 — the second day of the war — Israel’s borders along the Suez Canal in the south and the Golan Heights in the north collapsed under a massive assault by a coalition of Arab armies. Israel was caught unprepared.

headline: ‘If You Are Normal, You Search for Mushrooms’
text: What is it with Russians and their mushroom hunts?

headline: Want to Go to the Olympics? Don’t Tarry
text: Questions about the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, abound. Some people wonder whether the construction of the Olympic Park and other infrastructure in the resort city along the Black Sea will be completed when the Games begin on Feb. 7 (or will be worth the expected price tag of $50 billion). Others question the ethics of attending an event in a nation that recently passed a law that is widely interpreted as an effort to restrict open advocacy of homosexuality.

headline: 'Only'
text: Joseph J. Lhota's first television ad for the general election campaign focused on some of the similarities between him and his opponent, Bill de Blasio.

headline: Fighting Between Rebels Intensifies Over a Strategic Town in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A group of powerful rebel brigades in northern Syria is struggling to defuse an armed standoff pitting insurgents against an affiliate of Al Qaeda for control of a strategic town near the Turkish border.

headline: 'Everyone'
text: The first general election ad from the de Blasio campaign features excerpts from the candidate's primary night speech.

headline: Russia Evacuates Embassy in Libya After Attack
text: MOSCOW — The Russian Foreign Ministry said Thursday that it evacuated its embassy in Libya after armed men stormed the complex the day before, apparently seeking revenge for the killing of a Libyan Air Force officer.

headline: The Trip Up the Mountain That Left 11 Dead
After Fraud, Regulators Go After a Bank
text: You can’t run a Ponzi scheme without a bank.

headline: Now Screening | The King of Modern Longboarding Looks Back
text: The surf legend Joel Tudor has appeared in more than 100 surf films, but “The Ductumentary,” a documentary short presented by Vans that will have its premiere on Monday, is the first one he’s been involved with making. It’s a portrait of the Duct Tape Invitational Series, an unorthodox longboarding contest that Tudor, the two-time longboarding world champ, started in 2010 as an antidote to the Association of Professional Surfing’s longboard competition circuit. At 25 minutes, the documentary is equal parts surfer porn and examination of Tudor’s roots and impact on the sport.

headline: A Treacherous Trip Through the Mind of a Spy
text: Finn and Parker are not just another patient and therapist facing off in a dreary institutional office. They both work for the C.I.A., and they both have significant secrets to keep. But then that’s how they were trained.

headline: Forgotten Fabergé Comes Out of the Attic
text: Russian royals loved to collect figurines of their subjects. The Fabergé workshops produced about 50 sculptures in semiprecious stones and gold representing peasants, servants and the occasional Gypsy singer and street sweeper.

headline: The Writer and Man, Evermore
text: Edgar Allan Poe, among the unluckiest and most misunderstood of writers, is the subject of a tasteful, thoughtful exhibition that opens on Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum — about 100 years too late to do his reputation much good. Among Poe’s misfortunes is that many of his American contemporaries found his work morbid and unreadable. In some ways, he was the Mickey Rourke or Jerry Lewis of 19th-century letters, better appreciated in France, by writers like Baudelaire and Mallarmé, than he was at home.

headline: Visiting a Forgotten Nest of Early European Melody
text: MUSICIANS who specialize in early music might take umbrage at the suggestion that the major works of the German, Italian, French and English repertories have been thoroughly picked over. Yet in recent seasons, there has been a restlessness among these players that has led them to investigate less traveled works by composers from Spain, Latin America and other countries that were largely overlooked in the early-music boom’s first few decades.

headline: Development Comes With Downsides in Cambodia
text: Kalyanee Mam’s documentary “A River Changes Course” has won several prizes at film festivals, and deservedly so. Her intimate portrait of three Cambodian families struggling to maintain their ways of life amid environmental degradation caused by development is a beautiful example of the form. Instead of delving into the politics of their plight, Ms. Mam delivers a universal story.

headline: Colorful Guests Around the Plaza
text: COMING of age in San Antonio in the 1970s and ’80s, the artist Aaron Curry knew nothing about opera or ballet — or fine art, for that matter. His preferred entertainment was “Scooby-Doo” and “Jonny Quest” cartoons, “Star Trek” episodes and Iron Maiden heavy-metal music. “I grew up watching TV,” he said one afternoon in the shade of Lincoln Center’s leafy London plane trees. “I’d sleep with it on.”

headline: Giant Hornets Kill Dozens in China
text: SHANGHAI — Swarms of giant hornets have killed 42 people in Shaanxi Province and injured more than 1,600 in recent months, according to Xinhua, the official news agency. Government officials have yet to figure out why their attacks have been so widespread and deadly.

headline: Uncaging the Cage Fighter Within
text: ALTHOUGH New York still bans live professional mixed martial arts competitions, that regulation has no bearing on training. And this year the Ultimate Fighting Championship — the sport’s biggest promoter — opened its first gym in New York City.

headline: Advice From Elders Rivets a Couple on the Path to Marriage
text: One way to hit a conversational dead-end at a dinner is for a couple to gush over an unusual shared hobby. “We’re just really into brewing craft kvass right now,” they might announce, while giving each other mincing grins. “We’ve never felt better. And you would not believe the varieties!” It may be difficult for two so enmeshed in their own private world to realize that not everyone shares their enthusiasm.

headline: Victim of Military Hazing to Be Immortalized in Opera
text: On Oct. 3, 2011, Pvt. Danny Chen, a 19-year-old Chinese-American soldier from New York City who had been hazed and racially taunted by fellow soldiers, climbed into a guard tower on a military base in Afghanistan and killed himself with a gunshot to the head.

headline: Swimming With White Horses Away From the Battlefield
text: It’s difficult to know how to categorize “Vikingdom,” an English-language Malaysian epic starring a Briton (Craig Fairbrass) and an accentless Aussie (Dominic Purcell) as Vikings battling the god Thor (Conan Stevens, from “Game of Thrones”).

headline: The Thinking Person’s Guide to Elizabeth Gilbert
text: The magazine’s profile of Elizabeth Gilbert a couple of weeks ago not only drew comments about that author’s well-known book, “Eat, Pray, Love,” but it also instigated a debate about readers’ own intellects.

headline: BRIC House Celebrates Opening Weekend
text: Since it was founded in 1979, the annual Celebrate Brooklyn! music festival in Prospect Park — the strains of which the Miser has been known to enjoy, cold beverage in hand, as they stream through the living room window on summer nights — has been the primary public face of BRIC, an arts and technology incubator operating out of modest headquarters in a former vaudeville playhouse.

headline: Video of Police Chase and Eyewitness Reports of Shooting Near U.S. Capitol
text: Jordan Sekulow, executive director of the American Center for Law and Justice, was in his office at Second Street and Constitution Avenue Northeast in Washington when gunshots erupted outside, prompting a lockdown at the nearby United States Capitol about 2:30 p.m. Thursday.

headline: ‘Robert Motherwell: Early Collages’
text: A look at the new show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

headline: A Hit Maker by Any Name
text: Directed by William Hechter and Peter Miller, “A K A Doc Pomus” shines a light on the soulful, big-hearted man behind many magic moments in popular music. Born Jerome Felder, he called himself Doc Pomus, and, hobbled by childhood polio, he reached down deep, bringing forth hundreds of songs, some of them among the most poignant pop ever written. This static documentary portrait relies on the usual panning over photos and tag-team interviews, but the format, like the radio length of a song, doesn’t get in the way of its subject’s heart.

headline: Wheelies: The Pit of Vipers Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Anything for a Laugh
text: Babli is a lovable lout, a cocky car thief in Delhi with loud shirts and the inevitable heart of gold. But that’s not enough for a Bollywood hero. Babli’s also an orphan who gives his ill-gotten gains to the orphanage where he grew up and still lives, sharing a bed with his sidekick, T2, as in “Terminator 2.”

headline: Your Essential Thanksgiving Recipes
text: Updated | Nov. 7, 2013 We are no longer taking suggestions for essential Thanksgiving recipes, but we would love to keep hearing your thoughts and comments on dishes you consider Thanksgiving favorites. Feel free to continue posting in the comments section below.

headline: Stability, a Real Suburban Curve Ball
text: Last week, on the season premiere of “Eastbound & Down,” Kenny Powers was back, sort of. A schlub in a company-issued shirt and a would-be Michael Scott for a boss, he was a shell of the boorish ex-big leaguer he once was. The first words he uttered, sitting in his car on the way to work, were, “Love NPR.” He might as well be dead.

headline: Scenes From Capitol Hill During Lockdown
text: The Capitol was locked down briefly on Thursday afternoon after shots were fired in front of the building.

headline: Twitter I.P.O. Filing Opens Books on High-Flier
text: Updated, 10 p.m. | SAN FRANCISCO — If Lady Gaga were to send a message to her 40 million followers on Twitter summarizing the company’s debut on Wall Street, it might very well say: “Twitter IPO. Mobile. Born This Way.”

headline: At the S.B.A., Disaster Loans Continue, but Little Else
text: For the Small Business Administration, the government shutdown is not as complete as one might think. Nearly 40 percent of the agency’s employees remain on the job, according to a shutdown plan published on the agency’s Web site. But even so, the agency has stopped processing regular small-business loans, leaving would-be borrowers in limbo.

headline: Iran Frees Another Reformer, but Netanyahu Warns Iranians, in Persian, Not to Be ‘Dupes’
text: As Iran released another political prisoner on Thursday, Israel’s prime minister slipped into Persian to suggest that only “sadeloh,” or “dupes,” would be fooled by recent diplomatic overtures from the clerical government in Tehran.

headline: David Adamo
text: Untitled

headline: John Houck: ‘A History of Graph Paper’
text: On Stellar Rays

headline: Jack Whitten
text: Alexander Gray Associates

headline: ‘Design Office With Kim  Gordon — Since 1980’
text: White Columns

headline: Raymond Pettibon: ‘To Wit’
text: David Zwirner

headline: Unzipped
text: Ever since the 40th anniversary of my first novel, ‘Fear of Flying,’ peeped over the horizon, I’ve been thinking a lot about storytelling — why certain stories stick with us and others don’t.

headline: Let’s Read About Sex
text: Writing about sex can be uniquely powerful — and perilous. A group of novelists, memoirists and poets tell us about working blue: what novels first inspired them, what nouns they strive to avoid and who they think writes sex best.

headline: With Shutdown, Questions About Visiting National Forests
text: While closing gates around a national park or monument is relatively simple, closing a forest is not. Newspapers and radio and television news operations around the country are reporting that while offices and facilities within the national forests have been closed, the land is still open to outdoor enthusiasts.

headline: New York City Opera Files for Bankruptcy
text: New York City Opera, which was founded 70 years ago to help bring opera to the masses, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Thursday after an urgent $7 million fund-raising appeal fell short last month.

headline: He’s Back for More Blood
text: When insects are the best thing in your movie, it’s probably time to retire.

headline: The Numbers Behind Twitter
text: Updated to include international revenue statistics.

headline: Twitter’s Letter to Shareholders Is Short and Lightweight
text: Twitter’s ancestors, Google and Facebook, used their initial public offering filings to write long letters about the high-minded philosophies of their companies. But Twitter’s letter in its filing, which was made public on Thursday, was much more succinct — perhaps fitting for a company that has popularized short bursts of information.

headline: A Painter’s Cut-and-Paste Prequel
text: Abstract Expressionism is overrated. And it wasn’t initially a movement or style at all. It was a bunch of unalike artists, some great, some not, who shared a city, a war, some ideas and a bar, circa 1940. Pretty much everything else, including a fecund two-decade fad for soulful painting that grew from that moment, was largely a product of marketing and myth spinning.

headline: Cuba in America, Onstage and Unbound
text: The pianist Michele Rosewoman’s long-running project New Yor-Uba, which she revived for a new album and two nights of performances at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola, still looks good on paper and sounds better in practice.

headline: Cowboy With a Cause
text: “People were telling me it couldn’t be done,” the craggy, white-haired man in the denim shirt says. “And that’s the wrong thing to say to a cowboy.”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: baby smells, health insurance and food-borne illness. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Shots Fired Near the Capitol
text: Law enforcement officers shot a woman during a car chase from the White House.

headline: Vigneault Still Learning About His Rangers as Season Opens
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Alain Vigneault is about to start his 12th season as an N.H.L. coach, but of course this time is different. After the morning skate ahead of the Rangers’ opener against the Phoenix Coyotes here Thursday, he talked about how he felt as he prepared to coach his first regular-season game with the Blueshirts.

headline: Huddled Masses, Studiously Eyed
text: With so much contemporary art photography devoted to the slippery nature of photography itself, it’s a good corrective to regularly visit the International Center of Photography, an institution founded on faith in the medium as a window on empirical reality. Among the non-navel-gazing shows on view there are a pair devoted to the pioneering documentarian Lewis Hine (1874-1940), whose subjects included immigrants arriving at Ellis Island, children working in factories and coal mines, families living in Lower East Side tenements, black Americans and men building skyscrapers.

headline: Car Chase and Gunshots in the Capital
text: Car Chase and Gunshots at Capitol Hill

headline: Touching on Modern, Hip-Hop and Tap
text: Every Fall for Dance program — this year, especially — shows marvelously mind-widening diversity. Most dancegoers have relatively narrow tastes, but the festival ignores that. Each year, it keeps drawing our attention to things we hadn’t seen, didn’t know, might have missed, new and old; it loves to place dissimilar genres side by side. Its every performance sells out and is lustily cheered; I ardently hope that it leads people to see examples of dance they’ve never visited before.

headline: A Shooting Star Lights Up Manhattan
text: It was only 20 months ago, but seems far more distant: that stretch in February 2012 when Jeremy Lin, a relative unknown from the end of the bench, took over as a guard for the New York Knicks and promptly tore through the N.B.A. He scored more points in his first five starts than any other player in nearly 40 years, peaking with 38 against the Los Angeles Lakers (Kobe Bryant managed only 34 that night).

headline: Back in the Blue Saddle, for a Gallop to Abstraction
text: New Yorkers might be forgiven for greeting “Vasily Kandinsky: From Blaue Reiter to the Bauhaus, 1910-1925,” at the Neue Galerie, with a shrug and a distinct feeling of déjà vu. Wasn’t it just three years ago now that the Guggenheim mounted a full retrospective, a delirium-inducing helix of Kandinskys?

headline: ‘Extreme Measures’
text: Photos from the Chris Burden show at the New Museum.

headline: The Intoxicating, Tradition-Steeped Charm of New Orleans
text: With its last-frontier appeal and magical mixed bag of culture, New Orleans is quietly luring a circle of expats, who find an evolving city that’s just the right amount of undone.

headline: Living and Killing in a Materialist China
text: A blistering fictionalized tale straight out of China, “A Touch of Sin” is at once monumental and human scale. A story of lives rocked by violence, it has the urgency of a screaming headline but one inscribed with visual lyricism, emotional weight and a belief in individual rights. You can feel the conviction of its director, Jia Zhang-ke — one of the few filmmakers of any nationality who weighs the impact of social and political shifts on people — in every shot. In “A Touch of Sin,” the world isn’t an amorphous backdrop, pretty scenery for private dramas, it is a stage on which men and women struggle to fulfill basic moral obligations, including recognizing one another’s humanity.

headline: Andy Warhol Schlepped Here
text: All the art in the photographer Christopher Makos’s modest four-room apartment in a six-story walk-up building in the West Village is by friends or fellow scene-makers, a roll call of the New York art world of the ’70s and ’80s: Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman, Jeff Koons, Donald Baechler, Keith Haring. Mr. Makos lives much as he did in that era, a bohemian who brushes his teeth in the kitchen sink because his bathroom has only a toilet and a cast-iron tub.

headline: What I Love | Christopher Makos
text: Mr. Makos West Village walk-up is hung with art by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman and others.

headline: The Stuff of Building and Destroying
text: “Chris Burden: Extreme Measures” at the New Museum is a superb survey, but also a kind of transfiguration. It liberates the Los Angeles-based Mr. Burden from the clutches of history, expanding and rebalancing our understanding of his art.

headline: One Holds the Cards, the Other Is Bluffing
text: In “Runner Runner,” directed by Brad Furman from a script by Brian Koppelman and David Levien, Ben Affleck and Justin Timberlake face off, cleft chin to cleft chin, in a battle for ... well, what, exactly? The attention of the audience? Of Gemma Arterton, who plays virtually the only female character in the movie not employed as a hooker or a stripper? Huge sums of money? All of the above, or whatever.

headline: Plain or Painted? In Any Case, Unfaded
text: We now live in a culture in which everything must be original. We have to strip the paint off our oak paneling. Our architecture has to look as if it had always been there. Our jeans have to be faded. But original can turn around and bite you, as shown in the perplexing case of 90 Macdougal Street, a house in the Macdougal-Sullivan Gardens complex, between Houston and Bleecker Streets.

headline: Comedy Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Leader of Cancer Center Works on Changes After Feedback
text: HOUSTON — Ronald DePinho, the president of the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, part of the University of Texas, becomes animated when he talks about his ambitious plans in leading the institute’s efforts to combat the disease.

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Is There Really a Market for That?
text: “Concussion,” written and directed by Stacie Passon, deals with the age-old challenge of keeping that special spark alive. How do you find meaning in lives that seem to consist of routine, much less appreciate desire in its complexity and vividness?

headline: Hurdles for Condo Buyers
text: In New York, buyers intent on getting a co-op know to brace themselves for the notoriously invasive approval process. But increasingly, condominium buyers are also being asked to fill out lengthy applications and provide detailed financial information to buildings’ governing boards.

headline: Push for a Shift Could Affect Governor’s Race
text: Why would anyone want Debra Medina to run for governor as an independent?

headline: A Japanese Welcome, and Korean-Style Barbecue
text: With close to 800 locations in Asia and the United States, and three outposts already in Manhattan, could Westchester County be far behind? Apparently not. Last June, Gyu-Kaku settled into White Plains, a bold move in an area jammed with restaurants offering every culinary variety — or so one would think. With its very Korean spin on Japanese barbecue, Gyu-Kaku has managed to bring new and different tastes to the city center’s growing dining scene.

headline: Game Firms Get Great Tax Deals, Maybe Too Great
text: In the lobby of the Twisted Pixel Games studio in Austin, a futuristic motorcycle welcomes visitors with an electric blue glow. The robotic motorcycle stars in LocoCycle, a new video game produced almost entirely in Texas.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Wedding? Uncork the Rancor
text: “A.C.O.D.,” an unfunny comedy about a guy mooning over his parents’ divorce decades later, is so eager to please it’s hard to hate. But it’s sluggish even at 87 minutes, clichéd and gives you nothing of interest to look at other than some familiar faces. Early on, during one of its inertly staged and shot conversations between two people — the kind that switches between over-the-shoulder shots, the performers frozen on their marks and drained of animation — one of the character’s words didn’t match his mouth. The words just kept coming, and so did the perfunctory rest of it.

headline: Jazz Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Sell Them Trees, Then Steal Them Blind
text: The wry tone of “All Is Bright,” a sardonic, smart screwball comedy that teams Paul Giamatti and Paul Rudd as professional thieves trying to “go straight” by selling Christmas trees in New York City, is defined by its droll soundtrack of holiday favorites. Familiar carols are reduced to bouncy instrumental elevator music with a hint of jazz and a smirk on its face.

headline: Dance Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Majority Disapprove of Shutting Down Government Over Health Law
text: A wide majority of Americans disapprove of shutting down the federal government over differences about the 2010 health care law, including a majority of those who oppose the law, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 4-10
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Fleeing Her Troubles for a Host of New Ones
text: A ballad of photographs, music and memories — both the old we savor and the new we consciously construct — “I Used to Be Darker” picks at the seams of an unraveling family and watches to see what will happen.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bulgaria. Italy, Nigeria and Myanmar.

headline: The Pleasure of Crime
text: The question that I am most often asked about Ponzi schemes is “Why?” Didn’t the person behind the scheme know that it was inevitable he would be caught? That he would be sent to prison?

headline: Obama on Government Shutdown
text: The president addressed people at the M. Luis Construction Company in Rockville, Md.

headline: Dallas, 1963, Redux
text: “Parkland,” Peter Landesman’s taut but unsatisfying docudrama about the Kennedy assassination, is mercifully short. For the events depicted, no matter how familiar, still hurt. Watching the movie is like enduring dental surgery without anesthesia. You clench your fists, suck in your breath and remind yourself that the pain will end. And when it does, sooner than expected, you sigh with relief.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 4-10
text: LIVE BAT ENCOUNTERS

headline: Fighting School Bullies With a Camera
text: Remarkable as much for its insights as for its audacity, “The Dirties” approaches school violence with a comic veneer that slowly shades into deep darkness. Capturing the downward spiral of Matt (played by the director, Matt Johnson), an excitable high schooler terrorized by bullies and obsessed with bloodthirsty movies, this found-footage exercise unfolds with shocking credibility.

headline: Twitter’s Biggest Risk? Losing You
text: Even though Twitter’s staff has ballooned to about 2,000 employees, having talented workers isn’t nearly as crucial for the company as having quality users.

headline: Her Huddled Masses? They Must Settle for a 47-Foot Imitation
text: A New York vacation is not a New York vacation without a visit to the Statue of Liberty, and so, on Thursday afternoon, a tourist from Kuwait strolled up to Lady Liberty’s plinth and turned toward the camera, smiling broadly. His wife took a photo with her iPhone, tilting it up to make sure she captured the entire statue, crown to toe.

headline: A Feminist’s Daughter Finds Love in the Kitchen
text: On Mother’s Day last spring, my 10-year-old daughter listed some things she loves about having me as her mother. The first two surprised me: “You make my lunch most days,” she began, “and you make dinner.” Other observations followed, including that I am “huggy” and “smart.” But first came the kitchen.

headline: Telling Them Not to Take a Hike
text: We are planning a hiking trip with three other couples. One of them is now asking to bring their two adult children, who are in their early 20s. We would prefer the children not come; they would inevitably change the dynamic of the trip. So we exchanged e-mails on the subject with their parents. We wrote, “We assumed this was an old geezers’ trip.” Our friends replied, “Assumed or preferred?” How should we respond and still keep the peace?

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 4-10
text: Literary Events (Friday through Sunday) The literary smorgasbord known as The New Yorker Festival is offering ample servings of readings, discussions and screenings with writers, actors and others, at several locations. Online sales are closed for many events, but tickets to some notable ones are still available.

headline: Love Triangle, With Mom in the Middle
text: Set in a vibrant Puerto Rican community in the Bronx, “Babygirl” is a gently knowing coming-of-age tale about the dangers of combining intellectual precociousness with emotional immaturity.

headline: Making Life, and Your Cat, Sit Still
text: When Mimi Vang Olsen is commissioned to paint a portrait of a home and its inhabitants, her goal is not simply to record the color of the walls and the style of the sofa. Her aim is to produce a small, richly textured domestic drama, studded with the tiny but telling details that reveal the true nature of those who call the setting home and the intricate emotional relationships that bind them.

headline: Pet Portraitist
text: Mimi Vang Olsen, a painter of cats, dogs and domestic scenes, works out of a Hudson Street storefront.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Stress Brings Out a Real Monster in Him
text: The premise of “Bad Milo!,” Jacob Vaughan’s devilish comedy about a mild-mannered accountant with an angry critter lodged in his colon, is not nearly as gross as it sounds. For one thing, the anal intruder — which resembles a hairless troll doll — is rather cute. And for another, Mr. Vaughan is more eager to inspire giggles than gag reflexes.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Twitter’s Evolution From Side Project to Wall Street Hopeful
text: “People are at the heart of Twitter.”

headline: A Heartbreaking Loss for One and All
text: Inspired by a viral YouTube video and deftly directed by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason (“Designing Women”), “Bridegroom” is about an unmarried gay couple in their 20s and what happens when one of them dies. That’s the simple summary of this simply told but exceptionally moving documentary.

headline: Taking the Stigma Out of Dyslexia
text: “Dislecksia: The Movie,” directed by Harvey Hubbell V, is an informative, entertaining survey about what dyslexia is and how to treat it. A central theme is that the condition, estimated to affect up to 35 million Americans, is not a learning disability, but a learning difference.

headline: Elvin R. Heiberg III, General Who Took Blame for Hurricane Katrina Failures, Dies at 81
text: Lt. Gen. Elvin R. Heiberg III, who rose to the top of the United States Army Corps of Engineers in the 1980s and decades later expressed regret for failing to fight hard enough to build floodgates that he believed might have protected New Orleans from Hurricane Katrina, died on Sept. 27 in Arlington, Va. He was 81.

headline: Phantom Crises (Wonkish)
text: Simon Wren-Lewis is puzzled by a Ken Rogoff column that sorta-kinda defends Cameron’s austerity policies. His puzzlement, which I share, comes at several levels. But I want to focus on just one thing: Rogoff’s assertion that Britain could have faced a southern Europe-style crisis, with a loss of investor confidence driving up interest rates and plunging the economy into a deep slump.

headline: Newcomer’s Rite of Passage
text: Five people rehearsing in an otherwise vacant dance studio: That pitch may not appeal to everyone, but fans of the movement arts and ensemble acting will appreciate the possibilities. Yet few of those possibilities are explored with any depth in “Five Dances,” a promising though static new film that never leaves its taciturn shadows for a single emotionally gripping moment.

headline: Breaking From Recent Tech Tradition, Twitter Forgoes Multiple Stock Classes
text: Twitter’s initial public offering highlights many of the social network’s differences from rivals like Facebook. But the company’s prospectus highlights one unexpected change: the lack of multiple classes of stock.

headline: In Store | Old-World Luxury, For Sale Downtown
text: After doing everything from curation to publicity for design-world stars like Thom Mayne and Dror Benshetrit and luxury goods companies like LVMH, Melanie Courbet has ventured out on her own to indulge her passion for craftsmanship. At Atelier Courbet, her new SoHo gallery and shop in a 19th-century building on Mott Street, which opens Saturday, she will offer contemporary design by companies and workshops that use Old World techniques to produce everything from spoons to bicycles.

headline: Friends Come Together for an Intervention
text: Can’t a guy just get away for a few months at his family’s old cabin upstate? Do his city friends have to show up unannounced, en masse, all concerned and overhelpful?

headline: The Twitter Wealthy
text: Twitter’s public filing for an initial public offering says it has over 100 million daily users. It also has a few very lucky takers.

headline: Something Creepy This Way Comes
text: A girl proves to be a pain to her relatives in “Nothing Left to Fear,” a horror trifle about a minister’s family discovering that its new rural neighborhood is a passageway to a demonic petri dish — or something otherwise Hell-like. Dan Bramford (James Tupper of “Revenge”) and his wife, Wendy (Anne Heche), want only to assimilate into their congregation. But their adolescent daughters have boys on their minds, and that, of course, means jeopardy.

headline: Board Battle Leads to Exit of Telecom Italia Chief
text: LONDON — Franco Bernabè resigned as chief executive of Telecom Italia on Thursday after he clashed with some of the European telecommunications company’s major investors.

headline: Big Canadian Carrier Shuns New BlackBerry Phone
text: Rogers Communications, based in Toronto and one of the first carriers in the world to offer devices from BlackBerry, will not sell the ailing smartphone maker’s new flagship Z30 phone, the president of its wireless unit said on Thursday.

headline: Wall Street Seeks to Soothe, While Preparing for Trouble
text: Wall Street is preparing for the government to bounce its first check.

headline: Official’s Big Salary in California City May Lead to Prison
text: LOS ANGELES — Robert Rizzo, the former city administrator of Bell, Calif., accused of looting millions from city coffers, pleaded no contest to all 69 charges against him on Thursday, prosecutors announced.

headline: Armenian Church, Survivor of the Ages, Faces Modern Hurdles
text: ECHMIADZIN, Armenia — In this ancient city, tucked in a valley that has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, King Tiridates III converted to Christianity and declared Armenia to be the world’s first Christian state. The year was 301, more than a decade before the Emperor Constantine put Rome on a similar path.

headline: Tunisian Ex-Soccer Player Extradited
text: A former Tunisian soccer player who was sentenced to a decade in prison in Belgium in 2003 for planning a suicide bombing for Al Qaeda against a military base there — which is also used by NATO — has been extradited to the United States to face similar charges in an American court, the Justice Department announced Thursday. The player, Nizar Trabelsi, 43, was indicted under seal in 2006 in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Prosecutors say he traveled to Afghanistan in the spring of 2001 and met with Osama bin Laden and, later, Muhammed Atef, a chief military planner for the terrorist group. The indictment accuses him of obtaining chemicals in Europe to build a 1,000-kilogram bomb and joining others to scout the military base, Kleine Brogel Air Base, as a potential target for a suicide attack.

headline: Ballmer’s Bonus Shrinks on Weakness of Windows
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft‘s board of directors has again penalized the company’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, for the company’s performance by giving him a smaller bonus than he was eligible for.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter’s I.P.O. Filing, and Adobe Hacked
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: The Religious Dorm at the Public University
text: TROY, Ala. — There are many clues that life at the newest residence hall on the campus of Troy University is not centered on parties and beer.

headline: FIFA Official Urges Worker Protections
text: ZURICH — A vice president of FIFA on Thursday called for global soccer’s governing body to insist on minimum standards of worker protection on World Cup projects amid allegations of abuse that have troubled construction projects for the 2022 finals in Qatar.

headline: Furloughs Alter Routines for President’s Staff
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly before the federal government shut down at 12:01 a.m. Tuesday, a small group of top White House officials huddled in the West Wing for what turned out to be a discussion of critical importance: how to run the place.

headline: Europe Threatens Gazprom With Antitrust Action
text: The European Union’s top antitrust enforcer on Thursday threatened to formally charge the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom with restricting trade and price gouging, raising the stakes in a two-year investigation that has already created tensions with Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: The Moment a Photographer Became a Historian
text: Bill Eppridge, who was best known for his haunting photograph of a busboy kneeling beside the mortally wounded Senator Robert F. Kennedy, died Thursday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 75.

headline: Campaigning Again, for Obama to Say ‘No’
text: WASHINGTON — Elijah Zarlin was handcuffed outside the White House two years ago for joining in weeks of protests against the Keystone XL pipeline. His arrest would have been an ordinary rite of Washington, except for one thing: Mr. Zarlin had been an aide at the headquarters of Barack Obama’s first presidential campaign.

headline: Garment District Isn’t Just for Fashion Anymore
text: Manhattan’s garment district is undergoing a renaissance, with the recent sale and refurbishment of many office buildings and an influx of tenants from media, advertising, entertainment, technology and other, nonfashion industries.

headline: Russia: A Legal Victory for Kasparov
text: Garry Kasparov, the chess champion and opposition politician, on Thursday won a ruling against the Russian government in the European Court of Human Rights for an illegal arrest at a rally in Moscow in 2007. In the past, Mr. Kasparov has been arrested on pretexts like an allegation that he bit a police officer’s finger while protesting last year against the conviction of members of the band Pussy Riot. The court found that the 2007 arrest was “disproportionate to the aim of maintaining public order” and ordered Russian authorities pay Mr. Kasparov about $13,500 in damages.

headline: In Autumn, a Taste of the Season
text: Wanda Jacobson understands the appeal of fresh wood-pressed apple cider on a crisp autumn afternoon. What continually surprises her is what people will do to get it.

headline: Russia: More Charges for Greenpeace
text: Russian prosecutors have now pressed charges of piracy against the entire crew of the Greenpeace International ship the Arctic Sunrise, including the captain, Peter Willcox; the ship’s cook and doctor; and two freelance journalists who were among the 30 people aboard last month when Russian authorities seized the vessel during a protest in the Arctic Ocean. The prosecutors charged 16 people on Thursday and 14 on Wednesday. The charges carry a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison upon conviction. The activists said their attempts to scale the side of a Russian oil platform were meant to call attention to the environmental hazards of drilling in icy northern waters.

headline: U.S. Accuses 13 Hackers in Web Attacks
text: Thirteen members of a hacking collective that calls itself Anonymous were indicted on Thursday on charges that they conspired to coordinate attacks against prominent Web sites.

headline: Weary but Spirited, the Well-Traveled Rays Roll Into Fenway
text: BOSTON — The Tampa Bay Rays arrived here just after 4 a.m. Thursday, their fourth city and second country in five days. They were exhausted but satisfied, having won three straight win-or-go-home games.

headline: Britain: Online Surveillance Challenged
text: Three British organizations said Thursday that they had filed a legal challenge in the European Court of Human Rights to the online surveillance programs of the British spy agency the Government Communications Headquarters. The groups are seeking to have the court declare the collection of metadata, including e-mails and social media messages, in secret programs revealed by the American intelligence analyst Edward J. Snowden to be an illegal breach of the right to privacy. The case, financed through donations, has been brought by English PEN, the Open Rights Group and Big Brother Watch, as well as by a German activist. The government said that a similar challenge could not be brought in domestic courts, but that a complaint could be made only to the Investigatory Powers Tribunal, which does not act in public.

headline: Jack Dorsey Gave Evan Williams His Voting Power at Twitter
text: Twitter’s financial filing on Thursday raised new questions about the strained relationship between two of its founders.

headline: Boutique Winery Rises to Top Tier
text: Roanoke Vineyards, a boutique winery in its 13th year, has ascended to the top tier of Long Island estates. Its wines are consistently outstanding.

headline: Potential New Leader for Trading Commission Under a Lens
text: As Gary Gensler’s tenure as a Wall Street regulator draws to a close, the White House has begun to vet a senior Treasury Department official as a potential replacement.

headline: U.S. and Israel Share a Goal in Iran Talks, but Not a Strategy
text: JERUSALEM — Fearing that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was on the verge of ordering an airstrike on Iran’s nuclear plants, President Obama sent two emissaries here almost exactly a year ago to stop him. Warning that the White House could not abide an attack in the run-up to the November elections, the Americans persuaded the prime minister to give the newest sanctions time to bite, according to Americans and Israelis familiar with the tense exchanges.

headline: Experts See Potential Ways Out for Obama in Debt Ceiling Maze
text: WASHINGTON — Even as President Obama insists that he would be powerless to save the economy from catastrophe should Congress fail to raise the nation’s debt ceiling, some law professors say he does have options. They may be politically unattractive, unpalatable to the financial markets and subject to legal challenges, these experts say, but these choices are better than failing to live up to the nation’s financial commitments.

headline: Bats and Balls May Need an Introduction
text: The breeze whipping through the air last fall when the Oakland Athletics played the Detroit Tigers had nothing to do with the weather. It came from the Oakland bats, swinging and missing, over and over again.

headline: At Cuban’s Trading Trial, Dispute Over Secrecy of Data
text: DALLAS — Mark Cuban sent out a series of e-mails saying that he had sold his shares in the search engine company Mamma.com because he had received information that the company was about to recruit private investors whose contributions would dilute the value of the public shares, a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer said on Thursday.

headline: Amid Bloodshed in Pakistan, a Stock Exchange Soars
text: LONDON — If the best time to buy, as the old business adage says, is when there is blood on the streets, then Pakistan’s commercial capital, Karachi, offers the ideal investment opportunity.

headline: Wrong Side of History
text: Sarah Palin finally got her death panels — a direct blow from the Republican House. In shutting down the government, leaving 800,000 people without a paycheck and draining the economy of $300 million a day, the Party of Madness also took away last-chance cancer trials for children at the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Q. Which Night Is Trivia Night?
text: Morrison’s seems to have struck a chord with Long Island diners. The restaurant, which opened in June in Plainview, was packed to overflowing on a recent Saturday and was nearly full on a Tuesday, usually one of the slowest nights of the week.

headline: How a Debt Ceiling Crisis Could Do More Harm Than the Shutdown
text: The impasse in Congress this week has overshadowed the fact that the government is fast approaching its borrowing limit — or debt ceiling — later this month. Most economists and investors view the debt ceiling as a much more significant issue for the economy, with the potential to set off a global financial crisis. What is all the concern about? Here is an attempt to answer the basic questions.

headline: Twitter Puts Numbers to Its I.P.O. Talk
text: Millions of users seem to believe that Twitter has value.

headline: The Moderates Who Lighted the Fuse
text: WASHINGTON — THE government shutdown is the work of the so-called kamikaze caucus of about 40 Tea Party Republicans in the House of Representatives. But why is the body of the Republican Party in thrall to its erratic right foot? Maybe the real blame should go to the far more numerous non-Tea Party Republicans, from Speaker John A. Boehner down, who have been unable or unwilling to restrain the radicals.

headline: Why Italians Love Francis
text: ROME — ONE day, as Pope Francis was leaving the Casa Santa Marta, a spartan guesthouse in Vatican City where he lives in preference to the lonely but luxurious papal apartments, he met a bishop waiting for his driver. “Can’t you walk?” the pope smiled.

headline: Reform Turns Real
text: At this point, the crisis in American governance has taken on a life of its own. Some Republicans are now saying openly that they want concessions in return for reopening the government and avoiding default, not because they have any specific policy goals in mind, but simply because they don’t want to feel “disrespected.” And no endgame is in sight.

headline: The Ad Campaign:  De Blasio Not Resting on Laurels
text: Bill de Blasio, New York City’s public advocate and the Democratic nominee for mayor, is running his first campaign commercial of the general election — a documentary-style excerpt from his lofty primary night victory speech. Titled “Everyone,” the 30-second ad began appearing on local network TV across New York City on Thursday.PRODUCER AKPD Message and Media

headline: Frenzy Awaits an Opponent That Has Seen It Before
text: Alex Cobb went to high school in Vero Beach, Fla., but he was born in Boston and remembers enough to know what awaits the Tampa Bay Rays this weekend. Fenway Park has not hosted a playoff game in four years, and the atmosphere should be as charged as it was in Cleveland on Wednesday.

headline: Wendy Davis Enters Race for Texas Governor With a Shorter Speech
text: HALTOM CITY, Tex. — Exactly 100 days after the legislative filibuster that defied the Republican establishment and turned her into a Democratic star, State Senator Wendy Davis announced Thursday that she would run for governor, opening an underdog campaign to lead a state that last sent a Democrat to the governor’s mansion nearly 23 years ago.

headline: Unfair Business in College Sports
text: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is now the sole defendant in a lawsuit that could alter the college sports business model, under which everybody — the N.C.A.A., universities, media companies, coaches — makes money except the student athletes.

headline: Silvio Berlusconi Undone
text: Silvio Berlusconi’s two-decade-long spell over Italian politics seems to have finally broken this week. His attempt to bring down Prime Minister Enrico Letta’s coalition government by withdrawing his party’s support collapsed when many of Mr. Berlusconi’s closest political allies refused to go along.

headline: A Population Betrayed
text: It is outrageous that millions of the poorest people in the country will be denied health insurance because of decisions made mostly by Republican governors and legislators. These people will neither qualify for their state’s Medicaid program for the poor nor for subsidized coverage on new insurance exchanges that are being established in every state by the health care reform law.

headline: Phony Self-Denial in Congress
text: As the government shutdown continues, more members of Congress are making a show of refusing their salaries or donating them to charities. With hundreds of thousands of idled federal workers unpaid and unsure if they might ever be paid, lawmakers are left to making gestures in lieu of doing a more effective job for their $174,000 annual salary, which the Constitution mandates regardless of the shutdown.

headline: Stock Market Is a Bright Spot in Pakistan
text: The Karachi Stock Exchange has risen more than 44 percent in the past 12 months despite rampant violence nationwide.

headline: G.O.P. Elders See Liabilities in Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — The hard-line stance of Republican House members on the government shutdown is generating increasing anger among senior Republican officials, who say the small bloc of conservatives is undermining the party and helping President Obama just as the American people appeared to be losing confidence in him.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Lhota on the Common Ground
text: In his first television advertisement of the general campaign, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor of New York, takes pains to highlight his similarities with his Democratic opponent, Bill de Blasio, who is surging in the polls. The ad ends with a point of contrast that Mr. Lhota hopes will sway voters.

headline: Pirates Break With Past by Playing; Cardinals Relive It by Winning
text: ST. LOUIS — If Tuesday night was a raucous party, with Pittsburgh hosting Cincinnati in the Pirates’ first playoff game in 21 years, the St. Louis Cardinals countered Thursday with stately tradition. Clydesdales clip-clopped around the warning track before the game, and Busch Stadium was awash in its familiar sea of red.

headline: No Trends for Old Men?
text: Is there an age at which a man can no longer pull off certain fashionable looks?

headline: Finance Panel Didn’t Cave
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scissors, Not a Gun
text: To the Editor:

headline: Only a New Penn Station Will Do
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trials in Bangladesh
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pope’s Model for the Church
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is Baseball Still the National Pastime?
Mario Montez, a Warhol Glamour Avatar, Dies at 78
text: Mario Montez, whose glamour and poise as a drag performer elevated him to the heights of avant-garde theater and cinema in the 1960s and made him a fixture in films by Andy Warhol, died on Sept. 26 in Key West, Fla.

headline: Influence of Jackson Verdict Is Limited
text: After finding on Wednesday that the concert promoter A.E.G. Live was not liable in the death of Michael Jackson, members of the jury told reporters that despite their relatively short deliberations — about 13 hours, after a five-month trial — the job was not easy.

headline: Can We See Philosophy? A Dialogue With Ernie Gehr
text: The common currency of philosophy is language. But does it have to be?

headline: Goldman Banker With Year’s Top Tech Quarry
text: Anthony J. Noto, a former Army Ranger and pro-football executive, may seem an odd fit among the cerebral recluses and flashy moneymen of the tech world.

headline: Car Fire a Test for High-Flying Tesla
text: DETROIT — It’s an automaker’s worst nightmare: graphic video footage of one of its cars engulfed in flames after an accident.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 4, 2013
text: “Thank God the research didn’t find that novels increased tooth decay or blocked up your arteries.”

headline: In Leaked Video, Egyptian Army Officers Debate How to Sway News Media
text: CAIRO — A leaked video of senior Egyptian Army officers debating how to influence the news media during the months preceding the military takeover offers a rare glimpse of the anxiety within the institution at the prospect of civilian oversight.

headline: From Left to Right, A’s Maximize Their Lineup
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — If the name had not been used for a film of an entirely different genre, the sequel to “Moneyball” might be called “Platoon.”

headline: Fruit of the Loom Sees Workers in Their Underwear
text: LISTING a new job on LinkedIn typically prompts congratulations from friends and relatives, but 25,000 members of the professional networking platform who change their employment status also are about to get a change of underwear.

headline: Jobs Report Becomes a Casualty of Shutdown
text: On the first Friday morning of almost any other month, from the trading floors of Wall Street to the hushed hallways of the Federal Reserve, all the attention would be focused on two numbers: the latest government estimates for unemployment and job creation.

headline: Finally, It May Be Mattingly’s Moment
text: ATLANTA — He is an oddity of history, a man who has spent 24 years in the storied uniforms of the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers without ever reaching the World Series. Don Mattingly was a superstar who has coached and managed for winning teams. Yet he has never appeared, in any capacity, on the brightest stage.

headline: Decade of Dedication to an Urban Garden
text: Beside a parking lot in Harlem, there is a stash of sun-ripe tomatoes, okra, collard greens, sweet potatoes, strawberries and watermelons just for the asking.

headline: Corrections: October 4, 2013
text: NEW YORK

headline: Holier Than Thou? Oh, She’s Just Getting Started
text: There’s nothing like a death in the family to bring out the worst in people. This unhappy truth is displayed with delectably savage humor in “Bad Jews,” a zesty play by Joshua Harmon that opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater. Tracee Chimo, leading a flawless cast of four in the best comedy of the season to date, gives a ferocious performance as a young Jewish woman, Diana — she prefers to be called by her Hebrew name, Daphna — aggressively fighting to obtain a religious relic left behind by her grandfather.

headline: Good Evening, Heartache, Sit Down

headline: Stand-Out Performances

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: Sergei Belov, a Russian basketball star who led the Soviet national team in its controversial gold medal victory over the United States at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, died on Thursday in Perm, Russia. He was 69.

headline: A Pioneering AIDS Prevention Group Struggles to Stay Relevant

headline: New Trial Ordered for Man Who Helped a Long Island Motivational Speaker Kill Himself
text: The case started oddly enough in July 2009, when the body of a motivational speaker and father of three from Long Island was found tied up, with multiple stab wounds, in his black station wagon on a street in East Harlem.

headline: In a First, Saudis Cancel a Speech at the U.N.
text: Saudi Arabia, frustrated by what it apparently regarded as policy setbacks over Syria, Iran and Palestinian statehood, abruptly canceled its turn to speak this week at the annual United Nations General Assembly meeting, diplomatic officials and Arab news agencies reported Thursday.

headline: Levity Amid Competition as U.S. Takes a Slim Lead
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Jason Day stood over a 20-foot birdie attempt with a 2 ½-foot break Thursday, his confidence buoyed by having struck the same putt dozens of times in the scores of rounds he has played at Muirfield Village, his home course. What made the putt hard to read, for the fans gathered around the 18th hole, if not for Day, was that if it dropped, the visitors from the International team would earn their second point of the Presidents Cup.

headline: Many Win in Offering, but Some Are Off List
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The list of newly minted millionaires from Twitter’s public offering will be longer than the average tweet. But the list of who stands to make into the hundreds of millions of dollars is tiny, and shows that sometimes when you roll the dice early in a company’s life the payoff can be enormous.

headline: Assessing the Impact of the 2011 Debt Ceiling Showdown
text: A Treasury Department report released Thursday cited a series of economic indicators to illustrate how the August 2011 Congressional impasse over raising the debt ceiling hurt the economy.

text: Thursday, the fourth day of Alex Rodriguez’s arbitration hearing at Major League Baseball’s headquarters at Park Avenue and 46th Street in Manhattan, turned into an improvised day-night doubleheader for him.

headline: Thievery Comes After Carnage at Kenya Mall

headline: Adobe Announces Security Breach
text: Hackers infiltrated the computer system of the software company Adobe, gaining access to credit card information and other personal data from 2.9 million of its customers, the company acknowledged on Thursday.

headline: In Formula One, a Grip Not Easily Loosened
text: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium — The command center of the shimmering, multibillion-dollar road show that is Formula One Grand Prix racing is an unobtrusive, gray-walled motor home known colloquially as the Kremlin.

headline: After Isles’ Big Step, Tavares Takes Pressure in Stride

That is wise, given what Tavares has achieved since the Islanders selected him first over all in the 2009 draft.

headline: Reading Selections in the Empathy Study
text: A study published in the journal Science found that after reading literary fiction, as opposed to popular fiction or serious nonfiction, people performed better on tests measuring empathy, social perception and emotional intelligence — skills that come in especially handy when you are trying to read someone’s body language or gauge what they might be thinking. These were the reading selections used in one or more of the experiments in the study.

headline: New Diplomatic Avenue Emerges, in 140-Character Bursts

headline: India: Ex-Official Is Jailed in Graft Case
text: An Indian court sentenced Lalu Prasad, a former chief minister of the state of Bihar, to five years in prison for corruption on Thursday after he was found guilty of participating in a scheme in which officials created false receipts and siphoned off $6 million worth of public funds earmarked for animal husbandry for more than a decade. The sentence effectively bars him from participating in the coming national and state elections. Mr. Prasad is the first major political figure affected by a Supreme Court order disqualifying politicians who are sentenced to prison terms of more than two years. More than 40 politicians, bureaucrats and suppliers were sentenced in the case, but Mr. Prasad is by far the most significant. His party controls four parliamentary seats allied with the national governing party, and he is a loyal supporter of Sonia Gandhi, the president of the Congress Party.

headline: The Stunning, Sacred Retreats of California
text: Over the past half century, an odd mix of swamis, monks, Zen masters and utopians have secured thousands of acres of prime California real estate to make sanctuaries for those seeking to escape the world. Welcome to God’s country.

headline: Kershaw Foils Braves as Dodgers Win Easily

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 10 P.M. (NBC) ELIZABETH’S STORY: A MEREDITH VIEIRA SPECIAL Ms. Vieira interviews Elizabeth Smart, who, at the age of 14 in 2002, was kidnapped from the bedroom of her Salt Lake City home by Brian David Mitchell, a religious zealot, and his wife, Wanda Barzee, and subsequently chained up, dressed in disguise and raped before being rescued nine months later. Ms. Smart, left, who established the Elizabeth Smart Foundation to help prevent crimes against children, will discuss life with her captors as told in her memoir, “My Story,” to be released on Monday.

headline: Rangers Stumble in Vigneault’s Debut as Coach

headline: Indian, Chinese Passports Among Least Attractive for Global Visa Waivers
text: NEW DELHI— A global index that ranks countries based on freedom of travel for their citizens has ranked India among the bottom few with its South Asian neighbors like Afghanistan and Pakistan. India’s citizens have visa-free access to only 52 countries, with India ranking  in 74th place, along with Uzbekistan.

headline: Is Miguel Cabrera the Hero of the Post-Steroid Era?
text: Miguel Cabrera looked as if he were wearing pajamas, untucked and mismatched, as he lumbered around the Detroit Tigers’ clubhouse in a sweaty gray T-shirt and a pair of Nike shower shoes. Known to his teammates as Miggy, Cabrera wore his hair dense down the middle and bare on the sides — in what he called “a faux-hawk.” In an era in which even baseball players have come to resemble souped-up Eastern bloc Olympians, Miggy packs more of a stonemason physique: he is 6-foot-4 with massive arms and torso, but also a noticeable paunch of fluctuating size and, God bless him, well-articulated man-boobs. Yet he is the reigning American League M.V.P. and quite possibly the best hitter of his generation. (One of the fun parts about writing about baseball is inviting a “best of his generation” debate before the first paragraph is even over.)

headline: Should Video Games Be Considered a Sport?
text: Players compete in huge arenas, cheered on by thousands of screaming fans, with millions of dollars in prize money at stake. Top competitors must endure grueling training regimens, but also enjoy soaring salaries and corporate endorsement deals.

text: PARIS — A three-day standoff between security forces in the French port of Calais and several dozen Syrians ended Friday evening when the Syrians backed down, a migrant association in northern France said.

headline: Twitter Opens Up
text: TWITTER OPENS UP  |  Twitter on Thursday made public its prospectus for an initial public offering, providing a glimpse at the high-flying company’s financial health. The filing showed just how central smartphones and tablets are to Twitter’s business, underscoring the technology industry’s shift to a mobile world, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. But despite evidence that Twitter is increasing its revenue from mobile advertising, the company also showed that it has not yet turned a profit, and has been steadily losing money, and that its user growth has been slowing since the end of last year.

To be perfectly honest, I never felt I got it right. Several years back, when my twins were 17 and their older brother was 19, I described my frustrations in a parenting column:

headline: New York Film Festival: Jia Zhang-ke on Contemporary China
text: Updated, 8:10 a.m. | The drama “A Touch of Sin,” from the director Jia Zhang-ke, tells four stories of contemporary China that follow working-class characters pushed to the brink of violence when treated with brutality at work and elsewhere. The events in the movie are fictionalized versions of incidents widely reported in the press. The film, which won best screenplay at Cannes in the spring, was shown this week at the New York Film Festival and opens Friday in New York. (See Manohla Dargis’s review.) At Cannes, Mr. Jia spoke about how the film’s visuals and locations played into the stories. Speaking through an interpreter during an interview at the Paramount Hotel in New York, Mr. Jia discussed issues the movie raises. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: The Shutdown’s Data Blackout
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Today, for the first time since 1996 and only the second time in modern memory, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will not issue its monthly jobs report, as a result of the shutdown of nonessential government services. This raises an important question: Are the B.L.S. report and other economic data that the government provides “nonessential”?

headline: Twitter’s I.P.O. Plan Has an International Focus
text: LONDON — Twitter might have American roots, but the social-networking service is a truly international phenomenon, its filing for an initial public offering shows. And it is banking on growth overseas to fuel its continued expansion.

text: A Washington burger chain that offered free food to furloughed federal workers said it would end the deal on Thursday because it had become too costly.

headline: Italy Suspends Search for Shipwreck Victims
text: Having floated for at least two days in the choppy Mediterranean Sea to reach Europe, a rickety trawler overstuffed with African migrants fleeing war and poverty was nearing a Sicilian island, not even a quarter-mile away. But it was still dark and no one had yet spotted them. So to signal their position, someone set a match to a blanket.

text: ISTANBUL — “Goat droppings” is the polite translation for a graphic Turkish expression that describes something insipid: The idea is that goat pellets are relatively inoffensive, lacking the quality of real dung.

headline: Company Is Scolded for Mistakes at Fukushima
text: TOKYO — In an unusually public scolding, Japan’s nuclear watchdog agency criticized the operator of the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant on Friday for making mistakes that allowed radioactive water to leak into the Pacific Ocean, and ordered it to fix the problems quickly.

headline: Swiss Investigate Banks Over Currency Trading
text: FRANKFURT — The banking industry, already troubled by official inquiries that have badly damaged its reputation, got hit by another on Friday. Swiss authorities said they were investigating whether financial institutions had colluded to manipulate foreign exchange markets.

headline: Mobile Payment Startups Face Reluctant Indian Consumers
text: When Mrugank S., 33, an information technology professional in Bangalore, Karnataka, ordered five teaming carts of produce from Big Basket, an online grocery store, he chose “card-on-delivery” as the mode of payment. But when the two deliverymen wheeled up to his flat on the 14th floor of a tower, he pulled out a wad of bills.
