text: Twitter was largely silent last month about the details of its planned initial public offering, saying only that it had filed papers confidentially.

headline: Rodriguez Sues, Targeting Baseball and Medical Treatment
text: Faced with baseball’s longest doping suspension, Alex Rodriguez sued Major League Baseball late Thursday, accusing it of buying the cooperation of Anthony Bosch, the head of an anti-aging clinic at the center of a doping scandal, as part of a continuing “witch hunt” to force Rodriguez out of the sport.

headline: We Don’t Need No Education
text: The Republican shutdown of government is compounding what was already a disastrous year for Head Start, the federal program that prepares disadvantaged 3 and 4 year olds for school. This critically important program is already reeling from the sequester, the senseless across the board budget cuts that began last spring, which caused Head Start centers to scale back on transportation, basic learning materials and, in some cases, to even close their doors. According to the National Head Start Association, owing to the sequester cuts that began in March, 57,000 fewer children will have access to the program this year — with even deeper cuts to come if the mindless process of budget cutting continues.

headline: The Short-Seller Stands Tall
text: Your fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, took a $500-million loss on its investment in J. C. Penney. How did that feel?  I’m not emotional about investments. Investing is something where you have to be purely rational, and not let emotion affect your decision making — just the facts.

headline: Drinking Like Hemingway
text: A critical assessment of Brooklyn’s authors; why you’re gaining weight on Sundays.

headline: Why I Silence Your Call, Even When I’m Free
text: My cousin Stacey in San Francisco called recently. We hadn’t spoken since she visited me the previous month, and I missed her. I was sitting in my office, catching up on e-mail while refreshing my Twitter feed every few minutes. Hardly too busy for a chat.

headline: When Meta Met Data
text: Lost in all the anxiety and hand-wringing over revelations about big data, personal privacy and the National Security Agency is another unfortunate, and consequential, societal development: A transformation in the meaning of “meta.” This has happened specifically in relation to metadata — the transactional digital information that pinpoints the date and time you called someone, for example, or locates the spot from which you last accessed your e-mail account — but also to our larger understanding of the concept of meta; our metaunderstanding, as it were.

headline: Dead Man’s Burden
text: A family member died last winter and named me and my sister the heirs to his estate. In a letter accompanying the will (but not part of it), he asked us to donate several thousand dollars to certain organizations. Some of these are extremely right-wing groups, which we feel border on the fringe: paranoiac with no objectivity, with ties to militant political organizations. We feel conflicted about this — we want to honor our relative’s wishes but really take offense to some of these groups. L.B., CALIFORNIA

headline: And Then Steve Said, ‘Let There Be an iPhone’
text: The 55 miles from Campbell to San Francisco make for one of the nicest commutes anywhere. The journey mostly zips along the Junipero Serra Freeway, a grand and remarkably empty highway that abuts the east side of the Santa Cruz Mountains. It is one of the best places in Silicon Valley to spot a start-up tycoon speed-testing his Ferrari and one of the worst places for cellphone reception. For Andy Grignon, it was therefore the perfect place for him to be alone with his thoughts early on Jan. 8, 2007.

headline: Who Made Movie Popcorn?
text: In the 1920s, movie palaces rose up around the country like so many portals into a glamorous world. After you bought a ticket, you might pass through gilded archways and ascend a grand staircase lighted by a crystal chandelier to find your velvet seat. Eating was not meant to be part of the experience, says Andrew F. Smith, author of “Popped Culture: A Social History of Popcorn in America.” Theater owners feared that audiences would strew popcorn and peanuts on those crimson carpets. They hung signs discouraging people from bringing in food from vendors parked outside and didn’t sell it themselves.

headline: Bridging the Gap Between High School and College, at a Price
text: MY older son is about a month into his freshman year at college, and like most of his classmates, is adjusting to new roommates, classes and doing his own laundry.

headline: A Major Photography Museum in Marrakesh

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Let’s Read About Sex
text: This week, Francine Prose and Anna Holmes talk about the most erotic books they’ve ever read; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alison Wolf discusses “The XX Factor”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Aaron Curry Unveils New Sculpture
text: In his most significant public sculpture to date, Aaron Curry will unveil a new work at Lincoln Center’s Josie Robertson Plaza called “Melt to Earth.”

headline: The Gun Report: October 4, 2013
text: For practical, common sense ideas regarding gun control, maybe we should look to Canada, Adam Gopnik wrote on The New Yorker’s Web site on Tuesday. Gopnik’s parents live in Ontario, “surrounded by crops, animals, and pests—and indeed by farmers who need and use rifles.” In order to procure a gun for, say, culling a raccoon infestation, you need to fill out an application for a license and take a gun-safety course—and if your current or former spouse doesn’t sign your application, the police have to inform them that you’re applying for a firearms license.

headline: Getting It Right: Lore Segal Talks About ‘Half the Kingdom’
text: Lore Segal published her first novel in 1964. “Other People’s Houses” was a semi-autobiographical story about a young girl growing up in England after Hitler took control of Austria. When Ms. Segal was 10 years old, she left Vienna for England as part of the Kindertransport program. She moved to New York in 1951. In her new novel, “Half the Kingdom,” older hospital patients are mysteriously contracting Alzheimer’s disease at a rapid rate. In The New York Times Book Review, Patricia T. O’Conner wrote: “Fans of Segal’s fiction should feel right at home in this darkly comic novel.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Segal, 85, discussed what the book says about aging, the recurring characters in her fiction, whether she ever thinks of retiring and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Call for Self-Restraint at the U.N.
text: PARIS — It has taken more than two years and 120,000 deaths in Syria for the United Nations Security Council to finally cease being paralyzed by vetoes and make a decision.

headline: Sex Lives
text: SWINGLANDBetween the Sheets of the Secretive, Sometimes Messy, but Always Adventurous Swinging LifestyleBy Daniel Stern  Touchstone, $26.

headline: 1912: Titanic Disaster
text: “The Titanic, new White Star liner, founders off Newfoundland; reports are most contradictory, but appalling loss of life is feared,” said The New York Herald, a forerunner of the International Herald Tribune, describing one of the worst maritime disasters in history.

headline: Let’s Do It
text: “Birds do it,” Ella Fitzgerald sang. “Bees do it. Even educated fleas do it.” Musicians have always had an easy time expressing lust. Without sex, most of Prince’s work would be a John Cage-like experiment in complete silence.

headline: Love During Wartime
text: The big story is Lisbon in 1940: the last way out of Europe as the Nazis advance, a neutral port full of spies and desperate refugees. Thousands of them have struggled south from France, managed the almost impossible trick of getting the right papers with the right stamps at the right time in the right place, and now they’re waiting to see if they can arrange passage out. Lisbon in 1940 is famously melodramatic; it’s where Ingrid Bergman was heading at the end of “Casablanca.”

headline: No Sex Please, We’re Buddhist
text: Last summer my beloved, who is on a meditation kick that has reshaped the contours of his disposition in a most agreeable way, attended a weekend retreat at a Zen monastery. While there, he tucked his wallet under a mattress and returned from a serenity session to find it some $200 lighter. It was a small price to pay for a lesson in detachment, he later concluded, as I audibly gritted my teeth.

headline: Acquired Tastes
text: “The finding of an object,” Sigmund Freud wrote a century ago in his “Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality,” “is in fact a refinding of it.” The patterns and paths our lusts will take, what we will yearn to do and have done to us and whom we will wish to do these things with — to a great extent, our erotic longings are laid down early, beginning in childhood and even infancy. Freud has lost currency in recent decades, but few in the field of sex research, no matter how they qualify his premise or dismiss him as unscientific, would argue that our early experiences don’t have the power to profoundly shape our later cravings, and two experiments described in Jesse Bering’s “Perv: The Sexual Deviant in All of Us” lend indirect proof.

headline: What You Wish For
text: Discussing his classic noir tales of adultery and murder, “The Postman Always Rings Twice” and “Double Indemnity,” James M. Cain set forth a concept he called the “love rack.” For him, it meant finding a way to manipulate readers into caring about his criminal characters and their plight, and surrendering to the story. The term’s connotations of torture were apt. In Cain’s novels, desire is a prison, a death trap. If the author can seduce the audience into investing in that desire, and the fate of the lovers in its thrall, the reader essentially joins them on that rack, with each plot twist proving another pull of the rope, another turn of the screw.

headline: Cherry Bombshells
text: “A girl can do what she wants to do,” Joan Jett sings in her anthem “Bad Reputation,” “and that’s what I’m gonna do.” Similar sentiments drove the Runaways, Jett’s first group and perhaps the first teenage, all-female hard-rock band signed to a major American label. Despite defiant assertions of independence like the classic “Cherry Bomb,” the band remains cruelly underrated, a perception Evelyn McDonnell seeks to rectify in her scrupulously researched “Queens of Noise.” Ambition and self-determination are prevailing themes: for these women, pursuing those aims in the 1970s could be brutal, especially when contending with adolescent hormones.

headline: Rosedud
text: If you have not already done so, please see “The Room.” Certain films elicit so much joy they cannot be recommended highly enough. “The Room” is such a film. Not because it is good. No. “The Room” is not a good film. It is bad. Some call it “the best bad movie ever made.” But “bad” does not do it justice. In fact, no adjective I know fully conveys the comprehensive artistic disaster that is “The Room.” Perhaps some Amazonian tribe has a word that means “something so terrible it achieves a certain kind of majesty,” but in English we do not.

headline: The Price of Equality
text: Earlier this year, Sheryl Sandberg asked the members of a mainly female audience of undergraduates at Harvard University to stand up if they thought one day they could be C.E.O. of their company or even president of the United States. Many stayed seated. For the chief operating officer of Facebook and the fledgling elite she was addressing, one crucial barrier on the road to gender equality may well be what Sandberg calls the leadership ambition gap — the lack of women with the self-confidence to “lean in” like men.

headline: In Performance: Orlando Bloom
text: The actor performs a scene from the new Broadway production of Shakespeare’s “Romeo and Juliet.”

headline: Yoga Has Limited Menopause Benefits
text: Many women seek natural alternatives to hormone replacement therapy to treat menopause symptoms. Some have turned to yoga, but a rigorous new trial shows that its benefits may be limited, at best.

headline: The Devil’s Own
text: Many readers of Jeanette Winterson’s new novel will already have traveled with her to 17th-century England in her 1990 novel “Sexing the Cherry.” Like most of Winterson’s work, that early book is brief, copious and sometimes astonishing — Clarendon’s “History of the Rebellion” meets “Naked Lunch.” In “The Daylight Gate,” Winterson now puts her mind to the Pendle Hill witch trials of 1612, whose 400th anniversary has occasioned a small outpouring of fiction and poetry.

headline: Hell Hath a Fury
text: I can tell you in just two words why ALEX (MacLehose, $24.95), a thriller by the fashionable French author Pierre Lemaitre, was such a sensation in Europe. Partisan politics. Just kidding! The two words are — sadistic sex.

headline: Songs of Experience
text: When we first met Paul Chowder, the hyper-garrulous narrator of Nicholson Baker’s 2009 novel “The Anthologist,” he was furiously blocked on writing the introduction to an anthology of rhyming poetry, and somewhat less furiously blocked on salvaging his relationship with his longtime girlfriend, Roz. What came seeping from around those blockages was a mordant and effervescently graceful disquisition on the nature of poetry, poets, failure and the “interesting blind pain of wrongness”: a riff-tastic essay masquerading as a novel, or vice versa. The voice of Paul Chowder — prickly, whimsical, genially pedagogic, opinion-stippled and often lavishly intelligent — supplied the vessel, yet poetry, the novel’s subject and in some sense its main character, provided the sustenance.

headline: Now Screening | A Train Film to Celebrate Doug Aitken’s ‘Station to Station’ Tour
text: By now the resounding whistle of Doug Aitken’s “Station to Station” art train has blown all the way across the country, from New York City to the Bay Area. The “nomadic happening,” as the artist called it, brought artists, musicians and other creative visionaries together for exhibitions and performances in cities like Pittsburgh, Kansas City and Santa Fe last month. “What I really like about Doug is that he wants to communicate with the whole world,” said the German photographer and sculptor Thomas Demand, one of the project’s participants, who has known Aitken for nearly two decades.

headline: Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, Who Ousted U.S. From Vietnam, Is Dead
text: Vo Nguyen Giap, the relentless and charismatic North Vietnamese general whose campaigns drove both France and the United States out of Vietnam, died on Friday in Hanoi. He was believed to be 102.

headline: Image of the Day: October 4
text: Supporters of the Indian National Congress celebrated after the union cabinet gave a nod to the proposal for creating India’s 29th state.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FROM THE RUINS OF EMPIRE: The Revolt Against the West and the Remaking of Asia,  by Pankaj Mishra. (Picador, $17.) This is a superb history of Asian intellectual responses to Western colonialism in the 19th and 20th centuries, from Ottoman Turkey to Meiji Japan. Mishra tells this story through the biographies of two independent thinkers: the itinerant Persian-­born agitator Jamal al-Din al-Afghani and the Chinese reformer Liang Qichao.

headline: Netanyahu Plans to Meet With European Leaders on Iranian Nuclear Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that he would meet with European leaders next week in hopes of influencing the negotiations scheduled to begin Oct. 15 over Iran’s nuclear program, part of what he described as a “comprehensive international struggle.”

headline: Inside the List
text: Ocean State: Jhumpa Lahiri grew up in Rhode Island, right next to the state university’s main campus in Kingston, but you’d never know it from her first three books. Outside of her brief author’s biography, the state never makes an appearance in the story collections “Interpreter of Maladies” and “Unaccustomed Earth,” while in the novel “The Namesake” it earns just two passing mentions: once during a school field trip and once when the protagonist’s train is delayed by a suicide on the tracks “somewhere in Rhode Island.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE SIGNATURE OF ALL THINGS,  by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Viking, $28.95.) In this winning novel by the author of “Eat, Pray, Love,” a botanist’s hunger for explanations carries her through the better part of Darwin’s century, and to Tahiti.

headline: Golden Boy With Silver Hair
text: CHICAGO — Claiming an ever-smaller slice of the cultural pie and with fewer media outlets to spread the word, orchestras and their conductors struggle for visibility these days. But there are signs that Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra since 2010, has solved the problem better than most.

headline: No Comment Necessary: What If the Government Defaults?
text: In a Thursday report, the Treasury Department explained what would happen if Congress were to refuse to raise the federal debt limit.

headline: When Converting a Roth I.R.A. Back to a Traditional One Makes Sense
text: WHEN it comes to making financial decisions to save on taxes, you don’t usually get a do-over. Just ask all those people who rushed to make large tax-free gifts to family members at the end of last year before a historically high exemption was set to expire. Not only did the exemption not end, but it was increased for 2013. And there was no way to get those tax-driven gifts back.

headline: Snowboarding at the Cardrona Halfpipe
text: Every August, the world’s best snowboarders come to work on big-air and physics-defying in Wanaka, New Zealand.

headline: How Parents Handle Teenage Drinking
text: This week’s New Parent, Old Parent question really gets to the heart of why we created this collaboration between Booming and Motherlode. Back when he was in the thick of it, my colleague Mike Winerip wrote a column about how much he was struggling with how to handle the question of teenage drinking. Did he have to take a complete no drinking stance, he asked? Or should he assume that some drinking was inevitable, and try to teach moderation rather than abstinence? He was, he writes, assailed just for asking the questions — but what’s truly interesting is who the parents who knew exactly what to do about teenage drinking turned out to be: the parents of younger children.

headline: Company Man
text: Patrick Flanery’s first novel, “Absolution” (2012), was a beautiful book of secrets, a multilayered tale of post-­apartheid South Africa. His second, “Fallen Land,” is very different in style and substance, a dystopian story set on the outskirts of an unnamed Midwestern city that bears some resemblance to Omaha, where Flanery was raised.

headline: A Snowboarding Wonderland
text: Snowboarders flock to New Zealand’s South Island in August to take advantage of the halfpipe at Cardrona Alpine Resort.

headline: Icahn Gives Up Fight Over Dell Appraisal Rights
text: Carl C. Icahn is finally abandoning his battle against Dell‘s sale to its founder.

headline: Summer Camp for the Winter Olympics
text: WANAKA, New Zealand — From the bottom, they look like butterflies, dropping soundlessly into the halfpipe and soaring high above its walls, spinning and flipping, flashes of color cascading over the whiteness. It’s only after they skid to a stop and lift their bug-eyed goggles that you see the dreadlocks and soul patches, the Rockstar and Monster energy-drink logos, the tie-dye slickers and the ubiquitous ear buds.

headline: Nets’ Kidd Receives Two-Game Suspension
text: DURHAM, N.C. — The N.B.A. on Friday imposed a two-game suspension on Nets Coach Jason Kidd, who pleaded guilty in July to a drunken-driving charge.

headline: Both Hero and Villain, and Irresistible
text: Before there was a documentary about WikiLeaks — before there was a major motion picture about its founder — Julian Assange was a star.

headline: Another Missed Ritual: Jobs Numbers
text: Jobs Report Becomes a Casualty of Shutdown

headline: Cancellation of Trip by Obama Plays to Doubts of Asia Allies
text: BEIJING — As President Obama made apologetic calls to Asia to cancel his planned trip to the region, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, was taking a star turn in some of the same countries Mr. Obama would have visited.

headline: With No New Plan, Boehner Makes Angry Plea on Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans emerged from a closed-door meeting on Friday with no new strategy to end the budget standoff and an angry plea to President Obama to negotiate over his health care law.

headline: Wheels Calendar
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: New Fashion Runway: Wall Street
text: With his red-carpet gowns, lush cashmere sweaters and jet-set shoulder totes, Michael Kors has influenced fellow designers across the globe.

headline: The First Illicit Thing You Read
text: In the Book Review’s Sex Issue, a select group of writers shared their memories of the first illicit thing they ever read. More than 200 readers also wrote on The New York Times’s Web site about their experiences with books, poems and other works of literature that their parents or teachers might not have wanted them to read.

headline: Delivering the News, All of It, in 2 Minutes
text: LOS ANGELES — The mission: re-create the history of the news media in two minutes or less.

headline: Off the Charts: In Europe, Adult Unemployment Rises
text: The number of unemployed adults in the euro zone countries reached a record high in August, despite a continued decline in Germany.

headline: In Performance: Orlando Bloom
text: In the new Broadway production of “Romeo and Juliet,” Orlando Bloom and Condola Rashad star as the doomed young lovers.

headline: Q. & A. | Greg Lauren on His Foray Into Fragrance
text: With his fifth ready-to-wear collection behind him, the 43-year-old L.A. artist-turned-designer Greg Lauren will make his fragrance industry debut on Tuesday, when his namesake unisex fragrance hits shelves at the Barneys New York flagship on Madison Avenue. “I thought this would have the same emotional themes that I’d want to express in my collection, which never feels like a fragment is made for men and another for women,” said Lauren, a nephew of Ralph Lauren. The exclusive scent is the second in the luxury department store’s designer fragrance collection, which started in 2012 with a L’Wren Scott creation. Made by the New York perfumer Ralf Schwieger, whose work includes Lipstick Rose by Frédéric Malle and Eau des Merveilles by Hermès, the blend’s sweet aroma is built around tonka beans, vanilla and coconut, offset by a musky veil of sandalwood, amber and moss.

headline: The Building Has 1,000 Eyes
text: Some of the wealthiest people in New York City live at 740 Park Avenue: the industrialist David Koch and the financier Stephen Schwarzman, among others. It’s hard to pass the board inspection; it’s very hard to get past the vigilant doormen.

headline: Carnegie Hall and Stagehands Settle Contract Dispute
text: The negotiations lasted more than a year and led to a strike that canceled Carnegie Hall’s planned opening night for the first time in the hall’s 122-year history. But after only two days, the dispute between Carnegie’s management and its stagehands was settled on Friday, and the hall announced that it was fully back in business.

headline: T FALL TRAVEL
text: Can a modern family make a home among hordes of tourists under the watchful eye of England’s National Trust? The grandson of Vita Sackville-West and Harold Nicolson attempts to bring Sissinghurst, one of the most famous gardens in the world, into the 21st century.

headline: Shutdown’s Pinch Leaves Governors With Tough Calls
text: LOS ANGELES — With no end in sight to the federal government shutdown, governors across the nation are struggling with a cascade of tough decisions about when and whether to step in with state money to keep shuttered parks and programs operating until the deadlock is resolved.

headline: Luxury Moves to Mulberry Street
text: The architecture and development company Flank set out years ago to prove what others are now discovering: there is a market in Lower Manhattan for oversize condominiums in boutique buildings, no matter the neighborhood.

headline: Climbing to the Top of His Range
text: The resurgence of the countertenor voice — roughly equivalent to a male alto — in classical music began about 70 years ago in Britain, so it’s appropriate that one of the best of the emerging generation is Iestyn Davies, who hails from York, England.

headline: A New Life, Furloughed
text: Katherine Buckingham, a furloughed FEMA employee, is counting the days of the federal government shutdown until she can get back to work.

headline: Happy to Be Alive ... and Dancing
text: The choreographer David Dorfman drives a Saab convertible, which he bought in his early 50s. But don’t call it a midlife crisis car.

headline: De Blasio Focuses on Inequality as He Courts Business Elite
text: Bill de Blasio delivered on Friday his most detailed blueprint yet for how he would reimagine New York as a more equitable and populist metropolis, even as he works diligently behind the scenes to send a subtler message to the city’s corporate titans: He is not their enemy.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Reykjavik; Adams County, Pa.; San Diego
text: Iceland Airwaves, Reykjavik Since beginning in an airplane hangar in 1999, this music festival, from Oct. 30 to Nov. 3, has showcased an eclectic mix of musical acts in a variety of locations, from neighborhood clubs to art museums to the new Harpa concert hall. This year’s lineup includes the British electronic musician Gold Panda, the Syrian folk-pop musician Omar Souleyman, above, and the Swedish experimental group Goat.

headline: Trading an African Dashiki for Union Blue
text: “We most heartily endorse the earnest and energetic efforts being put forth by Mr. Delaney, and John Jones of this city, towards the enlistment of volunteers for the Artillery Brigade, to be composed entirely of colored men,” announced The Chicago Tribune on Oct. 2, 1863. The article focused on black Union recruitment in the city, a process that had been in full swing for months across the North and Union-occupied South. But the paper was burying the lede: by the fall of 1863 Mr. Delany – Martin Robison Delany, the nation’s foremost advocate for black migration out of the country – had become one of Uncle Sam’s best recruiters.

headline: Unemployment of Adults Falls in Germany, but Not the Rest of Europe
text: THE euro zone can be separated into two groups, at least in terms of unemployment: Germany and the rest.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Gravity,’ ‘A Touch of Sin’ and ‘A.C.O.D.’
text: In this week’s video, Times film critics share their thoughts on the science fiction thriller “Gravity,” the Chinese drama “A Touch of Sin” and the comedy “A.C.O.D.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: T FALL TRAVEL
text: Despite an ambitious face-lift with gleaming new architecture and a refurbished waterfront, Marseille remains a stubbornly glorious melting pot of seediness and sun — which is precisely why it’s so wonderful.

headline: Recalling Blitzkrieg Bop on the Bowery
text: Nobody knows what punk rock truly is. Some have defined it well: Kurt Cobain simply said, “Punk rock means freedom.” Others not so well: A 1992 Subaru commercial insisted that the Imprezas were “just like punk, except it’s cars.” In “Next Stop, Nowhere,” a 1982 episode of the television procedural “Quincy M.E.,” a murder has taken place in a club and a concerned parent describes punk to Jack Klugman’s titular coroner as “violence-oriented music that does nothing but reinforce all those bad feelings.” The episode is now the go-to example for getting the punk spirit horribly wrong on screen.

headline: Wheelies: The Rent More Cars Edition
text: Updated, 4:01 p.m. |

headline: Modernizing an English Garden
text: Can a modern family make a home among hordes of tourists under the watchful eye of England’s National Trust? The grandson of Vita Sackville-West and Harold Nicolson attempts to bring Sissinghurst, one of the most famous gardens in the world, into the 21st century.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Let’s Read About Sex
text: This week, Francine Prose, Anna Holmes and Alison Wolf.

headline: In Maui’s Upcountry, Where the Paniolo Roam
text: At the Oskie Rice Arena, the Friday night lights hung in the damp, mid-December Hawaiian air. Beaming through Maui’s notorious red clay dust, the lights served as a backdrop to one of the Upcountry’s biggest annual events. On the metal bleachers, families were bundled against their idea of the cold: a winter chill that sank just below 60 degrees. There were coats, blankets and hoodie strings pulled tight. There was Portuguese soup and Puerto Rican stew at the family-run concession stands, where the handwritten menus were scrawled in thick felt marker, crossed through as the “onolicious” fried ice cream or pork with tofu and macaroni ran out.

headline: Cowboy Culture on Maui
text: Welcome to the Upcountry, home of ranches, rodeos and a rich cowboy tradition.

headline: Long Before the Shutdown, Republicans Were Hurting National Parks
text: The closing of 401 national parks, monuments, waterways and memorials (plus 561 national wildlife refuges) as part of the broader government shutdown has the public in an uproar and Republicans in (partial) retreat. On Tuesday, the House passed a bill to fund these facilities as one of several measures to open those parts of the government whose shuttering has drawn the most criticism — a truly cynical gesture that rightly found no traction whatever in the Senate.

headline: Treasures of the Cinque Terre
text: It was a stroke of luck, really, that my luggage was lost when I flew to Italy this summer to visit the jewel box villages of the Cinque Terre — five heart-stoppingly picturesque hamlets on the Ligurian coast, dotted with pastel houses nestled amid terraced hills that drop to the jade and lapis waters of the Mediterranean. All I had with me were my eyes and feet. For the next few days, that would be all I needed. Unencumbered, I could leap lightly onto trains and trails, feeling sorry for the heavily laden travelers around me, even as I mourned the absence of my hiking sandals. And I saw at once that the Cinque Terre (pronounced CHING-kway TAY-ray) should not be reserved as a bucket-list destination: they are best seen pre-bucket, while you are still limber enough to hop on and off platforms and boats, scamper up winding medieval staircases and clamber onto slick sunning rocks in secluded coves and on friendly beaches.

headline: In the Cinque Terre, Sun, Sea and Sweeping Scenes
text: Views from Italy’s Ligurian coast.

headline: Terror That Melts From the Screen
text: As sexy as the technology may be, digital 3-D hasn’t exactly conquered the entertainment landscape. ESPN’s decision this summer to end its three-year-old stereoscopic sports channel strongly suggests the format will never be adopted as an across-the-board industry standard. But the format (or gimmick, depending on your point of view) does seem to have established a niche for itself. 3-D is now a more or less obligatory adornment for computer-animated family films and the high-end action franchises, although — despite rare exceptions like Ang Lee’s “Life of Pi” and Alfonso Cuarón’s “Gravity” — the process hasn’t found a foothold in straight dramatic filmmaking. Depth, it seems, is appropriate only for shallow subjects.

headline: Hapless and Hopeless
text: During the Bush years, I would often run into people mocking W for being stupid. I never thought he was — incurious, anti-intellectual, but not stupid. And the people around him certainly weren’t stupid — cynical, dishonest, but not stupid, especially regarding matters political.

headline: During Shutdown, Many Agencies Are Offline
text: WASHINGTON — During the government shutdown, federal agencies are not just shutting their doors and sending their employees home. Some are choosing to shut down their Web sites as well.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Let’s Talk About Sex
text: In The New York Times Book Review’s Sex Issue, Francine Prose and Anna Holmes write about the most erotic books they’ve ever read. Ms. Prose writes:

headline: Armory Show to Highlight a Shanghai Artist
text: Each year the Armory Show, New York’s largest art fair, commissions one artist to make his or her mark on the event, with tote bags and ephemera, an on-site installation and the production of an edition of prints to benefit the Museum of Modern Art. This year the fair’s focus will be on China, and the organizers have chosen the Shanghai provocateur Xu Zhen (pronounced shoo jen), a 36-year-old conceptual artist and one of the most influential among the younger generation. “Armory Focus: China” will feature 20 galleries showing the works of young Chinese artists, organized by Philip Tinari, the director of the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art in Beijing.

headline: The Virtues of Adding Hoc (Wonkish)
text: At an economics education event in Florida, so little posting today. But a quick note on some methodological thoughts.

headline: Decades in Solitary Confinement, Then Death in Freedom
text: Herman Wallace, one of the so-called “Angola 3″ prisoners known for their decades of incarceration and solitary confinement in Louisiana, has died just a few days after being released from jail, his legal team said on Friday. He was 71. The cause was liver cancer, the team said.

headline: FIFA Assigns Group to Study Winter Move for World Cup
text: ZURICH — Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, emerged Friday from two days of meetings to address serious questions about the 2022 World Cup with a concrete answer to one of them.

headline: Twitter’s I.P.O. and the League Table Fight
text: Thanks to the social network Twitter, the league tables for initial public offerings for both banks and stock exchanges could shift significantly.

headline: What’ll You Have, Mr. President?
text: WASHINGTON — Perhaps it was the dearth of kitchen workers at the White House as the federal shutdown dragged on, but President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. strolled out, coatless, to a nearby sandwich shop on a sunny Friday — both for lunch and for another photo opportunity to press House Republicans to reopen the government.

headline: Imported From France, a New Sitcom Set in Brooklyn
text: A 1998 action-comedy movie, “Taxi,” was set in a place with intriguing museums and galleries, appealing restaurants and a multicultural population — Marseille, on the southeastern coast of France.

headline: Acoustic Version of “Super Bon Bon”
text: By Mike Doughty

headline: Boehner: ‘This Isn’t Some Damned Game’
text: With no new plan on the fourth day of the shutdown, House Speaker John A. Boehner made an angry plea to President Obama for a discussion on his health care law.

headline: Acoustic Version of “Circles”
text: By Mike Doughty

headline: Possible Clues in Fatal Chase, but No Motive
text: The woman who was shot to death after a taut, high-speed car chase through the streets between the White House and Capitol Hill was still in her car, snagged on the curb of a grass-covered median, when the police fired at her, a Senate official said on Friday.

headline: After Killings, Tourists Are Told to Avoid Madagascar
text: JOHANNESBURG — Several Western countries issued travel warnings about the Indian Ocean island nation of Madagascar on Friday, citing mob attacks that killed two Europeans and a Madagascan accused of organ trafficking.

headline: In Rural Iowa, Spending, Not the Shutdown, Raises Worry
text: The Republican Party has long claimed to be the champion of business, large and small, and an advocate for fiscal responsibility. Yet now Republicans in Congress have precipitated a shutdown of the federal government and are threatening to let the nation default on its once Triple-A-rated debt.

headline: As Defense, a Handwritten Lesson on Senate Procedure
text: WASHINGTON — Senator John Boozman, Republican of Arkansas, took the unusual step of publicly releasing a handwritten letter to constituents explaining his choice on a procedural vote on stopgap spending legislation last week. Mr. Boozman, first elected in 2010, was one of 25 Republican senators who joined all of the Senate’s Democrats in voting to cut off debate on the measure. After that cloture vote, the Senate removed language in the spending bill that would have defunded the new health care law on a party-line vote. Mr. Boozman voted against removing the House-passed defunding provision, and against final passage of the spending bill itself.

headline: Pursuing a New Path Down the Aisle
text: Last Monday, Kathryn Ho received a text from her sister: Have you called the hotel to see what happens if the government shuts down?

headline: Shhh. Silence Being Observed.
text: There’s been a lot of noise about silence lately. Last month, art and music lovers poured into an Upper East Side church to hear the first New York performance of Yves Klein’s “Monotone-Silence Symphony,” a composition conceived around 1947, featuring a D chord followed by 20 minutes of silence. Around that time John Cage composed “4’33”,” first performed in August 1952, when the pianist David Tudor sat at a piano on a stage in Woodstock, N.Y., stopwatch in hand, without playing a single note. For 4 minutes 33 seconds, nothing but ambient sound could be heard.

headline: How to Find Sugar Man
text: Maybe you are a person who is looking to feel good. Nothing wrong with that, inherently. It’s not an aesthetic, per se, but it is a worldview. A person like that would find himself in good company at Barclays Center on Wednesday to see Rodriguez, owner of a feel-good story if e’er there were one.

headline: Still Duke, With Cracks
text: There was a time in the postwar era when John Wayne wasn’t merely a brawny block of granite, when his men of action were pocked with character flaws. (James Stewart found his own dark shadows in the same period.) John Ford questioned Wayne’s imperious nobility with “The Searchers” (1956), but Howard Hawks got there first, with “Red River” (1948), playing at the Museum of the Moving Image on Friday as part of its Complete Howard Hawks series.

headline: Video: A New Life, Furloughed
text: Katherine Buckingham, a furloughed FEMA employee, is counting the days of the federal government shutdown until she can get back to work.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Return of ‘The Nose’
text: Happily, the Metropolitan Opera has brought back its brilliant production “The Nose,” by Shostakovich, a hit of the 2010 season. Based on Gogol’s absurdist story, the production is by the South African artist William Kentridge, who incorporates his trademark films into his staging. The baritone Paulo Szot, who made a noteworthy house debut as the hapless, noseless bureaucrat Kovalyov, returns. Valery Gergiev conducts the sardonic score. (8 p.m. Tuesday and 1 p.m. Saturday, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, 212-362-6000, metoperafamily.org.)

headline: Two People and the Darkness
text: Certainly October dance in New York features the heavyweights — American Ballet Theater, the Forsythe Company and San Francisco Ballet among them — but there’s a potentially more elegant offering in the mix. The dazzling improvisation artists Lisa Nelson and Steve Paxton, who met in 1972 at Bennington College, reunite to present “Night Stand,” which opens at Dia:Chelsea on Thursday.

headline: The U.S. Has Defaulted Before
text: When it comes to debt delinquency, Americans have short memories. But then so do many other countries.

headline: Twitter’s R.&D. Spending Hits the Spot
text: Twitter’s research and development spending may be sky-high, but it hits the right spot. At 44 percent of revenue in the first half of the year, the microblogging site is spending far more as a proportion of its top line than Facebook. But with a lower number of users than its rival, Twitter needs to grow to make new investors happy.

headline: Back to School, With New Teachers
text: Can the right teacher make the difference between failure and success? Imagine learning about civil rights from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, economics from the financial expert Suze Orman and music from the producer Swizz Beatz. “Dream School,” a series beginning Monday night at 10 on the Sundance Channel, offers 15 Los Angeles dropouts — 17- and 18-year-olds whose educational trajectories were sidelined by pregnancy, bullying and neglect — a chance to start over by gleaning information, and not a little inspiration, from superstars.

headline: Letterman to Stay at CBS Through 2015
text: CBS announced on Friday that it had extended the contract of David Letterman to continue as the network’s late-night star through 2015.

headline: Big Ticket | Gravity-Defying Vistas for $15 Million
text: A floor-through combination unit at the Trump Palace with six terraces and gravity-defying vistas of the cityscape and Central Park sold for $15 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The four-bedroom, three-bath residence, No. 47A/B, had an initial asking price of $16.95 million and has monthly carrying charges of $14,425.

headline: T FALL TRAVEL
text: Over the past half century, an odd mix of swamis, monks, Zen masters and utopians have secured thousands of acres of prime California real estate to make sanctuaries for those seeking to escape the world. Welcome to God’s country.

headline: Sense and Superstition
text: SUPERSTITIOUS people do all sorts of puzzling things. But it’s not just the superstitious who knock on wood. From time to time, we all rap our knuckles on a nearby table if we happen to let fate-tempting words slip out. “The cancer is in remission, knock on wood,” we might say.

headline: Exclusive | 101 Central Park West
text: A gracious four-bedroom prewar duplex, owed by one family for 21 years, is about to enter the market at $12.25 million.

headline: On the Upper West Side: Haute Yet Homey
text: A gracefully renovated Upper West Side duplex that retains its homey prewar charms — original beamed ceilings and crown moldings — while providing an elegant palette for entertaining, thanks to an exacting makeover by the architect Annabelle Selldorf and the interior designer Victoria Hagan, is poised to enter the market for the first time in more than two decades.

headline: A Woman Whose Passion Made Her Dangerous
text: Lovers of Victorian literature who treasure George Eliot and her writing will find the novelist depicted with dignity and ample biographical detail in Cathy Tempelsman’s “A Most Dangerous Woman.”

headline: Beets, Raw and Cooked
text: This is one of those salads where the grain enhances texture and adds a nutritional punch, but isn’t what the salad is about. It’s about beets and spinach. I usually slice beets for salads, or cut them into wedges. But here I cut them into very small dice, so the quinoa/beets/walnuts/blue cheese mixture comes together in particularly appealing bites.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Green Heart Solved
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 76-year-old man with many medical problems who was found to have a green-colored heart during a routine bypass surgery. We asked our readers to look at all the patient’s recent medical problems in order to figure out why his heart was turning this odd color. In addition, we asked that you tell us how the surgeon proved the diagnosis. The correct diagnosis is…

headline: Across a Crowded Room
text: It took nothing less than an oil spill of monumental proportions to bring Philippe Cousteau Jr., an explorer and environmental activist, into contact with Ashlan Gorse, then  a correspondent for the cable television show “E! News.”

headline: Government Shutdown Changes  a T. Rex’s Travel Plans

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ on Fox Is First New Show to Be Renewed
text: Fox’s “Sleepy Hollow” has become the first of this fall’s batch of new network television shows to be renewed for a second season.

headline: To Stop the Craziness in Washington, Fund the Census
text: No one knows how the latest shutdown plus debt ceiling farce will end. But there is a way to try to stop the craziness from happening over and over again: Fund the census.

headline: Pastas for Fall
text: This week, Martha Rose Shulman takes the last of her summer vegetables to make fast and delicious pasta for a healthful fall meal. She writes:

text: If the Academy Awards were a horse race, the Hamptons International Film Festival, taking place for the 21st time from Oct. 10 to 14, would be quite the handicapper.

headline: National Parks Closed, Indian Lands Open
text: MOENKOPI, Ariz. — Keith Riddle and Merilyn Lassman had planned to celebrate their retirement with a visit to the Grand Canyon — “a lifelong dream of ours,” she said. But because of the government shutdown, and the closing of the entire national park system, they found themselves instead in this village on the Hopi Indian reservation, learning about a people they had known almost nothing about.

headline: Toyota’s Everycar, Straining to Get Noticed
text: The 2014 Corolla has emerged longer, lower, wider and just a little bit wilder. But it still risks getting lost in the crowded compact-sedan class.

text: NASA’s next Mars mission is getting to the launching pad, government shutdown or not.

headline: Lockheed Martin Furloughs 3,000 Workers
text: Lockheed Martin, the nation’s largest military company, said it would furlough 3,000 workers on Monday, and it expected that number to increase.

headline: Dealing a Blow to Berlusconi, an Italian Senate Panel Recommends His Expulsion
text: ROME — A special panel of the Italian Senate on Friday voted to strip Silvio Berlusconi of his current seat, a humiliating blow for a man who has dominated Italy for the past two decades but whose political career is now very much in jeopardy.

headline: Riots in Kenya After Killing of Muslim Cleric
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Deadly riots broke out in the coastal city of Mombasa on Friday morning after a popular but controversial Muslim cleric was fatally shot in what his followers said they believed was an attack by the security services.

text: Mr. Reinhart, former head of the Federal Reserve’s monetary division, is the managing director and chief United States economist for Morgan Stanley.

text: WASHINGTON — One of history’s greatest predators has fallen victim to Congressional gridlock.

headline: Clinton Says She’ll Probably Weigh 2016 Bid ‘Sometime Next Year’
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin to seriously consider a run for president “sometime next year,” she told a group of Long Island business people on Friday.

headline: Ireland Votes on Shutting Its Senate
text: DUBLIN — Ireland’s voters had a chance on Friday to accomplish what some American voters, with their government partly shut down, can only dream of: abolishing one house of the nation’s legislature. And the Irish were expected to vote to do so.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Italy, Bahrain, Kenya and France.

headline: Desperation Fuels Trips of Migrants to Spain
text: TARIFA, Spain — The southern tip of Spain is barely nine miles from the coast of Morocco, a distance so tantalizingly close that African migrants trying to reach Europe can see the Continent from the Moroccan shoreline.

headline: Police Officer in Brazil Jokes on Facebook About Breaking Truncheon Over Protester
text: A police officer in Rio de Janeiro faces disciplinary measures after posting a self-portrait on Facebook in which he held a broken baton and suggested that he had snapped it on the body of a striking teacher during a crackdown on protesters this week.

headline: What to Do When Asked to Accent Beethoven
text: Orchestra programs that pair a new work with a Beethoven symphony have become increasingly common. For the New York Philharmonic’s concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, the conductor Alan Gilbert took that idea to another level.

headline: Richards’s New Start as Rangers Left Wing Begins Well
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Brad Richards was annoyed at the question, which he has been asked repeatedly for the past few weeks.

headline: A Stew in Touch With Its Wild Side
text: Suppose you are craving wild mushrooms. In a perfect world, if you actually did trek into a forest, and knew where to go and knew what to look for, you might happen upon an enclave of golden chanterelles just waiting to be picked. The yellow beauties would jump into your basket at the touch of a pocketknife blade.

headline: Review: 2014 Toyota Corolla LE Premium
text: Known for reliability, not passion, the 2013 Toyota Corolla was past its prime. Tom Voelk and his neighbor Dick check out the 11th-generation 2014 model to find out if it’s back in fighting form.

headline: In a Quick Parole, Some See an Unwelcome Message
text: “Almost everything about this case makes me sad — and angry,’’ wrote Nora OBrien-Suric, a senior program officer for The John A. Hartford Foundation, in a recent blog post entitled “A Sordid Criminal Case Raises Important Geriatric Issues.’’

headline: Faithful Companion, Hiding in Plain Sight
text: SAN DIEGO — If the previous 2013 Toyota Corolla were an actor, it would be the faithful sidekick: the average Joe who always comes through, no matter what scrapes his buddy — the flashy, daring, irresponsible star — gets them into.

headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Mulls Transfer to State
text: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose collection has become a target of creditors in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy case, is formulating a proposal to protect the museum that might include asking Michigan’s governor, Rick Snyder, to consider state take-over of the city-owned museum, the Detroit Free Press reported.Many of the masterpieces in the museum’s collection are being appraised by Christie’s auction house at the behest of Kevyn Orr, Detroit’s emergency manager, who has said that he has no intention of selling the art but that none of the city’s assets can be taken off the table as the bankruptcy case proceeds.The new proposal would ask the state to begin providing substantial funding to the museum that would allow the museum to provide money to the city that might otherwise be found only by selling art. At a business luncheon on Thursday in Detroit, Mr. Orr said that the museum might consider long-term leases of art works as another way of avoiding any sale. “I’m deferring to them to save themselves,” he told business leaders, referring to the institute.

headline: Spotlight on Godard
text: Images from select films in the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Jean-Luc Godard retrospective.

headline: The First Time
text: For its Sex Issue, The New York Times Book Review spoke to several authors, including Sam Lipsyte and Alison Bechdel, about their first illicit reading experience. More than 200 readers then shared memories of their “first times” with us online. So I asked a few people at The Times if they would like to join the growing chorus, and here’s what they said:

headline: A Closer Look at Harvard’s Choice on Fossil Fuels
text: Updated, Oct. 15, 9:29 p.m. | The student effort to get universities and colleges to sell off their investments in companies hawking fossil fuels continues, as can be seen in the Twitter item and photo above from Bard College.

headline: One More Time, Clawing Their Way to a Verdict
text: Here are two ways to tell that “Twelve Angry Men” is set in the 1950s: First, someone produces a pack of cigarettes in a jury room, and no one says it is against the law to light up. Later, in a discussion about going to the movies, a “second feature” is mentioned, as though the audience always got to watch two films for the price of one.

headline: Pirates Rebound by Stifling the Cardinals’ Powerful Lineup
text: ST. LOUIS — Pittsburgh led St. Louis by 5-1 in the bottom of the sixth inning Friday, but Game 2 of their National League division series was far from decided. The Pirates’ starter, Gerrit Cole, had given up a flyout to the wall to start the inning, then walked Matt Carpenter. Fans at Busch Stadium — a red-clad capacity crowd announced at 45,999 — stood, roared and waved white towels as the perennial postseason star Carlos Beltran strode to the plate.

headline: De Blasio Speech Excerpt
text: Bill de Blasio spoke to a standing-room-only crowd on Friday, laying out his vision for making New York City more equitable. The following is a clip from that speech.

headline: Economic Confidence Plummets
text: Economic confidence has taken a nosedive in the last few days, reaching its lowest three-day rolling average since December 2011.

headline: Metro-North to Resume Full Service on Monday
text: The Metro-North Railroad is expected to return its New Haven line to full service by Monday, transit officials said, nearly two weeks after a power loss in Mount Vernon, N.Y., upended commutes for tens of thousands of travelers across the Northeast.

headline: An Inaugural Solo Effort, and Plenty of Teamwork
text: William Winant

headline: Yankees Make a Contract Offer to Girardi
text: With other teams peering in from the outside, the Yankees made a contract offer to Manager Joe Girardi on Friday, and expect to find out within a few days whether a deal is likely to be reached.

text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: After Hoping to Avoid It, Harvey Will Have Surgery
text: The Mets had promised: 2014 would be their year. They had the pitching. They had David Wright. They had Matt Harvey. They said they would spend money. It would all come together next year, they hoped, and they would be contenders again, at last.

headline: Gathered Acts of an Auteur Provocateur
text: Plus ça change, plus c’est la même chose. No filmmaker was more identified with the New York Film Festival’s first decade than Jean-Luc Godard; now entering its second half-century with a new programming director, Kent Jones, the festival is poised to begin New York’s first comprehensive retrospective devoted to ... Jean-Luc Godard.

headline: Elbowing Aside Vampires and Zombies
text: BURNABY, British Columbia — Evidence of witchcraft was all over the house — actually a soundstage in suburban Vancouver. A wine glass full of feathers. Apothecary bottles filled with dried roots and herbs. The bodies of beetles and scorpions, neatly mounted under glass. A wooden light fixture whose frame, when viewed from a certain angle, suggested a pentagram.

headline: Once More Into the Breeches
text: Is there a classic play more macho than Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar”? A tragedy of men’s frustrations, desires and actions, it offers just two small speaking roles for women. The word “men” occurs 54 times in the script, more than in any other Shakespeare play.

headline: Squatters’ Paradise Lost
text: Ash Thayer photographed life in several buildings in the East Village area that were occupied by squatters in the 1990s.

headline: A Soprano Braving the Shoals, Like a Stoical Isolde
text: The soprano Deborah Voigt is still wondering whether, during a crisis in confidence, she made the right decision last month to withdraw from the season-opening production of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” at the Washington National Opera. She had sung Isolde to acclaim in important productions over the previous 10 years. But last month, she found the long, punishing role beyond her current vocal capacities.

headline: Big Executive Moves Within Hispanic Media
text: The Hispanic media world was active on Friday with the announcement of executive changes at Telemundo, owned by NBCUniversal, and Fusion, the new English-language joint venture between the Disney-ABC Television Network and Univision Communications aimed at millennials.

headline: Cuba in America, Unbound
text: The pianist Michele Rosewoman’s long-running project New Yor-Uba, which she revived for a new album and two nights of performances at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola, still looks good on paper and sounds better in practice.

headline: Long, Strange Trip Ends for a Symbol of the ’60s
text: For many Americans, they prompt images of hippies and surfers, or perhaps memories of wholesome camping holidays. Europeans may associate them more with the police or parcel delivery. As for their name, take your pick: Type 2, T2, Kombi, Transporter, Bulli, Micro Bus, Samba Minibus, Vanagon, Caravelle, Clipper L.

headline: Adopted by Neighbors, a VW Camper Spreads Happiness
text: Sitting in the living room of her family’s 19th-century colonial home, Lesley Fowks recalled the day in 2002 that her son, Ian Brady, burst in with an announcement: the rusting 1977 Volkswagen camper van sitting in the side yard of a nearby house could be his “for free.”

text: With a little persistence, some elbow grease and a mom’s support, a young man’s dream car — in this case a VW camper van — was brought back to life.

text: PIERCE, NEB. — It was early in the bidding, and the auctioneer was still warming her pitch — and trying to fire up the crowd of thousands around her mobile stage, a flatbed trailer in a soybean field in the middle of the country.

headline: A Lantern to Show the Way
text: When the owners of the creative agency Fuzzco moved offices, they didn’t want to let their old work space go to waste. So they transformed it into the Pretend Store, a pop-up shop at 85½ Spring Street in Charleston, S.C., that will feature goods from a different design firm every month for the next three months. Each edition will also introduce a special collaborative product designed by Fuzzco and its guests.

headline: Week in Pictures for Oct. 4
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include stabbings on the Upper West Side, a monument at Grand Army Plaza, and the effects of the government shutdown on city beaches.

headline: Annotations on a Speech
text: Bill de Blasio on Friday delivered his most detailed blueprint yet for how he hopes to make New York a more equitable and inclusive city. Read the entire text of his speech here, as delivered, with annotations for context and clarity.

headline: No News Is Good News
text: Five days a week, Pat Kiernan, the morning news anchor for NY1, is awake before dawn, rushing from his brownstone in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to his station’s studios in Chelsea, where his broadcasts help the rest of us get ready for our day. It’s no surprise, then, that on the weekends, Mr. Kiernan, 45, likes to relax close to home with his wife, Dawn, a client-service representative for Nielsen, the television research firm, and with their daughters, Lucy, 11, and Maeve, 9. “On Sundays especially, I get to live on a more or less human schedule,” he said. But the reprieve is short-lived, and work invariably returns early Monday.

headline: Audrey Gelman, the Girl Most Likely
text: If you had to pick a low point for Scott Stringer in his recent David-versus-Goliath race against Eliot Spitzer for New York City comptroller, it would have been in early August. Mr. Spitzer, the scandal-plagued ex-governor, had a 15-point lead in the polls, coming off appearances on Jay Leno and Bill Maher.

headline: The Wages of Pop Music
text: A J Michalka, the star of “Grace Unplugged,” used to record with her sister in the teen-pop duo Aly and A J. (They now perform as 78Violet.) The songs were sturdy, melodic and espoused wholesome self-reliance. Aly went on to embody female independence in the charming film “Bandslam” and the TV series “Hellcats.” A J, alas, has succumbed to “Grace Unplugged,” which feels like a religious tract more than a movie.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom colonial in Glen Cove and another in Rye with five bedrooms.

headline: Loud, Brash, Raunchy: And Not Just the Clothes
text: Supermodels, drugs, clothes that emphasize a woman’s curves, a murder at the hands of a spree killer, a family riven by a spiteful will: the details of the Versace fashion empire have the makings of a fantastic HBO mini-series.

headline: The Lure of the ‘Savage,’ Deconstructed and Reassembled
text: Before we see a body, we are greeted with words. In “rite riot,” a new work by Nora Chipaumire performed Thursday at Le Skyroom at the French Institute-Alliance Française, Ms. Chipaumire is referred to as an “exotic installation” in the sarcastic text, which scrolls across a piece of fabric hanging from a wall and stretching across the floor. She is “notoriously dangerous, savage” and “bares her teeth and other body parts while in performance.”

headline: Friday Night Music: More Lucius

headline: Aging, Coming of Age, and Vampires
text: With 13 main-slate features to go between now and next Sunday, the last week of the New York Film Festival reinforces the impression that this is an exceptionally wide-ranging, even sprawling event. You could say that the festival, in its 51st edition, has one foot in the high end of the American commercial mainstream, and another in the realm of international art cinema.

headline: Questions Often Asked About Health Law
text: Millions of consumers rushed to the online health care exchanges on Tuesday only to be greeted with long waits and frustrating error messages.

headline: Why Fashion Films Are Usually Cartoons
text: During the 1990s, when access to fashion designers and their families was fairly easy, I learned one or two things about these glamorous creatures that I’ve tried to keep in mind.

headline: Mobsters, Urban Design and Murals
text: Arguably, he was the biggest mob informer since Joseph Valachi testified before Congress in 1963. And in “Mob Boss: The Life of Little Al D’Arco, the Man Who Brought Down the Mafia” (Thomas Dunne Books, $27.99), the veteran crime reporters Jerry Capeci and Tom Robbins spin a gripping, novelistic biography of the diminutive man behind the big mouth.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Gramercy Park area co-op, a Turtle Bay loft and a Kensington apartment.

headline: Better Sharpen Your Talons, Country Girl
text: If soap opera could be sold by the yard, “The Paradise” would be a bolt of beaded polyester chiffon. It’s not silk, but if you’re looking for something a little sexy on a budget, it’ll do.

headline: Morrissey Autobiography on Its Way, Again
text: Morrissey once sang: “You say that the day just never arrives/And it’s never seemed so far away/Still I know it’s gonna happen someday.” His fans could apply those lyrics to the publication of the singer’s autobiography, which is to be published in Britain by Penguin Classics on Oct. 17.

headline: Transnational Teams in Bali
text: The Transnational Teams world championship in Bali, Indonesia, last month was for teams that had not qualified for the knockout stage of the Bermuda Bowl, Venice Cup or d’Orsi Senior Trophy, and for anyone willing to travel to that beautiful island in the South Pacific.

headline: Editor’s Letter | The Journey
text: IN OUR SIGN OF THE TIMES ESSAY this month, our columnist Andrew O’Hagan takes on the notion that “good” is often really good enough, particularly when it comes to travel. In this age of bucket lists and extreme travel, in which we seek the extraordinary, the unique, the rare — longing to rocket into space or plummet beneath the sea — O’Hagan wonders if we’ve forgotten that the real value of travel is simply pleasure and inspiration. He makes the case that “the Ultimate Experience now poses a threat to the kind of small revelations that make us happy.” These we often find if we are looking where we might not expect.

headline: Daughters Inheriting the Practice
text: The latest additions to the witch infestation sweeping through the fall television season are delightful company, a welcome relief from the rather humorless witches and possible witches who have already turned up in shows like “The White Queen,” “Sleepy Hollow” and “The Originals.”

headline: The Nodding Ladies’-Tresses Orchid, Ever Young
text: Every autumn there are one or two perfect days when winds from the north sweep summer south, combing the season’s thick clouds into mare’s-tails and sending its insects, birds and milkweed seeds packing. Recently, on a day like this, I stood in a scruffy Bronx field. Summer’s last pink flowers and goldenrods’ chrome yellow blooms were intertwined with the brick-red leaves and frosty blue berries of Virginia creeper. There was a biting chill in the air that heightened the earthy, sour scent of leaves decomposing.

headline: Man on Fire Is Hospitalized in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — A week in which the capital was first shaken by a shutdown of the federal government and then rattled by a car chase and shooting on Capitol Hill ended Friday with scenes of a medical helicopter evacuating a man who the police believed set himself on fire on the National Mall.

headline: Gulf Coast Storm Pulls Federal Workers Off Furlough
text: NEW ORLEANS — Arriving in the waning weeks of a quiet hurricane season, Tropical Storm Karen chugged its way toward the Gulf Coast on Friday, prompting the usual preparations and drawing federal response workers out of furloughs.

headline: What Asthma Drugs Cost Us
text: Robin Levi’s two daughters both have drug-controlled asthma, thanks to top tier insurance. The students she tutors also have asthma but lack the same insurance and medical care.

headline: ‘Minnesota Nice’ Infuses the Night Life in Minneapolis
text: Another installment of “Tribes of Saturday Night,” a look at mating rituals around the country.

headline: What Was Past, and What Was Modern: Post-World War I Works
text: Carnegie Hall’s 2013-14 season kicked off Thursday evening with the American Symphony Orchestra and a program from an alternate universe.

headline: How Twitter’s I.P.O. Filing Evolved to Contain New Details
text: Laying the groundwork for its initial public offering, Twitter on Thursday filed a regulatory document that contains important details about its business.

headline: The Dating Scene? Hip, With a Bit of ‘Minnesota Nice’
text: MINNEAPOLIS — As night-life emissaries go, one could do worse than Robert John Wayne, a 31-year-old artist here who happily told a recent visitor about everything from an indigenous delicacy called the Juicy Lucy (a burger with cheese baked into the patty) to what women want, something Mr. Wayne should know, seeing as how he’s dating four of them.

headline: Asthma: The Hayes
text: Hannah and Abby Hayes discuss activities they can enjoy because of the drugs they take to manage their asthma.

headline: Asthma: The Pitres
text: Donza and Kemmoni Petri discuss their allergies, asthma and the drugs they take to keep their diseases in check.

headline: T Fall Travel Issue
text: The concept of leisurely travel has been in flux in recent times. As Andrew O’Hagan points out in his essay, the concept of “fine,” or perhaps “good enough,” has been lost in an age of “awesome” superlatives and extreme travel. In T Magazine’s Fall Travel issue, we discover a more contemplative mode of getting there, and being there, whether the destination is a place or something less defined. Whether with Michael Kimmelman finding Marseille, France, despite a slew of ambitious development projects, as gloriously scrappy as ever, or with the surreal and severe beauty of Craig McDean’s portraits from Iceland’s wilderness, a sense of really being present, a sense of place, is more important than a contrived sense of adventure. We also explore the Restoration Hardware tycoon Gary Friedman’s desire to become a force of disruption in the contemporary art world, a resurgence in appreciation for almost-forgotten Indian Modernist furniture and a family’s attempt to reinvigorate one of Britain’s most famous gardens by restoring its traditional agriculture. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Novels Pillorying Black Church Find Readers in Pews
text: DECATUR, Ga. — Kimberla Lawson Roby stood near the pulpit of a Baptist church in this Atlanta suburb one Saturday in late August, giving her testimony. She spoke of infidelities, mistresses, blackmail, out-of-wedlock children and extravagant spending. She did so as neither minister or worshiper, but rather as a novelist telling scores of rapt fans about her fictional characters.

headline: Chinny-Chin-Chins? Maybe It’s the Software
text: The answer: six.

headline: From Classic to Spiky, Earthy to Ethereal
text: Concert Artists Guild, which manages and promotes rising classical performers, is well aware of the challenges its musicians face as they embark on their careers. Stable, dependable engagements may well be a thing of the past, and it is necessary to think beyond the same traditional halls.

headline: New Music Bonds With Vintage Images
text: At a time when we are awash in a constant deluge of digital images shared by friends and strangers through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Flickr, it can be hard to recall when we were less instantly and intimately connected. In the 1970s, though, the world was still analog. Most photographs needed developing, usually by specialists. You posted an image by sticking it in an envelope, then into a mailbox. Sharing photos meant passing prints from hand to hand, or maybe gathering in a darkened den to dutifully watch while a relative or neighbor showed vacation slides.

headline: The Benefits of Intransigence
text: IF the government shutdown has shown us anything, it’s that the 80 or so House Republicans driving the crisis have emerged as the most unified force in politics: tightly organized, highly disciplined and ideologically firm.

headline: Twitter Bios and What They Really Say
text: “Wife, mom, lawyer, women & kids advocate, FLOAR, FLOTUS, US Senator, SecState, author,” reads Hillary Clinton’s Twitter bio, before veering off: “dog owner, hair icon, pantsuit aficionado, glass ceiling cracker, TBD ...” Written after she joined the microblogging service in June, those descriptors earned raves.

headline: Man on Fire on National Mall
text: Witnesses called emergency operators as bystanders tried to extinguish the flames using their own clothing.

headline: Louis Vuitton Revives Travel for the Genteel
text: PARIS — When you walk into L’Aventure, Louis Vuitton’s pop-up store next to the luxury brand’s Rue de Montaigne boutique, you are supposed to feel as if you have entered a stylish travel agency from the golden age of the grand tour, when Thomas Cook was king and wealthy travelers would think nothing of dragging along a dozen trunks on their journey.

headline: São Paulo Parties on the Hudson
text: To celebrate Arthur Medeiros’s third birthday last year, there was a three-course brunch for a dozen guests at the Hotel Plaza Athénée’s private dining room, which was expertly decorated to look like a scene from the movie “The Lion King,” complete with elaborate mini-jungle centerpieces. This was followed by another party at Dylan’s Candy Bar, and then the climax: a trip to see “The Lion King” on Broadway.

headline: Which Type of Therapy Works Best?
Index of Happiness? Bhutan’s New Leader Prefers More Concrete Goals
text: THIMPHU, Bhutan — “I think I can take President Obama one on one in basketball,” Bhutan’s newly elected prime minister said recently in an interview. “I’ve got some special moves.”

headline: Making Over Clergy Fashion
text: Stephen Fendler, president of CM Almy, shows off a rack of samples from his brand-new women’s collection, pointing out a piece he’s particularly proud of: a black blouse in a stretchy jersey knit.

headline: Guns and Children: A Dangerous Combination
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Group Moves to Develop Global Airline Emission Rules
text: BRUSSELS — Transportation officials from around the world on Friday reached a preliminary agreement to develop global rules by the end of the decade that would control airline emissions. The action by the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations body, represents the first major move toward industrywide rules to limit carbon pollution.

headline: Saudi Arabia: New Infections Raise Virus Cases to 136
text: Saudi Arabia has confirmed six new infections from the potentially fatal MERS virus, the World Health Organization reported Friday, raising the total number of cases worldwide to 136. Most of the cases, which have resulted in 58 deaths, have been in Saudi Arabia. The latest cases, the W.H.O. said in a statement, afflicted three men and three women, all from the Riyadh region. MERS stands for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. It is believed to be spread by bats and possibly camels. The concentration of MERS cases in Saudi Arabia has raised concern about the possible spread of the infection during the annual pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina later this month, when millions of Muslims from around the world visit the kingdom.

headline: How the Shutdown Hurts the Naval Academy

text: To the Editor:

headline: At the Trial of a Psychic, It’s Awkward for Her Clients
text: It is one thing, after having forked over tens of thousands of dollars to a psychic who warned that you had evil spirits blocking your happiness, to become suspicious and demand a refund. And, when that does not happen, to go to the police and swear out a complaint.

headline: On the Baseball Beat
text: “That’s Andrew McCutchen — he has a sock fetish, he collects them,” said Haley Smilow, pointing out the center fielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates as he batted Tuesday night in the National League wild-card game against the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. A recent F.Y.I. item mentioned that Batman was created by Bob Kane and Bill Finger, who worked out the character during an hour spent in Poe Park in the Bronx. I’ve heard of Bob Kane, but not Bill Finger. Can you tell me about him?

headline: The Netherlands: Greenpeace Activists Gain an Ally
text: Foreign Minister Frans Timmermans said Friday that the Netherlands intended to press a case against Russia in the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea for seizing a Greenpeace International ship, the Arctic Sunrise, which was sailing under a Dutch flag. Russian prosecutors this week filed piracy charges against all 28 members of the crew and 2 freelance journalists. The Dutch government called the detentions unlawful. Greenpeace issued a statement praising the decision as an important symbol of support for its activists, who are being held in a jail in the Arctic Ocean port city of Murmansk.

headline: Biker Was Playing Peacemaker When S.U.V. Hit Him, Lawyer Says
text: The man most seriously injured in an encounter between a swarm of motorcyclists and a family in an S.U.V. on the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan on Sunday was playing the role of a peacemaker, his lawyer said on Friday.

headline: Where Cowboys Roam
text: This sounds like the premise for a sitcom or a reality TV show: A straight couple opens a gay bar.

headline: 6 Die in Egypt as Islamist Opposition Tries to Re-energize Movement
text: CAIRO — At least six people were killed in political violence in Egypt on Friday in the buildup to a much-anticipated day of protests on Sunday calling for a rollback of the recent military takeover.

headline: Tardy Deliveries Keep New Books Out of Teachers’ Hands
text: Because all of the books associated with their new English curriculum have not yet arrived, teachers at Public School 125 in West Harlem have been pulling last year’s texts from storage, dusting them off and handing them out, even though they are not considered rigorous enough for the revised standards.

headline: Amid Questions, Town Welcomes a New College
text: WINGDALE, N.Y. — For 20 years, the 80 brick buildings of what was once the Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center have lain fallow, their weathered faces hidden by untamed vines, their windows buckling, their emerald lawns turning to weeds.

headline: Harry Macklowe Gambles Again
text: Harry Macklowe wanted to go higher. “Another story up?” he offered with a smile.

headline: For Coach, Seizures Are Mere Distractions
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Immediately after Jerry Kill has a seizure on the sideline, one longtime assistant takes over the headset and communicates with officials. The defensive coordinator handles the postgame news conference and splits the remaining news media obligations with the offensive coordinator. Should Kill miss practice, they revert to their schedule from a week earlier, with adjustments based on their next opponent.

headline: Hagel’s Week in Asia, Complete With Talk of Drones and Fiscal Standoff
text: ABOARD A U.S. MILITARY JET — Within the same hour that the White House announced that President Obama was scuttling the remainder of his long-planned trip to Asia because of the government shutdown, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was ending a weeklong trip to South Korea and Japan, as part of the administration’s continuing — and vexed — attempt to refocus defense, economic and diplomatic interests in the region.

headline: Upstart Abu Dhabi Airline Becomes Ally to European Carriers
text: PARIS — Just a few years ago, James Hogan, the chief executive of Etihad Airways, probably would have had trouble scoring a meeting with one of his European counterparts. These days, however, it seems he’s never been so popular.

headline: Boehner Urges G.O.P. Unity in ‘Epic Battle’
text: WASHINGTON — With his troops anxious for a way forward, Speaker John A. Boehner began a closed-door meeting of House Republicans on Friday morning with a recitation of letters from local schoolchildren on how they deal with stress.

headline: Cutting the Lean From Food Stamps
text: Many years ago a Korean man named Francis An arrived in New York via Argentina and observed that many communities in the city lacked the sort of grocery stores that could supply immigrants with the foods they were accustomed to in their native countries. He would eventually open a chain of supermarkets under the corporate name Bogopa, which in Korean means “yearning for you,” in low-income neighborhoods.

text: Speaker John Boehner barked Friday about the government shutdown: “This isn’t some damn game.”

text: Ever since winning his party’s primary on Sept. 10, Bill de Blasio, the Democratic nominee for New York City mayor, has reduced his public appearances significantly, in part because he has been busy raising money for the general election.
