headline: Curtain Is Rising on a Tech Premiere With (as Usual) a Mostly Male Cast
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter’s financial filing for its Wall Street debut was chock-full of juicy tidbits, from the name of its richest founder to a list of its escalating losses. But one revelation was particularly startling: Just a single woman among its top officials.

headline: Lawrence Goodwyn, Historian of Populism, Dies at 85
text: Lawrence Goodwyn, whose experience building cross-racial political coalitions in the 1960s led him to write an authoritative history of the rise of American populism in the 19th century, died Sunday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 85.

headline: Maximilian in Mexico
text: On Oct. 3, 1863, a Mexican delegation arrived in the Austrian port city of Trieste to officially offer Mexico’s imperial crown to the 31-year-old Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian, a scion of the Austrian branch of the Hapsburg royal family and the brother of the Austrian emperor, Franz Josef I.

headline: United States Has Lead in Tournament Slowed by Rain
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — After two days, it would appear the greatest obstacle in the United States team’s march to another Presidents Cup title might be the weather.

headline: Frankenstein Goes to Congress
text: Our question for today is: Why don’t the Republicans just throw in the towel? Really, this is not going well for anybody.

headline: Supervisors of Navy Yard Gunman Were Told of Issues
text: The mother of Aaron Alexis, the military contractor who killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard last month, told his bosses one month before the shootings that he had a history of paranoid episodes and most likely needed therapy. But Mr. Alexis’ managers at the Experts Inc., an information technology firm, decided to keep him on the job and did not require him to seek treatment, an internal company investigation has found.

headline: ‘Minnesota Nice’ Infuses the Night Life in Minneapolis
text: Another installment of “Tribes of Saturday Night,” a look at mating rituals around the country.

headline: China’s Economy, Back on Track
text: CHICAGO — NEXT month, President Xi Jinping and Prime Minister Li Keqiang will use an important meeting — the so-called Third Plenum of the Communist Party’s 18th National Congress — to unveil China’s priorities for reforming economic policy for the next decade.

headline: Rookie’s Mistake Opens Door for Red Sox
text: BOSTON — After several innings had passed and the raw emotion and taunting chants had subsided, Dave Martinez felt it was time to find out what had happened. Five innings earlier, Wil Myers, a 22-year-old rookie outfielder for the Tampa Bay Rays, had ducked under a fly ball, allowing what should have been an easy out to drop in for a ground-rule double — the key moment in an embarrassing afternoon.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: An insider trading trial opens in Dallas, an electric car catches fire in Washington and hotel building booms in Austin, Tex.

headline: University of Mississippi Investigating Anti-Gay Heckling at Theater Performance
text: OXFORD, Miss. — Every seat in the house was sold out for Friday’s performance of “The Laramie Project,” a play staged by the University of Mississippi theater department about an anti-gay hate crime.

headline: Herman Wallace, Freed After 41 Years in Solitary, Dies at 71
text: Herman Wallace’s world for much of the last 41 years had been a solitary prison cell, 6 feet by 9 feet, when he left a Louisiana prison on Tuesday, freed by a federal judge who ruled that his original indictment in the killing of a prison guard had been unconstitutional.

headline: What Can Be Sold in 140 Characters? That’s Now the Challenge for Twitter
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Once Twitter enters life as a publicly traded company, it will have to satisfy Wall Street’s demands for constant growth.

headline: Speed of Eagles Gives Giants Pause
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Spencer Paysinger has flashbacks of sprinting and sweating and sprinting some more, the motif of practice at the University of Oregon.

headline: Migrants Cast Their Lot on a Troubled Sea
text: A rising number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are daring the waters of the Mediterranean to reach Europe.

headline: Umenyiora Urges Falcons Not to Panic
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — Breaking slowly out of the gate, while inadvisable for a team aspiring to reach the playoffs, is hardly fatal. Atlanta Falcons players who are inclined to abandon postseason hopes after a discouraging September can be disabused of the notion by listening to their newly welcomed defensive end.

headline: Shutdown Din Obscures Health Exchange Flaws
text: The shutdown of many federal operations and activities this week has obscured widespread problems in the opening of insurance exchanges under President Obama’s health care law, giving the administration time to work out the kinks, members of both parties say.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Now Republicans Want a ‘Dialogue’
text: Republicans are now simply flailing. Because they lack any plausible explanation for their irresponsible conduct in creating and prolonging the government shutdown, they are inventing new demands by the hour.

headline: Raffling Off Assault Rifles
text: The Republican Party of Rhode Island is attracting well-deserved scorn for its plan to raise money  Sunday by raffling an AR-15-style assault rifle — the same sort of modified military weapon used last December in the Newtown school massacre in neighboring Connecticut.

headline: Pent-Up Demand for Health Insurance
text: There were plenty of computer glitches when millions of Americans went online to check out their options for affordable insurance policies on the new health care exchanges that opened for business this week. It was frustrating, but it was also an indication of overwhelming interest that exceeded all predictions.

headline: A Second Chance in California
text: The California Legislature passed a bill last month that bars government agencies from asking job applicants about criminal convictions until the agency has determined that the applicant meets minimum qualifications for the job. This measure will help remove unfair barriers to employment that keep millions of qualified workers trapped at the margins of society. Gov. Jerry Brown should sign this sensible bill.

headline: A Fracking Rorschach Test
text: A few weeks ago, a group of scientists led by David T. Allen of the University of Texas published an important, peer-reviewed paper in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The subject was our old friend hydraulic fracturing — a k a fracking — that infamous process that allows companies to drill for natural gas trapped in shale formations deep below the earth’s surface.

headline: Hip Injury Ends Season of Giants Guard
text: During 10 seasons in which he missed just seven games, guard Chris Snee, the physical and spiritual anchor of the Giants’ offensive line, was always the guy who played through any infirmity, including many he never acknowledged.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 4, 2013
The Frenzied Last-Act Effort to Save City Opera
text: In the frenzied final days of New York City Opera, when it was becoming clear that an urgent drive to raise $7 million for its very survival was failing, the general manager, George Steel, found himself scrounging for money wherever he might find it.

headline: The Shifting Fortunes of ‘the People’s Opera’
text: New York City Opera, the 70-year-old company that made opera affordable to the masses, championed new work and fostered the careers of major singers, announced this week that it will close.

headline: Dodgers Fall as Mattingly Follows Convention
text: ATLANTA — Follow the conventional wisdom, the thinking goes, and a manager can always sleep easily. Even if his moves backfire, the unwritten rules must be there for a reason. They are rooted mostly in logic.

headline: Word Search Technique
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Let’s talk about memory loss. There come, at certain times of life, points at which you are required to hold so much information in your brain that the absorption of additional material requires your brain to jettison other bits of trivia, such as where I put my car keys. Sometimes you have to really rack your brain just to remember your own children’s names, not that that has ever happened to me.

headline: Booster Proud of His Largess and Game-Day Parties
text: MEMPHIS, Tenn. — Roy Adams’s two-story brick home is tucked neatly into a middle-class residential street. In the driveway, University of Tennessee and Southeastern Conference flags fly at full staff. On the front door, a poster urges his guests to adhere to a five-drink limit.

headline: Game Day for a Booster
text: Roy Adams, the well-known booster, opens his Memphis home each weekend for parties that attract one hundred or more people to watch college football.

headline: Bill Eppridge, Who Captured Powerful ’60s Images, Dies at 75
text: Bill Eppridge, an award-winning photojournalist who made his most enduring mark with a historic image of a mortally wounded Senator Robert F. Kennedy lying on the floor of a Los Angeles hotel in June 1968, died on Thursday in Danbury, Conn. He was 75.

headline: Help at Running Back? Not Much Yet
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The return of Mike Goodson from a four-week suspension would seem like found money for the Jets, providing additional depth and skill to the running game, which already has shown it can be one of the team’s strengths.

headline: Impasse With Afghanistan Raises Prospect of Total U.S. Withdrawal in 2014
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States and Afghanistan have reached an impasse in their talks over the role that American forces will play here beyond next year, officials from both countries say, raising the distinct possibility of a total withdrawal — an outcome that the Pentagon’s top military commanders dismissed just months ago.

headline: To This Tycoon, Iran Sanctions Were Like Gold
text: TEHRAN — He called himself the “economic basij,” a reference to Iran’s hard-line paramilitary organization and defender of the Islamic Revolution. He drove a black Mercedes 500 SL and wore a $30,000 watch, as befits a man who put his self-worth at $13.5 billion.

headline: Health Exchange Enrollment Improves, but Is Still Short of Target
text: A state-by-state look at enrollment in the Affordable Care Act’s health coverage.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9:05 P.M. (Showtime) THE MASTER (2012) Philip Seymour Hoffman portrays Lancaster Dodd, the leader of the Cause, a therapeutic, religion-tinged cult built around using painful questions to delve into a subject’s past and get at the root of negative emotion and destructive behavior. Joaquin Phoenix (above left, with Mr. Hoffman) plays Freddie Quell, a World War II Navy veteran and alcoholic wreck who seeks solace through Dodd’s method. And Amy Adams is Peggy Dodd, the latest of her husband’s wives and the hidden hand that guides his empire. “ ‘The Master’ is really more Freddie’s story than Dodd’s, and some of the film’s drama resides in the struggle between the two characters — and perhaps the two actors — for supremacy,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, which earned its three principals Oscar nominations. “ ‘You’ll be my protégé and my guinea pig,’ Dodd says to Freddie shortly after their first meeting. There turns out to be a lot more to it than that. They are father and son, guru and disciple, passionate friends and bitter competitors locked in a relationship whose sexual undercurrents are as palpable and mysterious as the motion of water under the surface of the ocean.” The film, he added, “is wild and enormous, its scale almost commensurate with Lancaster Dodd’s hubris and its soul nearly as restless as Freddie Quell’s. It is a movie about the lure and folly of greatness that comes as close as anything I’ve seen recently to being a great movie.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 5, 2013
text: “I knew the N.C.A.A. rules. I just didn’t care for them.”

headline: Departing Director Conducts Locked-Out Minnesota Orchestra
text: MINNEAPOLIS – It may have been the worst-kept secret in the city, early this week, that Osmo Vanska, who resigned as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra on Tuesday, would conduct the players, who have been locked out for more than a year in a labor dispute, in their self-produced concerts this weekend. Mr. Vanska’s last hurrah was finally announced on Thursday, and he led the first concert on Friday evening at the Ted Mann Concert Hall on the campus of the University of Minnesota: piano concertos by Beethoven (No. 3) and Mozart (No. 27), with Emanuel Ax as soloist; Beethoven’s heroic “Egmont” Overture; and Stravinsky’s stirring “Firebird” Suite.

headline: Scherzer Pitches Tigers Past A’s in Opener
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Max Scherzer, an easygoing Missourian with a cruel arsenal of pitches, cut down the Oakland Athletics on Friday, leading the Detroit Tigers to a 3-2 victory in the opening game of their American League division series.

headline: Kerry, at Asia Summit, Warns of Damage to U.S. Standing
text: HONG KONG — Secretary of State John Kerry, standing in for President Obama at an economic summit in Asia, warned on Saturday that the United States’ reputation was endangered because of the government shutdown, which sends the message that “we can’t get our own act together.”

headline: House Approves Back Pay for Furloughed Workers
text: WASHINGTON — The House, in a rare Saturday session, voted unanimously to guarantee that federal workers will receive back pay once the government shutdown ends, offering a promise of relief if not an actual rescue to more than 1 million government employees either furloughed or working without pay.

headline: From Iranian Ayatollah, Support for U.S. Outreach, but Also Criticism
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader expressed support on Saturday for the recent diplomatic outreach to the West by President Hassan Rouhani and his aides, but criticized some actions by the president as “inappropriate.”

headline: A Note to Readers

headline: An App That Saved 10,000 Lives
text: While most start-ups feverishly track figures like the total number of users, Ron Gutman, the founder and chief executive of the health information start-up, HealthTap, is more interested in a different data point.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Oct. 4, 2013
text: Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar from Time magazine join Charlie Herman on WNYC’s Money Talking to discuss why the stock market is holding steady despite the government shutdown. And Twitter finally opens the curtains to reveal just how much money it’s making (hint: it’s not making a profit) and how many people are using it. And in the fight for Sotheby’s, does hedge fund manager Dan Loeb have better artistic taste?

text: Presentation from EconEd conference yesterday, here (pdf).

headline: Rodriguez, Citing Missed Opportunities, Rejected the Players Union

headline: In October, Showcasing a Thriving Sport That’s Not Football
text: ATLANTA — In a happy little coincidence for a team that deserves one, the Pittsburgh Pirates have this Sunday all to themselves. The Steelers, their N.F.L. neighbors on the city’s North Shore, are off this weekend. A fall Sunday in Pittsburgh, with only baseball on the schedule? Imagine that.

headline: Deciding Who Sees Students’ Data
text: WHEN Cynthia Stevenson, the superintendent of Jefferson County, Colo., public schools, heard about a data repository called inBloom, she thought it sounded like a technological fix for one of her bigger headaches. Over the years, the Jeffco school system, as it is known, which lies west of Denver, had invested in a couple of dozen student data systems, many of which were incompatible.

headline: For the Nets’ Lone Rookie, Time for Relaxation Remains a Distant Luxury
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Mason Plumlee had curved his body and long limbs into a folding chair and was saying how cool it was having star teammates, when his eyelids began to droop and flutter.

headline: Variety: An Entire Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I used to read the dictionary, although I never got all the way through. I did not, however, give up during the A’s (see Emily Cox’s and Henry Rathvon’s funny note below), but I did skip around to read up on whatever caught my young fancy.

headline: Twitter’s Main Characters, Not Counting the Usual 140

headline: The Mets’ Promise of Cash Isn’t a Promise to Spend
text: Sandy Alderson’s comments last Monday about the Mets’ off-season spending could not have comforted fans whose patience and desire to buy tickets are understandably frayed after five consecutive years of losing.

headline: From Charlie O. to O.co Coliseum, the A’s Have History
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twenty-three framed Sports Illustrated covers line the left wall of the entrance to the cramped Oakland Athletics clubhouse at O.co Coliseum. Familiar names (Reggie Jackson to Rickey Henderson) and titles (Bash Brothers to Moneyball) belie the blandness of the concrete bowl sitting alongside Interstate 880.

headline: Some in G.O.P. Try to Pick and Choose Amid Spending Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, a hard-core leader of House conservatives who helped force a government shutdown in a fight over the scope of federal health care spending, sent out a statement on Wednesday bragging that the House had voted to “fully fund the National Institutes of Health.”

text: CAIRO — A military court on Saturday convicted an Egyptian journalist of entering a military zone without authorization and sentenced him to six months in prison, but deferred his sentence indefinitely, a mixed decision in a closely watched test of news media freedom under the new government.

text: NEW YORK — Al Jazeera wants to make its name as American as pizzaburgers.

headline: A Killing by Sudanese Security Forces Stokes the Anger of a Protest Movement
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The killing of a young pharmacist by Sudanese security forces during an antigovernment demonstration here has become a rallying cry for the protest movement that has rocked Sudan for the last two weeks, threatening the government’s grip on power.

headline: Urging Patience, Obama Says Problems With Health Care Sites Reflect Demand
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged Americans who have flocked to the new government-run Web marketplaces for health insurance policies not to give up because of the technical problems attributed to greater-than-anticipated demand. Fixes are under way, he said.

headline: U.S. Raids in Libya and Somalia Strike Terror Targets
text: CAIRO — American commandos carried out raids on Saturday in two far-flung African countries in a powerful flex of military muscle aimed at capturing fugitive terrorist suspects. American troops assisted by F.B.I. and C.I.A. agents seized a suspected leader of Al Qaeda on the streets of Tripoli, Libya, while Navy SEALs raided the seaside villa of a militant leader in a predawn firefight on the coast of Somalia.

headline: Assad Says He May Seek Re-election
text: ISTANBUL  —  President Bashar al-Assad says that he would run for another  term if his people wished him to do so, but that he needs a few more months to decide, given the rapidly changing situation in his country.

headline: At the S.E.C., a Question of Home-Court Edge
text: SINCE Mary Jo White settled in as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, lots of tough talk has emanated from the agency about enforcement priorities. Just last week, Andrew Ceresney, co-director of enforcement, told an audience in New York to expect bolder actions out of the agency, especially when it comes to penalizing individuals.

headline: Thousands Rally Nationwide in Support of an Immigration Overhaul
text: Thousands of supporters of an immigration overhaul held rallies on Saturday at more than 150 sites in 40 states, trying to pressure Congress, despite the partisan turmoil in Washington, to focus on passing a pathway to citizenship for millions of immigrants here illegally.

headline: Mugged by a Mug Shot Online
text: IN March last year, a college freshman named Maxwell Birnbaum was riding in a van filled with friends from Austin, Tex., to a spring-break rental house in Gulf Shores, Ala. As they neared their destination, the police pulled the van over, citing a faulty taillight. When an officer asked if he could search the vehicle, the driver — a fraternity brother of Mr. Birnbaum’s who quickly regretted his decision — said yes.

headline: Fund That Looked Beyond Labels and Found Winners
text: WASHINGTON may have been paralyzed by partisanship, and European economies hampered by the hangover from a nasty recession. But the developed world’s stock markets hummed along in the third quarter, allowing the managers of three of the top-performing mutual funds to find winning investments in enterprises as varied as forklift makers and food retailers.

headline: European Stocks Finally Showing Signs of Recovery
text: JUST last fall, Europe was sinking into a double-dip recession and many global investors were questioning whether the European Union would even survive. Now signs of recovery have emerged, and European stocks have been ticking higher.

text: AFTER two difficult years, emerging-market stock funds posted solid gains in the third quarter, raising hope that this once-highflying asset class may be ready to rebound.

text: Someone at the National Weather Service clearly had the Washington budget showdown in mind in writing this weather forecast, which includes a not-so-hidden message (here highlighted in a red box).

text: JITTERY investors see danger in every market thrust upward.

headline: New Books Put Finances Atop Your To-Do List
text: MAYBE it’s because so many people find the subject boring. Maybe it’s because the language is so weird, saying “basis point” when you mean one-hundredth of 1 percent and “beta” instead of volatility. Or maybe it’s simply that so many people hate math.

headline: Mutual Funds
text: Highlights of mutual fund performance in the third quarter

headline: Fund Investors, Caught in Washington’s Circus
text: POLITICS and policy dominated the markets in the third quarter, especially during an eventful, nerve-racking and surprising final few weeks that left the markets in a state of heightened uncertainty.

headline: Rich People Just Care Less
text: Turning a blind eye. Giving someone the cold shoulder. Looking down on people. Seeing right through them.

headline: Active E.T.F.’s, Still Trying to Make Waves
text: ACTIVELY managed exchange-traded funds are supposed to combine the professional investment acumen available from mutual funds with the low costs, tax advantages and ease of trading of regular E.T.F.’s.

headline: Our Sickly Political System
text: IN our journalism and our conversations, we tend to talk about things in isolation, focusing on what’s happening right now and failing to connect the dots. The present outrage becomes our complete obsession; the countless frustrations that telegraphed it fade from view. So it is with the shutdown of the federal government, which we could and should have seen coming. Which we did see coming, more or less.

headline: An Audience Without an Opera
text: Last week, the New York City Opera announced that it was closing its doors and filing for bankruptcy, ending its 70-year existence orphaned, homeless, broke and all but out on the street. It was a disappointing demise to what was once an enterprising and insouciant company, a kind of scrappy newsboy thrust among the city’s elite, thanks to Fiorello La Guardia, who founded it in 1943. Its end was as au courant as it could be — a failed Kickstarter campaign and a final performance of “Anna Nicole,” just the kind of production unlikely to turn up at the Metropolitan Opera, just the kind you might use to explain why this city needs two major opera companies.

headline: Great Betrayals
text: AS a psychiatrist I find that friends frequently seek me out to discuss problematic events in their lives; it comes with the territory and I’m usually happy to do it. But I was surprised and shaken to hear from an old friend that her husband of nearly 25 years had long been accruing and hiding from her a huge credit card debt (in the six figures). Even after divulging his secret, the husband had lied about the amount, with the sum increasing every time it was discussed. And right from the start, he refused to document where the money was spent. He left it for his wife to ruminate on, trying to puzzle it out. The disclosure wreaked financial and emotional havoc on their family.

headline: A Wolf, a Sheep, or What?
text: FOR anyone who enjoys a good metaphor, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani’s visit to the United Nations has been a field day for sheep and wolves. Rouhani has been dubbed both a “wolf in sheep’s clothing” and a “sheep in wolf’s clothing” and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel called Iran’s previous president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, “a wolf in wolf’s clothing.”

headline: Why the Bad Rap on Generic Drugs?
text: IN an episode of “Orange Is the New Black,” the Netflix series set inside a federal prison, a journalist rattles off a series of budget cuts that are making life difficult for the inmates. Closing the running track. Canceling G.E.D. classes. And switching to generic drugs.

headline: Doctors’ Bad Habits
text: RECENTLY I was talking with a patient about her glucose levels, which have been inching their way toward diabetes. She was honest that she was eating too much junk and knew perfectly well that her diet was not doing her health any favors.

headline: High Tea for Two Tourists
text: A tradition is a habit whose logic has faded. A silly thing you keep doing even when you can’t remember why, like bringing a tree inside in December, or continuing to visit family.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: A Disillusioned Citizenry
text: Readers discuss what has bred public distrust of government.

headline: Howard Stern, My Literary Idol
text: WHEN asked to name the influences on my fiction and nonfiction, it’s become fairly customary, and perhaps a little pretentious, for me to cite the literary gods Franz Kafka, Samuel Beckett and George Orwell. And while it’s not untrue to say that these three legends, who broke such fertile ground in portraying the struggle of the alienated Everyman, made me want to be a writer, I would be remiss if I didn’t acknowledge a fourth artistic influence, one who might not come so readily to mind when thinking of literary inspiration but who is equally important to me: the radio host Howard Stern.

headline: Let’s Build a New Bridge. No Cars Allowed.
text: “O HARP and altar,” marveled the poet Hart Crane about the Brooklyn Bridge. But if you don’t love it as he did, don’t worry. With bridges, as with everything else in New York City, you are spoiled for choice. More than 2,000 bind this metropolis.

headline: Governing by Blackmail
text: SUPPOSE President Obama announced:

headline: The Promise and Peril of Pope Francis
text: TO understand Pope Francis — his purpose, his program and its potential pitfalls — it’s useful to think about what’s been happening to New York City’s Jews.

headline: Dirk Kramers
text: Dirk Kramers was the chief engineer of the catamaran that won this year’s America’s Cup. That makes four boats he has helped design and build that have won the race.

headline: Welcome to Ted Cruz’s Thunderdome
text: A PLACE ONCE CALLED WASHINGTON

headline: Dogs Are People, Too
text: FOR the past two years, my colleagues and I have been training dogs to go in an M.R.I. scanner — completely awake and unrestrained. Our goal has been to determine how dogs’ brains work and, even more important, what they think of us humans.

headline: The Cost of the Shutdown, by the Numbers
text: A look at the budget standoff’s effects on America’s economy, institutions and government workers.

headline: Video: The Cost of the Shutdown by the Numbers
text: A look at the budget standoff’s effects on America’s economy, institutions and government workers.

headline: Making a Deal With Murderers
text: SAN SALVADOR — THE president of El Salvador has helped save more than 2,000 lives in the past two years. Now if only he would admit it.

headline: The Supreme Court Returns
text: The Supreme Court begins a new term on Monday, even as the landmark rulings of last term continue to reverberate. The court has agreed to hear more than 50 cases so far on disputes both familiar and fresh: from affirmative action and freedom of speech, to campaign finance and the president’s power to make recess appointments.

headline: A ‘Good’ War, a Bad Father
text: World War II had been over for more than a decade when Dale Maharidge was born, but he still sees himself as damaged by that war, in particular by the Battle of Okinawa, in 1945. His father, Steve, a Marine sergeant, brought that battle home with him, to a suburb south of Cleveland. It lived on, taking the shape of desolate anger, forever on the edge of violence, of pain that he parceled out to his wife and children over the rest of his life.

headline: Getting Older, Growing Poorer
text: The basic outlines of poverty in America are sadly familiar. At last count, 46.5 million people were poor — 15 percent of the population. Women and children, especially in single-mother families, were, as always, hit hardest.

headline: Electronic Devices on Planes
text: The Federal Aviation Administration is considering relaxing restrictions on the use of electronic devices on airplanes. Since there is a lot of confusion among passengers about why restrictions apply, clarification is a sensible move. As it is, many passengers accidentally or deliberately violate the rules they don’t like or understand. According to one private survey, as many as 30 percent of passengers left their devices on when they were not supposed to.

headline: Hagel Recalls Most Defense Department Workers
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made a surprise announcement on Saturday that he would recall next week almost all of the 400,000 civilian employees of the Defense Department who had been sent home when the government shut down.

headline: Municipal Bonds, Stung Again
text: “SELL IN MAY,” the stock-market adage, would have served municipal bond investors well this year. Those who stayed in the market faced sharp losses.

headline: Michael Gould of Bloomingdale’s, on Passion and Compassion
text: This interview with  Michael Gould, chief executive of Bloomingdale’s, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Shorting Out The Wiring
text: For the moment, at least, the shutdown and the general scene of insanity in Congress is clearly hurting the Republican brand. And there’s a whole small industry of crunching numbers on the 1995-6 shutdown, etc., to estimate the likely impact on next year’s elections. For now the conventional wisdom is that the impact will be small, not nearly enough to restore Democratic control.

headline: Bible College Helps Some at Louisiana Prison Find Peace
text: ANGOLA, La. — Like most of his fellow inmates, Daryl Walters, 45, can expect to spend the rest of his days in the infamous prison on a former slave plantation here. He was sentenced to life without parole for a murder more than 20 years ago in a state where a life sentence means just that.

headline: Having Fun at AccuWeather, Rain or Shine
text: I REMEMBER being fascinated by snow at age 3. When I was 7, my grandmother gave me a diary, which I used to keep track of the days when it snowed. At around 9, I’d get up early and listen to weather forecasts on all the radio stations I could, so that I could track storms.

headline: A Bad Worker’s Mad Mom
The View From Toronto
text: MY first Toronto apartment was in a 32-story midcentury modern tower in the city’s midtown, a cluster of high- and midrise buildings with single-family homes scattered among them. The neighborhood is atop a mild escarpment, giving these buildings a height advantage on the city spreading south toward Lake Ontario.

headline: The View From Bangkok
text: MY wife and I live in a building with 24 floors in downtown Bangkok, a dwarf compared to most of the ones around us.

headline: Snap. Hold. Kick. All in the Blink of an Eye.
text: Field goals occur so swiftly and so regularly that they are often treated as afterthoughts. But a highly intricate three-part choreography is involved. The Giants’ field-goal unit breaks it down.

headline: The View From Dubai
text: OUTSIDE our door, high up in the Burj Khalifa, we board one of the tower’s 57 elevators and are catapulted even higher, to the 123rd floor, as if we were weightless objects being effortlessly lifted through the air. Our ears adjust several times as we speed along at almost 60 feet a second.

headline: In Surprise Announcement, Hagel Recalls Most Defense Department Workers
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made a surprise announcement on Saturday that he would reinstate almost all of the 350,000 civilian employees of the Defense Department who had been sent home when the government shut down last week.

headline: Athletic Art: 3 Acts and 3 Points
text: N.F.L. kickers last season attempted 1,016 field goals, each a quick, odd, almost artistic intermezzo to football’s other acts of fury. The field goal — snap, hold and kick take about 1.2 seconds — happens so swiftly and with such regularity, it is often treated as an afterthought, both omnipresent and overlooked.

headline: Cardinals Romp, Highlighting Challenges for New Conference
text: PHILADELPHIA — The royal blue “A” logo of the new American Athletic Conference is painted on the perimeter walls in the corners of Lincoln Financial Field, near the tunnels, the only indication of Temple’s new conference affiliation. The logos were hardly noticeable enough to be a target for the sharpshooting offense of No. 7 Louisville in its 30-7 romp over Temple on Saturday. The Cardinals (5-0, 1-0), the top team in the current A.A.C., flexed their muscles and demonstrated what they can do with a Heisman Trophy contender, Teddy Bridgewater, at quarterback, throwing for 348 yards and 2 touchdowns.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, October 6
text: “It’s like building a bridge from two sides of the river; you just hope it comes out in the middle.”

headline: The Long, Long Wait for Mental Health Care
text: The Long, Long Wait For Mental Health Care

headline: Ahead of the Market
text: How three of the top performers of the third quarter of 2013 fared against the market — and against their peer groups of funds.

headline: Obama Points to ‘Legitimate Concerns’ Over Redskins’ Name
text: The long-simmering debate over the Washington Redskins’ name took a new turn when President Obama said that he would consider changing it if he were the team’s owner.

headline: Secrets of a Field-Goal Kick
text: The Giants’ kicker, holder and snapper share the details of how a field goal is executed.

headline: In an Opera House, All the Office Is a Stage
text: Peter Gelb, 59, is general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

headline: As Syrian Refugees Develop Roots, Jordan Grows Wary
text: MAFRAQ, Jordan — For Jordan, a small desert nation that is one of the world’s driest, the recent home improvement trends at its biggest camp for Syrian refugees may prove particularly unsettling.

headline: For Syrian Refugees in Jordan, a New Sense of Home
text: Some refugees are seemingly settling in for the long haul by recreating fixtures of their past domestic lives.

headline: Readers Comment on the Government Shutdown
text: My Sunday column lacerates the House Republicans for the government shutdown and the flirtation with a debt limit default. To me, this isn’t politics as usual but a rare instance of a political party causing deliberate economic and national security damage in hopes of gaining leverage on another issue. The national security consequences haven’t garnered enough attention, and they’re compounded by something I didn’t have space to mention–President Obama’s cancellation of his Asia trip itinerary. At a time when there is broad agreement that we should recalibrate our diplomatic efforts to focus more on Asia, this is an instance when we’re backing away from Asia because of this domestic political crisis. And China is the winner. So read the column, please, and share your thoughts on it.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 6
text: As the government shutdown approaches the one-week mark, conversations about whether Congress can come to an agreement on raising the debt ceiling are cropping up on the Sunday talk shows.

headline: Toe Tags
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — First things first: Hands up if you were ready to write a strongly-worded comment or letter about 37 Down. Don’t be shy; I looked it up, too. I will bet that most people believe that the correct phrase is JUST DESSERTS instead of the correct JUST DESERTS, because the majority of people pronounce the second word with the accent on the allegedly wrong syl-AH-ble.

headline: Scores Are Killed in Iraqi Violence
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber killed at least 51 Shiite pilgrims who were crossing a bridge in Baghdad in the deadliest of several attacks in Iraq on Saturday, the police said. All told, the attacks claimed at least 80 lives, officials said.

headline: Treasury Secretary Says Size of Debt-Ceiling Rise Is Up to Congress
text: WASHINGTON – Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has declined to tell senior Senate Republicans how large an increase the Obama administration wants in the nation’s soon-to-be-breached $16.7 trillion debt limit, saying that is Congress’s job to decide under the Constitution.

headline: A Coded Plea in the Forecast

headline: Obama on Iran's Leadership
text: In an interview with The Associated Press, President Obama spoke about President Hassan Rouhani of Iran and of the estimated timetable for Iran to be able to produce nuclear weapons.

headline: Obama Defends the Health Care Law
text: President Obama defended the health care law and discussed the government shutdown in an interview with The Associated Press on Oct. 4, 2013.

headline: Conservative Georgia District Urges G.O.P. to Keep Up the Fight
text: FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga. — Just down the road from where Union troops suffered their worst defeat of the Civil War, Jeff Epperson sang the praises of his congressman, Representative Tom Graves, whose Defund Obamacare Act set the table for the partial government shutdown.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Waxing Nostalgic, Accepts Award at Yale
text: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — Hillary Rodham Clinton accepted an award at her alma mater, Yale Law School, on Saturday. At her 40th reunion, Mrs. Clinton, the former secretary of state, delivered a speech that took the audience down memory lane, highlighted her passion for children’s welfare and largely avoided politics.

headline: Giants Lose Ross and Add Two to Secondary
text: Weakened in the secondary by injuries as they headed into Sunday’s game with the Philadelphia Eagles, the Giants on Saturday added two defensive backs. In a surprise, Aaron Ross, the team’s first-round draft pick in 2007, was placed on injured reserve to make room for one of the two players.

headline: Plan for Ridding Syria of Chemical Arms Includes Brute Force and Chemistry
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and its partners are planning a series of rapid steps to dismantle Syria’s chemical weapons program, a strategy that is intended to guard against backsliding by President Bashar al-Assad and limit the time that international experts need to work in the country, according to senior American officials.

headline: By Cutting Rural Routes, Megabus Leaves a Void
text: Confused and frustrated South Texans in March began calling Sarah Hidalgo-Cook, the manager of the Southwest Area Regional Transit District, in March. They were learning through e-mails that bus tickets they had purchased through Megabus.com had been refunded, with no option to repurchase. Because her transit district oversees public transportation for eight rural counties, Ms. Hidalgo-Cook was the logical person to call.

headline: College Football Around the Country
text: The Day’s Best

headline: Minnesota Coach Misses Michigan Game After Seizure
text: Minnesota Coach Jerry Kill had a seizure Saturday morning and did not travel with the Golden Gophers, who fell to No. 19 Michigan, 42-13.

headline: In Spending $180 Million on Tutoring Help, Much Misuse
text: A federal program that set aside millions of dollars to provide remedial help for struggling students from low-income families quietly came to an end in Texas last month.

headline: A Top Mormon Leader Acknowledges the Church ‘Made Mistakes’
text: One of the top leaders in the Mormon Church acknowledged in an address to the church’s global membership on Saturday that past leaders had “made mistakes” that had caused some Mormons to have doubts, an admission that amounts to a significant change in tone in the leadership’s approach to Mormons who question, dissent or defect from the church.

headline: Finale of Elite Series Brings Its Own Excitement
text: The final tournament in the men’s Grand Prix series, which ended last week, did not live up to its billing.

headline: For Low Taxes, It All Depends on the Business
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Hammer Museum to Offer Free Admission
text: LOS ANGELES  — While admission fees at major art museums across the country keep rising, the Hammer Museum here is joining a small group of institutions bucking the trend. The Hammer Museum has announced this weekend that all exhibitions will be free to the public starting in February.

headline: One Talk Show That Will Never Book a Kardashian
text: On most talk shows with a comedian as host, whether “Jimmy Kimmel Live” or “Late Show With David Letterman,” the guests are usually celebrities, who pitch their latest movies and tell lighthearted stories before sliding down the couch to make room for the next A-lister. The few nonfamous people on hand are glimpsed waving from the studio audience or relegated to comic relief in “man on the street” segments.

headline: Newcomer From Japan Turns Heads, but Woods Steers U.S. to Wider Lead
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — The International team’s Australia-based yell squad, known as the Fanatics, serenaded the pairing of Adam Scott and Hideki Matsuyama on the first tee Saturday morning at Muirfield Village by singing, “We’ve got the best-looking golfer in the game,” to the tune of “He’s Got the Whole World in His Hands.”

headline: Sidney Lanier, 90, Experimental Stage Producer, Is Dead
text: The Rev. Sidney Lanier first tried to revive his dwindling congregation on the fringe of Manhattan’s Theater District by summoning actors to the pulpit to read stirring passages from the Bible and great literature. Then, in 1963, he dispensed with the pulpit — the altar and pews, too — to try something really dramatic.

headline: Grand Jury Indictment of Abu Anas al-Libi
text: American forces captured a Libyan militant, known by his nom de guerre, Abu Anas al-Libi, who had been indicted in 2000 for his role in the 1998 bombings of the United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

headline: Corrections: October 6, 2013
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Nicholas Oresko, 96, a Hero of the Battle of the Bulge, Dies
text: The hill ahead, outside the German town of Tettingen, had twice been assaulted by Sgt. Nicholas Oresko’s platoon in the previous two days, but it remained in enemy hands. Darkness was arriving to accompany the snow and cold. It was late afternoon, Jan. 23, 1945, the final stages of the Battle of Bulge, Adolf Hitler’s massive surprise attack inflicting heavy casualties as the Allies massed for a push toward Berlin.

headline: Red Sox Chase Price and Take Command in Series
text: BOSTON — David Price knew this could be his last start with the Tampa Bay Rays. He had seen the others ushered in and out. The Rays had drafted and developed him to be their ace, even as Matt Moore, Alex Cobb and Chris Archer joined the rotation, and as James Shields and Wade Davis were traded last winter for younger, cheaper talent.

headline: In Age of Anywhere Delivery, the Food Meets You for Lunch
text: Julio Diaz was hungry. The problem was that Mr. Diaz was sitting in his Mitsubishi S.U.V., had a great parking spot on the Upper West Side, and could not walk away from the car until the alternate-side parking period had passed.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 5, 2013
Irish Say No to No Senate in Blow to Prime Minister
text: DUBLIN — Irish voters have rejected a proposal to abolish the upper house of Parliament, delivering a blow to Prime Minister Enda Kenny, who had championed the measure, which had been widely expected to pass.

headline: Gunfire Wounds Israeli Girl, 9, Playing in Yard in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — A 9-year-old girl was shot in the chest Saturday night while playing outside her home in a West Bank settlement, in what the Israeli authorities suspect was an attack by a Palestinian who had broken into the settlement from one of the surrounding villages. The girl was in stable condition at a Jerusalem hospital, officials said.

headline: House Republican Efforts to Repeal or Weaken the Health Care Law
text: A chart showing House votes that Republican leaders identified as containing at least some provision weakening the health care law.

headline: As Germans Push Austerity, Greeks Press Nazi-Era Claims
text: AMIRAS, Greece — As they moved through the isolated villages in this region in 1943, systematically killing men in a reprisal for an attack on a small outpost, German soldiers dragged Giannis Syngelakis’s father from his home here and shot him in the head. Within two days, more than 400 men were dead and the women left behind struggled with the monstrous task of burying so many corpses.

headline: Karzai Is Planning to Be There for a Successor. Right There.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With less than a year left in his final term, President Hamid Karzai insists that he is eager to leave the presidential palace and lead a quieter life. It turns out, though, he may just be moving next door, to a lavish new home yards from the complex that has been the seat of his power for more than a decade.

headline: Selling Secrets of Phone Users to Advertisers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Once, only hairdressers and bartenders knew people’s secrets.

headline: A Federal Budget Crisis Months in the Planning
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly after President Obama started his second term, a loose-knit coalition of conservative activists led by former Attorney General Edwin Meese III gathered in the capital to plot strategy. Their push to repeal Mr. Obama’s health care law was going nowhere, and they desperately needed a new plan.

headline: Argentine Leader Has Head Injury
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, has been told by doctors to take a month off after recently suffering a head injury, her spokesman said Saturday.

headline: With Gusto and a Few Hiccups, Rose Makes an Electric Return to the Court
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Minutes before Saturday’s preseason game between the Chicago Bulls and the Indiana Pacers, Derrick Rose emerged from the tunnel at Bankers Life Fieldhouse to a rousing cheer. A large contingent of Chicago fans, many seated behind the Bulls’ bench, had made the three-hour drive to see Rose’s return to the court 526 days after he tore his anterior cruciate ligament in the first round of the 2012 playoffs.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 6, 2013
text: “Maybe some of us have not paid our taxes. But that is nothing compared to what they did.”

headline: Everything Changed at the Ball
text: Laura Marie Jenkins, a daughter of Mary R. Jenkins and Dr. Randall D. Jenkins of Portland, Ore., was married Saturday to Lt. John Stanley Plack, the son of Margaret M. Plack and Thomas P. Plack of Washington.

Bell of San Diego, was married Saturday to Zane McGee Kessler, the son of Twylah Jenonne Kessler and Ned A. Kessler of Edmond, Okla. The Rev. Jane Keener-Quiat, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Hell Roaring Ranch in Redstone, Colo.

headline: Samantha Levy, Ryan Alovis
text: Samantha Blake Levy, a daughter of Darcy Cohen Levy and Lawrence H. Levy, both of New York, was married Saturday evening to Ryan Paul Alovis, a son of Meryl H. Alovis and Kenneth D. Alovis of Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis Math officiated at the bride’s father’s vacation home in New Hope, Pa.

headline: Kristilyn Whigham and Percy Lambert
text: Kristilyn Shaquell Whigham and Percy Lawrence Lambert III were married Friday by the Rev. Dr. Toussaint K. Hill Jr., a Baptist minister, at the Biltmore Ballrooms in Atlanta.

headline: Allison Pennock, Matthew Danzig
text: Allison Tatnall Pennock and Matthew Isaac Danzig were married Saturday in New Castle, N.H. Vice Chancellor Donald F. Parsons Jr. of the Delaware Court of Chancery, who received permission from New Hampshire to perform this ceremony, officiated at the Great Island Common, a park.

headline: Mary Clancy, Jamie Riches
text: Mary Elizabeth Clancy and Dr. Jamie Cathleen Riches were married Friday evening at the Kaaterskill, an inn in Catskill, N.Y. Francis Tabone, a friend of the couple who became an Open Ministry minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Aditi Sen, Sudhir Muralidhar
text: Aditi Priyadarshini Sen, the daughter of Jyoti Misra Sen and Ranjan Sen of Baltimore, is to be married there Sunday evening to Sudhir Sudarshan Muralidhar, the son of Veena Muralidhar and Narasimhan Muralidhar of Cary, N.C. Sam Rosenfeld, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, will officiate at the Howard Peters Rawlings Conservatory and Botanic Gardens. B.S. Varadaraja Bhattar, a Hindu priest, will perform a traditional Hindu ceremony at the bride’s parents’ home Sunday morning.

headline: Tali Yahalom, Joshua Leinwand
text: Tali Ravit Yahalom, a daughter of Marlene Warshawski Yahalom of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Dr. Joshua Caleb Leinwand, a son of Bethsheba Mandel and Robert M. Leinwand of Brooklyn. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Jessica Smith, Andrew Pugliese
text: Jessica Elaine Smith and Andrew Paul Pugliese were married Saturday at the Barn at Hillsprings Farm in Tuscarora, N.Y. Richard D. Sullivan, a former town justice in Addison, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Result Favors A’s Even if Matchup Did Not
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — At first glance, it looked like a lopsided pitching matchup in favor of the Detroit Tigers. They had Justin Verlander, baseball’s highest paid pitcher, going against a 23-year-old July call-up named Sonny.

headline: Movie Review: 'Gravity'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Gravity."

headline: Movie Review: 'A.C.O.D.'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A.C.O.D.”

headline: Movie Review: 'A Touch of Sin'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Touch of Sin.”

headline: Bomb Kills 4 Soldiers In Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Four coalition soldiers were killed Sunday in southern Afghanistan, the American-led international military force said, in the coalition’s worst loss of life in a single episode since June.

headline: Libya Condemns U.S. for Seizing Terror Suspect
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s fragile interim government condemned the United States on Sunday for what it called the “kidnapping of a Libyan citizen” from this capital city a day earlier, and Libyan lawmakers threatened to remove the prime minister if the government was involved.

headline: The Shutdown Hurts the U.S. in Asia
text: With Obama hobbled, Xi can pursue his game plan.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe’s Fantasy Football Dreams
text: Among the many delightful and unexpected tidbits that Susan Dominus tells us about Daniel Radcliffe in the magazine this weekend, there’s the fact that he is nurturing a fairly recent obsession with fantasy football. “I probably know every starting player’s name in the league,” he told Dominus. “Actually, I don’t know why I’m being modest; I definitely know every starting player.”

headline: A Dad Grows in the Bronx
text: My lessons in Bronx parenting began on my first night in our new apartment, about an hour after my wife and I went to bed. My wife had moved in about a week earlier, but she still hadn’t adapted to the sounds of our new home.

headline: Ailing ‘Mayor,’ Absent From Strawberry Fields, Is Still Channeling Lennon
text: Outside a ninth-floor room in St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital on the West Side of Manhattan last week was a handwritten sign that said “Mayor of Strawberry Fields.”

headline: Disruptions: How the F.A.A., Finally, Caught Up to an Always-On Society
text: You know the scene in a movie when a character trails off into the past and is reminded of the moment it all began? I had one of those last week.

headline: Boehner Hews to Hard Line in Demanding Concessions From Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner stood his ground on Sunday alongside the most conservative Republicans in Congress, insisting that the House would not vote to finance and reopen the government or raise the nation’s borrowing limit without concessions from President Obama on the health care law.

headline: Cruz’s 21-Hour Speech Fueled a Ratings Jump at C-Span2
text: Given the meager approval ratings the public has consistently given Congress, it might seem surprising that anyone watches the unblinking live shots of the Senate and House on television. But government crises apparently have a way of ratcheting up interest in Washington procedural drama.

headline: Cate Blanchett at the New York Film Festival
text: She has played Katharine Hepburn. She has played Bob Dylan. She has played an elf. And at the New York Film Festival, Cate Blanchett played host to accolades.

headline: The Social Science Explaining Why More Climate Science Hasn’t Led to Greenhouse Action
text: Earlier this year, I took part in a fast-paced tour of the science of climate change at the Seattle Science Festival. I posted on the event at the time, but the Pacific Science Center has uploaded better video versions.

headline: Schoolboy's Face, Killer's Arsenal
text: LONDON — He has the face of a schoolboy, the wispy body of a youth, and a future that five different countries are hoping to claim for their national team.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 6:30 P.M. (13) MOYERS & COMPANY The novelist Wendell Berry, above, a farmer, environmentalist and literary agrarian voice, sits down with Bill Moyers to discuss a no-compromise plan to save the earth. The interview was taped at St. Catharine College in Kentucky — home to the new Berry Farming and Ecological Agrarianism Program — during a two-day celebration of the 35th anniversary of the publication of Mr. Berry’s seminal book, “The Unsettling of America.” “It’s mighty hard right now to think of anything that’s precious that isn’t endangered,” Mr. Berry says. “There are no sacred and unsacred places; there are only sacred and desecrated places. My belief is that the world and our life in it are conditional gifts. We have the world to live in on the condition that we will take good care of it. And to take good care of it we have to know it. And to know it and to be willing to take care of it, we have to love it.”

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Street Violence Across Egypt
text: CAIRO — At least 51 people were killed and hundreds were injured as street clashes erupted in several Egyptian cities on Sunday, in a surge of violence that raised new questions about the ability of the interim government to secure the fractured country.

headline: Fox Renews ‘The Simpsons’
text: “The Simpsons” has a quarter-century behind it and at least one more year ahead of it on Fox. The network has announced that it renewed this animated comedy for a 26th season, keeping new episodes on television through 2015 and dispelling speculation that the show might make its 25th season, the one that started last month, its last.

headline: Twitter C.E.O. Defends Representation of Women at the Company — Sort Of
text: When I was writing the article that ran in Saturday’s New York Times about the dearth of senior women at Twitter — and the total absence of women on its board — the company declined to comment.

headline: ‘Gravity’ Is Strongest at Box Office
text: “Gravity,” a space thriller starring Sandra Bullock, reasserted the drawing power of 3-D as it took in $55.6 million at the domestic box office and another $27.4 million in international markets for Warner Brothers. over the weekend. An overwhelming share of ticket sales came from 3-D screens and large-format Imax showings, in the United States and abroad. That reversed a trend that had seen 3-D falter, particularly in domestic theaters.

headline: Keystone XL Pipeline Commercial
text: TransCanada’s latest ad in support of its pipeline project contrasts Canada with other, more unstable, sources of United States oil imports.

headline: Cahill’s Late Theatrics
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls snatched a point and a playoff berth Saturday night in a 2-2 tie against the New England Revolution at Red Bull Arena, but like so much else for this club, it did not come easily.

headline: Bomber Kills 13 Children At Iraq School Playground
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber detonated a truck filled with explosives on the playground of an elementary school in northern Iraq on Sunday morning, killing 13 children and the headmaster, the police said. Shortly afterward, another suicide truck bomb struck a police station in the same village, killing three officers.

headline: We Are Now At War With Eastasia, I Mean The Deficit
text: This morning, for my sins, I found myself involuntarily watching bits and piece of the morning talk shows, and it seemed clear that Republicans have been given a new talking point. Suddenly, the shutdown/debt ceiling confrontation isn’t just about Obamacare; it’s about curbing runaway spending growth and exploding debt.

headline: Hitting the Ceiling: Disastrous or Utterly Disastrous?
text: Obama won’t, can’t negotiate over the debt ceiling, and Republicans still haven’t figured that out. So you have to say that it’s pretty likely that we will indeed hit the ceiling. Suppose that Obama’s lawyers tell him that extraordinary measures like just ignoring the ceiling or minting the coin are out. Then what?

headline: The Return of Speaker Pelosi?
text: It’s just one poll, but maybe the Republican lock on the House isn’t that unbreakable after all.

headline: Bryan Cranston Is Headed to Broadway
text: The Emmy Award winner Bryan Cranston, fresh off his popular run as the drug kingpin Walter White on the cable series “Breaking Bad,” will make his Broadway debut this season as Lyndon B. Johnson in the play “All the Way,” the producer Jeffrey Richards said on Sunday. The play, which wraps up a sold-out production on Saturday at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., received mixed-to-favorable reviews there; the notices for Mr. Cranston’s performance were strong, and producers are counting on his star power to drive ticket sales in the move to Broadway.

headline: Afghan Presidential Hopefuls Are Told to Leave Guns at Home
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The deadline for registering as a candidate in Afghanistan’s coming presidential election was Sunday, and the election commission had a request for contenders: When you come to declare your candidacy, do not bring your gunmen.

headline: Abortion Vote Exposes Rift at a Catholic University
text: LOS ANGELES — Not three weeks have passed since Pope Francis said the church had grown “obsessed” with abortion, declaring, “We have to find a new balance.” But on the campus of Loyola Marymount University, overlooking this city’s west side, a fight over abortion now threatens to rip the school asunder.

headline: Mideast Unrest as Foil to Promote Keystone Pipeline
text: TransCanada, the company trying to build the Keystone XL pipeline, is distributing a new round of ads in support of its stalled project.

headline: Instruments of Danger in Weapons Case Were Dogs, Authorities Say
text: James Austin stood in front of a two-story Brooklyn row house, watching his puppy, Dutchess, play with a pair of pants while, a few feet away, a friend’s dog, Stoney, was tethered to a fence. At that moment, they were companions — both to him and in the eyes of the law.

headline: U.S. Said to Hold Qaeda Suspect on Navy Ship
text: An accused operative for Al Qaeda seized by United States commandos in Libya over the weekend is being interrogated while in military custody on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, officials said on Sunday. He is expected eventually to be sent to New York for criminal prosecution.

headline: Despite Good Intentions, New Targeting Rule Creates Problems
text: The changes to college football’s targeting rule — and the subsequent backlash — speak to a quandary all football faces.

headline: Zoos Try to Ward Off a Penguin Killer
text: Zoos all around the world love penguins. They’re cute, they don’t require much space, they never eat zookeepers. And children adore watching them, especially at feeding time.

headline: Marketers Chase Evolving Consumer
text: PHOENIX — THE senior executives who spoke at a major marketing conference here seemed to be auditioning for a reality show called “Extreme Makeover: Corporate Edition.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 7
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Netanyahu Dressed Down After Appeal to Iranians
text: TEHRAN — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel tried to take his campaign against the Iranian leadership to Iran’s young population last week, saying that if they were truly free, they would be able to wear jeans, listen to Western music and participate in free elections.

headline: From Irving Berlin to Bon Jovi: An American Songbook Devotee Gives Rock Hits a Twist
text: It’s all in the arrangement. If you take a rock song like the Bon Jovi hit “You Give Love a Bad Name” and perform it in a pop-jazz style, it becomes a latter-day standard in the American Songbook. Or does it?

headline: U.S. Names Roster for World Cup Qualifiers
text: Injuries and inaction played a role when Jurgen Klinsmann, the United States national team coach, selected his 20-man roster for the two final matches in regional World Cup qualifying.

headline: Strife Joins Minnesota Musicians in Concert
text: MINNEAPOLIS — By the end of a disastrous week, classical music fans in this city sorely needed something positive to hang onto, however fleetingly. And, happily, they got momentary relief over the weekend in three concerts by the players of the Minnesota Orchestra, conducted by Osmo Vanska.

headline: Ivy League Home for a Cartoonist’s Vast Archive
text: Al Jaffee started out as a professional cartoonist in the early 1940s, and he has been at it ever since. Although best known for the three-panel fold-ins that Mad magazine has run since 1964, he has also produced work for Timely Comics, the forerunner of Marvel, for Playboy and Esquire, for the short-lived satirical magazine Humbug, and for The Moshiach Times, a Jewish family magazine that has carried his secret-agent strip “The Shpy” for the last 25 years.

headline: Federal Reserve to Unveil a Redesigned $100 Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve will begin circulating a new $100 bill on Tuesday with some modern and colorful anti-counterfeiting features, after overcoming problems that postponed its debut for more than two and a half years.

headline: A Multiplicity of Musicians With Many Traditions and Narratives
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The first striking thing about “Open City,” Vijay Iyer’s large-ensemble suite heard twice over the weekend at Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University here, wasn’t sound but a kind of theory of possibility suggested by the sight of the 20 people onstage.

headline: An Environmental Album Recaptured in a Concert
text: At a time when we are awash in a constant deluge of digital images shared by friends and strangers through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Flickr, it can be hard to recall when we were less instantly and intimately connected. In the 1970s, though, the world was still analog. Most photographs needed developing, usually by specialists. You posted an image by sticking it in an envelope, then into a mailbox. Sharing photos meant passing prints from hand to hand, or maybe gathering in a darkened den to watch dutifully while a relative or neighbor showed vacation slides.

headline: Giants Follow a Losing Formula
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Flawed teams find ways to lose, and by now the Giants must recognize the pattern. Interceptions, fumbles, penalties, blown coverages, even poor coaching decisions — this year’s Giants are dexterous and resourceful architects of defeat.

headline: Lamenting Slavery and Celebrating a Culture
text: There was no mistaking the African roots of Christine Salem’s new music — a tradition called maloya that has been honored by Unesco as part of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity — when she opened the World Music Institute’s season on Friday night at Symphony Space. Ms. Salem (pronounced sah-LEM) sang in a robust contralto and, much of the time, shook a sugar-cane rattle called a kayamb that was a blur of motion as it pinpointed breakneck 6/8 rhythms. She was backed by only two other percussionists and harmony singers, David Abrousse and Harry Perigone.

headline: Scratching a Muse’s Ears
text: Mary Oliver has spent most of her life with a mind ripe with poems — and with at least one steadfast dog by her side. It seems fitting then that her latest collection revels in the carrying on of dogs. “Dog Songs,” out from Penguin Press on Tuesday, is a sweet golden retriever of a book that curls up with the reader, with 35 poems and one essay about the dogs who have shared Ms. Oliver’s days.

headline: Point-Blank Perspectives on a Fatal Bullying Case
text: Events that received widespread news coverage when they happened can be difficult to turn into documentaries, but “Valentine Road” does an impressive job of making a 2008 shooting at a junior high school in Oxnard, Calif., horrifying and disheartening all over again.

headline: Survivor Among a Lifetime of Ghosts
text: One Saturday morning, as the heroine of Alice McDermott’s quietly exquisite new novel is just developing a classic case of preteenage insolence, her mother summons her to the kitchen for a cooking lesson. It’s all in a day’s work, but the girl, Marie, takes it for granted that her mother has already done the family’s laundry and hung it out to dry. This is a book so deft that even the damp shirts and school blouses on the clothesline have some import. Marie sees them “hung upside down by their hems, their arms waving in a way that made me grow dizzy in sympathy.”

headline: Swarm of Rivals Seeking Share of Social Media Pie
text: Twitter, poised to make its splashy entrance on Wall Street, has helped define modern social networking. But while seeking to establish itself as an Internet powerhouse, it must also prove it can fend off a rising threat from a younger generation of nimble social outlets that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share content.

headline: U.S.-Polish Showdown at Bali Tournament
text: Following on from Saturday’s column, we move to the diagramed deal, the penultimate board in one quarterfinal of the Transnational Teams world championship last month in Bali, Indonesia. The eventual winners, Mark Gordon, Pratap Rajadhyaksha, David Berkowitz, Alan Sontag, Jacek Pszczola (known as Pepsi) and Michael Seamon from the United States, were locked in a tense battle against Polish Students (Stanislaw Golebiowski, Piotr Tuczynski, Pawel Jassem, Jakub Wojcieszek, Michal Klukowski and Piotr Zatorski).

headline: Supreme Court Precedents in Play
text: The new Supreme Court term, which starts Monday, is notable for the number of major precedents that may be overruled or revised.

headline: ‘Big Fish’
text: Scenes from the new Broadway musical at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: What the Artists Are Doing
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always nice to start a brand new solving week with a debut. Today, Amy Johnson’s byline appears in The New York Times, and I would like to welcome her by saying that I enjoyed her puzzle. It’s great to see a debut puzzle that’s relatively clean and has such nice long fill. I also liked her colorful theme.

headline: ‘Fall for Dance’
text: Images of performances by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and other companies.

headline: Hip-Hop in Mixed Company of Swans and Other Woodland Creatures
text: The fifth and final program of this year’s Fall for Dance Festival was like a day at the cinema: the dancing equivalent of a short film, two cartoons and, at long last, a movie. The program, presented on Friday at City Center, got off to a ponderous start with a work that had its origins as a Sadler’s Wells London production. While that connection doesn’t automatically mean clunker, there are trademarks to such imports: ever-torquing limbs and more than a dash of melodrama.

headline: Divers Recover 83 More Bodies From Migrant Ship
text: ROME — Divers searching the underwater wreckage of a migrant ship that capsized last week in the Mediterranean Sea recovered another 83 bodies on Sunday, raising the death toll to 194, a figure that is likely to keep growing.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: E-CIGARETTES The European Parliament, meeting in Strasbourg, France, plans to vote on Tuesday on a broad set of proposed tobacco regulations — the most contentious of which is how to regulate electronic cigarettes. Advocates of e-cigarettes say they are less harmful than conventional cigarettes, because users inhale nicotine-infused vapors instead of smoke. Despite the products’ growing popularity, some European public health officials want them regulated as medical devices. Even if tobacco industry lobbyists prevail in getting the European Parliament to back a less stringent form of regulation, the vote would be only a step in a European rule-making process for e-cigarettes that could continue into next year or beyond.

headline: World Bank, Rooted in Bureaucracy, Proposes a Sweeping Reorganization
text: WASHINGTON — Jim Yong Kim, the genial American physician who took over as the president of the World Bank last year, recently conducted a survey of its 10,000 employees. The survey revealed a “culture of fear,” pervasive “fear of risk” and a “terrible” environment for collaboration at the huge development institution, which lends more than $30 billion a year and works in more than 100 countries.

headline: Without Health Insurance: Those Left Behind
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sex, Doubt and the Pope
text: Many liberal Catholics have been encouraged by Pope Francis’s comments about sexual ethics in a recent interview. His general point was that these are lesser matters, not to be emphasized at the expense of the church’s essential message of healing and salvation. Asked about homosexuality, he simply evoked God’s love for all humans: “when God looks at a gay person, does he endorse the existence of this person with love, or reject and condemn this person? . . . In life, God accompanies persons, and we must accompany them, starting from their situation. It is necessary to accompany them with mercy.” More widely, he said: “We cannot insist only on issues related to abortion, gay marriage and the use of contraceptive methods . . . . The dogmatic and moral teachings of the church are not all equivalent. The church’s pastoral ministry cannot be obsessed with the transmission of a disjointed multitude of doctrines to be imposed insistently.”
