text: To the Editor:

headline: No Limit on Donations
text: To the Editor:

headline: Abolish Runoff Elections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Afghanistan’s Victims
text: To the Editor:

headline: Europe Aims to Regulate the Cloud
text: LONDON — The words “cloud computing” never appeared in a 119-page digital privacy regulation introduced in Europe last year.

headline: It’s Not About ‘Mona Lisa’
text: To the Editor:

headline: In a World of Social Media, Alternatives for Everyone
text: Each social networking platform has a different take on inventive ways of private messaging and creating content with a rich infusion of images and videos.

headline: Nielsen to Measure Twitter Chatter About TV Shows
text: Only 98,600 people wrote messages on Twitter about the two-hour season premiere of “Grey’s Anatomy” last month. That’s a tiny fraction of the 9.3 million who, according to Nielsen, watched the show that night.

headline: Being Mayor
text: IN electing their next mayor, New Yorkers have a choice between a man with impressive political gifts but limited management experience and a seasoned manager who seems politically tone deaf.

headline: Abraham Nemeth, Creator of a Braille Code for Math, Is Dead at 94
text: Abraham Nemeth, whose frustrations in pursuing an academic career in math prompted him to develop the Nemeth Code, a form of Braille that greatly improved the ability of visually impaired people to study complex mathematics, died on Wednesday at his home in Southfield, Mich. He was 94.

headline: The Boehner Bunglers
text: The federal government is shut down, we’re about to hit the debt ceiling (with disastrous economic consequences), and no resolution is in sight. How did this happen?

headline: Pakistan Army Chief Says He Will Retire Next Month
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, confirmed Sunday that he would retire next month, laying to rest media speculation that he would extend his term or take a powerful new position in the military.

headline: A. C. Lyles, Prolific Producer of Westerns, Dies at 95
text: A. C. Lyles, who rose from the mailroom to producer at Paramount Pictures and created a string of profitable low-budget westerns, died on Sept. 27 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: A Balancing Act Around Lake Tahoe
text: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif. — Protecting this natural wonder, set in a mountain-ringed bowl 6,225 feet atop the Sierra Nevada, would have been difficult enough. But its placement, straddling the California-Nevada border, brings the two states into play, with sometimes-competing visions for the lake’s future.

headline: 4 Held in Iran Nuclear Site Plot
text: TEHRAN — The Iranian authorities have arrested four people suspected of planning to sabotage one of the country’s nuclear sites, the chief of Iran’s nuclear program told reporters on Sunday.

headline: When Wealth Disappears
text: LONDON — AS bad as things in Washington are — the federal government shutdown since Tuesday, the slim but real potential for a debt default, a political system that seems increasingly ungovernable — they are going to get much worse, for the United States and other advanced economies, in the years ahead.

headline: At a Nissan Plant in Mississippi, a Battle to Shape the U.A.W.’s Future
text: CANTON, Miss. — The United Automobile Workers — desperate to make inroads in the anti-union South where Toyota, Volkswagen and other foreign automakers have assembly plants — has never tried a unionization drive quite like the one at the Nissan plant here.

headline: Ain’t That Peculiar
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The night before every Jets game, safety Jaiquawn Jarrett shuts off his cellphone, as he used to do in college. In a separate room at the team hotel, right guard Willie Colon has two hours of acupuncture treatment. As needles poke and prod Colon, linebacker Antwan Barnes takes a 45-minute shower while rhythm and blues music plays in the background.

headline: Old Warhorse Is Having Trouble Finding His Stride
text: NEWARK — Like most everything in his career, Jaromir Jagr’s three-week tenure with the Devils has been eventful.

headline: Jets (2-2) at Falcons (1-3)
text: 8:40 p.m., Ch. 11, ESPN

headline: Using Twitter to Move the Markets
text: Last week, while everyone was wondering what Twitter is worth after the unveiling of its I.P.O., I spent some time on a little different math. How much could a single post on Twitter be worth?

headline: As DVRs Shift TV Habits, Ratings Calculations Follow
text: One day after Fox introduced the Headless Horseman drama “Sleepy Hollow” last month, the television world was impressed by its overnight rating, a 3.4 among adults age 18 to 49. Fox knew it would grow: based on last season’s viewing trends, Fox figured the premiere episode would finish between a 5.1 and a 5.4 rating once seven days of digital video recorder playback were added.

headline: Despite Hazards, Street Skateboarding Thrives
text: They race through the streets of New York, cruising through the cityscape as they try to outmaneuver taxis and dodge car doors swinging open.

headline: Rival Factions in Strike Underscore the Fissures in Post-Chávez Venezuela
text: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela — Rival union groups squared off outside this country’s biggest steel mill last week, arguing over whether to continue a lengthy strike at the government-run plant. Each faction blasted its message at top volume over loudspeakers, trying to drown the other out. Pushing and shoving ensued, along with dueling renditions of the national anthem.

headline: Pirates Beat the Averages and the Cardinals in Game 3
text: PITTSBURGH — Kevin Siegrist had never pitched in the major leagues before early June. Five years ago, he was drafted in the 41st round. But pedigree hardly matters to the St. Louis Cardinals, who develop their prospects well and expect results when they reach the majors.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Because of the shutdown, going to a government Web site was hit or miss: the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services was navigable but carried a disclaimer that information might not be “up to date.”

headline: Giants Close-Up
text: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE

headline: Booker Campaign Ad
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will start spending more than $1 million on Monday to broadcast this television commercial on Cory A. Booker’s behalf.

headline: Rays Fail to Control a Red Sox Pest
text: BOSTON — Six pitches into the bottom of the first inning Saturday night, as fans were still finding their seats to watch Game 2 of the American League division series between Boston and Tampa Bay, Jacoby Ellsbury stood on third base.

headline: In the Midwest, Recovering With the Help of Immigrants
text: Dayton, Ohio, is among many struggling cities that have launched programs to attract newcomers and their work skills.

headline: Target in U.S. Raid on Somalia Is Called Top Shabab Planner of Attacks Abroad
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The target of the American commando raid in the Horn of Africa, a Kenyan of Somali origin known as Ikrimah, is one of the Shabab militant group’s top planners for attacks beyond its base in Somalia, an American official said Sunday.

headline: Ailing Midwestern Cities Extend a Welcoming Hand to Immigrants
text: DAYTON, Ohio — Fighting back from the ravages of industrial decline, this city adopted a novel plan two years ago to revive its economy and its spirits: become a magnet for immigrants.

headline: Necessity Is the Mother of Reinvention as Players Shift Roles During the Postseason
text: DETROIT — Need and comfort often clash in the postseason, when a manager places a player in an unfamiliar role or asks him to perform a seldom-required task.

headline: Alabama Museum, in Area Where Stars Found Sound, Seeks an Audience: Tourists
text: TUSCUMBIA, Ala. — A tentative revival is under way in this rural nook of northwest Alabama, a holy place in the evolution of rock ‘n’ roll and home to a museum noticeably light on tourists.

headline: Braves’ Simmons Is Turning Heads and Double Plays
text: LOS ANGELES — Andrelton Simmons had just finished high school in his native Curaçao and figured that baseball was finished with him. Major league scouts, the same ones who had taken to his former youth teammates Kenley Jansen and Didi Gregorius, had passed on him. Simmons loved the game, so maybe he would play in a local league. Or maybe he would play semipro soccer. In any case, he would surely have to get a job.

headline: Corrections: October 7, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Fixing Immigration From the Ground Up
text: The immigration marches and vigils that took place across the country on Saturday, uniting tens of thousands of people in more than 40 states, were a plaintive reminder that immigration reform — remember immigration reform? — is among the many pieces of business that remain unfinished while Congress is in lockdown.

headline: The Fight Against Al Shabab
text: The raid by Navy SEALs on a Somali villa in search of a senior Shabab commander (his fate is unknown) and the capture by American commandos of a key terrorist suspect in Libya on Saturday were signs of a more assertive, targeted American role in trying to curb rising militancy and terrorist enclaves in North Africa.

headline: Mismanaging the Vote in New York City
text: Around the country, voting seems to be getting easier — not perfect, but certainly better. One glaring exception is New York City. Instead of leading the way to better, fairer, cleaner elections, the city’s Board of Elections runs a slow, often loony system that can’t seem to deal with voting in the computer age. New Yorkers who voted in a mayoral primary last month were forced to use ancient voting machines because the board couldn’t figure out how to make sure the newer optical-scanning machines would work for a possible runoff three weeks later.

headline: To Delight Stamp Collectors, Postal Service Turns a Famous Mistake Upside Down
text: In an effort to rekindle the public’s excitement over stamp collecting and interest a new generation in the hobby, the United States Postal Service has created an instant stamp rarity — a twist on one of the world’s most famous and valuable stamps.

headline: A Face-Off Short on Showdowns
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — As if on cue, the curtain of rain parted Sunday to reveal Tiger Woods on center stage. With a 1-up lead over his International team opponent, Woods stood on the 18th green at Muirfield Village with the decisive point in the Presidents Cup on his putter. He hit a long birdie putt to within concession range to clinch the 18th point, and the Cup, for the United States.

headline: News of Argentine President’s Latest Ailment Fuels Criticism and Speculation
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s political system was hit by uncertainty on Sunday after the disclosure that President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner had sustained a head injury more than seven weeks ago and was told by neurologists over the weekend to rest for a month while receiving treatment for chronic bleeding near her brain.

headline: A Dad’s Tall Tales and a Down-to-Earth Son
text: For a show that celebrates tall tales, “Big Fish” feels curiously stunted. Granted, this movie-inspired musical about a whopper-spinning traveling salesman, which opened on Sunday night at the Neil Simon Theater, is certainly big by most conventional measurements.

headline: Why Limit Political Donations?
text: The justices allowed corporate donations with the Citizens United ruling. Now they are considering individual caps. Why keep any limits?

headline: Breaking Away in the Old West
text: A group of rural counties in Colorado will vote in November to secede and work to form their own state.

headline: Fed Up on the Prairie, and Voting on Seceding From Colorado
text: CHEYENNE WELLS, Colo. — The Old West has decided it is fed up with the New West.

headline: Senate Chaplain's Shutdown Prayers
text: In the first week of the government shutdown the Senate chaplain, Barry C. Black, urged lawmakers to admit their mistakes. He prayed to deliver members of Congress from hypocrisy and ‘stubborn pride.’

headline: Give Us This Day, Our Daily Senate Scolding
text: WASHINGTON — The disapproval comes from angry constituents, baffled party elders and colleagues on the other side of the Capitol. But nowhere have senators found criticism more personal or immediate than right inside their own chamber every morning when the chaplain delivers the opening prayer.

headline: Pirates, Willing to Be Stupid, Made Smart Midseason Moves
text: PITTSBURGH — It was one of the more memorable comments by a general manager in recent memory, and it said everything about the often conflicting goals of the job. When the Pittsburgh Pirates’ Neal Huntington failed to make a move at the July 31 trading deadline, he summarized his efforts this way: “We were willing to do something stupid. We just didn’t want to do something insane.”

headline: Syrian Officials Sound a Conciliatory Note Toward the Opposition
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Coming from a Syrian deputy prime minister, it was an unusual statement. The country’s crisis, he said, began in part with a “popular movement” of peaceful protesters angry over economic disparities, and descended into war in part because officials were slow to make changes and failed to realize that the “repression of the popular movement” would lead to disaster.

headline: Anxious Allies Aiding Booker in Senate Bid
text: Cory A. Booker is an undisputed star of a new generation of African-American leaders, electrifying liberal audiences with his oratory and charming the social media set with his digital savvy.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 7, 2013
text: “We acknowledge our transgressions, our shortcomings, our smugness, our selfishness and our pride. Deliver us from the hypocrisy of attempting to sound reasonable while being unreasonable.”

headline: Beaten and Booed
text: Fans at MetLife Stadium lost patience with the Giants, who fell to the Eagles and dropped to 0-5 for the first time since 1987.

headline: Drug Testing in Schools Divides North Jersey District
text: DEMAREST, N.J. — Jason Baretz wore a striped convict’s outfit as he addressed a group at Northern Valley Regional High School at Demarest on a recent Monday evening.

headline: Raising Her Voice in Pursuit of a Quieter City
text: Dresner’s restaurant, on York Avenue at 78th Street, should be fine for lunch, Arline L. Bronzaft had said when the appointment was set up. “It might be quiet,” she said. Quiet was important.

headline: Raids Show the Limits of U.S. Military Strikes
text: WASHINGTON — Four vans with tinted windows converged in a comfortable Tripoli neighborhood as a leader of Al Qaeda returned home on Saturday from early morning prayers. As his wife watched with alarm from a window, the men — armed with silencer-equipped weapons, some masked and some not — smashed his car window. Within moments, they were gone, taking with them one of America’s most wanted terror suspects.

headline: S.U.V. Fatally Hits Girl, 3, in Queens
text: A 3-year-old Queens girl was killed Sunday evening when she was struck by a sport utility vehicle as she crossed a street with her grandmother, the police said.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Oct. 6
Third Biker Is Charged in Attack on S.U.V. Driver
text: A motorcyclist who smashed his helmet into a sport utility vehicle after a high-speed chase last week was arraigned Sunday on several charges as the Police Department moved to determine whether one or more of its officers were present at a subsequent attack on the S.U.V.’s driver.

headline: Quest to Honor a Veteran Spans Years and Continents
text: Johan Kinberg was at his home in Sweden, researching his family tree, when he came across an old newspaper article about a World War I veteran who jumped to his death in Manhattan in 1922. The veteran’s name was Kinberg, too.

headline: The Color of Affordable Care
text: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Breakthroughs in Prenatal Screening
text: More than 30 years ago, a 37-year-old friend of mine with an unplanned fourth pregnancy was told by her obstetrician that an amniocentesis was “too dangerous” and could cause a miscarriage. She ultimately bore a child severely affected by Down syndrome, which could have been detected with the test.

headline: Word of the Day | spasmodic
text: spasmodic •\spaz-ˈmä-dik\• adjective

headline: In Military City, Government Reassurances Are Little Comfort
text: LAKEWOOD, Wash. — The Pentagon’s announcement that thousands of civilian Defense Department employees would soon return to work, even as the federal government shutdown continued, was welcome news to this city, which generations ago hitched its star to the military. But the anxiety remains, as do the wounds already inflicted on lives and businesses, in some cases by months of spending cuts even before the shutdown began.

headline: Chat Service Aims to Challenge Bloomberg
text: The largest banks on Wall Street are teaming up to join a network that could challenge an important part of Bloomberg’s terminal business.

headline: Supreme Court Has Deep Docket in Its New Term
text: WASHINGTON — After back-to-back terms ending in historic rulings that riveted the nation, the Supreme Court might have been expected to return to its usual diet of routine cases that rarely engage the public.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (HBO2) SHAME (2011) A handsome Manhattanite named Brandon (Michael Fassbender, above) hooked on sex finds his routine disrupted by the arrival of his sister (Carey Mulligan), whose neediness threatens his detached self-control — and whose self-destructive tendencies fuel his own — in this drama from the director Steve McQueen. “We’re not bad people,” she says in a teary message on his cellphone. “We just come from a bad place.” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times: “Is ‘Shame’ the name of something Brandon does feel, or of something the filmmakers think he should feel? The movie, for all its displays of honesty (which is to say nudity), is also curiously coy. It presents Brandon for our titillation, our disapproval and perhaps our envy, but denies him access to our sympathy. I know, that’s the point, that Mr. McQueen wants to show how the intensity of Brandon’s need shuts him off from real intimacy, but this seems to be a foregone conclusion, the result of an elegant experiment that was rigged from the start.”

headline: Police Question Brooklyn Woman in Death of 19-Month-Old Son
text: A Brooklyn woman was being questioned by detectives late Sunday night after her 19-month-old son was taken to a hospital, where he later died, according to the police.

headline: Dodgers’ Bats Pound Questions Into Footnotes
text: LOS ANGELES — Returning home with a split of the first two games of a playoff series would buoy spirits in many cities. But when the Dodgers took the field Sunday night, the anxiety about the game that slipped through their grasp in Atlanta, which had stewed for 48 hours, seemed palpable among the capacity crowd. The cheers for the home team sounded more hopeful than assuring.

headline: News Quiz | October 7, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page. Good luck!

headline: Return of the Guardian Angels
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Pump for Reactor Stops in Japan
text: TOKYO — The operator of Japan’s wrecked nuclear plant said Monday that a pump used to cool one of the damaged reactors had stopped, possibly because of human error, in the latest problem at the facility.

headline: Japan Airlines Deal With Airbus Is Blow in Boeing Stronghold
text: Stung by all the problems with its new 787 Dreamliner over the past decade, Boeing waited too long to start updating its larger 777 jets, giving Airbus an opening to break into the Japanese market that Boeing had dominated for decades, aviation analysts said Monday.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Oct. 7, 2013
text: Before Taking the Quiz

headline: Bombing Near Polio Vaccination Site Kills 2 Pakistani Police Officers
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — At least two police officers were killed and a dozen people wounded on Monday when a bomb went off near a health care facility where polio vaccines were being dispensed outside this northwestern Pakistani city, officials said.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | New Exhibition Features the Paintings and Re-Paintings of Vincent Van Gogh
text: In “Seeing Double: Van Gogh the Tweaker,” Henry Adams writes about world-renowned artist Vincent Van Gogh’s habit of copying his own original paintings, a practice that had long been “something of a dirty secret” and now, the subject of an exhibition.

headline: Obama’s Absence Leaves China as Dominant Force at Asia-Pacific Meeting
text: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — Secretary of State John Kerry replaced President Obama at the opening of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting on Monday, leaving China’s president, Xi Jinping, as the dominant leader at a gathering devoted to achieving greater economic integration.

headline: Anonymous Men, Made Real
text: We highly recommend viewing this slide show in “full-screen” mode.

headline: Who Should Be Able to See Students’ Records?
text: Every day people share personal information about themselves online, using social media, blogs and even email messages. What happens when information collected about you from schools you’ve attended is added to a software program to track your–and your school’s–progress, habits and behaviors?

headline: Week 5 N.F.L. Quick Hits: The Woes of Romo
text: Andy Benoit takes a tour through Week 5, including high drama in Dallas with a familiar finish for Tony Romo; a rare Patriots game without a touchdown pass from Tom Brady; and a Philadelphia offense that finally reached its potential.

headline: For 3 Nobel Winners, a Molecular Mystery Solved
text: Three Americans won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday for discovering the machinery that regulates how cells transport major molecules in a cargo system that delivers them to the right place at the right time.

headline: New York Today: Mr. Lhota’s Neighborhood
text: Updated 12:27 p.m. | Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor, likes to point out that he was raised in the Bronx. (A long way from Cambridge, Mass., where his opponent, Bill de Blasio, grew up).

headline: Your Ideas for Revisiting the News
text: Which news stories from decades past would you like to see re-examined today? Our weekly online video series, Retro Report, revisits what are supposedly old stories — but they all have much to tell us about news today.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on Daniel Radcliffe’s Introspective Side
text: Susan Dominus, a staff writer for the magazine, profiled the actor Daniel Radcliffe for this week’s cover story. Her last article for the magazine was about college career-services counseling.

headline: Richard Jewell: The Wrong Man
text: The 1996 Olympics in Atlanta were rocked by a bomb that killed one and injured more than 100. In the frenzy to find the perpetrator, an innocent man became a suspect.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Regulations for Cloud Computing
text: The digital privacy regulation introduced in Europe last year, which did not initially address cloud computing, is expanding to cover this ascendant method of handling data, Danny Hakim reports.

headline: A Bombing Suspect, and the Rush to Judgment
text: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of Richard Jewell, an innocent man, who in the summer of 1996 was painted by some news media outlets as being a likely suspect in a bombing at the Atlanta Olympics, which killed one person and injured more than 100 others. Using archival footage and recent interviews with the lead players, the video explains how a good deal of the newspaper and television coverage relied on unidentified law enforcement sources to cast Mr. Jewell in the worst possible light. It was nearly three months before the federal government cleared him, and almost a decade before Eric Rudolph, a violent anti-abortionist, pleaded guilty to the bombing. Below, The Times’s main reporter on the story recalls lessons learned.

headline: Ex-Minister in Greece Is Found Guilty in Bribery Case
text: ATHENS — In a landmark verdict, a former Greek defense minister and co-founder of the country’s once-mighty Socialist Party, Akis Tsochatzopoulos, was found guilty on Monday of setting up a complex money-laundering network to cover the trail of millions of dollars in bribes that he is said to have pocketed from government weapons purchases.

headline: World Bank Lowers East Asia Growth Forecasts
text: HONG KONG — The World Bank lowered its growth forecast for large parts of eastern Asia, saying on Monday that the rebalancing of the once red-hot Chinese economy, lower commodity prices and weaker-than-expected exports were holding back expansion in countries like Indonesia, Malaysia and China itself.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 7, 2013
text: Update: Oct. 8, 2013

headline: Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, Spiritual Leader of Israel’s Sephardic Jews, Dies at 93
text: JERUSALEM — Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, who became a fiery figure in Israeli politics as the spiritual leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, championing the interests of Jews of Middle Eastern and North African origin, died here on Monday. He was 93.

headline: Inside the Political Crisis
text: The government shutdown that began last week seemed to come out of nowhere. But the take-no-prisoners strategy among Republicans was planned months ago, as part of a long-running effort to undo the Affordable Care Act, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mike McIntire report in The New York Times.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Rivals Seek Share of Social Media Pie
text: Twitter, poised to make its splashy entrance on Wall Street, has helped define modern social networking. But while seeking to establish itself as an Internet powerhouse, it must also prove it can fend off a rising threat from a younger generation of nimble social outlets that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share content, Jenna Wortham and Vindu Goel report.

headline: The Watery Tomb Europe Tolerates
text: COPENHAGEN — A FEW years ago, a young woman I met in a small fishing village in central Ghana told me that, after her husband left to try to get to Italy, she stepped out into the courtyard of their home and saw his ghost at the gate.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: October 4-6, 2013
text: In an interview with Slate on Sunday, Garen Wintemute, a professor of emergency room medicine and director of the Violence Prevention Research Program at the University of California, Davis, revealed why gun research is such an uphill battle in the U.S. While guns claim 30,000 lives a year and injure 75,000, “federal funding for research is less than $200,000 a year,” he told Tiffany O’Callaghan. “In contrast, public health research on motor vehicle accidents—which also claim 30,000 lives each year—receives close to $4 million.”

headline: IndieCade Games Festival Celebrates Winners
text: IndieCade, the four-day festival known as the Sundance of games, announced the eclectic winners of three awards on Sunday night in Culver City, Calif.

headline: Britain Sought European Permission for Possible R.B.S. Split
text: LONDON – The British government has filed for permission from the European Union to possibly split the Royal Bank of Scotland into two entities, a move that would essentially wall off troubled assets that crippled the bank and led to a government bailout five years ago, the European Commission confirmed on Monday.

headline: All the Rage | Funny Sweaters
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Today in Small Business: No Backbone
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Star Takes a Stab at ‘American Psycho’ Musical
text: An actor gives up the lead role he has played for nearly four years and the next thing you know, he’s turned to murder. Matt Smith, who has traveled time and space on the science-fiction TV series “Doctor Who,” is putting down his sonic screwdriver and picking up some sharper, Earth-made implements to play the bloodthirsty Patrick Bateman in a London stage musical adaptation of “American Psycho,” its press representatives said on Monday.

headline: Twitter’s Filing for I.P.O.
text: Twitter set the price of its initial public offering at $26 a share, valuing the company at $18.1 billion.

headline: Credibility All The Way Down
text: Ken Rogoff has responded to Simon Wren-Lewis and yours truly, and I’m glad to see that he’s taking the analytical questions we raised seriously. I guess it won’t surprise readers, however, to learn that I don’t find the response adequate.

headline: On Knowing What You Don’t Know
text: Brad DeLong catches Niall Ferguson making another whoopsie. And while chasing NF isn’t worth the effort for its own sake, I think there is a broader lesson here: namely, the importance of knowing what you don’t know.

headline: Karen Strauss Cook, Trader Who Helped Women on Wall Street, Dies at 61
text: Karen Strauss Cook, a trailblazing trader at Goldman Sachs who went on to help other working mothers find part-time jobs in finance, died on Wednesday in New York. She was 61.

headline: With Reid Statement, Relationship With Boehner Grows More Acid
text: Senator Harry Reid on Monday morning blistered Speaker John A. Boehner in a statement, worsening the already tense atmosphere over the shutdown and debt ceiling negotiations.

headline: Life in A Refugee Camp Near Muzaffarnagar
text: MALAKPUR, Uttar Pradesh— Of the 42,000 people who fled their homes in Muzaffarnagar after violence broke out between Hindus and Muslims in early September, several thousand have settled near this village, about 60 miles north of New Delhi, staying in rows of colorful tarpaulin tents that are just wide enough for a cot and just high enough to allow one to sit upright.

headline: A Magical Isle Loses the Last of Its Residents
text: It sounded like a nursery rhyme, but it was true.

headline: G.M. Recalls 1,600 Sonics for Fuel Tank Defect
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is on a hiatus because of the federal government shutdown, but that doesn’t mean automakers cannot initiate recalls on their own. General Motors said in a news release on Monday that it would recall about 1,558 Chevrolet Sonics from the 2013-14 model years in the United States because the strap holding the gas tank could break.

headline: Top Court Will Not Hear Argentina Debt Case
text: WASHINGTON – The Supreme Court refused on Monday to hear Argentina’s appeal of a lower court’s decision in favor of hedge funds that held bonds on which the country had defaulted.

headline: Ruth Benerito, Who Made Cotton Cloth Behave, Dies at 97
text: Half a century ago, working quietly in a New Orleans laboratory, Ruth Benerito helped smooth the fabric of modern life. In so doing, she helped liberate people from hours of household drudgery.

headline: Coping With Local Government Regulations
text: At the last She Owns It business group meeting, we talked about government regulations – especially at the state level (this was before the federal government shutdown). This post continues that conversation.

headline: The Netherworld of What Constitutes Insider Trading
text: Identifying insider trading sometimes seems like a game of three-card monte: first you see it, then you don’t.

headline: After Years of Pain, Greece Expects a Budget Surplus
text: ATHENS — Offering the first real hope that Greece could emerge from a six-year recession, the government on Monday presented a draft budget for next year forecasting a tenuous return to growth.

headline: Egyptian Attacks Are Escalating Amid Stalemate
text: CAIRO — The lethal conflict between Egypt’s military-backed government and its Islamist opponents escalated on Monday, with an expansion of attacks against government targets, signs that the authorities have failed to secure the streets and that both sides refuse to back down.

headline: Stir-Fried Beet Greens, Tofu and Beets
text: I had lots of beet greens on hand during the week that I was testing all of these beet recipes, so I decided to combine them with julienned beets in a stir-fry. The greens should be crisp-tender.

headline: Japanese Court Fines Rightist Group Over Protests at a School in Kyoto
text: TOKYO — In a widely watched decision, a court in Kyoto on Monday ordered a far-right group to pay $120,000 in damages to an elementary school for ethnic Koreans after the group staged demonstrations using slogans that the court characterized as racist.

headline: Beet and Chia Pancakes
text: Ever since I read Kim Boyce’s recipe for quinoa and beet pancakes, a recipe that inspired her wonderful book “Good to the Grain,” I’ve wanted to add puréed beets to a pancake batter. I finally got around to it. I used two-thirds whole wheat flour and one-third all-purpose flour in this very pink batter. Ms. Boyce uses a mixture of quinoa flour and all-purpose, which shows off the bright color of the beets to a better effect. I think millet flour would be a good choice too. It’s important to purée the roasted beets until they’re really smooth; I found using a powerful hand blender was more effective for this than my food processor.

headline: The Anxiety of Exodus
text: TEL AVIV — Israelis are fretting about emigration after a recent series on Channel 10 News featured disillusioned Israelis who left the homeland. The émigrés thought the country didn’t pay enough attention to the needs of the young and the middle class.

headline: Kobe Who? Showtime Has Moved to Dodger Stadium
text: LOS ANGELES — It is so loud inside Dodger Stadium these days that Tommy Lasorda cannot listen to himself talk, and Magic Johnson can hardly hear his own hyperbole. Not coincidentally, it is N.B.A.-arena loud — quite a feat for a building with the sky as its ceiling and a soothing outfield backdrop of rolling hills and mountains.

headline: The Dashilar Pilot
text: This project to regenerate a historic area of Beijing was introduced at the recent Beijing Design Festival.

headline: Solvay Pays Up to Get Into Fracking
text: Solvay is paying up to tap into fracking.

headline: City Ballet’s Chase Finlay Is Recovering From Injury
text: The New York City Ballet’s principal dancer Chase Finlay is not expected back onstage until the winter season after breaking his foot during a performance of “Swan Lake,” said a company spokeswoman.

headline: On the Verge | The Magical Mosaics of Yukiko Nagai
text: Yukiko Nagai was recently anointed one of design’s bright young things by the renowned Milan-based gallery owner Rossana Orlandi, who became entranced by the 32-year-old Japanese artist’s work, like the Patchwork Chair (above), which has a cushion made of marble and glass tiles. Nagai, whose studies in landscape design led to her interest in mosaics, uses the same technique to mimic other unlikely materials — wood grain and boar hide — always creating a second-glance surprise that subverts the viewer’s expectations of comfort.

headline: Image of the Day: October 7
text: A jewelry shop owner awaiting customers in Old Delhi.

headline: Martin Gardner’s The Monkey and the Coconuts
text: For the next several weeks we’ll be celebrating the life and interests of Martin Gardner, the American science and math writer who popularized the notion of recreational mathematics — math for fun. Many readers of this blog may be familiar with Mr. Gardner through his puzzles: we can’t go very long here at Numberplay without featuring a puzzle that Martin Gardner either discovered, created or popularized.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Monster Truck Crash Kills 8 at Mexican Air Show
text: At least 79 spectators were wounded, officials said, after an out-of-control truck drove into a crowd in Chihuahua on Sunday. The driver has been detained on suspicion of manslaughter.

headline: Legal Side Effect in Admission of Wrongdoing to the S.E.C.
text: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | When Philip A. Falcone admitted committing “multiple acts of misconduct” in a settlement this summer with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the hedge fund billionaire appeared to put his legal woes to rest.

headline: Some Civilians Return to Military Academies
text: WASHINGTON — United States military academies got some relief from their government shutdown struggles over the weekend as the Pentagon reinstated most of its furloughed civilian employees, allowing professors and other staff members to return to work on Monday.

headline: Should the President Negotiate?
text: For our polarized times, here are two polarized views of the debt ceiling debate, which is set to swallow up the unresolved government shutdown debate sometime late this week. First, Kevin Hassett and Abby McCloskey in the Wall Street Journal, attacking the president for his refusal to negotiate around a debt limit extension:

headline: Zoellick to Join Goldman as International Adviser
text: Goldman Sachs said on Monday that it had hired Robert B. Zoellick, the former president of the World Bank, as the chairman of its international advisory board.

headline: A Most Inquisitive Court? No Argument There
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court has what lawyers call a hot bench, and temperatures are rising.

headline: The Day My War Ended
text: Standing shoulder to shoulder with hundreds of heavily armed paratroopers, I looked around at all of us, breathing heavily, angry and resentful, surrounding the Baya mosque in Baghdad. The previous morning, we had arrested the head imam because he was stockpiling weapons in the mosque. Now, under amber street lamps casting wicked shadows, his followers were gathered, demanding his release. My adrenaline was still pumping from the explosion minutes earlier, when one of them tossed a grenade at our line of troops, injuring more than a half-dozen soldiers and civilians. After that, order descended into a running street battle, soldiers wrestling protesters, bodies slamming into the hard concrete. Months of pent-up aggression were suddenly released in a cathartic, chaotic performance.

headline: Expecting Not to Stay, but Now Right at Home
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — Paul Worrilow and Joplo Bartu, who shared a room during the Atlanta Falcons’ off-season training in the spring, would read their playbooks or watch practice videos on their iPads at night, and then quiz each other about the fine art of playing linebacker.

headline: The Making of Malala
text: The story of Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl, told by The Times’s Adam B. Ellick, who made a 2009 documentary about her before she was an international star.

headline: Feeling For | Backpackers and Businessmen Alike Check Into Hlemmur Square in Reykjavik
text: Klaus Ortlieb, a German-born hotelier who made his mark stateside with the Hotel Modern in New Orleans and two properties in New York City (the Gotham Hotel and the Standard East Village), proves once again that building a successful hotel is not unlike throwing a much-talked-about party. It’s all about appealing to a wide range of guests. So for the new Hlemmur Square hotel in Reykjavik, he designed a high-low model to accommodate the discerning traveler at any budget. The 26 shared, hostel-style rooms are available for as little as $20 per night, while the 18 private rooms, on a separate, plusher floor, cost as much as $182. A far cry from the standard-issue budget digs of yore, the hostel suites offer duvet-covered beds, complimentary local telephone calls and optional room service. And the upgrade to a private room comes with the usual boutique hotel comforts: modern décor (earth tones and oak parquet floors, gray walls dotted with black-and-white photographs of Old Reykjavik), extra-cozy beds (made with up with Lissadell linens) and stunning, top-floor views (of the city’s boldly colored roofs).

headline: An Educational Program for Graffiti Art
text: The institutionalization of graffiti culture continues apace: a program teaching the style and history of illegal tagging is set to begin this month.

headline: Top Editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer Is Dismissed
text: In the latest example of management turmoil at The Philadelphia Inquirer, William K. Marimow was fired as the paper’s top editor on Monday.

headline: After Years on Run, Libyan Was Found With Family
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — When Delta Force commandos homed in on Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai in a neighborhood of Tripoli this weekend, they found him settled with his wife and children in his family’s traditional home after nearly three decades on the move.

headline: How the Shutdown Is Affecting Cape Hatteras Seashore
text: Ocracoke Island, the southernmost barrier island of the Outer Banks in North Carolina, enjoys such a strong association with its one-square-mile historic village that some tourists here were surprised to learn the federal shutdown had affected their vacation plans.

headline: Healthful Muffins, Moist and Sweet, for Anytime
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes for supper, or, in this case, lunch.

headline: India Says It Has Killed 7 in Clashes Along Pakistan Border
text: NEW DELHI — India says it has killed seven fighters and is still fighting others in a Pakistan-backed force of several dozen who crossed a mountainous and thickly forested border area with the aim of killing Indian troops, ratcheting up tensions just as the two countries’ leaders agreed to work together to de-escalate the situation.

headline: Street Style: Tie Dye
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Oct. 1.

headline: Obama Challenges Boehner on Budget Vote
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday made an unscheduled visit to the Federal Emergency Management Agency in his latest bid to draw attention to the effects of the government shutdown and to challenge Speaker John A. Boehner’s claim that he does not have enough votes to pass a measure to finance the government.

headline: Competition and Productive Off-Season Keep Jets’ Kicker Sharp
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — For four springs, like clockwork, Nick Folk would be home in New York or training in California when the news finally floated his way: the Jets had brought in another kicker to take his job.

headline: The Flight of the Fly
text: Michael Dickinson has spent his career studying how flies fly and researchers in his lab have invented new devices to investigate the complex feat of insect flight.

headline: Focusing on Fruit Flies, Curiosity Takes Flight
text: SEATTLE — To hear Michael Dickinson tell it, there is nothing in the world quite as wonderful as a fruit fly.

headline: 57th Street Reopened After Crane Malfunction in Midtown
text: A crane malfunctioned on Monday at the same Midtown Manhattan high-rise that was the scene of a crane accident during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Weighing Surgeries in Light of a Breast Cancer Gene
text: When Tracy Dunbrook, a bioethicist in Sherman, Conn., tested positive for the BRCA gene mutation, she was told she had a 40 to 60 percent chance of developing ovarian cancer in her lifetime. Doctors advised her to have her ovaries removed.

headline: A St. Regis New York Face-Lift Spurs a Glamour Campaign
text: The St. Regis New York is showing off its $90 million renovation in a new multimedia ad campaign inspired by vintage advertising and fashion photography.

headline: A Recent Flourish for Winton Capital
text: Winton Capital Management is showing some improvement in the art of investing.

headline: Scalia’s Echo Chamber
text: Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia has seen the T.V. show “Duck Dynasty.” In an interview published on Sunday with New York Magazine’s Jennifer Senior, he said many people recommended it to him as a “great show” and he figured he’d “better look at it.”  He also said he’d seen “The Sopranos,” plus a couple of episodes of “Mad Men,” and that he loved “Seinfeld.” “Oh, boy,” he said, “The Nazi soup kitchen? No soup for you!”

headline: Monday Motorsports: IndyCar Crash Injures Franchitti and 13 Spectators in Houston
text: Three-time Indianapolis 500 winner Dario Franchitti broke his back and sustained other injuries in a huge last-lap crash Sunday at the Grand Prix of Houston. At least 13 spectators and one official were also injured by flying debris.

headline: Documenting a Pakistani Girl’s Transformation
text: There is a story to Malala Yousafzai’s improbable transformation from a quiet, deferential 11-year-old living near Pakistan’s tribal areas to a teenage spokeswoman for girls’ education. Malala, shot in the head by the Taliban last year, has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, to be announced on Friday.

headline: The Crazy, Intense Schedule of Competitive Youth Soccer? Bring It On
text: If my husband and I had to choose, we would live in Athens. While we were both athletes as children, as adults we make our home firmly in the world of content creation. Our daughter, however, lives much of her life in Sparta, by which I mean the world of highly competitive team sports.

headline: A Few Controversies Amid a Record Number of Foreign-Language Oscar Entries
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has just announced its  official list of contenders for the 2014 Oscar for best foreign-language film, and, as usual, the movies that were submitted — or left out or disqualified — reflect a process that is rife with politics and intrigue.

headline: Banksy Parodies Syrian Rebel Videos
text: Last Updated, 5:49 p.m. | The British street artist Banksy is apparently among the millions watching Syria’s war from afar, through glimpses of the fighting recorded on video and posted on YouTube. His latest video work is a brief parody of one of those clips released on Sunday as part of a series of works produced during a monthlong residency in New York that started last week.

headline: Losing Money on a Treasury Bill
text: Some investors in treasury bills — the safest, lowest-yielding assets around — are getting a little nervous.

headline: Obama Challenges Boehner to Hold a Vote
text: During a visit to FEMA on Monday, the president said there were enough Republican and Democratic votes in Congress to pass a clean spending bill and pressured the House speaker to call for a vote.

headline: Massacre at Baxter Springs
text: On the afternoon of Oct. 6, 1863, Maj. Gen. James G. Blunt lost 82 men when a Union baggage train making its way to Fort Blair near the southeastern Kansas town of Baxter Springs was attacked by Confederate guerrillas. The loss of the men was bad enough – but the Confederates also made off with Blunt’s clothing, sword, commissions, correspondence, official papers and a flag the ladies of Leavenworth, Kan., had presented to him four days earlier.

headline: Unease in Hawaii’s Cornfields
text: WAIMEA, Hawaii — The balmy tropical isles here seem worlds apart from the expansive cornfields of the Midwest, but Hawaii has become the latest battleground in the fight over genetically modified crops.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 1-7, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Energy-Saving Secret of Jellyfish
text: The moon jelly, or common jellyfish, is often viewed as a problem, an ecological invader, a nuisance to swimmers, or worse. A moon jelly population explosion last month clogged the water intakes of a Swedish nuclear power plant, forcing it to shut down. The jellyfish, which can be 2 to 15 inches in diameter, is such a concern that engineers in South Korea designed seagoing, prowling robotic blenders to liquefy the offenders.

headline: ScienceTake: The Jellyfish Engine
text: The moon jellyfish is slow, but there's a reason for that. Its undulating pace allows it to swim more efficiently than just about anything in the ocean.

headline: Young People Are Not as Digitally Native as You Think
text: Everyone knows young people these days are born with smartphones in hand and will stay glued to the Internet from that time onward. Right?

headline: The Age Suit and Talking to Older Drivers About Giving Up the Keys
text: Imagine you have arthritis in every joint. With a stiff neck, knees that won’t bend past 40 degrees and arms that take great effort to hold up, driving would be a chore. Getting into the driver’s seat would be a controlled fall of sorts, and after plopping down behind the wheel, turning your head to check the mirrors would be nearly impossible.

headline: The New World of the Kolache
text: This soft pastry of yeasted dough, traditionally filled with sweetened cheese or fruit, is now straddling several constituencies.

headline: The Kolache: Czech, Texan or All-American? (All Three)
text: HOUSTON — Morgan Weber grew up eating poppy-seed kolaches baked by his Czech grandmother, who honed her technique on a wood stove. Kolaches, soft pastries of yeasted dough with a divot in the center, traditionally filled with sweetened cheese or fruit, are a humble link to the Old World.

headline: Readers Ask About Families Who Want Different Plans, and Rise in Costs
text: In the last two installments of the Your Money column, I answered questions about the new health insurance exchanges. The first column discussed many of the basics, and the second column answered reader questions. You can find more readers’ questions and answers on In Practice, with the latest series below. If you’re still not sure how the law affects you and your family, please e-mail me your questions: tsbernard@nytimes.com.

headline: The Amazing Fruit Fly, Millions Left Out of the New Health Law
text: The humble fruit fly turns out to be a lot more complicated than you might think; a sweeping national effort to extend health coverage to millions of Americans will leave out two-thirds of poor blacks and single mothers.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 30-Oct. 6
text: Shall we dance? The choreography of sports is seen in all manner of competition.

headline: Collisions of Football Helmets and Money
text: The National Football League, so good at hyping its own games and stars, may have inadvertently sprinkled some of that promotional fairy dust on “League of Denial: The NFL’s Concussion Crisis,” a “Frontline” installment about brain injuries among players.

headline: A Magical, Flying Visit From a Magical, Flying Boy
text: In “Peter Pan,” at the New Victory Theater, Peter is played by a fit young man, Meyne Wyatt, rather than by a petite woman. And instead of tights and forest leaves, this Peter wears gym shorts, a T-shirt and sneakers.

headline: Default Threat Generates Fear Around Globe
text: LONDON — The bitter fiscal stalemate in Washington is producing nervous ripples from London to Bali, with increasing anxiety that the United States might actually default on a portion of its government debt, set off global financial troubles and undercut fragile economic recoveries in many countries.

headline: What Happened to Recreational Sports?
text: My children have no wish to live in Sparta, and I have no desire to change that.

headline: French Judges Drop Investigation Into Charges Against Sarkozy
text: PARIS — French magistrates said Monday they were dropping an investigation into charges that former President Nicolas Sarkozy had manipulated a fragile heiress into financing his 2007 campaign, removing a potential obstacle to the political return that Mr. Sarkozy is widely assumed to be planning.

headline: Trends in Interregional and International Trade
text: Well, I’ve just paid my first personal price for the shutdown; I’m trying to finish a paper for the Walter Isard memorial volume, and discovered that the International Trade Commission’s invaluable Dataweb is shut down. I know, people are missing essential medical care and more, and I’m complaining about a slight academic inconvenience. But it’s a symptom.

headline: A Painting as Talisman, as Enduring as Loved Ones Are Not
text: The goldfinch referred to in the title of Donna Tartt’s dazzling new novel is a charming painting of a pet bird created in 1654 by the Dutch artist Carel Fabritius, who died that year at 32, when the gunpowder arsenal in Delft exploded, destroying part of the city. His “Goldfinch” is considered a small but priceless masterpiece of Dutch painting.

headline: On Vieques, Destination Weddings for Gay Couples
text: With growing legalization of same-sex marriage it was just a matter of time before gay couples got the travel pitch for destination weddings. Now the W Retreat & Spa-Vieques Island has a partnership with the  same-sex wedding specialist Bernadette Coveney Smith, founder of the planning service 14 Stories, to offer destination wedding ceremonies for same-sex couples at the oceanfront resort on the Puerto Rican island.

headline: Cheating’s Surprising Thrill
text: When was the last time you cheated?

headline: Blame the Deficit Scolds
text: If we have a debt-ceiling crisis in a couple of weeks, with dire economic effects, don’t just blame Boehner’s Bunglers; you should also blame the deficit scolds — the Committee for a Responsible Peterson Budget and so on, and all the Very Serious People who have lent them support. For as Jonathan Chait reminds us, these organizations all cheered the Republicans on in 2011, as they made the first-ever use of the debt ceiling to blackmail a sitting president.

headline: Lessons of the Richard Jewell Case, False Balance, and More

headline: Record Sales for Broadway’s ‘Betrayal’
text: The new Broadway revival of Harold Pinter’s marital drama “Betrayal,” starring Daniel Craig (the current James Bond) and his real-life wife, Oscar winner Rachel Weisz (“The Constant Gardener”), set a box-office record at the Barrymore Theater last week for its first week of performances, a spokesman for the production said on Monday.

text: Norbert Leo Butz, with Jim Hershman on guitar, sings "Fight the Dragons" from the new Broadway musical "Big Fish," at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: Do Most Flowers Have 5 Petals?
text: Q. Most flowers I see have five petals. Is this generally true, and if so, why?

text: The architect Rafael Viñoly has been enlisted to help spice up the Spring Show NYC at the Park Avenue Armory, organized and founded by the Art and Antique Dealers League of America and produced by the Art Fair Company.

headline: SunTrust Analyst Explains His $50 a Share Price Target for Twitter
text: It has been only four days since Twitter first took the wraps off its initial public offering prospectus. But that hasn’t stopped Robert Peck from setting a high $50-a-share price target on the still-private social network.

headline: Sponges Recycle Food for Reefs
text: It is known as Darwin’s paradox: coral reefs are rife with animal and plant life, yet exist in clear, nutrient-free waters. Where is the food coming from?
