headline: How the U.S. Is Interrogating a Qaeda Suspect
text: The United States seized a leader of Al Qaeda — Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, better known as Abu Anas al-Libi — outside his three-story house in Tripoli, Libya, on Saturday and is reportedly interrogating him in the brig of the Navy ship the San Antonio, in the Mediterranean Sea. The following covers some basic questions about his interrogation.

headline: Charting Success in Battling AIDS
text: About a dozen countries hit hard by AIDS have reached a “tipping point” that means they are winning their battles against the disease, according to a new analysis.

headline: Gates’s Future Fuels Speculation as Microsoft Seeks New Chief
text: SEATTLE — There’s a question being whispered around Microsoft’s sprawling suburban campus: What will Bill Gates do?

headline: A Partnership Built on Fostering Change
text: Bill Gates met Melinda French in the 1980s, when he was Microsoft’s chief executive officer and she was a young associate product manager there. They married in 1994.

headline: A Disconnect in Money, Logic and Emotion
text: Stop for a minute and think about how we show the value of money. It’s in nice, neat columns on our financial statements. It’s in specific dollars and cents. The value of money appears to be a very clear-cut and logical part of our lives, at least on paper.

headline: Walkabout: Competing Visions for Lake Tahoe; AirBnB Subpoenaed for User Data
text: Natural Rivals Protecting Lake Tahoe, which straddles the California-Nevada border, brings the two states into play, with sometimes competing visions for the lake’s future. (The New York Times)

headline: Seeking Clarity on Fees at the Metropolitan Museum
text: Seeking to reconcile two contradictory realities — a friend said admission was free, and a sign said admission might or might not be $25 — Ingrid Opperman stood at the entrance desk to the Metropolitan Museum of Art on a recent morning and whipped out her English-German dictionary.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, Iraq, Italy and Iran.

headline: Tempers Flare in Ninth as Athletics Gain the Edge
text: DETROIT — Grant Balfour, the Australian-born Oakland Athletics closer, pitches with a maniacal streak. He fires himself up with screaming bursts of R-rated patter, a bizarre habit that can be unnerving even to teammates.

headline: Union Action at Scottish Refinery Could Escalate
text: LONDON — A labor action that began Monday at the huge Grangemouth refinery and petrochemical complex in Scotland could threaten the future of the unprofitable plant, analysts said.

headline: How Young Mice Tell Older Ones, ‘Get Lost’
text: As nocturnal animals, mice rely on the chemical substances called pheromones to share personal information with other rodents. Age, gender and general state of health are all determined by the sniff of a whiskery nose.

headline: A Hero Just Wants to Frolic With Muses, but What’s With That Evil Gnome?
text: New York City Ballet, approaching the end of its fall season at the David H. Koch Theater, has just added two new triple bills. Though one of these is a marvelous group of Balanchine story ballets, the most newsworthy item occurs in the other: the first revival in three years of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Namouna, a Grand Divertissement,” a fascinating and delicious if obviously frustrating work that demonstrates much of the nature of Mr. Ratmansky’s talent.

headline: When the Best-Laid Plans Still Aren’t Enough
text: I’M a partner and chief creative officer at Puccini Group. We conceptualize, design and operate restaurants, mainly in the hotel industry. So most of my business travel involves pitching new clients or researching cities for business development purposes. I’m an architect by training and I like seeing new places and how they are designed, so I don’t really mind the travel.

headline: Fast Food, Not Fine Dining, Tops Expense Account List
text: IN nearly 15 years of writing this column every week, the cold hammer of oppression has come down on me from New York just once, more than 10 years ago. On a trip to San Francisco, I was too tired to find a restaurant, so I stopped at a Walgreens near Union Square, bought a cheap little canned ham and some rolls and made a sandwich back in my hotel room.

headline: Alex Drexler: A Personal Quest for the Perfect White Shirt
text: Alex Drexler was not happy with the sock arrangement. Mr. Drexler was standing at his recently opened clothing store, Alex Mill, staring intently down at the socks, which were displayed unrolled, in a windowless frame, laying flat on a counter. Maybe they should be moved a few inches to the left? Or to the right?

headline: Tending to Colombia’s Disappeared and Their Final Homes
text: The double N in the title of “Réquiem NN” is no misprint: It stands for sadness and, very probably, suffering. In this brief documentary, the Colombian artist Juan Manuel Echavarría chronicles the stacked tombs of anonymous victims from his country’s decades of violent internecine conflict. Each is marked with the abbreviation for “no name” in Spanish, but as shown here, the unknown dead enter a kind of second life through the residents of Puerto Berrío, where bodies found in the nearby Magdalena River are buried.

headline: Fact-Checking Hynes’s Take on a Reversal
text: Charles J. Hynes, Brooklyn’s current and perhaps future district attorney, sat down to talk politics last week with a journalist who agreed to play pretend with him.

headline: A Polish History Lesson Emerges Through Song
text: The Polish cleric who would later be named St. Adalbert of Prague died gruesomely while trying to convert Prussian pagans to Christianity in 997. He ventured too close to a sacred oak grove and was attacked by a mob bearing axes and lances.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Avoiding a Candy Crush Crash, and Airbnb Subpoenaed
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Sleigh Bells, Glasser and Matana Roberts Release New Albums
text: SLEIGH BELLS

headline: Tiny Particle Looms Large on Eve of Top Physics Prize
text: It’s that time of year again, when physicists of a certain age, even if they do not want to admit it, are afraid to step into their morning shower for fear of missing the call from Stockholm.

headline: Do Republicans Believe in Their Own Crisis?
text: You would think Republicans would be the ones trying to scare the country about the imminent expiration of the Treasury’s borrowing authority. After all, they’re the ones trying to use the debt ceiling (and the government shutdown) as leverage to get their way on policies that would be laughed out of Washington at any other moment.

headline: Excerpts: Four New Books on Water
text: From its history to how we use it today, four new books tackle a subject that runs through all of our lives.

headline: Plenty of Water, but Little to Drink
text: Earth, “the blue planet,” has a lot of water. Most of the planet’s surface is covered with it. But less than 5 percent of that water is fresh, and much of that is locked up in ice sheets or inconveniently far underground. And it is not always most abundant where it is most needed.

headline: Cardinals Even Series Behind Gem by a Rookie
text: PITTSBURGH — In the opening game of the 1912 World Series, at the Polo Grounds, a 24-year-old rookie named Jeff Tesreau carried a no-hitter into the sixth inning for the New York Giants. Boston’s Tris Speaker broke it up with a triple, and Tesreau lost the game.

headline: Damien Hirst Sculptures Unveiled
text: On Monday, the British artist Damien Hirst unveiled 14 monumental bronze sculptures in Doha, Qatar. The installation is considered a bold move by the Qatar Museums Authority.

headline: Art, From Conception to Birth in Qatar
text: DOHA, Qatar — For weeks, 14 giant balloons had been mysteriously parked in front of the Sidra Medical and Research Center, a hulking steel, glass and white ceramic building devoted to women’s and children’s health that is to open on the outskirts of this city in 2015.

headline: How to Slice a Global Carbon Pie?
text: STOCKHOLM — It was the middle of the night. In a matter of hours, journalists from around the world would be showing up, expecting details about the latest big United Nations climate report. But behind closed doors here, as the final wording of that document was being worked out, things were not going well.

headline: Percussion Goes Global
text: Pedrito Martínez is known for his residency at Guantanamera in Manhattan. With his first album coming out this week, the challenge was to bring the energy of his performances to the studio.

headline: In a Safer Brooklyn, the End Nears for an Outbound Bus
text: Spider Duncan Christopher remembers when the bus to Manhattan was always full after a performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, or BAM. There was, he recalled, a simple reason that so many passengers once piled in.

headline: Pushing Boundaries of Rumba Fervor
text: It has become a familiar question backstage at festivals, concert halls or anywhere else that musicians gather on the road: Have you heard that amazing Cuban percussionist in New York City? Pedrito Martínez may not yet be known to the public, but among his peers, he is firmly established as a source of rhythmic delight and inspiration.

headline: Electric Water Droplets and a Secret to Long Life (in Rats, Anyway)
text: Thanks to the federal government shutdown, the big science news last week was a sudden halt to all manner of research projects. Scientists across the country found themselves locked out of their labs as any work deemed nonessential — a designation that could seem arbitrary at times — was stopped. “Academic medicine is no day at the beach,” said Ellen Beckjord, an assistant professor at the University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute, to The Huffington Post. “It doesn’t help matters when the rug gets torn out from under you like this.”

headline: Microsoft: The Cloud Can’t Be Slave to the Past
text: Microsoft will soon have a range of products to beef up its cloud computing business. According to the guy running the show, however, the most important thing is not what Microsoft is selling, but how it was made.

headline: Motion, Motion, Stillness, Stillness
text: Stamina. That’s what Molissa Fenley became most famous for, not long after she began performing her own works as a 22-year-old choreographer in 1977. Now a month shy of 59, she’s still at it, dancing with no signs of fatigue in a premiere and two reconstructions that began a run at New York Live Arts on Wednesday.

headline: Checking on Android Updates for Older Phones
text: Android Updates

headline: Pakistani Girl Shot by Taliban Says Militants Only Helped Amplify Her Message
text: As my colleague Adam Ellick reports, Malala Yousafzai, the young girl who was shot in the head by the Taliban a year ago, has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, to be announced on Friday.

headline: New Sculptures in Doha, Qatar
text: Images of the new sculptures by Damien Hirst unveiled this week.

headline: Multiethnic Style in Rego Park
text: In the latest Intersection video, we visit Rego Park, Queens, where Jamilla Galloway modernizes the pin-up look.

headline: Pals, Along for a Ride
text: Jack Kerouac doesn’t figure into Cloud Gate 2’s production of “On the Road,” even though this dance is about a journey, and it does strike an unmistakable note of male bonding. Performed by this Taiwanese company in a run that began on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, the work was inspired by a trip to Yunnan, a province in southwest China.

headline: Will Treasury Pay?
text: Treasury bills normally become more expensive as they come closer to their due date, but investors are paying less for bills due right after the nation hits its projected borrowing limit on Oct. 17.

headline: Hotels Go to Extra Lengths for the Repeat Customer
text: When Leslie Ciminello arrives at the Hotel 1000 in Seattle, she knows milk and cereal will be waiting in her room’s refrigerator. Lactose-free milk and gluten-free cereal, that is.

headline: In Times Square, a Friendly Jab at Atheists
text: If the evangelical organization Answers in Genesis was looking to take its message to a secular audience, it would be hard to do better than the heart of Times Square at noon on Monday.

headline: East Coast Calls It a Night for a West Coast Game
text: The San Diego-Oakland game Sunday night on NFL Network was a scheduling rarity: a major sports event shown live in prime time on the West Coast.

headline: Cuban Says He Was Taken Aback by S.E.C. Charges
text: DALLAS – Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, testified on Monday that he was cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission as early as 2004 in an inquiry into an Internet search engine company and was taken aback when he turned on the news one day in 2008 and heard that the agency was charging him with insider trading.

headline: A New Investment Bank, Kimberlite, to Focus on Advice
text: Wall Street’s big banks advertise themselves as full-service shops, boasting that they can offer a range of services to institutional clients. But one new investment bank is taking the opposite approach.

headline: At Ad Conference, Ron Burgundy and ‘Infobesity’
text: PHOENIX — HERE is a look at some highlights, sidelights and lowlights from the 2013 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which took place here from Thursday through Sunday.

headline: Meeting With Israelis, Palestinian Leader Strikes a Conciliatory Tone on Peace Talks
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — In a rare meeting with Israeli politicians, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority expressed optimism on Monday that a peace agreement could be reached in the nine months allotted to the current round of negotiations, and pointedly avoided questions that proved provocative in the past.

headline: Britain Replaces Minister Responsible for Scotland
text: LONDON — Less than a year before Scots vote on independence, the British cabinet minister responsible for Scotland, Michael Moore, was dismissed on Monday, apparently to give a harder edge to the campaign against the breakup of Britain.

headline: A Greek Tragedy With Elements of Danger. Carlos Danger.
text: Oedipus. Othello. Weiner?

headline: Billions in Debt, Detroit Faces Millions in Bills for Bankruptcy
text: DETROIT — This city is learning that it is expensive to go broke.

headline: Worsening Debt Crisis Threatens Puerto Rico
text: While Detroit has preoccupied Americans with its record-breaking municipal bankruptcy, another public finance crisis on a potentially greater scale has been developing off most Americans’ radar screens, in Puerto Rico.

headline: Powerhouse to Punch Line, N.F.C. East Is in Free Fall
text: If the N.F.C. East were a state, city or county, the federal government would declare it a disaster area and provide millions of dollars to bulldoze the refuse and start over.

headline: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 4
text: In the final episode of a four-part series, "Home" comprises images submitted by New York Times readers, who show their lives in high-rises around the world.

headline: Little Fear on Wall St. of Default, at Moment
text: Wall Street is showing few signs so far that it is fearing the financial panic it has been predicting should the government default on its debt.

headline: More Setbacks in Deal for U.S. Tire Maker
text: Updated, 12:47 a.m. | When Apollo Tyres of India announced a $2.5 billion plan to buy Cooper Tire and Rubber in June, deal watchers believed the subcontinent’s economic tiger was finally beginning to roar.

headline: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 3
text: In the third episode of a four-part series, "Glass" examines the recent proliferation of luxury condos and the growing segregation between the rich and poor.

headline: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 2
text: In the second episode of a four-part series, "Concrete" explores how, in New York City and globally, residential high-rises and public housing attempted to foster social equality in the 20th century.

headline: When Clothes No Longer Make the Man
text: As I watched the coverage of Milan’s fall fashion week — the penultimate of a month of fashion shows that began in New York and ended in Paris last Wednesday — I thought of Giacomo Leopardi, the great Italian poet and moralist. Leopardi fancifully portrayed fashion as death’s sister. In a dialogue between the two, Fashion explains to Death what they have in common: “We both equally profit by the incessant change and destruction of things here below…” I was struck by the special relevance of Leopardi’s statement to one earthly realm in particular: the writing of fiction, where the device of disclosing the nature of character through clothes seems to be all but destroyed.

headline: Garcetti, New Los Angeles Mayor, Reflects Changing City
text: LOS ANGELES — He is Jewish. He is Latino. He can break dance and play jazz piano. He speaks nearly impeccable Spanish. He has talked longingly about growing his own vegetables and maybe even raising his own chickens. He lives on this city’s hip east side.

headline: No Way U.S. Would Allow Debt Default? Don’t Bet on It
text: “The United States government is not going to default, ever.”

headline: A Growing Race With Big Risks
text: MARTINSBURG, W.Va. — The simplest way for the authorities to identify a mud-stained Avishek Sengupta as he lay unconscious in a hospital here last April was by the series of numerals written in a black permanent marker on his forehead: 69989.

headline: ‘A Short History of the Highrise’
text: At a time when Manhattan luxury condos can cost tens of millions of dollars, residential high-rise buildings made of glass have become symbols of gargantuan excess and privilege. But the history of vertical living goes far back in time and extends around the globe — from the biblical Tower of Babel, to Arizona cliff dwellings to the Soviet Khrushchyovka towers.

headline: Argentina: Surgery for President
text: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner will undergo surgery on Tuesday to drain an accumulation of blood near her brain resulting from a recent head injury, her doctors said Monday. The doctors, Facundo Manes and Gerardo Bozovich of Fundación Favaloro, a private hospital in Buenos Aires, said they opted for the surgery after Mrs. Kirchner was found on Sunday to have a tingling sensation and a slight loss of muscular strength in her left arm. Mrs. Kirchner’s spokesman had revealed Saturday that she had sustained a previously undisclosed “skull trauma” in August, and that doctors had told her to rest for 30 days as a result of the injury, which involves chronic bleeding between the surface of her brain and her skull.

headline: Obama and the Debt
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — THE Republicans in the House of Representatives who declare that they may refuse to raise the debt limit threaten to do more than plunge the government into default. They are proposing a blatant violation of the 14th Amendment, which states that “the validity of the public debt of the United States, authorized by law” is sacrosanct and “shall not be questioned.”

headline: China: Big Energy Project Planned
text: China is planning to build its largest coal gasification energy project in the western region of Xinjiang, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The $30 billion project is in the Zhundong area of the Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture, and it is expected to produce 30 billion cubic meters of gas per year, Xinhua reported Sunday, citing Xinjiang officials. The project will need an input of 90 million tons of coal per year and is expected to create 18,000 jobs, Xinhua reported. The article said “coal gasification is expected to be a key sector in the country’s clean energy initiative.” The coal gasification process can result in severe discharge of pollutants if it is not properly controlled.

headline: Nazis, Lynching and Obamacare
text: You might think that the methodical extermination of millions of Jews by a brutal regime intent on world domination would resist appropriation as an all-purpose metaphor. You might think that genocide, of all things, would be safe from conversion into sloppy simile.

headline: Iraq: Outburst of Bombings Sweeps Through Baghdad Neighborhoods
text: Twelve explosions hit Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad within 40 minutes on Monday, killing at least 37 people and wounding more than 100, security and medical officials said. In one attack in the Husseiniya area in northern Baghdad, a homemade bomb exploded near a restaurant, followed by a car-bomb blast in a nearby parking garage. The two explosions killed eight people and wounded 22.

headline: Why the Debt Ceiling Matters
text: The word we keep hearing is “catastrophe.”

headline: Senate Leaders Mull Raising Debt Ceiling in Challenge to House
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democratic leaders will move forward this week on a measure to raise the government’s legal borrowing limit without any policy strings attached, answering House Republicans’ taunts that Democrats would not force their politically vulnerable senators to cast that difficult vote.

headline: Leading a Title Bid With a Lifted Spirit
text: ATLANTA — The most joy Angel McCoughtry derived from the 2012 season was not leading the W.N.B.A. in scoring or steering the Atlanta Dream to the playoffs, but simply that it ended.

headline: Politicians for Sale
text: Nearly four years after its controversial ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court is once again taking up the issue of the regulation of money in politics. This time, the risk to the integrity of elected officials, and public confidence in government, may be even greater.

headline: The International Fallout
text: The Republican-induced government shutdown and the party’s threats to create another crisis next week over the debt ceiling are causing harm internationally as well as at home. They are undermining American leadership in Asia, impeding the functioning of the national security machinery, upsetting global markets and raising questions about the political dysfunction of a country that has long been the world’s democratic standard-bearer.

headline: A Breakthrough on Iraqi Visas
text: Even as the shutdown of the federal government dragged on last week and it seemed bipartisan cooperation had become an obsolete relic, members of Congress managed to honor a moral obligation. They rescued an important program that extends visas to Iraqi translators who risked their lives to assist American troops during the Iraq war and now face threats of retribution.

headline: Uighurs in China Say Bias Is Growing
text: KASHGAR, China — Job seekers looking for opportunities in this ancient oasis town in China’s far western Xinjiang region would seem to have ample options, based on a quick glance at a local help-wanted Web site. The Kashgar Cultural Center has an opening for an experienced dance choreographer, the prefectural Communist Party office is hiring a driver and nearby Shule County needs an archivist.

headline: Supreme Court Ponders Suits in Stanford Fraud Over Securities That Never Existed
text: WASHINGTON — On the first day of its new term, the Supreme Court heard arguments in a case arising from one of the most brazen frauds in recent history, the $7 billion Ponzi scheme orchestrated by R. Allen Stanford.

headline: Veto Halts Bill for Jury Duty by Noncitizens in California
text: LOS ANGELES — Breaking with Democrats in the State Legislature, Gov. Jerry Brown vetoed a bill on Monday that would have made California the first state to allow immigrants who are not citizens to serve on juries, saying that the responsibility should come only with citizenship.

headline: Governor’s Letter to the California Assembly
text: Gov. Jerry Brown of California told members of the California State Assembly that he was returning without his signature a bill on allowing noncitizens to serve on juries.

headline: For a Skilled Fund-Raiser, Lhota Looks No Further Than Home
text: As his second bid for mayor swung into gear, Rudolph W. Giuliani had a familiar problem. A Republican in an overwhelmingly liberal-leaning city, facing a Democratic incumbent who had left him gasping for campaign dollars four years earlier, Mr. Giuliani needed to do more than just galvanize voters weary of crime, squeegee men and scandal at City Hall. He needed money.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 7
Health Exchange Delays Tied to Software Crash in Early Rush
text: WASHINGTON — The technical problems that have hampered enrollment in the online health insurance exchanges resulted from the failure of a major software component, designed by private contractors, that crashed under the weight of millions of users last week, federal officials said Monday.

headline: Rescuing City’s Aging Blades, a Member of a Dying Trade
text: ROME — Carmine Mainella’s calling card is his call. “Arrotino, arrotino,” he shouted on a warm September morning, strolling with an easy gait on a sidewalk in central Rome, announcing his trade: a sharpener of knives, scissors, meat-slicing blades and sundry metal items that have lost their edge.

headline: Dull Knives? Dwindling Service in Rome
text: Rome’s knife sharpeners are becoming a dying breed as restaurants cast aside dull cutlery instead of repairing it, or rent knives instead of owning them.

headline: Corrections: October 8, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Bang For Your Buck
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s an interesting concept for aspiring puzzle constructors: the best way to cram as much theme material as possible into a grid is apparently to leave some of it out.

headline: Shareholder Adviser Plans to Escalate Fight Over Oracle Chief’s Pay
text: A group that advises several union pension funds plans to ratchet up the fight against Oracle Corporation‘s pay practices, especially for its founder, Lawrence J. Ellison.

headline: Navajo Leader Drops His Support for Slaughter of Wild Horses on the Reservation
text: PHOENIX — Under pressure by animal welfare groups and many of his own people, the president of the Navajo Nation, Ben Shelly, has reversed his stance on horse slaughtering, saying he will no longer support it and will order the temporary suspension of the roundups of feral horses on the reservation.

headline: Transit Agency Expands Real-Time Bus Information to Manhattan
text: New York City’s traffic can appear to be an ungovernable force — understood, perhaps, but never fully tamed.

headline: Charges Filed Against Mother of Dead Boy in Brooklyn
text: Anna Thomas had no criminal history, no interactions with child protective services and no history of mental illness, the authorities said. There was nothing that might provide an immediate explanation of what the police said was the killing of her 19-month-old son.

headline: Is There Any Hope for New York City Transit?
text: The latest M.T.A. budget proposal just extends existing problems, like overcrowding and dwindling service. What's the long-term solution?
