text: To the Editor:

headline: A New York Ad Campaign to Build Girls’ Self-Esteem
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brazil’s Leader Asks Canada to Explain Its Spying
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, crisply demanded an explanation on Monday from Canada over revelations that a Canadian intelligence agency had spied on Brazil’s mining and energy ministry and a top Brazilian diplomat, a development contributing to festering resentment in Brazil over the targeting of the nation by foreign intelligence agencies.

headline: Jesuit Campus to End Coverage for Elective Abortions
text: LOS ANGELES — The trustees of Loyola Marymount University, a Jesuit university in Los Angeles, voted Monday to eliminate coverage for elective abortions from the health care plans offered to faculty and staff members in 2014.

headline: Mother of ‘Baby Hope’ Is Identified, Police Say
text: More than two decades after the girl who would come to be known as Baby Hope was found dead in a cooler along a New York highway, a law enforcement official said on Monday that her mother had been identified.

headline: A G.O.P. Moderate in the Middle ... of a Jam
text: WASHINGTON — As a moderate House Republican, Representative Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania by definition typically finds himself somewhere near the middle when the majority of his colleagues veer well to the right.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 8, 2013
text: “When you’re in this business of governing, sometimes you must step up and govern.”

headline: A Humbled Knick Tries to Fit In, Hoping to Avoid Moving on Yet Again
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Chris Douglas-Roberts was challenging his physical limits when he tried to draw a charge on Tyson Chandler at Monday’s practice. Douglas-Roberts lost.

headline: Patrice Chéreau, Opera, Stage and Film Director, Dies at 68
text: Patrice Chéreau, a director whose iconoclastic theater, opera and film productions sometimes offered broad social critiques that made them both provocative and influential, died on Monday in Paris. He was 68.

headline: Robert C. Stebbins, Chronicler of Western Reptiles and Amphibians, Dies at 98
text: Robert C. Stebbins, who was considered by many to be the pre-eminent authority on the lungless salamander, the barking tree frog, the northern Pacific rattlesnake and hundreds of other amphibians and reptiles of the North American West, died on Sept. 23 in Eugene, Ore. He was 98.

headline: 100 Specialists to Carry Out Tricky Syria Disarmament
text: One hundred specialists drawn from the United Nations and the organization that polices the global ban on chemical weapons will be sent to Syria over the next eight months to help dismantle and destroy its roughly 1,000-ton arsenal, an extremely hazardous task that has never been tried and that could fail without Syria’s cooperation, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Monday.

headline: United States Lagging in Skills
text: United States lags behind other countries in basic math skills and  working with technology.

headline: Video Game Review, Beyond: Two Souls
text: Quantic Dream's newest cinematic game for Playstation 3 explores the action-packed emotional journey of a young woman with a mysterious gift.

headline: A Bit of Mystery, a Bit of Hollywood
text: David Cage, the writer and director of Beyond: Two Souls, a thriller released on Tuesday for the PlayStation 3, starring Ellen Page and Willem Dafoe, is among the most divisive figures in video games. That’s partly because of his outlandish pronouncements about the future of the medium, like when he said last month during a lecture to the British Academy of Film and Television that developing an algorithmic Martin Scorsese — artificially intelligent software that imitated Mr. Scorsese’s camera style and recreated it on demand — would be an interesting way to improve video game storytelling.

headline: Word of the Day | immolate
text: immolate •\ˈi-mə-ˌlat\• verb

headline: When the Treasury Runs Out of Cash
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Fourth Motorcyclist Is Charged in Attack on Driver of S.U.V.
text: A fourth motorcyclist was charged on Monday night in the recent attack on the driver of a sport utility vehicle after a high-speed chase that was caught on camera.

headline: Smith Saves the Day and Comes of Age
text: ATLANTA — It was all there for the Jets, and then it almost wasn’t. Their lead, which had grown to 13 points almost midway through the fourth quarter. Their discipline, which had improved after penalty-filled disasters the previous two weeks. Their sense of accomplishment, which comes from watching a rookie quarterback recover from the worst game of his brief career by delivering the best one.

headline: For Shoppers, Next Level of Instant Gratification
text: All the world’s a shopping cart.

headline: To Lift Hong Kong Park, Disney Deploys Iron Man
text: HONG KONG — Iron Man has proved his might at the Chinese box office. Now Disney is betting that the Marvel superhero has enough muscle to complete a turnaround at its underperforming theme park here — a task of crucial importance as the company hurtles toward the opening of a mega-resort in Shanghai.

headline: With a Ninth-Inning Home Run, the Rays Stave Off Elimination Again
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Boston Red Sox had thoroughly dominated their American League division series with the Tampa Bay Rays, standing a victory from a sweep on Monday night at Tropicana Field. The Rays, meanwhile, were trying to avoid a third early postseason exit since their run to the World Series in 2008.

headline: Share Your Advice for Young Women in the Workplace
text: Adam Bryant has interviewed hundreds of executives during more than four years of writing Corner Office, his semiweekly Q. & A. feature on leadership and management. This week, in a special installment of Corner Office in the Sunday Business section, Mr. Bryant interviews four executives about being a woman in a position of power. In these conversations, the executives explore the idea of gender and leadership in the workplace.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 7:45 P.M. (Cinemax) THE LOVELY BONES (2009) Mark Wahlberg, above, and Rachel Weisz play the grieving parents of Susie Salmon (Saoirse Ronan), a 14-year-old who has gone missing in 1970s suburbia, in this adaptation of the best seller by Alice Sebold, directed by Peter Jackson. Stanley Tucci is the neighbor who knows what happened. “As a pictorial artifact ‘The Lovely Bones’ is gorgeous,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It pulses and blooms and swells with bright hues and strange vistas.” But in the end, he added, the film — which focuses on Susie as she hovers in the “in-between” and tries to bring her killer to justice — “shows less audacity” than the novel “and too much art.”

headline: Moving Back to (Their) Town
text: I was having a drink one afternoon recently at the sunny end of the bar at the Kettle of Fish celebrating my recent move to New York after a 30-year absence, telling the story of how that bar, in its incarnation as the Lion’s Head, had become my regular haunt years ago.

headline: News Quiz | October 8, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Dodgers Eliminate Braves With a Two-Run Shot in the Eighth
text: LOS ANGELES — As if the $235 million payroll, and the decision to refrain from fully investing in Manager Don Mattingly, left any questions about the Steinbrenner-like expectations of the Los Angeles Dodgers, they issued another proclamation Monday.

headline: Cuomo’s Office Is Said to Rein In Ethics Board He Created
text: ALBANY — When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo created the Commission to Investigate Public Corruption in early July, he promised a muscular response to bad behavior by legislators that included allegations of bribe taking, favor trading and embezzlement.

headline: 2 Companies in Web Video Are Expected to Merge
text: In another sign that the world of digital video production may be entering an era of consolidation, two significant participants in the market, Alloy Digital and Break Media, are expected to announce on Tuesday that they will merge.

headline: U.S. Adults Fare Poorly in a Study of Skills
text: American adults lag well behind their counterparts in most other developed countries in the mathematical and technical skills needed for a modern workplace, according to a study released Tuesday.

headline: In Berlin, Musical Support for Rights in Russia
text: BERLIN — After weeks of insisting that the star-studded “To Russia With Love” concert he organized in Berlin was not aimed against any individual, government or law, the violinist Gidon Kremer allowed the music to speak.

headline: Record-Setting Diamond Sale Shows Appetite for Luxury in Asia
text: HONG KONG — As investors fret about the budget standoff in the United States and slowing growth in Asia, the confidence of the world’s superrich to splurge on top gems and works of art appears intact, judging by a string of Sotheby’s auctions in Hong Kong in the past five days.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Oct. 8, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Summer Camp for Olympic Snowboarders
text: In “Summer Camp for the Winter Olympics,” Joe Drape writes about summer training for the Winter Olympics.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Gives Details on Plan to Cut 10,000 Jobs
text: PARIS — The French-American telecommunications equipment maker announced on Tuesday details of a major restructuring plan that includes 10,000 job cuts worldwide over the next two years.

headline: Putting a Speed Limit on the Stock Market
text: When Brad Katsuyama was running the U.S. trading desk for the Royal Bank of Canada, his clients would send in orders every day, but every day, when Katsuyama went to buy or sell, something would go wrong. When he wanted to buy, offers to sell shares would suddenly vanish, and the price of the stock would shoot up. When he wanted to sell, the same thing would happen in reverse. “I started to realize that, day in and day out, I was getting screwed,” Katsuyama told me recently.

headline: Photographing by Santa’s Rules
text: It’s 80 degrees in New York and not yet Columbus Day, but walk into some convenience stores and you will already find plastic mistletoe and reindeer competing for shelf space with skeletons and Halloween candy.

headline: Is It Offensive for Sports Teams to Use Native American Names and Mascots?
text: Native American names and symbols have long been popular for all types of American sports teams at the professional, college and high school levels. Think of the Cleveland Indians, Atlanta Braves and Washington Redskins.

headline: Luck’s Effect on Colts Transcends His Statistics
text: As a rookie, Andrew Luck led one of the great N.F.L. turnarounds, taking a Colts team that was 2-14 without him in 2011 to 11-5 with him in 2012. This year, Luck has been even better, and Indianapolis, with a 13-3 record in its last 16 games and with recent victories over San Francisco and Seattle, has become a serious Super Bowl contender.

headline: New York Today: Turned Away
text: Updated 12:03 p.m. | And on the seventh day, Horst and Kristine Sahlmann of Hamburg, Germany, attempted to visit Grant’s Tomb.

headline: Daily Report: As Microsoft Seeks a Chief, Speculation on Gates’s Future
text: There is a question being whispered around Microsoft’s sprawling suburban Seattle campus, Nick Wingfield reports: What will Bill Gates do?

headline: Pacific Rim Leaders Urge New Focus on Global Trade Talks
text: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — Leaders at the Pacific Rim economic summit meeting declared at the end of their two-day meeting here Tuesday that the global trade talks known as the Doha round were at an “impasse” and urged trade ministers, due to meet here in December, to get negotiations back on track.

headline: What Is the Higgs?
text: Two physicists, Peter Higgs of Britain and François Englert of Belgium, on Tuesday won the Nobel Prize in Physics. But just what is the Higgs Boson?

headline: ‘Still Crazy After All These Years,’ Two Ways
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: For Nobel, They Can Thank the ‘God Particle’
text: The “God particle” became the prize particle on Tuesday.

headline: Study Suggests Fact-Checking Influences Political Behavior
text: The rise of professional fact-checking in recent years has brought both praise and criticism. One of the more common laments, even from fans of fact-checking, is that it has little effect — that politicians judged to be untruthful ignore the judgment against them and pay little price from voters.

headline: Close but Not Quite
text: It’s commendable to add nuance or texture to our prose with a word that’s slightly out of the ordinary. Just be sure the word you pick is the right one, used the right way. It’s not enough to be in the general vicinity. And a misstep is all the more glaring if the word is unusual.

headline: In Performance: Norbert Leo Butz of ‘Big Fish’
text: In the new Broadway musical “Big Fish,” a stage adaptation of the 2003 Tim Burton film, Norbert Leo Butz plays Edward Bloom, a father whose wildly inventive tales about meeting witches and befriending giants come to life on stage. In this video, Mr. Butz, with Jim Hershman on guitar, sings the number “Fight the Dragons,” in which he explains his love of storytelling to his son. The show, with music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa and book by John August, is at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: A Woman to Serve on Twitter’s Board? Here Are 25
text: There has been quite a kerfuffle over Twitter’s lack of gender diversity at the top, including my Saturday New York Times story about the issue and a stream of tweets in response from Dick Costolo, its chief executive.

headline: A Debutante With Lesbian Moms: How Does She Come Out?
text: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Britain Expands Program to Spur Home Purchases
text: LONDON — The British government on Tuesday began the second phase of a new program aimed at igniting home buying, in part by guaranteeing up to 15 percent of a mortgage loan.

headline: Today in Small Business: The ‘Enormous’ Benefits of Obamacare
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Worrisome Calm on Wall Street
text: Wall Street has predicted financial panic should the government default on its debt, but markets so far are showing few signs of fear, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. “We all tell ourselves, ‘This is something that is not going to happen,’” said David Coard, the head of fixed-income trading at the Williams Capital Group.

headline: Take Me to the Bad Old Bronx
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Default Deniers
text: You knew this would happen, didn’t you? As we close in on the debt limit, with Obama insistent that he will not give in to hostage-taking, there is a growing chorus of voices on the right insisting that the whole debt limit thing is scare tactics from the administration, and that hitting the limit will be no big deal.

headline: Nest Labs Reinvents the Smoke Alarm
text: The loud, sensitive smoke alarm is probably the least-loved electronic device in your household, but it is also an appliance that could get you killed if it’s not working properly. That is why Nest Labs, a start-up led by former Apple engineers, saw an opportunity to reinvent it.

headline: I.M.F. Cuts Forecasts for Global Expansion, and Warns U.S. on Its Stalemate
text: WASHINGTON — Emerging economies have cooled off. Europe remains in the doldrums. The United States is facing fiscal uncertainty, and its powerful central bank is contemplating easing its extraordinary stimulus efforts, with potentially global ramifications.

headline: Karzai Lashes Out at the U.S. for Its Role and Focus in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With the United States weighing a complete withdrawal from Afghanistan by the end of next year, President Hamid Karzai offered a stinging critique of the American-led campaign here, saying that coalition forces had inflicted needless suffering on Afghans.

headline: The Midterms: Sam Wang Weighs In
text: My Princeton colleague Sam Wang, one of the best poll aggregators out there — and one of the people who, if you were reading him, made you smarter than any of Romney’s advisors — takes on the PPP poll of selected Congressional districts. His conclusion:

headline: European Lawmakers Reject Tight Restrictions on E-Cigarettes
text: STRASBOURG, France — The European Parliament on Tuesday scrapped proposals by health officials that electronic cigarettes be tightly regulated as medical devices, setting the stage for a debate in the United States over the extent of regulation.

headline: De Keersmaeker’s Famous ‘Rosas’ Dance Gets the Fan Treatment
text: The movements may be simple, but dance fans still can’t get enough.  Now, a part of Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker’s seminal “Rosas Danst Rosas,” which she created in 1983 for her new four-woman company, has been replicated by more than 1,500 people all over the world, as part of a project to celebrate the work’s 30th anniversary.

headline: Inquiry Into Illicit Online Marketplace Extends to Britain
text: LONDON – Four men arrested in Britain on drug charges are being investigated over their suspected ties to Silk Road, an online marketplace that has been linked to narcotics sales and other illegal activity, British officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Concert for the Opposition
text: BERLIN — At the end of the evening, Daniel Barenboim and Martha Argerich sat down at the piano together and played “Grand Rondeau” in A-minor. The crowd in the chamber hall of the Berlin Philharmonic went wild. One does not see this kind of thing often: two world-famous pianists laughing playfully as they jostle over access to the pedals and then launching into an intimate, almost sentimental, rendition of a piece. Nor will anyone else see this performance again: The two times Barenboim performed during the Monday evening concert, the video operators in the room shut off their cameras.

headline: 1931: Leading Paris Couturiers
text: Offering a rare insight into the life of leading Parisian couturiers, The New York Herald from May 3, 1931 published gravures of Jean Patou enjoying a windy ride in a speed boat (with his beret surprisingly in place) and Lucien Lelong, schussing down a slope.

headline: Icahn Secures Seats on Nuance’s Board
text: Strike another victory for activist investors, and the billionaire Carl C. Icahn in particular.

headline: City’s Charter Schools Fear Having de Blasio for a Landlord
text: Charter schools in New York City have flourished over the past decade, attracting donations from Wall Street, praise from leaders in business and government, and free real estate from the city.

headline: South Korea Says North Restarted Nuclear Reactor
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s main intelligence agency confirmed on Tuesday that North Korea has restarted a Soviet-era nuclear reactor that has been used to obtain plutonium for bombs, according to South Korean legislators.

headline: Nuclear Power and the Shutdown
text: Try as they may, Tea Party Republicans who triggered the shutdown cannot disguise the fact that it is disrupting important government activities.

headline: Eric Garcetti Takes the Stage
text: The new mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, connected with Mexican-Americans at a recent celebration in the city.

headline: Genes Suggest European Women at Root of Ashkenazi Family Tree
text: Over the last 15 years geneticists have identified links between the world’s Jewish communities that point to a common ancestry as well as a common religion. Still, the origin of one of the most important Jewish populations, the Ashkenazim of Central and Eastern Europe, has remained a mystery.

headline: After the I.V.F., the Wait
text: I feel a twinge on my right side. Am I pregnant, or is it just gas? Two weeks of thinking about whether the embryo inside of me has implanted is driving me crazy.

headline: Back-to-Work Day at H.P.
text: Memo to Hewlett-Packard employees: It’s o.k. to come back in.

headline: The Journey to Europe
text: African migrants, trying to reach Europe, flood the tiny island of Lampedusa.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Don’t Teach to the Test
By Design | At Christie’s, the Legacy of a ’70s Decorator Hits the Auction Block
text: As the estate of a favorite client of the ’70s American decorator Michael Taylor comes up for auction, a former protégée recalls her boss.

headline: Dead 22 Years, ‘Baby Hope’ Has a Name Again
text: As the officers tacked up posters and handed out fliers last July, a van with loudspeakers inched through Washington Heights, announcing yet another attempt by the police to dredge up anything resembling a clue in an emotionally wrenching case from 1991: the little girl whose emaciated and bound body had been left in a cooler by a highway in Upper Manhattan.

headline: The Iditarod Trail by Snowmobile
text: The fourth checkpoint on the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, Alaska’s remote Winterlake Lodge will offer visitors a chance to follow the historic trail for 35 miles, this time by snowmobile.

headline: After Having Sloppy Start, Smith and the Jets Look Sharper
text: ATLANTA — As midnight approached, Geno Smith buttoned his blue dress shirt, knotted a red tie and slipped into dark slacks. Before reaching for the blue sport coat in his locker, Smith, the Jets’ first-year quarterback, sat on a stool and covered his feet with sweat socks and white athletic shoes.

headline: Debt Ceiling ‘Blackmail,’ Then and Now
text: Just to follow up on my post yesterday, in which I argued that what’s unprecedented about the looming debt-ceiling stand-off is the implausibility-cum-unknowability of the House Republican “ask,” not the idea of a debt ceiling “ask” itself, here’s Townhall’s Kevin Glass with an account of how the ceiling was raised during Ronald Reagan’s second term:

headline: Soundtrack for a Debt Showdown – In the Red, Got No Green and I’m Feeling So Blue
text: Expanded slightly, 12:14 p.m. | As some readers know, I’m a performing songwriter in spare moments. While going through a rough patch a couple of decades ago, I wrote a tune that could, sadly, serve as a soundtrack to the disgraceful Washington gridlock over the budget, the debt ceiling, and America’s fiscal future. It’s called “Bills, Bills, Bills” and here’s a new video built around the version that will be on my first album, coming later this fall:

headline: A Guide to Affordable Dental Care
text: Finding affordable dental services can be daunting for aging parents and a headache for family members coordinating their care. Retirees, after all, often lose dental insurance after leaving the workplace, and Medicare does not cover cleanings, fillings or dentures. Dental coverage for adults on Medicaid varies broadly, depending on the state.

headline: World Monuments Fund Lists Vista of the New Jersey Palisades as Endangered
text: The World Monuments Fund has listed the Cloisters in Manhattan and the Palisades in New Jersey on its annual list of endangered cultural sites, citing the construction of a new corporate headquarters in Englewood Cliffs that is to rise above the tree line as a threat to the view from the museum across the Hudson.

headline: Supreme Court Again Weighs Spending Limits in Campaigns
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed prepared to strike down a part of federal campaign finance law left intact by its decision in Citizens United in 2010: overall limits on direct contributions from individuals to candidates.

headline: Recent Deals Show Freer Capitalism Is Taking Hold in Japan
text: Japan Inc. is breaking some deep-rooted taboos.

headline: School Bus Drivers in Boston Stop Work, Surprising the City
text: BOSTON — School bus drivers infuriated parents and city officials on Tuesday morning with a surprise work stoppage that left thousands of the city’s 57,000 schoolchildren stranded at home or at bus stops.

headline: The Gun Report: October 8, 2013
text: After years of sponsorship, NBC Sports has decided it will not be a sponsor of the nation’s largest gun trade show in January, Media Matters has reported. At the Shooting Hunting and Outdoor Trade Show, or the SHOT Show, as it is known, gun manufacturers showcase their latest products, including an array of assault rifles, tactical shotguns and pistols with high-capacity magazines. Its organizer, the National Shooting Sports Foundation, calls it “a powerful display of industry unity and its resolve to meet any challenge affecting the right to make, sell and own firearms.”

headline: An Indian’s Maiden Visit to Pakistan
text: I traveled to Pakistan two weeks ago as one of five Indians who were invited to meet with six Pakistani leaders from various walks of life as part of an effort by the Asia Society and the Jinnah Institute in Pakistan to continue cross-border dialogue. Meanwhile, the Indian and Pakistani governments had, once again, been engaged in their characteristic rhetoric on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Image of the Day: October 8
text: A man performing a fire stunt in Amritsar, Punjab.

headline: U.S. Warned by Japanese Over Perils of a Default
text: TOKYO — Japan’s finance minister urged the United States on Tuesday to avoid a default that could cast the global economy into turmoil and hurt the value of Japan’s enormous holdings of United States Treasury bonds, a day after similar warnings from China, which has an even larger stake in American debt.

headline: How Google’s Search Changes Affect Small Businesses
text: Google recently switched to something known as secure search, limiting the data that can be seen using its analytics. This means Web site owners and managers can no longer see the string of words used by an individual to find their site in a search, which could have a profound effect on marketing efforts. Knowing how customers found them helps business owners optimize their sites so that they rank higher in search results.

headline: What Do You Look for in Modern Translation?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Dana Stevens write about what they look for in modern translation.

headline: Lift ‘Threats,’ Obama Insists, Spurning Talks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama intensified his pressure on House Republicans on Tuesday, calling on them to “lift these threats from our families and our businesses” as the federal government remained shuttered into a second week and the possibility that the United States would default on its debts grew closer.

headline: Indian Workers Strike Over Plan to Split State
text: NEW DELHI — Striking workers shut off electricity and cellphone service to a large section of the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh on Tuesday, as hundreds of thousands of government employees protested a decision to divide the state into two parts.

headline: U.S. Upholds Ban on Some Samsung Products
text: In another blow to Samsung Electronics in its continuing patent disputes with Apple, the Obama administration has decided to uphold a ban requested by Apple of some of Samsung’s mobile products.

headline: No Offense to Tourists: Taxi ‘Jeopardy!’ Is Easier
text: For three years, “Jeopardy!,” the popular game show, has been running quiz-like advertisements in New York City’s yellow taxis, offering passengers clues and prompting them to answer in the form of a question the way contestants on television do. Much like the experience of watching “Jeopardy!” from home, there’s no buzzer to ring or jackpot to win. Whether or not you know the answer, it will appear on-screen a few seconds after each clue.

headline: European Officials Consulted Business Leaders on Trade Pact
text: LONDON — Long before trade negotiations began with the United States this summer, European officials were consulting with business leaders from both sides of the Atlantic on how to structure a free-trade pact.

headline: ‘Imperfect Intelligence’ Said to Hinder U.S. Raid on Militant in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The reinforcements have already started arriving, armed extremists posted along the coastline and the rest of town, guarding against any more attacks on their stronghold, witnesses say. People suspected of spying for the enemy have been rounded up and arrested, residents say, adding to a sense that the worst is far from over.

headline: In Store | Sleek, Seductive Italian Furniture Makes Its Way Stateside
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Opinion Section Is Expanding
text: We’re very happy to announce an important expansion of the Editorial Department’s opinion offerings, to coincide with the IHT’s reincarnation as the International New York Times next week.

headline: Mementos of James Coburn Up for Auction
text: On Tuesday, Paddle8 began an auction of 59 items from the home of the actor James Coburn, who died in 2002, and his first wife, Beverly.

headline: Boehner Calls for Spending Negotiations
text: John A. Boehner, the Republican speaker of the House, and members of the House majority urge Democrats to negotiate to end a spending standoff that has shuttered the government for eight days.

headline: A Nuisance Can Be Tasty, Too
text: Foraging for weeds, and cooking with those forgotten or unloved specimens, has grown in popularity in recent years.

headline: New Ingredients Sprout From the Cracks
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Chicory is best known to suburbanites as a destroyer of lawns and gardens. But when Linda Hezel, a former nurse practitioner, spotted the enormous weed growing inside one of her large raised garden beds, she chose not to uproot it.

headline: Turkey Lifts Longtime Ban on Head Scarves in State Offices
text: ISTANBUL — The government on Tuesday lifted a ban on head scarves for female workers in state offices, ending a longstanding restriction that has polarized Turkish society.

headline: Waiting for the Market’s Call to Reason
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: A Transcendence Grounded in Austere Contemplation
text: “The New Ecstatic,” Sarah Skaggs’s latest evening of work and newest piece, seen at Danspace Project on Saturday, is a change for this choreographer. Known for creating dances with high-energy explosiveness, Ms. Skaggs has become more contemplative, more deliberate. She has slowed things down.

headline: Lhota, Speaking to Corporate Leaders, Harshly Criticizes de Blasio
text: Joseph J. Lhota unleashed a full-throated attack on his chief rival for the New York City mayoralty on Tuesday, deriding Bill de Blasio as an inexperienced and smooth-talking naïf with little understanding of what it takes to run a government.

headline: Passing the Time Until He Arrives
text: You think “Waiting for Godot” is depressing? Wait till you hear it in Yiddish.

headline: Walking on Sydney’s Wild Side
text: The blue-tongued lizard eyed me suspiciously but remained still long enough for photographs, while a kookaburra laughed and a diminutive wallaby rustled in the brush. Rock engravings of fish and kangaroos marked ceremonial sites of Aboriginal ancestors. Scented forests of eucalyptus and gum trees shaded our path over sandstone and thin topsoil, classic Outback topography surprisingly concealed on the outskirts of Sydney.

headline: The Meaning of Mountains
text: Pemba Gyalje Sherpa was part of the group of climbers who, in early August 2008, began the last leg of their summit of K2, a mountain in the heart of the Karakoram Range in northern Pakistan. At 28,251 feet, K2 is second in height only to Everest, but its peak is even steeper, colder and more desolate than its Himalayan sister.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Ghosts of Amsterdam

headline: They Put Art in the Game
text: The story of the Bucks’ old basketball floor, which was created by the Pop artist Robert Indiana and is currently an installation of 260 eight-foot panels at the Milwaukee City Hall.

headline: Hecklers Greet Hynes Effort to Renew Bid for Re-election
text: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, officially kicked off his reinvigorated bid for a seventh term on Tuesday morning amid questions about the viability of his campaign, which he is running as the Republican and Conservative nominee after losing the Democratic nomination last month.

headline: The Non-Paparazzi View of Daniel Radcliffe
text: The Italian photographer Luca Locatelli, whose images of Daniel Radcliffe appeared in this past weekend’s magazine, describes the experience of being part of what the paparazzi are focused on.

headline: Rules of Style | Ferragamo’s New Leading Lady on Flying in Style and Dressing Like a Star
text: Hollywood’s leading ladies and men have been wearing shoes by Salvatore Ferragamo since before the invention of talkies. In 1954, Audrey Hepburn famously wore suede Ferragamo ballet flats in “Sabrina,” and more recently, Drew Barrymore and Nicole Kidman have appeared in films wearing Ferragamo footwear. The latest ingenue to be associated with the brand, Kaya Scodelario, was cast by Ferragamo itself. The 21-year-old actress, best known for her role in the British TV series “Skins,” recently embarked on a whirlwind adventure, traveling from her hometown of London to Florence, Los Angeles and Shanghai to shoot “Walking Stories,” an online-only romantic comedy that Ferragamo will release in eight parts this month, every Tuesday and Thursday beginning today, at ferragamo.com. “We literally went around the world in two weeks,” she said.

headline: ‘Obamacare’ – With or Without Quotation Marks
text: A Times reader, Tom Bird, of East Lansing, Mich., raised a timely issue, given all that’s happening in Washington. He wrote that other news organizations, including The Associated Press, are putting the expression “Obamacare” in quotation marks, “signifying that it is not a neutral expression, but instead is political rhetoric that is being used in a partisan way.” And he added, “When will The Times wake up?”

headline: Key Moments From the Hearing on Campaign Contributions
text: The Supreme Court seemed prepared to strike down a part of federal campaign finance law setting overall limits on direct contributions from individuals to candidates. The Times’s Adam Liptak offered analysis of the arguments.

headline: Obama on Raising the Debt Ceiling
text: A week into the government shutdown, President Obama argued to raise the debt ceiling and said “health care shouldn’t have anything to do with keeping the government open.”

headline: Butter Tasting
text: Melissa Clark and a panel of dining connoisseurs, including Frank Bruni and Florence Fabricant, sample 13 different kinds of cultured butter.

headline: The N.F.L.'s Endangered Species
text: The pass-happy N.F.L. has a problem. Its quarterbacks are taking a beating.

headline: Spreading Culture
text: Diane St. Clair started making her extraordinary butter — the butter that Thomas Keller serves at Per Se and the French Laundry — after breaking her leg in an accident with a team of draft horses on her farm in Vermont.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: The N.F.L.’s Endangered Species
text: The pass-happy N.F.L. has a problem: its quarterbacks are taking a beating.

headline: Shutdown Denies Death and Burial Benefits to Families of 4 Dead Soldiers
text: WASHINGTON — The families of four soldiers killed in Afghanistan last weekend will not receive death benefits or the money to pay for their funerals because of the government shutdown.

headline: ‘NewsHour’ Ex-Anchors to Cede Ownership
text: Jim Lehrer and Robert MacNeil have been closely linked with the “PBS NewsHour” since the show’s beginnings in 1975, for many years as its co-anchors and, since 1981, as the show’s owners and co-producers through MacNeil/Lehrer Productions.

headline: David vs. Goliath
text: Shortly after 9 p.m. on a dark October night in 1863, four intrepid Confederates launched one of the most daring attacks of the Civil War. Nestled into the David, a cigar–shaped vessel 50 feet long and barely 5 feet in diameter, they steamed toward one of the Union Navy’s mightiest warships, the New Ironsides, on blockade duty in Charleston harbor. Each member of the crew — Capt. William T. Glassell, the pilot Walker Cannon, the assistant engineer J. H. Toombs and the seaman James Sullivan — carried a shotgun and revolver. But the real damage they intended was to come from a 134-pound explosive charge of at the end of a 30-foot spar extended from the prow of their vessel.

headline: $4 Million Grant to Help Rebrand Lincoln Center Institute
text: The Lincoln Center Institute, Lincoln Center’s educational arm since 1975, has received a $4 million grant from the Sherman Fairchild Foundation to support a rebranding effort and new programs.

headline: Beyond the Rhetoric: Researching and Writing About the Health Care Law
text: In this lesson, students will research the fundamentals of the largest national health insurance expansion in generations. Then they will design a brochure to answer important questions about the program and its relevance for their community, as well as the nation.

headline: Mourning Syrian Soldier, but Not Doubting a War
text: DAQAQA, Syria — Under a silvery canopy of olive trees, men and women crowded around the grave of a 24-year-old lieutenant in the Syrian Army. As a commander handed the dead man’s mother a Syrian flag folded into a neat triangle, the scrape of branches shifting in the wind could be heard over quiet sobs and prayers.

headline: Second Team of Weapons Experts to Head to Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The organization responsible for ensuring the destruction of Syria’s arsenal of chemical weapons said Tuesday that it was sending a second team of experts to the country, as the forces of President Bashar al-Assad and rebels seeking his ouster battled over strategic swaths of territory.

headline: The Elm
text: Inside Paul Liebrandt’s restaurant in the King & Grove hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Living in Canarsie, Brooklyn
text: This southern Brooklyn neighborhood is still recovering from the twin blows of the mortgage crisis and Hurricane Sandy.

headline: A Fearless Palate for the Drop-In Crowd
text: There were more luxurious fine-dining restaurants in New York than Corton, which closed this summer after nearly five years in TriBeCa, but very few that could deliver as many high-wire thrills. Paul Liebrandt’s cooking challenged you to pay attention. The precisely calibrated flavors might be contained in a single mouthful, or might unscroll themselves as you ate your way across several plates. The harmonies were multilayered, and so were the rewards.

headline: In Canarsie, a Coalition of the Tried-and-True
text: To walk or drive around Canarsie, a quiet suburblike peninsula on Brooklyn’s south shore, you might not immediately guess at the recent struggles its residents have endured. The streets are relatively clean, the rows of one- and two-family homes often well maintained, the living-room-carpet-size lawns conscientiously mowed.

headline: The Shadow of the Sequester
text: A final point on the debt ceiling, before I turn to less exasperating subjects: One of the underappreciated dynamics making the current mess worse is the fact that both left and right, for somewhat different reasons, have embraced the idea that the outcome of the last debt ceiling deal  — sequestration, with its butcher-knife cuts to domestic programs and defense — was a straightforward win for Republicans, and a huge concession by the Democrats. For liberals, this idea has fed into the widespread “never again” attitude where debt ceiling negotiations are concerned. (“We can’t get blackmailed like that a second time!”) For conservatives, it’s encouraged deeply implausible ideas about what they can expect the White House to offer them this time. (“We basically won outright in 2011, so why not try to go for Obamacare repeal this time around?”)

headline: Court Blocks City’s Plan for ‘Taxis of Tomorrow’
text: A judge on Tuesday blocked New York City’s plan for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow taxis, dealing a potentially decisive blow to one of the Bloomberg administration’s signature transportation initiatives.

headline: In Twitter’s I.P.O. Filing, Signs of a Start-Up That Has Matured
text: Twitter’s prospectus for an initial public offering was disclosed last week, showing that the brouhaha about its confidential filing was much ado about very little.

headline: Encouraging the Reviewers, Honestly
text: The credibility of online reviews has come under attack so many times that it is hard to know which, if any, to believe.

headline: Villard Michel Richard Opening at the New York Palace
text: Headliner

headline: Fantasy Football Week 6: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
text: As this topsy-turvy fantasy football season rolls along, the waiver wire options have become as plentiful as an ice cube in the Sahara.

headline: Nazism’s Feminine Side, Brutal and Murderous
text: German women and girls, under the Third Reich, were dissuaded from wearing makeup. They should glow from fresh air and exercise, Hitler thought, or better yet, from pregnancy.

headline: The ioSafe N2 Is a Disaster-Resistant Backup Drive
text: The simple argument for cloud backup services is that if your house burns down, all your physical backup drives burn with it. The argument against cloud backup services is that they are expensive and slow — it can take days to upload the contents of a modest computer.

headline: Meringue-Based Cakes, Fried Turkey Tails and More
text: To Indulge: An Ode to Belgium, Made of Meringue

headline: Each One Witchier Than the Next
text: You have to admire the versatility of school-age witches as television characters. You can use them to make a kid-friendly animated show, as Hub has done with “Sabrina: Secrets of a Teenage Witch,” which begins on Saturday. Or you can use them as pivotal figures in a not-remotely-kid-friendly show whose premiere features torture, rape, drug use and death by intercourse.

headline: Pentagon Says Shutdown Affects Military Death Benefits
text: Shutdown Denies Death and Burial Benefits to Families of 4 Dead Soldiers

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Israel, Pakistan, South Korea and China.

headline: Hi-Fi Accessories for Your Headphones
text: Because the headphone market is so competitive, electronics companies are turning their focus more and more to hi-fi accessories.

headline: An App to Create Your Movie-Star Photo
text: One reason celebrities look so polished in photos is that there are Photoshop artists to smooth every wrinkle, minimize every pore and erase every blemish. The rest of us? We have to live with poorly lighted mobile phone selfies.

headline: Filipino Opera, Informed by Oppression
text: “Noli Me Tangere,” billed as the first Filipino opera composed in the Western operatic tradition, has rarely been staged in its entirety since it received its premiere in 1957 in the Philippines.

headline: A Little Monster in Need of a Hug
text: When Tickle Me Elmo was released in 1996, demand for the toy created such hysteria that its name became insider shorthand for a hot holiday seller. Every year, analysts guess which toy will be “the next Elmo.” Hasbro is hoping that this year, that toy will again be Elmo.

headline: A Showcase for Sustainable Food
text: TerraVITA’s focus on sustainability has made it one of the South’s most progressive food and beverage festivals. Now in its fourth year, the multiday event in Chapel Hill, N.C., this year running Thursday to Saturday, includes special dinners, workshops and the Grand Tasting on the Green, highlighting dozens of chefs and food and beverage producers focusing on local or earth-friendly sourcing.

headline: Disembodied Voices Hold Forth, Uttering the Question on Your Lips
text: The stage is strewn with lighting poles, some upright, some toppled. Two clothed men treat an inert, naked man as if he were another stage prop, slowly tipped end over end and carried. They stick him horizontally against the back wall, pressing him high above their heads. The man seems to thaw, to develop a will, as he is dragged around.

headline: Obama on the Supreme Court
text: During a press conference a week into the government shutdown, President Obama discussed the consequences of the Citizens United case on financing elections.

headline: Face to Face With Time, No Blinking
text: It is impossible not to root for Clint Holmes, the longtime Las Vegas headliner whose determined campaign to establish himself as a New York cabaret star has brought him to the Café Carlyle for three consecutive years. His first two engagements were ambitious tributes to Bobby Short in 2011 and to Paul Simon and Cole Porter the year after.

headline: Wilson Out as Giants’ Woes Continue
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ starting running back David Wilson will not play Thursday against the Chicago Bears because of a neck injury sustained in a 36-21 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday. The Giants were not more specific about the injury to Wilson, who attended practice and was occasionally seen running but did not participate in any drills.

headline: Pleasing Deities, and the Eyes, With Storytelling Steps From India
text: The city’s dance world at this time of year offers no shortage of festivals, from the something-for-everyone programming at Fall for Dance to the genre-blurring lineup at Crossing the Line. While dancegoers flocked to those last week, a kind of inadvertent festival, the product of serendipitous timing, unfolded with less fanfare.

headline: Hotel Review: Topping Rose House in Bridgehampton, N.Y.
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: The Blackanese Sushi & Wine Bar in Johannesburg
text: On a stretch of the eastern fringe of downtown Johannesburg, the Maboneng Precinct (maboneng is Sotho for “place of light”) materializes like a hipster mirage. This once-gritty enclave has been transformed into a creative haven with galleries, a popular weekly market and, of course, restaurants. Last winter the Blackanese, a pocket-size Afro-Asian spot, joined the fray with a brick-and-mortar avatar of a successful mobile stall.

headline: Starbucks Aims to Move Beyond Beans
text: SEATTLE — In a suburb due east of Los Angeles, Starbucks is opening a $70 million, state-of-the-art plant that will produce cold-pressed juices.

headline: The Guarantee That Banks May Fear to Invoke
text: The mortgage orgy that banks entered into before the financial crisis has caused them — and their borrowers — immense pain since then. I have lost track of all the settlements and payments.

headline: Learning to Live With the Family Secret
text: Among American pop culture’s most profitable analogies continues to be the one between teenage angst and latent paranormal ability (magical, alien, vampiric). The latest television show to feed at this trough is “The Tomorrow People” on CW. And its title is perfect for the genre: Today we’re teenagers, but tomorrow we’ll be people!

headline: Oil Shocks Ahead? Probably Not
text: HOUSTON — OVER the last few months, as an Egyptian government fell in a coup, the United States considered an attack on Syria and disgruntled Libyan terminal guards blocked oil exports, the only predictable news was the rise in oil prices to levels not seen in more than two years.

headline: They, Like, Know the Lines
text: Along with a love of Lisa Frank Trapper Keepers and slap bracelets, Gen Y-ers share an almost aggressive nostalgia for the harebrained sitcom “Saved by the Bell.”

headline: Surf’s Up, and So Is the Curtain at This Festival
text: SAN DIEGO — Sitting silently in a seat was pretty much off limits at the Without Walls festival, a weekend of theater set in, near and around La Jolla Playhouse here. Instead, one play seesawed the audience up and down in an elevator (Dramamine recommended). Another put attendees to work in a power plant.

headline: The Me Generation Would Struggle Here
text: For a play that celebrates the individual, “Anthem” sure doesn’t trust its audience. Instead of illustrating ideas, this sporadically interesting show too often delivers exposition, desperate to overexplain rather than risk a moment of misunderstanding.

headline: The Long Shadow of Citizens United
text: Technically speaking, the Supreme Court’s controversial 2010 ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission was not up for reconsideration on Tuesday, when the court heard oral arguments in the first major case of its new term.

headline: The Met’s Commissioning Program Is Starting to Bear Operas
text: When Nico Muhly’s opera “Two Boys” has its American premiere at the Metropolitan Opera this month, it will be the first work to make it to the stage of the Met from a commissioning program that the company began seven years ago with Lincoln Center Theater.

headline: New Corporate Tax Shelter: A Merger Abroad
text: Executives at a California chip maker, Applied Materials, highlighted a number of advantages in announcing a merger recently with a smaller Japanese rival, but an important one was barely mentioned: lower taxes.

headline: Classical Musicians, Too, Make Berlin Their Capital
text: BERLIN — When Cameron Carpenter first came here, Berlin was covered in snow and looked as if spies might be lurking in the shadows. A year later, in 2010, Mr. Carpenter — the enfant terrible of the concert organ world — moved from the East Village to a loft in what was once a bombed-out neighborhood in the East German side of the city and is now the trendy district of Mitte.

headline: Obama on China
text: President Obama said at a news conference that it was important for U.S.-China relations to resume and that cooperation between the countries is not a zero-sum game.

headline: The 12 Best Restaurants in New York for Wine
text: Simply put, New York City offers the world’s greatest concentration of wonderful wine. Situated centrally among the world’s wine regions, it is free of the provincial tradition of drinking only the local wine. With an unparalleled variety

headline: Obama on Terrorism
text: During a news conference, President Obama discussed the recent attacks in Kenya and American foreign policy in Africa.

headline: Robert Redford in Pictures
text: Images of the actor and his work.

headline: Bessies Are Presented to Dancers in Ceremony at the Apollo
text: In their 29th year, the Bessies, known formally as the New York Dance and Performance Awards, remain a work in progress.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,269 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Moving to the Cadence of an Elizabethan Text
text: William Forsythe’s first work, “Urlicht,” was a lyrical, on-point pas de deux, set to a vocal section of Mahler’s Second Symphony, full of sustained tension and sculptural fluidity. One of his more recent pieces, “Sider,” is a large-scale ensemble work in which his dancers — some wearing Elizabethan ruffs, others hoods — manipulate large cardboard panels, scrambling and weaving through an unsettling, rule-bound universe, occasionally speaking in a mysterious language of familiar rhythms.

headline: Simona de Silvestro, the IndyCar Driver, Says the Future of Racing Is Electric
text: A woman has yet to win the Indianapolis 500, but Simona de Silvestro, the Swiss-born driver, could be the first. In last Saturday’s race at the Shell and Pennzoil Grand Prix of Houston, she came in second to Scott Dixon, her best finish ever (and first podium) in the Izod IndyCar Series.

headline: Higgs Boson Particle Theory Wins Nobel
text: Dennis Overbye, a Times science reporter, discusses the Higgs boson particle’s significance — and insignificance — in understanding our universe.

headline: These Donors Will Take Anything but Manhattan
text: Few major cultural donors are excited by the notion of contributing to an arts organization on a former landfill near a Costco warehouse in Queens.

headline: European Union Official Calls for More Surveillance of Migrant Routes
text: BRUSSELS — A senior European Union official called on Tuesday for vastly expanded patrols of Mediterranean waters, as horror mounted over the deaths of hundreds of African migrants near Sicily last week.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: The Handwriting Is on the Purse
text: G TRAIN STATION, on the way to J.F.K., rush hour on a Friday. I’m writhing about in search of my smartphone. “Is it in your suitcase?” my patient husband asks.

headline: Boehner ‘Disappointed’ by Obama’s News Conference
text: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, responded to President Obama’s lengthy news conference on Monday afternoon by reiterating that he “was disappointed that the president refuses to negotiate.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week | Curtain Call
text: To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of 14 of its visionary designers.

headline: Survey Says: Parents Are Happy, but Tired
text: Remember the research suggesting that mothers preferred housework to child care? The Daniel Kahneman study of almost 1,000 employed mothers in which the women reported feeling more negative emotions while caring for children than while doing almost anything else contributed to recriminations all over the Internet as parents wrestled with whether raising children was, indeed, “All Joy and No Fun,” as Jennifer Senior put it in a 2010 New York magazine article subtitled “Why Parents Hate Parenting.”

headline: Airport Noise Linked to Heart Risk
text: Older people living near noisy airports may have an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, a new study reports.

headline: Comfortable in the Contemporary, While Honoring the Venerable
text: The real thing: you know it when you see it. And on Monday evening at the opening-night show of the revitalized New York Cabaret Convention, now in its 24th year, at Frederick P. Rose Hall, the singer Carole J. Bufford showed the way forward. This brash cutie-pie belter with a pixie haircut triumphantly ended the show with renditions of “House of the Rising Sun” and “Can’t Help Lovin’ Dat Man” in which hard-shelled resilience and determination with deep emotional undercurrents crushed any tendencies toward self-pity or empty showboating.

headline: Argentine President Undergoes Surgery for Blood Clot
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, underwent surgery on Tuesday to drain a blood clot near her brain resulting from a head injury she sustained nearly two months ago, her spokesman said.

headline: India Increases Effort to Harness Biomass Energy
text: GHANAUR, India — THE hulking power plant set against the green countryside of Punjab state in northwest India does not look like a source of renewable energy. Yet filling its stockyard, instead of mounds of coal, are bales of rice straw. Machines break up the heavy straw cubes as men with pitchforks hoist fibrous mounds onto a conveyor belt leading to the power plant. Handkerchiefs cover their faces to protect them from dust swirling in the air.

headline: For Klinsmann, All Roads Lead to Brazil
text: Tuesday was the second anniversary of the first victory by a United States men’s national team under the direction of Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.

headline: Envoys Near Deal to Free Ex-Premier of Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — European diplomats appear close to negotiating the release of Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former prime minister of Ukraine, whose imprisonment by the government under her political rival has strained ties with the West and threatened to derail a trade agreement with Europe scheduled for signing in November.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Discusses Twitter, Netanyahu and Kerry on State Television
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 10:51 a.m. | While restrictions on the use of social networks by Iranians remain in place, the country’s new foreign minister openly discussed the “Happy Rosh Hashanah” message he posted on his official Twitter account last month on state television Saturday.

headline: Broadway ‘Soul Doctor’ to Close on Sunday
text: “Soul Doctor,” the Broadway bio-musical about the singing rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, will close on Sunday after 32 preview performances and 66 regular performances, the producers announced on Tuesday. The show received mixed reviews during its initial Off Broadway production last year, and had roughly the same reception when it re-opened on Broadway in August at Circle in the Square Theater.

headline: Undercover Detective Is Arrested in Attack on S.U.V.
text: An undercover New York City police detective who was among a group of motorcyclists chasing a sport utility vehicle on the West Side of Manhattan last month was arrested on Tuesday evening for his role in the episode, in which the vehicle was damaged and the driver was beaten, the police said.

headline: Falling Behind
text: Most jobs in our globalized economy require ever increasing skills. But the skill set of the American work force has improved little. In math ability, not only are American workers less skilled than those from most other rich nations, but the young are even less skilled than the rest.

headline: Obama to Pick Yellen as Leader of Fed, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Janet L. Yellen as chairwoman of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday, White House officials said Tuesday night, ending an unusually prolonged and public search to fill one of the most important economic policy-making jobs in the world.

headline: Annotations on a Speech
text: Joseph J. Lhota on Tuesday delivered a speech criticizing Bill de Blasio and offered a forceful argument in favor of aggressive policing tactics and the expansion of charter schools. Read the entire text of his speech to the Association for a Better New York, with annotations for context and clarity.

headline: A History of Fed Appointments
text: Janet L. Yellen will be the first Democratic nominee to run the Fed since President Jimmy Carter named Paul Volcker as chairman in 1979.

headline: The Economy Under Recent Fed Leaders
text: How effective the most recent Federal Reserve chairmen have been at fulfilling the system’s dual mandate — controlling inflation while maximizing employment.

headline: Surgery Ends Season for Sanchez
text: Finding Mark Sanchez on the Jets’ victorious sideline Monday night in Atlanta was not difficult. He was the one standing beside Coach Rex Ryan pumping his fist and sticking his tongue out with joy.

headline: Boehner on Negotiations

headline: Modern Updates to Old-School Building Materials
text: THERE was a time, long before Home Depot and cement mixers, when people had to build their homes from nearby materials. Centuries ago, the Indians of the Southwest used a mix of sand, clay, straw and water to make adobe homes. The Chinese constructed houses out of bamboo, and the English used a combination of straw and moist earth known as cob.

headline: In a Hot, Thirsty Energy Business, Water Is Prized
text: WITH so much focus on carbon emitted from the nation’s power plants, another environmental challenge related to electricity generation is sometimes overlooked: the enormous amount of water needed to cool the power-producing equipment.

headline: Nuclear Plants Vexed at Prices That Shift as Demand Does
text: WASHINGTON — AS costs and competition from cheap natural gas force more old nuclear plants to shut down, their owners have a new complaint: the electricity market is rigged against them.

headline: Unplugging Bottlenecks in Oil and Gas Deliveries
text: THE North American shale boom has brought with it many benefits, including new jobs, cheaper electricity and the potential for energy independence.

headline: In Return to Vancouver, Schneider Duels Old Team
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — When former Canucks goaltender Cory Schneider returned here for the first time as a member of the Devils on Tuesday, it was billed as a duel with his old partner in the nets, Roberto Luongo. With Vancouver’s 3-2 overtime win, Luongo earned bragging rights and his 350th career victory. Schneider is still looking for his first win in a Devils uniform.

headline: Yellen’s Path to the Pinnacle
text: Milestones in the career of Janet L. Yellen, President Obama’s choice to be chief of the Federal Reserve, including video recollections from friends and colleagues.

headline: Another Unlikely Moment for an Unlikely Star
text: LOS ANGELES — When Juan Uribe, soaked in beer and Champagne and partially undressed, rose from his seat behind the microphone late Monday night, ready to return to a celebrating clubhouse after a brief news conference, the moderator thanked him.

headline: At the Gravestone of ‘Baby Hope,’ Investigators Who Never Let Go
text: The headstone is like no other in St. Raymond’s Cemetery in the Bronx, both for what it is missing — a name — and what is there instead. A toll-free number.

headline: Pentagon Names Envoy for Guantánamo’s Closing
text: The Pentagon announced Tuesday that Paul M. Lewis, the top lawyer on the Democratic staff of the House Armed Services Committee, will fill the new position of military envoy for the closing of the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Mr. Lewis joins Cliff Sloan, who was appointed in June to be the State Department’s envoy. The appointment of Mr. Lewis, who had worked in the office of the Pentagon general counsel earlier in the Obama administration, is part of a larger turnover of staff on detention issues. In July, William Lietzau, who had been the Pentagon’s top policy official on detainee matters, announced that he was stepping down to take a private sector job.

headline: Stubborn Skills Gap in America’s Work Force
text: One of the few things that nearly everyone in Washington agrees on is that American workers are the best.

headline: Renovated Tenement Awaits the Return of One of Its Carpenters, Jimmy Carter
text: Don Kao vividly recalls his first day of work as an urban homesteader in the East Village. “I was standing in front of the building and I could see the sky right through it,” he said. “There was no roof. And I said, ‘Oh my God, what did I get myself into?’”

headline: Power Grid Is Attacked in Arkansas
text: ATLANTA — The federal authorities are investigating whether three recent attacks against the power grid in Arkansas are linked, and utility officials have asked residents to remain alert to the threat of more trouble.

headline: Jody L. Kriss
text: Mr. Kriss, 38, is a founder and principal of East River Partners, a company based in New York that acquires and redevelops brownstone properties in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: U.S. Issues Warning on Salmonella Believed to Be Linked to a Poultry Farm
text: The Agriculture Department issued a public health alert this week, saying that a strain of salmonella may have sickened 278 people who reported becoming ill after they ate poultry produced by Foster Farms.

headline: My Afro, Myself
text: LIKE many Americans, I’m a white person. But I am one of the select few who can make this boast: I once had quite a substantial Afro. Not a phony, permed, modest little Afro like the kind Mr. Brady sported in later seasons of “The Brady Bunch,” but a genuine, all-natural, Angela Davis-worthy ’fro with a radius of nearly a foot and a half (though that’s including skull as well as hair). My Afro was so large that it bounced when I walked. I was a life-size bobblehead, with a feather-light boulder of dead protein suspended over my shoulders.

headline: Janet Yellen: An Updated Reading List
text: Much of the recent coverage of Janet Yellen, President Obama’s choice to head the Federal Reserve, has focused on her personal style, portraying her as a consensus builder and referring to her quiet demeanor — offering a contrast with the sometimes abrasive image of the previous front-runner for the job, Lawrence H. Summers. But wider reading offers a more detailed picture of Ms. Yellen as an obsessive student of economics who chooses her battles carefully.

headline: Kansas Legislature Threatens Showdown With Court Over School Financing
text: TOPEKA, Kan. — As advocates of increased school funding brought their request to the Kansas Supreme Court on Tuesday, the staunchly conservative Legislature vowed to defy any court orders that it felt trampled on its sovereignty.

headline: China: Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters, Report Says
text: A Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia said Tuesday that Chinese security forces had fired on a protest in an eastern town in the Tibetan Autonomous Region, wounding at least 60 people, two of them critically. The violence took place on Sunday in Driru County, known as Biru in Chinese. Radio Free Asia said security forces were confronted by a crowd that had gathered to prevent the police from searching the home of Dorje Draktsel, who was detained last week after taking part in protests against orders that Tibetans fly the Chinese flag during the October national holiday period. The Tibet advocacy group, Free Tibet, said thousands of officials had flooded into the area in September to impose a “political re-education” campaign on the locals.

headline: SAC Is Said to Weigh Plea Deal in Insider Trading Case
text: After months of fighting the government’s insider trading case tooth and nail, the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is leaning toward admitting criminal wrongdoing and agreeing to pay a record financial penalty to resolve the charges, according to two people briefed on the deliberations.

headline: Transactions

headline: Uninsured Find More Success via Health Exchanges Run by States
text: WASHINGTON — Robyn J. Skrebes of Minneapolis said she was able to sign up for health insurance in about two hours on Monday using the Web site of the state-run insurance exchange in Minnesota, known as MNsure. Ms. Skrebes, who is 32 and uninsured, said she had selected a policy costing $179 a month, before tax credit subsidies, and also had obtained Medicaid coverage for her 2-year-old daughter, Emma.

headline: Atlantic 10 Hoping Edginess of Barclays and Brooklyn Will Rub Off on Conference
text: Virginia Commonwealth Coach Shaka Smart took a cab to Barclays Center for the Atlantic 10 Conference men’s basketball media day Tuesday, and before he entered, he snapped a picture of the arena. He sent the photograph as a text message to his six returning players. Immediately his phone began buzzing in response.

headline: China: Decision in Bo Xilai Appeal Expected Soon
text: Bo Xilai, a former senior Communist Party official who was sentenced to life in prison last month, expects a court in eastern China to make a decision soon on his appeal, a family associate said Tuesday. Mr. Bo was convicted of bribetaking, embezzlement and abuse of power in an effort to head off murder charges against his wife. His wife, Gu Kailai, was sentenced to life in prison last year for the murder of a British businessman. The family associate said that Mr. Bo’s lawyer had filed the appealed soon after the sentencing. The higher court judges are likely to review the appeal on paper rather than hear arguments in court, the family associate said. Political analysts said the higher court is unlikely to overturn the verdict, since party leaders were almost certainly the ones who had determined the verdict.

headline: Why Won’t McDonald’s Really Lead?
text: Every McDonald’s executive I’ve met who happens to be a parent says something like this: “I don’t let my kids eat at McDonald’s all the time. It’s a treat; we know that.” Yet these same executives, in literature and in public, say that they’re “championing children’s well-being.”

headline: Deadlock Worry Jolts the Market for T-Bills
text: The political impasse over the debt ceiling roiled a closely watched corner of the bond market on Tuesday, pushing up the price the government paid to borrow money for a month to its highest level since 2008, more than doubling from just a day earlier.

headline: He’s Over 80, but a Convict Gets No Parole
text: It began with a parking ticket dispute on a street in Manhattan more than 35 years ago, then lots of stupidity, shots fired, everyone lived.

headline: No Physicist Is an Island
text: LOS ANGELES — THE physicist Richard Feynman liked to gripe about what he called “Alfred Nobel’s Other Mistake.” The first mistake was the invention of dynamite. The second was creating the Nobel Prizes. Mr. Feynman thought it was ridiculous that something as material as a cash prize should be awarded to something as grand and open-ended as scientific research. (The griping wasn’t a matter of sour grapes; Mr. Feynman shared a well-deserved prize for physics in 1965.) This year’s physics Nobel has just been awarded to François Englert and Peter Higgs, for what is simply called “the Higgs mechanism.” But while Mr. Englert and Mr. Higgs undoubtedly deserve acclaim, bestowing an award on them alone distorts the nature of modern physics research.

headline: 8 Lawmakers Arrested at Immigration Protest
text: WASHINGTON — As several thousand demonstrators rallied around them, eight members of the House of Representatives were arrested on Tuesday outside the Capitol in a protest to push Congress to pass broad immigration legislation that includes a path to citizenship for immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: Cuomo Denounces Con Ed’s Proposed Rate Increase
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who has been a stern critic of utility companies since Hurricane Sandy struck a year ago, said on Tuesday that Consolidated Edison should be denied the $450 million rate increase it is seeking. Indeed, Mr. Cuomo said, Con Edison’s rates should not go up at all next year.

headline: Brazil’s Next Steps
text: After a decade of fast growth and rising incomes, Brazil has hit a rough patch that is testing its government’s ability to manage the economy and satisfy the growing aspirations of its people. President Dilma Rousseff, who faces elections next year, needs to push through policy reforms and public investment projects to revive growth and bring inflation under control.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 8

headline: Regaining Swagger, Tigers Force a Game 5
text: DETROIT — The Detroit Tigers slug, period. Manager Jim Leyland never asks his power-laden team to manufacture runs, because it is not its nature. So when the Tigers collectively slump, like the spell that began the final week of the regular season, they look listless. And there is not much Leyland can do about it.

headline: First End the Crisis, Then Talk
text: The demand from House Republicans on Tuesday morning — there’s a new one every day — was recycled from the last fiscal crisis they created: a bipartisan “supercommittee” of 20 lawmakers to negotiate a way out of the two crises (the government shutdown and debt-ceiling deadline) the House has now merged together. It was a particularly cynical flourish, given the Republican sabotage of the last supercommittee, and Democrats were right to dismiss it.

headline: A Study in Scarcity: Women at Central Banks
text: If confirmed by the Senate as the next chief of the Federal Reserve, Janet L. Yellen would be the highest-ranking woman ever in an economic policy-making position in the United States — and one of the most powerful women to serve in American government. No woman has led the Fed in the century since it was established, or the Treasury Department in its 224-year history.

headline: Britain and Iran Move to Repair Diplomatic Relations
text: LONDON — In an effort to repair long-strained relations, Britain and Iran announced Tuesday that each would appoint a chargé d’affaires, a rank below ambassador, to work toward resuming full diplomatic ties. The diplomats will remain in their own countries, but will discuss reopening embassies in London and Tehran.

headline: Call an Audible, Dan
text: WASHINGTON — Whenever I want to be called a detestable, insidious proselytizer of political correctness, I just bring up the idea of changing the name of the Redskins at a family dinner. What if our football team’s name weren’t a slur, I ask brightly. Wouldn’t that be nice?

What happened next exceeded even a child’s wildest imagination. Lobaton crushed a game-winning home run that landed in a tank of cownose rays in right-center field.

text: Over the last year, the apartment developer Arnie Gregory has opened 236 units in two early 1900s warehouses in the trendy downtown Minneapolis North Loop neighborhood. All are full and fetching higher-than-expected rents by about 25 cents a square foot.

headline: Anger Can Be Power

headline: Ralph A. Dungan, Aide in Kennedy White House, Dies at 90
text: Ralph A. Dungan, a prominent aide in the Kennedy White House who was later caught up in tumultuous Chilean politics as an ambassador and bitter university politics as New Jersey’s first chancellor of higher education, died on Oct. 5 at his home in St. John Parish, Barbados. He was 90.

headline: The Scent of the Wild in Williamsburg
text: A bearded, flannel-shirt-wearing backpacker from the Cascade Mountains of Portland, Ore., is not your typical perfumer. But in the case of Hall Newbegin, an obsessive love for the outdoors inspired him to create Juniper Ridge, a wild-crafted line of handmade colognes, soaps and incense, based in Oakland, Calif. First introduced at farmers’ markets in the Bay Area in 1998 and now carried in thoughtfully curated shops like Shelter Half in Los Angeles and Steven Alan Home in New York, Newbegin’s artisanal goods have a hyper-local focus. He forages aromatic plants, mushrooms, tree trimmings and moss on the trails around the West Coast, then distills everything using an old-fashioned enfleurage process to create essential oils that smell like the Mojave Desert after the rain or a dusky summer evening along the Timberline Trail on Mount Hood. “People say the scents remind them of camping,” said Newbegin, who currently lives by Mount Tamalpais in Northern California and trained in herbal medicine before becoming what he calls a “wildness nose.” The latest additions to his forest-centric range are two addition to his line of “backpacker’s colognes”: Big Sur, which is infused with wild sage, and Yuba River, a blend redolent of cedar log cabins and the richness of hiking-boot leather. Like all Juniper Ridge products, they’re made without petrochemicals or synthetic ingredients — “just real stuff from real places,” Newbegin explained.

headline: How Walking May Lower Breast Cancer Risk
text: Physical activity, even including walking, can substantially reduce a woman’s risk of developing breast cancer, encouraging new science shows, in part, it seems, by changing how her body deals with estrogen.

headline: Red Sox Grind Rays Down and Out of the Playoffs

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (Ovation) A YOUNG DOCTOR’S NOTEBOOK A morphine-addicted Russian doctor (Jon Hamm), accompanied by his younger self (Daniel Radcliffe, above right, with Mr. Hamm), relives stories of being dispatched in 1916 to a country hospital, where he performs surgeries in primitive conditions, longs for Moscow and lives in fear of killing his patients in this adaptation of Mikhail Bulgakov’s autobiographical short stories. “The two actors are wonderful in their scenes together (their half-foot difference in height can be excused as a metaphor for growth), and Mr. Hamm, especially, displays bountiful intelligence, depth of feeling and mordant humor,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “He gives an admirable delicacy even to a postoperative, postamputation line like, ‘You just might have to settle for saving the world three-quarters of a peasant at a time.’ ” In this second episode, the young doctor tries to appear more imposing as he lives in the shadows of his predecessor. Episode 1 will be rebroadcast at 1 p.m. and 2:30 a.m.

headline: News Quiz | October 9, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: U.S. Officials Say Libya Approved Commando Raids
text: WASHINGTON — The Libyan government in recent weeks tacitly approved two American commando operations in its country, according to senior American officials, one to capture a senior militant from Al Qaeda and another to seize a militia leader suspected of carrying out the Sept. 11, 2012, attacks on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi.

headline: Why Woody Allen’s ‘Blue Jasmine’ Wasn’t Released in India
text: India’s tough censorship policy has cost its people a wide range of visual pleasures, but even so, its latest blow would have been difficult to anticipate. Last Thursday, film fans in India woke up to the news that the next day’s planned release of “Blue Jasmine,” the latest film from the writer and director Woody Allen, had been canceled. Apparently, Mr. Allen was unwilling to follow the local guidelines for showing people smoking on film.
