headline: All Is Fair in Love and Twitter
text: Right in the center of South Park, a large, grassy oval near San Francisco’s financial district, there is a rinky-dink playground with slides, ladders and firefighter poles, all dented and dinged, connected by gritty brown pylons. Yet for many in Silicon Valley, this playground is hallowed ground. It was here, one breezy day in 2006, according to legend, that Jack Dorsey ordered burritos with two co-workers, scaled a slide and, in a black sweater and green beanie, like a geeked-out Moses on Mount Sinai, presented his idea for an Internet service that would allow users to update their current status and share what they were doing. “That playground right up there is where I first brought up the idea,” Dorsey, whose present-day uniform is a white Dior dress shirt and tailored dark blazer, told CNBC earlier this year.

headline: The First Tweet Ain’t the Deepest
text: The creation of Twitter was a sloppy, nasty thing, as Nick Bilton describes in his cover article for Sunday’s magazine. Bilton unearths the collusion and deception behind the scenes in Twitter’s early days. But even on the surface, right there in the Twitter stream, there was something ugly and confused going on. Nobody — founders included — really knew what Twitter was or how to use it. Take a look at the first tweets from the four men who could reasonably claim to have founded Twitter:

headline: India Trade Deficit Narrowed in September
text: HONG KONG — India’s trade deficit dropped to its lowest level since early 2011, data released Wednesday showed, providing a rare piece of good news from an economy that has been weighed down by inadequate infrastructure, a gaping current account deficit and a currency that has plummeted in recent months.

text: In another blow to Samsung Electronics in its continuing patent disputes with Apple, the Obama administration has decided to uphold a ban requested by Apple of some of Samsung’s mobile products, Brian X. Chen reports.

More than 300 people sent questions (most can be read here). Part 1 of his answers is here; part 2 of his answers is here.

headline: Taking Questions About When It’s Time for Assisted Living

[Update: Part 1 of her answers is here. Part 2 is here. Part 3 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

headline: The Sun-Dried Kid

headline: Washington Heights Remembers a Child It Mourned

headline: Taliban and Pakistan Argue Over Fate of Islamist Detainee
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban on Wednesday publicly disputed claims that the Pakistani government had released a senior militant detainee, drawing a firm rebuttal from the government and plunging efforts to start peace talks in Afghanistan into new confusion.

headline: SAC Considers Deal With Prosecutors
text: SAC IS SAID TO WEIGH PLEA DEAL  |  The hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, after months of fighting the government’s insider trading case, is leaning toward admitting criminal wrongdoing and agreeing to pay a record financial penalty to resolve the charges, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. Federal prosecutors have taken an aggressive stance in settlement talks with SAC, according to two people briefed on the deliberations.

headline: Turkish Court Upholds Many Convictions in Coup Case
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s highest appeals court on Wednesday upheld the convictions of 237 military officers accused of plotting to overthrow the government a decade ago. The case, which has riveted the nation, highlights the power struggle between Turkey’s pro-Islamic government and the once powerful military, which sees itself as the defender of Turkey’s historically secular state.

headline: Yellen’s Path From Liberal Theorist to Fed Voice for Jobs
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — When the economists Janet L. Yellen and George A. Akerlof hired a baby sitter for their son in the early 1980s, they decided to pay more than the going wage. They reasoned that a happier baby sitter would provide better care.

headline: Yellen’s Exclusive Interview, With Yellen
text: Janet Yellen, whom President Obama plans to nominate Wednesday to lead the Federal Reserve, was the editor in chief of the student newspaper at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn. She was also valedictorian of the class of 1963. So in keeping with a school tradition for the editor to interview the valedictorian, she interviewed herself.

headline: Europe Looks Ahead to Fed Choice
text: FRANKFURT — For a world increasingly nervous about events in Washington, President Obama’s choice Wednesday of Janet L. Yellen to be chairwoman of the Federal Reserve meant there was one less thing for global economists and investors to worry about.

headline: Seeking to Preserve a Plain Brick Firehouse With a Painful History
text: There is an old red brick, neo-Georgian building in Elmhurst, Queens, that looks like a firehouse from a movie studio lot: two truck bays with roll-down red doors — side by side, for engine and ladder — under four tall windows and an entablature embossed with the city seal.

headline: What the Latest Consumer Credit Report Tells Us
text: With the government shut down, reliable data is in short supply. Labor statistics? Retail sales? Business inventories? Trade balance? Health updates? The list of what we don’t know goes on.

headline: The Gun Report: October 9, 2013
text: The pro-gun movement is scared. Despite recent victories at the federal and state level, there’s a demographic drop-off on the horizon, writes Alexander Zaitchik, who covered this year’s Gun Rights Policy Conference in Houston for Media Matters. Indeed, gun industry veterans joke that N.R.A. now stands for “Normal Retirement Age.”

headline: Europe Votes to Tighten Rules on Drilling Method
text: European Union lawmakers voted narrowly on Wednesday to force energy companies to carry out in-depth environmental audits before they deploy a technique known as fracking to recover natural gas from shale rock.

headline: Janet L. Yellen, on the Economy’s Twists and Turns
text: The Federal Reserve is said to have a “dual mandate”: keeping inflation in check and the unemployment rate low. These metrics are charted for every year since 1941.

headline: Real Estate in West Vancouver

headline: House Hunting in ... West Vancouver

headline: Homes for $850,000
text: This week’s properties include a 1912 house near San Antonio and midcentury moderns in Florida and Missouri.

headline: What You Get for... $850,000
text: ALAMO HEIGHTS, TEX.

headline: Are Treasuries Terrifying?
text: Neil Irwin says yes. Felix Salmon says no. I say, yes and no.

headline: A Clever Solution to an Olympic Problem
text: For athletes and others going to the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, it’s a much-discussed riddle: how to take a stand against the host country’s reprehensible anti-gay laws, which have rightly caused international outrage, without running afoul of them or of the International Olympic Committee’s prohibition against political statements and protests.

headline: A Creative Renaissance in Philadelphia’s Fishtown
text: The scruffy neighborhood of Fishtown in Philadelphia is having a creative renaissance, coming on the heels of Stephen Starr and Joe Carroll’s recent opening of the barbecue restaurant Fette Sau. The southwest end of Frankford Avenue is becoming an artisanal avenue, with design shops, a small publishing press, restaurants and coffeehouses moving in to this former manufacturing district. Neighborhood pride is palpable; graceful metal sculptures line one stretch of sidewalk, and a wooden sign in a community garden reads “Welcome to Fishtown: Stop and smell the roses.” First Fridays, the free open gallery nights along Frankford Avenue, are also drawing newcomers.

headline: In California, Diving for an Elusive Delicacy
text: The abalone did not want to come off the rock. Fifteen feet underwater, I had jabbed my abalone iron (basically a hard metal spatula) underneath the shell, between the mollusk’s muscular foot and the rock, hoping for the “pop” I had been promised by our instructor. Nothing.

headline: CreatureCast: Royalty Sapped From Snails
text: Tyrian purple was one of the only bright dyes available to ancient civilizations. The sought-after pigment, whose color often worn by royalty, was created from the extracts of marine snails.

headline: They Can’t Handle the Truth
text: It’s remarkable and scary to watch Republican leaders trying to extract themselves from the box they’re in. They have now figured out that Obama won’t eviscerate health reform under threat — although their base refuses to believe it. They still can’t face the reality that Obama won’t offer any concessions, of any kind, under threat. In an odd way, their attempts to get something by repeating over and over the same old lies and misdirections — we’re not practicing extortion, he’s just refusing to negotiate! — makes me think of the classic tourist, believing that locals will understand English if only you talk loud enough.

headline: ‘Maybe WE Should Buy That Old General Store!’
text: The start-up was not a new software company, a new cupcake store, or even a new idea. It was actually a remake of a very old idea.

headline: The Color of Royalty, Bestowed by Science and Snails
text: We now take brightly colored fabric for granted. There were far fewer pigments available to the people of antiquity, and most of them were somewhat drab by today’s standards. Throughout the Mediterranean, the dye Tyrian purple was prized above all others. In ancient Rome, fabric dyed with Tyrian purple was worth its weight in gold. Its intense color, as well as its expense, made it a favorite of royalty and nobility and it was coveted as a status symbol. The association between purple and royalty that persists in many cultures today originated with this ancient pigment.

headline: Comcast Hopes to Promote TV Shows in Twitter Deal
text: Comcast customers will soon be able to reach some television shows from Twitter messages about those shows, the two companies announced on Wednesday, in what they hope will become an industrywide practice.

headline: Poems to Read by Jack-O’-Lantern Light
text: Most of the fun of Halloween is in the planning: choosing a costume, negotiating accessories (“But Dad, a real scythe would look so much scarier!”), decorating the house, dreaming about how much candy you could possibly amass, and where to hide it from your parents. It’s also, perhaps surprisingly, a fine time for poetry. For children who are squeamish about verse, poems about dark magic, graves, goblins and monsters are — no disrespect intended — a far cry from “Now We Are Six”: unabashedly fun, unsentimental and occasionally wicked.

headline: Kochs Deny Pushing for Shutdown Over Health Law
text: Updated, 12:43 p.m. | WASHINGTON – Koch Industries, whose co-founders, Charles and David Koch, are major donors to Tea Party-inspired conservative causes, accused Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, on Wednesday of spreading “false information” about the brothers by suggesting they are behind the move to end financing for President Obama’s healthcare law and the partial shutdown of the federal government.

headline: With New Abortion Restrictions, Ohio Walks a Narrow Legal Line
text: CLEVELAND — Angela H., married with two children, became pregnant accidentally and, after medical complications during her last pregnancy and severe postpartum depression, said neither she nor her family was ready for another child.

headline: 3 Arrested in Death of Tibetan Religious Leader in China
text: BEIJING — Three men have been arrested in the stabbing death of a prominent Tibetan religious leader and British citizen who founded a monastery and Buddhist center in Scotland, Chinese state news media reported Wednesday. The religious leader’s nephew and driver were also killed in the attack, which took place on Tuesday in the western provincial capital of Chengdu.

headline: Turning Education Upside Down
text: Three years ago, Clintondale High School, just north of Detroit, became a “flipped school” — one where students watch teachers’ lectures at home and do what we’d otherwise call “homework” in class. Teachers record video lessons, which students watch on their smartphones, home computers or at lunch in the school’s tech lab. In class, they do projects, exercises or lab experiments in small groups while the teacher circulates.

headline: Complacency on Wall Street Could Be Worse Than a Panic
text: Don’t look to a market panic to save us.

headline: Three Things the Development World Could Do Better
text: The notion that all foreign aid is a waste of money is dead wrong. In my last post, I wrote about the incredible success stories that I witnessed firsthand working on the ground in Africa on development for 25 years. But that doesn’t mean that everything went according to plan.

headline: Tepid Opening for Promoter of Electronic Dance Music
text: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | Investors didn’t seem to be in the mood to dance on Wednesday.

headline: Unrest Over Telangana Brings Andhra Pradesh to Standstill
text: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh— Over 80,000 state power workers protesting a plan to carve a new state out of Andhra Pradesh refused to go back to work on Wednesday despite the state government’s efforts at negotiations, raising concerns among government officials that a prolonged power outage could destabilize the entire southern Indian grid.

headline: Stanley Kauffmann, Critic, Dies at 97; Spent a Half-Century at the Movies
text: Stanley Kauffmann, whose literate, tightly constructed movie reviews appeared in The New Republic for more than a half-century and set a standard for critical ease and erudition, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 97.

headline: App Smart: Nature Apps
text: Kit Eaton reviews Audubon Trees, iBird Plus and RockHound, three apps that aim to deepen knowledge of the natural world around us.

headline: Cheat Sheets for Your Walk in the Woods
text: A family friend has an amazing ability to casually identify most, if not all, of the flora we encounter when we’re walking in the countryside. Her skill is based on experience and knowledge gained from a lot of reading. But now, thanks to my smartphone’s high-tech trickery, I can almost begin to rival her powers. As you take long autumn strolls in the wild, apps can be excellent nature guides.

text: AGE 27

headline: Obama to Meet With Congressional Democrats and Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is bringing Democrats and Republicans from the House and Senate separately to the White House before week’s end to try to resolve the continuing impasse over funding the government and raising the nation’s borrowing ceiling.

headline: O.E.C.D. Head Calls for Global Effort Against Climate Change
text: LONDON — The head of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development sought to make climate change a higher priority on the global agenda, urging the world on Wednesday to eliminate all emissions from burning fossil fuels sometime in the second half of this century.

headline: Andy Pafko, Who Watched Thomson’s Shot, Dies at 92
text: Andy Pafko, the All-Star outfielder who played on four teams that won the National League pennant but who also watched a once-sure Brooklyn Dodgers pennant disappear over a Polo Grounds wall in one of baseball’s most memorable moments, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Stevensville, Mich. He was 92.

headline: The Evolution of Verizon’s Higher Bid for Its Wireless Unit
text: It was never a secret that Verizon Communications wanted to buy back Vodafone‘s 45 percent stake in their enormous wireless joint venture.

headline: Space, the Ultimate Destination
text: Those who have seen Sandra Bullock’s harrowing adventure in “Gravity” and still want to travel to space will have the opportunity to win a suborbital flight through a new NBC reality series being developed by Mark Burnett’s One Three Media, the company that made “The Voice” and “Survivor,” in partnership with Virgin Galactic, the commercial space venture founded by Richard Branson, the owner of the Virgin Group.

headline: High-End Art, a Way to Stand Out
text: Luxury hotels have been increasingly adorning their public spaces with high-end art, but now, some are going a step further by decorating their suites with museum-quality works. The Regina Hotel Baglioni in Rome recently introduced an art exhibition in its new Roman Penthouse called “Luxury Is Not a Waste,” which includes 26 limited-edition pieces by contemporary Italian designers and architects like Michele de Lucchi, who have had their works displayed in museums including the Museum of Modern Art in New York and La Triennale di Milano in Milan. Also in Rome, the Rome Cavalieri has a suite with Andy Warhol’s “Dollar Signs” from 1981.

headline: Downsizing a Play (as Well as Its Wigs)
text: The three-foot-tall wigs were among the first things to go, followed quickly by the collapsing wall of dirt.

headline: Redskins’ Name Change Remains Activist’s Unfinished Business
text: WASHINGTON — Suzan Shown Harjo still becomes tense when she recalls the only Washington Redskins home game she attended, nearly 40 years ago.

headline: Without Services, Small Businesses Feel the Pinch
text: Chris Leh, the owner of a fledgling manufacturing company in Ephrata, Pa., recently landed the kind of deal that growing companies dream about, with a major client whose order volume will triple his annual sales to around $1.5 million.

headline: Shutdown Is Affecting Energy and Environmental Programs
text: As the government shutdown goes on, parts of the government related to energy and the environment are losing steam.

headline: Exercise as Preventive Medicine
text: A structured exercise program may be as good or better than frequently prescribed drugs for some common cardiovascular ailments, a large meta-analysis has found.

headline: A Glimpse of Yellen’s Career, Chronicled in Her High School Newspaper
text: She was valedictorian of the class of 1963, newspaper editor in chief, honor society inductee, psychology club member, budding scientist and rock collector. She won scholarships and prizes and studied math on Saturday mornings. She was bound for Brown University, where, she said, she would study math, anthropology or economics.

headline: A Breast-Feeding Latina Mother Looking for Support
text: This summer, the British poet Hollie McNish posted a video to YouTube in which she reads one of her poems, “Embarrassed.” With a voice full of emotion, she speaks about nursing her infant daughter in public bathroom stalls after being shamed out of breast-feeding whenever she went out.

headline: What If There’s Another Chemical Disaster?
text: The explosion at a fertilizer plant in West, Texas in April that killed 14 people and injured nearly 200 others had the force of a 2.1-magnitude earthquake. It leveled homes to ruble in a five-block radius and left a crater 93 feet wide and 10 feet deep.

headline: A New Way to Pay for Long-Term Care
text: I was visiting an assisted living facility recently with my sister, whose disability made that a prudent choice, when the marketing manager handed us a brochure. It asked, “Did you know a life insurance policy can pay for long-term care expenses?”

headline: As Pressure Mounts, House G.O.P. Weighs Short-Term Debt Deal
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans, increasingly isolated from even some of their strongest supporters more than a week into a government shutdown, began on Wednesday to consider a path out of the fiscal impasse that would raise the debt ceiling for a few weeks as they press for a broader deficit reduction deal.

headline: The Wonderful and Somewhat Ugly World of Parquet Courts
text: I came to Parquet Courts late.

headline: Date Is Set for 2014 Tony Awards Ceremony
text: The 2014 Tony Awards ceremony, the biggest night of the year for the Broadway theater industry, will be held on June 8 at Radio City Music Hall, organizers of the Tonys announced on Wednesday. A host for the show wasn’t named; usually the host is announced in the spring. The organizers also disclosed that nominations for Tonys, which recognize actors, directors and designers as well as new musicals and plays and revivals, will be announced on April 29; to be eligible for nominations, shows will have to open by Thursday night, April 24.

headline: By 2047, Coldest Years May Be Warmer Than Hottest in Past, Scientists Say
text: If greenhouse emissions continue their steady escalation, temperatures across most of the earth will rise to levels with no recorded precedent by the middle of this century, researchers said Wednesday.

headline: Bill Young, Florida’s Master Appropriator, to Retire
text: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, currently the longest-serving Republican in Congress, will retire in 2014, he announced Wednesday.

headline: Your Dot: On Walking Dogs and Warming Trends
text: Kip Hansen, a longtime reader, and sometime critic, of Dot Earth, sent this closer look at one animated graphic I pointed to in my recent post about innovative ways to communicate about climate change. I think he’s downplaying the scientific case, built on basic climate principles (“everything we do know”), for long-term warming, but his general point is worth exploring. Here’s his “Your Dot” contribution:

headline: Australia’s New Creative Commune
text: A factory space on Sydney’s fringe has become a surprising center for forward-thinking local artisans.

headline: Out of Position: Changing Cast in Heart of Giants’ Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants visit Chicago on Thursday night to play the Bears, a team with a rich heritage at linebacker, from Dick Butkus to Mike Singletary to Brian Urlacher.

headline: Is the Shutdown Affecting Your Business?
text: As Stacy Cowley writes in an article just published in The Times, Chris Leh, the owner of a fledgling manufacturing company in Ephrata, Pa., thought he was about to triple his annual sales to around $1.5 million.

headline: Further Thoughts From Paris
text: The Paris Fashion Week schedule is beginning to look as overcrowded as the New York Fashion Week schedule. With just over 100 officially sanctioned shows over nine days, the Paris collections, which ended last week, included so many designers that it became impossible for most publications to include coverage of them all.

headline: Fears for Economy Kept Stimulus Intact
text: WASHINGTON — The decision by Federal Reserve officials last month to continue the stimulus campaign came down to this: their anxiety that the economy might falter outweighed their anxiety that waiting to pull back would surprise and confuse investors.

headline: Nestle Is Said to Seek Buyer for Jenny Craig
text: LONDON— Nestlé, the Swiss food giant, is looking to sell its Jenny Craig brand, just seven years after spending $600 million to buy the weight-loss company from two private equity firms, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Clinical Trials Continue, but Only at a Crawl
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government has continued to enroll critically ill people in clinical trials at the National Institutes of Health since the government shutdown began last week, but the pace has slowed drastically, and many other sick people are having to wait for treatment.

headline: A Spin in the 2014 Cadillac CTS Sedan
text: Although Cadillac’s XTS – the brand’s flagship – gave me the impression of, say, a really, really well-appointed Toyota Camry, the CTS sedan had the opposite effect. I’d heard all the hype, as well as breathy admiration from my colleagues about what a grand car the CTS-V was. And I have to say, the CTS Vsport is as they described the V: fantastic.

headline: Watchdog Says Syria Has Been Cooperative on Weapons
text: GENEVA — The head of the international watchdog overseeing the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal said Wednesday that a team of 15 inspectors had begun to visit sites and that the Syrian authorities had been “quite constructive” and “cooperative.”

headline: Silver Screen and LEDs Join at Last
text: The world is discovering LED lights, and for good reason. They last 25 times as long as regular bulbs, they use a fraction of the power, they don’t get as hot and they’re very rugged. They’re cropping up everywhere: in homes, flashlights, car headlights, flat-panel TV screens, movie lights and Christmas lights.

headline: Good Populism, Bad Populism and the Shutdown
text: The big D.C. news today, of sorts, is Paul Ryan’s op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, sketching out what might be the G.O.P.’s leadership’s hoped-for path out of this mess: Negotiations to trade “relief from the discretionary spending levels in the Budget Control Act in exchange for structural reforms to entitlement programs,” presumably tied to some sort of short-term continuing resolution/debt limit lift. Notably, the piece does not mention Obamacare, which prompted much snark from pro-shutdown voices on Twitter last night, and then this broadside from Ben Domenech, prince of the libertarian populists, in this morning’s edition of The Transom:

headline: Israel Expresses Dismay at Cutback of U.S. Aid to Egypt
text: JERUSALEM — Officials and experts in Israel responded on Wednesday with a mixture of disappointment and alarm to the news that the United States planned to reduce its  military aid to Egypt in response to this summer’s brutal crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood and the continuing violence it has spawned.

headline: A Deal That Needs Some Special Tailoring
text: Jos. A. Bank’s $2.3 billion attempt to stitch up Men’s Wearhouse will be no cinch.

headline: Going Contract-Free: Finding a Phone and Plan That Fit
text: Just a few years ago, buying a cellphone without a contract was both unfashionable and largely unfeasible. No-contract options were available but getting your hands on the latest phones and the best data plans usually required a two-year contract.

headline: Join Us on Oct. 16 for TimesOpen: Performance
text: You’ve probably heard that performance matters on the web. You’ve heard that Google saw a 20% decrease in page views after increasing page load time by half a second. You’ve seen studies claiming e-commerce sites can see reduced performance and revenue due to one second of latency loading a site. You know the drill: gzip, concatenate, minify, reduce page size.

headline: Greenpeace Leader Offers Himself to Aid Detainees
text: MOSCOW — The executive director of Greenpeace International offered on Wednesday to travel to Russia and risk his own freedom with a possibly lengthy prison sentence, if it would help win the release on bail of the Greenpeace activists who are being held by Russia on piracy charges.

headline: On Cells and Nobels: Understanding and Modeling Prize-Winning Work on Vesicles
text: Overview | What are the Nobel Prizes, why did three American biologists win this year’s award in Physiology or Medicine, and how can students understand and illustrate their findings? In this lesson, students study these scientists’ discovery of cellular transportation systems – the compartments, called vesicles, that cells use to ferry compounds from one cell to another, or to carry materials within the cell — then build models of cells, showing how these vesicles work.

headline: Who Is Janet Yellen?
text: Janet L. Yellen, President Obama’s pick to head the Federal Reserve, is favored by Democrats and economists alike.

headline: A Conversation With Lavabit’s Founder
text: Ladar Levison, the founder of the secure e-mail service, spoke to The Times about his confrontation with law enforcement officials who demanded full access to his customers’ accounts.

headline: ‘Dinner With Friends’ Revival Boasts Weighty Names
text: An Off Broadway revival of “Dinner With Friends,” which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2000 for the playwright Donald Margulies, will star four highly regarded New York stage actors, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Skin Deep: The Fishtail Crown Braid
text: Follow these easy steps to recreate a popular runway look.

headline: Boston School-Bus Drivers Return to Work Amid Uncertainty
text: BOSTON — School-bus drivers returned to work Wednesday after a surprise daylong work stoppage that left thousands of schoolchildren stranded at home and at bus stops.

headline: Braids 2.0
text: Braids have returned to the runways and are showing their staying power.

headline: Cosmetics Sending Some Money Toward Breast Cancer Causes
text: It is National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and the disease is a major cause of the cosmetics industry. Here are some products intended to raise awareness and some money.

headline: Braids Woven to Each Personality
text: Rihanna with a cascading fishtail side braid. Eva Chen, the editor in chief of Lucky magazine, on Instagram with her purple locks woven into a slightly tousled crown braid. Allison Williams at an Emmys weekend party in a complicated French braid.

headline: For Girardi, It’s 4 More Seasons in Pinstripes
text: When he was a third grader in Illinois in the 1970s, Joe Girardi said, he wrote a school paper about how he would one day play for the Chicago Cubs. Years later, after Girardi had achieved that goal, many people wondered whether the team of his boyhood dreams might lure him from the Yankees to be the manager on Chicago’s North Side.

headline: Maverick and Scavenger
text: A Mike Kelley retrospective completely fills MoMA PS1.

headline: From the Screen, Quirks and All
text: Am I wrong to find it slightly unfortunate (and utterly inevitable) that William Finn, a brilliant composer and lyricist who specializes in gently funny and heartfelt small-scale musicals, is doing a movie adaptation? Probably. After all, there are many great movies turned into musicals, and such cultural borrowing and translating has been part of the art form since the start. And the 2006 indie hit “Little Miss Sunshine” does seem like a nice fit for Mr. Finn. Who better than the creator of “Falsettoland” to reinvent for the stage an intimate, quirky film about family and misfits that proves that a little sweet sentimentality can be a wonderful thing?

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Escape From Tomorrow
text: Randy Moore, the writer and director of “Escape From Tomorrow,” narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Keeping Score: It Was All Hands (and Arms) on Deck for Ousted Rays
text: The Tampa Bay Rays were facing elimination from the playoffs for the fourth time in nine days, but Manager Joe Maddon was not going to go out quietly. If it meant using his entire pitching staff and a kitchen sink or two, he was more than willing.

headline: Announcing Fed Nomination, Obama Praises Yellen
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday announced what he called perhaps his most important economic decision, nominating Janet L. Yellen to lead the Federal Reserve system and be his independent co-steward of the economy, calling her “one of the nation’s foremost economists and policy makers.”

headline: Republicans Using Shutdown to Stake Positions for Potential 2016 Bids
text: During the federal government shutdown, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has appeared guided by one goal: sticking as close as possible to Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards Shed Some Fees, but Face Scrutiny
text: Prepaid debit cards continue to grow more popular and offer more services that mimic traditional debit cards, even as the federal government weighs new rules for the cards.

headline: Financial Times to Consolidate Print Editions
text: LONDON — The Financial Times, signaling a tighter focus on digital publishing, plans to stop printing regional editions and produce only a single global daily newspaper.

headline: Timberlake Nets Second No. 1 Album This Year
text: The final installment of Justin Timberlake’s two-part “20/20 Experience” (RCA) has jumped onto Billboard’s album chart at No. 1, displacing Drake’s “Nothing Was the Same” (Young Money/Cash Money/Republic) and giving Mr. Timberlake his second chart-topping album of the year.

headline: Better Access to Contraceptives for Parents Means Better Outcomes for Children
text: What’s the long-term impact of access to birth control and family planning? The economist Martha J. Bailey pulled together decades of data and research on families surrounding two major policy changes in the United States: laws banning the sale of contraceptives and their repeal, and the expansion of federal funding for local family-planning clinics during the Johnson and Nixon administrations. She writes:

headline: $60 Million Gift to Establish Fellowships at Juilliard
text: Time was when a conservatory student’s main worry was about finding a job, either as a soloist or in a chamber group or an orchestra, after graduation. These days, many of them fear  that even if they do, they will be unable to repay the student loans that helped finance their training.

headline: Bail for Pakistani Ex-Leader Paves Way for His Exit
text: A Pakistani court granted bail on Wednesday to Pervez Musharraf, the country’s former military ruler, clearing the way for him to leave the country as early as Thursday, his lawyers said.

headline: Giambattista Valli: Looking Beyond the Clothes
text: Giambattista Valli’s career is a little young to be the subject of a coffee-table book. He started his signature label only in 2005 and became a couturier two years ago, so how to fill the nearly 400-page book ($100) being published this month from Rizzoli?

headline: Man Trades Elmo Costume for a Jail Suit
text: Elmo bad. Elmo go to jail.

headline: A Conversation With Lavabit’s Founder
text: For nearly a decade, Ladar Levison ran Lavabit, a secure e-mail service that served as an alternative for a tech-savvy crowd that cared about privacy. Then, last July, after two months of haggling with the F.B.I., Mr. Levison shuttered the service rather than give the government untrammeled access to his users’ communications and everything he had built.

headline: Chicago Symphony to Stream Performance of Verdi’s Requiem Online
text: Lots of people love the Verdi Requiem.

headline: The Hurdles Ahead for a Cooper Tire Deal
text: Cooper Tire and Rubber is heading perilously close to a collision in its just-commenced legal battle with Apollo Tyres.

headline: Madoff Trustee Asks Supreme Court to Let Him Sue Banks
text: Updated, 7:27 p.m. | The trustee seeking to recover money for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to review a ruling that prohibits him from suing several of the world’s largest banks that he contends aided the fraud.

headline: Trash Bags You Won’t Throw Out
text: Derelicte is really happening.

headline: Death Benefits for Soldiers to Continue
text: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials said Wednesday that they would contract with a charity group, the Fisher House Foundation, to restore death benefits to families of service members killed in action, including a $100,000 payment, that have been stopped by the government shutdown. The officials said the Pentagon would reimburse the group after the shutdown ended.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Delaware and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Delaware, Syria, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

headline: Manufacture New York Provides Production Facilities to Independent Designers
text: Almost a year to the day since she began pitching the idea for Manufacture New York, a work hive for independent designers with outposts in Brooklyn and Manhattan, Bob Bland was on the verge of opening the doors to the first iteration of her vision. “We gut-renovated this space with our bare hands,” she said one afternoon last month, casting her gaze over a 2,000-square-foot space at 23 West 36th Street that she is branding the Garment Center Pilot Program. “Although now I hear they’re rebranding as the garment district, which means we’ll have to redo all our branding.”

headline: Megyn Kelly Draws a Bigger, Younger Audience on Night 2 in Prime Time
text: In an impressive turnaround, Megyn Kelly, Fox News’ new prime-time host, reversed a somewhat disappointing performance on her first night at the center of the network’s lineup, scoring a smashing win across the board on Night 2.

headline: Dressed to Celebrate a Night for Nudity
text: Perhaps predictably, there was a lot of nudity at the “Take Home a Nude” benefit Tuesday night at Sotheby’s, where art was being auctioned to raise funds for the New York Academy of Art. Still, it took Sophie Portale a minute to figure out what was going on in a work by Lola Montes Schnabel.

headline: Scene City: Getting Undressed for Art
text: The New York Academy of Art held its annual Take Home a Nude benefit.

headline: G.M. to Recall Some 2014 Full-Size Pickups for Seat Problem
text: General Motors will recall almost 19,000 of its new 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra pickups because some front seats may not meet a federal safety standard, the automaker said in a news release Wednesday.

headline: Ford, Playing Catch-Up in China, Sees Sales Jump 51 Percent
text: Even as the Ford Motor Company has rebounded from the recession to become the most profitable of the big three American automakers, it has lagged in China, the world’s biggest car market.

headline: A New Danger for Democrats: Boehner’s Delegation
text: Speaker John Boehner isn’t taking the House Tea Party coalition with him to the White House on Thursday. Though President Obama invited the entire Republican caucus to discuss the budget crisis, Mr. Boehner is only bringing 17 others along. Perhaps he was worried about misbehavior, or maybe some on the hard right — deathly afraid of being branded a collaborator with a man they call a socialist — wouldn’t be caught dead in Mr. Obama’s home.

headline: Director of British Domestic Intelligence Agency Defends Spying Policies
text: LONDON — Warning that there are thousands of Islamic extremists who view British citizens as “legitimate targets,” the chief of Britain’s domestic intelligence agency, MI5, said this week that recent leaks about government spying capabilities had caused enormous damage, handing “the advantage to the terrorists.”

headline: Kerry, in Asia, Urges Focus on Law in China Disputes
text: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei — Secretary of State John Kerry encouraged Southeast Asian leaders on Wednesday in their efforts to resolve maritime disputes with China based on international legal principles, rather than by making individual deals as China would prefer.

headline: 36 Hours in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina
text: At midday in Sarajevo, muezzins call from minarets as church bells echo through the Dinaric Alps. Street cars rumble past hookah smokers and cafegoers. Chic women click-clack down cobbled alleyways. The city’s charisma is intoxicating, but the hustle and bustle belies a tragic past. In 1992, Bosnia-Herzegovina’s capital went from a beacon of diversity, with Yugoslav Muslims, Christians and Jews worshiping within feet of one other, to the site of a nearly four-year siege claiming more than 11,000 lives. But much has changed over the last decade or so. The creative spirit that Sarajevans fought to preserve is very much in evidence these days. Neighborhoods, cradled in this valley and ringing the foothills, are fertile entrepreneurial grounds and a testament to the epochs that came before. Cafes, theaters, boutiques and restaurants have sprouted among buildings in myriad styles, including Ottoman, Secessionist, Communist and modern. And locals and visitors alike are rediscovering the surrounding mountains on the slopes that hosted the 1984 Winter Olympic Games.

headline: Sarajevo Scenes
text: Eat, drink and shop during a tour of the capital.

headline: Trips to Ancient Iraq
text: Steppes Travel, a London-based company specializing in high-end cultural and archaeological tours, recently announced that it is offering two trips next year to the Kurdish city of Erbil in northern Iraq.

headline: Emma Thompson to Join Philharmonic’s ‘Sweeney Todd’
text: Following a year-end movie season in which she will play P. L. Travers, the surprisingly tough creator of “Mary Poppins,” Emma Thompson will pick up her umbrella and alight on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall, where she will play a murderous London shop proprietor who serves up surprisingly tough meat pies.

headline: The Soulful High-Tech Wizard
text: Alone onstage Tuesday evening at the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Jorge Drexler sang in Spanish, “There are so many things/I only need two: My guitar and you.” The song was “Guitarra y Vos” (“Guitar and You”). “Vos” can double as a pun on “voz,” or voice. When he stepped to the front of the stage to sing other songs, away from the microphones, his guitar and voice were indeed all Mr. Drexler needed in the intimate hall. He didn’t even need the guitar when he sang his Academy Award-winning song from “The Motorcycle Diaries,” “Al Otro Lado del Rio,” a cappella.

headline: Want to Meet Influential New Yorkers? Invite Them to Dinner
text: Jonathan Levy was standing on the coffee table in his spacious Upper West Side apartment, holding up a bottle of Lagavulin 16 like a trophy. It was after midnight on a Wednesday last month and the living room was packed with chief executives, designers, philanthropists and TV personalities.

headline: Rainbows I’m Inclined to Pursue
text: Swaggering across the stage of Frederick P. Rose Hall toting bottles of Jack Daniel’s and cracking dirty jokes, the Rat Pack commandeered the second night of the 2013 New York Cabaret Convention on Tuesday evening. Chasing away Noël Coward, Cole Porter and their fancy society friends, they ring-a-ding-dinged until daylight.

headline: Feeling For | The Warm, Rough Comforts of Wool
text: Nubby, fleecy or bouclé, creamy textured wool is cozier and more durable than the beige Belgian linen that designers have grown so fond of. Ideal for furniture, these fabrics nod to vintage Chanel suits and childhood teddy bears but still feel luxuriously modern.

headline: House Republicans Argue for Delay in Health Law Penalties
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans said Wednesday that chaos in the first nine days of open enrollment under President Obama’s health care law would justify a delay in major provisions of the law, including tax penalties for people who go without insurance in 2014.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Leader Talks Peace and Frolics on Camera
text: The BBC journalist who traveled to Pakistan’s northwestern tribal areas this month to interview the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, as drones hovered overhead, made it back to Islamabad with the sound bites he was after, but something unexpected too — footage of the militant “at play,” frolicking on a riverbank.

headline: Shopping Events in New York Beginning Oct. 10
text: Openings

headline: Jennifer Rubell: Two Legacies, Now Home to Roost
text: The first time Jennifer Rubell gave a dinner party, at age 9, a guest (a friend of her parents who was a diamond dealer) followed up the next morning with a thank-you gift: a heart-shaped diamond ring. Since then, Ms. Rubell, now 43, has worked as a hotelier, a food writer and an artist, but at heart she has remained a hostess.

headline: Catastrophe by the Spoonful
text: As a book about a cinematic comedy of errors, “The Disaster Artist” is much better than the mess of a movie it describes. That movie is “The Room,” which has gone all but unnoticed on the East Coast until lately but developed a West Coast following after its sickly 2003 release.

headline: PC Shipments: It Could Have Been Worse (and Probably Will Be)
text: The new personal computer sales numbers are out from the analysis firm IDC. Which bad news/good news would you like first?

headline: Shutdown or No, She’s Still Busy Fixing Washington
text: The scolding, cadenced admonitions rolling out of Olivia Pope — crisis handler, presidential girlfriend and major buzzkill — were a sign of continuity in last Thursday’s Season 3 premiere of ABC’s “Scandal,” an episode that was patchy and transitional but drew a series-record 10.5 million viewers.

headline: What Economists Think About a Possible Debt Default
text: As my colleague Jonathan Weisman wrote on the front page of Wednesday’s editions, some Republican leaders are arguing that a debt default would not be so terrible. Economists do not agree.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Escape From Tomorrow’
text: The Magic Kingdom isn’t always magical in Randy Moore’s comedy “Escape From Tomorrow.” The film, which had its debut in January at Sundance and is being released in theaters and on-demand Friday, was shot partially in the Disneyland and Walt Disney World parks. In this video, Mr. Moore narrates a scene where the ride Space Mountain causes some family problems.

headline: TV Talk: The DVR Dilemma
text: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss how viewers using DVRs make it difficult to judge a show’s success.

headline: Canadians Stuck in Egyptian Legal Limbo Thank Supporters via YouTube
text: Two Canadians who were detained in Cairo during the deadly security crackdown in August and are still barred from leaving the country despite their release last week posted a message of thanks to their supporters on YouTube on Wednesday.

headline: For City Ballet, Future Is Now
text: The usual rule is that a ballet’s original cast is never surpassed. Though its first dancers may grow better over the years, as they understand the choreography more completely, it was tailor-made to display their particular gifts. Yet there are a number of cases with today’s New York City Ballet where older audience members have been asking: “Was it really this good back then?”

headline: U.S. vs. Poles at Transnational Teams Quarterfinal
text: We have reached the last board of the Transnational Teams world championship quarterfinal between Mark Gordon, Pratap Rajadhyaksha, David Berkowitz, Alan Sontag, Jacek Pszczola and Michael Seamon from the United States and the Polish Students team: Stanislaw Golebiowski, Piotr Tuczynski, Pawel Jassem, Jakub Wojcieszek, Michal Klukowski and Piotr Zatorski. The Saturday and Monday columns described other boards from this exciting set, in which more than 5 international match points per board were exchanged.

headline: Barclays Names Head of Americas Banking
text: Barclays has reshuffled the leadership of its investment banking team in the Americas, including giving a top industrial and private equity banker a new prominent role.

headline: Oh Boy, Looks Like Reggie and Billy Are at It Again
text: Great theater can make an audience feel new things, perhaps reassess long-held beliefs. It turns out that bad theater can achieve that, too. As a lifelong Mets fan, I never thought I could pity the Yankees. But thanks to “Bronx Bombers,” I do.

headline: Yellen Named as Obama's Choice for Fed
text: Janet L. Yellen, 67, would be the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve if the Senate confirms her nomination for a four-year term.

headline: Obama Announces Pick to Lead the Fed
text: President Obama said Wednesday that his choice to head the Federal Reserve was its current vice chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen.

headline: Loss of ’22 World Cup Bid Still Rankles Head of U.S. Soccer
text: It has been three years, but FIFA’s decision to award the 2022 World Cup to Qatar still smarts for Sunil Gulati.

headline: Like Vines, Reaching, Twining, Curling
text: The veteran choreographer Lar Lubovitch, an art major before he discovered modern dance, has spoken about how he sees the stage as a canvas. Instead of using brush strokes to give a painting a sense of momentum, he relies on bodies that ripple through space, pause to crest and then sweep lushly in another direction. When they succeed, Mr. Lubovitch’s dances are visceral paintings come to life.

headline: Listen Up | An Avant-Garde Artist Makes a Bid for Pop Stardom
text: Alexis Georgopoulos took the moniker under which he makes music, Arp, from a defunct manufacturer of analog synthesizers. It was a fitting name for the kind of music the 39-year-old, New York-based artist made on the albums “In Light” (2007) and “The Soft Wave” (2010): instrumental outings with minimalist repetition and exploratory electronics that owed more to minimalist composers like Steve Reich and Philip Glass than anything resembling pop music. But on his new album, “More,” it becomes clear from the opening strains of the first track, “High-Heeled Clouds” — a dreamy ballad featuring breathy vocals, melodic keyboard lines and a hooky chorus — that Georgopoulos is taking the music in a more tuneful direction.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google’s Anti-Aging Start-Up, and the Man Tied to Silk Road
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Alice Lives Between Fantasy and Reality
text: “If I get high enough, I can see the Hatter’s house,” Alice says in the premiere on Thursday night of ABC’s “Once Upon a Time in Wonderland.” If we could get high enough, maybe we could see some reason to sit through this Disneyfied pastiche of Lewis Carroll and “1,001 Nights.” Or maybe not.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Park Delicatessen
text: In Crown Heights, a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop attracts a varied customer base.

headline: Blurring Boundaries, Sharpening Ideas
text: The term “transdisciplinary” is heard a great deal. But what does it actually mean? Does it go beyond using text in your dance piece, or video in your play? Does its very nature ask artists to question our understanding of genre, or to destabilize what it is that audiences think they are seeing?

headline: Investigating a Grudge During a Day in Berkeley
text: I’ve long held a grudge against graduates of the University of California, Berkeley. As the graduate of a pricey private university in the wintry northeast, I’ve never been able to shake the uneasy feeling that they got a similar education at a fraction of the cost in far nicer weather.

headline: ‘So I Told Hitler’ and Other Film Re-Enactments
text: A film festival that includes a pair of Weimar-influenced pre-code Hollywood musicals, three classic cartoons by John and Faith Hubley and a 1936 docudrama in which an American re-enacts her imprisonment in Nazi Germany might fairly be called eclectic. Or it might be called To Save and Project, as the Museum of Modern Art titles its annual survey of recently restored movies, which returned this week for its 11th edition. Organized by Joshua Siegel, an associate curator in the museum’s film department, the festival has a sweeping nature that suggests how much work is being done to reclaim film history — and how much more needs to be done. This year’s program contains some 75 feature films and shorts from archives around the world.

headline: Not a Teachable Moment, but a Respectful One
text: “Glee” isn’t just another comedy about the horrors of high school. Now in its fifth season, this cheeky Fox show has become a cabaret-meets-after-school-special that sneaks in as many life lessons as it does pop songs. In a recent episode, there was even a reminder about the importance of meningitis vaccines.

headline: Reincarnation of Treasured Instrument
text: This was a sound no musician should have to suffer: the destruction of her longtime instrument. In Wu Man’s case, in June, it was a loud crack, heard from her seat as a flight attendant, trying to stow her pipa in a coat closet up front, dropped it, breaking its neck.

headline: After an Introduction by de Blasio, a Brooklyn Hospital Hired His Wife
text: Sometime around 2005, a Brooklyn city councilman introduced his wife, who was looking for a new job, to the head of a hospital in his district.

headline: Meredith Whitney Appears to Be Trading Brokerage Firm for Investment Fund
text: Meredith A. Whitney appears poised to leave the industry that lifted her to fame.

headline: Wu Man Plays the Pipa
text: The musician performs a piece on her pipa, a traditional Chinese instrument.

headline: Polls Show Growing Concerns About Shutdown
text: More than a week into the government shutdown, a number of new polls have found rising exasperation with a dysfunctional government and economic concern, as well as disagreement about the debt limit and how Congress should handle it.

headline: Video Offers Glimpse of Russia’s Ban on Gay ‘Propaganda’ in Action on a Moscow Street
text: Video recorded this week during the arrest of gay rights activists in Moscow shows what Russia’s legal ban on “propaganda for nontraditional sexual relationships” looks like in practice.

headline: No Pastrami, but Skateboards and Zinnias
text: Michael J. Sclafani and Valentine Leung didn’t exactly set out to open a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop.

headline: Artisanal Housewares
text: Conscientious shoppers may prefer to buy socially responsible design — objects produced in a way that promotes the well-being of the artisans in Third World countries who make them — but the products have not always been easy to find or sophisticated enough to satisfy the tastes of some consumers. In recent years, however, that has begun to change, as collaborations between designers and artisans have flourished.

headline: Start Spreadin’ the News
text: The Viceroy New York, a 29-story brick hotel at 120 West 57th Street, is the latest and largest building designed by the architectural studio Roman & Williams. And it is filled with its signature touches, like shiny black fluted Italian glass block, crown molding, ultra-veined marble and a strategic use of brass. Rooms are “well-appointed modernist cabins in the sky,” said Robin Standefer, a founder of the firm. Over all, the hotel reflects a narrative that is “artistic, refined and glamorous — a way of looking at Uptown, and 57th Street in particular, that seems to have been lost in the last 20 years,” she said.

headline: If It’s All About Location, Does the Sky Count?
text: For many, a treehouse signifies questionable construction and freedom from adult supervision. But the projects in “Tree Houses” (Skyhorse Publishing, $50) show how a child’s hideaway has experienced a renaissance in material, sophistication and design. The Copper Cube, for instance, a metal-clad guesthouse in Germany, sits on stilts and has electricity and even a full bath. In Sweden, a saucer-shaped enclosure tied to trees with cables and aptly called the UFO is accessible via a retractable take-me-to-your-leader staircase. But traditionalists, fear not: there are plenty of fairytale-like cottages, too.

headline: Not Built in a Day
text: When David Nosanchuk wandered around Rome with a camera a couple of years ago, he didn’t realize he was making wallpaper. But Mr. Nosanchuk, a New York designer, had been invited to contribute ideas to Flavor Paper, a Brooklyn producer of avant-garde wallcoverings. And at some point he saw potential in his luminous prints of the Pantheon and Bernini’s Colonnade at St. Peter’s Basilica.

headline: A One-of-a-Kind, From Sketch to Auction
text: On Nov. 23, Sotheby’s New York will host an auction of items selected by the designer Marc Newson and Apple’s senior vice president for design, Jonathan Ive, to benefit (RED), the charity founded by Bono and Bobby Shriver. Mr. Newson described the 40-odd lots as “stuff we ourselves would kill to have,” including an anodized aluminum desk that he designed with Mr. Ive for the occasion.

headline: Discounts at Vermont Woods, DwellStudio, De La Espada and Lumens
text: Vermont Woods furniture is 15 percent off, Friday to Tuesday (a queen-size Modern Incline bed, regularly $2,394, will be about $2,035); (888) 390-5571, vermontwoodsstudios.com.

headline: Light up the Cigars: It’s a Chair
text: The Museum of Arts and Design, known as MAD, takes another leap beyond its origins in traditional craft with “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital,” an exhibition of new technologies that dominate many of today’s conversations about design. The show, which opens on Wednesday and runs through July 6, will present objects created through 3-D printing, digital weaving and computer-controlled milling. Included alongside the forward-thinking work of well-known designers like Ron Arad, Zaha Hadid and Maya Lin is a project by the Dutch-born designer Jan Habraken that represents his attempt to breed the ultimate chair. Mr. Habraken, is the founder of FormNation, a New York company. Recently he met a reporter in his Manhattan studio to discuss the concept of chair eugenics, or “chairgenics.” (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: A Bit Tori and Dean
text: A Park Slope Victorian goes Hollywood mod.

headline: The Circuitous Route Home
text: Even for Park Slope, the house is a showstopper, blooming with intricate mahogany paneling inlaid with mother-of-pearl, and nestled into a block just a few streets away from P.S. 321, the much-coveted elementary school.

headline: The Architecture of Autism
text: SONOMA, Calif. — Here is a truth about children with autism: they grow up to become adults with autism. Advocates estimate that over the next decade some 500,000 such individuals will come of age in the United States.

headline: Peace, Purpose and a Pool
text: Sweetwater Spectrum, a California residence for autistic adults, hopes to become a model for like-minded experiments across the country.

headline: T-Mobile to Make It Cheaper to Make Calls While Abroad
text: Cellphone plans are a little like languages: they don’t always translate well in foreign countries.

headline: Europe Pledges Aid to Italy for Refugees
text: ROME — The European Union’s top official on Wednesday visited the Italian island of Lampedusa, where a crowded boat capsized last week, killing hundreds of migrants, and announced that Italy would receive an additional 30 million euros, or $40.5 million, from the union to help deal with refugees.

headline: Longtime Florida Congressman to Retire
text: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the longest-serving Republican in Congress, said Wednesday that he would retire in 2014. “It’s my time,” Mr. Young, 82, told The Tampa Bay Times. He has long served on the Appropriations Committee, including a stint as chairman from 1999 to 2005, and is known for bringing millions of dollars to his district. A moderate Republican, Mr. Young came to Congress in 1971, at a time when most Southern conservatives were still Democrats. He said that he admires the spirit of Tea Party Republicans, but is “a little disappointed” with the current gridlock.

headline: Big-Money Manipulators
text: The dysfunction in Washington is incredibly dispiriting.

headline: For Journalists Who Seek Out Hidden Things, a More Visible Brand
text: A leading nonprofit organization in the field of investigative journalism is getting a free branding and advertising campaign, courtesy of a leading creative agency.

headline: Paul McCartney Makes Surprise Stop in Queens
text: A half-century after Beatlemania swept Britain, Paul McCartney faced squealing teenage girls once again when he performed on Wednesday afternoon in the Tony Bennett Concert Hall at the Frank Sinatra School of the Arts in Astoria, Queens. They didn’t scream all the way through the songs, as their grandparents might have, but they stayed on their feet — clapping, waving their arms, singing along — through oldies like “Eight Days a Week,” “Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da,” “We Can Work It Out” and “Blackbird.”

headline: Cutbacks in U.N. Food Assistance Set Off Outcry in Gaza
text: GAZA — Hundreds of women and children protested cutbacks in a United Nations food-assistance program on Wednesday, the latest in a growing backlash by Palestinian refugees and their offspring in this forlorn coastal strip against the agency that for decades has provided them with nutrition, education and health services.

headline: Struck by the Wish to Own
text: Alison Ehrmann lived in the quintessential brownstone on a quiet block on far West 100th Street. Her one-bedroom rental had high ceilings, exposed brick and a tiny kitchen. Her rent was $2,000 a month, just $200 more than when she moved in nine years ago. “I had great landlords, and they really valued good tenants,” she said.

headline: Risk to Food Safety Seen in Furloughs
text: WASHINGTON — The government shutdown is endangering what America eats, food safety experts said this week, as all inspections of domestic food except meat and poultry have halted and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recalled furloughed workers to handle a salmonella outbreak that sickened hundreds of people in 18 states.

headline: A Winner, to Get You There
text: I was a bit disappointed when I saw that  Citymapper had won the 2013 Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s App Quest competition when the results came out a couple of weeks back. Judging by its name, I figured it was just another piece of utilitarian software to help people figure out the city. I was hoping that the winner of the competition, held for apps that complement the transit experience, would be imaginative, like the runner-up, Subculture.FM. Not something so brusque, so practical, so obvious as a map.

headline: Giants (0-5) at Bears (3-2)
text: Thursday, 8:25 p.m.

headline: A Russian Region Neither at War Nor at Peace, but Facing a Crackdown
text: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — The race lasted only a few seconds and ended with the sound of a gunshot. Shamil Abdulayev, who was 24 years old at the time, had tried to run away from a group of men he knew were bent on abducting him. They wore ski masks and traveled in a white Lada sedan with tinted windows.

headline: Real Estate Boom in Phoenix Brings Its Own Problems
text: PHOENIX — Here, where the housing market endured one of the hardest crashes anywhere during the recession, the rebound has come faster than in most parts of the country, fueled by a vigorous job market, a sturdy rise in home values and an all-around sense that the worst of times is in the distant past.

headline: Future Look of City’s Cab Fleet Uncertain
text: If there is a heaven for iconic taxicabs, with a sneering Travis Bickle at the pearly gates, New York City is almost certainly its top feeder market.

headline: California Expands Availability of Abortions
text: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday expanded access to abortion in California, signing a bill to allow nurse practitioners, midwives and physician assistants to perform a common type of the procedure, an aspiration abortion, during the first trimester.

headline: Blitzer Causes Stir With Comments on Health Care
text: The CNN anchor Wolf Blitzer put himself into the middle of the political warfare over the Affordable Care Act onWednesday when he said on the air that the Obama administration should “accept the advice that a lot of Republicans are giving them” and delay the start of the program for a year.

headline: Government Standoff Shakes Trust in U.S. Debt
text: In good times and bad, the world’s financial system has long been able to rely on one thing: that the United States government would pay back its debt on time.

headline: Researchers Press for Broad Ban on Hockey Fights
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Researchers at a Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey called Wednesday for a ban on fighting at all levels of the sport, eight days after a Montreal Canadiens enforcer was hospitalized because of a fight on opening night of the N.H.L. season.

headline: The Yellen Fed? Precise and Predictable
text: There are no fast rules for running the Federal Reserve, but Janet L. Yellen has a few.

headline: A Cupboard of My Own
text: BIRMINGHAM, England — At the start of the 1960s, my parents bought a corner shop and moved into the house above it with their five children. Ten years later, I, the accidental sixth, was born. By the time I was 9, my brother and sisters had grown up and either temporarily or permanently moved out, leaving behind them a museum of abandoned items. Cluttering every shelf and corner were forgotten cardigans, orphaned dolls, discarded purses and grayscale strips of pouting photo-booth faces.

headline: In a Polluted Stream, a Pathway to Peace
text: MORRO BAY, Calif. — PEACE talks are under way again in Jerusalem. If the past is any guide, the two sides are stymied over difficult issues like settlements and borders. The negotiators badly need a new approach, and one is right beneath their feet, in the Kidron Valley, the deep ravine that runs from the Old City through the West Bank toward the Dead Sea.

headline: First, the Good News
text: Good news: The people who track killer asteroids for NASA are still on the case, despite the government shutdown.

headline: Gang of 40
text: In the 1970s, in its days of hard-line Communist isolation, China was ruled by the extremist “Gang of Four.” Drivers then were sometimes encouraged to proceed at red lights because red was the revolutionary color signifying advance — resulting in a chaos that was emblematic of the times.

headline: Protecting the Speech We Hate
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — SHOULD one-on-one advice and counseling be protected as free speech? It sounds like a no-brainer. Of course it should be. But a recent decision by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit says otherwise.

headline: For America, Life Was Cheap in Vietnam
text: OBITUARIES of Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese general who helped drive the American military from his country, noted, as The New York Times put it, that “his critics said that his victories had been rooted in a profligate disregard for the lives of his soldiers.”

headline: Does Literary Fiction Teach Empathy?
Netanyahu and Iran’s Leaders: A Look at the Record
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bob Costas, on Baseball
text: To the Editor:

headline: Uncivil Political Discourse
text: To the Editor:

headline: Displaced at Fukushima
text: To the Editor:

headline: Public Aid to Farms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Four Square Blocks: Philadelphia
text: Once home to Benjamin Franklin and Betsy Ross, Philadelphia’s Old City now hosts an assortment of design and fashion boutiques.

headline: As Drilling Practice Takes Off in U.S., Europe Proves Hesitant
text: LONDON — France and Bulgaria have already banned it, and in Britain the government’s attempts to promote it have led to heated demonstrations in the countryside. It is complicating Germany’s attempts to wean itself from fossil fuels and forcing Russia to recalibrate the energy-export strategy that sustains its economy.

headline: Charges Upgraded Against Police Detective in Motorcyclists’ Attack on S.U.V.
text: Prosecutors on Wednesday upgraded the charges against an undercover New York City police detective, saying he terrorized a family when he punched and kicked their sport utility vehicle as a group of motorcyclists he was with assaulted the driver after chasing the vehicle down.

headline: Chairwoman Janet Yellen
text: President Obama was wise to nominate Janet Yellen, vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, to be the Fed’s next leader. As a deeply respected economist, she will bring two vital attributes to that role as a steward of the economy.

headline: Cory Booker for the U.S. Senate in New Jersey
text: On Wednesday, New Jersey voters will go to the polls to choose a United States senator, replacing the late Frank Lautenberg. Mayor Cory Booker of Newark, a moderate Democrat, is running against an extremely conservative Republican, Steven Lonegan. Mr. Booker is far and away the better candidate to serve the needs of his entire state and to provide a national voice for the less fortunate across America.

headline: Monitoring Your Every Move

headline: Ex-Director of Charity Is Charged in Theft

headline: In Dugout, a Grinder Who Never Gave In
text: ST. LOUIS — Jeff Banister sat alone in the Pirates’ dugout after batting practice Monday in Pittsburgh. He is always at home there, in the hours before a game, basking in the silence and the scenery of a life he was never supposed to live.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: All the Time
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Jeffrey Wechsler is slowly establishing himself as a midweek constructor, and today he has a very timely puzzle for us in the sense that it deals with the days of the week. More specifically, it’s a representation of how people recorded their appointments prior to the invention of smartphones. (Yes, I know there are some people out there who don’t own smartphones. Please don’t send angry e-mails.)

headline: Business Groups See Loss of Sway Over House G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — As the government shutdown grinds toward a potential debt default, some of the country’s most influential business executives have come to a conclusion all but unthinkable a few years ago: Their voices are carrying little weight with the House majority that their millions of dollars in campaign contributions helped build and sustain.

headline: Friends, Romans, Countrywomen
text: A woman’s touch has not softened the hard and mighty “Julius Caesar.” On the contrary, the gripping, all-female, London-born production that opened on Wednesday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn has a muscular strength and ferocity guaranteed to keep everyone in the theater in sustained fight-or-flight mode.

headline: A Novel Prompts a Conversation About How We Use Technology
text: Has Dave Eggers written a parable of our time, an eviscerating takedown of Silicon Valley and its privacy-invading technology companies?

headline: Partly by Shunning Documentary, ESPN Lifts It
text: In August, ESPN pulled its name and logo from “League of Denial,” a “Frontline” documentary about how the N.F.L. handled — or, more appropriately, mishandled — the concussion crisis among its players. ESPN’s decision came seven weeks before the documentary was scheduled to run and ended a 15-month collaboration with “Frontline” that had already produced nine separate reports.

headline: Searching for the Father of ‘Baby Hope’
text: The detectives searching for Baby Hope’s killer have been tracking down her father’s relatives for about a week and are hopeful the family members can provide more leads, a person with knowledge of the matter said Wednesday.

headline: Extremist Group Gains Foothold Among Kenyans
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — When the United States tried to capture a powerful militant in Somalia last weekend, it did not go after the leader of the Shabab extremist group, but a Kenyan national whose ties were as much in his native country as in the Horn of Africa.

headline: Paul Desmarais, Canadian Magnate, Dies at 86
text: Paul Desmarais, who transformed a bankrupt bus line in a Canadian mining center into an international conglomerate with $527 billion in assets and, in the process, became one of his country’s most powerful businessmen, died on Tuesday at his country estate in the Charlevoix region of Quebec. He was 86.

headline: The Treasury’s Dwindling Cash Supply
text: Since May, the Treasury has been employing a set of “extraordinary measures,” to free up cash to pay its bills. Once these measures are exhausted, the Treasury will have to rely on revenues and its cash on hand until they are also exhausted.

headline: Tracing the Calendar Down to the Last Cent
text: WASHINGTON — Oct. 17 is the day the Treasury Department expects to exhaust its so-called extraordinary measures to keep paying the country’s bills, putting it on the precipice of default. But officials in Washington and traders on Wall Street have a second, yet more dire deadline in mind: Nov. 1.

headline: Shumpert Looks Sharp in Bid as Shooting Guard
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — There was intrigue on the court, if not exactly tightrope theatrics.

headline: Fairness an Issue, Even After Azerbaijan Votes
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — The slogan of Jamil Hasanli’s long-shot campaign to unseat Azerbaijan’s longtime president, Ilham Aliyev, in elections on Wednesday was “Enough!” Or, more specifically, as the red and white stickers plastered all over his headquarters and around this capital city made clear: enough corruption, enough monarchy, enough unemployment, enough stolen oil money, enough low-quality education and health services, enough disrespectful officials, and enough war over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh.

headline: More Malala Malaise
text: LONDON — This is a big week for Malala Yousafzai. It has been exactly a year since the Pakistani Taliban tried to assassinate her for championing education for girls. On Tuesday her memoir was released worldwide. And she is a favorite for this year’s Nobel Peace Prize, which is to be announced Friday.

headline: Peacekeeping by U.N. Faces New Scrutiny on 2 Fronts
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations was hit with a double dose of scrutiny over its accountability practices on Wednesday, charged in a lawsuit with gross negligence in Haiti’s deadly cholera epidemic, and accused by an anticorruption organization of oversight lapses in its own peacekeeping operations around the world.

headline: Week 6 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
text: The Denver Broncos are on their way to breaking records this season, having scored 230 points in five games. That’s 51 percent more points than the second-highest-scoring team and over twice as many points as the average N.F.L. team.

headline: Israel: Soldier Hurt by Mortar Shells From Syria
text: An Israeli soldier was lightly wounded by shrapnel on Wednesday when two mortar shells fired from Syria hit a military post in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights. A spokeswoman for the Israeli military said the strike was probably the result of errant fire, given the heightened fighting between Syrian government forces and rebels across the frontier in recent days. There have been numerous instances of fire from the Syrian civil war spilling into the Israeli-held territory, but injuries on the Israeli side have been rare.

headline: Japan: Workers Doused With Radioactive Water
text: Six workers at Japan’s wrecked Fukushima nuclear plant were sprayed with highly radioactive water on Wednesday after they accidentally disconnected a pipe in the reactors’ makeshift cooling system, the plant’s operator said. The operator, Tokyo Electric Power Company, or Tepco, said the workers took off their protective clothing after the incident and showered, and that there was no apparent risk to their health. Tepco said about 10 tons of tainted water also spilled onto the ground, though it was prevented from reaching the sea.

headline: Chinese Leader ‘Concerned’ About Debt Ceiling Issue
text: HONG KONG – In his meeting Wednesday night with Secretary of State John Kerry, Li Keqiang, China’s prime minister, raised the issue of Congress’s failure to extend the debt limit, underscoring Chinese concerns about the trillion dollars of U.S. government debt Beijing holds.

headline: Christian Conservatives to Meet Cruz and Rand Paul
text: A group of longtime Christian conservative activists are holding a private meeting Thursday in Washington to hear informal presentations from two of the most talked-about potential Republican presidential candidates: Senators Ted Cruz of Texas, and Rand Paul of Kentucky.

headline: The Big-Bank Subsidy
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Fat and Thin Find Common Ground

headline: Cardinals’ Wainwright Cuts Down Upstart Pirates
text: ST. LOUIS — When it was over — the decades of losing, the revival of a proud baseball town, the exhilarating playoff run — the Pittsburgh Pirates’ best player found a simple reason to be satisfied.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (Fox) GLEE The show bids farewell to its onetime star quarterback, Finn Hudson, portrayed by Cory Monteith, left, who died July 13. The playlist includes “Season of Love,” “I’ll Stand by You,” “Fire and Rain,” “If I Die Young,” “The Surrender” and “Make You Feel My Love,” performed by Lea Michele, Mr. Monteith’s on- and off-screen girlfriend.

headline: Yo-Yo Ma and the Mind Game of Music
text: Yo-Yo Ma began playing the cello at the age of 4. Now 57, he has received numerous Grammy Awards, the National Medal of Arts and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. In 1998 Mr. Ma founded the Silk Road Project, a nonprofit organization that brings together musicians from around the world. Last month, Sony Masterworks released his Silk Road Ensemble’s “Playlist Without Borders” CD and “Live From Tanglewood” concert DVD. Mr. Ma recently called from his home in Cambridge, Mass. A condensed and edited version of our conversation follows:

headline: Show of Power by Libya Militia in Kidnapping
text: TUNIS — Libya’s prime minister, Ali Zeidan, was hauled from his bed at 2:30 a.m. Thursday by a group of militiamen who stormed into the luxury hotel where he lives in downtown Tripoli, a kidnapping that would be extraordinary by almost any standard.

headline: Snowden’s Father Arrives in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — After fleeing his home in Hawaii for Hong Kong, then spending a month as resident of an airport transit zone in Moscow before winning temporary asylum in Russia, Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American intelligence contractor, is getting a visit from his father.

headline: Airbus Predicts Growth in Air Cargo Market
text: HONG KONG — The air cargo market is showing signs of life after years of pain following the global financial crisis, senior executives of the European plane maker Airbus said in a news media briefing on Thursday. The officials forecast solid growth powered by demand for freighters from emerging markets over the next 20 years.

headline: What Does Your Hairstyle Say About You?
text: You might wear it long, straight, curly or braided. Maybe you obsess over it every morning — blow drying, brushing, combing or gelling. Or perhaps you sport a crew cut and don’t worry much at all. No matter how we wear it, our hair can be an important way in which we express ourselves.

headline: Women on the Front Lines and Behind the Lens
text: Stephanie Sinclair has mostly happy memories of her childhood in Miami, where she grew up encouraged by her parents to be carefree, confident and defiant. It was there, in an elementary school broadcast arts program, that she requested to be a camera operator, offering the first inkling of what she would do with her life.

headline: Despite Climate Concern, Global Study Finds Fewer Carbon Capture Projects
text: WASHINGTON — The number of large-scale projects to capture and bury carbon dioxide has fallen to 65 from 75 over the last year, a worldwide survey has found, despite a consensus among scientists and engineers that such projects are essential to meet international goals for slowing the buildup of climate-changing gases.

headline: The Final Insult in the Bush-Cheney Marriage
text: In the final days of his presidency, George W. Bush sat behind his desk in the Oval Office, chewing gum and staring into the distance as two White House lawyers briefed him on the possible last-minute pardon of I. Lewis Libby.

text: Updated 12:03 p.m. | They looked at radar maps. They studied tree-fall patterns. They tallied eyewitness accounts.

headline: Sinking of Migrant Boat Off Italy Complicates Politics in Germany
