headline: Daily Report: Novel Prompts Reflections on Our Technological Lives
text: Book critics are divided over the quality of Dave Eggers’s highly anticipated novel “The Circle,” which went on sale Tuesday. Is it an eviscerating takedown of the tech industry? Or is it a sanctimonious screed that fails to understand its subject? But in Silicon Valley and beyond, the book’s theme promises to spark an even bigger debate over the 21st-century hyperconnected world that Mr. Eggers describes, Julie Bosman and Claire Cain Miller report.

headline: Alice Munro Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
text: Alice Munro, the renowned Canadian short-story writer whose visceral work explores the tangled relationships between men and women, small-town existence and the fallibility of memory, won the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday.

headline: North Korean Leader Tightens Grip With Removal of His Top General
text: SEOUL, South Korea — State news media on Thursday confirmed the removal of a hard-line general as North Korea’s military chief, the latest sign of an overhaul by the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who South Korean officials say has replaced nearly half of his top officials in the past two years.

headline: Britain Weighs Creating System to Reward Whistle-Blowers

headline: Bank of England Retains Low Interest Rate

headline: Experience as It Once Was
text: WORLITZ, Germany — I was going 115 miles per hour on a German autobahn when it occurred to me that one reason the German economy is doing so well is that people can get from one place to another so fast. With most of the rest of Europe confined to a limit of about 80 miles per hour, Germany has a clear competitive advantage.

headline: Pakistani Student Wins Top European Rights Award
text: LONDON — Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl who was shot in the head by the Taliban for her advocacy of girls’ education, was awarded the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought on Thursday by the European Parliament.

headline: Faith in U.S. Debt Is Rattled
text: The fiscal impasse in Congress has been testing investors’ confidence that the United States – considered the most reliable borrower in the world – will be able to pay back its debt on time, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Investors in recent days have shifted money out of the $1.7 trillion market for the short-term government debt known as Treasury bills. It now costs more for the United States to borrow money for a month than it does for the average highly rated American company to do so, Mr. Popper writes.

headline: Cities Report Better Finances, but Worries Persist
text: Fiscal conditions are slowly improving for American cities, aided by increases in sales tax and income tax revenue, but rapidly rising pension and health costs for city workers continue to pose a potentially crippling threat, according to an annual study released Thursday by the National League of Cities.

headline: Kwame M. Kilpatrick, Former Detroit Mayor, Sentenced to 28 Years in Corruption Case
text: DETROIT — Kwame M. Kilpatrick, the former mayor of Detroit, stood before a federal judge on Thursday and apologized for putting the people of his city through a corruption scandal so vast that prosecutors say it helped accelerate Detroit’s march toward bankruptcy.

text: The author of “Identical” ranted about Patti Smith’s National Book Award. Then he read her book — “a perfectly wrought account of what it means to give your life to art and to another person.”

text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and House Republicans failed to reach agreement on a six-week extension of the nation’s borrowing authority during a meeting Thursday at the White House, but the two sides kept talking, and the offer from politically besieged Republicans was seen as an initial step toward ending the budget standoff.

headline: Oil Spills Becoming Frequent Hazard for Fishermen Near Mumbai

He was looking for crabs, lobsters and prawns in the Arabian Sea to sell in Mumbai, which is almost 30 miles southwest from his village, Peerwadi.

headline: Automatic Destabilizers
text: The debt ceiling situation remains extremely foggy. Republican leaders seem, slowly, to be coming to the realization that Obama is serious about this business of not engaging in hostage negotiations — but they’re still trying to bargain (kill your main achievement? No? OK, how about killing Social Security instead?). Will they realize that this just isn’t going to work before the money runs out? Nobody knows.

headline: Following Up on Our Sales Training, Profit-Sharing, Health Insurance and the Shutdown
text: I usually pick one thing that has happened to me recently to write about, but the reality of life as a boss is that a typical day, week, or month consists of a series of unrelated events. They don’t always fit together into a neat narrative with a clear theme.

headline: T-Mobile Hands Consumers a Pleasant Shocker

headline: S.E.C. Won’t Pursue Action Against ‘Rebecca’ Producers
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to pursue any action against the Broadway producers of “Rebecca,” the Gothic musical that was derailed last fall before performances began because of a fraud scheme involving phantom investors.

text: In Brooklyn’s ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods, Mendel Epstein made a name for himself as the rabbi to see for women struggling to divorce their husbands. Among the Orthodox, a divorce requires the husband’s permission, known as a “get,” and tales abound of women whose husbands refuse to consent.

headline: Standoff on Debt Default Fails to Rattle Asia, Yet
text: HONG KONG — When the United States government was borrowing heavily four years ago to cover costs related to the global financial crisis, Wen Jiabao, then the prime minister of China, strongly and publicly warned Washington to make sure that Chinese investments in Treasury securities were safe.

headline: The Gun Report: October 10, 2013
text: Next week, Oakland, Calif., could be the only city in California with the right to make its own rules governing gun licensing and registration. A bill called AB180, sponsored by Assemblyman Rob Bonta, is on Gov. Jerry Brown’s desk. For the bill to become law, it must be signed by midnight on Sunday.

headline: Elephants Get the Point of Pointing, Study Shows
text: We point to things without giving much thought to what a sophisticated act it really is. By simply extending a finger, we can let other people know we want to draw their attention to an object, and indicate which object it is.

headline: The Expulsion of the Consuls
text: By Oct. 8, 1863, Britain had crossed the line — at least in the eyes of Judah P. Benjamin, the Confederate secretary of state. Benjamin’s frustration rang out loud and clear from a letter he wrote that day to Allan Fullarton, Britain’s acting consul in Savannah, Ga. Fullarton’s offense? Like other consuls, he was helping British subjects in the Confederacy avoid conscription, which Confederate officials were increasingly applying to citizens and noncitizens alike. Britain allowed that foreign-born men could be required to take part in emergency local defense but denied the Confederacy’s right to draft them into regular military service. But to Benjamin, every time a foreign consul took it upon himself to determine the reach of Confederate conscription, he made an unacceptable assault upon the Confederacy’s sovereignty.

headline: A Thriller Armed With Thought
text: “Captain Phillips,” a movie that insistently closes the distance between us and them, has a vital moral immediacy. It was directed by Paul Greengrass, the British filmmaker who quickened the pulse of contemporary action cinema with the second and third installments in the Bourne franchise, features that proved yet again that big-screen thrills and thought need not be mutually exclusive. Kinetic action and intelligence are similarly the driving forces in “Captain Phillips,” which, like Mr. Greengrass’s Bourne movies, shakes you up first with its style and then with its ideas.

headline: Jason Collins, Openly Gay and Still Unsigned, Waits and Wonders
text: LOS ANGELES — Since making the announcement last spring that he is a gay professional basketball player, Jason Collins has been widely praised, received much support and made many new friends. But with training camp for a new season under way, he has been waiting for a call from an N.B.A. team. Any N.B.A. team.

headline: Detroit Film Festival Will Focus on the City
text: Detroit may be ailing, but a new film festival there intends to give it a good dose of positive attention. The Freep Film Festival, presented by the Detroit Free Press and the Detroit Media Partnership, which manages the newspaper’s business operations, will screen around a dozen documentaries in four days, all of which focus on Detroit and its surrounding regions.

headline: Five Ways to Teach the Shutdown
text: Update: Oct. 17, 2013: Now that the shutdown is over, use our 6 Q’s About the News to answer questions about the results.

headline: The Many Front Pages of New York, Past and Present
text: You’re probably more likely to have read about it online than in print, but this is National Newspaper Week. And if you can’t take a reporter to lunch, at least pause and reflect on the fact that while New York remains that rare, robust daily newspaper town, that’s nothing compared to the choices available in the city a century ago.

headline: Jonas Brother Against Brother (Against Brother); Tour Canceled
text: The Jonas Brothers were to have played the first of 19 concerts in a North American tour on Friday in Upper Darby, Pa., but they may break up instead. At the very least, the tour, which was to include a concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan on Oct. 23, has been scuttled because of what the group’s spokesman, Jesse Derris, described to People magazine as “a deep rift within the band” and “a big disagreement over their musical direction.”

headline: G.O.P. Leaders on Debt Limit Increase
text: Republican members of the House announced their proposal for a short-term debt ceiling increase.

headline: Delaware Court Lifts Injunction on Activision Blizzard’s Deal With Vivendi
text: The Delaware Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously reversed a lower court ruling on Activision Blizzard‘s move to buy back most of Vivendi’s stake in the video game maker for $8.2 billion, letting the transaction move forward.

headline: Image of the Day: October 10
text: Children playing on the Marina beach in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: Nicholas Kristof brings some promising news from the developing world: Illiteracy and AIDS are receding, ancient diseases such as Guinea worm and polio are on the way out, and child mortality is dropping.

headline: Norwegian Investigated in Deadly Mall Siege in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Norwegian police said on Thursday that they were investigating whether a Norwegian citizen was involved in the deadly siege of the Westgate shopping mall here in late September.

headline: The Debt Ceiling and the Housing Bust
text: Suppose that we hit the debt ceiling, and that the Treasury manages to engage in “prioritization” — paying interest on bonds, so that all the burden falls on other kinds of spending. How should we think about the economic impact?

headline: Former Liu Associates Are Sentenced
text: Two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, managed to avoid lengthy prison sentences on Thursday for their roles in attempting to funnel money to Mr. Liu’s mayoral campaign through an illegal fund-raising scheme.

headline: After High Demand, Royal Mail Shares Are Priced at High End
text: Royal Mail, whose roots date back to the court of Henry VIII in the 16th century, is so deeply woven into the public fabric of Britain that even former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher did not push to sell it. Three attempts over the last two decades to privatize the postal service failed in the face of overwhelming objection.

headline: Mobile Banking Players Are Shaking Up China’s Cozy Oligopoly
text: The biggest threat to Chinese banks’ cozy oligopoly may be in the hands of the nation’s consumers. Two online companies, Alibaba and Tencent, are making incursions into the country’s financial services market, providing an alternative to the capped deposit rates and sluggish service offered by the country’s big lenders. The disrupters are taking on risks, and savers should be glad.

headline: Ghost Hunting
text: The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in Weston, West Virginia, rumored to be haunted, is the site of Saturday night ghost hunting tours.

headline: Getting Into the Spirit
text: Everyone has a ghost story, or at least that’s how it has always seemed to me. My mother’s best friend used to tell a doozy about a soldier she met when she was a bookkeeper in the Air Force. He claimed to be a ghost, then proved it by walking into the middle of a moonlit airfield and disappearing before her eyes. Another friend of my mother’s used to bring over a Ouija board when she baby-sat for me. As that plastic pointer whizzed around the board (with seemingly little help from her fingers), she spoke of the messages that the spirit world sent to her on a regular basis.

headline: 3rd Ward, Brooklyn Art and Design Space, to Close
text: Updated, Oct. 11 | 3rd Ward, the Brooklyn art, design and educational work space, where for seven years students and artisans have built wood furniture, learned about photography and pursued other creative endeavors, in Bushwick and at an outpost in Philadelphia, is closing, an owner, Jason Goodman, announced on Thursday.

headline: 2 Founders of BlackBerry Weighing a Takeover Offer
text: OTTAWA — The two men who founded the company that became BlackBerry may now try to save it.

headline: World Leaders Urge U.S. to End Its Debt Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — The exhortations have come from China, Singapore, Switzerland, Mexico, Japan and South Africa, from heads of government, bankers and business leaders: Raise your debt ceiling and reopen your government, for the good of the American economy and the world’s.

headline: Snowden’s Father Meets the Press in Moscow
text: As my colleague Andrew Roth reports, Lon Snowden, the father of the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, arrived in Moscow on Thursday to visit his son, and was met at the airport by a scrum of Russian journalists, including camera crews from the main state television channel and the government’s English-language network, RT.

headline: Wheelies: The J.F.K. Lincoln Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Suit Revives Goldman Conflict Issue
text: At a March 2012 meeting, a group of examiners at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York agreed that Goldman Sachs had inadequate procedures to guard against conflicts of interest — guidelines aimed at stopping firms from putting their pursuit of profit ahead of their clients’ best interests.

headline: Video of the Libyan Prime Minister Speaking After His Release
text: The Libyan government released video footage showing the prime minister, Ali Zeidan, speaking to fellow cabinet members and officials after his release on Thursday from a kidnapping that took place before dawn at a hotel in the capital, Tripoli.

headline: Koons Work to Be Auctioned for Brooklyn School
text: Benefit auctions for scrappy public schools in New York sometimes feature an item or two – a designer handbag, lunch with a minor celebrity – arranged by parents with connections. But when a list of art works was circulated recently among parents for an Oct. 23 auction to benefit P.S. 130, a school in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn serving a significant number of students from poor families, one art donor’s name fairly leapt off the page: Jeff Koons.

headline: U.N. Backs Peace Effort for Central African Republic
text: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved a resolution on Thursday aimed at stabilizing the Central African Republic, a dangerous and dysfunctional country that has descended into near-total chaos over the last half year.

headline: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts
text: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm find natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

headline: For Silicon Valley Novels, Blurring Fiction and Nonfiction
text: Mark Twain once said: “It’s no wonder that truth is stranger than fiction. Fiction has to make sense.” It seems that Dave Eggers has people questioning which of those two types of storytelling he wrote about in his new book, “The Circle.”

headline: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Running Backs
text: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

headline: Modern Love | Lost and Found
text: A 17-year-old girl, put up for adoption at birth, finds her biological mother on Facebook.

headline: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Wide Receivers
text: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

headline: A Husband Lost, a Daughter Found
text: Four years ago, when people asked if I was married or had children, my answers were easy: “Yes” to the first and “no” to the second, because my husband was alive and the newborn I had placed in an open adoption when I was a teenager hadn’t yet found me on Facebook.

headline: Scott Carpenter, One of the Original Seven Astronauts, Is Dead at 88
text: M. Scott Carpenter, whose flight into space in 1962 as the second American to orbit the Earth was marred by technical problems and ended with the nation waiting anxiously to see if he had survived a landing far from the target site, died on Thursday in Denver. He was 88 and one of the last two surviving astronauts of America’s original space program, Project Mercury.

headline: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Tight Ends
text: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

headline: Antitrust Fine for Supplier of Seat Belts
text: A Japanese seat belt supplier said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay a $71.3 million fine to settle antitrust charges, less than a month after one of its executives was sentenced to prison for fixing the price of auto parts sold in the United States and abroad.

headline: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Kickers
text: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

headline: Safety Agency Cites Texas Plant in Explosion
text: The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited the owners of a fertilizer plant in West, Tex., that blew up in April, killing 15 people, with 24 “serious violations,” Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, said on Thursday. But the agency has not announced the action because its public affairs staff has been furloughed by the government shutdown, Ms. Boxer said.

headline: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Team Defenses and Special Teams
text: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

headline: Market Report | Warming Up Cold-Weather Looks With Houndstooth
text: Nothing says cold-weather dressing quite like houndstooth, and the classic broken-check Scottish pattern is everywhere you look right now. Mulberry made the already bold style even more so by introducing a pop of red in a statement wool coat. Roger Vivier printed differently sized squares of it onto a pair of calf hair booties that will liven up any outfit. And Thom Browne, Tommy Hilfiger and Azzurra have also incorporated the time-tested pattern into clothing and accessories.

headline: After Injury, Craig Bierko Takes Leave from Broadway’s ‘Matilda’
text: Craig Bierko, the Tony Award-nominated stage and film actor who recently joined the Broadway cast of “Matilda the Musical” as the villainous Miss Trunchbull, has taken a leave from the production following an injury.

headline: A Sleeping Giant in African Soccer Is Starting to Stir
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Less than a week before the most important match in its history, Ethiopia’s national soccer team trained on a wet, uneven field on the outskirts of the capital. Nearby, a woman hung her wash on a clothesline. Birds of prey circled overhead, and sometimes a plane flew past at low altitude, coming from the capital’s busy airport, which a few months ago added a connection to Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Umami Burger
text: Inside the burger chain’s new restaurant in Greenwich Village.

headline: The Meat Is Only the Start
text: Umami is sometimes defined as the flavor beyond all flavors, the flavor that cannot be described, but my waitress at Umami Burger in Greenwich Village has no time for such reveries.

headline: Jeff Fluhr of Spreecast, on Finding Employees Who Fit
text: This interview with Jeff Fluhr, chief executive of Spreecast, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Living With Cancer: Hospital City
text: When you travel to cancer central, you may find yourself more perplexed by the currency, language, customs, costumes, cuisine and time zone than you would have been if you had landed in Timbuktu. In Hospital City, you can lose your way as well as your confidence in everything you took for granted.

headline: Growing Up With a Disabled Sibling
text: “Mom, when are you going to write a book about me?” my 7-year-old son, Noah, asked as we sat on the floor of his room, surrounded by packing materials from the box that had arrived earlier that day. Inside were copies of my new book, each with a picture of me holding Noah’s brother, Henry, on the cover. Henry has Down syndrome, and the book is about the first three years of his life. Noah had come home to find Henry admiring it while I danced around taking photos for our Facebook page. Noah stood by watching the commotion patiently enough. He understood that Henry was having his turn. He just wanted to know whether the next book would be about him.

headline: Crawford Rediscovers Himself With Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — Of all the indicators suggesting the return to form of Carl Crawford, a player once thought to be worth $142 million, the biggest was not the three home runs he hit in the last two playoff games for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the diving catch he made over the railing near the left-field stands or a comfortably stolen base.

headline: MARKET REPORT
text: Spruce up cold-weather dressing with a little something inspired by the bold, classic men’s-wear pattern.

headline: From 'Weeds' To Broadway
text: Returning to Broadway after a long, successful run in Hollywood, Mary Louise Parker is set to take the leading role in the play “The Snow Geese.”

headline: Stage Scenes: Mary-Louise Parker
text: A look at some of the actress’s past stage performances.

headline: Never Neutral, and Proud of It
text: As her Showtime series “Weeds” was nearing its eighth and final season last year, Mary-Louise Parker kept haranguing her agents to send new plays her way. But while she was itchy to find a vehicle back to her first love, theater, a part of her also felt that she would never act onstage again.

headline: In Uganda, a Chance to Work With Gorilla Researchers
text: In addition to staring in awe at a rare African species, safari-goers can give an assist to science by working with gorilla researchers. Uganda-based Premier Safaris has partnered with the renowned gorilla expert Dr. Gladys Kalema-Zikusoka to offer research-focused itineraries to see mountain gorillas in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park.

headline: When Bird Was a Fledgling
text: The ideal way to ingest Stanley Crouch’s new book is probably on audio, late at night, while driving between the major cities of the Midwest, your headlights pushing past truck stops and dying cornfields. You’ve got to be willing to submit to the spell Mr. Crouch is working to cast.

headline: Danish Art’s Subtler Sides at Scandinavia House
text: The Miser has a soft spot — if you can call it that — for Denmark’s arch-brooders. Given their outsize influence on contemporary culture, you might be tempted to associate the likes of Kierkegaard and Lars von Trier with a distinctly Danish sensibility. But the Danish contribution to Western art isn’t limited to histrionic bursts of angst, irony and the absurd. “Danish Paintings From the Golden Age to the Modern Breakthrough,” an exhibition opening this weekend at Scandinavia House, brings together a selection of masterpieces from the late 18th to the 20th centuries that make use of subtler, more austere aesthetics.

headline: A Turnabout From Manga to Zen
text: It’s been a full decade since Mariko Mori’s last New York museum show, and viewers who remember that exhibition might not even recognize the artist in “Rebirth: Recent Work by Mariko Mori,” at Japan Society. The futuristic fashion plate of Ms. Mori’s earlier photographs and videos — the artist herself, in Manga-inspired get-ups — seems to have vanished, and so has her contemporary Japanese landscape of malls, airports and business districts.

headline: Holding Court in All Their Petaled Glory
text: THE stately chrysanthemum, one of nature’s noblest flowers, harbors a dark secret. It enjoys pain.

headline: Bjarne Melgaard: ‘Ignorant Transparencies’
text: Gavin Brown’s Enterprise

headline: Weeklong Search Continues for a Boy With Autism
text: It has been a week since Avonte Oquendo, a 14-year-old from Queens, was last seen, captured on surveillance video darting down the hallway of his school and then running out onto the street in Long Island City.

headline: Josh Smith
text: Luhring Augustine Gallery

headline: Whoa, Are Snow White and Mulan Really Working the Street?
text: Jim (Roy Abramsohn) is a doughy dad on a Disney vacation with a pair of cute towheaded kids and a nagging wife (Elena Schuber). Shortly after Jim receives an unwelcome call from his boss — firing him without warning or explanation — things turn weird. The theme park that promises magic for the masses takes on a decidedly sinister cast. Is it all in Jim’s head, or does evil stalk the happiest place on earth?

headline: Edmund de Waal: ‘Atemwende’
text: Gagosian Gallery

headline: Kunié Sugiura: ‘Photographic Collages: 1977-1981’
text: Leslie Tonkonow Artworks + Projects

headline: ‘Death of a Cameraman’
text: Apexart

headline: Are Disasters Lurking in European Banks? Who Knows?
text: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, gave a generally upbeat speech on Thursday. “We have seen much progress in the banking sector of the euro area,” he told the Economics Club of New York.

headline: Judge Says New Jersey Can Begin Allowing Same-Sex Marriages in Two Weeks
text: A judge on Thursday cleared the way for same-sex marriages to start in New Jersey in two weeks, dismissing the state’s request to prevent the weddings until after an appeal of the court decision allowing them is completed.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Northern Ireland, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Toughing It Out, Against All Odds
text: There are times in “The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete” when the emotions it stirs up are so naked and unembarrassed that it feels as if you’ve entered a cinematic time machine back to the silent era, to when child actors like Jackie Coogan gutted you with sentiment. Coogan played the title character in Charles Chaplin’s glorious 1921 weepie “The Kid,” the urchin with the tight grip around the Tramp’s neck and lock on the audience’s affections. The heartbreakers in “Mister & Pete,” a melodrama about two children slipping through the cracks, shed fewer tears than the Kid did — poverty can toughen even the most tender bodies — but their hold on you is as fierce.

headline: Sally Field, Ken Burns and Philip Roth Honored by Scholarly Society
text: Updated, 11:02 a.m. Friday | Last year, Sally Field won an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Mary Todd Lincoln. This weekend, she’ll be making a turn as another first lady, Abigail Adams.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: Two generations of one of England’s most celebrated families — Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant — make beautiful, unusual and deeply personal art that draws from the natural world.

headline: Lamentation for a Home of Punk Rock
text: Because of the cruel accidents of age and geography, I never set foot in CBGB during its 1970s punk heyday. So I can’t look at “CBGB” — Randall Miller’s sweet and nostalgic elegy to that defunct club and its owner and presiding spirit, Hillel Kristal, known to all, whether they actually knew him or not, as Hilly — and say, with the authority of experience, “It wasn’t like that.” I will leave it to others to point out the film’s lapses of chronology, taste and historical detail. But on the other hand, I would swear on a stack of Dead Boys T-shirts and a first pressing of Richard Hell and the Voidoids’ “Blank Generation” that it could not possibly have been like that: so silly, so trivial, so boring.

headline: Mixing and Matching Many Tastes of Japan
text: Takahiro Okada, a manager of the TriBeCa bar Shigure, said there were two ways customers could enjoy the distilled spirit shochu, a specialty of the house.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: Winter Weather Advisory

headline: Turning Advanced Statistics Into Fantasy Football Analysis
text: What can machine learning and statistics do for fantasy football? It turns out, quite a bit.

headline: Why Alice Munro Is Canada’s First Nobel Prize Winner for Literature (With an Asterisk)
text: Alice Munro, the Canadian writer who’s widely acknowledged as the greatest living short-story writer (and, according to Jonathan Franzen, the best living North American fiction writer, period), was named the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature this morning.

headline: For Finger Lakes Rieslings, Smashed Potatoes Inspired by Costata
text: On my first visit to Costata, Michael White’s SoHo steakhouse, I was bowled over by the crisp, deeply burnished smashed potatoes. I got the recipe, and then I waited for a wine inspiration. Of course, with a robust bottle of red and a slab of grilled meat, I’d have been done with it. But I wanted to give the potatoes marquee billing.

headline: A Life Ravels Out, and a Brooding Family Sets Forth
text: William Faulkner’s novel “As I Lay Dying,” published in 1930, is about a family hauling the dead body of one of its members on a journey of several days over rough terrain in a mule-drawn cart. That might be one definition of a fool’s errand, the primary fool being Anse Bundren, a stubborn, suspicious and toothless Mississippi farmer who insists on burying his wife, Addie, in her hometown. Another definition might be the attempt to turn Faulkner’s splintered, lyrical book into a movie. In this case the fool would be James Franco, who directed and stars in the first film adaptation of a book that has long been considered unfilmable.

headline: Janet Joy
text: I’ve been remiss in not writing anything about Janet Yellen’s nomination to head the Fed; partly that was because I wasn’t sure exactly what to say, and how to explain why I and so many other economists are really happy with her selection.

headline: In New Case, Former Leader of Pakistan Is Arrested
text: LONDON — The Pakistani police arrested Pervez Musharraf, the nation’s former military ruler, on Thursday, opening a new criminal prosecution against him that frustrated plans by his supporters to fly him out of Pakistan.

headline: Peering Past New York’s Locked Doors
text: THE New York fall cultural calendar is a busy one. The fashion world has September all sewn up, and between auctions and openings, the art world has November all nailed down. The holidays hold December hostage. That leaves October.

headline: Jilted, and Communing With a Serial-Killing Cannibal
text: There are probably a good number of you out there who would never see a play that trades on the portrayal of a creepily charming Jeffrey Dahmer character. Who can say if this number is higher or lower than the number of you who would be persuaded to attend for precisely that same reason?

headline: Oh, Hey, Romeo, What’s Up?
text: Passions and nostrils flare in the latest screen version of “Romeo & Juliet,” a sufficiently entertaining, adamantly old-fashioned adaptation that follows the play’s general outline without ever rising to the passionate intensity of its star-cross’d crazy kids. Adapted by Julian Fellowes, who’s taken liberties with the original text, and dutifully directed by Carlo Carlei, it deploys the familiar emotional beats — if not all the lines — along with the usual mixture of comedy, romance and tragedy. Shot in the actual Verona and at other Italian attractions, it looks pretty, feels light and moves fast, with a 118-minute running time that’s in keeping with the original’s “two hours’ traffic of our stage.”

headline: Taking Off to Find Yourself? Be Sure a Self Is There
text: Those of us who have rolled our eyes at the narcissistic entitlement of millennials  — come on, you know you’ve done it — are gently scolded in Mike Lew’s bumpy road comedy, “Bike America,” for failing to recognize the genuine desperation beneath their whiny self-absorption.

headline: Strong Start for ‘American Horror Story’
text: Cable television demonstrated again Wednesday night that it can produce powerhouse drama that can match or exceed anything on network television – the latest example being the new season of the FX drama “American Horror Story.”

headline: All He’s Got to Do Is Save the World
text: Until your eyes glaze over after about a half-hour, “Machete Kills” might put a twisted smirk of guilty amusement on your face. The high point of those opening minutes is a fantastically gaudy fake trailer for a sequel, “Machete Kills Again ... In Space,” which embodies the director Robert Rodriguez’s nostalgia for trashy B-movie exploitation flicks.

headline: Reliving the Show That ‘Dropped Like a Bomb’
text: The International Exhibition of Modern Art, otherwise known as the Armory Show, woke American art from its provincial slumbers 100 years ago. Was it a good thing or a bad thing, and is there any reason to care about it now? With more than 100 works from the original exhibition and a big, richly illuminating catalog, “The Armory Show at 100: Modern Art and Revolution” at the New-York Historical Society offers an excellent opportunity to ponder such questions.

headline: A Room Is Tense as African Rhythms Meet Jazz
text: Behind the drums at Iridium on Wednesday night, Ginger Baker leaned back, his chin drawn in toward his Adam’s apple, holding his sticks toward the bottom, his time as far back as his posture, head fixed within a narrow swiveling perimeter, wide eyes on amber alert.

headline: 2013 Carnegie International
text: Images from the exhibition at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh.

headline: Global Extravaganza, but on a Human Scale
text: PITTSBURGH — The 2013 Carnegie International is a welcome shock to the system of one of the art world’s more entrenched rituals. This lean, seemingly modest, thought-out exhibition takes the big global survey of contemporary art off steroids.

headline: Josh Sapan’s ‘Big Picture,’ on Group Photos as Collectibles
text: OUT OF STORAGE,

headline: BBC and Discovery Cut Back on Collaborations
text: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s and delivered natural history programs like “Blue Planet,” “Planet Earth” and “Life” to American viewers. Some of the BBC’s wildlife documentaries and films will be co-produced by its cable channel BBC America instead of Discovery in the future, the British broadcaster said Wednesday. Discovery will continue to work with the BBC on some programs, but will also strike deals with other producers for science and natural history programs. The two collaborators have become more like competitors over the years. Discovery is increasingly an international brand, and it wants to have worldwide rights to its programming; meanwhile, the BBC wants to bolster its own branded channel in America. The two companies said they had mutually agreed to go their separate ways.

headline: Mixed Up Quote
text: Happy 11/11, everyone! I’ll be filling in on the blog again this week, playing SIDE B to Deb Amlen while she’s off on vacation.

headline: Airline Extras at a Package Rate
text: Are airlines taking a cue from magazines, Netflix, even Internet and cable packages?

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: clinical trials, the Nobel prize and noisy airports. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Starting a Vapor Trail
text: I was recently at a dinner party at a friend’s house. In the middle of the meal, a young woman pulled out an electronic cigarette, took two puffs, then put it away. A few guests clearly wondered about the white smoke she exhaled. Shouldn’t people excuse themselves to indulge their addictions in private? This bothered me because she was among friends and shouldn’t have needed the security mechanism of a cigarette. What do you make of this?

headline: ‘A Fantastic Journey’
text: Images from the Wangechi Mutu show at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: A Window, Not a Mirror
text: How much does the cash-drunk New York art industry care about racism, neocolonialism, wanton consumption, persistent sexism, environmental spoilage or any other global realities? Next to not at all. How much does the same industry care about big, superbly made objects that pleasure the eye? Hugely.

headline: Paper Gallery: Mirth, Mayhem, Manga and More
text: Readers who lack tickets to this weekend’s New York Comic Con gathering may want to savor some hard-bound alternatives. Here’s a sampling.

headline: State Agency Appeals After Judge Calls Air a Natural Resource
text: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality is appealing a lawsuit that it has already won — one that was filed by children. Environmental advocates say the appeal shows that the state will go to any lengths to fight the suggestion that it address climate change.

headline: In the Finger Lakes, Devotion to Riesling Shows
text: I’ve consumed rieslings from all over the United States. Smith-Madrone, Trefethen and Stony Hill make fine rieslings in Napa Valley, but these are legacy vines.

headline: Democracy Is Instrumental to a Maestro-Free Ensemble
text: What the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which opened its 41st season on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, has always done best is to reanimate war horses. The concentration, intensity and hair-trigger responsiveness it takes for 35 or 40 musicians to play without a conductor can translate into excitement and volatility, as it did here in Beethoven’s “Eroica” Symphony.

headline: The Melancholy Effects of Growing Older in Gay Culture
text: The current reconstruction of Miguel Gutierrez’s “myendlesslove,” which opened on Wednesday at the Abrons Arts Center at Henry Street Settlement, dates to 2006, when the original piece received its first and last performance. But its roots are actually older. In 2005, Mr. Gutierrez choreographed “Retrospective Exhibitionist,” a piercing solo that explored the plight of a performer with fearlessness, innocence and humor. It was raw in a way that only New Yorkers can pull off; his tools, other than his own body, included a television and a boom box.

headline: A Photographer With Problems
text: There’s a moment when the thriller “Forgetting the Girl” leaves behind the twitches of its characters’ psychological troubles and moves headlong into the full-bodied shivers. Directed with unerring atmospherics by Nate Taylor, this dark tale — in which Jungian shadows eventually get their close-ups — reminds us of a simple truth: Some people are flat messed up.

text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Libidinous Specters in the House
text: The “Paranormal Activity” concept spawns yet another comic variation (after “A Haunted House” and “Scary Movie V”) with “Ghost Team One,” a rude and somewhat crude effort in which typewriter-font intertitles, a mobile camera and staccato surveillance video intersect with a stream of slacker potty talk. A drunken Sergio (Carlos Santos) is lurching around a boisterous house party he’s hosting with his sex-obsessed roommate Brad (J. R. Villarreal) when he stumbles upon what seem to be spectral lovers canoodling in a closet. Their house, it turns out, might be haunted by a long-dead brothel madam. An investigation kicks into high gear after Brad inadvertently copulates with a ghostly visitor.

headline: What I Love | William Wegman
text: The artist and author William Wegman lives and works in Chelsea with his family and quartet of Weimaraners.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Oct. 11-17
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: GTT ★
text: DALLAS

headline: Dance Listings for Oct. 11-17
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Flights of Fancy
text: Let us consider the problems of the long novel, in which the heft is apt to come in for almost as much critical examination as the content. There is, for instance, Jack Beatty’s famous critique of James A. Michener’s “Chesapeake” (865 pages): “My best advice is don’t read it; my second best is don’t drop it on your foot.” Presumably, Beatty read it — or at least skimmed it — before offering these helpful hints, but you get the idea. In this hurry-scurry age, big books are viewed with suspicion, and sometimes disdain.

headline: Wegman’s Weimaraner Republic
text: Visit William Wegman’s home and studio — a pair of connected buildings in Chelsea — and you’ll get a nice warm greeting from the visual artist, filmmaker and author best known for his images of dogs in assorted get-ups and poses.

headline: Deadline Friday for New Yorkers to Register to Vote
text: Friday is the deadline to register to vote in the Nov. 5 general election, which in New York City will include the election of the next mayor.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 11-17
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Madame Restell’s Other Profession
text: In July, the Streetscapes column looked at the claim that the 1870 Stuyvesant was the first New York apartment house, and decided in the affirmative. But no one is on solid ground in declaring a first unless he can also propose a second, and it turns out that runner-up is a lot harder to find than the winner. Whereas the Stuyvesant was built by an old New York family, the likeliest No. 2 is the work of a woman shunned by society.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 11-17
text: Raptor Festivals

headline: Alice Munro: Excerpts From Her Work
text: Below are selections from the work of Alice Munro, who was awarded the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday. They are reprinted with the permission of Alfred A. Knopf.

headline: Rewarding Stellar Credit
text: Lending terms are easing up for borrowers who have superior credit. But mortgages are no easier to come by for applicants with unexceptional FICO scores.

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 11-17
text: ‘The Next Level: East Side Access Photographs by Hiroyuki Suzuki’ (through Oct. 27) Sometimes you have to dig deep to discover something beautiful. For the Japanese photographer Hiroyuki Suzuki — who has drawn inspiration from the scope and energy of major construction projects in Tokyo, Shanghai and Dubai — that meant descending 18 stories below Grand Central Terminal to capture images of the work now under way for the nearly $8.3 billion East Side Access Project, which will connect Long Island Rail Road trains in Queens to the Terminal in Manhattan. He started photographing in 2011, the year work began; it is expected to be completed in 2019.

headline: Canadian Carrier Backtracks on BlackBerry Snub
text: OTTAWA — BlackBerry has received a bit of good news. Rogers Communications, Canada’s largest wireless carrier, has backtracked on its earlier decision not to sell BlackBerry’s new flagship smartphone.

headline: Afterlife? What Afterlife?
text: Good for nothing besides the employment of insipid young actresses, films like “I Will Follow You Into the Dark” believe that romance is best dealt with in hurried montage and that a crisis of faith is an acceptable substitution for a personality.

headline: Insufficiently Conservative? Take That!
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: For Girls, Their Own Way to Reach the Heavens
text: Lyn Pentecost settled into a plush, comfortable seat in a planetarium in Manhattan. No, not that planetarium. This one is for only girls.

headline: Happenings | Mexican Summer, the Little Indie Label That Could, Throws an Anniversary Bash
text: For certain indie rock aficionados, a release put out by the Greenpoint, Brooklyn, record label Mexican Summer carries as much weight as a 10.0 review on the review site Pitchfork. Founded in 2008 by Andrés Santo Domingo, Keith Abrahamsson and Tom Clapp as the more tuneful offshoot of their rock-oriented imprint Kemado Records, Mexican Summer has since become a bastion for experimental pop, not to mention a model for successful music publishing in the 21st century. The label, which took its name from a track by the folk singer Marissa Nadler, one of its artists, has enjoyed one success after another. The first LP by the scrappy guitar-pop band Best Coast moved more than 100,000 copies (and subsequently landed in a Windows ad), a sizable number even for a major these days. The garage rocker Kurt Vile, the lo-fi experimental weirdo Ariel Pink and the chillwave act Washed Out have also experienced success with Mexican Summer. A considerable percentage of the label’s sales are on vinyl, according to Abrahamsson.

headline: This Week's Movies: Oct. 11, 2013
text: The New York Times movie critics on “Captain Phillips,” “CBGB,” and “Romeo & Juliet.”

headline: Boxer’s Tale, Fashioned by a Fighter
text: WHEN the experimental composer Fred Ho answered the door of his apartment on a quiet, leafy street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn recently, he seemed much as he always has: beefy and muscular, with a warm smile that, over the next hour, would return to accompany some robustly expressed views about music and politics. If he had not mentioned that he felt too weak to sit, and preferred to speak while lying on his living room sofa, you probably would not guess that he is seriously ill — that, in fact, he is in the final stage of colorectal cancer, which he has been fighting since 2006.

headline: Where Séances Go Badly
text: Cassadaga, Fla., has been called “the Psychic Capital of the World.” With its dilapidated Queen Anne mansions and its oak trees dripping with Spanish moss, this ghostly hub seems like the perfect setting for a horror story about an obsessed spirit harassing a lonely artist.

headline: Building for the Sake of Deconstruction
text: Do you like to solve puzzles? William Forsythe’s “Sider,” which had its United States premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, offers puzzles upon puzzles, and analogies, too. Yet where most puzzles tantalize with intriguing pieces of a larger picture that make you want to put together, the surface of “Sider” is as enticing as a sheet of cardboard.

headline: You Only Live Forever
text: Discussing one of his country’s most famous exports during a visit to the Soviet Union in the 1980s, John le Carré described James Bond as “a sort of licensed criminal who, in the name of false patriotism, approves of nasty crimes.” One has the sense, he told Radio Times in 2010, that Bond “would have gone through the same antics for any country really, if the girls had been so pretty and the martinis so dry.” It’s an accusation that has existed in various forms ever since the publication of “Casino Royale” in 1953. Bond’s creator also suffered doubts, as any reader of Andrew Lycett’s expansive 1995 biography, “Ian Fleming” (recently republished by St. Martin’s Press), will know. While working on “Moonraker,” the third of his 14 Bond books, Fleming complained that Bond’s future was “nothing but a vista of fantastic adventures on more or less the same pattern, but losing freshness with each volume.”

headline: On the Market in Aspen, Colo.
text: Homes in ski country offering from one to five bedrooms and priced from $1,150,000 to $15,500,000.

headline: She’s Where the Work Is
text: As Irving Berlin names alternative occupations to the theater in “There’s No Business Like Show Business,” a butcher and a baker lead the list. To those you might add the Baker’s Wife, from the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical “Into the Woods.” Joanna Gleason portrayed that character so movingly that I fell in love with her when I first saw the show in 1987.

headline: Russia: Shake-Up at Space Agency
text: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev fired the general director of Russia’s beleaguered space agency on Thursday as part of a shake-up that had been expected after a series of embarrassing rocket failures. The dismissed official, Vladimir A. Popovkin, was appointed to lead the agency, Roscosmos, in 2011 after a failed rocket launching destroyed three satellites needed for a Russian global navigation system. Mr. Medvedev said that Oleg Ostapenko, a deputy defense minister with long experience in space operations, would be the agency’s new chief. A leadership change at Roscosmos was widely expected after the failed launching of an unmanned Proton-M rocket in July. It was the fourth failed Proton launching in three years.

headline: The Joys of Being Wendish, Festival and All
text: SERBIN — In a light-filled 19th-century Lutheran church with red stenciling above the blue and white balcony, worshipers prayed and sang in German. It was the closest the visitors to this Central Texas community could come to honoring their heritage now that almost no one in Texas knows Wendish, the Slavic language their ancestors spoke in Germany.

headline: A Piece of Italy for Everyone
text: Leaving Fortina on a Friday night this autumn, a tiny patron in a pink tutu clasped hands with her parents and happily chirped her newfound word: “Ciao! Ciao! Ciao!” Passing them on the way in, a young woman in a black sequined shift and very high heels texted as she teetered toward the door. I have never in my dining experience witnessed such a seamless transition from kiddie hour to singles scene.

headline: Prison Oversight Faulted in Ariel Castro’s Death
text: Prison guards in Ohio falsified records and failed to properly complete their rounds on the day Ariel Castro, the man convicted of holding three women captive in his Cleveland home for a decade, hanged himself in his cell last month, according to a state report released Thursday. The report suggested that Mr. Castro may have asphyxiated himself during a sexual act.

headline: Boeing 787, Grounded in Norway, Nearly Fixed
text: Boeing is almost finished repairing several balky systems on a new 787 Dreamliner operated by Norwegian Air Shuttle, the latest airline to complain about annoying malfunctions, the airline’s chief executive said Thursday.

headline: Pentagon’s Top Weapons Expert to Retire
text: Ashton B. Carter, who built upon academic specialties in medieval history and theoretical physics to become the Pentagon’s top expert on budgets and weapons, announced Thursday that he was retiring as deputy defense secretary. Mr. Carter, 59, was central to an emergency effort under former Secretary Robert M. Gates to rush heavily armored transport vehicles to Iraq. The initiative was hailed by troops as a lifesaving defense against roadside bombs. He was promoted to deputy secretary in 2011 and oversaw the complex task of devising strategy in a time of declining budgets, and he was said to have been under consideration when Mr. Obama picked Chuck Hagel to follow Leon E. Panetta as secretary.

headline: Columbus Day Closings in New York City
text: NEW YORK

headline: He Died as He Loved to Live, on the Edge
text: Shane McConkey took huge risks in pursuit of his dreams, pulling off feats that most people can hardly fathom (and some dismiss as foolish): big-mountain skiing, base jumping from glaciers, skiing off cliffs à la the chase scene in “The Spy Who Loved Me.” In 2009, he died the way he lived — doing what he loved — and a new documentary, “McConkey,” serves as a rousing testament to that freewheeling spirit.

headline: Pentagon Drops Backup Helmet for F-35 Pilots
text: The Pentagon said on Thursday that it had decided to stop working on a conventional backup helmet for pilots of the new F-35 fighter jet and stick with a troubled, but improving, higher-tech model.

headline: A Senator Raises Privacy Questions About Cross-Device Tracking
text: A lawmaker has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate online ad companies that track consumers across devices, like showing them ads on their phones based on Web sites they visit on a computer.

headline: From Rock Album to Stage Musical
text: “Broadway Idiot,” a documentary by Doug Hamilton about the making of the Broadway show “American Idiot,” never feels as if it were delving too deeply into the creative process, which turned a best-selling Green Day album into a stage musical. But as a chronicle of how one rock star slowly fell victim to the Broadway bug, it’s kind of amusing.

headline: A Glass, Maybe a Bottle, and a Few Plates
text: Francesca’s Wine Bar and Bistro, in Collinsville, is more than just an intimate place in which to enjoy a glass of merlot or pinot noir. It is also the nearest thing this former mill town has to a fine-dining establishment.

headline: Two Are Charged in Plan to Send Goods to Taliban
text: Two New York City men have been arrested on charges that they sought to supply the Taliban and other terrorist fighters with warm clothes and equipment for use in wintertime battle with United States forces in Afghanistan, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Hitting Pay Dirt
text: Unlike many recent documentaries about our careless stewardship of the planet, Deborah Koons Garcia’s “Symphony of the Soil” doesn’t feel like a rap on the knuckles. Unfolding with gentle joy and an unexpected beauty, this ode to the miracle of the Earth’s topmost layer gives us a newfound respect for the ground beneath our feet.

headline: Health Act Embraced in California
text: LOS ANGELES — There are radio and television commercials galore, along with Twitter and Facebook posts and scores of highway billboards. There are armies of outreach workers who speak Spanish, Tagalog, Cambodian, Mandarin and Cantonese, all flocking to county fairs, farmers markets, street festivals and back-to-school nights across the state. There are even dinner parties in Latino neighborhoods designed to reach one family at a time.

headline: A Bizarre Scavenger Hunt in San Francisco
text: Spencer McCall’s puzzling documentary “The Institute” wades into the mysteries of an experiment in alternate-reality gaming that took place a few years ago in San Francisco. Curious gamers loved the scavenger hunt/ sub-Pynchon intrigues, engineered by benevolent creators representing a supposed organization; we learn about it, a little, which is not quite the same as playing along.

headline: In Florida, Opposition by the State and Snags in Signing Up on the Web
text: MIAMI — Be it gold, silver or bronze level, there are two ironclad requirements for buying health insurance in Florida on the federal online exchange: patience and persistence.

headline: Court the Soul, Pummel the Sexuality
text: A searing look at the role of American evangelical missionaries in the persecution of gay Africans, Roger Ross Williams’s “God Loves Uganda” approaches this intersection of faith and politics with some fairness and a good deal of outrage.

headline: Suit Filed Against Warner Bros. in Screenplay Theft
text: LOS ANGELES — Warner Brothers responded harshly on Thursday to a legal complaint over the authorship of its Clint Eastwood baseball movie, “Trouble With the Curve.” But its opponents did not back down.

headline: VW Plant Opens Door to Union and Dispute
text: FRANKFURT — The face-off between Volkswagen and the United Automobile Workers over organizing the company’s new plant in Tennessee is rapidly becoming a global clash of cultures.

headline: Serenity, and a Few Sly Smiles, for the U.S.
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At its core, soccer is a game of rhythm and flow. But the international version is fundamentally stunted.

headline: Stocks Rally, Talks Stall, Then Skepticism Returns
text: Investors embraced signs of a political compromise that could avert a default on government debt, sending stocks surging on Thursday.

headline: Wheelchair Racer Could Be First to Win 3 Major Marathons in a Season
text: CHAMPAIGN, Ill. — On a recent afternoon, Tatyana McFadden wheeled her racing chair onto a quiet street to begin a training session. She rolled through the University of Illinois campus here, past the football stadium, by a cemetery and then a residential street lined with bungalows. Cornfields were in the distance. Her legs, which she has never used to walk, were tucked beneath her torso.

headline: Blue Cross Plans Jump to an Early Lead
text: Color the new online insurance marketplaces Blue.

headline: Outside National Parks, Feeling Squeezed by the Shutdown
text: SPRINGDALE, Utah — In the 10 days since Zion National Park closed its gates, the community on its doorstep has become a shutdown ghost town. Hotel rooms are dark, and housecleaners are working half-shifts. Herds of campers and sightseers have streamed away along the only highway out of town, and canceled reservations from New Zealand, California and Germany are piling up every day.

headline: Gay Rights Protests Follow Gergiev to Carnegie Hall
text: The furor in the West over Russia’s new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality continues to dog the conductor Valery Gergiev, who is one of Russia’s most important cultural exports these days. Mr. Gergiev, a prominent supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who signed the law, drew protests Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, just as he did last month at the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Lapsed, but Listening
text: Just days before he got the diagnosis of the cancer that would kill him in 2011, Christopher Hitchens was flinging word bolts at pilgrims while promoting his book “God Is Not Great.” After his presentation, I asked him why, given that so few Americans self-identify as atheists, his book had found such a large audience.

headline: Fed Up With Fund-Raising for My Kids’ School
text: AMID the flurry of school notices coming home in my kids’ backpacks, the PTA donation envelope carries a nostalgic pang. I remember thinking, only four years ago as my first child entered school, that a modest contribution to the PTA was my only cash obligation to New York City’s public schools — beyond being a dutiful taxpayer, of course.

headline: Two Brazilian Brothers to Pay Nearly $5 Million in Insider Trading Case
text: The bullish bet on H. J. Heinz flashed all the telltale signs of insider trading.

headline: Dealing With Default
text: So Republicans may have decided to raise the debt ceiling without conditions attached — the details still aren’t clear. Maybe that’s the end of that particular extortion tactic, but maybe not, because, at best, we’re only looking at a very short-term extension. The threat of hitting the ceiling remains, especially if the politics of the shutdown continue to go against the G.O.P.

headline: Libya’s Security Crisis
text: The American commando operation that snatched a suspected leader of Al Qaeda from his neighborhood in Tripoli, while successful, does not offer a permanent strategy to the threat from extremists in Libya. That point was reinforced on Thursday when the country’s prime minister, Ali Zeidan, was briefly kidnapped by militia members in apparent retaliation for his consenting to the raid.

headline: An Inadequate Offer From the House
text: Speaker John Boehner on Thursday said he was willing to delay briefly a disastrous default of the country’s financial obligations but was not willing to reopen the government. “I would hope that the president would look at this as an opportunity and a good-faith effort on our part to move halfway — halfway to what he’s demanded,” he said.

headline: Gambling on Loaded Language
text: New York voters will decide in November whether to allow seven new casinos to open across the state. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and most members of the Legislature are strongly in favor of these casinos. But they do not have the right to skew the language on the ballot, as they have contrived to do, in a way that tips the scales in favor of a pro-gambling outcome.

headline: A Nobel Prize for Alice Munro
text: Over a long career, Alice Munro’s work has deepened and widened, so that coming new to one of her stories, you find all the others in your mind, mapping in some vestigial way a Canadian geography that feels continuous, no matter how much the stories shift in time and place.

headline: Jerry Kill Makes a Difficult, but Prudent, Call
text: Those who knew Jerry Kill best, who watched him go through seizures in packed stadiums and return to work as if nothing happened, dreaded the situation that unfolded Thursday. They dreaded the day that Kill, an epileptic who inspired thousands of fellow epileptics, would step away from coaching.

headline: In Africa, Seeking a License to Kill
text: CAPE TOWN — MEMBERS of the African Union will meet in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, today to discuss recent calls by some African leaders to withdraw from the International Criminal Court. These calls must be resisted. The continent has suffered the consequences of unaccountable governance for too long to disown the protections offered by the I.C.C.

headline: For CVS Regulars, Ads Tailored Just to Them
text: ONCE, the letters in the name of the CVS drugstore chain stood for Consumer Value Store. Now, they could also stand for Customized Virtual Shopping.

headline: Saudi Women Drive, Despite Ban, and Find Some Support on the Kingdom’s Roads
text: Last Updated, Friday, 11:30 a.m. | A brief flurry of civil disobedience on the roads of Saudi Arabia this week, by women who flouted the conservative kingdom’s ban on female drivers and documented it on Twitter and YouTube, ended on Thursday in a predictable manner — with an image of officers pulling alongside one car, captioned simply, “Police stopped us.”

headline: After Tragic Loss During Hurricane Sandy, a Woman Chooses Not to Return
text: Patricia Dresch and her husband, George, lived in their home in Tottenville, Staten Island, for about 30 years, a wood-frame house where they raised two daughters.

headline: Can Playing Ball Be Bad for Children?
text: Do competitive sports overwhelm childhood or enhance it?

headline: Tutoring Help in Texas
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sarcasm in the Court
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rearview Cameras on Cars
text: To the Editor:

headline: Politics and Art
text: To the Editor:

headline: The G.O.P. Role in the Fiscal Crisis
Refuge From the Storm
text: To the Editor:

headline: C.I.A. Warning on Snowden in ’09 Said to Slip Through the Cracks
text: WASHINGTON — Just as Edward J. Snowden was preparing to leave Geneva and a job as a C.I.A. technician in 2009, his supervisor wrote a derogatory report in his personnel file, noting a distinct change in the young man’s behavior and work habits, as well as a troubling suspicion.

headline: Kochs and Other Conservatives Split Over Strategy on Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Under attack for the government shutdown, some of the most vocal elements of the conservative wing of the Republican Party are publicly splintering, a sign of growing concerns among even hard-core conservatives that the defeat-health-care-at-any-cost strategy may have backfired.

headline: Undercover Police, Just About Everywhere
text: It may not have occurred to people that New York City needed to deploy an undercover detective to spy on Occupy Sandy, a relief operation run by activists that delivered food and supplies to parts of the city ruined by the hurricane. But Detective Wojciech Braszczok, who embedded with the Occupy Wall Street forces under the nom de activist Albert, was putting posts on Twitter last November about the Sandy operation, which, by the way, received consistently high grades from people for its nimble, effective work.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 10, 2013
Ryan Is Again in the Forefront for the G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan may have temporarily receded into the Capitol shadows after his stinging vice-presidential defeat in November, but he remains a powerful presence among House Republicans, earning the respect of hard-line conservatives for his budget blueprint and the trust of anxious moderates for his pragmatism.

headline: The Alphabet Soup of Health Spending Plans
text: H.S.A.’S, F.S.A.’s — there’s an alphabet soup of health spending plans out there. Last month, when I mentioned health savings accounts in an article, some readers seemed to confuse them with flexible-spending arrangements, which function quite differently.

headline: U.N. Questions Criticism of Its Peacekeepers
text: The United Nations responded on Thursday with a mix of diplomatic decorum and criticism to a report asserting systemic flaws in the way that it selects and trains peacekeeping troops. The conclusions of the report, undertaken by Transparency International UK, a prominent corruption monitoring group, appeared to have surprised and angered some United Nations officials.

headline: U.S. Offer Would Let Some States Open Parks
text: The governors of at least four states expressed initial interest in an offer on Thursday from Interior Secretary Sally Jewell to allow them to reopen national parks in their states, though it remained unclear whether any such deals could be reached soon.

headline: The Quashing of a Case Against a Christie Ally
text: FLEMINGTON, N.J. — Prosecutors sent tremors through rural Hunterdon County when they announced a sweeping indictment of the local Republican sheriff and her two deputies in 2010.

headline: Fifth Suspect Is Indicted in 2005 Killing of Ex-Lebanese Premier
text: PARIS — An international court has indicted a fifth suspect in the 2005 killing of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanon prime minister, describing the suspect, like the other four indictees, as a member of Hezbollah.

headline: No Clues in Deaths of Brooklyn Mother and Infant
text: A woman and her 11-day-old son were found unconscious in their Brooklyn home on Thursday morning and were later pronounced dead, but the authorities could provide no immediate explanation for what had killed them.

headline: N.L.C.S. Preview: For the Dodgers, a Model in the Opposite Dugout
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers get a lot of attention for their payroll, which was $216 million on opening day, a full $100 million more than the payroll of the St. Louis Cardinals, their opponents in the National League Championship Series.

headline: Master of the Intricacies of the Human Heart
text: Alice Munro, named on Thursday as the winner of the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature, once observed: “The complexity of things — the things within things — just seems to be endless. I mean nothing is easy, nothing is simple.”

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 11-17
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Not Wasting Time, PGA Starts New Season With a Crowd
text: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — Before sunrise, the Argentine Miguel Ángel Carballo was on the practice range waiting to see whether the new PGA Tour season would take flight with or without him. He would spend the next six and a half hours hoping to hear his name called.

headline: Mercury Astronaut Scott Carpenter Dies at 88
text: Mr. Carpenter was the second American to orbit the Earth, following John Glenn, now the only surviving member of America’s original space program.

headline: Corrections: October 11, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Little Girl Blue Howls Again, but Talks Sensibly, Too
text: The party onstage at the Lyceum Theater, where “A Night With Janis Joplin” opened on Thursday night, turns out to be more crowded than you might expect. This latest in Broadway’s endless stream of boomer-bait musical tributes isn’t just a matter of a big-voiced singer, her backup band and a bottle of Southern Comfort.

headline: The Dangers of Pseudoscience
text: Philosophers of science have been preoccupied for a while with what they call the “demarcation problem,” the issue of what separates good science from bad science and pseudoscience (and everything in between). The problem is relevant for at least three reasons.

headline: Response to a Threat
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — As far as I know, Peter A. Collins is a lovely guy, but he seems a bit grumpy today. Let’s see if we can cheer him up by saying nice things about his puzzle.

headline: City Council Moves to Stall Land Leases at Public Housing
text: The New York City Council and a group of tenants sued the Bloomberg administration on Thursday over plans to lease land in public housing developments for the creation of market-rate apartments.

headline: Inconvenient Uncertainties
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE headline in The New York Times yesterday was succinct. “By 2047, Coldest Years May Be Warmer Than Hottest in Past, Scientists Say.” Not, say, “around 2050” or “within our lifetime.” The specificity makes the crisis feel real, imminent and terrible. Call it a convenient truth. The story was about a new study published this week in the journal Nature that calculated that by 2047, the average temperature will be hotter across most parts of the planet than it had been at those locations in any year between 1860 and 2005.

headline: Jury Finds Toyota Not Liable in Death of California Driver
text: A jury in Los Angeles cleared Toyota Motor of fault on Thursday in a fatal 2009 accident in which a 66-year-old woman crashed her Camry.

headline: Booker’s Father Dies After Long Illness
text: The final stretch of the United States Senate campaign in New Jersey, already more unpredictable than expected, was jolted again on Thursday by the death of the father of the Democratic candidate, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark.

headline: Lhota Continues to Trail de Blasio by Wide Margin, Poll Finds
text: At least it is not a 50-point lead anymore.

headline: Grand Jury Cites Deaths of Children in Inquiry
text: A Brooklyn grand jury found that 19 children in New York City died of abuse and neglect because the city’s child protective agency had failed to rigorously investigate cases even after a city report recommended new practices in 2007.

headline: Mother to Visit American Held in North Korea
text: The mother of Kenneth Bae, an American of Korean descent who has been held in North Korea for nearly a year and is in failing health, has been granted permission by the North Korean authorities to visit him and arrived in Pyongyang on Thursday, his family reported.

headline: Imero Fiorentino, Lighting Designer Who Mastered Television, Dies at 85
text: He made drinks sparkle, desserts shimmer and Richard M. Nixon look less shadowy — all with meticulous tricks of the light.

headline: Off the Couch and Back With the Jets for Garrard
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It was not really the jogging, the weight training or the physical therapy that told David Garrard his chronic left knee troubles had healed enough for him to come out of retirement. It was playing wide receiver for his wife, a quarterback on a flag football team in Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: Coop and Papa, Manning Up in Good Times and Bad
text: Gary Cooper and Ernest Hemingway, two models of American virility, had similarities, not least as outdoorsmen: Cooper grew up on a farm in Montana, and Hemingway was a big-game hunter and deep-sea fisherman. But they were also a study in contrasts: Cooper worked with movie crews; Hemingway labored alone. Cooper was understated and conservative, Hemingway volatile and a liberal. The mix, as John Mulholland’s exhaustive documentary “Cooper & Hemingway: The True Gen” demonstrates, made for a friendship spanning decades.

headline: Shirley Chisholm Gets a Stamp of Approval
text: A stamp honoring Shirley A. Chisholm, the former congresswoman from New York, may soon grace your mail.

headline: Jealousy and Spite as Game Figurines
text: There’s a new nerd in town, and he’s causing all kinds of problems for Scott (Sam Eidson), the loathsome role-playing gamer whose downward spiral fuels “Zero Charisma.”

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,270 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Ah, Those Giddy Teenage Pool Parties
text: A horror movie rises from the dead with “All the Boys Love Mandy Lane,” a theatrical release seven years in coming. Though it had its premiere at the 2006 Toronto International Film Festival, this feature-length debut from Jonathan Levine has a timeless premise: Horny teenagers are picked off by a bloodthirsty killer in an isolated location. The delay is marginally more an injustice than a condemnation.

headline: Linear Genius, Bold and Transformative
text: “Every time we take the subway in New York, we’re in Vignelli-land,” says Paola Antonelli, senior curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, in the new documentary “Design Is One.” Ms. Antonelli is referring to the Italian couple Lella and Massimo Vignelli, whose firm designed many graphic elements for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Mr. Vignelli created a 1972 subway map that the designer Milton Glaser refers to in the film as a conceptual breakthrough.

headline: Calm Before the Storm
text: Henri Cole’s lyric verse about watching a hurricane from afar reminds the artist Hernan Bas of visiting a cemetery in New Orleans before Katrina.

headline: One of England’s Most Renowned Clans, in Its Native Habitat
text: Two generations of one of England’s most celebrated families — Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant — make beautiful, unusual and deeply personal art that draws from the natural world.

headline: The Dubious Case for Professional Licensing
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Syrian Civilians Bore Brunt of Rebels’ Fury, Report Says
text: LATAKIA, Syria — Before dawn on Aug. 4, Raed Shakouhi, an olive and walnut farmer in a government-held hilltop village near the Syrian coast, just across a valley from rebel territory, was woken by gunshots and cries of “God is great.”

headline: Ask Well: Leaving Nail Fungus Untreated
text: Question:

headline: The Mystery Man Behind the Monsters
text: Escalators that eat people; a human sacrifice amid backyard barbeques. In any pantheon of cartoonists, Gahan Wilson and his uniquely mordant sense of humor fit somewhere between Charles Addams and Gary Larson. Armed with a perverse comedic view of the monsters behind every corner and an illustration style that hits with the thwack of a nightmare, Mr. Wilson has been reassuring his readers for more than 50 years that things really are as bad as they seem, probably worse.

headline: Word of the Day | wanderlust
text: wanderlust •\ˈwän-dər-ˌləst\• noun

headline: The Human Rights Watch Report
text: Human Rights Watch said it had documented for the first time that Syrian rebel groups targeted civilians in Latakia for executions and hostage-taking. More than 200 people were still being held, the agency said.

headline: Verlander’s Mastery Extends Athletics’ Misery as Tigers Advance
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Detroit Tigers celebrated in a haze of smoke, pitcher Justin Verlander among those puffing on cigars between smiles and hugs. The ceiling dripped the spent remains of 15 cases of sparkling wine. A stereo thumped.

headline: For Giants, a Familiar Start With Another Ugly Ending
text: CHICAGO — In the Giants’ season-opening game, Eli Manning threw an interception on the first play from scrimmage. Demonstrating improvement in the sixth game of the season Thursday night, Manning did not throw an interception until the third play of the game.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 11, 2013
text: “We cannot be compared to other countries where they had strong institutions of army and police. In Libya we did not have institutions.”

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) UNBREAKABLE: ONE GIRL CHANGING THE WORLD On Oct. 9, 2012, Malala Yousafzai, a teenage spokeswoman for girls’ education in Pakistan, was shot in the head by Taliban attackers. Her story of courage and determination captured the public’s imagination and inspired a global movement, resulting in her nomination for the 2013 Nobel Peace Prize. If she wins on Friday, she will be the youngest recipient ever. In this special edition of “20/20,” Ms. Yousafzai, above, speaks with Diane Sawyer about her passion for learning amid threats, the moments leading up to the assassination attempt, her recovery and her new memoir, “I Am Malala.” Margaret Warner will also interview Ms. Yousafzai on “PBS NewsHour,” at 7 on Channels 13 and 49.

headline: News Quiz | October 11, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: The Faces of ‘Carrie’
text: A look at some of the many versions of the picked-on heroine’s signature look.

headline: A Conversation With: Human Rights Activist Rikke Nöhrlind
text: On Thursday, the European Parliament, which consists of elected representatives from the 28 member countries of the European Union, passed a resolution that condemned caste-based discrimination as a human rights violation.

headline: On Iran Talks, Congress Could Play ‘Bad Cop’
