text: WASHINGTON — When Iranian diplomats sit down in Geneva next Tuesday with the United States and five other world powers for a new round of talks about Iran’s nuclear program, Congress will not have a seat at the table. But that does not mean it will not have a voice.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing, Oct. 11, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Bay Area Averts a Transit System Strike, for Now
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Minutes before a state-ordered 60-day cooling off period was set to expire on Thursday night, negotiators for employees of the Bay Area’s main commuter railroad said they would stay at the bargaining table, temporarily averting a major transit strike.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Alice Munro Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
text: In the article “Alice Munro Wins Nobel Prize in Literature,” Julie Bosman writes about the announcement of the winner of this prestigious prize.

headline: W. Eugene Smith’s ‘Big Book,’ His Way
text: W. Eugene Smith won renown for perfecting the modern photo essay during his years at Life magazine. But he was also well known for being the most difficult photojournalist an editor would ever encounter.

headline: Are Some Youth Sports Too Intense?
text: Do you know children or preteenagers who are on sports teams so competitive that they spend several days a week nearly every week of the year playing? Whose families have organized their whole lives around getting these students to and from games and practices?

headline: Chemical Weapons Watchdog Wins Nobel Peace Prize
text: LONDON — Urging the destruction of an “entire category” of unconventional weapons, the Norwegian Nobel Committee awarded its 2013 Peace Prize on Friday to a modest and little-known United Nations-backed organization that has drawn sudden attention with a mission to ensure that Syria’s stocks of chemical arms are eradicated.

headline: Alitalia Board Approves $676 Million Rescue Plan
text: Scrambling to stave off an imminent collapse of Alitalia, the airline’s board voted unanimously late Friday to approve a rescue package of 500 million euros, or $676 million, for the carrier that was likely to result in its partial renationalization five years after it was rescued from bankruptcy.

headline: New York Today: Winging It
text: Updated 12:03 p.m. | It is an annual fall migration — via FedEx.

headline: Police Are Getting the Military’s Leftover Armored Trucks
text: The Sept. 11 attacks and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have had a broad impact on American society. It could be argued that one of its vestiges has been a keen interest in armored vehicles by many police departments.

headline: Del Monte Foods Sells Consumer Products Division for $1.68 Billion
text: Del Monte Foods is finally shedding its long-held canned fruits and vegetables business.

headline: Taking the Path of Profits Over Growth
text: In the “Innovators Solution: Creating and Sustaining Successful Growth,” Clayton Christensen and Michael Raynor suggest impatience for profits and patience for growth. This means that when starting a new venture, profits are most important. Without them your venture will have a hard time reaching sustainability.

headline: JPMorgan’s Loss Is Corporate Law Firms’ Gain
text: Updated, 8:38 p.m. | The calls started flooding into JPMorgan Chase last month.

headline: Gay People Have Children, Too
text: LONDON — Daniel Vais, an Israeli Londoner with no connection to Russia, got in touch with me last week. “We need someone to talk about what it’s like in Russia now, because we don’t really know,” said Vais, who runs the local TEDx event in Hackney, the part of east London where I live. He was organizing a small gathering at a theater near the Olympic Park to support Russia’s beleaguered gay community and wanted me to talk about my own experience living in Russia and the history of gay rights there.

headline: JPMorgan Swings to Loss
text: JPMorgan Chase reported a third-quarter net loss on Friday of $380 million, or 17 cents a share, as regulatory and legal woes dragged down the bank’s results. Excluding the one-time costs, JPMorgan’s earnings were $1.42 a share, or $5.8 billion, beating analysts’ expectations of $4.65 billion, or $1.21 a share. The bank’s earnings were weighed down by a legal expense of $9.2 billion.

headline: Each Generation Gets a Carrie It Deserves
text: Carrie White has been remarkably resilient. Getting pelted with tampons for decades will do that to a girl.

headline: Career Builders and Now Doting Parents
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: The ICT Revolution Isn’t Over
text: We have a Griswold Center event tonight in which Bob Gordon and I will discuss — debate is too strong a word — his pessimism about future growth. I’ll post more about all that after the event; don’t want to give away my (weak) punchlines. But I thought I would make one casual observation about technology.

headline: France Upholds Ban on Hydraulic Fracturing
text: PARIS — France’s highest court on Friday upheld a government ban on a controversial drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing, in a defeat for a method that has revolutionized the oil and natural gas industry in the United States.

headline: Divide Narrows as Talks to Resolve Fiscal Crisis Go On
text: WASHINGTON — Political divisions over the nation’s finances appeared to narrow on Friday as President Obama and Congressional Republicans showed greater flexibility in their negotiations. But officials headed into the weekend without a deal to end the shutdown and avert what could be a devastating default after the government reaches the current borrowing limit on Thursday.

headline: Wells Fargo Quarterly Earnings Jump 13%
text: For Wells Fargo’s investors, it is hard to argue with 15 consecutive jumps in quarterly profit. And that trend continued on Friday, when the bank announced a 13 percent rise in third-quarter profit to a record $5.6 billion, or 99 cents a share, beating the expectations of analysts.

headline: Christina Romer on Janet Yellen
text: Janet Yellen’s longtime friend and colleague, Christina D. Romer, discusses Ms. Yellen’s relationship with her husband, George A. Akerlof, a Nobel prize holder in economic science.

headline: Kerry Visits Afghan Leader, Seeking End to an Impasse
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Last Saturday, Secretary of State John Kerry called President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan with a simple question: If Mr. Kerry came to Kabul, would it help break a deadlock in negotiations to keep American forces in Afghanistan beyond next year?

headline: Israeli Man Fatally Bludgeoned in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli man who was a colonel in the reserves was fatally bludgeoned in the Jordan Valley area of the West Bank on Friday, according to the Israeli military, and security forces detained five Palestinians in connection with the attack.

headline: Google to Sell Users’ Endorsements
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Those long-forgotten posts on social networks, from the pasta someone photographed to the rant about her dentist, are forgotten no more. Social networks want to make them easier to find, and in some cases, to show them in ads.

headline: A Rescue on the Subway Tracks
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Poland Moves Forward on Bill That Would Transfer Private Pensions to State
text: Ignoring warnings that it could deter foreign investment, the Polish government has announced a draft bill that would require private pension funds to transfer about 35.2 billion euros, or $47.6 billion, in government bonds to the state in February.

headline: Daily Report: Google to Sell Users’ Endorsements
text: Google, following in Facebook’s footsteps, wants to sell users’ endorsements to marketers to help them hawk their wares, Claire Cain Miller and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Royal Mail Shares Surge in Debut
text: Updated, 12:39 p.m. |

headline: Toyota Recalls 10,000 Models for Windshield Wiper Problem
text: Toyota will recall about 10,000 of its newest and most popular models to fix a problem with the windshield wiper switch, the automaker said Thursday. The action covers 2013-14 Camry and Camry Hybrid models, the 2013 Avalon and Avalon Hybrid and the 2014 Corolla.

headline: Off the Charts: And the Last Shall Be First
text: Oct. 9 has twice been a turning point for stocks in this century. After the 2001 recession, the American market hit bottom on Oct. 9, 2002, and then peaked exactly five years later, on Oct. 9, 2007. American stocks underperformed most of the world during that five-year period, but have outperformed in the six years from 2007 to now. Within the United States, sectors that lagged in the earlier period have been strong more recently.

headline: A Tale of Two Recessions and World Markets, Turned on Their Heads
text: WHAT’S in a date?

headline: Small Businesses in Mumbai Bear Brunt of High Inflation
text: MUMBAI— Nayan Lapsia spent much of a humid Wednesday afternoon looking despairingly at the idle cash register at his store in Crawford Market, a colonial-era open-air market in the heart of Mumbai, India’s financial capital. Though customers have stopped by fleetingly to glance at goods, things were unusually quiet at his shop, Shah Bhavanji Kunvarji & Company, which is stacked with all manner of spices and dry fruit.

headline: Amber Teething Necklaces Pose Choking Hazard
text: When model Gisele Bündchen posted a photo of herself and her young child on Instagram this summer, the snapshot, which showed her infant daughter wearing tiny earrings, ignited debate on blogs about the appropriate age for ear piercing. But a more serious concern, missed in many of the discussions, was the delicate necklace of amber beads looped around the baby’s neck.

headline: The Costs of Fantasy Politics
text: As of this morning, there’s reason to hope that some time next week the government shutdown will end, the debt ceiling will be temporarily raised, and I’ll be able to write a follow-up to my column on Pope Francis, or something about what should be the political story of the moment — the don’t-call-it-trainwreck debut of Healthcare.gov — or even (who knows?) something more esoteric and random and fun. But for today, let me go one more round with Ben Domenech, who wrote yesterday in defense of a Republican strategy that would lift the debt ceiling while keeping the government shutdown going, and going, and going — a move that I likened on CNN to postponing a murder-suicide in order to just concentrate on slitting your own wrists, but which Domenech regards in a more favorable light. To my previous suggestion that the shutdown is ratifying the public’s pre-existing distrust of G.O.P. governance, he writes:

headline: The War On The Poor Is A War On You-Know-Who
text: Lots of people have been referencing this Democracy Corps report on focus-group meetings with Republicans, and with good reason: Greenberg has basically provided a unified theory of the craziness that has enveloped American politics in the last few years.

headline: Don’t Feed the Trolls
text: Some readers have been asking when I’m going to reply to certain rants aimed my way. The answer is, never.

headline: Skills Practice | Concise Writing
text: This week, the third in our new Skills lesson series, Sarah Gross, an enthusiastic Twitter user and “connected educator,” suggests using an article on the art of the Twitter bio to teach lessons about concise writing and word choice.

headline: Five Fillings for Stuffed Peppers
text: These roasted yellow peppers are filled with a savory mix of quinoa seasoned with garlic and parsley and tossed with Manchego or Parmesan cheese. The roasted peppers make a nice contrast in color and flavor to the sweet tomato sauce. You’ll get plenty of Vitamin C and lycopene from both the peppers and the sauce in this dish.

headline: Week 6 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Saints (5-0) at Patriots (4-1)

headline: Notes on Interregional and International Trade
text: My brief paper (pdf) for a Walter Isard memorial volume.

headline: The Fed’s Downward Trend at the Top
text: Since Paul Volcker, who stands 6 foot 7, left the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve in 1987, each successive Fed leader has stood at least a bit closer to the ground. Interest rates, coincidentally, have followed a similar path. With Janet Yellen poised to take over, the federal funds rate — a benchmark that sets the overnight cost of borrowing for banks — is effectively zero.

headline: An Academic Home
text: Andrew K. Rose, a colleague of Janet Yellen at the University of California, Berkeley, discusses Ms. Yellen's role as a professor.

headline: My Fake Levantine Romance
text: Our first date was at the best hummusia in Israel. We sat hillside in a white stone building, while the hummus, soaked with olive oil and topped with pine nuts and Egyptian brown beans, melted in our mouths like clotted cream. We were a few miles from Jerusalem on a scorching desert afternoon, in the Arab village of Abu Ghosh, a town known not only for its hummus but also for its peaceful relationship with nearby Jewish settlements.

headline: Parts and Labor (and Luck)
text: I recently took my car to a mechanic because it had suddenly started making an alarmingly loud noise when the brakes were applied. He removed and cleaned the brake pads, but the noise persisted. After three more hours, he finally declared it a mystery. He didn’t charge me anything, and I didn’t offer to pay. But the following day, the brakes made significantly less noise, and now they are barely audible. Am I obligated to return to his shop and offer payment? ANAT CHEMERINSKI, BALTIMORE

headline: Who’s Winning the Architecture Arms Race?
text: Answer: Baku, Azerbaijan, where the government is spending an estimated $6 billion a year on architecture projects. As we wrote in February, Azerbaijan’s leaders want to make their capital city a destination for the rich and fabulous. The latest example: the Heydar Aliyev Center designed by Zaha Hadid, for whom it offered the rare opportunity of nearly total design freedom. Every roof and ceiling panel is different, Hadid says. Though the center does not officially open until Nov. 1, people are already climbing on its base, says the photographer Iwan Baan. “But I haven’t seen any skateboarders yet.” Maya Lau

headline: Catie Marron: Blame Pastis, Not the High Line
text: Your book, “City Parks: Public Places, Private Thoughts,” is an anthology of writers musing about their favorite public parks. What was the genesis of the idea?  I went to Paris for the first time when I was 23. We went to the Luxembourg Gardens one morning, and I was nearly moved to tears. It became my favorite place in the world. Whenever I was in Paris, I would insist on going there, even on the way to the airport.

headline: Why Don’t We Dance Anymore?
text: When a dance move is born, the air is heavy with promise. Think of Chubby Checker, doing the twist with casual grace on “American Bandstand.” Think of that first surreal nightclub scene in “Sweet Charity,” in which Shirley MacLaine’s young dancehall hostess is mesmerized by a troop of dancers serving Bob Fosse’s unique style of über-mod gesticulation. Think of Jennifer Beals’s solo audition in “Flashdance,” the movie that led to a million ripped sweatshirts. Think of Michael Jackson’s first moonwalk.

headline: Smoking Is for the Birds
text: The secret to making it in the N.F.L.; Mario Batali’s wine of the season; who is an essential employee anyway?

headline: Nicolas Jaar Tests the Limits of Dance Music
text: When Nicolas Jaar was 17, he e-mailed a piece of electronic music, which he made on his laptop, to a record label in Brooklyn. He’d heard an interview with the owner of the label, Wolf + Lamb, who was going on about house music and “elasticity.” Jaar felt he knew exactly what the guy was talking about. Wolf + Lamb agreed to put out Jaar’s first E.P. and invited him to perform at a somewhat sketchy space called the Marcy Hotel in Williamsburg. At the time, Jaar was a senior at the Lycée Français on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.

headline: The 9.29.13 Issue
text: WE LIKE YOU SO MUCH AND WANT TO KNOW YOU BETTER

headline: Who’s Winning the Architecture Arms Race?
text: Hint: It’s the place spending an estimated $6 billion a year on it.

headline: Autumn of the Jackass
text: At first glance, the old man in the cardigan and the backpack-toting boy sitting on an outdoor bench in a Los Angeles suburb were an image of harmless innocence: just a drowsy octogenarian being looked after by his fidgety grandson. When the old man leaned back, closed his eyes and appeared to nod off, the cherubic child took out a permanent marker and pulled off its cap. With painstaking precision, the boy proceeded to write the word “fart” in thick capital letters on his grandfather’s forehead.

headline: Who Made That Android Logo?
text: Irina Blok may have drawn one of the most recognized logos in the world, but her association with the green Android has not made her famous. Blok can think of only one incident when she garnered the public’s attention for designing it. In 2010, she and her 6-year-old daughter were in a movie theater waiting for “Alice in Wonderland” to begin when an Android logo flashed on the screen. Her daughter, Blok recalls, suddenly stood up and yelled, “My mommy invented that!” Everyone in the row in front of them turned around to stare. Blok was so embarrassed, she says, that she sank down behind her tub of popcorn.

headline: Ahab, Huck and Walt
text: Norman Mailer once said of “The Sopranos” that the “wide canvas” associated with the Great American Novel was “moving to television.” “The Wire” has been compared to the work of Dickens. So it makes sense that literary types were following along on Twitter when “Breaking Bad” wrapped up on Sept. 29.

headline: Sports
text: AMERICAN PASTIMESThe Very Best of Red SmithEdited by Daniel Okrent  Library of America, $29.95.

headline: Inside the List
text: Ode to Meat: As Ron Swanson, the gruff parks director on NBC’s sitcom “Parks and Recreation,” Nick Offerman plays America’s cuddliest libertarian outside Rand Paul. (Inside Rand Paul it’s too dark, Groucho Marx never said.) How much overlap exists between Offerman and his character? It’s a question the actor — who grew up on an Illinois farm, loves woodworking and deplores the increasingly “soft” temperament of his hometown — invites in his autobiography, “Paddle Your Own Canoe,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SAN MIGUEL,  by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Penguin, $16.) In Boyle’s mesmerizing 14th novel, two utopians from different eras — Will Waters, a veteran of the Civil War, and later, Herbie Lester, a World War I veteran — establish private idylls on the desolate Channel Islands off the California coast. As these men pursue dreams of freedom and self-reliance, their wives grapple with the hardships of raising a family in brutal isolation.

headline: It’s Not Just Political Districts. Our News Is Gerrymandered, Too.
text: I read an interview this last week with someone who gets his news from a narrow band of information providers.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: PERV: The Sexual Deviant in All of Us,  by Jesse Bering. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Melissophilia, climacophilia, titillagnia: Bering provocatively examines notions of deviance and the wide- ranging triggers of human desire.

headline: International Arrivals
text: Whether they’re arriving by boat, plane or a great gust of wind, characters in three new picture books find themselves in unknown territory. Their stories focus not on the voyage over but on the complex journey that begins upon arrival, as they learn how to navigate a puzzling new world until it gradually turns into a place that feels like home. While many children’s books about the experience of immigration are rooted in particular cultures and histories, all three of these books emphasize the universal aspects of acclimating to the unfamiliar.

headline: Thrills and Chills
text: Where would teenage mysteries be without idiotic antics like going down to the docks alone late at night or opening haunted lockets? And where would Victorian London be without Undead motifs like fog and Scotland Yard? In two new middle-grade novels, Colleen Gleason and Jonathan Stroud have vamped up the familiar world of Holmes and Watson — and Scooby-Doo and Nancy Drew — to paranormally exhilarating effect.

headline: Views of the Rebellion
text: The slow crackup of China’s last imperial dynasty during its “century of humiliation” was so fantastical it could have been made up by a comic book artist: an aspiring civil servant failed his entrance exam, fell into a delirium, dreamed he was the younger brother of Jesus Christ sent to deliver China from the Qing dynasty and ignited the Taiping Rebellion in 1850. Twenty million people died in the ensuing chaos. In the late 1890s, peasants from the north, affronted by Western influence in the empire, formed a secret society to practice the martial and spiritual disciplines of Chinese folk religion, which some believed made them invulnerable to European bullets and cannon fire. The belief did not survive the test of experience, but did earn the Boxer Rebellion an enduring place in popular memory.

headline: Selling a Hoarder’s Home: The Trouble With Stuff
text: The one-bedroom condo on Park Avenue was described by the broker, Jeffrey Tanenbaum of Halstead Property, as a “hoarder’s paradise, with seven cats, one dog and 12 armoires packed to the brim.”

headline: Catsaway
text: Even for two cats lucky enough to be born in the fishing port of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, in its 19th-century heyday, the usual rules of sibling rivalry apply. “Don’t be a chicken, be a cat! Be adventurous!” Cecil, hearty and omnivorous, taunts his brother Anton, who would rather doze off to sea chanteys than chase rodents. But when Anton is pressed into service as a mouser on the bark Mary Anne, he’s forced to exert himself as never before. Cecil, hoping to catch up with his brother, stows away aboard another ship and finds he is not always as popular at sea as he was at home.

headline: The Killer Went Postal
text: Jayne Anne Phillips is not sentimental. From her debut story collection, “Black Tickets,” right through to the extraordinary novel “Lark and Termite,” her fiction teems with missed chances and tough luck, and her characters — even the children — are resilient hard cases. So about 50 pages into “Quiet Dell,” Phillips’s latest novel, any reader familiar with her work might wonder if there’s some trick afoot, maybe even a case of identity theft.

headline: Pride, Prejudice and Drudgery
text: Beloved books like “Pride and Prejudice” or “Gone With the Wind,” or books left unfinished like “The Mystery of Edwin Drood,” have always prompted efforts to imagine a continuing life for their characters. We cling to them in hopes that some of the qualities of Austen or Mitchell or Dickens can be recaptured, restoring our sense of delight, maintaining the mysterious bond that returns us to Mrs. Bennet declaring that “Netherfield Park is let at last” or Scarlett O’Hara deciding to wait until tomorrow to think about her problems. Alas, with few exceptions, these efforts rarely satisfy.

headline: Today in Small Business: An Entrepreneur for Halloween
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Talk of the Townies
text: In his 2004 introduction to Barry Hannah’s story collection “Airships,” Richard Ford noted that writers like Donald Barthelme and Gertrude Stein “banged themselves and their sentences against conventional and intransigent American prose syntax, grammar and diction, with often unsustained results — failing most often to express the matter at hand.” The distinguishing mark of literary greatness, Ford suggested, remains the combination of the two: a fresh sentence-level flair and a rigorous focus on the story at hand. Yet he mentioned only a handful of writers who have managed it: William Faulkner, Alice Munro, Raymond Carver and of course Hannah himself.

headline: Foreign Indiscretions
text: “I can’t believe she did a cartwheel,” Lily Hayes’s mother laments almost halfway through Jennifer DuBois’s psychologically astute second novel, which takes not only its title but its controlling metaphor from this gymnastic feat. The cartwheel in question — performed during an interrogation in a Buenos Aires police station — is so amazingly tone-deaf it ends up casting Lily as the killer of her beautiful American roommate, Katy Kellers, stabbed to death while Lily was navel-gazing in the night without a solid alibi.

headline: No Faith in Progress
text: The name Karl Kraus means little to German speakers anymore, and less to most Americans. So why has a celebrated contemporary American novelist brought out an annotated translation of two literary essays by this Viennese satirist who was born when Ulysses Grant was in the White House and died before Franklin Roosevelt completed his first presidential term? The full answer comes only toward the end of Jonathan Franzen’s engrossing, highly original volume. But that slow burn is part of his purpose. As a declared enemy of the easy response in an instant-access culture, Franzen finds in the unduly neglected Kraus a model of how to provoke readers while at the same time getting them to do some work.

headline: Killing Giants
text: To judge by “David and Goliath,” Malcolm Gladwell’s favorite word is “we.” In fact, it’s been his favorite word since his first book, “The Tipping Point,” launched his enormously successful career writing about how the world doesn’t necessarily work the way “we” think it does.

headline: Earth Control
text: If we wanted to bring about the extinction of the human race as quickly as possible, how might we proceed? We could begin by destroying the planet’s atmosphere, making it incapable of supporting human life. We could invent bombs capable of obliterating the entire planet, and place them in the hands of those desperate enough to detonate them. We could bioengineer our main food sources — rice, wheat and corn — in such a way that a single disease could bring about catastrophic famine. But the most effective measure, counterintuitive as it may be, would be to increase our numbers. Population is what economists call a multiplier. The more people, the greater the likelihood of ecological collapse, nuclear war, plague.

headline: Spies Like Us
text: In the aftermath of 9/11, the New York Police Department began regarding Islamic “houses of worship — and everyone who prayed there — as possible criminal organizations,” Matt Apuzzo and Adam Goldman tell us in “Enemies Within.” For that reason, those houses of worship get special attention from officers in the department’s intelligence unit.

headline: Special Forces
text: Particular military strategies become identified with particular wars, often giving rise to confusion about whether the war’s outcome is due to the strategy or to something else. Debates persist, for example, about how much credit David Petraeus’s counterinsurgency strategy should get for the temporary de-escalation of violence in Iraq several years ago. Now the United States is out of Iraq, and the war in Afghanistan has come to be seen as the embodiment of counterinsurgency.

headline: The Gun Report: October 11, 2013
text: A man charged with killing a bystander in Columbia, S.C., has been granted immunity from prosecution after citing the state’s Stand Your Ground Act. In the early morning hours of April 17, 2010, an S.U.V. filled with teenage boys had been threatening Shannon Scott’s 15-year-old daughter, driving by their home and firing a gun. Shortly after, Darrel Niles, 17, a high school basketball player, drove by, and mistakenly believing Niles was involved with the earlier menacing, Scott, 33, shot him in the head with a .380 bullet, killing him instantly.

headline: New Chapter, Old Story
text: In “The Devil That Never Dies,” Daniel Jonah Goldhagen reports that there has been a worldwide rise in lethal anti-­Semitism. If he had to pick a role model for the new generation of Jew-haters, he might settle on an elderly Sunni cleric named Yusuf al-Qaradawi.

headline: Bookshelf: Meow
text: New picture books about cats, including David Wiesner’s “Mr. Wuffles!,” in which a house cat’s silly name belies his predatory nature.

headline: Bookshelf: Meow
text: BITS AND PIECES  Written and illustrated by Judy Schachner.  32 pp. Dial. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

headline: Bookshelf: Trunk Show
text: New picture books about elephants, including Michael Slack’s “Elecopter.”

headline: The Fox Says, ‘I Can Make You Famous’
text: Studio 6A, the Rockefeller Plaza home of NBC’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” was filled with artificial smoke and laser lights when Bard and Vegard Ylvisaker arrived. These Norwegian brothers, who had spent the previous days traveling from Oslo to London to New York, did not seem to be particularly fazed as they surveyed their surroundings, which included a squad of dancers in fox masks and makeup, two long rows of full-length mirrors and a man dressed in a head-to-toe horse costume.

headline: Bookshelf: Trunk Show
text: ELECOPTER  Written and illustrated by Michael Slack.  32 pp. Christy Ottaviano Books/Henry Holt & Company. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: Mass Evacuations as Cyclone Phailin Nears India’s East Coast
text: Officials in Orissa and the northern part of the adjoining Andhra Pradesh state, scrambled Friday to evacuate thousands of people from the coastline as a major cyclone headed for landfall from the Bay of Bengal.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jonathan Franzen’s ‘Kraus Project’
text: This week, Jonathan Franzen discusses his “Kraus Project”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alan Weisman talks about “Countdown”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review
text: This week, Jonathan Franzen and Alan Weisman.

headline: Ylvis and the New Clout of Novelty Pop
text: Dave Itzkoff and Ben Ratliff discuss the YouTube explosion of “The Fox.”

headline: Concerto for Piano and YouTube
text: Visitors browsing through the YouTube channel of the pianist Valentina Lisitsa can watch her in hundreds of videos. There are live webcams of her practicing at her home in North Carolina, long blonde hair tossing and brow furrowed in concentration as she reads through new works. There she is in a red gown playing Schumann’s “Traumerei” at a concert in Seoul, and recording Rachmaninoff’s Concerto No. 3 at the Abbey Road Studios in London.

headline: It’s No Longer the Economy, Stupid
text: It’s no longer the economy, stupid — it’s the government.

headline: Popcast: Ylvis and the New Clout of Novelty Pop
text: This week: the chart semiotics of a novelty hit.

headline: A Bridge Between Western Science and Eastern Faith
text: ATLANTA — Quantum theory tells us that the world is a product of an infinite number of random events. Buddhism teaches us that nothing happens without a cause, trapping the universe in an unending karmic cycle.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jonathan Franzen’s ‘Kraus Project’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Edmund Fawcett reviews Jonathan Franzen’s “Kraus Project,” in which Mr. Franzen translates and annotates the work of Karl Kraus, the Viennese satirist of technology and modernity. Mr. Fawcett writes:

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Captain Phillips,’ ‘CBGB’ and ‘Romeo & Juliet’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Captain Phillips,” “CBGB” and “Romeo & Juliet.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Parents Offer Best Advice to Steer Clear of Teenage Drinking
text: This past week’s topic for New Parent/Old Parent was teenage drinking and how to deal with it as a parent (and there were comments). The first thing that struck me was that in all my time moderating reader comments, I can’t remember so many as lengthy and nuanced — an indication, I think, on how complex and difficult the issue is and how much it can vary from child to child and from family to family. I was also touched by how many of the responses conveyed a sense of parental humility. I have worked hard to be a very good parent, but boy, did I fail on this front … a lot.

headline: In a Bid for Men’s Wearhouse, a Merger Battle With Modern Strategies
text: On Wednesday, the first volleys of a war started when Men’s Wearhouse issued a news release rejecting a $2.3 billion takeover offer from Jos. A. Bank Clothiers. For spectators, it is not only a battle to watch for its outcome but also for how hostile takeovers have evolved.

headline: A Bash Brother Returns to St. Louis, Wearing Dodger Blue
text: ST. LOUIS — During a team workout Thursday afternoon at Busch Stadium, Mark McGwire, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ hitting coach, stood near the batting cage surrounded by reporters eager to gauge his feelings about his return here to face the Cardinals in the National League Championship Series, which begins Friday night.

headline: Spain to Proceed With Indictment of China’s Ex-President
text: MADRID — Spain’s national court has approved the indictment of Hu Jintao, the former Chinese president, as part of an investigation into whether the Chinese government tortured and repressed the people of Tibet as part of an attempted genocide.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Limbaugh Reads the Polls
text: Via The Atlantic

headline: Detained American’s Mother Visits Him in North Korea
text: The mother of Kenneth Bae, an American Christian missionary serving a 15-year term of hard labor in North Korea’s penal system, visited him for 90 minutes in a “very emotional reunion” on Friday at a Pyongyang hospital where he has been convalescing since the summer because of poor health and severe weight loss, Mr. Bae’s sister reported on Friday.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Montreal; Key West, Fla.; California
text: Beat Nation: Art, Hip Hop and Aboriginal Culture, Montreal An exhibition of contemporary aboriginal art, above, will be at the Musée d’Art Contemporain de Montréal from Oct. 17 to Jan. 5. Beat Nation will feature painting, sculpture, installation, performance and video works that reflect the juxtaposition of urban culture with traditional identity, according to the show’s organizers. Performances, tours, gallery talks and workshops planned in collaboration with aboriginal artists are scheduled.

headline: Tributes for Seamus Heaney Are Planned
text: The poet Seamus Heaney, who died in August at age 74, will be honored next month at several free public events in New York.

headline: When Having a Nanny Cam Isn’t Enough
text: HAVING recently hired a new nanny, I received a refresher course in running a miniature human resources department. It’s a costly process filled with terror to varying degrees — from being sure you’ve picked the right person to complying with labor, wage and tax laws that are easy to run afoul of.

headline: Are Competing Bankruptcy Plans a Good Thing?
text: As LightSquared’s creditors get prepared to consider which of four reorganization plans to vote for, it bears noting how much Chapter 11 has been changed by the 2005 amendments to the bankruptcy code.

headline: Many Tune In to a Sad Night on ‘Glee’
text: Though it was hardly what the show or the Fox network would ever have wanted, Thursday’s episode of “Glee” — which dealt with the death of the character played by Cory Monteith, the star who died of a drug overdose in July — lifted that series to its best ratings in a year.

headline: A Familiar Look From 2(x)ist
text: In an article in the Thursday Styles section several months ago, headlined “Less Ab. More Flab,” my colleague Eric Wilson wrote of how increasing numbers of underwear companies were toning down their advertising — flashing less flesh and featuring more realistically shaped models than the god-like specimens who flaunt their startling good looks from any number of billboards and bus shelters around the city.

headline: Movie Review: 'Romeo & Juliet'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Romeo & Juliet.”

headline: Movie Review: 'CBGB'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "CBGB."

headline: ‘Bed and a Chair’ Finds Its Leading Men
text: A jazz-inflected celebration of the songs of Stephen Sondheim has signed its leading men: the Tony nominees Norm Lewis (“The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess”) and Jeremy Jordan (“Newsies”).

headline: Image of the Day: October 11
text: Hindu festival of Durga Puja being celebrated in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: A Theologian’s Influence, and Stained Past, Live On
text: Can a bad person be a good theologian?

headline: Up Is Down: Republicans Defend D.C.
text: In their strategy of cherry picking popular programs to exclude from the federal government shutdown, House Republicans were particularly gleeful in approving a proposal to make an exception so that the District of Columbia city government can fund its budget.

headline: Strong Demand for Royal Mail Stock May Not Translate to Lloyds Shares
text: The Lloyds Banking Group shouldn’t get too cocky after the sharp rise in Royal Mail’s shares. Lloyds, a state-backed British bank, may be tempted to focus its next share sale entirely on retail customers after strong demand sent the postal service’s shares up 36 percent in their first few hours of trading. But the differences between a secondary offering from Lloyds and Royal Mail’s primary one warrant a different approach.

headline: Movie Review: 'Captain Phillips'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Captain Phillips."

headline: Follow the Tracks of the Crime Drama
text: It says a lot about the current cultural pre-eminence of television that the Museum of Modern Art is promoting Mikko Niskanen’s “Eight Deadly Shots” — a five-and-a-quarter-hour film made as a mini-series for Finnish TV in 1972 — as a forerunner of “The Wire,” “Breaking Bad” and “The Killing.”

headline: At Citi, Pandit Is Gone but Is Still Serving the Bank’s Shareholders
text: Michael L. Corbat is approaching his first anniversary as chief executive of Citigroup. The bank’s chairman, Michael E. O’Neill, installed him after organizing a putsch to oust Vikram Pandit as C.E.O. The new boss has accelerated some cost cuts and clarified strategy around the edges, but the broad direction is still Mr. Pandit’s. Either way, it is serving shareholders well.

headline: Making Tracks With a New Old Sound
text: There are very few pop musicians under the age of Dolly Parton who wouldn’t bristle at being called “old-fashioned,” and yet the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter Diane Birch understands that her biography and music could lead someone to believe that she may possess such qualities.

headline: United Has a High-Minded New Magazine
text: United Airlines’ latest attempt to polish its first-class service doesn’t involve flat-bed seats or on-demand television. Instead, United is appealing to the intellectual senses of its elite travelers, with Rhapsody, a monthly literary and luxury lifestyle magazine edited by Ink Publishing, the in-flight media company.

headline: A Sun Rises on a Plunge Into Abstraction
text: BOCHUM, Germany — The audience members had gathered in the darkness at 4.30 a.m. in the Cour d’Honneur of the Palais des Papes in Avignon, France. When Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s “Cesena” began, with a screaming man running in a circle, they couldn’t at first see anything. Then, as dancers and singers arrived onstage, and the unearthly sounds of the polyphonic medieval music known as ars subtilior filled the air, the sun rose, slowly revealing the performers. By the end, everyone was bathed in the morning light.

headline: Darkness Falls; Still, She Sings
text: When it comes to musicals, Selma, the heroine of “Dancer in the Dark” (2000), prefers Hollywood to Vladivostok — or so we’re told when she’s on trial for murder. This may not be true of Lars von Trier, whose movie seems to reference, in its song-and-dance sequences, Soviet films as much as American ones.

headline: High School Classmate Reflects on Yellen
text: Charles Saydeh reflects on his junior high and high school classmate, Janet Yellen.

headline: What Has All This Done to Us?
text: This week brings an ambitious show that should be required viewing for anyone who is curious — and that should be everyone — about the ways digitalization affects, facilitates, improves, inspires and sometimes ruins various forms of visual culture. “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital” which opens on Tuesday at the Museum of Arts and Design, will present the efforts of some 80 architects, designers and artists from 20 countries, with the designers in the majority. Presenting digital-dependent work from the last decade, displays will run the gamut from life-changing (if not saving) to frivolous, among them dinnerware, sports shoes, furnishings, clothing, buildings and various forms of three-dimensional art. Those represented include Bathsheba Grossman, Greg Lynn, Marc Newson, Magnus Larsson, Roxy Paine, Frank Stella, Zaha Hadid and J. Mayer H. Architects (whose seemingly astounding Metropol Parasol, completed in 2011, spans a plaza in the old quarter of Seville, Spain). The show may harbor a bit much in the way of jewelry and bad art, and most of the buildings will be represented by photographs, but new and useful information should compensate. (Through July 6, 2 Columbus Circle, 212-299-7777, madmuseum.org)

headline: Some Stones Shine Brighter
text: A jewelry store is generally a staid, rather somber place, reminiscent of a museum or library. But a jewel’s journey to reach a glass case can have a considerably livelier start.

headline: Prizewinner, and So Much More
text: “I don’t really call myself a composer,” Caroline Shaw told Zachary Woolfe in an interview in The New York Times in April. Earlier in the week, a Pulitzer Prize jury had begged to differ, making Ms. Shaw, at the age of 30, the youngest-ever winner of the music prize, for her “Partita for Eight Voices.” Ms. Shaw, for her part, prefers to think of herself as a musician: She sings as a soprano in Roomful of Teeth, the dynamic a cappella ensemble for which she wrote “Partita,” and plays violin in the American Contemporary Music Ensemble, also known as ACME.

headline: There’s Beauty in All This Mess
text: David Dorfman Dance is plunging with abandon into themes of time, memory and fear in “Come, and Back Again,” which comments on matters like the eccentricities of family life, the resilience of the human spirit and what Mr. Dorfman calls “the beauty of our personal messes.” For the elaborate production, the Brooklyn sculptor Jonah Emerson Bell has designed a large wall, built from refuse, personal mementos and found objects, on which portraits by Caledonia Curry will be projected.

headline: Activity Does Not Always Equal Productivity
text: In all likelihood, you get more done today than you ever have before. That’s mostly because you can do so much more, so much faster, wherever you are, through e-mail, texting, instant-messaging, Twitter and posting.

headline: Combine Sounds; Hear What Happens
text: Ben Vida played acoustic guitar and trumpet in the Chicago minimalist quartet Town & Country, which for nearly 10 years used repetition, drones and delicate, drumless sonorities to get to intense places carefully, like post-prog chamber music, or a Slint-Morton Feldman collaboration.

headline: A Headstand Without a Helmet? The Postal Service Halts ‘Just Move’ Stamps
text: “Let’s Move!”

headline: Peas in a Vintage-Soul-Style Pod
text: Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig are not sisters, or even related in any way, but they have been merrily twinned as the frontwomen of the indie band Lucius for nearly a decade. Both 28, they met as students at the Berklee College of Music and then, post-graduation, moved to Brooklyn in 2007 to forge a musical career. “We knew we wanted to work together and sing together and write together,” Ms. Laessig said. “But we were just kind of experimental, and that’s why it took so long to come into what we are now.” After assembling a band through friends and neighbors, their first album as a five-piece, “Wildewoman,” is due Tuesday from Mom + Pop Music. But their act — with Andrew Burri, Peter Lalish and Ms. Wolfe’s husband, Dan Molad, on drums, guitars and bass — has already earned fans for its girl-group harmonies and resourceful rhythms; for their Tiny Desk concert on NPR, they turned an empty cashew container into a drum. They’ve performed with Wilco, and worked as jingle writers and in commercials. (Those were their voices in the Mercedes ad with Willem Dafoe broadcast during the “Breaking Bad” finale.)

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: After years of struggle and strife, the citizens of Serbia’s war-torn capital are recasting their home into a burgeoning hub for design, culture and creativity.

headline: On the Verge | Belgrade, Europe’s Latest Urban Success Story
text: After years of struggle and strife, the citizens of Serbia’s war-torn capital are recasting their home into a burgeoning hub for design, culture and creativity.

headline: On View: No It Is by William Kentridge
text: Kentridge presents a triptych of films: “Workshop Receipts,” “The Anatomy of Melancholy,” and “Practical Enquiries,” all of which feature animated images on top of flipbooks.

headline: Big Ticket | River Views for $9.495 Million
text: A glass aerie with 10-foot ceilings, ebony floors and sweeping views of the Hudson River, the Statue of Liberty and the George Washington Bridge from its 14th-story perch on the southwest corner of the Superior Ink building sold for $9.495 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Hulu Is Said to Pick a New Chief Executive
text: The owners of the online streaming service Hulu are preparing to appoint Mike Hopkins, a veteran of Fox Networks, to be the next chief executive.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Video Report Bolsters Claims of Summary Executions of Civilians by Syrian Rebels
text: As my colleague Anne Barnard reports, an investigation from Human Rights Watch released on Friday bolsters claims that Syrian rebels conducted a massacre of civilians in August in Latakia, the heartland of President Bashar al-Assad’s ruling Alawite sect.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Schools Fear Shutdown’s Threat to Lunch Programs
text: WASHINGTON — The National School Lunch and Breakfast Program could soon be a casualty of the partial government shutdown, leaving millions of children without an important source of nutrition, a group representing school nutrition workers warned Congress on Friday.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Completely Ready or Not, Steve Mills Takes Charge of Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — In September 2009, only months after leaving a high-ranking post at Madison Square Garden, Steve Mills returned to Princeton, his alma mater, to teach a freshman seminar with Harold A. Feiveson, a professor who specializes in nuclear weapons and energy policy.

headline: Pakistani Girl, a Global Heroine After an Attack, Has Critics at Home
text: SWAT VALLEY, Pakistan — The question for the class of 10th graders at an all-girls school here in this picturesque mountain valley was a simple one: How many of them, a district official wanted to know, had heard of Malala Yousafzai?

headline: Portuguese, Right Down to the Olives
text: Fado is a treat: a charming restaurant with the best Portuguese food I’ve ever had (including during recent meals in Portugal). On my first visit to this three-year-old Huntington restaurant, I spent the night kicking myself for not having come sooner.

headline: Bill Weir Leaving ABC for CNN
text: The former “Nightline” anchor Bill Weir will join CNN next month in an as-yet- undefined anchor role as well being as the network’s chief “innovation correspondent,” covering developments in the technology world.

headline: United Nations Human Rights Chief Condemns Mass Executions in Iraq
text: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, on Friday condemned Iraq’s execution of 42 prisoners over two days this week, denouncing such mass executions as “obscene and inhuman” and warning that they undermine efforts to reduce violence and achieve a more stable society.

headline: Homage to the Vegetable and the Local
text: Dennis Foy, the onetime lord of Tarragon Tree, the ’70s and ’80s destination restaurant in Chatham that helped give birth to the farm-to-fine-dining aesthetic, celebrates the vegetable and the local at his year-old restaurant in Lambertville.

headline: Jets’ Willie Colon Attends to His South Bronx Roots
text: The quarter-mile strip of asphalt and concrete connects the pillars of Willie Colon’s life in the South Bronx. It does not have an official name. It is an access road that branches off Concourse Village East, a road that is now paved, not covered in dirt and dust and gravel as it was more than a decade ago, when it bridged the chaos of Colon’s neighborhood and the structure of his school.

headline: Honeymoon in Vegas
text: Tony Danza stars in this new musical at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

headline: G.O.P. Helps Americans Like Government
text: There’s a lot of terrible news for Republicans inside the new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, but one of the worst bulletins is this: Americans are becoming more appreciative of government.

headline: Cruz Is Heckled During Speech
text: While speaking at the Voter Values Summit, an annual gathering of social conservatives, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was repeatedly interrupted by protesters.

headline: Doughboy in Love and Battle
text: At this moment, there’s probably no better way of dispelling the tiresome myth that silent films were technically and dramatically crude than by directing skeptics to the radiant new Blu-ray of “The Big Parade” from Warner Home Video. Directed by King Vidor, and originally released by MGM in November 1925, this tale of three buddies caught up in what then was called the Great War was one of the most financially successful films of the silent era. It played for almost two years at the Astor Theater in New York and enjoyed similar success worldwide.

headline: From Ring-a-Ding Swagger to Swooning Romanticism
text: MILLBURN, N.J. — Many a tut has been tutted in recent years over the contamination of Broadway by the spirit of Las Vegas, the world capital of the flashy, boozy floor show. So I am happy to report that you can score one for Team Broadway. The delightfully unexpected “Honeymoon in Vegas,” which opened this week at the Paper Mill Playhouse here, has wrestled the neon mirage of its title into the solid, satisfying shape of a classic Broadway musical.

headline: Days After Disaster, Another Migrant Ship Sinks Near Italian Island
text: ROME — A ship filled with migrants apparently trying to reach Europe capsized in the Mediterranean Sea on Friday about 100 nautical miles southwest of the island nation of Malta, sending rescue boats and helicopters racing to the scene, officials said. At least 206 passengers were rescued, and 27 bodies were recovered.

headline: Assured That It’s Just Meant to Be
text: When she met a schoolmate, Alejandro de Castro, in 1992, Carly Brien instantly thought, wow, was he handsome — well, as third graders go.

headline: Glaad Sees Improvement in Depictions of Gays and Lesbians on TV
text: No television network is “excellent” when it comes to representations of gays and lesbians, but most of the nation’s biggest networks earn a grade of “good,” Glaad, formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, said in a study released on Friday.

headline: The Culture Paradox of 21st-Century New York
text: Last week The Guardian  published an essay by the singer-songwriter David Byrne, which received a fair amount of attention online, arriving under the headline “If the 1% Stifles New York’s Creative Talent, I’m Out of Here.”

headline: Artists on Artists | William Kentridge on the Subtle Drama of the Indian Minimalist Nasreen Mohamedi
text: The South African artist William Kentridge is best known for creating low-tech animated films, often based on charcoal drawings, that explore the painful effects of apartheid. He describes his current show (“Second-hand Reading,” at Marian Goodman Gallery through Oct. 26) as being about “the excess of making.” Filled with drawings of trees, people and text made on the pages of old encyclopedias, the show also includes several animated videos and sculptural sound pieces, including one built from drums and percussion instruments and another that transforms old sewing machines into a hand-cranked phonograph.

headline: A Ransacked Endowment at New York City Opera
text: A fundamental premise of successful investing is “sell high, buy low.” So what explains the New York City Opera board’s decision to do the opposite?

headline: Michael Shvo Is Back, and as Brash as Ever
text: At the height of the real estate boom, the broker Michael Shvo brashly coined the phrase “Let’s Shvo” to define his style of marketing. That meant 24-hour sales offices, parties featuring red carpets and leggy models, and aggressive selling tactics that some considered questionable.

headline: A Healthy Relationship All Around
text: There are many ways to measure the heart of Shelley Yeffet Wininger.

headline: Weekend Wheels Calendar
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: An Unusual Coalition Presses for End to Shutdown
text: Shutdowns make strange bedfellows. Case in point: A letter released Friday from the Chamber of Commerce, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United Way urging Congress to reach a budget deal.

headline: Activision Closes Deal for Most of Vivendi’s Stake
text: Thanks to a court’s timely intervention, the video game maker Activision Blizzard closed its deal on Friday to buy a majority of Vivendi’s stake in the company for $8.2 billion.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 11
text: Pictures include the filming of a new sitcom, “Brooklyn Taxi”; a march over the Brooklyn Bridge; and a real estate developer at the top of his newest tower.

headline: Netanyahu Takes a Lonely Stance Denouncing Iran
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the son of a historian, often complains to his inner circle that “people have a historical memory that goes back to breakfast.”

headline: A Tale of Two Sport Sedans
text: The IS 250 and IS 350, redesigned for 2014, take the Lexus performance sedan back toward its sporty origins — with different degrees of success.

headline: A Novel Way to Sidle Up to the High Line
text: There are apartment buildings near, along and even touching the High Line. And now there will be one, underneath, at least partly.

headline: Making Portraits Together
text: Harvey Stein, whose latest book is “Harlem Street Portraits,” has been photographing Harlem for more than two decades and has witnessed its evolutions.

headline: Following Kerouac Through Mexico
text: The writer visited Mexico in the 1950s and ’60s to experience greater freedom.

headline: Concern Grows for Jailed Pussy Riot Member
text: Updated, 6:43 p.m. | Lawyers have been granted access to Ms. Tolokonnikova, a spokesperson for the Voice Project said on Friday afternoon. “The family are still being restricted, but Nadya is O.K.,” Hunter Heaney said by e-mail, expressing relief that Ms. Tolokonnikova had been able to visit with her lawyers in Mordovia.

headline: Finance Class on the Web, for Students of All Ages
text: In an ideal world, a master class available to everyone would reveal all the secrets to retirement planning, telling you how much to save, where to invest and what to do when the stock market crashes.

headline: Kerouac’s Mexico
text: I found Jack Kerouac’s Mexico on a strip of beach that separated the old hotels from the heaving Pacific, at a bar near where he sat on the sea wall and watched the sunset 61 years ago.

headline: Weekend Reading: Wall Street’s View of the Fiscal Crisis
text: As the budget shutdown in Washington continued, investors on Wall Street faced criticism that calm markets were encouraging House Republicans and making a default more likely. Here’s a look at what some of the experts are saying about the fiscal crisis.

headline: Coins Celebrating Pope Misspell Name Above All Names
text: ROME — It seems absurd that any official Vatican memorabilia would misspell the name Jesus. Or that the Italian institute that mints coins, passports and postage stamps would make such an error. And yet the fact remains: a new series of special commemorative coins honoring Pope Francis got it wrong.

headline: Review: 2014 Lexus IS 350 AWD
text: Lexus is known for coddling, not sport sedans. The 2014 IS 350 is designed to change that. Can it lure buyers away from Audi, BMW, Cadillac and Mercedes? Tom Voelk checks out an AWD model to find out.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Bulgaria, the West Bank and Pakistan.

headline: Green Goddess Roasted Chicken
text: Green Goddess dressing is good for salad but can be even better as a marinade for the mildness of roast chicken.

headline: Who’s on Line First?
text: October baseball is known to be extremely competitive, especially for fans who have vied for good World Series tickets through the years.

headline: Back to the Bronx With Willie Colon
text: Willie Colon, the Jets’ right guard who was raised in the South Bronx and recently revisited his old neighborhood, is intensely proud of where he grew up.

headline: Chicken Offered to the Green Goddess
text: My mother learned how to marinate chicken in spiced yogurt from Madhur Jaffrey’s famous tandoori recipe.

headline: 2010 Yellen Senate Confirmation Hearing
text: Excerpts from the 2010 Senate confirmation hearing of Janet L. Yellen, after her nomination as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: Who’s on Line First?
text: Major League Baseball’s semifinals, otherwise known as the League Championship Series, begin Friday night in St. Louis, with the Cardinals hosting the Los Angeles Dodgers. The other side of the bracket, the Boston Red Sox versus the Detroit Tigers, will begin Saturday. Do you have tickets to any of the games?

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Fending Off Foreclosure With Rock ’n’ Roll
text: A 40-year-old man sings “I slept with your mother” to a horrified buddy from high school. A rabbi break-dances in an exhilarating hip-hop version of “Hava Nagila.” A “Welcome to Sayreville, N.J.” sign gets entrance applause when it is rolled onstage.

headline: Living in the Wild Wild Northeast
text: From the Princeton Town Topics, which used to be all about (a) parking (b) deer:

headline: A Two-Level Approach to Protecting Riders’ Head in Impacts
text: There are mishaps that no rider, regardless of how skilled, could avoid. But if that rider knew exactly what kind of accident it was going to be, an engineer could build the ideal helmet to withstand it.

headline: Dodge Fires Off a Retro Rocket
text: TESTED Dodge Charger SRT8 Super Bee.

headline: An Early American, Ready to Try Again
text: BRIAN HEAD, UTAH — On Sept. 17, 2003, an all-new model from the Indian Motorcycle Company of America was delivered to me for a review.

headline: Kaleidoscope of Chords
text: During an onstage interview halfway through a concert on Thursday night at the Miller Theater at Columbia University, the conductor Brad Lubman asked the composer Georg Friedrich Haas how he had become interested in writing microtonal music. It was a simple question that might have occurred to anyone in the hall. Mr. Haas’s works, some of which have become staples of the contemporary repertory, make striking use of sounds that lurk between the semitone steps of the conventional Western scale.

headline: A Redesign That Hits or Misses
text: Lexus knows its audience.

headline: 20 Years Later at the New York Film Festival, Still ‘Dazed and Confused’
text: It may make some members of Generation X feel that much less youthful to know that Richard Linklater’s high school comedy “Dazed and Confused” is celebrating its 20th anniversary. But the film, set in 1976, always felt a little like a movie from another era. On Thursday night, Mr. Linklater shared his own 35-millimeter print  with a New York Film Festival audience that ranged from longtime fans to those new to the film.

headline: Friday Night Music: Shovels and Rope
text: People have been recommending this couple, and they are indeed a joy:

headline: Every Time a Postman Rings ...
text: There was “Touched by an Angel,” and now comes “Signed, Sealed, Delivered,” so named, presumably, because someone realized that “Touched by a Postal Carrier” might send the wrong message.

headline: They Like the Cars, but Love the Engines
text: REDWOOD CITY, CALIF. — No doubt there are devoted followers of most any automotive make or model, no matter how obscure. But now that like-minded enthusiasts can connect so easily online, the clubs dedicated to those long-gone marques find it easier to assemble their congregations of the faithful.

headline: Evolution and Bad Boyfriends
text: THROUGHOUT history and in societies all over the world, parents have tried to influence the love lives of their children — with mixed success. Parents and children frequently don’t see eye to eye on what makes a suitable partner, as studies across cultures have confirmed.

headline: Six Pack
text: The unlikely object of affection at the center of one club of enthusiasts is an obsolete 6-cylinder engine that Chrysler stopped using in the 1980s.

headline: Ethiopia: Land of Dust, Eucalyptus and Hope
text: I had already spent the last few hours watching Haftay hopscotch up the gravel path toward whatever it was that lay on the other side of the ridge. My guide, Mulualem Gebremedhin, and I had spent most of the day — the first of three we would spend hiking together in eastern Tigray on Ethiopia’s northern border — lagging several steps behind Haftay, a local villager accompanying us on the first leg of our trip.

headline: Moving Into a New MacBook Air
text: Q. I have a MacBook Air running Snow Leopard (Mac OS X 10.6.8) and I am considering buying a new MacBook Air with the Mountain Lion (OS X 10.8) operating system. I have accumulated a large number of files over the years in various applications (notably Microsoft Word and Excel, Pages, Keynote and Keychain) on my current machine. Will I be able to readily move these to the new Mac?

headline: A TV Show That Isn’t Made of Whole Cloth
text: ON TELEVISION, the fashion world rarely shows itself. Instead, with most programs and Webcasts, you get a checklist of compulsory scenes: the nervous, befuddled designer; the delayed fabric order; the world-weary “you’re toast” looks from the pros; a meltdown or two; and, inevitably, a blast of “Pump Up the Jam,” the 1989 hit.

headline: In Trinidad and Tobago, Wheelchairs for the Water
text: Beachgoers with mobility issues visiting Trinidad and Tobago can now use amphibious wheelchairs at a flagship beach that allow people with disabilities to safely enter the water.

headline: How to Know if You’re a Banana Republic
text: An excerpt from an e-mail to clients from Jonathan Lewis, chief investment officer at Samson Capital Advisors:

headline: An Essentially American Narrative
text: Amid comic book epics, bromantic comedies and sequels of sequels, films about America’s tortured racial history have recently emerged as a surprisingly lucrative Hollywood staple. In the last two years, “The Help,” “Lincoln,""Django Unchained,""42” and “Lee Daniels’ The Butler” have performed well at the box office, gathering awards in some cases and drawing varying degrees of critical acclaim.

headline: A Slower Pace for Walkers and Survivors
text: In the short life of AMC’s zombie-apocalypse series, “The Walking Dead,” the show’s band of survivors has started each season in extremis, on the run and looking for a safe haven. In Season 2 they found it on a farm; in Season 3, driven off the farm, they locked themselves inside a prison.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Miley Cyrus Explains Her Fashion Sense, Nicky Hilton Writes a Book, and Kate Moss Makes Another Comeback
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREOct. 5 – 11

headline: Los Angeles, the City of Dancing Angels
text: Los Angeles is a city that values its beauty sleep. Cocktails clink as early as 5 p.m. Dinner parties start at 7 p.m. And unlike in Miami or New York, bars and clubs peak around 1 a.m., in part because state law bans alcohol from being sold after 2.

headline: Italy vs. Monaco at the Bermuda Bowl in Bali
text: The Bermuda Bowl was the premier event at the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, last month.

headline: A Former Fed Colleague Reminisces
text: Kevin Hassett, now an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, remembers Janet Yellen’s outreach to junior economists at the Federal Reserve.

headline: The Pick of the Apple Orchard
text: Once, I slept in a blooming apple orchard under a full April moon, surrounded by fragrant blossoms as big as saucers.

headline: From Flying Bows to Intent Faces, Verdi Via a Laptop
text: At one moment during the Chicago Symphony Orchestra’s performance of the Verdi Requiem on Thursday evening, conducted by Riccardo Muti and streamed live from Orchestra Hall in Chicago, viewers could see the rosin glistening on a bow during close-up shots of the violinists.

headline: Investigation Moves Slowly in Kenyan Mall Siege
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The crater of rubble where the mall collapsed is still so hot that investigators are having a hard time examining it for clues. None of the bodies of the militants killed in the deadly siege have been clearly identified. Even the four attackers captured on security cameras are being called “pink shirt, white shirt, black shirt, blue shirt,” because investigators are not sure of their real names, said an official who had been briefed on the investigation.

headline: Tim Gunn, a Lucky Guy
text: Mr. Gunn, a recent Emmy Award recipient, has emerged as a breakout star of “Project Runway.”

headline: Weak Bank Revenues Show the Tough Road Back for the Economy
text: Anyone looking for reasons the economy is not growing faster should contemplate the bank earnings that have started to roll in.

headline: Tim Gunn: A Lifetime of Making It Work
text: At Lincoln Center on the second day of New York Fashion Week, Tim Gunn quietly encouraged with a quick hug, a kiss on the cheek or a last-minute word of praise the four contestants who were about to show their final collections to a gathering audience of nearly a thousand invited guests. In turn, the designers smiled back at him, grateful for their mentor’s presence on the day that would determine the Season 12 winner of “Project Runway.”

headline: An Alliance in Media Petitions Justices
text: The nation’s biggest television broadcasters are collectively asking for the Supreme Court’s support in their quest to stop Aereo, a small Internet start-up that threatens some of the underpinnings of the TV business.

headline: A Vigorous Macbeth, Swept Up in the Darkness
text: Given all the blood, gore and spookery that Shakespeare crammed into his shortest tragedy, it’s easy to overproduce “Macbeth.” But the current rendition at Hartford Stage unleashes the play’s terrifying energy by pointedly rejecting theatrical furbelows.

headline: Overscheduled Children: How Big a Problem?
text: Now that the school year is under way, my wife and I are busy managing our children’s after-school schedules, mixing sports practices, music lessons, homework and play dates. It can be a complicated balancing act for our elementary-age daughters, as some days end up overstuffed, some logistically impossible, some wide open. Still, compared to when we were children, the opportunities they get to sample on a weekly basis is mind-blowing.

headline: Psychic Found Guilty of Stealing $138,000 From Clients
text: A jury found a Manhattan psychic guilty on Friday of swindling two women out of $138,000 in a case that probed the fine distinction between providing an unusual service and running a confidence scheme.

headline: 10 Signs Your Parent Is Overscheduled
text: I would like to say I’m calling this “the year of ‘no.’ ” My iPad screen saver is a big, glorious “NO,” emblazoned and encircled in the middle of the screen. “No” is supposed to be my default response to any additional activities for our family, for the children, for me: no to the camp open house, no to taking gymnastics even if you can car pool there lots of the time, no to the speaking engagement, the coffee, the committee. No, no and no.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook’s No. 2 and Instagram’s Man of Vision
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: New Arrest in Inquiry on Art Looting
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office and federal authorities have expanded their investigation into antiquities smuggling by Subhash Kapoor, a longtime Upper East Side art dealer who is accused of selling looted items from India that have ended up in private collections and museums around the world.

headline: Pinstripes, Onstage
text: The costume designer David C. Woolard created Yankee home game uniforms from different eras for Eric Simonson’s new play “Bronx Bombers.”

headline: Diplomacy, Free of Gravity
text: DanceMotion USA, a State Department program produced by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, sends American companies to perform abroad for cultural diplomacy but also arranges collaborations between American troupes and foreign ones.

headline: With Money Tight, Museums Embrace Nudes
text: PARIS — Over the last few weeks, the hottest cultural ticket in this city has been a museum exhibition that confronts viewers with images of a nude man on a cold morgue slab and the rapper Eminem, staring down from the walls of the Musée d’Orsay, naked and brandishing a firecracker in front of his crotch.

headline: The Leaning Tower of Power: Chrysler’s Venerable Slant Six
text: In the Sunday Automobiles section, Dave Wallace writes about an event that he and his wife attended with her red Dodge Dart convertible. Here’s the story behind one of Chrysler’s most famous power plants: the Slant Six.

headline: An Extended Addams Family
text: Gomez, Pugsley, Wednesday and three other members of the Addams Family, represented by heads once worn by circus clowns, greet visitors to the Southampton Center, a new cultural space in the former home of the Parrish Art Museum. Looming in the distance, past freshly painted white walls hung with 66 original drawings by Charles Addams, is a huge banner with a likeness of the mischievous Uncle Fester, a prime member of the whimsically ghoulish family made famous in cartoons in The New Yorker, a recent Broadway musical and television series, movies and books.

headline: Beets for Breakfast, or Dinner
text: Beets are a fall favorite on Well. We’ve put them in smoothies, lasagna and spring rolls. We’ve tried to convert beet skeptics and even let our readers eat beet cake.

headline: At Ralph’s Restaurant, an All-American in Paris
text: On the afternoon of Sept. 23, a few hours after the Giorgio Armani show had signaled the end of Milan Fashion Week, a planeload of very important editors experienced a terrifying moment aboard an Air France flight destined for Paris. According to an item in Page Six that appeared the next morning, the plane “was forced to abort its landing feet from the ground,” and one passenger described the event as “a near-death experience.”

headline: Another ‘Spring,’ and Another Storm to Weather
text: The riot that erupted at the 1913 premiere of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” is legendary. One of the less-well-known details is the performance of the conductor, Pierre Monteux. In Stravinsky’s recollection, Monteux kept his back turned to the brawl and guided the orchestra through this groundbreaking and difficult score “impervious and as nerveless as a crocodile.”

headline: Bookshelf | A Grand Tour of Brooklynized Design
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: New Rule Affects Home Businesses

headline: Economists to Watch for the Nobel Prize
text: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science will be awarded early Monday morning New York time (1 p.m. Swedish time, at the earliest). Every year predictions are made, and the actual winners are not always among the betting pool favorites. (And besides, there are also fewer prominent betting pools available this year.)

headline: Q & A: Medicare and the Insurance Exchanges
text: Shirley Mierzejewski was “very upset” when she found out her Medicare health insurance premiums will nearly double next year.

headline: Sean MacPherson: A Hotelier Recalibrates the Mood
text: “The Waverly Inn was a lie, but it was a good lie,” Sean MacPherson, the restaurateur, hotelier and tastemaker, said recently. He was referring to what is probably his best-known local production, the durably successful and clubby West Village restaurant and celebrity petting zoo where Harvey Weinstein, Sting or Mariah Carey can be spotted tucking into a $55 plate of truffled macaroni and cheese.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Janet L. Yellen is nominated to lead the Federal Reserve, Alcatel-Lucent announces job cuts and shares of Britain’s main postal service start trading in London.

headline: Erich Priebke, Nazi Who Carried Out Massacre of 335 Italians, Dies at 100
text: Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who was sentenced to life in prison for helping to organize the execution of 335 men and boys at the Ardeatine Caves in Italy in 1944, died on Friday under house arrest at his home in Rome. He was 100 and the oldest surviving convicted Nazi war criminal.

headline: The High-End Matchmaking Service for Tycoons
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On a characteristically foggy evening here, a group of predominantly single venture capitalists, tech executives, hedge-fund managers and philanthropists gathered for a cocktail party in a penultimate-floor suite at the St. Regis apartment complex.

headline: Berlusconi Aiding War Victims? Italy Speculates on His Penance
text: ROME — Perhaps he will clean toilets, or sweep streets, or collect trash. There is no shortage of graffiti to be scrubbed off the palazzo walls of Rome. Or maybe Silvio Berlusconi, the powerful former prime minister, could pay his debt to Italian society by working in a soup kitchen.

headline: A Designer Defends Futility as a Noble and Useless Pursuit
text: No one seems to know when or where Ludwig Mies van der Rohe uttered the now-clichéd assertion that “less is more.” What we do know is that in 1981, another great design mind described it, if memory serves, as “the silliest thing I’ve ever heard.”

headline: New, Young Help for Poor in Infamous Bronx Courts
text: On a recent afternoon in the South Bronx, Cordice Smith, a 79-year-old Korean War veteran wearing a Yankees hat, was standing in the tiled lobby of his apartment building — something he no longer takes for granted. Earlier this year, he almost lost his home after receiving a letter from his landlord’s lawyer: an eviction notice.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 11
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the filming of a new sitcom, “Brooklyn Taxi”; a march over the Brooklyn Bridge; and a real estate developer at the top of his newest tower.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Netted
text: Fashion Week in Paris is full of ideas, both on the runway and from the public attending the shows.

headline: A Throwback to the 1960s, and to the Bible
text: Clearly, Tamar was going for the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: It’s All Been Done Before
text: “I’m not a concept, Joel,” says Clementine in the final scene of “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.”

headline: With More Glitz, a Club Is Reborn
text: Phil Ciganer is not given to hyperbole. So when he expresses strong feelings — as he did watching music fans stream into his club, the Towne Crier Cafe, on Oct. 4 — he can be taken literally.

headline: Copland, Beyond the ‘Fanfare’
text: Amid the awards crowding the walls of Aaron Copland’s former home in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., hangs a neatly framed movie advertisement with a modest distinction of its own: The ad, from a 1961 issue of Variety, focuses its sales pitch on the composer, Copland, not the star or the director. The novel approach suggests the centrality of the score and its creator to the enterprise.

headline: Judge to Decide Next Week in Casino Referendum Suit
text: ALBANY — The State Board of Elections urged a judge in Albany on Friday to dismiss a lawsuit challenging a statewide casino referendum, saying the case had been filed too late and too close to Election Day.

headline: Schottenfreude
text: The German’s language’s ability to express the inexpressible explains why so many words have been embraced into English.

headline: Winslow Is Suspended for Four Games
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Kellen Winslow, the Jets’ leading receiver, will miss the next four games after being suspended for violating the N.F.L.’s policy on performance-enhancing substances. Winslow is eligible to return to the active roster on Nov. 4, but because of a bye week for the Jets, he will next be available for their Nov. 17 game at Buffalo.

headline: Declared Legally Dead, as He Sat Before the Judge
text: Donald E. Miller Jr. is legally dead, an Ohio judge explained to Donald E. Miller Jr. this week in court.

headline: The Leading Men (and Woman) of Physics
text: Who were the other scientists pictured with Marie Curie at the Solvay Conference in Physics in 1927?

headline: Fond Recollections of Dictators, Colored Later by the Lessons of History
text: SEOUL, South Korea — MONICA MACÍAS calls herself the daughter of dictators. Two of them.

headline: Nothing Certain as England Chases World Cup Dreams
text: England, the country that gives so many of the world’s top players employment and huge salaries in its Premier League, remains tenuously on the brink of the World Cup.

headline: Dining at a Star in Queens
