text: When Michelin, the French publisher of travel books, issued its 2014 New York City dining guide this month, it gave stars to 58 restaurants in Manhattan, six in Brooklyn — and one in the entire borough of Queens. That Queens restaurant was the Danny Brown Wine Bar & Kitchen, a cozy Continental on Metropolitan Avenue and 71st Drive in Forest Hills. Owned by Mr. Brown, who runs the kitchen, and his wife, Audrey, who manages the front of the house, the restaurant, which attracts a crowd of stylish locals, was, for the fourth time, awarded a single star.

headline: Teeth, Art and Iguanas
text: Caroline Stern’s dental office on West 57th Street seems like an attempt to cure toothaches by distraction.

headline: Anger Lingers in Sudan After a Crackdown
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — On the first Friday after the protests began, Samar Ibnoaf, 23, said, she stepped outside her grandmother’s house to take a look at the growing demonstration nearby.

headline: Raising the G.E.D. Bar Stirs Concern for Students
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The high school equivalency exams taken by people who dropped out of school and immigrants seeking a foothold in the American education system are about to get harder and potentially more expensive, causing concern that fewer will take and pass the exams.

headline: Texas: Company Sets Aside Payment for Visa Fraud
text: Infosys, an Indian outsourcing company based in Bangalore, said in an earnings report that it had set aside $35 million for a possible settlement in a visa fraud inquiry in Texas. For more than two years, federal authorities have been examining whether Infosys misused visas to bring temporary technology workers from India. In its report, the company said the Department of Homeland Security had “found errors in a significant percentage” of its hiring records.

headline: In Sickness and in Health, Long After the Bike Is Due Back
text: For years, the rise of cycling in New York City has sown disharmony.

headline: She Doesn’t Just Play a Mother on TV
text: Betsy Brandt says she did not learn much about how to cook methamphetamine during her five seasons on “Breaking Bad.” But she did get hooked on the show. Speaking three days before its finale last month, she said she still had not accepted that it was ending. “You’ll probably hear me screaming out the window,” she said. Nevertheless, she has moved away from the dark side to a comedic role on “The Michael J. Fox Show,” in which, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, she “harks back to Suzanne Pleshette on ‘The Bob Newhart Show.' ” Since moving to New York in June, Ms. Brandt, 40, has been living in an apartment on the Upper West Side with her husband, Grady Olsen, 40, who works for OpenText, a software company, and their two children, ages 4 and 8.

headline: James A. Emanuel, Poet Who Wrote of Racism, Dies at 92
text: James A. Emanuel, a poet, educator and critic who published more than a dozen volumes of his poetry, much of it after his frustration with racism in the United States helped motivate him to move to France, died on Sept. 28 in Paris. He was 92.

headline: In California, New Package of Gun Laws but One Snag
text: LOS ANGELES — Democrats in the California Legislature passed a sweeping package of gun control bills after a string of mass shootings across the country, cracking down on assault rifles, high-capacity magazines and lead ammunition. But on Friday, Gov. Jerry Brown, also a Democrat, vetoed several key pieces, including a ban on semiautomatic weapons that many had considered the toughest restriction on gun ownership in the country.

headline: Picnic Over, Missouri Seeks to Build Its SEC Credentials
text: Missouri’s schedule in September looked as if it had been generously arranged at a neighborhood cookout by Coach Gary Pinkel’s friends and neighbors, eager to see him rebound after a 5-7 campaign in 2012, his first losing season since 2004.

headline: Strapped In, but Still at Risk
text: GAITHERSBURG, Md. — For more than two hours, Xiaopeng Li struggled to securely install two rear-facing car seats for his young children in his Toyota Sienna minivan.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. Is Bowery a street or an avenue?

headline: The Mystery Behind the Model for a Vanished Rockwell Painting
text: Norman Rockwell painted “Sport,” a cover for The Saturday Evening Post that was published in 1939. It is instantly recognizable, one of his scenes of iconic Americana, and yet a discerning eye may see hints of some personal turbulence behind its placid facade, said the author of a forthcoming biography.

headline: India Braces for Cyclone Expected on East Coast
text: NEW DELHI — A monstrous cyclone that may be among the most powerful storms ever recorded in the Bay of Bengal was expected to hit the eastern coast of India by Saturday night.

headline: At Drone Conference, Talk of Morals and Toys
text: The people came for the technology, certainly, and for the flying demonstrations they were promised. They came to find the hobbyists and dreamers who shared their vision of drones as a force of good — or at least good business.

headline: A Private Artist Goes Public
text: Janet K. Ruttenberg hovered over a 15-foot-long piece of paper that was spread across the grass in Central Park. It was an unusually balmy October afternoon and she was painting one of her favorite subjects: the Sheep Meadow. Wielding a 40-inch-long brush, she dabbed some yellow paint and described the curious pull of the vast lawn, with its tableaux of couples, families and single New Yorkers, all set beneath the elegant skyline of Central Park South.

headline: Britain: Rules for Press Proposed
text: Britain’s three main political parties on Friday agreed on a plan to regulate the country’s newspapers, but the proposal faced heavy criticism from the press, casting doubt over its future. Because of worries about press freedom, the government wants newspapers to agree voluntarily to be governed by a new regulatory body and whatever rules it sets up, and has suggested some incentives to win their cooperation. The move to tighten regulations follows a phone-hacking scandal that emerged in 2011 and led to the closing of a newspaper in Rupert Murdoch’s media empire. Under the plan agreed to Friday, the new regulator could impose fines of up to $1.3 million for violations of its code of conduct. Several prominent newspaper groups argue that any regulatory body set up by politicians could be used to control the news media. It is unclear if the parties will now press ahead with their plan or try again to win more media support.

headline: Request to Appoint Lawyer for Terror Suspect Is Denied
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday rejected a request that he appoint a lawyer to represent a terror suspect who was captured last weekend in Libya and was said to be undergoing interrogation while in military custody on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Anger and Indifference After a School Ends a Full-Contact Tradition
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J. — Lawrenceville School students trickled out of the brick buildings of the campus on a recent afternoon to begin their activities of dance, soccer and community service.

headline: Venezuela Intercepts Ship With 5 Americans Aboard
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Maps of Venezuela hanging on the walls of schoolrooms and in government offices show a large striped area to the east of the country’s border with Guyana marked “Zone in Reclamation.” For more than a century, Venezuela has claimed that it is the rightful owner of this zone, which consists of about three-quarters of Guyana’s national territory. The longstanding feud has often darkened relations between the two nations.

headline: More Sex, Anyone?
text: You made me laugh. You, the reader who wrote that, on the subject of sex before marriage, your mother asked your father the farthest he had gone with his before-marriage girlfriend. “Poughkeepsie,” he replied.

headline: Midnight Scavengers
text: Three hundred people gathered in the parking lot of a shuttered Lower Manhattan supermarket on Oct. 5 for the start of Midnight Madness.

headline: Hollywood Ponders Movie on Book About Snowden
text: LOS ANGELES — For more than a week, Hollywood has been exploring what could be one of the most difficult nonfiction projects it has ever tried: a proposed film based on the journalist Glenn Greenwald’s planned book about Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive whistle-blower.

headline: Airlines Cash In on Every Inch, Even the Jammed Bins Overhead
text: A frosted cake. A 10-gallon hat. A car muffler.

headline: Wooing ‘Hometown Industry,’ de Blasio Meets Wary Wall St.
text: It was an unadvertised stop on Bill de Blasio’s schedule. In a corporate boardroom high above Midtown Manhattan, the populist insurgent and sudden mayoral front-runner was courting an unlikely constituency: New York City’s plutocratic class.

headline: C.I.A. Disputes Early Suspicions on Snowden
text: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. said Friday that it did not suspect Edward J. Snowden of gaining access to computer files without authorization when he was working as a technician for the agency in Geneva in 2009, and did not send him home as a result.

headline: And Now, Ted Cruz Cloned
text: Our question for today is: What does next Wednesday’s Senate election in New Jersey mean to those of us who don’t live in New Jersey?

headline: One Long Night in Puzzle City
text: Along 11th Avenue, women in tight dresses and stiletto heels wobbled home in the misty hours after midnight.

headline: Tackling, at the Turn of the Century
text: WASHINGTON — THE public was increasingly upset over the physical toll wrought by football. University faculties were in an uproar over funds diverted from education to the sport. The president called the leaders of the football establishment to the White House to demand change — and they responded.

headline: For Safety in Reactors, Company Thinks Small
text: CORVALLIS, Ore. — Jose N. Reyes has a surefire way to make certain that in case of accident, his nuclear reactor is surrounded by plenty of cold water: install it at the bottom of a giant swimming pool.

headline: An Island of Designer Toys and Dueling Artists Within New York Comic Con
text: After eight years of catering to fans in capes and masks, New York Comic Con is hoping to expand its audience.

headline: Rolling the Dice on Food-Borne Illnesses
text: The government shutdown has caused staff reductions at two important federal health agencies, increasing the risk of serious harm to American consumers from food-borne illnesses. The two agencies — the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — have decided to focus their remaining resources on imminent threats. But they have shut down very important work that allows them to spot potentially serious problems in advance and take steps to head them off. The longer Congressional Republicans allow the shutdown to continue, the greater the danger of harm.

headline: The Villain in ‘Gravity’ Is Real
text: The new movie “Gravity,” in which George Clooney and Sandra Bullock play astronauts adrift in space, has been variously praised as a riveting drama and criticized for scientific inaccuracies. But the phenomenon that sets the plot in motion is not a Hollywood fantasy. It is space junk, a very real villain. While Mr. Clooney and Ms. Bullock are out completing repairs, they hear that a Russian missile strike on a satellite has caused a chain reaction, with the debris taking out other satellites, and that flying bits of metal are coming their way. They survive the initial collision, but the junk ruins their shuttle.

headline: Neighborhood Watch Fantasists
text: After George Zimmerman decided to shadow Trayvon Martin and then shot the unarmed teenager to death, accounts described him rather innocuously as a “neighborhood watch volunteer.” Mr. Zimmerman, who was ultimately acquitted, could have been described more accurately as a self-appointed sentinel, legally armed and fully protected against the full consequences for homicide under the state’s notorious Stand Your Ground law.

headline: U.S. Team Shifts Focus to Sizing Up Its Players
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — As World Cup qualifying matches go, there was little to see here Friday night. The United States had already clinched its place in Brazil next summer, and its opponent, Jamaica, was all but eliminated from contention.

headline: Don’t Blame the Norwegians
text: HAMBURG, Germany — AFTER Santa Claus, Geir Lundestad has what may be the most joyful job in the world. Every year, on the second Friday of October at around 10:30 a.m., the suave, gray-haired Norwegian historian picks up his phone to inform a lucky earthling that he or she has just won the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Resolving Disputes in Asia
The Pope and Conservative Catholics
A Call for Privacy Laws
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prescribing Generic Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Using Devices in Flight
text: To the Editor:

headline: Louder Voice for the Rich?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Arts, Under Threat
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Unequal Wealth
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Family’s Need to Know
text: When you drive into Bloomington, Ind., a classic college town of 82,000 dominated by Indiana University, one of the first things you see is a large, handmade billboard with the picture of a pretty young woman. Next to her picture is her name, Lauren Spierer, and, in bold red letters, the word “MISSING.” More than two years ago, Lauren, who was finishing her sophomore year, disappeared.

headline: In Libya, Premier Calls Kidnapping Failed ‘Coup’
text: TUNIS — Prime Minister Ali Zeidan of Libya said on Friday that his kidnapping the day before by militia members was no different than a “coup” and had been orchestrated by opponents in the legislature who want to force him from office.

headline: A Warning to Egypt’s Generals
text: President Obama’s decision to reduce but not terminate military aid to Egypt is a measured attempt to protect American interests in a tumultuous region while affirming the president’s support for democracy. One message is that the relationship between the two countries remains crucial to regional stability. The other is that America cannot sit by while the Egyptian Army tramples on Egypt’s political opposition, foments violence and turns increasingly authoritarian, thus ensuring further turmoil.

headline: Shutdown’s Quiet Toll, From Idled Research to Closed Wallets
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency has stopped monitoring mercury contamination in the Everglades and testing water after the recent floods in Colorado.

headline: 3rd Buccaneer Found With Infection
text: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers said Friday that a third player had a MRSA infection, a thorny strain that has been a concern in N.F.L. locker rooms over the past decade.

headline: 2 States Plan 2-Tier System for Balloting
text: PHOENIX — Barred by the Supreme Court from requiring proof of citizenship for federal elections, Arizona is complying — but setting up a separate registration system for local and state elections that will demand such proof.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 11
Teacher Leaves Yeshiva Amid Abuse Scandal
text: Yeshiva University said Friday that a Yeshiva College teacher was “no longer employed by the university” following news reports that he had been previously convicted of lewdness with minors.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 12, 2013
text: “Netanyahu is most comfortable predicting disaster, scaring people into doing something. The problem is now he’s lost momentum. His message is clear, his message is the same, the situation is the same, but everyone else’s perspective has changed. It’s like you’re the only one in a dark room with a flashlight.”

headline: Share Your Citi Bike Wedding Story
text: They have been used as resting places and makeshift gyms. They have also helped inebriated people get home and helped a mayoral candidate navigate the city.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: 2 Oregon at 16 Washington

headline: Corrections: October 12, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Vacancy Clause
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The first thing we’re going to do is skip over discussing the northwest sector of this puzzle, because we are all adults here. And the answer is no, no one — including the constructor — noticed it. Instead, we’re going to focus our attention on the rest of John Farmer’s lovely, Scrabbly grid.

headline: Giants’ Manning Shoulders Blame for Turnovers, but Problems Run Deeply
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tom Coughlin, who led the Giants to two Super Bowl triumphs, three N.F.C. East titles and five playoff berths in his first nine years as their coach, insists he and his staff have not lost their way after a devastating 0-6 start.

headline: Detroit Arms Facing Test From Boston Bats
text: BOSTON — When Quintin Berry talks about the Boston Red Sox hitters, he does not include himself in the group. Berry has batted only nine times in 14 games for the Red Sox, who have included him on their American League Championship Series roster for his speed, not his bat.

headline: For a Night, a Convicted Donor Can Stay Late at the Opera
text: Alberto Vilar, a longtime major donor to the Metropolitan Opera before his conviction for financial crimes, will be able to attend a sold-out performance on Saturday night — thanks to a federal judge’s agreement to extend his 11 p.m. curfew.

headline: Spanish Formula One Driver Found Dead
text: Maria de Villota, a 33-year-old Spanish racing driver, was found dead in her hotel room in Seville, 15 months after she sustained multiple skull fractures — and lost an eye — in a Formula One testing accident in England.

headline: ‘Wolf Hall’ Mini-Series With Mark Rylance Is Coming to PBS’s ‘Masterpiece’
text: A big British costume drama, adapted from big British literary works with a big British star, is coming to PBS’s “Masterpiece”? Well, of course it is. But in this case, it’s still a big deal, because the literary works are “Wolf Hall,” Hilary Mantel’s Booker Prize-winning novel about the ascent of Thomas Cromwell, and its similarly decorated sequel, “Bring Up the Bodies.” And the star is Mark Rylance, the Tony and Olivier Award-winning actor, who will portray Cromwell, the powerful minister to Henry VIII, in this television drama.

headline: With a Huge Line to Cover, the Jaguars Can Still Hope
text: Gamblers everywhere have an adage: there is no such thing as a bad game if you have money on it. The Denver Broncos and the Jacksonville Jaguars will demonstrate that again Sunday in what will be, by all indications, a brutal mismatch, one that has become the talk of the N.F.L.

headline: After Steady Presence for Years, Kenseth Is Driver to Beat in Chase
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The last time Matt Kenseth dominated a Nascar season was 2003, when he took the points lead in early March and never relinquished it on the way to one of the more uneventful championship runs in the sport’s history.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY (2012) Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman, above) sets out with the wizard Gandalf (Ian McKellen) and a posse of dwarfs to battle a dragon in Peter Jackson’s adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien’s first Middle-earth fantasy novel, part of a planned trilogy. Richard Armitage plays the exiled dwarf king Thorin, who leads the expedition through a series of encounters with orcs, elves, trolls and other beings. Andy Serkis returns, with the assistance of computer generation, as Gollum. “The meeting between Bilbo and Gollum, which takes place in a vast, watery subterranean cavern, is the one fully enchanted piece of ‘An Unexpected Journey,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a funny, haunting and curiously touching moment that summons the audience to a state of quiet, eager attentiveness. Even if you aren’t aware of the apocalyptic importance of Gollum’s precious ring, you feel that a lot is at stake here: Bilbo’s life and integrity; Gollum’s corroded soul; the fate of Middle-earth itself.” He added, “If only some of that feeling animated the rest of the movie.”

headline: Returning Home
text: Willie Colon, an offensive lineman with the Jets, has maintained a special bond to his South Bronx neighborhood.

headline: Beltran Lifts Cardinals Past Dodgers in a Taut Game 1
text: ST. LOUIS — The voices of the Cardinals fans at Busch Stadium had turned raspy, harsh and a little desperate by the eighth inning Friday night. St. Louis had not managed much against the Los Angeles Dodgers’ starter, Zack Greinke, an old antagonist, in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series, and the score remained tied going into the ninth.

headline: 800,000 Evacuated as Powerful Cyclone Hits India
text: NEW DELHI — A powerful cyclone whose spinning arms engulfed much of the Bay of Bengal weakened Sunday morning as it crashed into India’s eastern coast, flooding homes and roads throughout the region and disrupting electricity and communications.

headline: Senate Takes Lead as House Republicans’ Talks With White House Fail
text: WASHINGTON — Senators Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell on Saturday began last-ditch negotiations on reopening the government and raising the debt ceiling as talks between House Republicans and the White House collapsed, dashing hopes for a quick resolution to the political crisis that has paralyzed the government.

headline: Mother and 3 Young Children Are Killed in a House Fire on Long Island
text: A Long Island woman and her three young children were killed in a fast-moving house fire in Suffolk County late Friday night, the police said.

headline: From the Archive Come Brides of The Times
text: Into the Lively Morgue they descend, rich and richer alike, the well born and the even more well off. Cue the organ music: here come the brides. These women marched down the aisle during the 1920s and 1930s, as the country’s economy and marriage rates were plunging — and they marched into The New York Times’s portrait studio in the days before or after their weddings, defying the adage that women wear their wedding gowns one time only.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Oct. 11, 2013
text: The federal government could default on its debt if it does not increase the amount of money it can borrow by October 17. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine what will happen to the economy and Wall Street if Washington doesn’t raise the debt ceiling. Domestic and foreign investors are closely watching and making decisions that could affect the nation’s economy for years to come.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (2) vs. Jamaica (0)
text: With a spot in Brazil next year already assured, the United States national team defeated Jamaica in its final home World Cup qualifier to lock down first place in the final round — the hexagonal — of qualifying in the Concacaf region.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
text: On tomorrow morning, with David Plouffe, Dan Senor, and Peggy Noonan. I believe we’re going to be doing movie criticism, focusing on the new film in which Tom Hanks and his crew are taken hostage by Tea Party Republicans Somali pirates. But I might be wrong about that.

headline: Business and the GOP
text: Still no resolution on the debt ceiling, and I think people are still too optimistic here. Republicans still aren’t willing to walk away from this without some kind of trophy, so they can claim victory; the whole point of Obama’s position is that you don’t get anything, not even something trivial, as a reward for threatening disaster.

headline: Dodgers’ Top Hitters Haven’t Been Getting Chances in Key Situations
text: ST. LOUIS — Once again on Saturday, during Game 2 of their National League Championship Series against the Cardinals, when the Los Angeles Dodgers could have used a big hit from Adrian Gonzalez or Hanley Ramirez, neither had the chance to deliver.

headline: Like Pirates, Steelers Having a Rare Season
text: PITTSBURGH — They came wearing jerseys of their newest heroes, McCutchen, Alvarez and Liriano. They set up chairs, huddled in blankets and waved Jolly Roger flags. Hundreds of Pittsburghers gathered here on a chilly night, in front of a giant projection screen at the foot of the Roberto Clemente Bridge, to watch their Pirates in Game 5 of the National League division series.

headline: Variety: Diagramless Puzzle
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Fred Piscop appears to be on a very specific diet of sorts. Today’s diagramless puzzle is a tasty SCHMEAR of various salads, with a sprinkling of crunchy Xs as croutons.

headline: Kirilenko, Nets’ Versatile New Veteran, Plays With a Revived Hunger
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Andrei Kirilenko hid out this off-season in St.-Tropez, France, “away from civilization,” he said, as he has for the better part of a decade. But this summer, for the first time since he can remember, he did not touch a basketball.

headline: N.S.A. Director Firmly Defends Surveillance Efforts
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The director of the National Security Agency, Gen. Keith B. Alexander, said in an interview that to prevent terrorist attacks he saw no effective alternative to the N.S.A.’s bulk collection of telephone and other electronic metadata from Americans. But he acknowledged that his agency now faced an entirely new reality, and the possibility of Congressional restrictions, after revelations about its operations at home and abroad.

headline: African Union Urges International Court to Delay Kenyan President’s Trial
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The members of the African Union said Saturday that no sitting head of state should be prosecuted by an international tribunal and that the trial of Kenya’s president at the International Criminal Court should be postponed, according to the group’s chairman, who spoke after the closed-door session.

headline: Cost of Flood Insurance Rises, Along With Worries
text: MIAMI — Sharp increases in federal flood insurance rates are distressing coastal homeowners from Hawaii to New England and are starting to hurt property values and housing sales in areas just beginning to recover from the recession, according to residents and legislators.

headline: Four Executives on Succeeding in Business as a Woman
text: The executives, ranging from the president of a beauty products company to the general counsel at Pfizer, shared their stories about headwinds they have navigated over the years and advice to women wanting to succeed at work.

headline: Readers’ Advice for Young Women in the Workplace
text: Before Adam Bryant’s special installment of Corner Office on women and leadership, The Times asked readers to give their own advice to women who are early in their careers. Here are excerpts from the more than 500 responses.

headline: The Secrets of the Shenandoah
text: South Pacific tropical islanders, boreal dawns, perilous ice floes and distressed whaling ships hardly belong to our usual mental inventory of American Civil War images. They evoke Herman Melville more than Stephen Crane. But they were all part of the long, strange global odyssey of a Confederate ship called the Shenandoah.

headline: Talks Clear Path for U.S.-Afghan Deal on Troops
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After more than a week of hard-line posturing by Afghan and American officials, Secretary of State John Kerry and President Hamid Karzai defied expectations and agreed on key elements of a deal that, if completed, would keep American troops in Afghanistan beyond next year.

headline: When the Stock Price Hides Trouble
text: WHEN a company receives criticism about its executive pay practices, a typical defense is to cite a rising stock price as justification of its pay. If total shareholder return is up, the theory goes, stockholders have no right to complain about what might otherwise look like outsize pay at their companies.

headline: Tigers’ Torii Hunter Seeks Elusive Title
text: BOSTON — The next time a player says he has not even thought about his pending free agency, understand that he is lying. Or, at least, that he is not like the Detroit Tigers’ Torii Hunter, who enjoyed last season in Anaheim but knew he might not play there forever.

headline: Sports Legends Selling Relics? Hey, That Glove Really Is Gold
text: There comes a time when a sports legend must decide whether to hang on to this championship ring and that game-worn jersey, or to cash in on the memorabilia market, which can fetch stunning sums for rare and historic artifacts.

headline: Packing a Punch on the Bases, Too
text: In 1950, Dom DiMaggio led the American League in stolen bases with 15. It is the lowest total that has led either league, and if DiMaggio was to be believed, it was hardly on purpose.

headline: Student Data’s Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mug Shots, Forever or Not
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, October 13
text: “Too many Americans still can’t find a job, and worry how they’ll pay their bills. The Federal Reserve can help.”

headline: Stuck on Usual Quarrel: Raising New Revenue
text: WASHINGTON — Be skeptical. Be very, very skeptical.

headline: And Now, From the Woman Poised to Run the Fed ...
text: Last week, after President Obama nominated Janet L. Yellen, the Brooklyn-born, Brown-and-Yale-educated economist, to lead the Federal Reserve, commentators praised her intellect and expertise. But they were also quick to celebrate the fact that she would be the first woman to hold the top job at the 100-year-old central bank. Fairly typical was the sentiment expressed by Justin Wolfers, a University of Michigan economist, who wrote on Bloomberg View: “Tonight, I feel reassured that my daughter’s economic future is in good hands. I also plan to tell her that she, too, can grow up to become the most powerful economist in the world. It’s a potent stimulus.” Ms. Yellen seems more at ease speechifying in the realm of monetary policy and inflationary models than discussing her gender. But over the years, she has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her own rise in a male-dominated field.

headline: German Outrage Swells Over a Bishop’s Spending
text: BERLIN — Since being elected in March, Pope Francis has quickly made a mark with his displays of modesty, eschewing lavish papal apartments for a spartan guesthouse in Vatican City, wearing simple vestments, carrying his own bag and preaching against a Roman Catholic Church hierarchy that he said was overly insular and too often led by “narcissists.”

headline: The Soaring Cost of a Simple Breath
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The kitchen counter in the home of the Hayes family is scattered with the inhalers, sprays and bottles of pills that have allowed Hannah, 13, and her sister, Abby, 10, to excel at dance and gymnastics despite a horrific pollen season that has set off asthma attacks, leaving the girls struggling to breathe.

headline: The Science Behind a Call for Safer Hockey
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — The message from researchers last week for a Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey was clear: the game as it is played now causes too much brain trauma, and it must change fundamentally.

headline: Penn State Opens Ice Arena Fit for a Division I Team
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Penn State christened its $90 million Pegula Ice Arena with a 4-1 victory over Army on Friday night before an overflow crowd announced at 6,370. And Coach Guy Gadowsky’s first words were a salute to the fans who had ushered in a new era for the hockey program.

headline: Staring Into the Abyss
text: No deal. And for a very good reason: the president has made it a matter of principle that he will not make concessions that reward hostage-taking, and Republican leaders refuse to release the hostages without getting something that will let them claim victory.

headline: Riding Out the Political Storm
text: The stock market began the week in a funk and ended in subdued celebration as apparent progress in the debt-ceiling impasse seemed to confirm the Wall Street consensus that dysfunction in Washington won’t lead to a debt default or set off a global cataclysm.

headline: A Striking Absence of Women
text: Twitter, the popular social networking company, recently drew unwelcome attention to itself and the technology industry when it revealed in the filing for its initial public offering that none of the seven people on its board was a woman. One academic accused it of “male chauvinist thinking;” Twitter’s chief executive, Dick Costolo, seemed to only make matters worse by referring to that critic, Vivek Wadhwa, as the “Carrot Top of academic sources,” alluding to the over-the-top standup comedian Carrot Top.

headline: Haiti’s Imported Disaster
text: Haiti’s cholera epidemic, now entering its fourth year, has killed more than 8,300 people and sickened more than 650,000. It is a calamity, though one fundamentally different from the earthquake, hurricanes and floods that have beset the fragile country since 2010.

headline: Fighting Back Against Revenge Porn
text: Revenge porn is one of those things that sounds as if it must be illegal but actually isn’t. It’s the term of art for publishing sexual photos of someone without his or her — usually her — permission, often after a breakup.

headline: It’s Not Only Mothers and Children
text: For impoverished Americans, the biggest obstacle to health insurance remains the refusal of 26 mostly Republican-led states to expand their Medicaid programs as called for under the health reform law. As a result, up to an estimated eight million people will get no help at all because they earn too little to buy subsidized coverage on the new insurance exchanges and too much to qualify for Medicaid in states that won’t expand their programs.

headline: Monarchs Fight for Their Lives
text: The more you know about monarch butterflies, the more extraordinary they seem. Their life cycle — the adaptive web of behaviors they have evolved — is almost unbelievably complex. They migrate en masse (this month, as a rule) from all across the Midwest and Northeast to just a few high altitude sites in Mexico, where they winter, sheltering in profusion beneath a canopy of fir trees, from whose trunks they draw the residual heat they need to stay alive. Winter past, they migrate thousands of miles northward, where they lay their eggs on milkweed plants, the only plant a monarch caterpillar can eat.

headline: Your Vintage Wedding Photos
text: A selection of readers’ heirloom wedding photos from around the world.

headline: The Death of Willie Sherman
text: It was no secret that 9-year-old Willie was the favorite child of William Tecumseh Sherman. In fact, his wife, Ellen, reproved him repeatedly for making his preference for Willie uncomfortably obvious to their other children. But on the evening of Oct. 3, 1863, the boy lay dead in a Memphis hotel room. Sherman would write the next day to Ulysses S. Grant that Willie was “the one I most prised [sic] on earth.” But Willie’s death was the tragic consequence of a series of decisions for which Sherman would blame himself the rest of his own life.

headline: Alex Gibney
text: Alex Gibney is an Academy Award-winning documentary filmmaker. His latest projects are “Mea Maxima Culpa” about the Roman Catholic Church and “The Armstrong Lie” about Lance Armstrong.

headline: The End of the Nation-State?
text: SINGAPORE — EVERY five years, the United States National Intelligence Council, which advises the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, publishes a report forecasting the long-term implications of global trends. Earlier this year it released its latest report, “Alternative Worlds,” which included scenarios for how the world would look a generation from now.

headline: The Kurtz Republicans
text: “THEY told me,” Martin Sheen’s Willard says to Marlon Brando’s Kurtz in “Apocalypse Now,” at the end of a long journey up the river, “that you had gone totally insane, and that your methods were unsound.”

headline: A Mad Tea Party
text: WASHINGTON — HOW awful are Ted Cruz and his Cruzettes?

headline: The Disconnect on Anonymous Sources
text: ERIC Schmitt remembers being surprised when, as a member of a Times newsroom committee on reporting practices, he was given information about what bothered readers of The Times most. It wasn’t political bias, or factual errors, or delivery problems.

headline: Is Music the Key to Success?
text: CONDOLEEZZA RICE trained to be a concert pianist. Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, was a professional clarinet and saxophone player. The hedge fund billionaire Bruce Kovner is a pianist who took classes at Juilliard.

headline: Shrinking Hours
text: ONCE, an hour with your therapist ran for about 60 minutes. But there’s been a steady time deflation: first there was the 50-minute hour and now we have 45-minute “hours.”

headline: London’s Great Exodus
text: LONDON — OUR neighbors Lauren and Matt and their kids moved out of London to Cambridge the other week. Bibi, Andy and their two left for Bristol in June. Another of my 8-year-old’s classmates and her family are heading out after Christmas.

headline: From the Streets to the ‘World’s Best Mom’
text: NASHVILLE — WHEN men paid Shelia Faye Simpkins for sex, they presumably thought she was just a happy hooker engaging in a transaction among consenting adults.

headline: How to Save Your Local Opera
text: Take a cue from New York City Opera’s demise and don’t use your endowment to make ends meet; never let your operating costs exceed your basso profundo’s calorie count.

headline: College’s Identity Crisis
text: IS a college degree’s worth best measured by the income its recipient makes 5 or 10 years down the road? Is college primarily a catapult to wealth? These were questions implicitly raised by President Obama’s recent proposal that the federal government look at graduates’ earnings when rating schools in an effort to steer students toward the best ones.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Too Tethered to Tests?
text: Readers debate the influential role of SAT and A.P. exams.

headline: Stuck in a Dispute Between PayPal and Itself
text: If PayPal isn’t the most reviled online company in the country, which is? The Haggler invites reader suggestions for this unhappy title, but before you write in, consider the sheer quantity of animosity that PayPal inspires. There are anti-PayPal Facebook sites, anti-PayPal YouTube tirades, PayPal-loathing Twitter accounts and more than 550 complaints about PayPal on ConsumerAffairs.com.

headline: City of Water
text: ONE of the great things about New York used to be how easy it was to ignore the natural world. With a public transportation system that never closes, moving from climate-controlled apartment to office to entertainment, and living high above the earth itself, New Yorkers never had to worry much about anything as mundane as the weather.

headline: When Debate Stalls, Try Your Paintbrush
text: I LEAD a team of scientists that is designing a cognitive computing chip and software ecosystem inspired by the human brain. It will help computers sense, perceive, act and reason more like humans. In the face of much skepticism and tremendous technical unknowns, our goal is finally within reach.

headline: Out of Network, Out of Luck
text: For several hundred patients at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, it started with a certified letter informing them that they were no longer allowed to see their physicians. The reason? They were unlucky enough to have insurance called Community Blue, which is offered by a rival hospital system. Astoundingly, they were barred even if they could pay for the care themselves.

headline: Ebb and Flow on the Supreme Court
text: By two measures, the Roberts court has upended the existing legal order fewer times than any predecessor since the early 1950s.

headline: How Activist Is the Supreme Court?
text: WASHINGTON — JUSTICES Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg are ideological antagonists on the Supreme Court, but they agree on one thing. Their court is guilty of judicial activism.

headline: Redskins’ Owner Stubbornly Clings to Wrong Side of History
text: On Jan. 14, 1963, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama delivered an inaugural address in which he declared his unwavering allegiance to “segregation now, segregation tomorrow and segregation forever.”

headline: You’d Better Have a Plan
text: MY parents emigrated from South Korea to the United States when my father enrolled in graduate school here for a Ph.D. in physical chemistry. My mother makes the woman who wrote “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother” look like a kitten. She had strong ideas on how to raise children and pushed my older sister, Lydia, and me.

headline: A Surprising Case Against Foreign Aid
text: IN his new book, Angus Deaton, an expert’s expert on global poverty and foreign aid, puts his considerable reputation on the line and declares that foreign aid does more harm than good. It corrupts governments and rarely reaches the poor, he argues, and it is high time for the paternalistic West to step away and allow the developing world to solve its own problems.

headline: Missy Franklin Finds New World on Campus
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — The strain showed on Missy Franklin’s face as she lay on her back, scissoring her straight legs a few inches off the ground as painstakingly as a seamstress cutting a pattern. Franklin’s strong core was obvious on Friday well before she joined a dozen of her University of California swimming teammates in the afternoon for their weekly hourlong dance class, which, to their dismay, featured more segmental rotations than hip gyrations.

headline: As China Vows Austerity, Giant Brass Fish Devours $11 Million
text: HONG KONG — Chinese Communist Party leaders’ vows of a new era of humble austerity in government may have met their most exotic adversary yet: an $11 million, 2,300-ton, 295-foot-long puffer fish.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Sticky Wages and the Macro Wars
text: Simon Wren-Lewis, following up on Bryan Caplan, makes the case that downward nominal rigidity of wages is simply a fact, attested to by overwhelming evidence. Furthermore, it’s a fact that we understand fairly well in terms of behavioral economics. So he suggests that the unwillingness of many macroeconomists to incorporate this fact in their models — because it doesn’t have “microfoundations” — says something disturbing about the state of the field.

headline: From Summer Camp, a Parable for Washington
text: FOR all Americans who want their government to work — and I presume that is most of us — the recent discord in Washington over the government shutdown and debt limit has been painful to watch. But for me, the high-stakes squabbling among Democrats and Republicans is also a reminder of a dissonance with which I have lived throughout my life.

headline: At Least for One Game, Texas and Its Embattled Coach Return to Glory
text: DALLAS — These were the Longhorns that Texas Coach Mack Brown had lauded, the recruits he had molded and sold as championship contenders this season, heaping expectations that they had not come close to meeting.

headline: Seeking a Staredown With Google Glass
text: SOON, many people will be seeing the world through computerized glasses, and not just those made by Google.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 13
text: With fiscal negotiations between House Republicans and the Obama administration crumbling on Saturday, all eyes turned to the Senate just days before the United States faces the possibility of a devastating financial default on Thursday. Key senators from both parties will take to the political talk shows on Sunday to discuss the prospects for a deal.

headline: In a Mood? Call Center Agents Can Tell
text: IN a YouTube clip from one of Steve Jobs’s last interviews, he appears to be enjoying reminiscing about how he first hit upon the idea for the keyboardless tablet that eventually became the iPad.

headline: Chipping Away at Sex Trafficking in America
text: I’ve written a good deal about sex trafficking in other countries over the years, from Cambodia to India, Pakistan to Philippines. But I probably haven’t written enough about the problem right here in America, and in the last few years I’ve tried to remedy that. My first aim is to remind people that this is a major problem at home, and that a lot of prostitution is less voluntary than people usually assume. The second aim is to show that the problem isn’t hopeless, and that there are things we can do about it.

headline: Duets, Messages, Crowds and the Country-Pop Blend
text: Growing up in the San Felipe Courts housing projects of Houston’s Fourth Ward, Kenny Rogers used to walk to elementary school through better neighborhoods, admiring what he came to recognize as the mark of success: automatic water sprinklers. In the 1980s, in the middle of a run that earned him 12 Billboard-chart-topping albums and 24 No. 1 hits, Mr. Rogers built an 18-hole golf course at his home near Athens, Ga., and covered it in automatic sprinklers. “I’d spend hours sitting on a golf cart admiring them,” Mr. Rogers says. “I like to joke I have them inside my house now.”

headline: For Aid Insuring Latinos, Groups Look Close to Home
text: Though they make up roughly a third of the state’s population, Latinos account for nearly two-thirds of the more than six million Texans without health insurance. But in the 13 days since a federal insurance marketplace aimed at helping the uninsured find coverage opened, health care advocates across the state have encountered common obstacles in getting Latinos registered, including limited access to computers and the lack of an e-mail address.

headline: The Last Person Did Everything Just Right
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Tutoring Company in Texas Draws Fire as State Pulls Back Services
text: When two of Marcos Sifuentes’s children received free laptops from a tutoring program through their San Antonio middle school, the family signed up for wireless access at home for the first time. Mr. Sifuentes added an Internet hot spot to his cellphone plan so they could continue their lessons.

headline: Taken to Task
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Jeff Chen has set himself a Sisyphean task today in more ways than one. SISYPHUS didn’t have any help rolling his BOULDER up the hill, but because resources here are limited and the Across Lite (and possibly the New York Times game play) version of the puzzle does not display the way Mr. Chen had planned, I’m going to help him out. That what friends are for, right?

headline: Cousin Arrested in ‘Baby Hope’ Killing After 22 Years
text: It was a cold case that had eluded investigators for more than two decades. A little girl with no name had been stuffed into a cooler and left beside a Manhattan highway. On Saturday, however, the mystery seemed to have been lifted with the arrest of a cousin of the girl, known as Baby Hope, the police said.

headline: Online Application Woes Make Students Anxious and Put Colleges Behind Schedule
text: With early admission deadlines looming for hundreds of thousands of students, the new version of the online Common Application shared by more than 500 colleges and universities has been plagued by numerous malfunctions, alarming students and parents and putting admissions offices weeks behind schedule.

headline: What $250 of Prescriptions Looks Like
text: Comparing the costs of five medications between the United States and other countries.

headline: Senate Democrats on Shutdown Talks
text: Top Senate Democrats led by the majority leader Harry Reid lamented the failure to end a 12-day-old government shutdown at a news conference in Washington on Saturday.

headline: Vows: Kerry and Chris
text: Kerry Whichello and Chris Belair met while working behind the scenes on “Late Show With David Letterman.” They plan to spend the rest of their lives laughing together.

headline: A Rookie Remains on a Roll and Extends the Cardinals’ Edge
text: ST. LOUIS — Only once, in the sixth inning, did Michael Wacha of the St. Louis Cardinals act like a giddy 22-year-old rookie pitching in his first postseason. And it happened in the tensest moment of Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.

headline: Three Up-and-Comers Share Secrets of Success
text: Three Americans on the rise. Three ideas about their success.

headline: Week 6 Matchup: Steelers (0-4) at Jets (3-2)
text: 1 p.m., CBS

headline: Washington Cannot Keep Up, and Oregon Keeps Rivalry One-Sided
text: SEATTLE — Marcus Mariota was finally contained Saturday. He was trapped, boxed in. It took two concrete walls, a narrow walkway in between and a few dozen reporters in his path, but finally Mariota was stopped.

headline: Governor Vetoes Bill to Limit Use of Generic Drugs in California
text: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown has vetoed a bill that critics said would have hindered the use of cheaper versions of high-priced biotechnology drugs, providing a victory for health plans and generic drug companies over brand-name pharmaceutical manufacturers.

headline: 30 Seconds With Lou Holtz
text: Lou Holtz prepared for his job as ESPN’s wise and witty college football analyst by serving as a head coach at six colleges over 33 years.

headline: College Football Around the Country
text: TERRY BAGGETT The Army back, right, ran for a team-record 304 yards and had four touchdowns in a 50-25 home win over Eastern Michigan. It was the first 300-yard rushing game in the Football Bowl Subdivision this season.

headline: G.O.P.’s Hopes to Take Senate Are Dimming
text: WASHINGTON — Next year was supposed to be a prime opportunity for Republicans to retake the Senate. And for a while, everything seemed to be breaking their way: a wave of Democratic retirements, a fluke in the electoral map that put a large number of races in states that President Obama lost, a strong farm team of conservative Senate hopefuls from the House.

headline: How HealthCare.gov Was Supposed to Work and How It Didn’t

headline: From the Start, Signs of Trouble at Health Portal
text: WASHINGTON — In March, Henry Chao, the chief digital architect for the Obama administration’s new online insurance marketplace, told industry executives that he was deeply worried about the Web site’s debut. “Let’s just make sure it’s not a third-world experience,” he told them.

headline: Palin Endorses Lonegan in New Jersey Senate Race
text: NEW EGYPT, N.J. — With polls suggesting a tightening race and only a few days remaining in the United States Senate contest in New Jersey, thousands of people gathered at a racetrack here to watch Sarah Palin endorse the Republican candidate, Steve Lonegan.

headline: Behind Flurry of Killing, Potency of Hate
text: LONDON — From a comfortable couch in his London living room, Sean O’Callaghan had been watching the shaky televised images of terrified people running from militants in an upscale mall in Kenya. Some of those inside had been asked their religion. Muslims were spared, non-Muslims executed.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 12, 2013

text: RAMTHA, Jordan — The Syrian rebel leader was sitting comfortably on a cushion at his home here recently, his wife and children filling the rooms with conversation and laughter. Then one day he shaved off his beard and slipped back into Syria, where he leads a rebel brigade.

headline: Donald Cabana, Warden Who Loathed Death Penalty, Dies at 67
text: The first time Donald A. Cabana saw the gas chamber at the Mississippi State Penitentiary, in 1971, he was invited to sit inside it. He was 25 years old, had only brief experience as a corrections officer and was on a tour of the place — better known as Parchman Farm — hoping to work there one day. Certainly he did not envision himself as its future warden.

text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Carmelo Anthony interrupted an otherwise uneventful trip to New England by disclosing that he had taken a “huge risk” by opting against off-season surgery on his left shoulder.

headline: Tigers Lose No-Hit Bid but Not Game
text: BOSTON — Anibal Sanchez was once a prospect blazing a path toward Fenway Park, toward postseason glory, toward the spoils that eventually went to Jon Lester, his teammate in 2005 on the Class AA Portland Sea Dogs, a Red Sox affiliate.

headline: Having Starters Can Finish Off an Opponent
text: BOSTON — The prevailing theory before the American League Championship Series was that the Boston Red Sox’ approach at the plate could wear down the Detroit Tigers’ starters and force them to use their vulnerable bullpen. That is exactly what happened in Game 1.

headline: Hotel Relax by the Runway
text: Hotel Relax by the Runway

headline: Spending Dispute Leaves a Senate Deal Elusive
text: WASHINGTON — With a possible default on government obligations just days away, Senate Democratic leaders — believing they have a political advantage in the continuing fiscal impasse — refused Sunday to sign on to any deal that reopens the government but locks in budget cuts for next year.

headline: Quick Evacuation Efforts Help India Minimize Deaths From Cyclone
text: NEW DELHI — The powerful cyclone that struck India’s eastern coast this weekend washed away thousands of mud homes, knocked down power lines, blocked many of the region’s roads and damaged crops and fishing boats. But reports from the region on Sunday showed the success of one of the biggest and most rapid evacuations in India’s history, an operation that moved more than 800,000 people to safety.

headline: Flim Flam Forever
text: Aha. Paul Ryan, the Serious, Honest Conservative (the media myth) — as opposed to Paul Ryan the unserious, dishonest partisan (always the reality) — made a brief reappearance over the past couple of days. Needless to say, his initiative was completely useless, and the debt talks were in breakdown.

headline: Wage Flexibility in Doctrine and Policy (Wonkish)
text: I probably should have made clear in my post on sticky wages that I was arguing for stickiness as a central issue in the history of macroeconomic thought, not as a central issue in current policy. I’ve been arguing for years that when you’re in a liquidity trap wage flexibility actually hurts rather than helps; this is the paradox of flexibility, which arises, roughly speaking, because under current conditions the aggregate demand curve is upward-sloping thanks to debt and balance sheet effects.

headline: U.S. impasse threatens to roil Asian economies
text: The U.S. shutdown battle is heading straight for Asia.

headline: From One Child to Two
text: The first time I told my mother I was pregnant, she shrieked with glee. She had been praying for the arrival of her first grandchild since my wedding.

headline: Disruptions: Bit by Bit, Virtual Reality Heads for the Holodeck
text: While sitting in a stuffy Hollywood hotel conference room recently, I plotted my next move outside a snow-covered, ancient castle. I raised an arm to block the falling snow as I peered up. As I looked from side to side, white drifts extended into the distance.
