headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 14, 2013
text: “Without going to jail, you cannot be a big politician.”

headline: Trading Shoes at Lincoln Center
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Scores of Pilgrims Die in Stampede on Bridge in India
text: NEW DELHI — Thousands of religious pilgrims in northern India panicked on Sunday when they thought a narrow bridge they were crossing was collapsing, Indian officials said. The resulting stampede left at least 109 people dead and about a hundred more injured.

headline: Week 6 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Putting Brady in Position to Succeed
text: Andy Benoit takes a quick tour through Week 6, including appearances from the Good Cam Newton, a sack-happy and undefeated Chiefs team and an Eagles coach who faces a big choice.

headline: Happy Columbus Day
text: Because most schools in the United States are off today, The Learning Network is taking a quick fall break as well.

headline: Syrian Rebels Urged to Let Inspectors See Arms Sites
text: LONDON — Pressure intensified on Syrian rebels on Monday to permit access to chemical weapons sites in areas under their control, as officials said the rapidly shifting lines in the civil war made it difficult for inspectors to reach some locations and called for all parties to ease the process of dismantling Syria’s toxic arms.

headline: Ansel Adams: Master Photographer, Master Marketer
text: It has now been five years since the global economic system nearly collapsed into ruin, and the ensuing half-decade has been difficult for most — apart from the infamous 1 percent — including professional photographers. The ease and accessibility of digital technology combined with the rise of the mostly free Internet have eliminated many of the ways photographers eked out a middle-class living. Even university jobs — once a stable and comfortable perch — have been replaced by cheap and benefits-free adjuncts.

headline: Facebook Buys Israeli Maker of Data Compression Software for Mobile Web Effort
text: Updated | Added sale price.

headline: New York Today: Monumental Mystery
text: Updated 10:00 a.m. | If you’ve ever passed by the monument in the middle of Columbus Circle, you may have noticed a strangely provocative inscription.

headline: Bay Area Transit System Strike Is Postponed a Day
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A strike deadline for employees of the Bay Area’s main commuter railroad was postponed another day on Sunday night after labor, which had brought the two sides close to a deal, apparently reached an impasse.

headline: Daily Report: Fears for Privacy as Cities Widen Surveillance Efforts
text: Federal grants of $7 million awarded to Oakland, Calif., were meant largely to help thwart terror attacks at its bustling port. But instead, the money is going to a police initiative that will collect and analyze reams of surveillance data from around town, Somini Sengupta reports in The New York Times.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Nick Bilton on the Not-So-Lighthearted Side of Twitter
text: Nick Bilton, a technology and business columnist for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story, about the origins of Twitter. It was adapted from his book, “Hatching Twitter: A True Story of Money, Power, Friendship and Betrayal,” to be published on Nov. 5.

headline: Dolly the Sheep: A Controversial Clone
text: In 1997, Scottish scientists revealed they had cloned a sheep and named her Dolly, sending waves of future shock around the world that continue to shape frontiers of science today.

headline: The Clone Named Dolly
text: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of Dolly the sheep, the first clone of an adult mammal. The Scottish scientists who created her recall the painstaking process of trying to get the experiment to work. After hundreds of tries, they successfully took a cell from an adult sheep, fused it to another sheep’s unfertilized egg and implanted the resulting embryo in a surrogate mother. But Dolly’s birth, and the rush of media attention that followed when the news broke in 1997, gave way almost instantaneously to fears and speculation about what this discovery meant for humanity’s ability to manipulate biology. The debate only intensified in 1998, when an American scientist isolated human embryonic stem cells, which can develop into any type of cell in the body, raising the hope of a new field of regenerative medicine. Here, one of the science reporters who covered the debate for The Times offers a rearview commentary.

headline: How a Start-Up Got a $1.9 Million S.B.A. Loan Offer
text: I have often said that when entrepreneurs decide how to finance a company, the decision is generally made with more emotion than reason.

headline: Economists Clash on Theory, but Will Still Share the Nobel
text: WASHINGTON — The economist Robert J. Shiller in 2005 described the rapid rise of housing prices as a bubble and warned that prices could fall by 40 percent.

headline: As Microsoft Updates Mobile Software, a Cautionary Tale
text: REDMOND, Wash. — If Microsoft has learned anything while competing against Google in the Internet search business, it’s that Google clings to a dominant position like a squatter does a house.

headline: Shareholders Voting on Alitalia Bailout Plan
text: PARIS — Shareholders of Alitalia were expected to approve a 500 million euro bailout of the Italian carrier in a vote Monday evening, but it remained unclear how much support the plan might ultimately receive from its largest investor, Air France-KLM.

headline: SAC’s Cohen Selling Art
text: As his legal troubles have deepened, the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen has sold stocks to meet withdrawal requests from investors. Now Mr. Cohen, the owner of SAC Capital Advisors, is also selling significant works of art from his celebrated collection, Peter Lattman and Carol Vogel report in DealBook.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Wins the Battle, Not the War
text: Sebastian Vettel won the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday, but failed to clinch his fourth straight Formula One world championship. His top rival, Fernando Alonso, finished fourth, which was good enough to deny Vettel from mathematically clinching the title. With four races remaining and 100 points possible, Vettel leads Alonso by 90 points.

headline: Minor Victory by Far-Right Party Has France Asking if Bigger Changes Are Ahead
text: PARIS — The triumph by the far-right National Front party in a minor election in the south of France has created headlines across the country and prompted politicians and political analysts to take a hard look at the landscape, a little more than a year after the election of a socialist president, François Hollande.

headline: Is The Times Being Stealthy?  Or Just Improving Its Reporting in Real Time?
text: When an article goes online in one form, changes a few hours later and appears in print in still another form, what exactly is happening? Is this sneakiness, as some claim, or just garden-variety editing to make an evolving story better?

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: A bit of leather warms up a modern chair — and a room for that matter — with its earthy hue and gently worn patina.

headline: Aam Aadmi Party Breaking the Rules of Identity Politics
text: NEW DELHI— The upstart Aam Aadmi Party rattled the political establishment earlier this year when it announced that it would take its anticorruption campaign to the people by contesting all 70 seats in the Delhi state assembly elections this winter. Now the party is taking a step further to upend politics as usual by ignoring the conventional wisdom on candidates’ religious affiliations.

headline: The Party of Gimme
text: Members of Congress negotiated frantically over the weekend to reopen the government and stave off a default that is now only four days away. Every proposal fell apart, however, and the reason is pretty simple: at every step, Republicans insisted on winning something in exchange for performing those two necessary acts.

headline: “Interesting From China.”
text: When The New-York Daily Times began publication in 1851, China was ruled by a weak and stagnating Qing dynasty. Hong Kong was a young British colony, ceded to Queen Victoria at the end of the first Opium War only nine years earlier. And the devastating Taiping Rebellion, which would leave at least 20 million dead, more than almost any other military conflict in history, had just begun in a corner of what is now the southern region of Guangxi.

headline: Again, No African Leader Wins Annual Good Governance Prize
text: LONDON — For the fourth time in five years, a prestigious multimillion-dollar prize offered annually to African leaders for good government went unawarded on Monday, renewing questions about the stringency of its rules, the paucity of candidates and the state of democracy on the continent.

headline: Implications for Banks as Madoff Litigation Grinds On
text: It has been nearly five years since the Ponzi scheme perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff came to light, and litigation surrounding the case grinds on.

headline: Obamacare Success
text: This morning I talked to someone who successfully signed up for Obamacare — with great difficulty, but she did succeed in the end. Since New Jersey is one of the states that defaulted to a fed-run exchange, this shows that people are starting to trickle through. I know, one example — but the plural of anecdote is data.

headline: S Chair, Meet Tom Vac
text: Jan Habraken used 3-D software to “breed” classic chairs with the goal of designing the ultimate offspring. In this clip, he introduced a Verner Panton model to a chair by Ron Arad.

headline: The Hurdles to Success for the Affordable Care Act
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Ten Jewish Men Detained  at Temple Mount
text: JERUSALEM — Ten Jewish men were removed from the Temple Mount on Monday morning and questioned by the police after they unfurled an Israeli flag, sang the national anthem and danced at the holy site, according to Israeli authorities.

headline: Tourists Stranded at Everest Base Camp in Tibet
text: BEIJING — At least 86 tourists were trapped by heavy snow on Monday at the north base camp of Mount Everest in central Tibet, according to Xinhua, China’s state news agency.

headline: 'Rally'
text: The latest ad from the Lhota campaign highlights the candidate's stance on charter schools.

headline: Peppers Stuffed With Rice, Zucchini and Herbs
text: I used a medium-grain rice that I buy at my local Iranian market for these peppers. The package says that the rice is great for stuffing vegetables because it doesn’t swell too much, and it’s right. It goes into the peppers uncooked and steams in the oven, inside the peppers (so it’s important to cook them long enough and cover the baking dish). Make sure that you spoon the sauce left in the baking dish over the rice once the peppers are done. These are good hot or at room temperature. I like to use green peppers.

headline: Market Report | The Irresistible Appeal of a Leather Chair
text: A bit of leather warms up a modern chair — and a room for that matter — with its earthy hue and gently worn patina.

headline: A Major New Resort in the Bahamas
text: Baha Mar, a $3.5 billion luxury resort, is scheduled to open in December 2014 in Nassau in the Bahamas.

headline: Do You Know Who I Am?
text: One of the odd things about the debates we’ve been having over economic policy since the financial crisis is how many people on one side of these debates — the side I’m not on, as it happens — believe that they can win arguments by pulling rank. Critics are dismissed as just bloggers, which supposedly disqualifies them from pointing out errors and untrue statements; ideas are dismissed (wrongly, as it happens) as not part of what anyone has taught graduate students , as if this removes any possibility that the ideas might nonetheless be right.

headline: Terra-cotta Warriors Get a Sex Change
text: The terra-cotta warriors who stand subterranean watch at the tomb of China’s first emperor have been called symbols of many things: military might, the longevity of Chinese culture and the organizational zeal and lust for power of the ruler who unified the country and had the statues buried with him. For Prune Nourry, a French artist whose work focuses on the subject of gender imbalances, the clay soldiers represent men, lots and lots of them.

headline: The Nobel
text: It’s an old jibe against economics that it’s the only field where two people can win the Nobel for saying exactly the opposite thing; even the people making that jibe, however, probably didn’t envisage those two guys sharing the same prize, which is kind of what happened here.

headline: Mullins to Donate $15 Million to the Art Center College of Design
text: The Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., a training ground for automobile designers, will formally announce Tuesday that it has received a $15 million donation from Peter and Merle Mullin to enhance the school’s industrial and transportation design programs. Mr. Mullin said in a telephone interview that he had long admired the school.

headline: Martin Gardner’s ‘The Annotated Alice’
text: This week we continue to celebrate the life of the popular science and math writer Martin Gardner, who would have been 99 years old next week, on Oct. 21. Mr. Gardner published more than 100 books in a variety of fields: philosophy, religion, magic and — as many Numberplay readers are probably aware — recreational math puzzles. I recently wondered — of everything Mr. Gardner has written, which has been his biggest seller? There’s “My Best Mathematical and Logic Puzzles,” which seems to be wedged onto every math bookshelf. And “Aha! Insight.” Everyone has a copy of that. And then there’s “Classic Brainteasers.” But which book has been the most popular? I asked Martin Gardner’s son, Jim, whose answer surprised me:

headline: Switching Platforms
text: A generational shift in getting the news.

headline: Israel Warns Against Easing Sanctions on Iran
text: JERUSALEM — Israel urged the world powers on Monday not to ease sanctions against Iran as talks on the nuclear dispute were about to resume, arguing that now of all times was the time to keep up the pressure.

headline: In Bhutan, a Bid to Turn Basketball From a Royal Sport to a National One
text: THIMPHU, Bhutan — With just seconds left in the game, the queen of Bhutan went to the hole like a hungry snow leopard pouncing on a mountain goat, taking two dribbles and three long strides before putting up a royal layup.

headline: Image of the Day: October 14
text: Last day of celebrations of the Hindu festival of Dussehra in Mysore, Karnataka.

headline: New Director for Museum of Biblical Art
text: The Museum of Biblical Art in Manhattan has appointed Richard P. Townsend as its new director, the museum is to announce on Tuesday.

headline: Missing a Young Friend in a Changed Kabul
text: On the streets of Kabul last March, I saw a small figure turn a corner about 20 feet ahead, then a flash of recognition, a huge smile and a big wave. For 10 maddening minutes we stared at each other, Samir and his shy little sister Malika on one side of the barricade, I on the other — too far apart to speak, too long to keep waving like an idiot.

headline: Today in Small Business: Taxes Are Still Due
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Way Out of the Cooper Tire-Apollo Tyres Mess
text: Investors in Cooper Tire and Rubber are being forced to pick lanes. Legal wrangles have put Apollo Tyres’ agreed $2.5 billion offer for Cooper Tire, its American rival in doubt, and tensions at Cooper’s China joint venture have undermined its value. But a negotiated price reduction still looks possible. Cooper shares may be pricing in too much bad news.

headline: Senators Near Fiscal Deal, but the House Is Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders neared the completion Monday night of a bipartisan deal to raise the debt ceiling and end the government shutdown while the rest of the world braced for the possibility of an American default that could set off a global financial disaster.

headline: New Off Broadway Theaters Planned for West Midtown
text: Two New York theater veterans have signed a 10-year lease to open an Off Broadway performance center early next year that would provide more options for producers and artists creating small-scale work.

headline: Walkabout: Some National Parks Reopen; Bay Area Transit Strike Looms
text: States Reopening Some Parks With the government shutdown continuing, some states are reopening national parks and other tourist spots using their own funds and private donations. (Jaunted)

headline: In the South, Cake or Pie for Dessert?
text: Pie or cake: Which better defines the Southern cook’s signature dessert? The Southern Foodways Alliance Symposium, now in its 16th year, dedicates many hours to debating such searing food topics as this one. (Last year they took on the merits of barbecue competitions.) At this year’s symposium at the University of Mississippi, Kim Severson, the Atlanta bureau chief for The New York Times and a former food writer, made the case that cake reigns supreme in Southern kitchens as well as Southern literature. And Kat Kinsman, the managing editor of CNN’s food blog Eatocracy, spoke up for pie at their Oct. 5 appearance.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Vietnam Bids Farewell to General Giap
text: Mourners crowded near the grave site of Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap during his burial ceremony at Vung Chua-Yen island, in the central province of Quang Binh, on Sunday. General Giap, who led campaigns that drove both France and the United States out of Vietnam, died Oct. 4 in Hanoi. He was believed to be 102.

headline: Carl Bernstein Plans Memoir on His Cub Reporter Days
text: The writer Carl Bernstein has struck a deal to write a memoir of his early years as a cub reporter in Washington, his publisher, Henry Holt & Company, said on Monday.

headline: In Our Pages: October 15
text: 1913 U.S. Balloon Victory at Hand

headline: A High School Is Actually Not Manhattan’s Saddest Spot, a Researcher Says
text: A research group that named Hunter College High School the saddest tweeting spot in Manhattan now says it was mistaken in its finding. The group’s acknowledgment of the error came to light after many questions were raised about an initial post on the study.

headline: For Sale in Queens: A Ribbon of Land, Three Feet Wide
text: Just a few weeks back, a local community board said that a small piece of city-owned land on a leafy block in Murray Hill, Queens, could be put up for sale. The surrounding streets are lined with smooth lawns and shingled houses. The spot itself is grassy and dappled with trees. But there is a catch.

headline: Garnett Says Nets Are ‘a Work in Progress’ on Defense
text: PHILADELPHIA — As blunt as Kevin Garnett was Monday about the Nets’ defensive struggles, he was equally direct about the team’s lofty defensive ambitions.

headline: Analyzing the Sweet Tooth
text: Q. Even after a large meal I often get a craving for something sweet. Is there a biological basis for this, or is it a learned behavior?

headline: Ralph Lauren's Parisian Dream
text: Suzy Menkes sits down with David Lauren to discuss Ralph Lauren's donation to restore and modernize the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris.

headline: Peugeot Shares Fall on Possibility of  Deal to Raise Capital
text: PARIS — Shares of PSA Peugeot Citroën tumbled on Monday as investors anticipated that the struggling French automaker was closing in on a deal to raise fresh capital that would dilute the value of its stock.

headline: Plastic Merges into China’s Farmland: Report
text: Call it “plearth,” perhaps.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: Individually they run two of the most coveted — and contrasting — labels in fashion, Sacai and Kolor. But the Japanese design couple Chitose and Junichi Abe find some common ground in their airy Tokyo home.

headline: Home/Work | Two Designers and One Very Modern House in Tokyo
text: Individually they run two of the most coveted — and contrasting — labels in fashion, Sacai and Kolor. But the Japanese design couple Chitose and Junichi Abe find some common ground in their airy Tokyo home.

headline: Street Style: Braids
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Oct. 7.

headline: The Solar Robots
text: A California company thinks robots that can install and clean thousands of solar panels may make solar energy competitive with fossil fuels.

headline: A Staff of Robots Can Clean and Install Solar Panels
text: RICHMOND, Calif. — In a dusty yard under a blistering August sun, Rover was hard at work, lifting 45-pound solar panels off a stack and installing them, one by one, into a concrete track. A few yards away, Rover’s companion, Spot, moved along a row of panels, washing away months of grit, then squeegeeing them dry.

headline: Keeping Colorful This Fall
text: The must-have item of the autumn season is a coat in a bright hue — or even a print.

headline: The Immune System, From the Inside
text: The way many immunologists see the world, there are only two human diseases. In the first, the immune system is too lethargic, allowing infectious diseases and cancers to attack the body. In the second, the immune system is too aggressive, leading to an array of autoimmune diseases like lupus and multiple sclerosis.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Jerome Barrillon joined Keiler, Farmington, Conn., in a new post, executive director for industrial accounts. He had worked for companies that include Ahlstrom and Illinois Tool Works.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: A Feeding Instinct Starts in the Womb
text: Hungry babies instinctively open their mouths as their mother’s breast or a bottle draws near. Now, researchers from England and France report that this instinct — the anticipation of touch — is a skill fetuses teach themselves in the womb. Studying scans at monthly intervals between 24 and 36 weeks of pregnancy, the scientists found that the youngest fetuses were more likely to touch their heads and that as they matured, they began to touch their mouths more. And by 36 weeks, the fetuses began to open their mouths before they touched them.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: October 11-13, 2013
text: In Columbus, Ohio, one teenager is a victim of gun violence every day, and half of the offenses were committed by other teens, The Columbus Dispatch reported yesterday. In some neighborhoods, everyone knows someone who has died of gun violence.

headline: Female Meerkat: Will Nurse for Rent
text: In meerkat communities, only the dominant female breeds; when others try to breed, the dominant female will often kill the pups or force another mother to abort.

headline: Scene City: Friends of Siri on the Big Screen
text: “Her,” a new film by Spike Jonze, closes out New York Film Festival.

headline: When the Financial Past Is Not Prologue
text: Imagine that I flip a coin five times, and with every flip, the coin comes up heads. Now let’s say I offered you a bet on the next toss. Which side would you pick?

headline: Ronaldo ... for the Defense
text: Heading into the final day of the group stage of World Cup qualifying in Europe, Portugal requires a mini-miracle to overtake first-place Russia in Group F and avoid a two-game playoff with an opponent to be determined.

headline: Ads Propose Sunday in the Kitchen With Glad
text: A leading brand whose purpose is to help consumers keep food fresher longer is joining the fight against wasting food.

headline: How to Opt Out of Google’s Plan to Use Your Name and Comments in Ads
text: Updated on Oct. 15 in response to reader comments on their opt-out experience. |  When Google announced last week that it would change its terms of service to allow it to show people’s social networking activity — like names, photos, ratings, reviews and comments — in ads across more than two million Web sites, it strongly emphasized that users could easily opt out.

headline: What Cheating Says About Us (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Another Henry Moore Work Is Stolen in Britain
text: A large bronze sculpture by Henry Moore has been stolen from a park in Scotland, the latest outdoor artwork by the modernist sculptor to have been nipped by thieves in Britain, according to The London Evening Standard. The 1950 work, “Standing Figure,” which was taken last week, is over seven feet tall.

headline: Science Bookshelf
text: 1 FIVE DAYS AT MEMORIAL by Sheri Fink. Crown. The case of a New Orleans surgeon suspected of euthanizing patients during the Katrina disaster.

headline: When We Next See Our Hero ...
text: Fans of James Bond movies aren’t likely to recognize the hero of this new James Bond novel. Fans of the original Ian Fleming books may have less trouble seeing aspects of their man here, if only dim resemblances. Which doesn’t mean that “Solo,” by William Boyd, isn’t a perfectly well-carpentered and, at times, suspenseful novel. (He was tapped by the Ian Fleming estate to write the latest installment of 007’s adventures.) It just doesn’t feature a hero, who — aside from some pretty generic traits like an eye for the ladies, an ability to kill and an appreciation for expensive cars and a good meal — really feels like the Bond we have come to know over the last five decades.

headline: Art Matters | A Brief History of Mike Kelley’s ‘Day Is Done’
text: Whenever anyone commits suicide, as the artist Mike Kelley did early last year, everyone tends to look for answers. There are none to be found in “Mike Kelley,” the exhibition, a sprawling retrospective of the prolific multidisciplinary creator at MoMA PS1 in Queens, which appeared earlier this year at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam and will travel to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles next spring. There is, however, one piece that can clearly be read as an inflection point in his career. It’s also a worthy introduction to Kelley’s practice.

headline: Bartman and Fielder: A Tale of Two Pop-Ups
text: In the bottom of the ninth inning Sunday night, as the clock ticked toward midnight, Boston’s Jarrod Saltalamacchia lifted a foul pop-up near the first-base stands at Fenway Park. Detroit first baseman Prince Fielder moved toward the short wall and into that ambiguous intersection between player and fan where everyone is reaching for the ball and fan interference is rarely invoked.

headline: Moose Die-Off Alarms Scientists
text: CHOTEAU, Mont. — Across North America — in places as far-flung as Montana and British Columbia, New Hampshire and Minnesota — moose populations are in steep decline. And no one is sure why.

headline: Shiller on Boom, Bust and Human Nature
text: Since 2007, Robert J. Shiller, one of this year’s Nobel laureates in economic science, has been a regular contributor to the Sunday Business section of The New York Times. He started in that role as the downturn in the housing market, which he had been calling attention to, was being increasingly felt.

headline: The End of a Farmer’s Era
text: One of the Greenmarkets’ longest-standing participants is officially retiring at the end of this year’s growing season.

headline: To Market, to Market, No More
text: CHANGEWATER, N.J. — As he pushed a manual weeder through an inch-tall row of fall cilantro, Bill Maxwell ticked off a list of the types of people who make good vegetable farmers: worriers, workaholics, obsessive followers of the weather, those able to nap in a truck cab in the middle of Manhattan’s Union Square.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Premiere Is Highest Rated Show of TV Season
text: “The Walking Dead” is officially devouring the rest of television.

headline: Keeping Score: Clutch Hitting Explained (It’s Not What You Think)
text: If it were any other player stepping to the plate in the eighth inning of a playoff game with the bases loaded and his team down by four runs, the situation would have been tense, to say the least. But with David Ortiz it seemed there was only one option: a game-tying grand slam.

headline: In Performance: Eric Bogosian
text: The playwright performs a scene from the show “100 (Monologues),” a LAByrinth Theater Company production at the Bank Street Theater.

headline: Ordinary Women: Wendy Lower Talks About ‘Hitler’s Furies’
text: In “Hitler’s Furies,” recently placed on the long list for the National Book Award, Wendy Lower presents the harrowing evidence of crimes committed by German women during the Holocaust. Dwight Garner wrote that previous books “have offered up poster girls of brutality and atrocity” and “Ms. Lower’s revisionist insight is to track more mundane lives, and to argue for a vastly wider complicity.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Lower discussed the changing view of women’s role in the Nazi regime, the challenges of writing for a non-academic audience, what she found most shocking in her research and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Touring Southeast Asia, Chinese Leader Outshines Kerry
text: At the East Asia Summit meeting in Brunei last week, Secretary of State John Kerry had barely finished counseling Southeast Asian countries to stick together in their quarrels with China over the South China Sea when Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China embarked on tours of Thailand and Vietnam.

headline: In New Nuclear Talks, Technological Gains by Iran Pose Challenges to the West
text: GENEVA — Iran is expected to make an offer on Tuesday to scale back its effort to enrich uranium, a move that a year ago would have been a significant concession to the West. But Iran’s nuclear abilities have advanced so far since then that experts say it will take far more than that to assure the West that Tehran does not have the capacity to quickly produce a nuclear weapon.

headline: Moncler Files to Go Public on Milan’s Stock Market
text: Moncler, the cold-weather apparel maker, said on Monday that it had applied to go public on the Milan Stock Exchange, becoming the latest fashion company to pursue a stock listing.

headline: Britain Makes an Overture to Repair Ties With China
text: LONDON — After months of frosty relations with China, the British government took steps on Monday toward reconciliation, promising to relax visa rules for Chinese businesspeople and some tourists and saying that it had no plans for more high-profile meetings with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader.

headline: Death Did Not Part Them, and Some People Don’t Like It
text: There was an enjoyable thriller in 1970 called “Colossus: The Forbin Project,” in which a monolithic United States military computer system unites with its Soviet counterpart to commit nuclear blackmail and conquer the world. Today, of course, schoolchildren hold computers in their palms, and so we have Jeffrey Jackson’s smart, provocative and often funny play  “Two Point Oh,” a delightful production from the troupe Active Theater, which puts a human face on global software despotism.

headline: California Imposes New Home Care Regulations
text: California has become the latest state to tighten oversight of home health agencies that provide custodial care — help with bathing, dressing, toileting and other basic tasks — to older adults and people with disabilities.

headline: Parasites: Hookworm Vaccine Will Be Tried in Africa
text: The first African clinical trial of an experimental vaccine against hookworm is planned for next year.

headline: Helping T-Cells Fight Cancer
text:
An experimental immunotherapy could help T-cells, a type of white
blood cell, recognize and destroy cancer cells.

headline: Testing the Limits of ‘Terminal’
text: Our new patient was 51, always a problematic age — old to some, young to others. He had turned yellow a few weeks before.

headline: A Belief in Books on Paper
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: A Solution for Zoo Penguins
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The Military’s Hail Mary
text: The latest reason to worry about the military’s handling of sexual assault complaints comes from Jo Ann Rooney, President Obama’s nominee for under-Secretary of the Navy.

headline: A Martyr in Drag, Slinging Hash for That Thankless Daughter
text: A breeze from distant Provincetown just blew into the East Village, bringing audiences with a taste for lowdown drag a last chance at a summer fling. “Mildred Fierce,” a musical spoof of — really, do I need to tell you? — opened on Saturday night at Theater 80 on St. Marks Place. It’s the kind of goofy, bawdy, anything-goes diversion that might kick off a festive night on the town in that popular gay resort destination.

headline: Haunted by a Child’s Illness
text: A child’s serious illness can cast a very long shadow across a family, often for years after the crisis has passed.

headline: Buyout Firms Combing U.S. for Sky-High Sums to Invest
text: Private-equity funds are in a mad dash for cash.

headline: Moscow Police Round Up Targets of Riot at Market
text: MOSCOW — A day after residents and members of hate groups rampaged through a vegetable market in a working-class district of Moscow, beating and terrorizing migrant workers, the police swept through in force on Monday.

headline: A Dual Tribute to Two Titans
text: While watching T. Oliver Reid and Karen Oberlin stumble through an evening of Frank Sinatra and Billie Holiday standards at the Metropolitan Room on Sunday evening, I recalled the many unlikely pairings who have struggled to find common ground in variety shows. The theory behind such couplings seems to be that two is better than one; if nothing else, the novelty element will see them through.

headline: A Twirling Airiness in a Recital of Schumann, Bach and Debussy
text: When the teenage French pianist Lise de la Salle presented a recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art six years ago, the New York Times critic Bernard Holland ended an admiring review with a blunt declaration: “Ms. de la Salle has a substantial career ahead of her.” That prediction has been borne out in subsequent years, as this focused artist — now 25 — has garnered widespread renown for her recordings and increasingly prominent engagements.

headline: For Many Hard-Liners, Debt Default Is the Goal
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Two Who Continue to Endure: Verdi and Levine
text: Leave it to James Levine to remind us that the work he does is more than substantial enough to warrant all the attention, hope and ink lavished upon him these last few years. Sidelined for almost two full seasons by illnesses and injuries serious enough to warrant concern that he would never conduct again, Mr. Levine silenced doubters during a concert for the ages with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in May.

headline: Diseases That Spread From Animals
text: In his Op-Ed, David Quammen explores the origins of potential afflictions that might cause future pandemics. This accompanying article looks deeper at the symptoms, circumstances and fallout that characterized the Black Death, Spanish Influenza, Ebola virus, AIDS and SARS.

headline: In Struggle With Weight, Taft Used a Modern Diet
text: William Howard Taft, the only massively obese man ever to be president of the United States, struggled mightily to control his weight a century ago, worrying about his health and image, and endured humiliation from cartoonists who delighted in his corpulent figure. But new research has found that his weight-loss program was startlingly contemporary, and his difficulties keeping the pounds off would be familiar to many Americans today.

headline: On National Pregnancy and Infant Loss Remembrance Day, a Mother With a Candle to Light
text: Around town, people recognize me for different things. For some, I’m the woman who grocery shops on Friday mornings. For others, I’m the woman who bikes downtown. For still others, I’m the bookstore browser, the teacher, the wife of the beekeeper, the mother of the two boys with a skateboard. But rarely do people recognize me as the mother of a child who is gone.

headline: A Surreal Collage of Shaking, Swooning and Stumbling
text: Four dancers in an open space — how might they relate to one another? That question was the principal point of commonality on a bill pairing choreography by Rebecca Davis and Taisha Paggett at Danspace Project last weekend. In both cases, the answers were mystifying.

headline: Almost Over
text: Senate Republicans have figured out what to do:

headline: Qaeda Suspect Is Brought to New York for a Hearing
text: The terrorism suspect who had been undergoing interrogation on a Navy ship after his recent capture in Libya was brought to New York over the weekend and was to appear before a federal judge on Tuesday, officials said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, India, Saudi Arabia and Afghanistan.

headline: With Skylanders, Swap Characters, or Their Halves
text: Activision has built its Skylanders brand into a global powerhouse, with sales of more than $500 million in 2012 in the United States. This year, the company hopes to expand with the next video game in the franchise, the highly anticipated Skylanders Swap Force, which was released on Sunday.

headline: Breaking Through Cancer’s Shield
text: For more than a century, researchers were puzzled by the uncanny ability of cancer cells to evade the immune system. They knew cancer cells were grotesquely abnormal and should be killed by white blood cells. In the laboratory, in Petri dishes, white blood cells could go on the attack against cancer cells. Why, then, could cancers survive in the body?

headline: With iOS 7 Upgrade, Podcasts Move to an Apple App
text: Finding Podcasts

headline: What Is the Debt Ceiling?
text: During the October 2013 government shutdown, The Times’s David Leonhardt explained the debt limit and how a failure to raise it could have affected the economy both at home and abroad.

headline: Angst Endures for a Pioneer of Grunge
text: “All the demons used to come round,” Eddie Vedder sings in “Future Days,” the ballad that closes “Lightning Bolt,” Pearl Jam’s 10th studio album. “I’m grateful now they’ve left.” Well, not entirely: Pearl Jam still needs something to brood about.

headline: Belongings That Remain After You Go
text: When the people have vanished, all that remains is their stuff: a bicycle, a garden gnome, a bedraggled doll, a pumpkin and about 40 other items poised at the front of the stage.

headline: Business Rebuilds in a Thriving City in Iraq
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Perception is not always reality with emerging business travel destinations. That’s especially true for Erbil, the political and business capital of the autonomous Kurdish region in the north of Iraq. The city is becoming an alternative to Iraq’s southern provinces to tap into the country’s oil wealth and other business opportunities.

headline: A Maryland Hill’s Prehistoric Secret
text: LOTHIAN, Md. — For weeks, Al Luckenbach puzzled over the bones surfacing in the pit atop the Patuxent River bluff here. They were hard to identify: fragments and shattered splinters, unlike the intact animal bones heaped in the nearly 9,000-year-old feast site down the hill.

headline: Roll Over, Stradivarius
text: NAZARETH, Pa. — For guitar aficionados, a visit to the C. F. Martin & Company factory is akin to a religious experience. They talk in reverential tones about the handcrafted instruments that have been coming off the production floor here for more than 150 years, even referring to certain models in online discussion forums as “the Holy Grail” of the acoustic guitar.

headline: Taking Killers and Thrillers to the Web
text: Before Amazon, Hulu and Netflix started soaking up all the oxygen in the streaming-video world, other companies were trying to establish themselves as purveyors of television-quality original Web shows.

headline: Troupe Has the Courage of Its Commissions
text: It’s expensive to produce new ballets. There are few remarkable ballet choreographers to make them. The outcome is uncertain. Mixed repertory programs don’t sell well. What audiences really want — and will pay for — are full-length story ballets, preferably “Swan Lake” or “The Nutcracker.”

headline: Video: What Is the Debt Ceiling?
text: The Times’s David Leonhardt explains the debt limit and how a failure to raise it in the next several days could affect the economy both at home and abroad.

headline: Always Alone Together, Even When They’re Apart
text: At Dia:Chelsea on Saturday, two black panels shaped like twin towers were showered in opalescent light. Hands gripping the panels were the only visible parts of the bodies that rolled the shapes gradually forward toward an audience on risers and then back into the darkness at the rear of the large space.

headline: Farming’s Avant-Garde
text: When the photographer Henk Wildschut set out to study the food industry in the Netherlands, he found a “clean world of rules and protocols,” not a dishonest and unethical industry that he expected.

headline: Gallery | Modernist Masterpieces, In Their Twilight Years
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: ScienceTake: Sharing a Peahen's Gaze
text: Do a peacock’s feathers, in all their iridescent beauty, really win the girl? Scientists put an eye-tracking helmet camera on a peahen to find out where her gaze lingered.

headline: Shopping for Fall Fashion? Relax: You’ll Look Great
text: Before Olivia Kim was named the director of creative projects at Nordstrom this year, she worked at Opening Ceremony, where she played an influential role in its many indie discoveries and unconventional collaborations. Now she has unveiled her first project for Nordstrom: a series of pop-ups. The first, in eight Nordstrom stores (items are also sold online), is called French Fling and is a homage to all things French. The custom-built installations were designed by Rafael de Cárdenas, and the design firm M/M Paris did the graphics. Among the handpicked selection of goods are Olympia Le Tan clutches (in a limited run of 16), $1,295 to $1,595; and New Era caps with titles of Jean-Luc Godard films across the front, $35. Gift items from the Parisian shop Merci, available for the first time in the United States, include home goods and this Liberty-print medallion, $10, which can be worn as a necklace or wrapped around the wrist. See nordstrom.com/pop for information.

headline: How to Feed the World
text: It’s been 50 years since President John F. Kennedy spoke of ending world hunger, yet on the eve of World Food Day, Oct. 16, the situation remains dire. The question “How will we feed the world?” implies that we have no choice but to intensify industrial agriculture, with more high-tech seeds, chemicals and collateral damage. Yet there are other, better options.

headline: Introducing The International New York Times
text: Today we celebrate the debut of The International New York Times (www.INYT.com), a news report tailored specifically for the valued members of our global audience.

headline: A Visit to Beijing’s First R.V. Park
text: European and American style campers, symbols of luxury and freedom in China, are gaining popularity among affluent vacationers eager to escape urban congestion.

headline: Chinese Embracing the Perceived Freedom of R.V.’s
text: Ah, the smell of grilling meat, the feel-good squeal of Katy Perry and the thwack of fly swatter on prey. To Tian Xuan and his 20-something friends barbecuing outside their Cherokee-brand trailer in Beijing, it felt like an idyllic scene out of a Hollywood movie — except for the insects and the industrial-strength smog that had drifted in from nearby Hebei Province.

headline: Nature Overflows in These Musty Rooms
text: LONDON — There was a Galápagos fern, collected by Charles Darwin himself. There were mahogany cabinets filled with plants from the East India Company, including the two tea leaves whose discovery launched the Indian tea trade. There was an antelope net made of baobab bark, from David Livingstone’s storied Zambezi expedition more than 150 years ago.

headline: Nobel Prizes and an Astronaut Mourned
text: It was Nobel Prize week, with many of the honors going to scientists at American universities. But there was plenty of news in other quarters, from Hawaii to Neptune, from lost lizards to a lost moon.

headline: Former Defense Chief Says Fiscal Standoff Is Hurting Military Readiness
text: WASHINGTON — Leon E. Panetta, who has been in charge of the federal budget, intelligence-gathering and then defense for two Democratic presidents, on Monday said the fiscal impasse is hurting all three areas.

headline: Good (and Bad) News for Air Travelers
text: AS the travel season hits full speed with the holidays on the horizon, here are some of the pros and cons I’ve been noticing on the road lately.

headline: Geno Smith's Growing Pains
text: The Jets’ season has been a series of ups and downs, all coinciding with the performances of quarterback Geno Smith. William C. Rhoden says the team and its fans need to be patient with the rookie.

headline: Geno Smith’s Growing Pains
text: The Jets’ season has been a series of ups and downs, all coinciding with the performances of quarterback Geno Smith. The team and its fans need to be patient with the rookie and allow him to grow into a winner.

headline: Making It | From Hermès, Couture Jewelry Inspired by Crocodiles
text: Hermès reinterprets the intricate pattern of a crocodile’s scales into a dazzling collection of couture jewelry.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Computer Club of Jobs and Wozniak Reunites, and What’s Next for @Jack?
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Between Big Cities, a Road Passes the Russia Left Behind
text: LYUBAN, Russia — A few times every day, the high-speed train between St. Petersburg and Moscow barrels through the threadbare town of Lyuban. When word gets out that the head of Russia’s state railway company — a close friend of President Vladimir V. Putin — is aboard, the station’s employees line up on the platform standing at attention, saluting Russia’s modernization for the seconds it takes the train to fly through. Whoosh.

headline: Predictions for Health, Science and Life
text: In the early 21st century, we take for granted a pace of change that can leave the near-miraculous seeming unremarkable but also upend ways of life with little warning. Scientists, professors and others peer around the corner to offer their take at what might be coming next.

headline: Emerging From an Egg, as Others Tuck Into Food
text: SOMETIMES I can be on the road for two or more weeks, traveling to several countries, and it can get very tiring, but traveling is a huge part of my job as president and founder of Iredale Mineral Cosmetics.

headline: Down a Road Less Traveled, Looking for the Still Heart of Russia
text: A year and a half ago, the photographer Dmitry Kostyukov came to me with an idea: to document the road journey between St. Petersburg and Moscow, an abysmal stretch more easily hopped by air or high-speed rail, and seldom traveled by anyone with the money or privilege to avoid it.

headline: Hunter at the Wall
text: Revisiting a 2006 article on Torii Hunter, the Detroit Tigers player known for his ball-catching prowess.

headline: Rampage in Moscow Unfolds on Camera
text: Updated, Tuesday, 1:00 p.m. | As my colleague Andrew Kramer reports, video posted online late Sunday offered visceral images of rioting by Russian nationalists who beat and terrorized migrant workers at a vegetable market in a working-class district of Moscow.

headline: With Running Backs Hurt, Giants Turn to Rookie
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Leaving the practice field Monday morning, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was asked about the limited number of running backs he had available during the workout.

headline: Tommy Scott, Country Singer With a Traveling Medicine Show, Dies at 96
text: Tommy Scott, a country singer and songwriter who began his career in the 1930s as a member of one of the last traveling medicine shows and later became its leader, keeping it alive for more than five decades of one-night stands long after its dubious comedy and digestive cures became cultural relics, died on Sept. 30 in Toccoa, Ga. He was 96.

headline: Three Tuesdays. Three Debates.
text: An analysis of the first mayoral debate featuring Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota.

headline: Richmond Awaits a Bold Antipoverty Plan
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Dressed on an unseasonably warm day, as ever, in a tailored suit, tie and pocket square, Mayor Dwight C. Jones, a fourth-generation pastor, arrived at a late-afternoon meeting this month to talk about his ambitious — some say quixotic — plan to subdue poverty in this city, once the capital of the Confederacy and now one of the nation’s poorest urban areas.

headline: On a New Jersey Islet, Twilight of the Landline
text: MANTOLOKING, N.J. — Hurricane Sandy devastated this barrier island community of multimillion-dollar homes, but in Peter Flihan’s view, Verizon Communications has delivered a second blow: the telecommunications giant did not rebuild the landlines destroyed in the storm, and traditional telephone service here has now gone the way of the telegraph.

headline: Rally at the Alamo Will Call on Texans to Raise Their Rifles High
text: HOUSTON — Hundreds of armed demonstrators are planning to converge at the Alamo in San Antonio on Saturday to test the limits of the gun laws in one of the most gun-friendly states in the country, by openly carrying their shotguns, assault weapons and other types of rifles in public.

headline: Beneficiaries of Medicare Left Confused by Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — Medicare beneficiaries can sign up for private health plans starting Tuesday, but federal officials fear that many of them, out of confusion, might go to the new federal insurance exchange.

headline: Signs of Affection, or Not, at the Old Ballgame
text: Baseball fans have found myriad ways to display affection for their teams, on placards and bedsheets — and the occasional body part.

headline: Harper’s Redesigns Its Web Site and Embraces Branded Content
text: HARPER’S Bazaar is joining the growing list of media properties whose publishers are supplementing more traditional forms of advertising with sponsored content.

headline: The 180-Pound Gorilla in the Operating Room
text: There was unrestricted viewing of Disney and National Geographic DVDs, and a stock of favorite snacks. But Holli — who goes by a single name — was not a model hospital patient. While recovering from complicated surgery in September, she methodically yanked out every staple from her 10-inch-long incision. Another time, she looked a medical resident in the eye and ripped a catheter from her arm. Boredom gave way to tantrums.

headline: Rangers Put Backup Goaltender on Waivers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Goaltender Martin Biron, normally effusive after Rangers practices, looked grim Monday sitting at his dressing room stall. Moments earlier, Coach Alain Vigneault told Biron he had been put on waivers, leaving him two choices: report to Hartford of the American Hockey League (or whichever N.H.L. team claims him) or retire.

headline: The Bloodlust of Pundits Swirls Around Jamie Dimon
text: Jamie Dimon should be fired.

headline: Netflix, as Easy as Changing the Channel
text: The television two-step is familiar to nearly every household with a TV set and a Netflix subscription. To watch cable, the television must be on one setting; to browse Netflix, it has to be on another. For some family members, toggling between the two is easy; for others, it’s so befuddling that it discourages any straying from cable at all.

headline: No Reason to Wait on Marriage
text: In a wise ruling last month, New Jersey Superior Court Judge Mary Jacobson declared that same-sex couples “must be allowed to marry in order to obtain equal protection of the law under the New Jersey Constitution.” On Thursday, she ordered that same-sex marriages be allowed starting Monday because New Jersey would suffer no harm if gay men and lesbians are permitted to wed.

headline: Testing Europe’s Conscience
text: After the drowning of more than 300 Africans near the Italian island of Lampedusa, the European Commission president, José Manuel Barroso, pledged 30 million euros, or about $40.7 million, last week to help Italy deal with an overwhelming influx of refugees. While this is a good start, it is far from enough.

headline: Fukushima Politics
text: “Zero nuclear plants.” With this recent call, Japan’s very popular former prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, is again in the limelight. His bold new stance challenges his protégé, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, whose policies would restart as many nuclear power plants as possible (now all shut down), and even promote the export of nuclear reactors. Mr. Koizumi deems the pursuit of nuclear power “aimless” and “irresponsible.”

headline: Unearthed: A Possible Stop Along the Revolution
text: Maybe George Washington slept there, or maybe he only watered his horse and ordered stronger stuff for himself. Either way, David Freeland sounded excited as he crossed the threshold where a famous Colonial-era tavern, the Bull’s Head, once welcomed thirsty out-of-towners.

headline: When the News and the Novel Collide
text: I thought I knew what I was writing about. Three years ago, when I started working on my second book, I imagined it would one day be a quiet, multigenerational novel revolving around a thousand-year-old synagogue in Cairo. At the time, I wasn’t thinking much about current events. The book was set mostly in the past. And Egyptian politics were, at the time, relatively stable. In early 2010, Hosni Mubarak was beginning his 30th year as president of Egypt, the Muslim Brotherhood was outlawed and Tahrir Square was nothing more than a traffic circle in the middle of Cairo. Over the past three years, all this has changed. At first I tried to convince myself that my novel was unrelated to the revolution that toppled Mubarak. But eventually I realized that the book would have to adapt. The landscape of my imagination had shifted beneath my feet.

headline: The Senate Tries to End the Crisis
text: The Senate, forced to extinguish the wildfire set by the House, is nearing a deal to reopen the government and end the imminent threat of default by the United States government. Some of the provisions in the deal are troubling, and senators need to ensure that it doesn’t in any way give in to Republican blackmail. If they can do so, the agreement may finally represent a way to end the crisis without encouraging blackmail when the debt ceiling comes up again.

headline: Governor’s Crusade Against Corruption Comes With Too Many Asterisks
text: “The politicians in Albany won’t like it, but I work for the people, and I won’t stop fighting until we all have a government that we can trust.”

headline: Conjuring Up Our Own Gods
text: BIG SUR, Calif. — “AMERICANS are obsessed with the supernatural,” Jeffrey J. Kripal, a scholar of religion, told me here at Esalen, an institute dedicated to the idea that “we are all capable of the extraordinary.”

headline: The Heartache of an Immigrant Family
text: LOS ANGELES — WHEN we talk about immigration to America, we tell a hopeful story about courage and sacrifice. But that story obscures the fact that, especially for the poor, immigration is often a traumatizing event, one that tears families apart.

headline: Changing the Debt-Ceiling Game
text: THERE’S a lot of talk these days about raising the debt ceiling, to create time for more meaningful budget negotiations. But why should anyone expect Act II of this tragedy to unfold any differently from Act I? What we need most isn’t more time, but to change the debt-ceiling game itself, to make “debt-ceiling moments” less fraught with peril, less prone to stalemate, and more conducive to productive negotiations.

headline: Spurs Stay Consistent by Thinking Globally
text: SAN ANTONIO — When the San Antonio Spurs sent an intern to Argentina in July to ferry a new contract to guard Manu Ginobili, it seemed a routine trip. The Spurs preferred hand delivery to the mail. A previous contract had been brought for Ginobili to sign on his honeymoon.

headline: A World Without Privacy
text: In his great and prophetic novel “1984,” George Orwell laid out his vision of what totalitarianism would look like if taken to its logical extreme. The government — in the form of Big Brother — sees all and knows all. The Party rewrites the past and controls the present. Heretics pop up on television screens so they can be denounced by the populace. And the Ministry of Truth propagates the Party’s three slogans:

headline: As China Moves to Lower Professor’s Profile, Colleges Are Seeking to Raise Theirs
text: BEIJING — It is hard to know exactly which transgression propelled Xia Yeliang, an accomplished Peking University economist, from opinionated irritant to a marked enemy of the ruling Communist Party. There was his 2009 public letter that ridiculed the technical school degree held by the nation’s propaganda minister and the interview he gave last year to Radio Free Asia, describing China as a “Communist one-party dictatorship.”

headline: The Ad Campaign: Looking for a Boost, Lhota Turns the Focus to Charter Schools
text: Joseph J. Lhota is turning to education issues in hopes of giving his sagging bid for mayor a surge in the home stretch. On Monday, Mr. Lhota, the Republican nominee, released a 30-second advertisement, titled “Rally,” attacking Bill de Blasio, the Democratic nominee, for his criticism of charter schools. Mr. de Blasio has pledged to end the Bloomberg administration’s policy of awarding free rent to charter schools housed in public school buildings — a change that Mr. Lhota has said would “annihilate” charter schools, which are publicly financed but often managed by nonprofit groups.

headline: Love and Politics
text: You’ve got to be taught to hate and fear,

headline: Tigers’ Verlander Rediscovers a Machinelike Efficiency
text: DETROIT — Justin Verlander had grown tired of the questions this season of whether he was hurt or tired, of whether he was feeling the pressure of the $180 million contract he signed before the season.

headline: Paul Rogers, Shakespearean Actor and Tony Winner, Dies at 96
text: Paul Rogers, an actor who came to fame as a versatile Shakespearean in his native England and later won a Tony Award on Broadway in Harold Pinter’s harrowing family drama “The Homecoming,” died on Oct. 6 in London. He was 96.

headline: To Catch Patriots, Jets Must Focus on Pass Coverage
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Nick Mangold fiddled with a Lego set on Sunday night, while 225 miles to the northeast, Tom Brady fiddled with the Saints’ defense. As Mangold, the Jets’ center, played with his nephew, a television showed New England’s winning drive, which culminated in a touchdown pass by Brady with five seconds remaining. No, Mangold did not smash the Legos or fling them across the room.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Id al-Adha, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday and Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 14, 2013
Dodgers Shortstop Fights Jabs of Pain as the Team Battles to Stay Alive
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the most famous images in Dodgers lore — and postseason baseball history — is Kirk Gibson limping around the bases after hitting a pinch-hit, game-winning home run in the ninth inning off the A’s Dennis Eckersley in Game 1 of the 1988 World Series.

headline: No Quarter for Former SS Captain, Reviled Even in Death
text: ROME — The death on Friday of Erich Priebke, the former SS captain sentenced to life in prison for helping to organize the execution of 335 civilians at the Ardeatine Caves in Italy in 1944 during World War II, has barely dimmed his notoriety.

headline: Hunter Says He’s Not Out After Tumbling Over a Wall
text: DETROIT — The day after Torii Hunter tumbled over the bullpen wall at Fenway Park in an all-out effort to prevent David Ortiz’s game-tying grand slam, he held court with reporters in the Tigers clubhouse, somewhat playfully answering their questions about the memorable play.

headline: Chinese Bodyguards, When Police Won’t Do
text: Capable, inconspicuous and “not too tall.”

headline: Waiting in Line for an iPhone
text: A tweaked version of a movie made by Casey Neistat on what it’s like to wait in line for a new iPhone was used by Apple to thank some employees for the most successful iPhone launch ever.

headline: For Carrión, No Debate and Confounded Allies
text: When Bill de Blasio, the Democratic nominee for mayor, and Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate, debate each other Tuesday for the first time in this year’s general election contest, there will be one clear loser: Adolfo Carrión Jr.

headline: Carrión: The Third Man
text: Among the candidates competing to be mayor of New York City, the Independence Party's Adolfo Carrión Jr. is polling a distant third behind his better-known rivals Bill de Blasio and Joseph J.Lhota.

headline: Senate Women Lead in Effort to Find Accord
text: WASHINGTON — As the government shutdown dragged on, Senator Susan Collins of Maine was spending another weekend on Capitol Hill, staring at C-Span on her Senate office television as one colleague after another came to the floor to rail about the shuttered government.

headline: Unable to Hold Still
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today, I think it’s most fitting to start the post with a quote from puzzle editor Will Shortz:

headline: Corrections: October 15, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Is France Becoming Too American?
text: The nation that brought us the baguette is now counting carbs. Are the French losing their je ne sais quoi?

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Let Each Bill Stand Alone
A Peace Prize Worthy of the Name?
An American Shutdown Reaches the Earth’s End
text: Joseph Levy was preparing for a season of scientific research in Antarctica last week when he got the call: Stand down.

headline: A State Inquiry Is Said to Target Job Agencies
text: The newspaper advertisement looked like the answer to her problems. “Housekeeping needed. No exp needed, up to $18.75 hr.” Zade rushed to the Manhattan employment agency that had posted the notice. Her husband had been suffering from kidney problems for five years and had not been working. Zade, 51 and an immigrant from Kosovo, needed a job. Now.

headline: Reading the Signs
text: Robert J. Shiller, a Yale economist and one of this year’s winners of the Nobel Prize in Economic Science, is known for indexes he created and has used to predict stock market and housing bubbles in the economy.

headline: A Proposed Movie Deal for a Piracy Suspect Has a Surprise Ending: His Arrest
text: BRUSSELS — The only thing more enticing to a pirate than treasure, according to Belgian authorities, is the chance to see himself in a movie.

headline: Women in Senate Urge Compromise
text: As talks to reopen the federal government continue, three Republican senators have emerged as the leading voices for compromise and are illuminating the growing power of women in the Senate.

headline: Mark B. Read, Criminal Turned Author, Dies at 58
text: Mark Brandon Read, a notorious Australian criminal and self-described “murdering maggot” who spun tales from his violent history into a successful comedy routine and 10 top-selling books, including one illustrated for children, died on Wednesday in Melbourne. He was 58.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 15, 2013
text: “Where we find ourselves right now is unacceptable for America. It’s unacceptable as leaders that have been elected by the people of this country. We owe it to our constituents to resolve this now.”

headline: Modern Subways Zip Below, but a City’s Trams, Slow and Sweaty, Plod On
text: HONG KONG — This city has one of the world’s most highly regarded subway systems, with spotless stations, cellphone service on trains and even computers with free Internet access on some platforms. Getting from one side of Hong Kong Island to the other takes a mere 25 minutes for the eight-mile journey on trains that have a 99.9 percent on-time record.

headline: To Form German Coalition, Merkel’s Party May Need to Support a Minimum Wage
text: BERLIN — Germany has long held out against introducing a nationwide minimum wage, and over the weekend Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasized her rejection of the idea. But it may be the price she has to pay to build the stable government she has promised voters.

headline: Malaysian Court Restricts Use of ‘Allah’ to Muslims
text: BANGKOK — A Malaysian court ruled on Monday that non-Muslims may not use the word “Allah” to refer to God, the latest decision in a long dispute that has polarized the multicultural country.

headline: Politics on Parade in the Mayoral Race
text: Even as they marched in New York's Columbus Day Parade, the mayoral rivals Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota were preparing for the crucial next phase of the race, the television debates.

headline: In Brooklyn, Questioning Violent Death Near Capitol
text: She was the one with the side ponytail and the smile, the mourners remembered, the one who once stood up to bullies in school and could make friends with anyone. Above all, her friends and family said on Monday evening at her wake, the Miriam Carey they knew was not the erratic, mentally ill woman seen on television screens and newspaper reports across the country after she was shot and killed in a car chase across the heart of Washington two weeks ago.

headline: China: Tourists Rescued on Mt. Everest
text: Chinese rescuers had evacuated by Tuesday morning 86 tourists trapped by heavy snowfall at the north base camp of Mount Everest, at an altitude of 17,000 feet in central Tibet, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. The tourists, all but 13 of them Chinese, had been ready to go to a lower altitude after sightseeing when the storm hit on Monday, Xinhua reported, citing the local government. No casualties were reported on Monday. Without proper acclimatization, severe altitude sickness can occur at 17,000 feet. Unlike the south base camp in Nepal, which is usually reached by trekking, the north base camp draws tourists who often drive up by jeep and visit the nearby Rongbuk Monastery.

headline: Dodgers Get Key Hits and Crucial Win in Game 3
text: LOS ANGELES — With each random movement — lifting his left arm, breaking into a trot, laughing at a joke — a sharp pain jolted through Hanley Ramirez’s rib cage. Swinging a bat or, worse, stopping a swing felt as if a knife were working into the crack in his eighth rib.

headline: Major Earthquake Strikes Central Philippines
text: MANILA — The death toll rose to 93 after a powerful earthquake violently shook the central Philippines on Tuesday morning. The tremor also injured hundreds and smashed one of the country’s oldest churches, officials said.

headline: Ethiopia: 2 Men Killed While Preparing a Bomb for an Attack, an Official Says
text: Two Somali men killed in a bomb blast were believed to have been plotting an attack in Ethiopia when they accidentally blew themselves up, Redwan Hussein, Ethiopia’s minister of information, said on Monday. The explosion took place Sunday afternoon as thousands were gathering in the capital, Addis Ababa, to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer game between Ethiopia and Nigeria. Security officials found grenades, a revolver and explosives at the scene, Mr. Redwan said. He characterized it as a terrorist plot but said it was not yet clear who was behind it. The Shabab militant group, which claimed responsibility for last month’s attack on a Kenyan shopping mall, carried out a pair of bombings in Uganda during the broadcast of the World Cup final in 2010. Like Kenya and Uganda, Ethiopia has troops in Somalia. The two men killed in Sunday’s blast were in the country illegally, Mr. Redwan said. He said that the attackers had apparently intended to strike multiple targets but that the bombs had detonated unexpectedly before the men could execute their plan.

headline: Sailing Beneath the Red, White And Green
text: New Yorkers gathered for the 69th Annual Columbus Day Parade along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Monday. The West Point marching band was supposed to lead the parade, but did not because of the partial shutdown of the government. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the mayoral candidates Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota were in attendance.

headline: Peering Inside Mumbai’s Premier Padminis
text: Cars, trucks, mopeds and bicycles vie for space on the streets of Mumbai, India, where they hurtle four or five abreast over bumpy roads that often don’t even have painted lanes. Then there are the rickety carts and grizzled animals that weave through the chaos.

headline: Word of the Day | officious
text: officious •\ə-ˈfi-shəs\• adjective

headline: China: 6-Year Term for Protester in Blast
text: A court in Beijing sentenced a man to six years in prison on Tuesday after finding him guilty of detonating a homemade bomb in Beijing’s Capital International Airport in July, state-run news media reported. The man, Ji Zhongxing, had been trying to draw attention to his allegations that officials in Dongguan, an industrial city in far southern China, ignored his complaints that security officers there beat him so severely in 2005 that he was unable to walk and had to use a wheelchair. The blast badly injured Mr. Ji and slightly wounded a police officer. The case kindled widespread debate in China, with some Internet users voicing sympathy for Mr. Ji and his ire with government officials. Dongguan officials said they had given him compensation of 100,000 renminbi, or about $16,400, on condition that he drop his complaints. Mr. Ji pleaded not guilty to the charges. His lawyers argued that he had not meant to detonate the explosive, the China News Service reported. The maximum sentence for the charge was 10 years in prison.

headline: New People’s Daily Building in Beijing Draws Risqué Comparisons
text: Is it a chamber pot? Is it a penguin? Is it a … phallus?

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (BET) BET HIP HOP AWARDS 2013 Snoop Lion hosts and performs at this ceremony, taped on Sept. 28 at the Atlanta Civic Center, where the evening’s major honoree, M C Lyte, left, receives the “I Am Hip-Hop Icon” award. Future, Rocko, Diddy, Rick Ross, Bone Thugs-n-Harmony and 2 Chainz take to the stage in this eighth year of the presentations. Kendrick Lamar leads the nominations with 14; Drake follows with 13, and J. Cole with 10. “Real Husbands of Hollywood,” Kevin Hart’s reality series spoof starring some well-known spouses — Nick Cannon (married to Mariah Carey), Boris Kodjoe (Nicole Ari Parker), Duane Martin (Tisha Campbell-Martin) and J. B. Smoove (Shahidah Omar) — has its second-season premiere with back-to-back episodes, starting at 10.

headline: Big Players in Gambling
text: Some of the top spenders on gambling issues in Albany from 2005 until mid-2013. The spending includes lobbying and political contributions. Some groups lobbied on a number of subjects, in addition to gambling.

headline: Casino Referendum Led Gambling Industry to Spend Richly in Albany
text: During the final two months of this year’s legislative session in Albany, more than three dozen companies, Indian tribes and trade groups with an interest in gambling or horse racing lobbied New York’s state government. There were more lobbyists representing the gambling industry than there are members of the Legislature.

headline: News Quiz | October 15, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Europe’s Polluted Cities
text: Cities in Bulgaria and Poland had the highest levels of air pollution, as measured by concentrations of particulates, in a survey of 386 European Union cities.

headline: Bulgaria’s Air Is Dirtiest in Europe, Study Finds, Followed by Poland
text: Hold your breath if you visit Bulgaria.

headline: China Venerates a Revolutionary, the Father of Its New Leader
text: Ancestor veneration in China is back. The Communist Party has devoted official meetings, books, a six-episode television documentary, a garish children’s performance and postage stamps to mark a century since the birth of Xi Zhongxun, a veteran revolutionary who served under Mao Zedong and then Deng Xiaoping.

headline: Ethnic Violence Returns to Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Sunday night, mothers were asking on social networks whether to send their children to school the following day. Concerned young people messaged their friends and told them to “be careful tomorrow.” I made a mental note not to dress in a way that would allow me to be mistaken for a teenage boy from the Caucasus (which has happened) and thought it was a good thing my oldest son — who does look like he is from the Caucasus — is in school in the United States.

headline: Afghan Provincial Governor Killed in Mosque Attack
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bomb exploded at a mosque in eastern Afghanistan on Tuesday morning, killing the provincial governor as he prepared to give a speech honoring the start of a major Muslim holiday, officials said.

headline: Apple Hires Burberry Chief to Polish Image of Online Stores
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s brick-and-mortar stores are among the most lucrative in the world. Now the company is trying to make its online stores just as successful, and with a dash of style from the high fashion world.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Oct. 15, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Online Application Problems Sow Worry Among Students
text: In the article “Online Application Woes Make Students Anxious and Put Colleges Behind Schedule,” Richard Pérez-Peña reports on recent problems plaguing the new online version of the Common Application.

headline: Bay Area Transit Strike Averted for Now as Talks Continue
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Panicked commuters here got another reprieve early Tuesday when transit workers, who had threatened a strike at midnight Monday, stayed at the bargaining table.

headline: The Not-So-Hidden Cause Behind the A.D.H.D. Epidemic
text: Between the fall of 2011 and the spring of 2012, people across the United States suddenly found themselves unable to get their hands on A.D.H.D. medication. Low-dose generics were particularly in short supply. There were several factors contributing to the shortage, but the main cause was that supply was suddenly being outpaced by demand.

headline: Alitalia Shareholders Agree to Stock Plan
text: PARIS — Shareholders of Alitalia on Tuesday approved a plan to raise 300 million euros, or $407 million, in fresh capital for the Italian carrier after a marathon meeting in Rome that sought to persuade its largest investor, Air France-KLM, to increase its contribution to an overhaul of the debt-laden airline, which has been unprofitable for a decade.

headline: Italian Prime Minister Calls Populism a Threat to Stability in Europe
text: ROME — With European parliamentary elections less than eight months away, Prime Minister Enrico Letta of Italy on Monday warned that the rise of angry populism poses the greatest threat to stability on the Continent and could undermine critical efforts to build and strengthen the euro zone’s political and financial institutions.

headline: Do You Believe in Ghosts?
text: Halloween is coming, and this past weekend the Times Travel section featured a piece about ghost-hunting tours at the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum, a mental hospital in West Virginia built in the 1800s that is now “rumored to be a hotbed of paranormal activity.”

headline: Letta, Italy’s Premier, Says His Goal Is to Move ‘From Austerity to Growth’
text: This is a transcript of an interview with Prime Minister Enrico Letta of Italy in Rome on Oct. 14, 2013, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: Iran Presents Nuclear Plan to Big Powers
text: GENEVA — Speaking in English and using PowerPoint, Iran’s foreign minister outlined a proposal to representatives of the big powers on Tuesday that would constrain his country’s nuclear program in return for a right to enrich uranium and an easing of the sanctions that have been battering the Iranian economy.

headline: Israel Warns Against Partial Agreement With Iran
text: JERUSALEM — Israel said on Tuesday that it would “embrace a genuine diplomatic solution” that would bring about the dismantling of Iran’s potential nuclear weapons program but warned world powers against any partial agreement and urged them not to ease the sanctions on Iran prematurely.

headline: New York Today: Showdown
text: Updated, 12:52 p.m. | With three weeks left in the mayoral campaign, Joseph J. Lhota will go face-to-face tonight with the man who has been trouncing him in the polls.

headline: Glimpses of Shiller, Through the Years
text: Robert Shiller struggled mightily to choose a major when he was a college student at the University of Michigan in the 1960s. He took so many long walks around Ann Arbor trying to decide among the academic fields that intrigued him – economics, journalism, law and others – that he eventually injured his foot and had to see a doctor.

headline: Talking to Iran
text: The U.S. shutdown won’t shut down talks with Iran.

headline: Daily Report: Landlines Vanish From a New Jersey Islet
text: Hurricane Sandy devastated Mantoloking, N.J., a barrier island community of multimillion-dollar homes. But in Peter Flihan’s view, Verizon Communications has delivered a second blow: the telecommunications giant did not rebuild the landlines destroyed in the storm, and traditional telephone service here has now gone the way of the telegraph, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: London’s National Theater Names New Director
text: Rufus Norris, a veteran theater director, is to replace Nicholas Hytner as director of London’s National Theater, the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Export Fair in China Loses Steam
text: GUANGZHOU, China — With nearly as much floor space as five McCormick Places in Chicago, the sprawling Canton Fair, which opened in Guangzhou Tuesday morning, is a monument to China’s industrial versatility and export prowess.
