headline: Prize-Laden Cast Is Set for ‘Realistic Joneses’ on Broadway
text: Four actors known for biting performances – the Emmy Award winner Toni Collette (“United States of Tara”), Michael C. Hall (“Dexter”), the Tony Award winner Tracy Letts (“Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?”), and the Oscar winner Marisa Tomei (“My Cousin Vinny”) – are set to star on Broadway this spring in Will Eno’s dark comedy “The Realistic Joneses,” the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: In the Senate, All Eyes on Cruz
text: WASHINGTON — As the Senate reached a deal on Wednesday that would end the government shutdown and increase the debt limit, all eyes were on the man many consider responsible for the current standoff — Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas.

headline: The Backfire Effect
text: I’m coming to this a bit late, but I see that there’s now extensive evidence that facts not only don’t win arguments, they make people on the wrong side dig in even deeper: “When your deepest convictions are challenged by contradictory evidence, your beliefs get stronger.”

headline: Apps to Protect Your Array of Passwords
text: We all know that we need to use strong passwords on Web sites. In fact, a different password for every site you frequent is wise.

headline: House Republicans Consider Their Options
text: WASHINGTON — As the Senate reached a deal Wednesday that would reopen the federal government and raise the debt ceiling, the House Republican leadership team continued to ponder whether taking up its own measure first was in the best interest of its members.

headline: For South Carolina Senator, a House Vote Would Have Been Different
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Tim Scott, Republican of South Carolina, who was elevated to the Senate from the House earlier this year when Senator Jim DeMint retired, said he might vote differently on the proposed budget deal now than he would have as a representative.

headline: Dutch Cable Company Rejects Liberty Global’s Buyout Offer
text: LONDON – Ziggo, the largest provider of cable television services in the Netherlands, has rejected a buyout offer from Liberty Global, the media company controlled by John C. Malone, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Jazz & Colors Returns to Central Park
text: The sounds of jazz will waft throughout Central Park again this fall, as Jazz & Colors returns for a second year. The concert, free and open to the public, will take place on Nov. 9, according to a press announcement scheduled for release on Thursday.

headline: CMJ, Day 1
text: The festival kicked off on Tuesday.

headline: Observing Grizzlies at a Canadian Resort
text: The Orford Bay in British Columbia’s Bute Inlet is famous for an abundance of grizzly bears between September and November, and the Sonora Resort, 30 miles off the coast of Vancouver Island, gives its guests the chance to see these animals with daily four-hour tours.

headline: CMJ: Seesawing Between the Past and a Forward-Looking Present
text: “I’ve seen it all before but I just didn’t know,” sang Matthew Paul of Ghost Wave on the first afternoon of the CMJ Music Marathon. The song was a measured, droney throwback to the Velvet Underground. Yet Ghost Wave, from New Zealand is a younger and larger band, with one guitarist devoted to distortion from a teardrop-shaped guitar and another band member — front and center — playing just tambourine or shaker.

headline: Warren Buffett on Driving Violations, Baseball and Jamie Dimon
text: Warren E. Buffett offered an unusual defense of Jamie Dimon on Wednesday morning, comparing the billions of dollars that JPMorgan Chase has paid in fines to state troopers handing out a speeding ticket.

headline: Cruz Won’t Block Senate Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas conceded defeat but did not express contrition as he emerged from a meeting of Senate Republicans called to ratify the agreement.

headline: Senate Leaders Announce Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democratic and Republican leaders on Wednesday reached final agreement on a deal to reopen the government and extend its borrowing authority into February, with final passage looking increasingly possible by Wednesday evening.

headline: Hunting the Perfect Logo
text: The many rejected designs for Tavern on the Green’s new signage.

headline: Share Your Emergency Room Experience
text: This year, in my series Paying Till it Hurts, I have been reporting on the high cost of medical care in the United States as the country endeavors to expand insurance coverage through the Affordable Care Act. Whether you are insured or uninsured, I would like to hear about your medical bills and your experiences with managing the costs of health care. Most of the patients featured in this series so far have been people who commented on previous articles or responded to a callout like this one and graciously shared their story with me.

headline: Remaking Tavern on the Green, One Fork at a Time
text: The old restaurant is being remade by a couple of Philly guys who are making a big bet. It starts with getting the details right.

headline: The Octopus That Almost Ate Seattle
text: In the months leading up to the hunt, Dylan Mayer trained twice a week in his parents’ swimming pool, asking friends to attack him, splay their arms and grab him, drag him to the surface and shove him below it, pull off his mask, snatch his regulator, time his recovery. By last Halloween, he was ready, and as the light began to fade that afternoon, the broad-shouldered 19-year-old jumped into a red Ford pickup truck with his buddy and drove some 40 minutes from Maple Valley, Wash., to West Seattle. They arrived at Alki Beach around 4 p.m., put on their wet suits and ambled into Cove 2. Then they slipped into Elliott Bay, the Space Needle punctuating the city line in the distance like an inverted exclamation point.

headline: Some Republicans Question Cost of Outcome
text: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said the announcement of a deal to reopen the government and avert a default on government obligations would not be a time for finger pointing. But fingers are indeed being pointed, mainly at ardent conservatives who tied further government financing to the gutting of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: White House Supports Deal and Urges Quick Passage
text: WASHINGTON — Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said Wednesday that President Obama supported the compromise reached by the Senate leaders, and he urged lawmakers in both chambers to pass it quickly.

headline: When Nets Salute Kidd, Thorn Should Receive an Assist
text: While the Nets are hoisting No. 5 to the Barclays Center rafters Thursday night for Jason Kidd, they might also consider raising a banner, or at least a toast, in honor of Rod Thorn.

headline: Is the Right Winning?
text: While the press focuses, for understandable reasons, on the Republican Party’s abject failure to accomplish anything remotely like its stated objectives in the shutdown/debt ceiling fight, Peter Beinart makes the case that the G.O.P.’s mix of intransigence and internal chaos is successfully pushing the American political debate to the right:

headline: Nazis, the American Revolution and 9/11
text: On her Facebook page on Monday, Sarah Palin said President Obama should be impeached if Congress did not raise the debt limit and the nation went into default  — or if he tried to avoid that awful outcome by raising the debt limit without a Congressional vote of approval.

headline: Mitch McConnell on Fiscal Deal
text: The Senate minority leader speaks about the bipartisan bill to reopen the government and avoid default.

headline: Rowing With Esther Lofgren, Olympian
text: The gold medalist rower talks about her workout.

headline: The Workout: Rowing With Esther Lofgren, Olympian
text: Members of the U.S. national rowing team follow an intense training regimen that combines rowing, weight lifting and aerobic training for 45 to 60 hours a week. We asked Esther Lofgren, an Olympic gold medalist, to take us through the rower’s workout.

headline: Gridlock Has Cost U.S. Billions, and the Meter Is Still Running
text: WASHINGTON — Containers of goods idling at ports. Reduced sales at sandwich shops in downtown Washington. Canceled vacations to national parks and to destinations abroad. Reduced corporate earnings forecasts. Higher interest payments on short-term debt.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | 12 Years a Slave
text: Steve McQueen, the director of “12 Years a Slave,” narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Black Marks Routinely Expunged From Brokers’ Records, Report Finds
text: Updated, 5:11 p.m. |

headline: Paper That Backed Cruz for Senate Now Wishes He Weren’t There
text: Updated, 3:13 p.m. | WASHINGTON — One year after endorsing Ted Cruz for Senate, The Houston Chronicle on Wednesday called the Texas senator “part of the problem” in Washington.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: Once favored by the leading lights of Old Hollywood, the Trousdale section of Los Angeles fell out of fashion in the ‘70s — its trove of midcentury architecture tarted up or torn down — only to be rediscovered by a new wave of glamorous Angelenos devoted to preserving its unique style. It’s ready for its close-up, again.

headline: Private Stock, Paying Hard to Get
text: Do a not-all-that-deep Google dig on Jon Koon, the owner and designer of Private Stock, and you’ll happen upon pictures of him at the 2011 birthday party of the rapper Young Jeezy. Mr. Koon helped build Jeezy’s clothing line, 8732, and in the photos, in a room full of people skilled at flaunting their wealth, he looks like a man at peace with his success: gold sunglasses, cigar half-smoked, Champagne bottle uncorked and gripped by the neck.

headline: Chris Kittrell, Frontman for the Band Baby Alpaca
text: AGE 28

headline: Is It Harder to Pitch a Professional or a Family Member?
text: Debra Reisenthel, chief executive at Palo Alto Health Sciences, has been trying to raise money the past four months from investors. As we explain in a small-business guide we have just published about pitching investors, her goal is to finance the development and production of a biofeedback device that measures carbon dioxide output and trains people to breathe in a way that helps them manage anxiety disorders.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘12 Years a Slave’
text: The period drama “12 Years a Slave” stars Chiwetel Ejiofor as Solomon Northup, a free man from the pre-Civil War American North who is abducted and sold into slavery in the South. In this video, the director Steve McQueen narrates a scene that takes place on the plantation where Mr. Northup serves, featuring Michael Fassbender as his owner Edwin Epps and Lupita Nyong’o as Patsey, the slave Epps rapes.

headline: Hill & Dale: Lounge on Lower East Side
text: By now, many New Yorkers have experienced the novelty of an $18 deconstructed Sazerac served by a sanctimonious mixologist in Prohibition-period dress at some spurious speakeasy. Though the old-timey trope continues at Hill & Dale, the Volstead Act is repealed in favor of an unpretentious cocktail lounge destined for midweek trysts and co-workers’ birthdays.

headline: A Splashy Art Party at Philip Johnson’s Glass House
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Kills a Provincial Official
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A suicide bomber killed a senior provincial official and at least nine guests at the official’s home in northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday, in the most high-profile political assassination by the Islamist insurgency there this year.

headline: Greece’s Parliament Clears Way for More Charges Against 6 Right-Wing Lawmakers
text: ATHENS — As part of a widening effort to clamp down on violent extremism in Greece, the country’s Parliament moved on Wednesday to lift the immunity of six lawmakers of Golden Dawn, the neo-fascist anti-immigrant party prosecutors portray as a criminal organization involved in murder, attempted murder, blackmail and other crimes.

headline: Reid Thanks GOP Leader for Cooperation
text: Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, announced an agreement on Friday with his Republican counterparts to reopen the federal government.

headline: Acrostic
text: Acrostic puzzle for October20, 2013

headline: Cruz Says He Won’t Block Shutdown Deal
text: As both parties announced an agreement that would lead to the reopening of the government, Senator Ted Cruz, who had pushed the Republicans’ cause, said he would not try to delay a vote.

headline: Sum Worth More Than the Parts in Advance Auto Deal
text: The sum is worth more than the parts – auto parts, that is. Advance Auto’s $2 billion takeover of rival General Parts International resulted in the acquirer gaining $1 billion in market cap. That’s bang in line with the net present value of promised cost savings. Nobel Prize winner Eugene Fama’s efficient markets hypothesis may be flawed, but when it comes to the nitty-gritty of corporate finance, it often seems to work just fine.

headline: Awards
text: The truth is, nothing will ever top this:

headline: Senate to Act First, Followed by House
text: With Senate Republican hard-liners promising not to delay a vote on the agreement to reopen the government and raise the debt limit, the Senate is expected to take up the bill first.

headline: On E.U. Carbon Emissions Rule, First the Announcement, Then the Uproar
text: On Monday, the European Union’s environmental ministers agreed to delay a plan to hold cars to tough new carbon emissions limits by 2020. On Tuesday they faced the music.

headline: Dollhouse Made Them Do It
text: It was a blog about her old dollhouse that reunited Eden Cayen with Gerard Sambets. Ms. Cayen had restored her childhood dollhouse after it was unearthed in her mother’s barn upstate. She had furnished it with vintage dollhouse furniture, posting photos of her miniature projects at eloisemoorehead.com.

headline: Helpless and Contemptible
text: Matt Fink, a lawyer turned historian, sends this quotation:

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for October 20, 2013

headline: House Conservatives Blame Moderates, Not Boehner
text: WASHINGTON — Moments before the Senate deal was finalized on Wednesday, some House conservatives were alternately defiant and defeated, acknowledging they may have lost the current battle but vowing to fight on.

headline: Judge Rejects Suit to Block Vote on Casinos
text: ALBANY — A judge dismissed a lawsuit on Wednesday that sought to stop a casino gambling referendum next month in New York State, saying the legal challenge over the measure’s wording was “untimely and lacking in legal merit.”

headline: Wheelies: The Take a Deep Breath Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Christie Flips on an Immigration Bill
text: Immigrant advocates heard correctly over the weekend: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey really does support allowing unauthorized immigrants to pay in-state tuition at his state’s colleges and universities.

headline: The Government’s Coming Shortfall
text: If Congress does not raise the debt ceiling, the Treasury will have to rely on daily incoming revenues to pay its bills and will have to choose to delay certain payments or not pay for some programs altogether.

headline: América Móvil Drops Bid for KPN
text: LONDON — América Móvil, the Latin American telecommunications giant owned by Carlos Slim Helú, said on Wednesday that it had dropped its 7.2 billion euro, or $9.7 billion, bid to acquire the Dutch telephone provider Royal KPN.

headline: In Thailand, Redefining the Tastes of Childhood
text: I grew up on turkey and cheese sandwiches, Frosted Flakes and Capri Suns. In elementary school, I proudly traded my Fruit Roll-Up for Kraft’s cracker and cheese dip and my Cool Ranch Doritos for California Raisins. I was an all-American girl growing up in homogeneously backwater north Florida. This was the land of hamburger cookouts and pizza parties. Yoo-hoos after a long day of water skiing. A trip to IHOP for pancakes and eggs after a Sunday Southern Baptist revival.

headline: The Art and Craft of ‘Privilege Signs’
text: The various fonts and options that make up a privilege e sign.

headline: The Coca-Cola Goldline Program
text: The full details on the Coca-Cola Goldline Program.

headline: Max Irons: Out of Character, but in His Element
text: On a recent Wednesday, the British actor Max Irons accompanied a reporter to the Cloisters, the museum devoted to the art of medieval Europe. It was a setting that may have felt familiar to King Edward IV, the character Mr. Irons plays on the Starz series “The White Queen,” a lusty take on the Wars of the Roses.

headline: 'Can't Go Back'
text: The latest ad from the Lhota campaign claims that a de Blasio administration would return the city to its crime-ridden past.

headline: Original Review: ‘Fiddler on the Roof’
text: Howard Taubman’s 1964 review of the musical at the Imperial Theater.

headline: Knight Capital to Pay $12 Million Fine on Trading Violations
text: On the morning of Aug. 1 2012, Knight Capital, Wall Street’s biggest trading firm, sent out a wave of accidental stock orders – more than four million – that reverberated through the market and eventually resulted in a $460 million loss for the firm.

headline: On the Verge | Trousdale, Los Angeles’s Forgotten Architectural Mecca, Makes a Comeback
text: Once favored by the leading lights of Old Hollywood, the Trousdale section of Los Angeles fell out of fashion in the ’70s — its trove of midcentury architecture tarted up or torn down — only to be rediscovered by a new wave of glamorous Angelenos devoted to preserving its unique style. It’s ready for its close-up, again. See the slide show.

headline: New York Guitar Festival to Return in January
text: When David Spelman presented the last installment of the biennial New York Guitar Festival, in 2012, he mused, in a New York Times interview, about putting the festival on hiatus. But when he was asked whether that meant that there would be no 2014 festival, Mr. Spelman said, “I always answer my cellphone. And I don’t like to say no.”

headline: Boehner Supports Deal, but Says G.O.P. ‘Fight Will Continue’
text: WASHINGTON — House Speaker John A. Boehner threw his weight on Wednesday behind the Senate deal to reopen the government and avert a default. He pledged to continue fighting President Obama’s health care law, but in a different manner.

headline: Facebook Eases Privacy Rules for Teenagers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook has loosened its privacy rules for teenagers as a debate swirls over online threats to children from bullies and sexual predators.

headline: Even a Doomed Queen Just Wants to Have Fun
text: Every new television season should have a camp classic, but it’s been hard to find one among the grindingly dull shows trotted out this fall. ABC’s “Betrayal” had promise, with some risible plots and ripe performances (Henry Thomas as a brain-damaged scion and James Cromwell as his imperious dad are a hoot), but it’s just not enough fun.

headline: The Golden Years of Tavern on the Green
text: The restaurant’s cabaret phase, and other archival photos from this New York institution’s colorful past.

headline: Cyrus’s ‘Bangerz’ Hits No. 1
text: With a blitz of media and constant online chatter, Miley Cyrus easily clinched the top spot on Billboard’s album chart this week. “Bangerz” (RCA), her latest, opened with 270,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, becoming Ms. Cyrus’s fifth No. 1 album, including three released under her Disney alter ego, Hannah Montana. “Bangerz” also tops the charts in Britain, Canada, Australia and Ireland this week. Ms. Cyrus, 20, has been perhaps the most unavoidable figure in pop culture since at least Aug. 25, when her hypersexed, tongue-wagging performance stole the show at the MTV Video Music Awards.

headline: Jury Rules for Mark Cuban in Setback for S.E.C.
text: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | The government mocked Mark Cuban as a winner in “his mind,” claiming that the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team possessed a “competitive edge” that drove him to insider trading.

headline: At the New York Premiere of ‘Her,’ a Party Makes Do Without Its Voice
text: One important guest was missing from the New York premiere of “Her,” the new movie from Spike Jonze, which closed the New York Film Festival on Saturday night: the woman who plays the title character.

headline: A Lesson in Time Management for a Wagner Coach
text: The first-grade students at Public School 80 entered Room 108 single file at 8:10 on a clear and blustery morning on Staten Island, placed their book bags in cubbyholes and waited. It was time for Bashir Mason to check their homework.

headline: Gadgets to Help the Party Host
text: The stresses of hosting a party can pile up this time of year. Whether it’s for a holiday get-together or a tailgate extravaganza, drinks must be mixed and food must be cooked, preferably with a carefree attitude that puts your guests in awe of your party-throwing prowess.

headline: Life on Ships That Make World Go Round
text: Rose George is a young British journalist who writes smart books about subjects we mostly prefer not to think about. Her last one, “The Big Necessity” (2008), about human waste and society, is among the best nonfiction books of the new millennium. Give the paperback edition to the person in your life who never puts down the toilet seat.

headline: Times Reporter Plans to Take Fight to the Supreme Court
text: For James Risen, an investigative reporter for The Times, the bad news just keeps on coming. When I wrote about him in late July, a federal appeals panel had just ruled against him in a case related to a leak investigation.

headline: How to Get Your Last Name Posted After You Win a Learning Network Student Contest
text: We like having student contests on The Learning Network, and we run them regularly.

headline: On Glowing Pickles and Undiscovered Galaxies: Student STEM Contest Winners
text: A video sent in by  one of many students who entered our contest from a Project Lead the Way school.

headline: An Assassin Abroad: Peter Savodnik Talks About ‘The Interloper’
text: For most of us, Lee Harvey Oswald exists most vividly in downtown Dallas, poised to make the worst kind of history. In his new book, “The Interloper,” Peter Savodnik recounts Oswald’s time living and working in the Soviet Union. He went in 1960, with the hopes of building a permanent existence there after a childhood of frequent moves. He found his future wife, and became a father for the first time, but he returned to the United States in 1962, bitterly disappointed in his failure to start over in Russia. Mr. Savodnik argues that this time overseas reveals a great deal about Oswald’s personality and his infamous crime. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Savodnik discussed Oswald’s time in Minsk, the Russian view of conspiracy theories and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Robert Rauschenberg and Photography
text: A new show Pace/MacGill Gallery explores photography’s role at the center of Rauschenberg’s work.

headline: Taking Flight Without Taking Off
text: Travelers who fancy themselves flyboys and girls can test their skills at Fly the Dream, a new virtual entertainment store where customers can navigate a simulated flight of an F-16 Falcon, a single-engine fighter aircraft developed by General Dynamics for the Air Force in the early 1970s.

headline: Aggression Unleashed, and Moderated Too, in Pumped-Up Touring Return
text: Trent Reznor’s recent record with Nine Inch Nails, “Hesitation Marks,” represents a self-possessed next move for a band whose old meanings have been displaced, if not entirely eclipsed. The currents that it rose from in the late ’80s — harsh and jabbering industrial music, creep-out cinema, roaring psychosexual anger — long ago became normalized; as elements of art, those things live and die on immediate response and don’t get the kind the group desires anymore, especially from fans in their 40s.

headline: A ‘Wild’ Book Tour With a Soundtrack
text: As I dig out of a mountain of work built up after recent travels in Asia, I’m enjoying listening to Jon Mooallem read excerpts from “Wild Ones,” his alternately amusing and unsettling book about the human species’ dysfunctional relationship with all manner of wild animals (he focuses on the American subspecies of humans).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, New Jersey, the Philippines and Pakistan.

headline: Case Pits Freezing Assets Against Hiring Lawyers
text: WASHINGTON — Kerri and Brian Kaley, a New York couple, were unable to hire a lawyer to defend themselves against serious criminal charges because the government had frozen their assets. That seemed to trouble several justices at a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday.

headline: 110 Seconds With Pogue: Windows 8.1
text: The Times’s David Pogue weighed in on the updates to Microsoft’s Windows 8 operating systems, one of which is designed for desktops, the other for tablets.

headline: Ronan Farrow to Host Show on MSNBC
text: The search for new hosts for cable news programs turned up a familiar name on Wednesday when MSNBC announced that it had hired Ronan Farrow, son of Mia Farrow and Woody Allen, to take over an hour of its weekday schedule starting early next year.

headline: Reconciling 2 Worlds With Windows 8.1
text: Just about one year ago, Microsoft gave us two new operating systems.

headline: House Republicans Gearing Up for Round 2
text: WASHINGTON — Coming out of a closed-door meeting Wednesday afternoon, in which Speaker John A. Boehner explained to his conference that he would be taking up the Senate deal and likely passing it with the help of Democratic votes, Republican lawmakers were already regrouping for the next fight.

headline: Roundup at the Chelsea Hall, With Flinging, Stumbling, Collapsing
text: Forty-five years is a long time, as far as choreographic careers go — long enough, in Lar Lubovitch’s case, to have created more than 100 works. That kind of experience might bring a certain comfort with trying new ideas. A dance about cowboys? Hey, why not?

headline: Rhapsody in Deal to Expand in Latin America
text: Rhapsody, the subscription music service, is expanding to Latin America through a bundling deal with Telefónica, one of the world’s largest telecom providers.

headline: Forget the Spoonful of Sugar: It’s Uncle Walt, Uncensored
text: BURBANK, Calif. — In the coming movie “Saving Mr. Banks,” a comedic drama about the turbulent making of “Mary Poppins” in the 1960s, Walt Disney acts in a very un-Disney way. He slugs back Scotch. He uses a mild curse word. He wheezes because he smokes too much.

headline: Be as Creative as a Kindergartner
text: Tom and David Kelley are brothers behind the design and consulting firm IDEO known for designing the first Apple mouse and an early laptop computer. David Kelley also founded the d.school Institute of Design at Stanford while Tom Kelley wrote the popular book “The Art of Innovation,” in 2001.

headline: Milder Accounts of Hardships Under Mao Arise as His Birthday Nears
text: HONG KONG — The famine that gripped China from 1958 to 1962 is widely judged to be the deadliest in recorded history, killing 20 to 30 million people or more, and is one of the defining calamities of Mao Zedong’s rule. Ever since, the party has shrouded that disaster in censorship and euphemisms, seeking to maintain an aura of reverence around the founding leader of the Communist state.

headline: Muscle and Speed Win a Crowd’s Adulation
text: The Mariinsky Orchestra‘s three-concert stand at Carnegie Hall, which ended on Tuesday evening, was billed as a 60th-birthday celebration for its music director, Valery Gergiev. And Mr. Gergiev was indeed the center of attention at the first concert, last Thursday (reviewed earlier), when he led a long program of Stravinsky ballet scores and was the target of protests by gay-rights activists for supporting the candidacy of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who is limiting dialogue on homosexuality in Russia.

headline: Urban Living
text: The next mayor should keep architecture and planning front and center, a critic argues.

headline: States Report Health Insurance Application Numbers
text: Minnesota’s state-run health insurance exchange reported Wednesday that 5,569 households had completed applications for coverage in the first two weeks of operation, representing 11,684 people. The exchange portal has run relatively smoothly after struggling with technology problems for a few days after it opened on Oct. 1, said April Todd-Malmlov, the executive director.

headline: Reflections on a Couple of Boston Homers
text: Before Torii Hunter even finished flipping over the wall at Fenway Park on Sunday night, before he even hit the ground, the image of his flailing legs juxtaposed against the raised arms of a triumphant Boston police officer had already become a baseball classic.

headline: An Artist Who Gets a Lift From Gravity
text: John Knuth comes from a school of artists who allow nature to activate their works. But unlike some who let their pieces be entirely dictated by the whims of the elements, the Los Angeles-based artist remains involved with the process, exerting a measure of control over his science-based abstractions. His recent series of fly paintings — in which he fed the insects pigment, which they then regurgitated onto canvases — were ironically beautiful gradients of pointillist abstraction. For his next body of work, which he will create on site at Human Resources, an art space in Los Angeles’s Chinatown, the process is even messier.

headline: Building a Better City
text: On Jan. 1, the next mayor — either Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate, or Joe Lhota, the Republican — will face a fiscal cliff of unpaid bills. Schools will need to be saved, union contracts negotiated — the future of New York envisioned.

headline: A Computer Championship in Indonesia
text: How would you compare humans with computer programs when it comes to playing chess or bridge?

headline: Making Opera of Art and Vice Versa
text: As a flickering projector beamed film fragments and India ink drawings into a dollhouse-size model of the Metropolitan Opera’s gold proscenium in a small workroom not far from the real stage, the artist William Kentridge was explaining how some of the embryonic images flitting by would be developed over the next two years into his new production of Alban Berg’s “Lulu.”

headline: One Met Isn’t Enough
text: When “The Refusal of Time,” a multimedia installation and meditation on time by the South African artist William Kentridge had its premiere last summer at (d)ocumenta 13 in Kassel, Germany, Neal Benezra, director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, had his eye on acquiring it.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Shutdown Dysfunction, and Smile, You’re Being Tracked
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Thierry-Maxime Loriot, Curator of the Jean Paul Gaultier Exhibition
text: THE RUFFLE-AND-ROSETTE-FESTOONED corset that was being prepared for the Jean Paul Gaultier fashion exhibition making its long-awaited tour stop in New York at the Brooklyn Museum, beginning Oct. 25, had discreet panels of stretch fabric sewn into the sides. It was a spring 2011 sample created for Beth Ditto, the outspoken singer who once took Topshop to task for not offering larger sizes, who once pointed out that Karl Lagerfeld is a former “fat kid,” and who is not someone you would ever have expected to be found on a designer runway.

headline: Kim Kardashian’s Ex Sells the Engagement Ring
text: Kris Humphries, the Boston Celtics player known formerly as Kim Kardashian’s husband, has sold the 20.5-carat engagement ring he gave to his former wife. The ring, which reportedly cost him $2 million, was auctioned on Tuesday by Christie’s in New York for $749,000 (including the commission). That topped the auction house’s presale estimate of $300,000 to $500,000, but Twitter users were quick to point out the losing numbers.

headline: New York Department Stores Revamp Cosmetics and Fragrance Sections
text: With increasing competition from specialized retailers like Sephora and Ulta, as well as the Internet, several New York City department stores have, perhaps necessarily, decided to give their areas dedicated to cosmetics, skin care and fragrances a makeover.

headline: Furor Over Yahoo Mail Changes
text: It has become the online equivalent of a riot.

headline: Columbia to House a Trove of Prokofiev’s Items
text: A foundation dedicated to Sergei Prokofiev will give a priceless trove of musical manuscripts, letters and other items belonging to the composer — including a suitcase — to the Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Columbia in an effort to make them more accessible to scholars. Most of the materials represent Prokofiev’s work from 1918 to 1938, the years he visited or lived in the West.

headline: Two Longtime Gossip Columnists Share Their Secrets (Well, Some of Them)
text: When gossip columnists get a juicy tip but the sourcing is problematic, there’s a tradition called the blind item, in which the subjects are described in detail but not named. As in: What married media duo could not stop bickering during a two-and-a-half-hour interview with a reporter?

headline: A Line of Luxe Basics Made for Dancing
text: Nili Lotan, whose namesake line of luxe basics is a wardrobe staple for both celebrities and everyday, on-the-go women, introduced her spring 2014 collection last Thursday with a performance in her TriBeCa showroom. The Israeli-American designer said that the “very minimal, clean, pure” aesthetic of her 25 new pieces remained true to the vision of her very first collection a decade ago. To present the clothes, she commissioned LeeSaar the Company to incorporate them into an original modern dance, but because the spring looks weren’t designed specifically for dancers, she faced a few obstacles in preparing for the unusual show format. “It’s not models, so you’re not dealing with size 2,” she said. “They’re short and they’re big-muscled, and it was a challenge because most of the samples are a size 2, size 4.” She wound up designing special briefs for the dancers to perform in.

headline: Settlement Report Finds Banks Giving Timely Mortgage Relief
text: The $25 billion national mortgage settlement, intended to help homeowners affected by the housing crisis, appears to be running ahead of schedule, according to a new report by the monitor of the program.

headline: Lifted From a Russian Lake, a Big, if Fragile, Space Rock
text: MOSCOW — Russian officials on Wednesday retrieved the largest fragment so far of a meteor that exploded in February over the city of Chelyabinsk, but as divers and a mechanical winch lifted it from the bottom of a lake, the rock broke into three pieces, and then broke the scale — literally — when all together it weighed in at more than 1,250 pounds.

headline: After Decades, a Water Tunnel Can Now Serve All of Manhattan
text: Of all New York City’s sprawling mega-projects, the water tunnel snaking beneath the grid — connecting the Bronx to Upper Manhattan, Upper Manhattan to Central Park, Central Park to Queens, and, eventually, Queens to the western edge of Brooklyn — is perhaps the hardest to love.

headline: Beauty Is Its Own Excuse
text: The novelist Allan Gurganus discovered the secret to happiness: collecting.

headline: Wine Accessories
text: Well-designed wine accessories highlight any vintage, and maybe even that $6 bottle of merlot.

headline: When the Saint Came Marching In
text: Collections collect collectors. It doesn’t work the other way around.

headline: Wine Accessories: Palette Pleasers
text: Brad Cloepfil, an architect known for designing buildings like the Seattle Art Museum and the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, developed his interest in wine in a roundabout way.

headline: Discounts at Jonathan Adler, Garnet Hill and Others
text: Selected glassware is 30 percent off at Apartment 48 Thursday through Oct. 31 (the Mod hourglass, regularly $38, is about $27); (212) 807-1391, apartment48.com.

headline: Waltzing With the Stars
text: Although Vienna was a birthplace of modernism, its contemporary designers get scant notice in the United States. At least, that’s the view of Michael and Anna Trubrig, a Viennese couple who recently opened Stillfried Wien in TriBeCa to offer vintage and new items from Austria, Germany and Switzerland.

headline: Don’t Try This in Yoga Class
text: Pablo Pardo, a Venezuelan-born industrial designer who worked for Fisher-Price and DaimlerChrysler, started his own lighting company, Pablo, in San Francisco 20 years ago. The business has grown in prestige because of products like Circa, a new lamp that supplies balanced light via a flat-panel LED screen. A round shade-like element, which houses the LEDs, rotates a full 360 degrees and tilts 45 degrees to send the light were it is needed. The lamp also features a four-stage dimmer control and, on most of the models, a USB port for charging mobile gadgets.

headline: If You Could Make It There, You Were Made
text: They were built as speculative housing in the last years of the 19th century, two blocks of elegant town houses in Harlem, divvied up between three architectural teams, including one led by Stanford White. When they were finished, ownership was restricted to whites only. But by the 1920s, the King Model Houses, named for their developer, David King, and known colloquially as Strivers’ Row, had become home to black artists, socialites and professionals like Scott Joplin, Eubie Blake and Dr. Louis T. Wright.

headline: Bonnie Prints
text: Scotland has inspired schoolgirl uniforms, a New Year’s Eve song and a Mel Gibson epic, and now it must be credited for wallpaper patterns by Lake August, a Los Angeles company. Alexis Hartman, Lake August’s founder and designer, resolved to start the business while traveling in Scotland a few years ago and realized her ambition earlier this year.

headline: Chip Kidd: Start Making Sense
text: After 27 years of designing book covers for Knopf, Chip Kidd, the noted graphic artist, novelist and interpreter of superheroes in books like “Batman: Death by Design,” is passing on his wisdom to children. “Go: A Kidd’s Guide to Graphic Design”($17.95) came out this week from Workman Publishing. In 150 highly legible and humorous pages, it manages to teach the principles of form, content, color, type and even a bit of history.

headline: The Renovation Was Overdue
text: Creating living quarters in a Craftsman-style cottage that once housed a library.

headline: Putting Their Stamp on It
text: When Karen Gilliam and Sara Van Beckum began renovating their home in Portland, Ore., which once served as the local branch library, they weren’t planning to live there full time. The couple, who are voice-over artists, were based in New York City and intended to split their time between New York and Oregon.

headline: China, Spitting and Global Tourism
text: Living in Beijing a long time, you learn to anticipate a spitter. The crackling crescendo may begin as he nears, leaving you wondering — is it a territorial thing? Then the finale: a terrific “ptchoo!” and an opalescent glob whirling like a tiny Frisbee into the gutter or onto the pavement near your feet. Or your eye, as happened to my companion standing downwind from a spitter at an open train window, in the western region of Xinjiang.

headline: The Armani Experience
text: It was awkward, in more ways than one.

headline: Scattered by War, Syrians Struggle to Start Over
text: MAFRAQ, Jordan — Watering the plants on her balcony back home in Syria this spring, Wedad Sarhan took delight in how they were stirring to life after the winter months. A jasmine tree filled the small balcony with its sweet scent. An apricot tree, planted eight springs earlier, was blossoming for the first time.

headline: The Historic Scale of Syria’s Refugee Crisis
text: Dramatic images from the Syrian refugee crisis, which exploded to encompass six million people by October 2013.

headline: The Cost of Gridlock
text: Continued uncertainty over fiscal policy has eroded gross domestic product growth over the last several years, according to Macroeconomic Advisers, an independent economic research firm.

headline: A Prairie of the Imagination
text: Federal Twist, a garden in New Jersey, serves no purpose — except an emotional one.

headline: The Good-for-Nothing Garden
text: KINGWOOD TOWNSHIP, N.J. — The best kind of garden is a useless garden. James Golden’s green parcel, in the quiet hummocks above the Delaware River, is literally good for nothing. He has made sure of it.

headline: Designer Wine Accessories
text: While designer wine accessories might not be necessary says architect Brad Cloepfil, they are beautiful and that can be an important part of our surroundings.

headline: To Get Through His Day, These Soothe His Ears
text: In times of stress and lots of work, I try to listen to the most soothing music possible. This usually happens first thing in the morning while I’m performing the morning routine. Here are some things I’ve been listening to recently. NICO MUHLY

headline: Theater, Dance, Film, Pop: Don’t Pin Him Down
text: His schedule crowded and his list of collaborators long, Nico Muhly has many other projects planned for this year and next in addition to “Two Boys,” opening on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera. His recent New York premieres have ranged from the melancholy score for the choreographer Benjamin Millepied’s “Neverwhere,” which had its debut with New York City Ballet last month, to sensitive music for a new production of “The Glass Menagerie,” now on Broadway. Here is a look at nine other Muhly projects, from arrangements for an Icelandic pop artist’s lushly wistful new album to songs for an eminent mezzo-soprano and pianist.

headline: ‘Two Boys’ and One Composer
text: When Nico Muhly’s opera “Two Boys” was first performed two years ago in London, Paul Cremo convened a small focus group.

headline: In Performance: Nico Muhly
text: Nico Muhly performs an excerpt from “I’m Only Sixteen” from his opera “Two Boys.” He is accompanied by the tenor Paul Appleby.

headline: James Golden’s Picks
text: Q. Where is the perfect spot to put a plant in the garden?

headline: When the Gold Dust Settles
text: “The Luminaries,” Eleanor Catton’s remarkable second novel — the winner of this year’s Man Booker Prize — is a lot of things, and I mean a lot, but above all, perhaps, it is a love story, one that takes all of 826 pages to truly arrive. And it’s not even a novel in the normal sense, but rather a mass confabulation that evaporates in front of us, an astrological divination waning like the moon, the first section 360 pages long (or are those degrees?), the last a mere sliver. But it’s a sliver that delivers.

headline: Cameron Criticizes The Guardian for Publishing Secrets
text: LONDON — The battle lines hardened between the British authorities and The Guardian newspaper over its publication of material leaked by the fugitive American intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden, when Prime Minister David Cameron accused the newspaper on Wednesday of damaging national security.

headline: Finally Back in the East, the Rangers Seem at Home
text: WASHINGTON — Playing a game in the East for the first time this season turned out to be just what the Rangers needed. They dominated the Washington Capitals, 2-0, on Wednesday, their most impressive outing of an otherwise dreadful start to the campaign.

headline: Shopping Events in New York Beginning Oct. 17
text: Openings

headline: Flying Close to the Law
text: Duke Riley, a Brooklyn artist, trained 50 homing pigeons to fly from Havana, Cuba, to the Florida Keys carrying illicit cigars and cameras to record the journey.

headline: Avian Artistry, With Smuggled Cigars
text: Pablo Escobar was loose. He darted across a noisy warehouse, searching for a corner to loom in.

headline: Massachusetts: Bomb Suspects’ Sister in Court
text: A sister of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev appeared in a South Boston district court on Wednesday to address an outstanding warrant for her arrest. The woman, Ailina Tsarnaeva, 23, was arraigned in January 2011 on a charge that she misled an investigator looking into the passing of a counterfeit bill at a Boston Applebee’s; the warrant was issued when she failed to appear later for a court date. Prosecutors say that she knew members of the group that allegedly used the bill, but that she lied to the police about the incident. On Wednesday, Judge Michael C. Bolden released Ms. Tsarnaeva, who now lives in New Jersey, on $1,500 personal recognizance and required her to check in weekly with probation officers. She could face up to 2.5 years in prison if convicted.

headline: Iran's Nuclear Talks in Geneva
text: Two days of discussions between Iran and six world powers ended on Wednesday. They were the first talks on Iran’s nuclear program since Hassan Rouhani’s election as president.

headline: Massachusetts Schools Dial Back on Obesity Reports
text: The state Public Health Council voted Wednesday to stop automatically sending letters home with public school students about their weight. The state is one of 21 that collect data about students’ body mass index, but some parents say the letters with their children’s results can cause self-esteem problems and the risk of bullying. The testing will continue in Grades 1, 4, 7 and 10 with increased confidentiality protections; parents will receive results only if they ask for them.

headline: Man Gets 30-Year Sentence for Raping Bird-Watcher in Central Park
text: A 74-year-old bird-watcher who was raped in Central Park confronted her attacker in court on Wednesday at his sentencing, describing in detail how he brutally assaulted her while she was photographing hummingbirds.

headline: In Greece, the Banking Chief Draws Scrutiny
text: ATHENS — In an era when central bankers like Ben S. Bernanke dominate the global economic stage, few hold as much power within their own country as Georgios A. Provopoulos, the governor of the Bank of Greece, who has played a crucial role in keeping Greece out of bankruptcy and in the euro zone.

headline: Body of Nazi War Criminal Moved to Airport in Rome After Clashes
text: As my colleague Elisabetta Povoledo reported, a funeral for Erich Priebke, a former Nazi officer who died under house arrest in Rome last week while serving a life sentence in Italy for the wartime massacre of more than 300 civilians, was called off on Tuesday, after angry protests and clashes at a church run by renegade Catholics.

headline: British Police on Defensive Over Downing Street Clash
text: LONDON — As an experienced politician, Andrew Mitchell might well have known it was a bad idea to swear at the police officers who had just ordered him to get off his bicycle outside the prime minister’s office on Downing Street in September 2012.

headline: Senate Passes Measure to End Fiscal Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans conceded defeat Wednesday in their bitter budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law, agreeing to end a disruptive 16-day government shutdown and extend federal borrowing power to avert a financial default with potential worldwide economic repercussions.

headline: Maxine Powell, Motown’s Maven of Style, Dies at 98
text: Maxine Powell, the Miss Manners of Motown, who as the director of the label’s in-house finishing school in the 1960s was considered in no small part responsible for its early success, died on Monday in Southfield, Mich. She was 98.

headline: An Activist Investor Is Urging Darden to Break Itself Up
text: Over 45 years, Darden has grown from a single restaurant in a landlocked Florida city to a 2,100-outlet empire, with its Olive Garden and Red Lobster brands blanketing the country.

headline: Ex-Coach Says Greatness Remains Within Federer’s Reach
text: If Paul Annacone is bitter about losing his roster spot on Team Roger Federer last week, he is doing an Oscar-worthy job of hiding it.

headline: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds
text: The owner of a company that has done nearly $1 billion in work on the steel skeletons of two World Trade Center towers and a transit hub is expected to be implicated in a criminal fraud case that would be among the largest to involve the misuse of funds designated for minority- or women-owned businesses, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: In New Book, Cheney Recalls 5 Heart Attacks and His Brush With Death
text: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Dick Cheney was so close to death in 2010 that he said farewell to his family members and instructed them to have his body cremated and the ashes returned to Wyoming, he writes in a new book on his long battle with heart disease.

headline: Thin at Running Back, the Giants Sign Hillis
text: The Giants on Wednesday signed the free-agent running back Peyton Hillis, who rushed for 1,177 yards for the Cleveland Browns three seasons ago. Hillis, a 6-foot-1, 245-pound, six-year veteran, has played for Denver, Cleveland and Kansas City. He was also with Tampa Bay during the preseason this year.

headline: Larry Benoit, ‘Babe Ruth for Hunters,’ Is Dead at 89
text: Larry Benoit, who tracked whitetail deer through the snowy woods of northern New England and southern Canada for more than seven decades, shooting at least 200 of the biggest and most prized specimens, known as trophy bucks, while becoming one of the nation’s most revered deer hunters, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Duxbury, Vt. He was 89.

headline: Obama Addresses Deal to End Fiscal Dispute
text: President Obama made a public statement Wednesday night after the Senate voted to pass a bill that would end the government shutdown and increase the debt limit, allowing the nation to avert a default on its financial obligations.

headline: Assault of Dutch Diplomat in Moscow Frays Ties Between Russia and the Netherlands
text: MOSCOW — The year 2013 was officially supposed to be one of cultural exchange to highlight the friendship between Russia and the Netherlands. But lately, the most common exchanges between officials have been threats and legal actions amid an intensifying quarrel over the arrest and prosecution of Dutch citizens detained by the Russian Coast Guard aboard a Greenpeace ship flagged in the Netherlands.

headline: Hugh White on ‘The China Choice’
text: Australia has always been one of the United States’ most loyal allies, but now that the Australian economy depends mightily on the sale of iron ore to China, attitudes are a little more blurred. So perhaps it is not surprising that a provocative thesis — that the United States should share power with China in the Asia-Pacific region — should come from a former Australian government defense official.

headline: Stumbling Blocks in Reducing Balance on a Student Loan
text: YOU’VE been working hard and paying your student loans on time, and you find yourself with a bit of extra cash. So you decide that instead of spending it, you’ll make an extra loan payment, to whittle down your principal faster and save money on interest.

headline: Ending the Shutdown
text: Congressional Republicans agreed to support plan to reopen the government about 24 hours before the Treasury was due to exhaust its borrowing authority.

headline: Case Against Michigan Ban on Gay Unions Is Sent to Trial
text: DETROIT — A federal judge on Wednesday ruled that a case contesting Michigan’s ban on same-sex marriage would go to trial early next year, one among some 30 such challenges playing out in courthouses around the nation.

headline: De Blasio Lashes Out at Lhota Over a Television Ad
text: The race for mayor of New York City entered a tenser and more incendiary phase on Wednesday, as the candidates clashed over a harsh and provocative television advertisement suggesting that the Democratic nominee, Bill de Blasio, would return the city to an era of crime, riots and graffiti-covered subway cars.

headline: Dodgers Get Out of Jam and Back Into Series
text: LOS ANGELES — With the midday sun radiating warmth across Chavez Ravine and the palm trees beyond the outfield pavilions rippling slightly in the breeze as a late-arriving crowd trickled in, the ambience that typically accompanies taut playoff baseball was absent Wednesday at Dodger Stadium.

headline: Sebelius Stands Firm Despite Calls to Resign
text: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, has no intention of bowing to Republican demands that she resign after the troubled rollout of President Obama’s health care law, people close to her said Wednesday. And the White House expressed “full confidence” in her.

headline: Second Thoughts on Voter ID
text: On Friday, Richard Posner, a highly respected federal judge, offered an unusual admission. He had made a mistake, he said, in voting to uphold one of the country’s first voter-ID laws. As courts in Texas, North Carolina and other states deal with litigation over ever-stricter versions of such laws — all enacted in the name of preventing nonexistent fraud — the question is what effect Judge Posner’s admirable candor could have.

headline: The Disappearing Moose
text: For such large creatures, moose are a relatively hidden species. They are hard to count. They live where humans do not like to go, along the boggy fringes of northern lakes and rivers where the sound of summer mosquitoes fills the air. They thrive in cold weather, and their well-being depends on sharp, cold autumns and late springs, which protect them from their most important predator: not the wolf, but the winter tick.

headline: Europe Cracks Down on Tobacco
text: The European Parliament voted last week to toughen regulations on the marketing and sale of tobacco that puts the Continent ahead of the United States in discouraging smoking, particularly among children.

headline: The Republican Surrender
text: UPDATE: President Obama signed the bill reopening the government and lifting the debt ceiling early Thursday morning.

headline: Photography in Service to Humanity
text: Robin Hammond just “thought it was cool” when he enrolled in a photography program in Wellington, New Zealand. But he soon found a serious calling as a photographer while paging through a copy of W. Eugene Smith’s “Minamata” in his college library.

headline: Effort to Evacuate Syrian Civilians Is Thwarted by Shelling
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — It seemed promising until the shelling started: under a brief cease-fire, 200 civilians were preparing to evacuate on Wednesday from a rebel-held town near Damascus that the government has blockaded for months. Their flight was arranged in a small-scale local deal that some aid workers and others hoped could become a blueprint for building trust and, perhaps, helping to end the war.

headline: A Tree Grows in Canada
text: This Friday is Persons Day in Canada, a special day on the country’s calendar that commemorates, of all things, a judicial decision. It was on Oct. 18, 1929, that the Privy Council, a court in London that served then as the highest appeals court for Canada, declared women to come within the definition of “persons” in Canada’s basic law, thus qualifying them for appointment to the national Senate. It was, Beverley McLachlin, the chief justice of Canada, said in a speech earlier this year, “the beginning of a rights revolution that would transform Canadian society.”

headline: Republican Collapse
text: Congress has finally worked out a deal to end the government shutdown and dodge default, but not before the Republican Party demonstrated to Americans just how conflicted and dangerous it is.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Toxins
text: “Lead helps to guard your health.”

headline: At Brooklyn’s Domino Sugar Site, Waning Opposition to Prospect of Luxury Towers
text: It is the consummate landmark for 2013 Williamsburg: a monument of the Brooklyn neighborhood’s industrial past that a developer has decided to transform into luxury high-rise buildings, knowing that people will pay to live in them for the unmatched views, the industrial-chic glamour and the neighborhood, the most up-and-coming of them all.

headline: The Myth of the Medical-Device Tax
text: WASHINGTON — IN the last few days of negotiations in Congress, repeal of the Affordable Care Act’s tax on medical devices emerged as a key Republican demand. The medical-device industry waged an intense lobbying campaign — even garnering the support of many Democrats who favored the law — arguing that the tax would stifle innovation and increase health care costs.

headline: Search Tools Wanting on Many Exchanges
text: SHELBYVILLE, Ky. — As he was trying to sign up for health insurance through Kentucky’s new online exchange this month, Kenny Wheeler hit a wall.

headline: Most Regions Experienced Modest Growth
text: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserve’s 12 districts, according to survey results released by the Fed on Wednesday. The survey is based on information collected on or before Oct. 7.

headline: Tigers May Catch Themselves by the Tail
text: DETROIT — With the Detroit Tigers leading by seven runs in the sixth inning on Wednesday, a fan in a Justin Verlander jersey tried to start a wave in the center field stands. It petered out within two or three sections, and after several attempts, the fan sat down.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 16, 2013
Snowden Journalist’s New Venture to Be Bankrolled by eBay Founder
text: For years, the tech billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar has been experimenting with ways to promote serious journalism, searching for the proper media platform to support with the fortune he earned as the founder of eBay. He has made grants to independent media outlets in Africa and government watchdog groups in the United States. In a more direct effort, he created a news Web site in Hawaii, his home state.

headline: Let’s Make a Deal
text: Well, um, yippee.

headline: Door May Open for Challenge to Secret Wiretaps
text: WASHINGTON — Five years after Congress authorized a sweeping warrantless surveillance program, the Justice Department is setting up a potential Supreme Court test of whether it is constitutional by notifying a criminal defendant — for the first time — that evidence against him derived from the eavesdropping, according to officials.

headline: Latin America Brings Up Its Dead, Seeking Truth to Help Settle the Past
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the aftermath of Chile’s 1973 military coup, the Nobel Prize-winning poet and diplomat Pablo Neruda was found dead. Although he was long thought to have perished from prostate cancer, a judge recently ordered his remains exhumed from a grave overlooking the Pacific Ocean to investigate claims that he was poisoned.

headline: Red, White and Blue Reprieve for Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — A month ago, when the United States men’s soccer team handed Mexico a 2-0 defeat in Columbus, Ohio, and put Mexico’s World Cup hopes in peril, the sports tabloid Esto took to English to scream shock and dismay on its front page: “WHAT?”

headline: My Cloistered Teenage Soul
text: A few months ago, I found myself shifting nervously in the driver’s seat of a parked rental car and avoiding the rearview mirror, afraid I’d catch a disquieting glimpse of my adolescent self glaring back. I’ve never come entirely to grips with him — or rather, I’ve never entirely forgiven him his lies and his cowardice. And now that I was about to walk into my 20-year high school reunion, his ghost was unbearably palpable.

headline: Juror’s Gesture Livens CityTime Fraud Trial
text: There would be accusations about millions of dollars in illegal kickbacks and how fraud was at the heart of New York City’s scandal-ridden payroll modernization project. But before any of that could be heard came the matter of the juror and her middle finger.

headline: Contract Employee Arrested After Dry-Ice Bombs Are Found at Los Angeles Airport
text: LOS ANGELES — For three days this week, the discovery of dry-ice bombs at Los Angeles International Airport rattled public confidence here.

headline: Lhota Explains Role in Crime Data
text: There have been many disputes over who deserves credit for the steep drop in crime in New York City that began in the 1990s. There have been more than a few over who deserves credit for the creation of CompStat, the management system that was an important tool in bringing murder and mayhem under control.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 17, 2013
text: “We fought the good fight. We just didn’t win.”

headline: Booker, Winning Rocky Senate Bid, Gets a Job to Fit His Profile
text: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark easily won New Jersey’s special Senate election on Wednesday, finally rising to an office that measures up to his national profile.

headline: Rodriguez’s Arbitration Case Resumes
text: New York’s version of October baseball resumed on Wednesday as Alex Rodriguez returned to Park Avenue to continue his arbitration hearing on the 211-game drug suspension that Major League Baseball is trying to impose on him.

headline: If the Scores Are So Low, Why Are the Games So Long?
text: DETROIT — The notion seemed contradictory, a nine-inning, 1-0 baseball game that could last almost four hours. It is a soccer score, after all, and in that sport, the game would be over in less than two hours.

headline: What Kind of Senator Will Booker Be?
text: Cory Booker, the mayor of Newark and one of the best-known young politicians in America, will be the next United States senator from New Jersey.

headline: Housing That's Not a Luxury
text: What  programs could increase the amount of affordable homes in New York and elsewhere?

headline: The New Look for The Times
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reform in Turkey
text: To the Editor:

headline: Start-Up Problems at the Health Exchanges
What Puts Young Women at Risk of Prostitution?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Loss of Privacy: The Fault Lies With Us
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seeking Lessons From the Fiscal Crisis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Losing a Lot to Get Little
text: WASHINGTON — For the Republicans who despise President Obama’s health care law, the last few weeks should have been a singular moment to turn its problem-plagued rollout into an argument against it. Instead, in a futile campaign to strip the law of federal money, the party focused harsh scrutiny on its own divisions, hurt its national standing and undermined its ability to win concessions from Democrats. Then they surrendered almost unconditionally.

headline: As Secession Talk Swells in Catalonia, Business Leaders Remain Wary of Costs
text: SANT SADURNÍ D’ANOIA, Spain — Sparkling Cava wine has become an emblem of Catalonia as one of the strongest exports from Spain’s northeastern region. Over the last decade, annual shipments of cava have climbed about 50 percent, to 161 million bottles.

headline: Obama Speaks After Senate Passes Bill
text: President Obama thanked the leaders of both parties after the Senate voted to pass a bill that would end the government shutdown and increase the debt limit.

headline: Corrections: October 17, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Those Star-Crossed Lovers, Caught Between Feuding Parents
text: Harken, all ye who have loved unwisely, to the woeful tale of Lady Capulet and her Tybalt. This little-known but intriguing tragedy, which opened on Wednesday night at Classic Stage Company, presents the devastating consequences of a Veronese noblewoman’s illicit passion for a younger kinsman who is called the Prince of Cats, a realm that evidently has room for cougars.

headline: Can You Tell Me How to Get to Nezavisimosti Street?
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Coming up with a theme for a puzzle is the kind of thing that can happen anywhere, at any time. Most of my best ideas come to me just as I’m falling asleep or waking up. Some people find that their creative juices flow best when they’re exercising. Sometimes a word or phrase gets stuck between the brain cells, and you happen to notice there is something fun and unusual about it. That’s what happened to Gary J. Whitehead. We’ll read more about that below.

headline: Limits Approved for Genetically Modified Crops in Kauai, Hawaii
text: Legislators on the island of Kauai in Hawaii have approved a bill that would restrict the use of pesticides by companies developing genetically modified crops there.

headline: Anthony Likes Idea of Becoming Free Agent
text: The Knicks have yet to start the regular season, but some of the focus is already beginning to drift toward next summer, when Carmelo Anthony is eligible to opt out of the final year of his contract. According to an article posted Wednesday on The New York Observer Web site, Anthony fully intends to do so.

headline: 2 Officers Accused of Harassing Latinos Now Await Verdict
text: HARTFORD — The federal trial of two police officers accused of harassing Latinos in a Connecticut town concluded here on Wednesday with lawyers in the case presenting very different views of the officers and how they did their jobs.

headline: Trial Opens for Imelda Marcos’s Ex-Aide
text: When the former personal secretary to Imelda Marcos contacted a London gallery three years ago about selling a Monet masterpiece that Mrs. Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, had bought in the 1970s, the gallery was understandably leery.

headline: Italy: No Solution on Burial of Ex-Nazi
text: After protests Tuesday evening halted the furtively organized funeral of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain associated with a World War II massacre, the former Nazi’s corpse lay Wednesday at a military airport near the capital, waiting for a resolution. Five days after Mr. Priebke’s death at 100, the question of how to dispose of his remains was unresolved, after various cities in Italy, Germany and Argentina, where he lived for decades, declined to offer a final resting place. Discussions for alternative solutions continued Wednesday, a spokesman for the Rome prefecture said. The halted funeral was in the town of Albano Laziale, southeast of Rome.

headline: House Votes to Approve Senate Plan
text: Hours after the Senate passed its measure, the House voted 285 to 144 to approve the Senate plan, which would fund the government through Jan. 15 and raise the debt limit through Feb. 7.

headline: Odd Bedfellows in Realigned Big East Bond Over Basketball
text: Grant Gibbs is a senior point guard for Creighton, with neat brown hair and cornflower blue eyes. He was raised in Marion, a small city in eastern Iowa, where his mother was a home economics teacher at the local high school. His father works at the Quaker Oats cereal distribution factory in Cedar Rapids.

headline: Central African Republic: Group Reports New Deadly Attacks
text: A new wave of attacks and killings has engulfed parts of the Central African Republic, Doctors Without Borders reported Wednesday. The organization is one of the few international aid providers that has remained in the country, which has descended into near-total chaos in the past half year. In a statement, Doctors Without Borders said more than 30,000 people had been displaced in the northwestern town of Bossangoa, and thousands more in surrounding areas.

headline: Japan: Many Dead or Missing After Typhoon
text: A powerful typhoon struck eastern Japan on Wednesday, causing landslides and floods that left at least 17 people dead and 43 missing, the police said. Tokyo briefly ground to a halt as bullet trains and flights were suspended when the storm, Typhoon Wipha, swept through with strong winds and rain. At the wrecked Fukushima nuclear plant, workers released the Pacific rainwater that collected near storage tanks, but the company that operates the plant said the contamination was far below safe drinking water levels.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Seahawks (5-1) at Cardinals (3-3)
text: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: Hands Empty but Spirit Unbowed, House Republicans Take Stock
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner strolled into a late-afternoon meeting with House Republicans and gave them one key directive: go home after it was all over on Wednesday night and get some sleep. Their fight was done.

headline: Disposal of Chemical Arms in Syria Progresses
text: Inspectors from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the agency based in The Hague that is responsible for policing a global ban, have reached 11 of Syria’s 20 sites, the agency said Wednesday, and had verified their contents and begun destroying equipment at six. The work, part of a joint mission with the United Nations, advanced the process of dismantling Syria’s toxic arsenal, under a Security Council resolution unanimously approved last month. President Obama had earlier threatened military strikes against Syria over the Aug. 21 chemical attacks near Damascus that killed hundreds of people.

headline: First Task for Panel in New Playoff System: Easing Suspicions of Bias
text: IRVING, Tex. — On paper, the credentials of the 13-member college football selection committee announced Wednesday appear above reproach. Yet even as the mechanics of their mission — to seek a true Football Bowl Subdivision champion — were rolled out, officials acknowledged it would be hard for the members to be perceived as neutral enough to satisfy fans’ scrutiny.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Far Behind, Lhota Takes a Risk
text: Confronting stagnant poll numbers and a lackluster debate performance, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor, is hoping an aggressive new advertisement can refocus the race on an issue that Republicans typically dominate: public safety.

headline: Top Republicans Split on Fiscal Vote
text: The vote on the budget legislation split influential House Republicans.

headline: A Teachable Moment
text: One of the themes running through my various government shutdown posts has been the importance of seeing the current wave of right-wing populism clearly and weighing its merits and demerits judiciously. That requires understanding the strategic thinking that led to the shutdown in the first place … acknowledging the legitimate sense of political disappointment that underlies the right’s inclination toward intransigence … and most importantly, recognizing that relative to the G.O.P. establishment (such as it is), today’s right-wing populists often have better political instincts and better policy ideas.

headline: Examining the Status of Iran’s Nuclear Program and Talks
text: Negotiators in Iran’s protracted nuclear dispute reported “substantive and forward looking negotiations” last month and said they would reconvene Nov. 7 to 8 for further talks. The following covers some questions about Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: After Mayoral Debate, Back on the Trail
text: Bill de Blasio met Muslim supporters and Joseph J. Lhota served food at a Jewish soup kitchen on Wednesday, a day after the mayoral rivals sparred in a televised debate.

headline: Bruno Metsu, 59, Dies; Led Senegal at World Cup
text: Bruno Metsu, a French soccer coach who led Senegal’s national team in an exhilarating and improbable run to the 2002 World Cup quarterfinals, died on Oct. 15. He was 59.

headline: Week 7 N.F.L. Probabilities: Jets Over Patriots
text: What is often the most interesting thing about a statistical prediction model is discovering why the model disagrees with conventional opinion.

headline: Raids to Free Minks Up Ante on Animal Rights
text: NEW HOLSTEIN, Wis. — Next to their white clapboard house on a rural road here, in long rows of cages set beneath the roofs of seven open-air sheds, Virginia and Gary Bonlander are raising 5,000 minks. Or were, anyway, until two Saturdays ago, when the police roused them from bed at 5 a.m. with a rap on their door.

headline: A Syrian Refugee Family’s New Life
text: Millions of Syrians have fled the civil war, scattering to neighboring countries like Jordan. Many have dreams of returning to a homeland long vanished.

headline: In China’s Campaign Against Bloggers, a Burst of Rumor-Mongering
text: The Chinese government has described its recent campaign to control online speech as an effort to stop unfounded rumors. In recent days, though, such rumors have only seemed to mushroom.

headline: Disruption on the House Floor as Measure Passes
text: WASHINGTON — And just when it seemed as if things could not get any more bizarre in the Capitol, a House stenographer, shouting and protesting, was dragged off the House floor as the House voted to pass the Senate deal, 285 to 144, late Wednesday night.

headline: Mayor of Chinese City Is Held by Communist Party Investigators
text: HONG KONG — Communist Party investigators have detained the mayor of Nanjing, a major city in eastern China, on allegations of “grave disciplinary violations,” a term that almost always refers to corruption and abuses of power, state-run news media reported on Wednesday.

headline: When Renovation Means Erasing the Past
text: The fetish for destroying historic houses to feed the hunger for infinite white space has led to a global style of architectural homogeneity.

headline: Study Finds Gains From Teacher Evaluations
text: The education research of recent years has pointed overwhelmingly to the importance of teachers. Perhaps more than anything else – quality of principal, size of school, size of class – the strength or weakness of classroom teachers influences how much students learn and even how they fare later in life.

headline: Brazil’s Protests, on and Off the Wall
text: Not long after 2 a.m. last Sunday, some 30 photographers and friends swept the downtown dust off two walls that closed in a small but busy street near São Paulo’s Luz subway station. They had just slathered glue onto several large photos and were about to paste them onto the walls when the police showed up and asked what they were doing.

headline: Hong Kong Rents Soar, Squeezing Out Small Shops
text: On a busy intersection in the crowded Hong Kong neighborhood of Sheung Wan — among dried-seafood traders, hardware stores and clothing shops — a trio of shops has been shuttered for the last few weeks: a tiny flower shop, a wine-and-tobacco store and a fruit vendor who mixed juices for passers-by to consume on the narrow sidewalk.

text: Congressional Republican leaders conceded defeat in their budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law after the government shut down for 16 days.

headline: President Signs Bill; Employees Told to Return to Work
text: About 12:30, President Obama signed the measure passed by the Senate and the House to reopen the government and extend federal borrowing power. Earlier, the Office of Management and Budget said federal employees should return to work on Thursday.

headline: What’s on Thursday

(USA) WHITE COLLAR Season 5 opens with the F.B.I. agent Peter Burke (Tim DeKay) behind bars after being accused of murdering a senator — forcing Neal Caffrey (Matt Bomer, above left with Willie Garson) to return to his con man roots to set the record straight and overturn the charges. A new round of “Covert Affairs,” at 10, begins as Annie Walker (Piper Perabo) sheds the life she knew to operate off the grid in pursuit of Henry Wilcox (Gregory Itzin).

headline: News Quiz | October 17, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: As China Mocks U.S. Debt Fight, Its Loyalty to Treasuries Remains
text: Updated, 7:00 a.m. | China reacted to Congress’ deal avoiding a debt default for now with welcomes, warnings and mockery on Thursday. It took a retired official to emphasize the awkward fact that China has little choice but to stay shackled to the dollar — for now.

headline: Japanese Leader Rejects Appearance at War Shrine
text: TOKYO — For a third time this year, Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, refused supporters’ calls to visit a controversial Tokyo war shrine on Thursday, sending a ceremonial offering instead in what was apparently an effort to avoid angering Asian neighbors, including China.

headline: Chinese Leader Gets a Cartoon Makeover
text: China’s new leader, Xi Jinping, has brought a more down-to-earth style to the job than his famously formal predecessor, Hu Jintao. But a new animated video portrays Mr. Xi and the rest of China’s ruling Politburo Standing Committee in a light far more playful than typically seen in China.
