headline: Are Women Better at Compromising and Collaborating?
text: Women make up less than 20 percent of Congress, yet they have emerged from the budget standoff as the real team players in Washington. According to a front-page article this week, a small group of female senators were the leaders in a bipartisan effort that paved the way to end the government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling.

headline: The Long March of the American Right
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Chinese to Invest in British Nuclear Power
text: LONDON — Britain said on Thursday that it would allow Chinese firms to buy stakes in British nuclear power plants and eventually acquire majority holdings.

headline: CMJ: Despite Frustrations, Guitars Impress on Day 2
text: At least I got my guitar blare. Day 2 of this year’s CMJ Music Marathon was full of frustrations: some to do with the inaccurate online schedule — really, phantom sets by bands I wanted to see? Doesn’t anyone update these? Also frustrating were the travel times between the Lower East Side and Brooklyn. And then there were the baby bands who had decided — even before the release of a debut album — what their songwriting formula was and were determinedly playing sets of formula songs. I won’t slam them here; may they remember when they considered themselves creative.

headline: New York Today: The Ex-Mayors
text: Updated 12:01 p.m. | What do New York City mayors do after leaving office?

headline: Where’s That Advance Care Directive?
text: Nancy Wagner, a social worker at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J., encounters this frustration at least once a week: A patient arrives in the emergency room and tells the inquiring staff that yes, she has indeed prepared and signed an advance directive. But, well, she doesn’t have it with her.

headline: Driving Through Manhattan in a Huge R.V.
text: Navigating New York City streets in a normal vehicle can be trying enough. When the roads aren’t an awful patchwork of lumpy asphalt and haphazard steel plates, thick clusters of pedestrians crowd into the right-of-way at intersections, making your path look like a canyon that’s slowly closing in upon itself.

headline: Divided We Stand
text: JERUSALEM — Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, the Israeli spiritual and political leader who died on Oct. 7 at 93, was buried by an astonishing number of mourners. The official police tally at the day of the funeral estimated the figure at 800,000; the number was then revised, by the police itself, to about 400,000.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Shifts Its Rules on Privacy for Teenagers
text: Facebook has loosened its privacy rules for teenagers as a rising debate swirls over online threats to children from online bullies and sexual predators, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: If Not Now, When?
text: LONDON — It is possible to imagine a scenario more favorable to Israel than the current one, but it is not easy.

headline: Africa’s Trauma Epidemic
text: LAGOS — It was dusk and I was on my way home from Abeokuta, a vibrant city in southwest Nigeria. My driver had switched off the car’s air-conditioning so I could open the windows and feel the breeze. He was weaving between potholes in the road when suddenly, the scene ahead changed.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Government Shutdown Ends After 16 Days
text: In the article “Republicans Back Down, Ending Crisis Over Shutdown and Debt Limit,” Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker report on the final negotiations that ended the fiscal impasse in Washington.

headline: Investors Fear the Next Political Battle
text: Investor relief on Wednesday at the last-minute agreement to raise the nation’s borrowing limit and end the government shutdown was tempered by the knowledge that the deal did not represent a permanent solution to the budget crises that have become more frequent in recent years, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Under the deal, the government will be financed through Jan. 15 and the Treasury will have borrowing powers until Feb. 7 — at which point sharp political divisions could re-emerge.

headline: What A Drag
text: As many people have been pointing out, the economic costs of GOP attempts to rule by extortion didn’t begin with the shutdown/debt crisis, and haven’t ended with the (temporary?) resolution of that crisis. The now widely-cited Macroeconomic Advisers report estimated the cost of crisis-driven fiscal policy at 1 percentage point off the growth rate for three years, or roughly 3 percent now. More than half of this estimated cost comes from the “fiscal drag” of falling discretionary spending, with the rest coming from a (shaky) estimate of the impacts of fiscal uncertainty on borrowing costs.

headline: Key to Ants’ Evolution May Have Started With a Wasp
text: How should we judge the success of an animal? Philip S. Ward, a biologist at the University of California, Davis, offers what could be called the Picnic Test. “Have a picnic anywhere in the world,” he suggests. “Who would pick up the crumbs?”

headline: The Blood and Tears, Not the Magnolias
text: “12 Years a Slave” isn’t the first movie about slavery in the United States — but it may be the one that finally makes it impossible for American cinema to continue to sell the ugly lies it’s been hawking for more than a century. Written by John Ridley and directed by Steve McQueen, it tells the true story of Solomon Northup, an African-American freeman who, in 1841, was snatched off the streets of Washington, and sold. It’s at once a familiar, utterly strange and deeply American story in which the period trappings long beloved by Hollywood — the paternalistic gentry with their pretty plantations, their genteel manners and all the fiddle-dee-dee rest — are the backdrop for an outrage.

headline: Air Pollution Linked to Lower Birth Weights
text: Air pollution, even at relatively low levels, is associated with a significant increase in the risk for low-birth-weight babies, a new study has found.

headline: Fall in Revenue at Goldman Sachs Raises Concerns
text: Updated, 5:53 p.m. | Among Goldman Sachs employees, the chatter started months ago that 2013 was going to be a good bonus year. The Wall Street bank began the year strong, and despite concerns about the economy, its profit doubled over year-ago levels in the second quarter.

text: Real estate and investment banking helped propel the Blackstone Group to yet another profitable quarter.

headline: Syrian Official Says Peace Talks Could Be Held in Late November
text: LONDON — A Syrian government official said on Thursday that long-postponed peace talks under international auspices — known in diplomatic shorthand as Geneva II — could be held in late November, raising speculation about who would attend and who would represent the fractured Syrian opposition, which is seeking to topple President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Government Gets Back to Business, but Effects of the Shutdown Linger
text: WASHINGTON — The United States government sputtered back to life Thursday after President Obama and Congress ended a 16-day shutdown, reopening tourist spots and clearing the way for federal agencies to deliver services and welcome back hundreds of thousands of furloughed workers.

headline: Quality Preschool Is the ‘Most Cost-Effective’ Educational Intervention
text: A decade or so ago, when it was time to send my children to preschool, it never occurred to me to do anything else. For an upper-middle-class family like mine, enrolling my kids in a half-day nursery school program with all of its benefits (socialization and school readiness, among them) was a no-brainer.

headline: Donna Tartt: By the Book
text: The author of “The Goldfinch” and “The Secret History” says that personally, “to paraphrase Nabokov: all I want from a book is the tingle down the spine, for my hairs to stand on end.”

headline: Transmuting Forms, Click by Click
text: Robert Rauschenberg, an artist of towering achievement, painted not only with the brush. He also employed, in his works on canvas, the photographs he took throughout his life, as well as found objects. Although the progression of his work aligns with Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism, Pop Art and Conceptual Art, no one movement can claim him. Rauschenberg said that when it came to photography, “the camera is the transport for my eye and carries my seeing from place to place.”

headline: Why Don’t More Owners Open Their Books?
text: This is something I have never understood. Why is it that we business owners are so reluctant to share financial information with employees? For more than 35 years I’ve found that, when I share meaningful information with the people who work with me, our performance as a company improves. The process of sharing a company’s financial performance is known as open-book management.

headline: For Brian O’Kelley of AppNexus, Learning Never Stops
text: This interview with Brian O’Kelley, chief executive of AppNexus, an advertising technology company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Booker Gives Senate Victory Speech
text: After winning the special Senate election on Wednesday, Cory A. Booker, mayor of Newark, thanked supporters and promised to bring a new kind of politics to Washington.

headline: KPN Still Open to Deal With América Móvil

text: Culture and fine cuisine converge for guests at the Four Seasons Hotel Gresham Palace in Budapest–they can now dine on the stage of the Hungarian State Opera House while enjoying a private performance by opera singers and musicians.

headline: As Public Monuments Crumble, Private Aid Seen as Possible Savior
text: NEW DELHI – On a recent afternoon, Hari Om, a 25-year-old craftsman from Dholpur district in Rajasthan, was chiseling star-shaped patterns on blocks of red sandstone near the Humayun’s Tomb, a 16th-century monument built by the Mughals in New Delhi. He is one among 1,500 craftsmen who worked on the restoration of the ancient structure.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Raking Near the Great Works’
text: As the autumn foliage reaches its peak in parts of the United States, we present this timely Poetry Pairing. It features “Raking Near the Great Works,” a poem by Megan Grumbling, and the article “Pedal Peepers in Vermont” by Katie Zezima.

headline: A New Book, to Be Given Away, Documents the Wrath of Hurricane Sandy
text: After Hurricane Sandy swept through the region, people wandered the Rockaways like zombies, cloaked in blankets to protect against the mid-autumn chill. Families were left traumatized by homes reduced to skeletons. For weeks, the elderly and disabled, trapped in their apartments on high floors, waited for food and heat.

headline: G.E. Smith and Jorma Kaukonen Not Enough? Bring Your Own Guitar
text: More than 150 guitarists – among them, Mark Stewart, G.E. Smith, David Broza, Captain Kirk Douglas and, by a Skype link, Jorma Kaukonen – will join forces at the City Winery on Nov. 17 for the Guitar Mash Benefit Concert and Jam. The ensemble will also include some high-profile amateur pickers like Tom Colicchio, the celebrated chef, and Chad Smith, who is better known as a drummer (for the Red Hot Chili Peppers). The concert, in its second year, will raise money for music education programs, including those run by the Church Street School for Music and Arts and Little Kids Rock, a program that offers music workshops in public schools.

First, Stepan returned to the game and said afterward that he was O.K., and second, the Rangers scrupulously followed concussion treatment protocol.

headline: Senator Suggests Heritage Foundation Has Grown Too Extreme
text: The Heritage Foundation, and its political action wing, helped orchestrate the move by House Republicans to force a government shutdown, believing that this confrontational strategy might block the startup of the Obama administration’s health care law. headline: Fantasy Football: Week 7 Tiered Player Rankings
text: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: On Jewishness, as the Fiddle Played
text: “Fiddler on the Roof” — created by Jerry Bock (music), Sheldon Harnick (lyrics), Joseph Stein (book) and Jerome Robbins (direction and choreography) and based on the stories of Sholom Aleichem — was a blockbuster success when it opened in 1964, smashing all box office records in its day. The initial production played 3,242 performances, the longest-running show on Broadway for years. There have been four Broadway revivals and countless national tours; some 200 schools across the country put it on each year.

headline: Good Beer in Berlin? Finally, Yes
text: Gendarmenmarkt, lined with imposing buildings like the French Cathedral and the Konzerthaus, may be Berlin’s most beautiful square. But just a block away, the setting looked like the rest of the central German capital: a mix of cranes, construction sites and creative parking.

headline: Finding a Global Groove in Lisbon
text: Eeva Tuuhea remembers the precise moment when she received a friend’s phone call telling her that the Hot Clube de Portugal, an iconic Lisbon jazz joint since the 1940s and her beloved regular hangout for two decades, was on fire — literally.

headline: Lviv’s, and a Family’s, Stories in Architecture
text: “Here we have architecture, and what was inside perished,” Ihor Zhuk said. “Only a skeleton of this creature remains, like shells of sea creatures that lived many, many years ago.”

headline: Going on a Burmese-Food Diet in the Bay Area
text: Burmese food has been an undeserved straggler in the American hierarchy of Asian cuisines; in New York City, as far as I can tell, we only have one dedicated Burmese restaurant. But things are slowly changing as Myanmar, the country formerly known as Burma, has finally opened to foreign tourists, and “Burma: Rivers of Flavor,” a deeply researched and sumptuously photographed cookbook by Naomi Duguid, has made the wider world more conscious of the cuisine, which mixes influences of China, India and Thailand with traditions from its own varied ethnic groups.

headline: German Parties to Begin Talks to Revive Coalition
text: BERLIN — Exuding good will, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative bloc and its Social Democratic rivals agreed on Thursday to open formal negotiations next week on reviving the “grand coalition” that led Germany from 2005 to 2009 and that both sides suggested could now steer the biggest European economy into four more prosperous years.

headline: After the Dark, the ‘Dream’
text: As the director Julie Taymor started imagining her new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” she made two choices early on: She wanted children to populate the fairy world, and all the fairies to stay earth-bound. “I had no interest in flying,” she said. “That was definitely something I didn’t want to do.”

headline: The Insufficient Craziness Theory
text: Every time Republicans suffer a rejection of the most right-wing items on their agenda, a significant number decide they haven’t been sufficiently crazy. That was the conclusion that many Republicans drew from the defeat of Mitt Romney in 2012. And now that Republicans in Congress have been forced to surrender in their fight with President Obama over the budget, health care and the nation’s credit, some are drawing the same conclusion.

headline: Storm Watching in Style
text: Storm season on Vancouver Island in Canada runs from November through February, and with the storm-watching package at the Wickaninnish Inn, a 75-room Relais & Chateaux beachfront property in Tofino, guests are encouraged to embrace the rainy weather.

headline: Should Parents Face Arrest if Their Child Is a Bully?
text: Sheriff Grady Judd, of Polk County in Florida, told ABC News that he would like to arrest the parents of a teenage girl who has already been arrested and charged with aggravated stalking in the death of a 12-year-old girl.

headline: Decision: New York Progress and Protection PAC vs. James E. Walsh, et al.
text: Read the full decision in the case of New York Progress and Protection PAC vs. James E. Walsh, et al.

headline: Plea Agreement Could End SAC’s Advisory Business
text: The hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is moving closer to a plea deal with prosecutors that would force it to wind down its business of managing money for outside investors, punctuating its decline from the envy of Wall Street to a firm caught in the government’s cross hairs.

headline: Skull Fossil Suggests Simpler Human Lineage
text: After eight years spent studying a 1.8-million-year-old skull uncovered in the Republic of Georgia, scientists have made a discovery that may rewrite the evolutionary history of our human genus Homo.

headline: The Shutdown Shuts Down
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Market Report | What’s Black and White and Swirled All Over?
text: Marble — the ho-hum black-and-white pattern, rather than the material — is getting a face-lift. Balenciaga printed icy variations onto the soft silk of a T-shirt and the structured leather of a pair of pumps, and Josh Goot used it on a silk skirt that looks like it’s made of actual stone. Other designers showcased the pattern in the precious materials of jewels and accessories. Lele Sadoughi created a classic bracelet with the timeless motif; Monique Péan encrusted rough, marbled agate with a showstopping design of shiny pavé diamonds; Ralph Lauren used antique-looking shades of marble for a modern iteration of standby tortoiseshell sunglasses; and Stella McCartney contrasted the bold, geometric lines of a clutch with swirling lines of black and white.

headline: Belgian Brewery Buys U.S. Maker of Craft Beers
text: As European interest in American craft beers begins to mirror the mania for them stateside, the Duvel Moortgat Brewery of Belgium on Thursday announced a deal to buy the Boulevard Brewing Company, a craft brewery in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Authorities Worry 3-D Printers May Undermine Europe’s Gun Laws
text: PARIS — The gun fired four shots into a gelatin block. Each nine-millimeter bullet punched deep into the substance, which was meant to mimic the density of a human body.

headline: U.S. Judge Denies Bid by Lhota Supporters to Accept Unlimited Donations
text: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a bid by a conservative group supporting the mayoral candidacy of Joseph J. Lhota to accept unlimited contributions, saying it would be too disruptive to change New York’s campaign fund-raising laws less than three weeks before Election Day.

headline: Readers Ask How Insurance Subsidies Are Calculated for Students
text: In two recent installments of the Your Money column, I answered questions about the new health insurance exchanges. The first column discussed many of the basics, and the second column answered reader queries. You can find more readers’ questions and answers on In Practice, with the latest series below. If you’re still not sure how the law affects you and your family, please e-mail me: tsbernard@nytimes.com.

headline: Peering Through Katy Perry’s ‘Prism’
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the evolution and regression of Katy Perry as manifested on her new album, “Prism.”

headline: A Spanish Lender’s Face-Saving Move
text: The Spanish lender BBVA is learning the Chinese art of saving face.

headline: After Pause, Resupplying Economic Data
text: Even as Wall Street breathed a sigh of relief on Thursday that the government shutdown was over and the risk of a default on United States debt was off the table for now, attention immediately turned to a critical, if more ordinary, matter for investors and traders: when will federal number-crunchers be providing data on the economy again?

headline: Text to Text | ‘Enrique’s Journey’ and ‘In Trek North, First Lure Is Mexico’s Other Line’
text: Last month we introduced our new Text to Text series, which matches Times content with excerpts from often-taught literary, cultural, historical, or scientific material. Read more about the format, and consider submitting an idea.

headline: Behind the Scenes on Changes to a Story on Pope Francis
text: Laurie Goodstein covers one of the most scrutinized beats at The Times. As national religion correspondent, her recent articles on Pope Francis have been the topic of plenty of conversation and discussion – and have had very heavy readership.

headline: Questions Follow Knicks’ Anthony During a Return to His Hometown
text: BALTIMORE — The present somehow seemed lost Thursday when Carmelo Anthony returned to his hometown. It was all about the past and an uncertain future.

headline: And on Sunday, They Sang
text: Cleopatra’s Needle draws a dedicated bunch to its Sunday afternoon jazz open mike.

headline: The Challenge of Diabetes for Doctor and Patient
text: My patient was miserable — parched with thirst, exhausted and jumping up to go to the bathroom every few minutes. His vision was blurry and he’d been losing weight the last few weeks, despite eating voraciously. I’d only just met him, but I was able to diagnose diabetes in about a minute. What was unusual was that this was a scheduled office visit; usually, patients with such overwhelming symptoms are the provenance of emergency departments and urgent care centers.

headline: Was It All Boehner’s Fault?
text: As a follow-up to my post on the lessons of the shutdown, and my insistence on the essentially indefensible folly of what we’ve just witnessed from House Republicans, let me say something about the alternative interpretation that’s come up in a number of mini-debates I’ve had on Twitter over the last week or so, with conservative writers like the Weekly Standard’s Jay Cost and Sean Davis of the nascent webzine The Federalist. Against my indictment of the Republican caucus as a whole, they’ve basically argued that the seeming irrationality of G.O.P. strategy across the last few weeks mostly just reflects the mistakes, shading into incompetence, of John Boehner’s negotiating strategy, rather the kind of deeper, essentially methodless dysfunction that I see when I look at the House Republicans. At bottom, these interlocutors think that the House Republicans are a fairly normal majority with a serious leadership problem, and they think I’m a victim of what you might call the pundit’s limited-horizon problem, which fails to work in vitally-useful knowledge — political science research in Cost’s case, business-school theory in Davis’s case — that would pin more of the responsibility on Boehner, and less on his backbenchers. (You can also read a more personalized version of this argument here, from the pseudonymous blogger Thomas Crown, which is based on a slight misreading of a tweet I wrote to Davis — such are the perils of Twitter! — but which works off the entirely correct assumption that my analysis of internal House dynamics lacks the benefit of sustained personal experience with high-stakes negotiations in politics, law or the business world.)

headline: Frites Show
text: The life of a Balthazar potato, from farm to fry.

headline: James Franco, Chris O’Dowd Likely for ‘Of Mice and Men’ on Broadway
text: The Oscar-nominated actor James Franco (“127 Hours”) is set to make his Broadway debut this spring as George in a revival of John Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men,” possibly opposite Chris O’Dowd (“Bridesmaids,” “Girls”) as Lennie, a person directly involved with the production said on Thursday. The 1937 play, like the classic novella by Steinbeck, depicts the friendship of the big-dreaming George and the mentally limited Lennie, migrant field workers in California during the Great Depression.

headline: China Hints at Effort to Export Cars to West
text: WUHAN, China — Chinese automakers are starting to ask some of the largest Western auto parts companies to supply parts that meet American and European regulatory standards, according to senior executives at the parts companies.

headline: Shalom Japan
text: Inside the fusion restaurant in South Williamsburg that doesn’t take itself too seriously.

headline: 22 Hours in Balthazar
text: Balthazar may look like a rustic bistro, but behind the scenes, it’s a highly efficient, well-oiled potato-chipping machine.

headline: Chopsticks and Challah
text: Manischewitz and bubbly is the drink at hand, blushing darkly in a flute glass with a jag of lemon peel. It is a play on a kir royale, with the syrupy Sabbath dinner wine subbing for crème de cassis. It could be a gimmick, but it works: the sparkler, Palmer Brut from Long Island, is fruity and expansive, smoothing over Manischewitz’s neurotic sweetness.

headline: Standards, and Regulars
text: Only gradually does it dawn on you that you might be the only one not here to sing. You start to notice the sheet music at the elbow of nearly everyone else at the long S-shaped bar — the slim blonde; the big guy with glasses; the man with the wide Harry Belafonte forehead. You’re at Cleopatra’s Needle, an Upper West Side fixture that’s been serving Middle Eastern food and a daily helping of live music for more than 20 years at 2485 Broadway, at 92nd Street, and this is jazz open mike on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Runners and Bikers Descend on a Reopened California Park
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — Bonnie Clarfield spent Thursday morning carrying out detritus from the government shutdown at the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area: park closure signs, caution tape, and armfuls of trash.

headline: ‘An American in Paris’ Is Planned for Paris, and May Head West to Broadway
text: A new musical adaptation of “An American in Paris,” the 1951 film where Gene Kelly danced and dazzled to the music of George and Ira Gershwin, will have a world-premiere production in Paris in December 2014, then aim for Broadway in the spring of 2015, the producers announced Thursday.

headline: The Life of a Recreational Mathematician
text: The life of recreational mathematician Martin Gardner, as told in family photos.

headline: Decades Later, Condemnation for a Skid Row Cancer Study
text: A medical researcher from Columbia University, Dr. Perry Hudson, made the skid row alcoholics in Lower Manhattan an offer: If they agreed to surgical biopsies of their prostates, they would get a clean bed and three square meals for a few days, plus free medical care and treatment if they had prostate cancer.

headline: Washington Redskins Running Back Gets a New ’91 Mazda
text: Always know where you came from and where you’re going. That’s how Alfred Morris, the Washington Redskins’ 24-year-old star running back, lives his life. It’s also why he has held on to a 1991 Mazda 626.

headline: Touring Boulevard Brewery
text: The Boulevard Brewing Company in Kansas City, Mo., is part of a booming American craft beer industry that is drawing interest — and bids — from European brewers.

headline: Vitamin D Ineffective for Preventing Osteoporosis
text: In a large review of studies, researchers have found almost no evidence that taking vitamin D supplements has any effect in preventing osteoporosis in middle-aged adults.

headline: Learning to Lean In Together
text: The first night my husband and I lived together, we had been married for two years. His work was in a small town in Massachusetts, where he and his ex had raised their now college-age children. My work and life were in New York City.

headline: The Strong, Largely Silent Type
text: True solitude is a rarity at the movies, for those of us in the audience contending with yakkers and texters, and for the people on screen as well. The lonesome strangers of the old westerns almost always had a town to ride into or out of, a buzz of social life to contrast with their individualistic ways. Even movies that emphasize the isolation of their main characters tend to provide them with companions, human or otherwise. Piscine Patel in “Life of Pi” had his tiger, Richard Parker; Chuck Noland in “Cast Away” had Wilson the volleyball. Those guys did a lot of talking, even when nobody else was around.

headline: Letters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Four Freedoms Video
text: Here.

headline: After Outcry, Missouri Rape Case Is Reviewed
text: After widespread scrutiny on the Internet, officials in Missouri this week called for a review of a case involving the rape of a teenager that prosecutors said they had dropped last year for lack of evidence.

headline: Former Pentagon Official to Be Chosen as Homeland Security Chief
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate Jeh C. Johnson, who framed many of the administration’s national security policies as the Defense Department’s general counsel during Mr. Obama’s first term, to become the next secretary of the Homeland Security Department, according to administration officials.

headline: Misleading Numbers on 401(k)’s
text: Are you upset about what happened to your 401(k) account during and after the financial crisis? Perhaps you shouldn’t be, says a trade group for the companies that manage those accounts.

headline: Avoiding a Foul
text: A few years ago, my husband left me after I discovered his series of extramarital affairs. One of his trysts was with a local soccer mom. Her young son plays on the same team as mine; they live on the same block as us, and we travel in the same social circles. (She remains in her marriage; my ex is not present in our lives.) I feel great resentment about her role in the dissolution of my marriage. I think a confrontation is in order, but the soccer field does not seem right. Any ideas?

headline: Seems This Anarchist Is a Laptop Hogger
text: At the very end of “The Fifth Estate,” the filmmakers offer their subject, the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, a chance at pre-emptive rebuttal. Not the actual Assange, of course, but the actor Benedict Cumberbatch, with platinum locks and an Aussie accent providing an uncanny simulacrum. Asked what he thinks of “the WikiLeaks movie,” Assange snorts that it’s more like “the anti-WikiLeaks movie,” bashes the books it’s based on and casts imperious doubt on its accuracy.

headline: Google Tops Estimates, but Prices of Ads Slide
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For more than a decade, Google’s search advertising business has seemed almost magical in its ability to mint money. But the magic is beginning to wear off as people spend more time on mobile devices, where the company makes less money on ads.

headline: Old Informs New at Dual Frieze Fairs in London
text: LONDON — Minutes after the Frieze Art Fair opened here Wednesday morning for V.I.P. collectors, Mark Fisch, a New York real estate developer, paused in front of a table at the booth of a Berlin gallery called Contemporary Fine Arts. On display were 10 carefully arranged replicas of Greek and Roman objects — urns, vases and animals — each copied from works at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where Mr. Fisch happens to be on the board. Fashioned from Play-Doh, they were made this year by the Bruce High Quality Foundation, a Brooklyn artist collective, and were included in a recent retrospective of the collective’s work at the Brooklyn Museum. Now the faux antiquities are priced at $6,500 to $38,000 each.

headline: Throwaways, Put Together Just So
text: Almost anything, even the most banal object, can be beautiful if you see it in the right way. If you’re not good at seeing that way, it helps to have someone present things to you in certain arrangements. That’s where the sculptor Tony Feher comes in. A much-admired but less-than-famous New York artist (born in Albuquerque in 1956), Mr. Feher organizes the kinds of things that most people throw away into simple but surprisingly exciting configurations.

headline: Report That Turkey Exposed Spies Strains Its Relations With Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Persistently strained relations between Israel and Turkey have not been helped by a report that last year Turkey revealed to Iran the identities of up to 10 Iranians who had spied for Israel.

headline: Protests After France Expels 2 Immigrant Students
text: PARIS — Shock over France’s recent expulsion of a 19-year-old Armenian student and a 15-year-old Kosovar girl, whom the police took off a school bus so that she and her family could be sent back to Kosovo, gathered momentum on Thursday with protests by students condemning the deportations and calling for the resignation of the interior minister.

headline: Seafood, Without Going Overboard
text: The first time I visited Bistro 146, a one-year-old seafood restaurant in Pleasantville, I was with a friend whose wife has nicknamed him the Outraged Consumer. He is not easy to please, and sure enough, the evening did not start out well.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, Malta, Afghanistan and Chile.

headline: It’s Not Nice to Fool the Bullied Daughter
text: The last time we saw Carrie White, she was looking a little, well, red around the gills. She had just taken a splashy blood bath in Brian De Palma’s 1976 horror freakout “Carrie,” and then settled in for what looked like the big sleep. Stephen King’s tormented teenager proved a restless soul, though, and returned in a 2002 television movie and a short-lived 1988 Broadway musical that was revived off Broadway again in 2012. Now she’s back, as they like to say in movie ads, in a fine, largely faithful screen remake, directed by Kimberly Peirce that stars Chloë Grace Moretz as its goddess of gore. It’s hard to keep a franchise crazy down, especially one that can be retrofitted for today’s fears.

headline: 'Attention'
text: The latest ad from the de Blasio campaign features Mr. de Blasio's daughter, Chiara.

headline: How It Felt to Be Caught in the Act
text: There was a time on Broadway when “to be Hirschfelded” meant you’d earned the right to burst out the stage door and scream, “I made it!”  Al Hirschfeld, who died in 2003 at 99, was a master illustrator whose line drawings were highly coveted by performers who dreamed of being depicted in his signature squiggles and swoops. During a career that spanned over 80 years, his work appeared in the pages of The New York Times, on the walls of the Museum of Modern Art and on album covers, movie posters and postage stamps.

headline: It Really Was All Germany’s Fault
text: In 1962, when Barbara Tuchman published “The Guns of August,” her Pulitzer Prize-winning account of the opening of World War I, she found a ready reader in President John F. Kennedy. As the Cuban missile crisis unfolded, the book confirmed the president’s belief that war was more likely to break out by accident than by design, and in the folly of a brinkmanship that leaves no fallback position short of actually fighting.

headline: On View | Where Diet Cola Is the New Paint
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Posters Lost to Nazis Are Recovered, and Up for Sale
text: Two poster collections that were lost to their owners under Nazi rule in the 1930s are now for sale in Manhattan. Each collection is made up of thousands of pieces, many of them bearing the signatures of designers as prominent as Alphonse Mucha or Gustav Klimt.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: TV Talk: ‘The Walking Dead’
text: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss “The Walking Dead” and the show’s outstanding viewership.

headline: The Pre-emptive Rate Lock
text: Fixed mortgage rates inched upward as the federal budget deadline loomed. Now that the budget stalemate is over, however, borrowers getting ready to apply for home loans shouldn’t wait around for the still-reasonable rates to drop — lock in the best rate you can get, industry experts say.

headline: After Cutting a Deal, McConnell Draws Criticism From All Sides
text: With Congress stuck in a bitter dispute over fiscal matters, there seemed to be no good solution for Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader up for re-election next year. Forge a compromise and risk attack from a primary opponent on the right. Block a deal and give fodder to a general election opponent on the left.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Nokia’s Moves to Wearable Tech, and Bezos’s League of Shadows
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Following in the Wake of Oars and Paintbrush
text: PHILADELPHIA — WHEN rowers descend here next weekend for the Thomas Eakins Head of the Schuylkill Regatta, they’ll be racing in a riverscape brought to life in Eakins’s celebrated rowing paintings.

headline: Two Boys’ Schooling, for 13 Years of It
text: Late in the documentary “American Promise,” one of its directors, Michèle Stephenson, sits next to her adolescent son, Idris — one of the movie’s subjects — as he reads a disheartening e-mail. They’ve been opening college admissions notices and wading through some bad news. The two are shown separately and together, and at times in close-up. (Participants either talk directly to the camera — and sometimes to the various silent camera persons, who are introduced in the final credits — or avoid its gaze.) You can see every flicker in their faces, which allows you to notice and think about the glassiness in Idris’s eyes. He never cries, but you may find yourself on the verge.

headline: A Gala for Brass in Brooklyn
text: The Miser finds it curious that despite the wide diversity of its musical offerings, New York isn’t especially known for its brass bands.

headline: His Subject, Himself
text: American anti-Semitism, which was running high throughout the 1930s, steadily increased after the onset of war. During the entire period, polls showed, well over a third of the populace stood ready to back discriminatory laws. Nor was this a mere offshoot of the general xenophobia spawned by isolationism. Every synagogue in Washington Heights was desecrated (and some were smeared with swastikas); in Boston, beatings, wreckings and defilements had become near-daily occurrences by 1942. The disgraceful fever, which ruled out all but a trickle of immigration and so cost countless lives, reached its historic apogee in 1944 — by which time the Holocaust was more or less complete.

headline: Fame and Infamy
text: It could be said that Norman Mailer was a man and a writer halfway between fame and infamy and yet with little in the way of middle ground. He was, in varying combinations, a world-class drinker, feuder, provocateur, self-mythologizer and anti-feminist. He was a war protester, a mayoral candidate, a co-founder of The Village Voice, as well as a wife stabber, a serial husband (of six wives), and a father (of nine). He was a boxer, an actor, a filmmaker, a poet and a playwright. He was also a journalist and a novelist of enormous and singular narrative inventiveness and thrust, a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, and one of the least boring and most tireless and tiresome public figures of the last half of the 20th century.

headline: With Mall Reopened, Tourists Return
text: WASHINGTON — The National Mall hummed back to life on Thursday as National Park Service employees carted away barricades, skimmed debris from fountains and passed lawnmowers over neglected grass.

headline: The Dakota’s Cousins and How They Grew
text: Oh, the Dakota this, the Dakota that. Sometimes it’s as if the Dakota were the only apartment building in New York!

headline: Have I Got a Movie for You
text: For anyone interested in Hollywood deal-making, James Toback’s documentary “Seduced and Abandoned” provides the vicarious thrill of being at the table. You listen as financial movers and shakers coldly calculate the box-office potential of a project half-jokingly pitched by Mr. Toback and his sidekick, Alec Baldwin, as “Last Tango in Tikrit.”

headline: After 15 Years, Still a Mix of Dance and Dare
text: During the first half of the Silk Road Ensemble’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, the audience behaved impeccably. Its members assumed what George Bernard Shaw would have called their “churchiest expression” and held back applause until the end of each work. Then came Shane Shanahan’s percussion solo in Giovanni Sollima’s “Taranta Project.”

headline: Jaded, Maybe, but Not Ready for Vegas
text: The problems with “Paradise,” Diablo Cody’s first directing effort and fourth produced screenplay, begin almost immediately as its damaged heroine, the ickily named Lamb (Julianne Hough), sits on a beach and — in singularly annoying voice-over — catches us up on her life so far. This cheap trick might help Ms. Cody avoid actually showing us things, but it doesn’t bode well for what’s to come.

headline: Into a Galaxy of New Pieces, Jittery to Enigmatic
text: The San Francisco Ballet, led by the artistic director Helgi Tomasson, is a national treasure, prized for its dancers along with its fervent insistence on commissioning new ballets. For its first visit to New York in five years, the company’s two-week season showcases four mixed-bill programs, a rarity in a time when story ballets sell. (There is one scheduled, but it’s not the same-old: the New York premiere of Christopher Wheeldon’s “Cinderella” is next week.)

headline: New York Soda Ban to Go Before State’s Top Court
text: The battle over big sodas is not yet finished.

headline: In Store | L.A.-Made Handbags That Feel Right at Home in New York
text: The leather goods designer and retailer Clare Vivier is one of the most prominent ambassadors of the new Los Angeles fashion scene. Yet her bags are especially well suited to the demands of life in New York. The line, recently rebranded as Clare V., is polished enough for a party, but not too precious for the subway — auxiliary pouches and pockets cleverly accommodate gadgets or spare pairs of shoes. “New York is full of working women who want to look chic while being prepared for all sorts of situations,” Vivier said. Those women can now find the entire Clare V. range at the brand’s second boutique and first East Coast outpost, which opens tonight in a former dressmaker’s shop on Elizabeth Street in NoLIta. Walking into the space feels like being transported to California, thanks to its airy, light-flooded interior (by the L.A.-based architect Barbara Bestor, who also designed Vivier’s Silver Lake flagship) and its mostly SoCal-sourced lifestyle goods (jewelry by Annie Costello Brown, hats by Westbrook Maker, scented candles from the Chateau Marmont). Monograms, a Vivier signature, can be embossed on the spot. Also on view, and worth a visit in its own right, is a colorful nine-foot-wide collage wall by the New York florist and artist Simone Shubuck, a close friend of Vivier’s for 20 years.

headline: Reopening Is Hit-and-Miss in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — Government workers streamed into the John C. Kluczynski Federal Building in downtown Chicago on Thursday morning. Many of them, clutching takeout coffee, said they were late for their first day back and expected a daunting backlog of work.

headline: Oil Companies Are Sued for Waste of Natural Gas
text: HOUSTON — In the sharpest challenge yet to the surge in flaring of natural gas in the Bakken shale oil field, North Dakota mineral owners this week filed 10 class-action lawsuits seeking millions of dollars in lost royalties from some of the nation’s largest oil companies.

headline: A Boundless Appetite for a Universe of Sound
text: After a remarkable trilogy of concert films with Neil Young, the latest music documentary from Jonathan Demme, “Enzo Avitabile Music Life,” turns the spotlight on the mushier notion of world music. Not that the sounds of all nations gathered by the Neapolitan musician and groove ambassador Enzo Avitabile, the film’s focus, don’t have soul. But the fuzziness of Mr. Avitabile’s sentiments on boundary-blind unity is echoed in the movie’s slack, tag-along portraiture.

headline: Where Even the Peaches Are Charred
text: Oak + Almond may be an offbeat name for a restaurant, but its location is familiar to many: next to the Department of Motor Vehicles in Norwalk, at the Wilton border. The owners, Jon Paul Pirraglia and his sister Johanna Gannon, worked at the Tuscan Oven, which their parents ran for years at the same site.

headline: A Gene That Doesn’t Recede
text: With a cocked eyebrow and a sly grin that with a slight curl of a lip can turn into a nasty scowl, Danny Huston portrays Jack Hussar, a reasonable facsimile of his father, the famed director John Huston, in “2 Jacks.” Depending on your perspective, this satirical comedy about Hollywood nepotism and wheeling and dealing, adapted from Leo Tolstoy’s early short novel “Two Hussars,” is either a son’s revenge or a tribute.

headline: What I Love | Deepak Chopra
text: Deepak Chopra’s Midtown West apartment is as much a tribute to his cultural heritage as it is an expression of his spiritual beliefs.

headline: Deepak Chopra: An ‘Inner Stillness,’ Even on the Subway
text: Deepak Chopra, the controversial New Age guru and booster of alternative medicine, lives just below the penthouse on the 69th floor of a Midtown West condominium. The long elevator ride gives fellow residents like P. Diddy abundant opportunity to buttonhole the good doctor and seek guidance about their mantra and yoga issues. Sometimes, the encounter even results in a house call. “They invite me for a cocktail or to teach them meditation and I go,” said Dr. Chopra, an internist by training. “What the heck.”

headline: A Zest for Peril and Playfulness
text: Whatever the economic challenges facing classical music, there is no shortage of superb young artists eager to enter the field. In recent years, the Ebène Quartet, comprising four young men based in Paris, emerged as the most exciting new string quartet to come out of France. Now another Paris-based ensemble, the Hermès Quartet, is ready to take its place in the new generation.

headline: Where Love Coexists With Death
text: Rocky Braat, a few years into his career as a graphic designer, quit to seek authenticity (his word) by traveling to India, as so many young Americans have done before him. But his jaunt is different. After a chance stop to visit a home for children with H.I.V., he decided to stay. What compels him to remain there, working at the home, today?

headline: Nuggets of Frontier Greed and Justice
text: The Discovery Channel is teaching a pretty good lesson in money’s power to make human beings behave badly, with a four-part documentary about the California gold rush called “Gold Fever.” In recounting the story of that mid-1800s stampede westward in search of quick wealth, the program serves up one historical tidbit after another that seems like an allegory about the toll greed takes.

headline: Europe Moves to Shield Citizens’ Data
text: BRUSSELS — Lawmakers here have introduced a measure in the European Parliament that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking private data.

headline: Two Challengers to Chardonnay
text: Pinot blanc and viognier, grapes that flourish in Europe, play minor roles in Long Island vineyards. Both yield food-friendly, dry whites that harmonize especially well with fish and shellfish from the region’s waters.

headline: Boston Tourists Make Up for Lost Time
text: BOSTON — For the first time in 16 days, tourists on Thursday spilled into the Charlestown Navy Yard, the national historic park that contains the U.S.S. Constitution, the world’s oldest commissioned warship that is still afloat.

headline: A Day in the Life of a Ghost
text: Call it one kind of hell on earth: In “Haunter,” 15-year-old Lisa is the only member of her Reagan-era suburban family who realizes that they are reliving the same day, over and over. Yet, unlike Bill Murray’s weatherman in “Groundhog Day,” they are absolutely, positively dead. And the lingering menace in this serviceable ghost story from the director Vincenzo Natali and the screenwriter Brian King is that things could actually get worse.

headline: Executing Italian Civilians Was ‘Terrible’ for Executioners, Nazi Said Before Death
text: As officials in Italy continue to search for a solution to the problem of where to bury the body of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who died in Rome last week under house arrest, the voice of the unrepentant Nazi was heard in a video interview released on Thursday by his lawyer.

headline: In Key Races, No Sure Thing on G.O.P. End
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Comedy Listings for Oct. 18-24
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: ‘Modern Art and the Metropolis’
text: A look at an exhibition of works by the French modernist Fernand Léger, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: University of Illinois Acquires Gwendolyn Brooks Archives
text: The University of Illinois Rare Book and Manuscript Library has acquired the archives of the poet Gwendolyn Brooks.

headline: Take It, and Run With It
text: The question isn’t whether “The Birthday Boys” is funny. The question is whether you can stand any more sketch comedy with a white male sensibility.

headline: The City as a Muse
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Fernand Léger show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art is not your typical single-star vehicle. Its title — “Léger: Modern Art and the Metropolis” — may feature only the big name of this French Modernist painter. But the show itself teems with so much work by other artists that it has the mood of a crowded, high-spirited, sometimes confusing reunion.

headline: Movie Listings for Oct. 18-24
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Only an Exterminator Can Save the World
text: Asking a bug, even a very large one, to carry your whole movie seems as if it ought to be against animal cruelty codes, but that’s just what “Big Ass Spider!” does. The makers of this humorless horror comedy seemed to think that the mere existence of a gigantic, humanity-threatening spider would be enough.

headline: Snowden Says He Took No Secret Files to Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, said in an extensive interview this month that he did not take any secret N.S.A. documents with him to Russia when he fled there in June, assuring that Russian intelligence officials could not get access to them.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 18-24
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: In New York, Looking Forward to a Paycheck
text: Office workers poured in and out of the imposing building at 26 Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan on Thursday morning. Some had been deemed essential and had worked through the shutdown, but others were eager to get back to the job – and start being paid again.

headline: A Crushed Spirit, Healed by the Whispers of Angels
text: “There.”

headline: A New Line | Whimsical Objects, Imported From the Island of Hydra Straight to Fifth Avenue
text: Beginning today, a 10-piece collection of jewelry by the Greek designer Elena Votsi, who has stores in Athens and Hydra (where the pieces are made), will be available for the first time stateside at Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue. In the short film above, “A Day in Hydra with Elena Votsi,” the artisan, who designed the medal for the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, discusses her own history and design inspiration for the rings, necklaces and earrings that she likens to objects, like “toys,” that can be as fun alone as they are on the body. It’s no wonder, then, that included among her selection of work at Bergdorf Goodman is a gold ball ring that resembles a baby’s rattle and a gold-and-diamond ring that looks like a wound-up ribbon, which in Greek culture is a symbol for everything from athletics to marriage. “Even from a very young age I loved Greek history,” said Votsi, who discusses her Hydra roots in the video, which was produced by LoveGold, an online community dedicated to gold jewelry.

headline: An American Adrift in Hong Kong
text: The conventions are trundled out in Stanley J. Orzel’s cross-cultural romance, “Lost for Words,” but not the tension or the chemistry. Sean Faris, resembling a very poor man’s Ethan Hawke, plays Michael Vance, a former Marine who has been hired by the information technology department of a company in Hong Kong. Michael is despondent, having been dumped by his girlfriend stateside, until he meets a dancer, Anna Zhou (the gorgeous if opaque Grace Huang, assaying a woefully underdrawn character). How do they meet? He bumps into her as he arrives at the airport and as he jogs in a park.

headline: Jazz Listings for Oct. 18-24
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Love, in Its Guises, Rebounding
text: One thing is certain about David Dorfman’s “Come, and Back Again”: the show has heart. This hourlong dance production, which made its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater on Wednesday, features monologues about love and grandmothers. It has video projections of the heart shapes found on the stationery of young girls. I’ve never seen a show with more hugging.

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 18-24
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Fiorano Wine Estate in Italy Making a Comeback
text: ROME — A fresh breeze was blowing in from the Mediterranean to the west, clearing the air here at the Fiorano estate on a brilliant day this month. The harvest was in, the grapes had been crushed and the juice was settling in concrete tanks in the newly constructed winery, beginning the slow process of fermentation.

headline: Paint It Noir
text: Displaying a near-smothering fascination with 1940s noir, “Cut to Black” is a mildly engaging lowlife odyssey that struggles not to choke on its own style.

text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Two Mothers, Divided by Their Sons
text: Subdued in mood and palette, “Torn” sensitively explores the aftermath of a mall bombing through the eyes of two mothers who each lost a teenage son in the explosion.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 18-24
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: ‘A Girl Without Wings’
