text: Taymour Grahne Gallery

headline: Nick Hornby: ‘Sculpture (1504-2013)’
text: Churner and Churner

headline: Making Cities Work for People
text: “It seems like you’re at a tipping point between becoming L.A. or becoming Copenhagen,” the narrator of “The Human Scale” says to an urban planner for Christchurch, New Zealand, a city rebuilding from an earthquake in 2011.

headline: ‘Burying the Lede: News as Art’
text: Momenta Art

headline: Lucas Blalock: ‘Id, Ed, Ad, Od’
text: Ramiken Crucible

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 18-24
text: Harvest Fairs (Friday through Sunday) With Halloween less than two weeks away, pumpkin fever is high at the city’s parks, gardens and farms. On Saturday a Halloween Harvest Festival at Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens will include costumed canines competing (at 1 p.m.) for the grand prize of a visit to a doggy spa.  There will also be events for humans, including a performance of spooky tales by the Variations Theater Group. From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. (rain or shine), 32-01 Vernon Boulevard, at Broadway, Long Island City, (718) 956-1819, socratessculpturepark.org; free.

headline: Karl Wirsum
text: Derek Eller

headline: Paola Pivi: ‘Ok, you are better than me, so what?’; ‘Audible Presence’
text: Galerie Perrotin

headline: ‘Mike Kelley’
text: Images from the new show at MoMA PS 1.

headline: Trying to Keep Religion Out of the Charter School Classroom
text: SAN ANTONIO — At the Eleanor Kolitz Hebrew Language Academy, a fifth-grade foreign-language class is taught entirely in Hebrew, with students shifting into English only long enough to translate words like “research” and “to overcome.” In middle school, these charter school students will take a class on Israeli culture. Officials say the class is in line with the state mandate that public schools teach about the culture of the country where the instructed language is spoken.

headline: This Show’s as Big as His Career
text: Plainly put, the Mike Kelley retrospective, fresh from Europe to MoMA PS1, knocks everything else in New York this fall right out of the ring. It’s immense, filling 40,000 square feet of gallery space, including a sub-basement boiler room. And it’s that extremely rare thing, a huge show that should be huge. Kelley earned this blowout; his work sustains it.

headline: Academic Suggests an Entrance Test for Beijing’s Migrant Workers
text: A suggestion from a professor at a prestigious Beijing university that the Chinese capital begin an examination process to screen the quality of migrants has touched off criticism in blogs and in the Chinese press. The recommendation from Wen Guowei, a professor and urban planning expert at Tsinghua University, highlighted some of the difficulties faced by China’s quickly growing cities and also the discrimination outsiders can face.

headline: A Promoter Finds a New Cause: God
text: In “I’m in Love With a Church Girl,” Jeff Atkins, the 37-year-old rapper better known as Ja Rule, plays Miles Montego, a drug dealer turned concert promoter. “He’s smart, he’s rich, and he’s good-looking,” audiences are instructed. Though not all of those qualities are obvious, Mr. Atkins plays the character with a perfunctory swagger.

headline: Sinning a Little to Defeat the Demons
text: The title “Hellbenders” refers to a Brooklyn-based group of interfaith ministers whose peculiar practice involves racking up sins. These are debauched exorcists on a suicide mission: misbehave enough to invite possession, then commit suicide, dragging the demon with them to the underworld.

headline: A Schizophrenic’s 15-Minute Fame
text: Every Monday, Marcelle Danan, a French art dealer in Los Angeles, picks up William Laga, an artist she represents. They buy canvases and paints, and then Mr. Laga creates: abstract maplike visions blending hues and textures. Since Mr. Laga is a schizophrenic whom Ms. Danan met on the street, “Mondays With William,” a spare, cleareyed documentary by Steve Beebe, starts out as a feel-good film about art’s power to reclaim lives but becomes a commentary on the homeless and the mentally ill among them.

headline: For Police Commissioner, the Next Mayor Will Have a Wide Array of Options
text: The topic came up late in the New York City mayoral debate, and the division could not have been clearer: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee, would seek to keep the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, if elected; his Democratic opponent, Bill de Blasio, would not.

headline: Debate Shows Power of Cities to Limit Reach of Drilling
text: DALLAS — Claudia and Ed Meyer do not want natural gas drilling near their West Dallas home or anywhere else in the city, for that matter.

headline: A Pizza Parlor’s Upscale Neighbor
text: Abeetza Next Door in Greenvale hews to a classic formula. We’ve all been to one of these Italian spots that combines a pizza parlor with a more upscale dining room behind or alongside it.

headline: Ah, Berlin, Home to Concerts With Phalluses
text: Based on stage shows in Berlin in 2010-11, “Peaches Does Herself” records a body-positive rock opera starring the happily raunchy, ditty-slinging singer of the title. The fan-friendly hit list spans electro thunks, guitar-riffing glam chants and even ballads as Peaches — an elfin figure at the center of yonic and phallic sets and costumes — moves from innocence to experience. It’s a mix of brash celebration and sexual-wilderness heartbreak.

headline: Remembering Pillars of Israel’s Past
text: This month is the 40th anniversary of the 1973 war between Egypt and Israel, and the analysis of that conflict continues to this day. The war is one of many challenges to the fledgling state of Israel examined in “The Prime Ministers: The Pioneers,” a vivid insider’s perspective based on Yehuda Avner’s memoir.

headline: The Last King of Ireland
text: DUBLIN — Oscar Wilde still lounges, louche-like, on a boulder in Merrion Square. As always, the Liffey, a river crossed by bridges named for playwrights and patriots, lumbers its way to the sea. Grafton Street is packed with moneyed pedestrians. But Irish ayes are missing.

headline: Storing Solar Energy
text: A new solar thermal plant in Arizona, called the Solana Generating Station, can store solar energy so it is available whenever it is needed.

headline: Behind Bars, Where Anything Goes
text: Is that political commentary lurking beneath the grunts and four-word sentences of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone?

headline: Chopping, Flipping and Feinting in Search of Lost Art
text: There was an amusing Saturday morning cartoon series in the early 2000s, “Jackie Chan Adventures,” in which the title hero traveled around the globe tracking down 12 magic talismans representing the Chinese zodiac. Mr. Chan’s latest movie, “Chinese Zodiac,” also concerns a worldwide hunt for astrological symbols, but despite its bigger budget and scale, it’s hardly as entertaining.

headline: Doubts Fall on Afghan Police as Kidnappers Exact Dire Price
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — The way Dr. Nisar Ahmed Barak sees it, he was robbed twice — and both times by law enforcement authorities.

headline: Expatriates on the Road, With a Dead Body
text: Like someone using a thin smile to hide a heavy heart, “The Taiwan Oyster” employs a comic veneer to camouflage a deep sense of melancholy. This is a film that holds tight to its sorrow while trying not to scare you away.

headline: Government Reopens After Shutdown
text: National parks, monuments, museums and federal agencies reopened on Thursday after a 16-day shutdown of the government.

headline: Action, Comedy and the Brisk Snap of Breaking Bones
text: Everybody loves a character with absolute confidence, peerless skill and unshakable cool. The square-jawed gangster known as Boss (the undeniably appealing Akshay Kumar) is that kind of guy. He knows he can win any fight, and there are plenty for him in Anthony D’Souza’s “Boss” — in the marketplace, at the multiplex, in the desert. Between lethal kicks, as he easily dispatches 10 or 12 tough guys, Boss — whose agility is beyond Olympian — does a few dance steps and smiles. This is a man who prefers to fight to music, which is good, because sometimes that drowns out the sounds of all those necks being snapped.

headline: Lingering Confusion in Debt Ceiling Deal’s Temporary Fix
text: WASHINGTON — DID Congress just kill the debt ceiling?

headline: Those Hazardous Flying Birds
text: WHEN a US Airways jet leaving Reagan National for New York struck birds as it took off, it had to return to Washington. A JetBlue flight departing from Westchester County Airport was rerouted after colliding with birds. Ditto for another JetBlue flight leaving Kennedy Airport.

headline: Security Council Elects 5 New Members
text: Chad, Chile, Lithuania, Nigeria and Saudi Arabia were elected Thursday to seats on the 15-member United Nations Security Council for two-year terms starting in January. It was the first time that Saudi Arabia had sought to gain one of the nonpermanent seats on the Council; its decision to vie for a seat appeared to reflect the kingdom’s wish to be more assertive in resolving the Syria war and the Arab-Israeli conflict. The Saudis, who support the rebellion seeking the ouster of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, have criticized the Council over what they regard as its insufficient response to the turmoil in the Middle East. Last month the Saudi foreign minister canceled his General Assembly speech, apparently to show the Saudis’ displeasure. The new Council members replace Azerbaijan, Guatemala, Morocco, Pakistan and Togo.

headline: Israel: Palestinian Is Killed at Army Base
text: Israeli soldiers on Thursday fatally shot a Palestinian man who drove a construction vehicle into an army base near Ramallah in the West Bank, barging through a gate and repeatedly trying to run over a soldier, the Israeli military said in a statement. The official Palestinian news agency Wafa identified the man as Yunis Radeideh, 30. In two attacks in July 2008, Palestinians driving construction vehicles in central Jerusalem were shot and killed after plowing into traffic and pedestrians, killing three Israelis. In March 2009, the Palestinian driver of an earthmover flipped over an Israeli police car, wounding two police officers before he was shot dead. According to initial reports, the driver in that episode, Marei al-Radeideh, was a brother of the driver killed at the army base on Thursday.

headline: Rivers’s Move Brings Power, and Scrutiny
text: LOS ANGELES — On the wall of Doc Rivers’s new office inside the Los Angeles Clippers’ practice center are keepsakes more reflecting a diversity of interest than a tribute to his cherished vocation. For example: behind his desk hangs a signed picture of Muhammad Ali.

headline: Small Plates, and a Taste of Many Cultures
text: Mistral, the restaurant that Scott Anderson and his business partner, Stephen Distler, opened in May, only solidifies the dazzling reputation that Mr. Anderson established at Elements, the other notable Princeton restaurant that he and Mr. Distler own. The new ingredient is Ben Nerenhausen, the talented chef they lured from the Restaurant at Meadowood in St. Helena, Calif., which has three Michelin stars.

headline: Blood and Screams, Before the Show Starts
text: THE tone of Halloween marketing typically takes its cue from the national mood. The more scary the real world seems, for instance during and right after the financial crisis, the less scary Halloween ads are. Conversely, when consumers are upbeat, Madison Avenue produces ads that favor the frightful.

headline: Court Rules on ‘Stand Your Ground’ Costs
text: SEATTLE — A state appeals court here in Washington, in a major ruling on the “stand your ground” debate over personal safety, said Thursday that a defendant who successfully uses a self-defense claim is entitled to reimbursement for lost wages and other costs, as well as legal fees.

headline: The Damage Done
text: The government is reopening, and we didn’t default on our debt. Happy days are here again, right?

headline: Rev. John Grange, Who Welcomed Bronx’s Latinos, Dies at 73
text: The Rev. John Grange, a Spanish-speaking son of Irish-Americans who helped rebuild the impoverished South Bronx parish where he was raised into a more hospitable and promising place for Hispanic immigrants to New York City, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 73.

headline: Crisis Over, Everyone Back to Work
text: To the Editor:

headline: How God Is Real for Some, but Not for Others
text: To the Editor:

headline: Benefits of Charter Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: More American Jewish Students Take Up Study of the Arab World
text: Miriam Berger studied Arabic at Wesleyan University, lived twice as a student in Jordan, did thesis research in the West Bank and, after graduation, worked in Cairo. And like many of the Americans she has met each step of the way, she is Jewish.

headline: Anger Across Europe
text: To the Editor:

headline: Haunted Houses in High Definition
text: Every year around this time it seems fitting to give thanks to horror-movie fans, whose willingness to support their genre of choice by actually laying cash on the line is substantially responsible for keeping a lot of studio library divisions and independent video companies in operation. This Halloween, the seasonal offerings include some big-ticket gift sets, like “Chucky: The Complete Collection,” an anthology of all six films in the “Child’s Play” series (Universal; Blu-ray, $84.98; DVD, $59.88; not rated), and “Friday the 13th: The Complete Collection,” which offers Blu-ray editions of 12 films in that slasher franchise, from the original 1980 “Friday the 13th” directed by Sean S. Cunningham to its 2009 remake-reboot directed by Marcus Nispel — in effect, closing the circle (Warner Home Video; $129.95; R).

headline: Erdogan, Syrian Rebels’ Leading Ally, Hesitates
text: ISTANBUL — From the start of Syria’s civil war, rebels fighting President Bashar al-Assad have had no better ally than Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. He has effectively kept Turkey’s border with Syria open, allowing fighters a haven in the south of his country as weapons, cash and other supplies have flowed to the battlefield.

headline: At 19, Jameis Winston is a Quick Learner and a Decisive Leader
text: First-year college quarterbacks typically hesitate with both their throws and their words. It is rookie indecision, the thing that holds them back for a moment from firing a ball through a closing window in the defense or makes them recoil before responding to questions about keeping their cool in front of a heckling crowd.

headline: Settlement for a Shackled Pregnant Woman
text: A detained Mexican woman who had been shackled to her hospital bed while giving birth in Nashville will receive $490,000 in a settlement and also has the prospect of a resident visa.

headline: Questions Surround Mt. Everest Tragedy
text: The deadly avalanche by Mount Everest hit around 5 a.m., when the trekkers were asleep at camp. It was Monday, near the end of the weeklong trek, and the four Australian tourists and the Tibetans accompanying them were on their way back to the trailhead village by the mountain’s east flank. Of the 10 people in the party, one Australian and three Tibetans died. A Chinese news report identified the dead Australian as Kenneth Dean Higgins, age 60, but did not name the Tibetans.

headline: ‘No One Wants to Be There’
text: Nolan Conway photographs unlucky drivers whose cars have been towed to the Manhattan pound on Pier 76.

headline: Common Interests, Not Confrontation
text: When a few dozen Republican pragmatists in the Senate finally roused themselves and stood up to the Tea Party this week, the budget crisis quickly came to an end. Now it’s time for them to lead their party to accept the challenge President Obama issued on Thursday and permanently change the way Congress does business. Confrontational tactics failed the Republicans when Mr. Obama stood up to their demands, but rational negotiations — on ways to promote the public interest, not the agenda of interest groups — can still succeed.

headline: Suspect Recalls the Short Life of ‘Baby Hope’
text: Anjélica Castillo liked to ask questions. She was chatty and a little headstrong for a 4-year-old.

headline: At Day Care for Dogs, a Surprise: Choke Collars That Can Kill
text: To begin with, the Bryants are not suing.

headline: Many Ex-Players May Be Ineligible for Payment in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
text: When the N.F.L. agreed to pay $765 million to settle a lawsuit brought by 4,500 retired players who said the league hid from them the long-term impact of concussions, lawyers in the case said all retirees would be eligible for a share of the settlement.

headline: White House Weighs Easing Iran Sanctions’ Bite With Slow Release of Assets
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, in the wake of a promising first round of nuclear diplomacy with Iran, is weighing a proposal to ease the pain of sanctions on Tehran by offering it access to billions of dollars in frozen funds if the Iranian government takes specific steps to curb its nuclear program, a senior administration official said Thursday.

headline: A Thaw in Geneva?
text: Talks in Geneva this week have reinforced the hope that Iran and the major powers — the United States, Britain, Russia, France, Germany and China — may finally be serious about resolving the long-running dispute over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Scapegoating the Roma, Again
text: The Roma, sometimes called Gypsies, have been part of the European cultural landscape for centuries. They have also suffered greatly from discrimination and prejudice, particularly in times of economic crisis, when they become scapegoats.

headline: Jury Issues Overshadow Testimony in Fraud Case
text: The second day of the fraud trial concerning New York City’s ill-fated payroll modernization project started much as it had on the first day: with the unusual  scrutiny of a juror.

headline: Shooting History: Additions Required
text: “One of the hardest things to figure out is when you’ve really finished a film, when to say stop,” the director Jehane Noujaim said.

headline: Napoli Breaks Detroit’s Starters
text: DETROIT — It takes a lot to awe a hitter with almost 450 career home runs. But when you crush a ball the way Mike Napoli did Thursday night at Comerica Park, even the greats envy you.

headline: From the Right, Despair, Anger and Disillusion
text: CLEVELAND, Tenn. — “The premise was good,” said Bob McIntire, 53, an insurance executive here in deep red Bradley County, where the local Democrats would have trouble filling up a phone booth.

headline: Police Say Shoplifters Had Fetus in Bag
text: When a guard at a Victoria’s Secret in Herald Square stopped two teenage girls on Thursday afternoon, he discovered some stolen items in their possession, but — tipped off by a strong odor — also something far more heinous, the police said.

headline: Hopeful City, Buoyed by Campaign Vows, Waits for Change in Iran
text: TEHRAN — During his presidential election campaign, Hassan Rouhani excited Iranians’ expectations by promising to get suffocating Western sanctions lifted and revive the economy while increasing personal freedoms: opening up access to the Internet and taking the much-hated morality police off the streets, among other things.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Oct. 17
This Week's Movies: Oct. 17, 2013
text: The New York Times film critics on "Carrie," "All Is Lost" and "12 Years a Slave."

headline: After Man Survives Hanging, Iran Plans a Second Attempt
text: Death penalty opponents pleaded with Iran on Thursday to spare a convicted drug felon who survived a hanging and was sent from the morgue to a hospital to recuperate so he could be rehanged. It appeared to be the first time that the judicial authorities in Iran, one of the world’s top users of the death penalty, twice ordered a hanging carried out.

headline: William F. Niehous, Survivor of Abduction in Venezuela, Dies at 82
text: William F. Niehous, an American businessman from Ohio, had been given up for dead by almost everyone but his family when he emerged from the Venezuelan jungle on June 30, 1979 — gaunt, bearded and longhaired as a hermit — three years, four months and two days after being kidnapped by leftist guerrillas.

headline: Arizona Utility Tries Storing Solar Energy for Use in the Dark
text: When it snowed in Flagstaff, Ariz., recently, thousands of people woke up and turned up their electric heating, and Arizona Public Service saw electricity demand reach a morning peak. To meet the demand, the company used the previous afternoon’s sunshine.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 18, 2013
text: “It beats climbing the walls, wondering where your next paycheck is going to be and how you’re going to make your bills.”

headline: Two Parties Start Work to Avoid Repeat Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — With the government reopened and a debt default averted for now, Congressional negotiators on Thursday plunged into difficult budget talks to avoid a repeat crisis within months, and quickly agreed to lower their sights from the sort of grand bargain that has eluded the two parties for three years.

headline: A Year Abroad vs. a Year Wasted
text: The cost of college continues to rise. Meanwhile, there's growing pressure for U.S. students to study abroad. How important is this global experience?

headline: Corrections: October 18, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Shape Shifters
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Back in high school, I had a bad habit of falling asleep in my trigonometry class. It was not because the teacher was dull. Hindsight being 20/20, I now know that she was a lovely woman who tried her best to engage a bunch of adolescents in the mysteries of math.

headline: Father May Not Know Best
text: Much patience is demanded from the family of Arthur Winslow, the British patriarch waging a long battle to see that justice is properly served in “The Winslow Boy,” the 1946 play by Terence Rattigan that is being splendidly revived by the Roundabout Theater Company at the American Airlines Theater.

headline: The Ad Campaign: A Daughter Gets Her Turn
text: An advertisement featuring Bill de Blasio’s 16-year-old son, Dante, and his endearing Afro, helped push his father to victory in the Democratic primary. Now, with the general election a few weeks away, Mr. de Blasio is hoping to rekindle some of the family charm.

headline: New York Lawmaker Pushes Bill to Thwart Phone Theft
text: Smartphone theft has been a rising problem in many parts of the country, partly because of the devices’ high resale value. A top New York lawmaker thinks the solution is to go after the sellers who help make stealing phones so profitable.

headline: Grieving Father Finds an Outlet in His Music
text: Before last Dec. 14, Jimmy Greene had been a jazzman for most of his 38 years, well known among serious jazz fans. He had dozens of albums to his name. He played with such luminaries as Freddie Hubbard. He was a scholar, too, teaching jazz at a public university.

headline: A Simpler Family Tree?
text: A skull discovered in the Republic of Georgia may indicate that early species in the genus Homo are actually more closely related members of a single evolutionary lineage.

headline: In North Dakota, New Concerns Over Mixing Oil and Wheat
text: ROSS, N.D. — While three generations of the Sorenson family have made their livelihood growing wheat and other crops here, they also have learned to embrace the furious pace of North Dakota’s oil exploration. After all, oil money helped the Sorensons acquire the land and continue to farm it.

headline: A Literary Festival Means No Effrontery to Brooklyn
text: It’s not that the literarily inclined of Washington Heights in Manhattan begrudge Brooklyn all the attention being lavished upon its writers, artists, musicians, brownstones, outfits, bars, restaurants, flea markets, renegade craft shows and artisanal mayonnaise shops.

headline: Fusing Teams as Never Before
text: Shahid Khan, the owner of Fulham Football Club and the Jacksonville Jaguars, has plans to integrate his teams in ways no other owner has done.

headline: Owner of Jaguars and Fulham Seeks Football Fusion
text: LONDON — The mile-long walk from the Putney Bridge tube stop to Craven Cottage, the home of Fulham Football Club, is among the most scenic in English soccer. On game days, fathers and sons, young couples and hardened fans amble together through Bishop’s Park past rose bushes, stone sculptures and the Thames.

headline: Dominican Court’s Ruling on Citizenship Stirs Emotions in New York
text: Nina Paulino was born in the Dominican Republic. She loves her native country.

headline: Budget Gaps Between the Parties
text: How the deficit reduction proposals differ between the plans passed by the Senate and by the House earlier this year.

headline: Jets’ Top Pick Aims to Return to Field and to Form
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When the Jets selected Dee Milliner ninth over all in April’s draft with the hope that he would ultimately replace Darrelle Revis, a premier cornerback they had traded to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, General Manager John Idzik said he was “comfortable” with Milliner’s medical history.

headline: Building the Battle Room for ‘Ender’s Game’
text: A look at the creation of the battle room for “Ender’s Game,” which required a combination of digital and physical special effects and scrupulous attention to physics.

headline: China Reports a Modest Acceleration in Growth
text: HONG KONG — China’s economy expanded by 7.8 percent in the third quarter, compared with a year earlier, the government said on Friday, indicating a firming of economic activity after slower growth in the first part of the year.

headline: For Garnett and Pierce, New Uniforms Do Nothing to Ease Rivalry With Heat
text: LeBron James almost glowed Thursday while describing the battles he had fought against the Boston Celtics. The team was a persistent hurdle when he was rising to superstardom with the Cleveland Cavaliers. And the grappling continued when he took his title ambitions to Miami.

headline: The Biggest of the Smaller Breweries
text: A beer maker is considered a craft brewer if it produces six million barrels or fewer a year, and a noncraft brewer owns less than 25 percent of it.

headline: Free-Swinging Red Sox Near Strikeout Record
text: DETROIT — The Red Sox have had their triumphant moments in this American League Championship Series against Detroit for sure, but they have also looked foolish at times flailing at Detroit’s pitching.

headline: Placing Reality on Hold, at Least Temporarily, in a Ferrari FF
text: MONZA, Italy – It was Luca Cordero di Montezemolo, the urbane chairman of Ferrari, who suggested where driving one of his company’s fastest grand touring cars might carry me.

headline: Amid Heavy Pollution, Beijing Issues Emergency Rules to Protect Citizens
text: Snappily titled the Six Stops and One Wash, a new and complex string of regulations by the Beijing city government is aimed at combating the effects of persistent, heavy air pollution on the populace. A major rule will take private vehicles off the roads on alternate days, depending on their license plates, when pollution is especially bad.

headline: In Antwerp, a Derelict House With a Squatter Turns Into a Graceful Estate
text: The Belgian architect Vincent Van Duysen is known for rigorous, spare design that retains a sense of life. Captivated by a once-stately house in Antwerp, he distilled it to its elements — and made it his home.

headline: Inside a Fifth Avenue Pied-à-Terre, an 18th-Century European Palace
text: With a storied imagination, a collector’s passion and an obsessive attention to detail, Howard Slatkin has created a one-of-a kind Fifth Avenue aerie in which every doorknob, tile and 19th-century silk lampshade was designed by him.

headline: Inside the Many Houses of Not Vital, Maker of Dreamscapes for Adults
text: Painter, sculptor, house builder, designer, explorer, philanthropist, bon vivant — the Swiss artist Not Vital sees the universe in his own singular and most elegant way.

headline: Game-Changing Investments for the U.S.

Susan Lund is a partner at McKinsey & Company and the McKinsey Global Institute based in Washington.

headline: Ad Assails M.L.B. in Rodriguez Case
text: Hispanics Across America, the group that has organized boisterous shows of support for Alex Rodriguez outside the Park Avenue office building where he is contesting his 211-game drug suspension, has placed a full-page advertisement in The New York Times asking for fair treatment for the Yankees’ third baseman. The advertisement also attacks what it terms the double standard of Major League Baseball in seeking such a large punishment for Rodriguez, and singles out Commissioner Bud Selig for harsh criticism.

headline: Red Sox One Win Away After Beating Sanchez
text: DETROIT — It was a best-of-three now, the American League Championship Series, and it was supposed to only get tougher for the Boston Red Sox. The Detroit Tigers could send out Anibal Sanchez, Max Scherzer and Justin Verlander. Against them, the Red Sox had seemed helpless while their own rotation had been hit or miss.

headline: At Al Smith Dinner, Colbert Doesn’t Spare Politicians
text: When the comedian Stephen Colbert took to the dais on Thursday for his keynote speech at the Al Smith white-tie charity dinner, the annual gathering of New York’s Roman Catholic elite, he immediately flashed a sly glance at Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, sitting a few seats away.

headline: Full Text of the Oxford Consensus 2013
text: In August, at the Sixth Annual Forum for Chinese Theology on “Christian Faith and Ideological Trends in Contemporary China,” held at Oxford University, Chinese scholars representing a wide range of ideological backgrounds committed themselves to work together to address challenges facing China and the world.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 8 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR Clinton Kelly and Stacy London, far right and second from right, sign off after 10 seasons of tutoring fashion misfits in the art of personal presentation with this double bill, starting with a fan-mail special that divulges a few backstage secrets. Then, in the finale at 9, they crisscross the country to check on past subjects before heading to Las Vegas for an end-of-series blowout — and one last makeover.

headline: Q. and A.: Yang Fenggang on the ‘Oxford Consensus’ and Public Trust in China
text: In late August, two dozen Chinese public intellectuals from four of the country’s main ideological schools — Confucian, New Left, Liberal and Christian — met at Oxford University’s Wycliffe Hall to discuss their country’s problems. Remarkably, for a group of people who in Chinese public life are often at each other’s throats, they came up with what is now being dubbed the “Oxford Consensus” — four theses expressing their hopes for a pluralistic, liberal China.

headline: News Quiz | October 18, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Students in Southwest China Recruited to Assist Forced Demolition
text: It was the sort of internship best left off one’s résumé. College students in the southern Chinese city of Guiyang were recruited to serve as backup security during a forced demolition, The Beijing News reported on Friday.

headline: San Francisco Area Transit Strike Stymies Commuters
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Commuters here spent much of Friday scrambling for buses, ferries and car pools after transit workers for the Bay Area Rapid Transit system walked off the job for the second time in three months.

headline: China Reports a Modest Acceleration in Growth
text: HONG KONG — China’s economy steadied in the third quarter, expanding by 7.8 percent compared with a year earlier, the government said Friday, indicating that the economy has pulled out of a jittery period of slowed growth thanks to revived investment, consumer spending and factory production.

headline: In China, Escaping Pollution From Inside a Car
text: Automakers around the world have long been under heavy pressure to reduce tailpipe pollution, starting in the United States in the 1960s. But in China, the issue is cleaning up the already filthy outdoor air before it gets into the cars.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Oct. 18, 2013
text: Use this question to test your ability to edit a piece of writing.

text: The video above, along with the related article “Flying Close to the Law,” document a Brooklyn artist’s exhibition on cigar-smuggling pigeons.

headline: In Kenya Inquiry, Norway Looks at Somali Migrant
text: LARVIK, Norway — As a boy, the Somali immigrant sold newspapers door to door in this peaceful seaside Norwegian town and told neighbors he was going to be a doctor and help people in Africa.

headline: How Good Are You at Time Management?
text: Little children don’t have to worry about managing their time. Others manage it for them — steering them from playtime to naptime and back to more playing. But as we get older, we have more responsibilities. And one of the keys to success in high school and beyond is learning how to manage our limited time so we accomplish everything we need to get done.

headline: Side by Side, Battling Cancer and Sending Off the Bride
text: When I caught up with Nancy Borowick on Thursday morning, she was running around East Harlem shooting a neighborhood feature for AM New York, a free newspaper distributed in the subways. Earlier this week, she worked fund-raisers for a charter school and a humanitarian relief organization. She is 28, a freelance photographer, and often rises at 6 a.m. to call assignment editors at newspapers around the city looking for day work — a politician campaigning, a news conference by the mayor, a good perp walk.

headline: CMJ: Scenes From Day 3
text: The first and possibly last amusing thing about Hookworms, a band from Leeds, is its name. Hooks and catchiness (ohrwurm, which translates to “earworm,” is a German term for an all-too-catchy song) are extremely low priorities for a band that is built around Minimalist repetition, kinetic drones and an onslaught of guitars and keyboards. They do play what could loosely be called rock songs; Matt Johnson, the keyboardist, sometimes shrieks phrases that are probably English words, though they go through so much reverb and echo there’s rarely a chance of deciphering them. But Hookworms also spent part of their set, and their debut album “Pearl Mystic,” creating and sustaining noises that are deliberately amorphous: no beat, just resonance and distortion.

headline: Fashion at the Frieze Art Fair
text: Art is the centerpiece of this annual event in London, but the clothing worn by visitors can be just as memorable.

headline: New York Today: Murder Milestone

headline: Saudi Arabia Rejects U.N. Security Council Seat in Protest Move
text: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia stunned the United Nations and even some of its own diplomats on Friday by rejecting a highly coveted seat on the Security Council, a decision that underscored the depth of Saudi anger over what the monarchy sees as weak and conciliatory Western stances toward Syria and Iran, Saudi Arabia’s regional rival.

headline: A Stage on a Stage, and Reality in Illusion
text: LONDON — This year has been a battle of operatic bicentennials. In May, Wagner turned 200. Verdi did the same last week.

headline: Daily Report: Google Exceeds Earnings Estimates as Ad Prices Slip
text: For more than a decade, Google’s search advertising business has seemed almost magical in its ability to mint money. But the magic is beginning to wear off as people spend more time on mobile devices, where the company makes less money on ads, Claire Cain Miller reports.

headline: A Campus Marriage, Then Balancing Careers and Children
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: SAC May Become a Family Office
text: PLEA DEAL COULD END SAC’S ADVISORY BUSINESS  |  The hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is moving closer to a plea deal with prosecutors that would force it to wind down its business of managing money for outside investors, Ben Protess and Peter Lattman report in DealBook. An agreement to stop operating as an investment adviser is one feature of a larger deal SAC is negotiating over insider trading charges, according to people briefed on the case, who said the plea deal would also require SAC to plead guilty to criminal misconduct and pay more than $1 billion in penalties.

text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: HSBC to Appeal $2.46 Billion Judgment
text: LONDON — HSBC Group said Friday that it would appeal yet again a $2.46 billion judgment in a long-running securities fraud lawsuit in the United States related to a consumer-loan and credit-card business that the British bank acquired more than a decade ago.

headline: Popcast: Peering Through Katy Perry’s ‘Prism’
text: This week: the evolution and regression of Katy Perry.

headline: This Bubble Gum, Too, Shall Pop
text: In the video for “Roar,” the first single from Katy Perry’s new record “Prism,” Ms. Perry plays a young woman going native in the jungle after a plane crash, learning to live with wild animals. “I got the eye of the tiger,” she sings, borrowing a line from Survivor, “Louder than a lion.” In her performance of “Roar” at the recent MTV Video Music Awards, she played a boxer in a ring; that setup made sense of the song’s “I am the champion” line, borrowed from Queen.

headline: Facing a Pitiless Void
text: Having endured a summer of existential threats to the planet — zombie hordes, alien invaders, the usual stuff — moviegoers can now settle in for an autumn of more intimately scaled ordeals. Spectacles of collective apocalypse, the staple of the blockbuster economy, give way to individual stories of adversity and the struggle to survive in limited space. Superheroes step aside in favor of ordinary (albeit highly competent) people equipped with nerve, resourcefulness and impressive but not always reliable technology. Their archenemies are the laws of nature and political economy, abstract forces that take the form of lethal satellite debris, heavy weather and desperate pirates.

headline: Morgan Stanley, Under Gorman, Returns to Basics and Profit
text: Morgan Stanley surprised analysts on Friday with strong third-quarter results that relied on a back-to-basics approach.

headline: Sex, Love and the Teenage Star
text: “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” the three-hour romantic film directed by Abdellatif Kechiche, has drawn chatter for its long and explicit lesbian sex scenes, which accelerate the emotional awakening of its young protagonist, Adèle, played by the 19-year-old Adèle Exarchopoulos (pronounced ex-ar-KHOO-puh-lus). As she navigates young adulthood in northern France, Adèle struggles to steady herself while simultaneously confirming that few things in life are as devastating as first loves.

headline: Skills Practice | Using Storyboards to Inspire Close Reading
text: This week, the fifth in our new Skills Practice series, Jonathan Olsen shows how storyboarding might be used not just to help students plan presentations or writing, but also to encourage more careful reading.

headline: Keanu’s Excellent Directing Adventure
text: Keanu Reeves shuffled onto the terrace of a high-rise in the financial district of Manhattan, tossed a rumpled pack of American Spirit cigarettes and a half-eaten Clif Bar on the coffee table, and gingerly lowered himself onto the couch. Tall, with scruffy beard and mustache, he’d returned to this temporary home fresh from intense fight training for his next project, a thriller called “John Wick.” With wisps of gray visible in the long, dark brown hair, the 49-year-old Mr. Reeves called himself, multiple times, “a salty dog” of the film business, and if he’s embracing the real-life role of grizzled lifer, he’s also relishing the confidence that comes with experience.

headline: Off the Charts: In the Developed World, Industrial Production Stalls
text: Industrial production continues to rise in countries like India and China, but has stalled out in much of the developed world. In the United States, it is rising, but remains below the level reached in 2007.

headline: Factory Output Returns, but at Widely Different Rates
text: INDUSTRIAL production collapsed during the financial crisis, then rallied strongly when the crisis ended. But now, while production has continued to rise in Asian countries like India and China, it has stagnated in much of the world.

headline: Family Films of a Very Different Sort
text: Some people are troubled by contradictions — by impulses clashing with intentions, needs complicating wants, violence coexisting with compassion. The director Claire Denis thrives on such things. From her autobiographical debut in 1989, “Chocolat,” to modernist reveries like “Beau Travail” (1999) and “The Intruder” (2004), she has searched for sublimity in the profane and exploited the terror in ecstasy. And while she may be the most independent filmmaker in France, she is preoccupied with belonging, making films about family with the help of a surrogate family of collaborators.

headline: Electrical Grid Is Called Vulnerable to Power Shutdown
text: Over the past few months, the discoveries of two engineers have led to a steady trickle of alarms from the Department of Homeland Security concerning a threat to the nation’s power grid. Yet hardly anyone has noticed.

headline: At Gurney’s, Spa and Yoga Packages
text: Gurney’s Inn, the upscale resort and spa in Montauk, N.Y., set on 11 acres along the Atlantic Ocean, is trying to attract guests during its fall and winter off-season with two packages. With the Seawater Spa Getaway, available from Oct. 1 to Dec. 31, guests can book either one night for $449 a person, which includes $245 for spa treatments, or two nights for $799 a person, which includes $400 for treatments.

headline: Feeling For | Rarefied Fragrances, Now Available for the Home
text: Dawn and Samantha Goldworm, the twin founders of 12.29, have scented Rodarte’s runways and Poltrona Frau’s boutiques, but now their intoxicating fragrances can be enjoyed at home. Their aromatic pillars are enveloped in paper-thin, matte-white Limoges porcelain with a delicate pocked texture, designed by Studio Toogood to appear like lace when the candles — with romantic names like A Dark Affair and Forget Everything But Me — are lit.

headline: K.K.R. to Buy European Debt Investment Firm
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Friday that it planned to buy Avoca Capital, a European debt investment firm that oversees $8 billion in assets, in a bet that the Continent would offer attractive new opportunities.

headline: Dangerous Donations
text: LONDON — Muslims this week are celebrating  Id al-Adha, a religious holiday marking the end of the Hajj pilgrimage and commemorating Abraham’s obedience to God. Those who can afford to do so mark the occasion by sacrificing a goat, cow or camel.

headline: Pickup Soccer in Brazil Has an Allure All Its Own
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In Brazil, the ball is always moving. It moves on grass and on sand, on concrete and on cobblestone. Sometimes, during the rainy season, it even moves on water.

text: Driven by a passion to play, young Brazilians carve a soccer field from the side of a mountain by hand.

headline: Munro Will Miss Nobel Ceremony for Health Reasons
text: Alice Munro, the Canadian short-story writer who won the Nobel Prize in Literature last week, is unable to travel to Stockholm to accept her award because of health reasons, the administrators of the prize said on Friday. The ceremony is planned for Dec. 10. “No decision has yet been made about who will receive the Nobel Prize in Literature on her behalf,” a statement on NobelPrize.org said.

headline: Finding New Ways to Generate Sales Leads
text: Rachel Shlaferman is an independent Aflac agent who works for a district office in Marriottsville, Md. Every day, she makes at least 200 phone calls with the hope of getting one appointment.

headline: Baseball Cathedrals, From on High
text: The baseball diamond is instantly recognizable from above — green grass (even when it was artificial), distinct dirt and stands waiting to be filled.

headline: The Most Lethal Weapon Americans Faced in Iraq
text: In the first part of this series, At War explored the various conventional weapons used by insurgents in Iraq, as evidenced by reports, called “storyboards,” written by United States forces detailing the contents of captured weapons caches. Often times these weapons had been considered obsolete before 2003. But they were well known to Western intelligence services and militaries.

text: The silent dance of the dinner rush.

headline: The 10.6.13 Issue

headline: The Jean-Georges Kitchen From on High
text: While designing the kitchen at his namesake restaurant on Columbus Circle, Jean-Georges Vongerichten traded American efficiency for Old World tyranny. The five food stations, staffed by six cooks (two on fish) and one floating chef (a chef de tournant) are arranged perpendicular to the pass, which is where the food is handed off to the food runners (seen at the bottom of the page), all under the scrutiny of another chef, who runs the line. Typically, Vongerichten says, “you cook against the wall, turn around, plate it and it goes out.” At Jean-Georges, the staff members cook various elements at their stations and then walk them up to the pass — where they assemble the dishes with monastic precision. When your shrimp appetizer, being plated lower left by two cooks, comes with crispy baby artichokes, crispy mushrooms, smoked paprika gel, lemon fennel purée, microthyme and parsley, a more collaborative and focused effort is required. (Also: tweezers).

headline: The Knuckle-Curve
text: Batting First and Playing Left Field . . . Jim Gilliam

headline: Terry Lenzner on Tricky Dick and Dirty Tricks
text: You’ve been called one of the most dreaded private investigators in the world. What was it like to serve Nixon with a subpoena?  I did not think, when I started the investigation into the Watergate break-in, that it was going to reach anybody in the White House, at any level. I went into the investigation with a completely open mind. I wrote the subpoena myself. When I walked through the West Wing with it, people were saying, “Great work, Terry, keep it up.” I thought that was interesting.

headline: Annual Cavity Drive
text: Several dentists in our area offer to purchase candy during Halloween from their young patients for $1 per pound. Presumably they do this to reduce the risk to their patients of developing cavities. Unfortunately, the dentists then give the candy to the local food cupboard. There is little doubt that most (if not all) the clients who use the food cupboard can little afford proper dental care. I believe such behavior is thoughtless, unethical and unprofessional. I am a retired dentist. BILL BOWEN, ROCHESTER

headline: Kermit Lynch Knows the Terroir
text: For much of the last 35 years, the wine critic Robert Parker dominated the international wine scene. Parker invented the 100-point rating system for wine, and his reviews wielded such influence over sales that vintners everywhere worked to please Parker’s palate, making oaky, intensely flavored, high-alcohol wines. Kermit Lynch, meanwhile, through his wine shop in Berkeley, Calif., and also through his nationwide distribution business, chose to sell only French and Italian wines made in the unadulterated, old-school traditional style aimed at accentuating terroir — each vineyard’s unique combination of weather, soil and geography.

headline: Los Angeles: Goat-Stew City, U.S.A.
text: Everyone with Internet access is a critic, but some forms of amateur criticism have higher standing than others. Amateur literary critics, like Dylan Lucia, an Amazon reviewer who gave one star to “Fahrenheit 451” (“Bradbury is a good writer [I’ll give him that], but I HATE his writing style”), may lack a nuanced understanding of the English language; some amateur film critics, like the IMDB reviewer who gave 10 stars to “Wrath of the Titans” (“i never saw a movie this good before in my life”), may have never seen another movie before in their lives. But all of us with a tongue and a functioning digestive tract are authorities on food. After all, we have a commanding range of experience to draw from: we eat, according to one study, an average of 4.9 times a day. When it comes to food, everyone is not just a critic — everyone is a connoisseur.

headline: Washington’s Metaphor War
text: Plus: Child stars gone wild, the accidental selfie and how to be worldy.

headline: Who Made That Kale?
text: Scientists disagree about when humans first tasted kale. But it is known that the ancient Greeks cultivated leafy greens, which they boiled and ate as a cure for drunkenness. And early Roman manuscripts include references to “brassica,” a word that encompassed wild turnips, cabbages and kalelike plants. By the Middle Ages, kale had spread through Europe and Asia. The Italians developed plants with “dinosaur” scales, while the Scots created varietals with leaves like frilly petticoats. The Russians produced kale that could survive in the snow. But by the time Tim Peters, who was then farming in Oregon, began experimenting with the plant in the 1980s, kale had become “boring.” “You only saw the green kind in the supermarket,” he says, “if you could find it at all.”

headline: Sweet Home Cooking Alabama
text: Frank Stitt opened the Highlands Bar and Grill on a gritty street corner in Birmingham, Ala., in 1982, when most of the city’s elite still took its meals in country clubs and restaurant dining meant flambéed everything at the Hyatt downtown. His was a Southern cuisine married to French technique, which meant it was plain and simple as much as it was the exact opposite. Stitt, who was 28, intended the Highlands to evoke a classic worth-a-detour restaurant in a small European town, although transplanted to a fading American steel city.

headline: The Predawn Chowdown
text: After up to 10 hours of standing with virtually no breaks and no real nourishment, there are generally two options for a famished team of chefs, cooks, waiters, bussers, porters and everyone else it takes to run a restaurant.

headline: It’s Not What You Drink, It’s Where You Drink It
text: The best hotel, dive, cocktail, neighborhood and restaurant bars in New York City.

headline: The Strange Science of Creating a Perfect Bar
text: If I’ve gleaned anything from a lifetime of drinking in bars about what makes the great ones great, it’s that every detail matters: the pictures on the walls, the range of spirits offered, how customers are greeted, the volume at which music is played. And then there’s that metaphysical quality that’s hardest to capture and impossible to fabricate: something like what Romans called genius loci, the spirit of the place. It doesn’t really matter what kind of bar we’re dealing with: It either has it or not.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: Painter, sculptor, house builder, designer, explorer, philanthropist, bon vivant — the Swiss artist Not Vital sees the universe in his own singular and most elegant way.

headline: Heritage: Same As It Ever Was
text: Senator Orrin Hatch is unhappy with the Heritage Foundation, which he worries is becoming political and losing its “reputation”.

headline: Excerpts From Colbert's Speech
text: A few selected excerpts from Stephen Colbert's keynote address at the Al Smith dinner.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Carrie,’ ‘All Is Lost’ and ’12 Years a Slave’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the drama “12 Years a Slave,” “All Is Lost” and the horror remake “Carrie.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: 36 Hours in Cardiff, Wales
text: Tell a Londoner you are heading to Cardiff for the weekend and the response will probably be a quizzically arched eyebrow. The Welsh capital, which was largely built during Britain’s 19th-century coal boom, isn’t generally considered one of the country’s most attractive cities. But times are changing. Major regeneration projects since the 1990s — a new performing arts center, a revamped waterfront and a 74,000-seat stadium, to name a few — have given the city a fresh face. Don’t worry, though, Cardiff still has its edge: the punk rock scene is as vibrant as ever, and Welsh rugby fans have never cheered louder.

headline: From Castles to Concerts in Cardiff
text: Shuttle between the past and the present during a tour of the Welsh capital.

headline: Redefining the Next Policy Debate
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline:
U.S. Army Hones
Antiterror Strategy
for Africa, in Kansas
text: FORT RILEY, Kan. — Here on the Kansas plains, thousands of soldiers once bound for Iraq or Afghanistan are now gearing up for missions in Africa as part of a new Pentagon strategy to train and advise indigenous forces to tackle emerging terrorist threats and other security risks so that American forces do not have to.

headline: In Sickness and in Health: A Wedding in the Shadow of Cancer
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — Shortly after Nancy Borowick’s boyfriend got down on one knee and popped the question, she began to worry about the wedding. If everything had been normal, Ms. Borowick and her husband-to-be, Kyle Grimm, would have waited a year, until the spring of 2014. She’s 28, he’s 27 and they would have liked the extra time to build their careers and get used to living together. Ms. Borowick works as a freelance photographer and is often up by 6 a.m., calling newspaper photo desks around the city in hopes of getting an assignment. Mr. Grimm is a junior lawyer at a corporate firm who is already married, to his job.

headline: The China-Debt Syndrome
text: Matthew Yglesias notes an uptick in Very Serious People warning that China might lose confidence in America and start dumping our bonds. He focuses on China’s motives, which is useful. But the crucial point, which he touches on only briefly at the end, is that whatever China’s motives, the Chinese wouldn’t hurt us if they dumped our bonds — in fact, it would probably be good for America.

headline: Baseball Cathedrals, From on High
text: The National League Championship Series concludes this weekend at St. Louis’s Busch Stadium, now in its third iteration, and the American League Championship will run its course at Boston’s Fenway Park, the one and only. These stadiums, as well as many others, are where players have run the bases countless times, and where for years fans have root, root, rooted for their home teams.

headline: Dealing With a Client Who Calls and Calls and ...
text: A LOT of us are self-employed these days — whether by choice or necessity — and eager to attract as many clients as possible. And that sometimes means agreeing to work with people who are, to put it mildly, challenging.

headline: Africa’s First World Problems — and Opportunities
text: It won’t be long now before the horrors at Westgate Mall in Nairobi are out of the headlines and relegated to the annals of horrible terrorist attacks (and possibly intransigent police corruption and ineptitude).  Here in Rwanda, a nation that has, against the odds and prognosticators, moved farther beyond one of the greatest tragedies in recorded history, my friends and colleagues see Westgate as a wake-up call to start paying more, and different attention, to this part of our precarious world.

headline: Booking the Bets
text: By the time you read this, we’ll know the winner of the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature. Is it the Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami? Did the British bookmaker Ladbrokes accurately favor him as prizewinner? “I dare say, now the odds list is part of the story,” Alex Donohue, a Ladbrokes spokesman, told me in a phone interview. “It’s in the mix for how people assess the prize.”

headline: When to Decide if Your Child Needs Outside Help
text: How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond her years?

headline: Horror
text: LET THE OLD DREAMS DIEBy John Ajvide Lindqvist  Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s, $27.99.

headline: Inside the List
text: 11/22/63: As the 50th anniversary of the Kennedy assassination approaches, Americans remain divided on the big question: Who did it? According to an Associated Press-GfK poll conducted in April, 59 percent of the country believes in a conspiracy, while 24 percent accepts the Warren Commission’s conclusion that Lee Harvey Oswald acted alone. Another 16 percent isn’t sure. (Yes, that adds up to 99 percent. The rest probably blames President Obama.) The best-seller list reflects this split personality. “Killing Kennedy,” by Bill O’Reilly and Martin Dugard, echoes the Warren Report’s lone gunman thesis and has spent 34 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list; it’s currently on the extended list at No. 22. Meanwhile, a new case for conspiracy hits the nonfiction ­list at No. 14: “They Killed Our President,” by the renowned historian and investigative journalist Jesse (the Body) Ventura, who with Dick Russell and David Wayne argues the president was killed by “disgruntled C.I.A. agents, anti-Castro Cubans and members of the Mafia. . . . Members of the U.S. military were also involved.” Like the former professional wrestler he is, Ventura confronts his biggest rival head on. “Since Bill O’Reilly apparently thinks he knows so much about the J.F.K. assassination,” he writes, “I’d like to publicly challenge him. . . . How about a public debate? Let’s do it. Let’s set it up! I’ll be there, Bill.”

headline: Time’s Up
text: The temptation to read THE OCTOBER LIST (Grand Central, $26) backward — which is to say, forward — must be resisted, or you’ll hate yourself for spoiling what might well be Jeffery Deaver’s most fiendish thriller ever. Taking inspiration from Kierke­gaard (“Life can only be understood backward; but it must be lived forward”), the devious author begins his story with Chapter 36 and methodically works his way back to Chapter 1. Let’s admit that the prose is a bit flat, and the characters lack nuance, the unavoidable consequence of withholding key information about persons and motives until those last (first!) five chapters give it all up. The reader is never lied to in Deaver’s brilliant shell game, merely misdirected, and the best part of this trick is that despite being in on the game, we continue to make false assumptions.

headline: Without a Cue
text: Don Tillman doesn’t know he has Asperger’s syndrome, although his symptoms are obvious to friends and colleagues. He flinches from physical contact and cooks all his meals according to an unvarying schedule; his approach to courtship consists of handing women a detailed questionnaire to test their suitability.

headline: Community Groups Still Reeling After the Shutdown
text: The notices went out on Tuesday to dozens of homebound seniors in Antrim County, in the northwest corner of Michigan. Because of the government shutdown, aides that visit older adults in their homes would stop coming or reduce their hours significantly, effective immediately.

headline: Forged in Battle
text: Shortly after I moved to Jerusalem last spring, I made history as the first woman to play in a 30-year-old poker game, joining a group of graying, good-natured guys who had long ago immigrated from South Africa, England and the United States. It was just before Jerusalem Day, which celebrates Israel’s capture of the east side of the city — and the rest of the West Bank — from Jordan in 1967.

headline: Desperate Characters
text: The title of Emma Chapman’s first novel, “How to Be a Good Wife,” is beyond ironic. What we encounter here in Marta Bjornstad is a woman clinging to domesticity as though to a flimsy plank in a turbulent sea. Marta is going under, and the power of this extraordinary book resides in large part in its unwavering focus on her deepening dislocation from the world around her, from her adult son and in particular from her husband.

headline: A House of Her Own
text: In the late 19th century B.W.H. (Before Women’s History), a flourishing genre of books focused on the lives of women connected to great men of the Revolutionary era. The mother and wife of George Washington were particular favorites, along with the wives of such men as Alexander Hamilton and James Madison.

headline: Have Another
text: In so lovingly collecting and editing Flann O’Brien’s widely scattered and almost forgotten short fiction, Neil Murphy and Keith Hopper have done the study of Irish literature a great service. They’ve also done a lot of detective work; the man born Brian O’Nolan, in Strabane, in 1911, published secretively, under a string of pseudonyms, in two languages. Several of these pieces had never been republished.

headline: How He Won
text: Richard Wolffe’s account of the 2012 election is a fine ­behind-the-scenes campaign-trail book that makes me wonder about the future of behind-the-scenes campaign-trail books. It is a well-trod genre, more so now thanks to the runaway success of John Heilemann and Mark Halperin’s “Game Change,” about the 2008 campaign. “The Message,” Wolffe’s third on President Obama, is one more entrant in the field.

headline: Who Decided?
text: The Bush administration opened with a second Pearl Harbor, ended with a second Great Crash and contained a second Vietnam in the middle.

headline: Friendship, Hateship, Loveship, Manship
text: I wasn’t a quarter of the way through this 918-page T. C. Boyle collection before I started to worry about turning into a T. C. Boyle character myself. There’s a certain progression to many of these stories — a semi-normal person clinging to his sanity, if not his dignity, against a bruising series of misfortunes — that pretty much tracks my reading experience, too.

headline: Toyota to Recall 803,000 Vehicles for Air Bag Problem
text: UPDATED

headline: Twins City
text: It is always a pleasure to visit Kindle County, Scott Turow’s shadow version of greater Chicago, which he has been building and populating since he all but created the modern legal thriller in 1987 with “Presumed Innocent.” One of the many satisfactions of the string of assured and gripping novels since then has been returning to the county’s courtrooms and barrooms, catching glimpses of characters who were central to earlier works and hearing echoes of the compromises that marked them.

headline: Will Have Small Glass of Wine
text: Do we really want to hear about the ­middle-aged escapades of Bridget Jones, the tipsy, ditsy, formerly 30-ish heroine of two previous novels and two previous movies? Hapless, inept, prone to romantic calamity, lurching from one mishap to the next through a hazy fog of faux pas and cigarette smoke, Bridget was so specific to her age that allowing her to reach 51 feels like a violation of the natural order of the fictional universe, as if a new Harry Potter book had him using magic to refinance his mortgage.

headline: Price Drop: Save Millions
text: A look at some resale apartments in white-glove buildings where prices have dropped.

headline: May I Have a Price Check?
text: It’s the era of superlatives for trophy properties in Manhattan. Not a day seems to go by without a new contender for the largest, tallest or priciest.

headline: Crossing Paths Briefly, With Life-Altering Results
text: At every stage of his career, Isamu Noguchi had a knack for seeking out great mentors and collaborators: Brancusi, Buckminster Fuller, Martha Graham. A new show at the Noguchi Museum suggests that we should add to this formidable list the name of Qi Baishi, one of China’s most respected modern ink painters.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SHE MATTERS: A Life in Friendships,  by Susanna Sonnenberg. (Scribner, $16.) The mentor, the little sister, the confidante, the rival. Sonnenberg’s redemptive memoir captures the fervor of women’s friendships, reflecting on the companions who populated her childhood and adolescence, as well as those who have left their mark on her adult selves as writer, mother and wife.

headline: Out of All the Gin Joints in New York, I Had to Pick Five?
text: I lost some sleep after thinking about bars I love, across different categories, for my article in this week’s Food & Drink Issue of the magazine. I was limited to choosing one favorite in each of five categories: cocktail bar, dive bar, hotel bar, neighborhood bar and restaurant bar. I knew I couldn’t write about bars I’ve written about before, either in the magazine or elsewhere (Milano’s is an exception, but then, it is an exceptional kind of place). And I tried not to pick the most obvious choices, at least to me, in every category. But as I whittled my long list down to a short one, there were a few runners-up I was particularly bereft not to be able to include, so I will give them their due here:

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE GOLDFINCH,  by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown, $30.) The “Goldfinch” of the title of Tartt’s smartly written Dickensian novel is a painting smuggled through the early years of a boy’s life — his prize, his guilt and his burden.

headline: The Year of Serena Williams
text: A professional since 1995 and a Grand Slam champion since 1998, Serena Williams has still managed to break new ground in 2013.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Donna Tartt, Helen Fielding and Jill Lepore
text: This week, Donna Tartt talks about “The Goldfinch”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Helen Fielding discusses “Bridget Jones: Mad About the Boy”; Jill Lepore on “Book of Ages,” about Benjamin Franklin’s sister Jane; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Britain Looks to Fracking as North Sea Oil Dwindles
text: BARTON, England — Driving down a bumpy country road in northwest England, one comes upon a bare patch the size of a soccer field at the edge of a peat bog. Workers are erecting a security fence and unrolling watertight film to protect the soil from chemical contamination. Near the middle is a big rectangular hole where a drilling rig will go.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review
text: This week, Donna Tartt, Helen Fielding and Jill Lepore.

headline: With Giving Season in Full Force, Seeking to Understand Donors
text: WE have entered giving season. This is the time of year when charities increase their outreach to donors who traditionally wait to the fourth quarter to make annual gifts. And what would this season be without research into the state of our giving habits?

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack International Convoy in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the first major attack in Kabul since July, insurgents struck at an international convoy on Friday as it passed a heavily fortified residential compound, killing at least two Afghans who were in the area and wounding at least four others, officials said.

headline: Is the Health Care Fight Over?
text: Leading up to the crisis in Washington, the right-wing of the right-wing party stressed that blocking the continuing resolution was essential because it represented the last, best chance to stop the Affordable Care Act. “Last, best chance” was actually a mantra of sorts. “This is our last chance and our last best chance to do something about this,” said Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, on the Senate floor in late July. “[T]his may be the last best chance to defund Obamacare before it goes into effect,” the political group FreedomWorks argued over the summer.

headline: How Do You Know When Your Child Needs Outside Help?
text: This week, I pose the question in the continuing New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Booming and Motherlode. My query for experienced parents: How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond his or her years?

headline: The Beautiful (Street) Game
text: Pickup soccer games, known as pelada, have long been a part of Brazilian culture, attracting players day and night.

headline: Movie Review: '12 Years a Slave'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "12 Years a Slave."

headline: Movie Review: 'Carrie'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Carrie.”

headline: TV Stars Lead Online Push to Curb China’s Shark Fin Appetite
text: I was in China for the first time last weekend to speak on the role of online and social media in fostering progress on a finite planet (read my talk here). I broke away from the meeting — the first International Conference on Climate Change Communication — to check out a real-time example of how this works.

headline: Movie Review: 'All Is Lost'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “All Is Lost.”

headline: Delhi’s Urban Sprawl
text: As Delhi continues to expand, people living at the edges of the sprawling city question the benefits of urbanization.

headline: These Cleaners Never Close
text: Netflix and FreshDirect were among the first Internet-based services to replace brick-and-mortar businesses in New York City. And now comes DashLocker — a service that aims to take the place of dry cleaners and laundromats, and in some ways also play the role of a full-time doorman.

headline: Google Stock Tops $1,000, Highlighting a Tech Divide
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has done something few companies ever do in the stock market: it has joined the $1,000 club.

headline: Waking Up to a Bloodsucking Lover
text: LONDON — Matthew Bourne, the British choreographer, achieved worldwide fame when he put a corps de ballet of male, sexually alluring swans onstage in his 1995 reworking of “Swan Lake,” a brilliant expression of his ability to use physical imagery in the service of theater, and a rereading of the famous classical work that gripped audiences everywhere. “Swan Lake” followed Mr. Bourne’s witty 1992 reimagining of “The Nutcracker”; later, he went on to rework other ballet classics, among them “Cinderella” and “La Sylphide.”

headline: Black History’s Missing Chapters
text: The television mini-series “Roots,” about the slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants, is a classic, inspired by real lives and real history. But it is a truism among historians that young people do not know enough about African-American contributions to history. Even a tiny slice of recent history — the civil rights movement — is not required teaching in most states, the Southern Poverty Law Center found in a recent assessment.

headline: Photographs From ‘Before They Pass Away’
text: Images from Jimmy Nelson’s book.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Amsterdam; San Antonio, Tex.; London
text: Kazimir Malevich and the Russian Avant-Garde, Amsterdam The work of the early-20th-century Russian avant-garde pioneer Kazimir Malevich, above, is the subject of a major retrospective at the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam from Oct. 19 to Feb. 2, 2014, and the museum’s first dedicated to a key figure from its collection since reopening in 2012. The retrospective will include more than 500 works by the artist as well as those by contemporaries like Marc Chagall and Wassily Kandinsky. The exhibition is accompanied by lectures, discussion evenings and opportunities to create D.I.Y. Malevich-inspired postcards and life-size compositions.

headline: Girl With Earring and Entourage
text: “Girl With a Pearl Earring” is coming. Last seen in New York in 1984, this beloved Vermeer vision of a winsome young woman looking over her shoulder with wide, limpid eyes will be at the Frick Collection beginning on Tuesday. Her portrait will be joined by 14 more works by the 17th-century Dutch masters in “Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals: Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From the Mauritshuis.”

headline: Images From the Edges of the Earth
text: For sheer splendor, the catwalks of New York, Milan and Paris combined can barely touch the eagle hunters of Mongolia. Riding squat ponies through the mountains, these Turkic peoples wear high-domed and winged fur hats, embroidered felt boots and leggings, cloaks of reindeer hide, studded metal belts, fearsome hooded eagles perched on their arms.

headline: If You Feel Compelled to Do Something, Don’t
text: For a week, I kept notes about two different columns I was thinking of writing. When I finally sat down to try to write the first one, the notes had disappeared from my computer.

headline: Tough Talk, Screaming Riffs and Elegant Soul Rhythms From a New Mixtape
text: August AlsinaDOWNTOWN: LIFE UNDER THE GUN

headline: A Dominican Force in Latin Jazz
text: The Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra, led by the pianist Arturo O’Farrill, has often worked to tease out connections or pay living tribute, with the understanding that Latin jazz is both a historical idea and a vibrant contemporary art. “A Night of Afro Dominican Jazz: Honoring and Remembering ‘El Comandante’ Mario Rivera,” which opens the band’s 12th season on Oct. 25-26 at Symphony Space, should be a case in point.

headline: The Gun Report: October 18, 2013
text: Last week, California Gov. Jerry Brown signed 11 new gun laws and vetoed six others. Among the vetoed bills is AB 180, which would have allowed Oakland to pass gun control measures that are stricter than the state norm. SB 299 would have required owners to report stolen guns within seven days. SB 374 would have banned the sale of semi-automatic rifles with removable magazines. And SB 755 would have added drug abuse convictions to the list of what would prohibit someone from owning a gun for 10 years.

headline: Thomas Foley, House Speaker, Dies at 84; Democrat Urged Parties to Collaborate
text: Thomas S. Foley, a courtly congressman from Washington State who as speaker of the House sought to still the chamber’s rising tide of partisan combat before it swept the Democratic majority, and Mr. Foley himself, out of office in 1994, died on Friday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 84.

headline: Glass and Steel to Invade Cast-Iron SoHo
text: SoHo, the downtown neighborhood known for its cast-iron lofts and 19th-century tenements, is about to get something with an uptown flavor: a glassy high-rise.

headline: Check Out the Legs on That Viking
text: It’s a tossup as to which element of the 1958 film “The Vikings” plays more comically today: Kirk Douglas’s bird-damaged eyeball or Tony Curtis’s skimpy short-shorts. Certainly, there will be unintended laughs on Friday at 6:45 p.m. at Anthology Film Archives when it opens a series called “The Middle Ages on Film: Vikings!” that considers the historical accuracy (or lack of it) in movies that have dealt with those seafaring raiders.

headline: Cracked Sondheim, Newly Repaired
text: For all too few months in London this year, a great, unconquerable musical was finally mastered. The show was “Merrily We Roll Along,” Stephen Sondheim and George Furth’s reverse-chronology portrait of the toll of showbiz success. Since its brief original Broadway run in 1981, “Merrily” had been consigned to that limbo of beautiful, broken theater pieces that could never be put right. Then the Menier Chocolate Factory, the London company responsible for the Tony-winning revivification of “La Cage aux Folles,” came up with an interpretation, directed by Maria Friedman, that found a pulsing, unifying heart in this high-concept work.

headline: Movements at a Museum
text: It’s a week for the big ballet stories. On Wednesday, Matthew Bourne’s “Sleeping Beauty” opens at City Center and the San Francisco Ballet begins its run of Christopher Wheeldon’s “Cinderella” at the David H. Koch Theater. But it’s also a week for other kinds of stories, as embodied in work by the French choreographer Boris Charmatz, who will present the second part of his series — “Musée de la Danse: Three Collective Gestures” — at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Killer Whale, Captive Whale
text: On Feb. 24, 2010, Dawn Brancheau, a senior trainer at SeaWorld Orlando in Florida, was killed when Tilikum, a 12,000-pound bull orca, grabbed her as they interacted in shallow water and dragged her into a deep pool, mutilating and drowning her. It was the third human death the whale had been implicated in since 1991. “If you were in a bathtub for 25 years, don’t you think you’d get a little irritated, aggravated, maybe a little psychotic?” Jane Velez-Mitchell suggested afterward in a CNN panel discussion. But had Tilikum turned violent from the stress of living outside his natural environment? Or was he, like the overgrown kid he was portrayed as, just playing?

headline: A Rising Showcase for Daring Opera
text: When New York City Opera went belly up recently, many aficionados turned to Gotham Chamber Opera. Like City Opera in its prime, Gotham stands for unusual repertory, creative productions and rising young singers. With intriguing shows in locations that have ranged from the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to a Lower East Side burlesque club, it is an agile, adventurous company that may benefit from audiences and donors freed by City Opera’s demise, a silver lining in a storm cloud.

headline: Big Ticket | Awaiting a New Interior, but Sold for $35 Million
text: A limestone mansion that was built on the Upper East Side in 1909 but later used by the Knoedler Gallery to display fine art for several decades sold for $35 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The property received landmark designation in 1974.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: foot fungus, sleep patterns and new drugs. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
