headline: My Body Changed. So Did Intimacy.
text: I was messing around on the couch with an old boyfriend when he mentioned that he had a new sex med and that it was stashed in the fridge because it had to stay cold.

headline: New Delhi Puzzled Over Governing Hybrid Rural-Urban Areas
text: AGRAULA, Uttar Pradesh — As we left New Delhi and approached the border with Uttar Pradesh, Ashok Mittal, who owns and develops property in the latter area, told me, “When we cross over, you won’t just see it. You’ll feel it.”

headline: Making War on the Draft
text: One summer night in 1863, an angry mob surrounded the house of James Sill, the draft enrollment officer for Marion township in Putnam County, Ind. Sill had a list of eligible men whom he intended to draft into the Army. The mob, dozens strong, was there to take it from him, by force if necessary.

headline: More on Chicken
text: In the wake of the salmonella Heidelberg outbreak in chicken, which I wrote about on Wednesday, here are some updates:

headline: Image of the Day: October 18
text: An aerobatics show in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: New Ways With Broccoli
text: Slice the raw broccoli very thin for this delicious salad. If you can’t find purslane you can substitute mâche.

headline: Reflections on a Paris Left Behind
text: Even Hemingway struggled with this city, working on a memoir of his poor early days, “A Moveable Feast,” off and on for years, before it was finally published after his death. Christopher Hitchens once called it “an ur-text of the American enthrallment with Paris,” identifying an unthinking nostalgia “as we contemplate a Left Bank that has since become a banal tourist enclave in a Paris where the tough and plebeian districts are gone, to be replaced by seething Muslim banlieues all around the periphery.”

headline: Lessons From Living in London
text: How do you make a new city your own? How do you turn it from a place you know as a tourist into a place you call home? How do you transform yourself from traveler to resident?

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Return of Bridget Jones
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Sarah Lyall reviews Helen Fielding’s “Bridget Jones: Mad About the Boy,” the third novel starring the heroine played by Renée Zellweger in two movie adaptations. Ms. Lyall writes:

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A one-bedroom in the West Village; another in the East Village; and a row house in Lefferts Gardens.

headline: In High Demand at the Local Library, Spanish for Beginners
text: “Hola! Como estas?” Benjamin Lothson, a Spanish teacher, said to his students as his classroom at the Muhlenberg library in Chelsea slowly filled up.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

text: A five-bedroom home on a lake in Asbury Park; and a Stamford farmhouse built in 1870.

headline: All the Rage
text: The convergences and confluences at the megafair also include some unusual beds and a bunch of blue sculptures.

headline: The Gap Between Schooling and Education
text: The world has made dramatic gains in getting children — even very, very poor children — into school. But are they learning? The discomfiting conclusion from Lant Pritchett, a senior fellow at the Center for Global Development and professor at Harvard’s Kennedy School, is, in many cases, no.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: The Belgian architect Vincent Van Duysen is known for rigorous, spare design that retains a sense of life. Captivated by a once-stately house in Antwerp, he distilled it to its elements — and made it his home.

headline: No Ruling in Macy’s v. Penney? Try This
text: The end may be near for the long-running fight between Macy’s and J. C. Penney over Martha Stewart merchandise. Then again, it may not.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Putting a Price on Twitter
text: Twitter’s immature market debut leaves plenty of room for investors’ animal spirits. Early disorganization and a late focus on the top line make the microblogging service seem younger than Facebook was when it went public. Facebook was profitable, while Twitter is in the red — but its revenue is growing faster than Facebook’s.

headline: The Mexican Soda Tax
text: The soda tax didn’t fly in Albany, but it’s found new life in Mexico City. On Thursday the lower house of Mexico’s Congress approved new taxes on sugary beverages and high-calorie foods as part of a broader reform plan proposed by President Enrique Peña Nieto. If the proposal passes the Senate, the government will levy a 1 peso (8 cent) per liter tax on sugary beverages such as soft drinks, and a 5 percent tax on packaged foods that contain 275 calories or more per 100 grams.

headline: The Times Is Working on Ways to Make Numbers-Based Stories Clearer for Readers
text: Many readers have written to me recently, given the federal budget crisis, to make a simple request: Please advocate for news stories that put large numbers in context. If The Times does not do that, they say, it is part of the problem, and if it does do so, other news organizations are very likely to follow suit.

headline: California Sees Gridlock Ease in Governing
text: LOS ANGELES — Before Washington, California was the national symbol of partisan paralysis and government dysfunction.

headline: Five Ways to Fill a Pepper
text: Peppers of all shapes and colors are still on offer at autumn markets. These are far superior to the fleshy, uniform supermarket peppers that look pretty but have very little flavor. I’ve been buying them by the bagful and stuffing them with all sorts of fillings, some traditional, most not.

headline: A Little Getaway After the Big Event
text: Unlike many brides, the last thing Kersten Deck wanted to do after her wedding last May was go on a big, fancy honeymoon.

headline: A Clam Chowder of Thin Over Thick
text: There’s always a line outside Swan Oyster Depot, San Francisco’s justly famous, 100-year-old oyster bar. Many come in for a cold draft beer and freshly shucked clams and oysters on ice. I make it a point to do so whenever I’m in town.

headline: Case Against Madoff Sons Is Dismissed in London
text: Of the many questions asked about Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, among the most frequent is whether his sons knew about the fraud despite their staunch insistence that they were kept in the dark.

headline: Replicas of Caterers, Faux Antiquities and Other Art World Microtrends at Frieze London
text: Today, the 11th edition of Frieze Art Fair London opened its tent city in Regent’s Park to the public, featuring work from 152 of the world’s leading contemporary art galleries. That number, down from 175 last year, reflects an uptick in quality control from Britain’s largest art fair, which runs through Sunday. Still, the volume and variety of artworks lining its carpeted halls is overwhelming. As with any such event, coincidences, confluences and doppelgängers inevitably crop up. Here, some of the microtrends to be spotted at this year’s fair.

headline: BP Recovers in Exploration Activity
text: BP is recovering from the paralysis that followed the 2010 Gulf of Mexico disaster, at least in terms of looking for more oil and gas. That was the message Friday from Mike Daly, the company’s executive vice president for exploration.

headline: Nomination Revives Debate Over Homeland Security
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nomination on Friday of Jeh C. Johnson as the next secretary of homeland security reignited criticism of the department and led Republicans and Democrats to blame one another for its problems.

headline: Right Place, Right Tine
text: Judging by a glance at their forks, the restaurants that appear in this weekend’s Food and Drink Issue might not seem so different from one another. Those forks you see above are just . . . forks, right? That’s not how the new management of Tavern on the Green sees things. As Max Chafkin writes, the restaurateurs are thinking very carefully about every contending fork’s curvature and heft, ridges and tines — and whether it will make Tavern on the Green a success.

headline: Q. and A. With Red Bulls’ Mike Petke
text: After playing seven years in his 14-year professional soccer career for his hometown team, Mike Petke believes he can lead the Red Bulls to the promised land — a championship in Major League Soccer. The club, first as the MetroStars and later as an outpost in the energy drink empire of an Austrian company, have gone to the league’s title match once — in 2008, losing by 3-1 to Columbus. After two years as an assistant to Hans Backe, Petke was named the team’s interim coach, then got the job full-time only weeks before the start of the 2013 season. The first team to clinch a playoff berth, if the Red Bulls win their final two regular-season games (at Houston on Sunday and against Chicago on Oct. 27) they will finish No. 1 over all, win the Supporters Shield and a berth in next season’s Concacaf Champions League. Petke spoke with Jack Bell of The Times before training on Tuesday at the Red Bulls training complex in Hanover, N.J.

headline: Obama Announces Homeland Security Choice
text: The president announced his selection for secretary of Homeland Security, Jeh C. Johnson, a former general counsel for the Department of Defense.

headline: Historical Society May Play a Role at Seaport Museum
text: The City has begun discussions with the New-York Historical Society about a role in overseeing the South Street Seaport Museum.

headline: A Shy and Logical Guy Finds His Open and Wild Match
text: On “30 Rock,” he was the nerdy but easygoing and affable writer nicknamed Toofer (two-for-one) because he was both a minority and a Harvard graduate. But in his real life, stardom had led the actor Keith Powell to withdraw.

headline: Tone Changes in One of England’s Toughest Jobs
text: SUNDERLAND, England — On the eve of his first game in English soccer’s most hapless job, Gus Poyet thought it best to begin by telling reporters who he wasn’t.

headline: Where Art Is in the Air, and in the Ground
text: The fiery hues of autumn hold inspiration for artists and museumgoers alike. Before the air becomes too chilly and the last leaves flutter to the ground, take time to visit three outdoor exhibitions where nature’s palette is the backdrop for the art.

headline: Weekend Reading: Take the Wall Street Earnings Quiz
text: Investment banks are struggling in Wall Street’s third-quarter earnings season following a drop in mortgage refinancing and a downturn in trading. How well do you know the big banks? Test yourself by matching the financial giant to the quote about their earnings reports.

headline: Drunken Driving Arrest for Ex-Refco Financial Officer
text: The former chief financial officer of Refco, the collapsed brokerage firm, offered a Florida state trooper $1,000 to let him go after being pulled over for drunken driving earlier this week, according to a police report.

headline: An Action Plan for Hurricanes
text: Here are some suggestions owners can use to prepare for storms and steps they can follow if damage occurs:

headline: Video Game Sales Bounce Back, Thanks to Grand Theft Auto
text: The video game industry’s stay in purgatory has had a reprieve — at least for a bit.

headline: Talk About Political Dysfunction ...
text: ON Oct. 5, American Special Forces captured Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, an operative of Al Qaeda living in Libya. Five days later, a group of Libyan militiamen kidnapped their own prime minister, Ali Zeidan. After five hours, having faced no opposition from the police or the army, they released him. The prime minister’s captors made no demands for cash, nor did they overtly request any changes in current government policy. Nor was anyone hurt — an aspect that gave the whole affair the air of a vast publicity stunt.

headline: Data-Mining Our Dreams
text: ARE dreams really meaningful?

headline: Review: 2014 Chevy Cruze Turbo Diesel
text: Europeans choose diesel engines for their fuel efficiency. Will Americans ever embrace them? Tom Voelk checks out the Chevy Cruze Turbo Diesel to see if G.M. has cleaned up its diesel act.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photos from France, Afghanistan, Iraq and Pakistan.

headline: A Landscaper’s Biggest Job Yet: Mowing the Lawn at Fresh Kills Landfill
text: Silvio Gallazzini recently hired a fellow landscaper to manicure his own backyard in New Jersey, which is understandable given the demands of his latest job. There was no way he could do it all himself.

headline: Fantasy Football: How Rookie Running Backs Have Fared
text: Back in August, we ranked this season’s N.F.L. rookies, from a fantasy football perspective, at each position. With six weeks in the books, it’s time to revisit the rookies.

headline: A Top Syrian Intelligence Officer Is Killed in Fighting
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — One of the Syrian government’s most prominent intelligence officers, Maj. Gen. Jamea Jamea, was killed during fighting in the eastern provincial capital of Deir al-Zour, Syrian rebels and the state news media said on Friday as government warplanes bombed the city after several days of fierce clashes.

headline: CBS Orders Full Seasons for 3 New Comedies
text: CBS gave an early vote of confidence to three comedies it introduced in September, announcing on Friday that “The Millers,” “The Crazy Ones” and “Mom” had all won renewal orders that will take them through the current season.

headline: Internal Combustion as a Term of Art
text: The state of the internal-combustion art has never been more artful. Direct fuel injection, variable valve timing, computer-controlled ignition systems and a hundred other technologies have become tools for shaping how an engine performs. Engineers can add torque here, subtract it over there, let the engine rev at one point and hold it back at another. This is a new artistic medium, and Audi’s latest V-8 engine is a masterpiece.

headline: Diesel Wagon: What’ll They Think of Next?
text: TESTED Volkswagen Jetta SportWagen 2.0L TDI

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: A new generation of visionaries are using next-level technologies to create products, projects and experiences that test the limits of design — and our imaginations.

headline: For These Young Visionaries, Design is an Illusion
text: Pick up an iPhone 5 and you are holding 727,040 pixels in your hand. Individually, they have no smell, no texture, no meaning. They make no sound; the faint hiss of old televisions has disappeared. Only in sum do pixels become more — information, images and art; a world engorged with screens. But how can an artist or designer make something more interesting than that everyday digital reality? How do you create something technological that transcends technology? In essence, how do you get people to look up from their own devices?

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 18
text: Here is a slide show of photos from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: politicians on the campaign trail, tourists at Liberty Island and crowds admiring Bansky graffiti.

headline: From Beirut to Washington
text: I’VE spent most of my career covering Middle East politics. I always thought it was its own unique field. But, in the last few weeks, I’ve felt myself to be at a real advantage trying to explain American politics. You see, it turns out that all those years covering Sunnis and Shiites, Israelis and Palestinians, tribal conflicts and “Parties of God” have been the best preparation for covering today’s Washington, D.C., and particularly the Tea Party. Seriously, you’d get a much better feel for Washington politics today by reading “Lawrence of Arabia” than the Federalist Papers. This is not good news.

headline: Why the Budget Conference Is Ill-Fated
text: There was a lot of sunny talk about common ground and shared goals when the four budget leaders of the House and Senate met on Thursday to prepare for the big negotiation to come. A joint conference committee has until mid-December to construct a 2014 budget and prevent another shutdown in January, and the leaders worked hard at sounding optimistic.

headline: Making Pasta Look Pretty in Pink
text: I’ve had pasta with red sauce hundreds of times; it’s classic, comforting and exactly what you’d expect to coat your linguine. But this autumn’s crop of jewel-like beets has me thinking in an entirely different direction. These days when I make pasta, I think pink: pink beet sauce, that is.

headline: Cavatelli with Brown Butter Beets
text: Beets add an earthy note to pasta, especially when they are both topped with brown butter.

headline: A Beep in the Night
text: “Mrs. Feld, you were confused!”

headline: The Last of the Sheiks?
text: DURHAM, England — THIS summer, disgruntled Saudis took their grievances online in droves, complaining of ever-growing inequality, rising poverty, corruption and unemployment. Their Twitter campaign became one of the world’s highest trending topics. It caused great alarm within elite circles in Saudi Arabia and sent ripples throughout the region. The rallying cry that “salaries are not enough” helped to prove that the monarchy’s social contract with its people is now publicly coming unstuck, and on a significant scale.

headline: Same-Sex Marriages in New Jersey Can Begin, Court Rules
text: Same-sex couples can start marrying on Monday across New Jersey, after the state’s Supreme Court denied Gov. Chris Christie’s attempt to block the weddings and suggested that he would have a difficult time winning an appeal of a lower-court ruling that allowed them.

headline: A 1930s Farce, but Not as Groucho Played It
text: The wallpaper in the hotel room is loud enough. But Gordon Miller, the struggling would-be Broadway producer who lives there in “Room Service,” often manages to outshout the décor. He delivers the line “My God, there must be somebody I can sue!” at the top of his lungs while jumping up and down like a frustrated 3-year-old.

headline: Revisiting a Revolution
text: In the third movement of Shostakovich’s Symphony No. 11, “The Year 1905,” the violas play a melancholy theme over the subdued pizzicati of the lower strings. When Semyon Bychkov led the New York Philharmonic in a brilliant performance of the work on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the melody unfolded tenderly. It softly re-emerged with radiant introspection at the end of the third movement, called “In Memoriam.”

headline: Audi’s V-8 Masterpiece
text: The S7 and S8 come with different versions of an impeccably engineered V-8 engine that sets Audi apart from its luxury performance-car competition.

headline: Out of Network, Not by Choice, and Facing Huge Health Bills
text: Once the cardiologist figured out why Raquel and Michael D’Andrea’s 9-week-old daughter was so frail and unable to eat, he immediately sent her to the hospital for heart surgery.

headline: The Posh London Homes That Posh Londoners Covet
text: In 10th grade, my English class read “Portrait of the Artist as a Young Dog,” Dylan Thomas’s great book of autobiographical short stories, featuring examples of some early poetic attempts by the Thomas-ian protagonist. One day I gushed to the teacher, Mr. Weber, about the amazingness of those poems — how could anyone have been so talented so young? It was embarrassing because, as Mr. Weber gently explained, the author was making a joke at the expense of the character: the point was that the poems were not good at all.

headline: Gwen Stefani Shimmies and Shakes in Metallic Fringe
text: The Girl: The singer’s fringed ensemble was full of movement at the black-tie opening-night gala for the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills last night.

headline: A Painter’s Evolution in Abstract Landscapes
text: “The style was so controlled!” the artist Stan Brodsky said, not altogether admiringly, as he stood in front of one of his paintings at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

headline: A Short History of the Fainting Couch
text: Recamier, méridienne, chaise longue, daybed — we’ve long needed a place to lounge.

headline: Fox Gives ‘Brooklyn Nine-Nine’ a Big Vote of Confidence
text: The Fox network is putting as much faith as it can muster behind the new comedy series “Brooklyn Nine-Nine,” announcing on Friday that the show would be renewed for the full television season and be introduced to the enormous audience that remains after a Super Bowl broadcast.

headline: Is Kent the Westchester of London?
text: In Turner Contemporary, in Margate, the gallery workers were hanging a new exhibition: works by J. M. W. Turner, John Constable and their peers, a collection of rarely seen early-19th-century landscape sketches offset by the shark skin and whale spine of the Irish contemporary artist Dorothy Cross. The floor was littered with cables and vacuum-cleaner components, masking tape and Stanley knives. It was a scene that could have been straight out of a gallery on Cork Street, but instead the few visitors were able to look out over the water to where the North Sea meets the English Channel.

headline: Big Sound in a Small House, Keen to Reach the Next Stage
text: But who will fill the arenas? Not with fans, with sound — anthemic rock has taken a beating in recent years. Or more accurately, it’s been puréed into a softer, lighter version of its former self, be it the deep exhales of Coldplay or the turned-up muscle-folk of Mumford & Sons.

headline: In Exploring Abuse, Encountering ‘Tender Territory’
text: The author and actor Martin Moran calls Two River Theater’s decision to stage “A Map of the Soul,” a first-ever bundling of his one-man shows “The Tricky Part” and “All the Rage,” “brave and ambitious.”

headline: Washington Reopens for Business
text: The capital comes back to life with tourists and federal workers after the end of the government shutdown Wednesday night.

headline: Making Ballet Speak in Many Languages
text: The high and rising international reputation of the San Francisco Ballet derives from its deep bench of talent and its commitment to new work. The mixed-bill programs that the company is presenting during the first week of its visit to New York put forward both strengths at once. After an opening night on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater that offered three New York premieres of recently choreographed pieces, the troupe went one better on Thursday, with four.

headline: Kenyan Leader Can Skip Parts of Hague Trial
text: PARIS — Kenya’s president can be absent from parts of his trial on charges of crimes against humanity to fulfill his duties at home, but he will have to be present for a number of important hearings at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, the court announced Friday.

headline: As Baseball Integrates, Satchel Throws Heat
text: In the pleasant parlor of a Kansas City boardinghouse, a young woman excitedly flips through the pages of a magazine. It is 1947, and change for black Americans seems enticingly close. She finds what she is looking for: an ad for Wheaties cereal. The spokesman-endorser is Jackie Robinson, who has recently become the first black player in modern major-league baseball.

headline: Christopher Bailey: Burberry’s Fitting Appointment
text: THIS WEEK INVESTORS weighed in on the news that Christopher Bailey would become the chief executive of Burberry, where he is already chief creative officer, and it wasn’t pretty.

headline: Video: G.M. Tries Diesel Again, This Time With an Efficient Chevy Cruze
text: Americans tend to think of hybrids when they want a car with high fuel economy. Europeans, on the other hand, turn to diesel-powered cars. The only manufacturers to offer diesel power to American car buyers with any regularity have been  Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz. So it’s only natural that Chevrolet is jumping into the game with the Cruze Turbo Diesel.

headline: A Year After Sandy, Collectors Consider the Lessons
text: Scott Nadler’s home in Oceanside, N.Y., was among the thousands severely damaged when Hurricane Sandy’s storm surge pummeled the South Shore of Long Island nearly a year ago. There was some relief, however, in finding that although saltwater had flooded his garage, the 1971 Chevrolet Chevelle SS 396 he’d owned for 10 years was repairable.

headline: A Fix for a Chirp Under the Hood
text: Honda Crosstours that foul spark plugs and Jeep Wranglers that run hot are among the vehicles with mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Mailer Gala Honors Diaz, Angelou and Its Divisive Namesake
text: At the fifth annual Norman Mailer Center Benefit Gala on Thursday at the New York Public Library, honored writers and even the M.C.’s grappled with the legacy of the gala’s namesake.

headline: Landlord vs. Tenant: When It All Began
text: “Everybody loves a landlord,” the Master of the House gustily sings in “Les Misérables.” At few times would that glibly insincere boast have rung less true than in New York City during and after World War I, when coal shortages, Socialist agitators and the scarcity of apartments conspired to bring about emergency rent regulation.

headline: Problems of Growing Up Female
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Throughout Charlotte Vincent’s “Motherland,” which takes place on a white stage, several scenes repeat in exacting precision: Aurora Lubos walks onto the stage holding a bottle, unscrews its lid and flings its dark red contents onto a pristine wall. She then hikes up her dress, spreads her legs and leans against it with a hollow expression; it looks like menstrual blood. The stain sets.

headline: On Late TV, Hosts Go From Snide to Sweet
text: In one of the signal moments of the greatest talk show in my lifetime, “Late Night With David Letterman,” on NBC, Cher called the host a big jerk.

headline: Dirty Antebellum Secrets in Ivory Towers
text: When Craig Steven Wilder first began digging around in university archives in 2002 for material linking universities to slavery, he recalled recently, he was “a little bashful” about what he was looking for.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google and Facebook Partner on Ads, and Talk to Me, Siri
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: NBC Cancels Two Series and Will Bring Back ‘Community’
text: Cancellation news arrived again on Friday evening with NBC swinging the ax this time and removing both the comedy “Welcome to the Family” and the drama “Ironside” from the schedule.

headline: Clarity at Yoga, Cheating at the Diner
text: With all the projects that the choreographer Larry Keigwin has going, his week could use four or five Sundays. This fall, Mr. Keigwin, 41, is choreographing a new musical, “If/Then,” to open in Washington next month and on Broadway in the spring, and preparing his own dance company’s 10th-anniversary performances at the Joyce Theater from Oct. 29 to Nov. 3. In spare moments he is starting a magazine, ArtDesk, which just published its first issue. He lives with his partner, Christian Keesee, 51, a banker, and sometimes Mr. Keesee’s son, Blake, 16, in a town house in the East 70s, joined by their three dogs.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 18
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: politicians on the campaign trail, tourists at Liberty Island and crowds admiring Banksy graffiti.

headline: An Elegant Little Soiree of String Players, Just Playing a Few Old Tunes
text: As a rule, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is all about intimacy. Its concerts often feel like conversations between a handful of players, the musical equivalent of confidences shared across a dinner table. But for the opening of its new season on Thursday, the society peopled the stage of Alice Tully Hall with a small crowd.

headline: Forget Their Dad; Just Listen to Them
text: When Theo Spielberg decided it was time to get serious about starting a rock group, he only had to look across the hallway of his family’s home to find a lead singer. Joined in his bedroom by his sister Sasha, he grabbed his guitar and started plunking out a chord progression he’d been toying with since college, while she sang a pleading and melodic vocal about unspecified desires.

headline: Old, but Not Off the Stage
text: They are out there nearly every afternoon in Balsley Park, a small plaza on Ninth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets.

headline: Exotic Thrills for the Privileged, to a Jazz Score
text: In early-1930s London, behind endless clouds of cigarette smoke, society was being remade. “Dancing on the Edge,” a new Starz mini-series beginning Saturday, takes place in the swank hotels, garden parties and jazz clubs of that era to capture the moment when black music served as a social lubricant that brought together poor, itinerant musicians and the aristocracy, including members of the royal family, for a marriage that was tenuous by design.

headline: The Charter School Fight
text: The mayor’s race, otherwise somnolently lacking in drama since the primaries retired the name Sydney Leathers to the history of grade-B scandal, received an infusion of heat recently over the dependably combustible issue of charter school education.

headline: House Tour | Howard Slatkin
text: Howard Slatkin, an interior decorator, gave T Magazine's Sara Ruffin Costello a tour of his palatial Fifth Avenue apartment.

headline: The New Nice Guys of Comedy
text: In an era when the most celebrated television dramas ask you to identify with often-repellent antiheroes, the new stars of late night are ingratiating nice guys.

headline: Finding Your Flair, Pompadour Optional
text: Most nights around 8, you can catch “Thelma & Louise” on television at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn. As you may recall, that Ridley Scott 1991 film was a game changer in Hollywood, redefining the outlaw buddy movie by starring two women, instead of men, as partners in crime and self-discovery.

headline: Logging Miles After Night Falls
text: In the developing scene of urban running crews, socializing and drinking are a large part of the draw.

headline: Executive on Mayoral Race’s Fringes Says Goal Is to Offer Ideas
text: Jack Hidary had the gumption to start his first Internet company at a time when most people knew little of the Internet beyond e-mail. So when he looked earlier this year at the field of mayoral candidates, which included several career politicians and a former congressman best known for tweeting a picture of his underpants, he thought, “Why not jump in?”

headline: Into These Woods, Suspect in a Killing Vanished a Year Ago
text: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y. — Last year about this time, Eugene Palmer, a 73-year-old retired truck driver with a love of the craggy backwoods, shot and killed his tempestuous daughter-in-law, Tammy Palmer, the police said, and vanished into the vast wilderness of Harriman State Park.

headline: Miles, Then Margaritas
text: There are runners who get up early every morning to get in their miles and who meet up for weekend events in city parks sponsored by the New York Road Runners club, or the like.

headline: When the E-Mail Is Not Quite Spam, but Not Quite Desired
text: I’m opting out. Not of the workplace, but of newsletters I haven’t signed up for, business tips I never asked for, blog posts I won’t read, events I can’t attend, pet updates, recipes for organic vegan chocolate mousse that I will never make, and jokes that have been circulating on the Web since 2004 (but thanks, Mom).

headline: Deal From the Venice Cup and Bermuda Bowl
text: One of the arts of declarer play is making life difficult for the defenders. And if you need a misdefense, usually the quicker you put your opponent on the spot, the better.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Prada’s Latest Desert Outpost, Karl Lagerfeld’s Class on Being Karl, and Gwyneth Paltrow’s Newest Crusade
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREOct. 12 – 18

headline: A Risky Homecoming for White-Tailed Deer
text: Staring across Staten Island’s West Shore Expressway, the buck struck a pose in the late light of an autumn day, antlers burnished like new bronze. His muddy feet described his journey from Old Place Creek, just below the road’s shoulder, to a spot where he no doubt anticipated a better view, but instead found one of New York City’s busiest highways. The deer’s intent gaze was troubling. Suddenly driving 50 miles an hour seemed much too fast, and the road’s shoulder, much too narrow.

headline: Deadlines for Colleges Are Delayed
text: Several of the nation’s top colleges and universities have postponed their early application deadlines over the last few days, prompted by continued reports that students and high schools are stumbling over technical problems with the Common Application.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Bigger, Bolder
text: Paris Fashion Week could easily be called the Greatest Show on Earth.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
text: With a storied imagination, a collector’s passion and an obsessive attention to detail, Howard Slatkin has created a one-of-a kind Fifth Avenue aerie in which every doorknob, tile and 19th-century silk lampshade was designed by him.

headline: Nicholas Loeb: Forget All the Rest, He’s Mr. Condiment
text: On a recent afternoon, Nicholas M. Loeb walked into the Hillstone steakhouse on Park Avenue South, not far from his penthouse duplex apartment. Tall and handsome in a dress shirt, faded jeans and loafers, he sat down, ordered spinach and artichoke dip and lined up four bottles on the table. “This is our company that I just launched, Onion Crunch,” he said. “And this year we launched three new flavors: chipotle, bacon and barbecue.”

headline: Q. and A.: Jia Zhangke on Violence, Censorship and His New Film ‘A Touch of Sin’
text: One afternoon, as a late summer thunderstorm rolled into Beijing, a small group of Chinese and foreign journalists sat in the Beijing office of Jia Zhangke, the Chinese director, watching his latest film, “A Touch of Sin.” Mr. Jia had finished one round of appearances at film festivals and was in Beijing for a spell, before heading to festivals in the fall in Toronto; New York; San Sebastián, Spain; and elsewhere. The film had made its world premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May, where it won a best screenplay award.

headline: The Call of the ‘Wild’ on the Pacific Crest Trail
text: The Pacific Crest Trail, a 2,650-mile hiking and equestrian trail that reaches from Mexico to Canada, has been called the Appalachian Trail of the West Coast. But that description does it a disservice, for the Pacific trail is longer, wilder, more punishing and also grander than its East Coast cousin.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Turn It Around
text: Their album is just out — and it’s really, really good. (But where’s “Genevieve”?) I was worried that it would be overproduced, but while it’s different from the live performances, it’s different in a good way, with the voices even more gorgeous.

headline: For Jewish School’s Football Team, It’s Thursday Night Lights
text: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — Early Thursday morning at a Jewish high school here, Elan Kainen donned the prayer shawl that had been a gift from his maternal grandfather and recited the prayers of the Shacharit service. Nine hours later, he went through another ritual, one involving pads, cleats and a helmet, as he suited up for what might be the final game of his high school football career.

headline: Online Happy Hours, From Corner Bar to Corner Office
text: A little after 4 p.m. on a recent Thursday, Eric Fleming, the head of strategy for Mash+Studio, a content marketing firm in SoHo, gathered his co-workers for happy hour.

headline: When Celebrity Sex Videos Are Rated Y (for Yawn)
text: Rob Lowe in the hotel room.

headline: Sports Ministry Fraud a Symptom of Venezuela’s Race for Dollars
text: Venezuela is investigating athletes on its national motorsports teams for defrauding the government of tens of millions of dollars, Reuters reports.

headline: Editor’s Letter | Life At Home
text: The homes featured in this issue are each wildly different and support wildly different ways of living. What unites them is the clear point of view each one possesses — each reflecting its inhabitant in the most basic, but profound, way.

headline: Three Dimensions of IndyCar
text: IndyCar is the only series that races on three types of courses: oval, street and road. Tony Kanaan, the 2013 Indianapolis 500 winner, and Simona DeSilvestro of KV Racing explain the differences in driving at Pocono Speedway, a high-speed oval, and at Mid-Ohio’s road course.

headline: Book Bags for the Children, and Bags of Crack at Starbucks
text: A sign outside an 11th-floor apartment in the Jacob Riis Houses in Lower Manhattan reads: “Warning: This Property Protected by Jesus Christ.” But outside, in a nearby courtyard, that particular responsibility apparently fell to Dwayne Mitchell.

headline: Chinese Company Buys Chase Manhattan Plaza
text: One Chase Manhattan Plaza, the 60-story office tower that has been home to one of New York City’s most important banks for half a century, has a new owner: Fosun International of China.

headline: Russia: 2 Bomb Makers Die, Police Say
text: Two people suspected of being militants were killed Friday when an improvised bomb that the police said was being prepared for a terrorist attack exploded in a mosque’s cemetery in the North Caucasus region, where Russia is struggling to contain an insurgency. A police spokeswoman for the republic of Kabardino-Balkaria said officers responding to the blast in the village of Dugulubgey found the remains of two bodies, as well as two pistols and a Kalashnikov assault rifle stolen from a police officer in 2008. The device was estimated to have contained more than 20 pounds of explosives, and it shattered the windows of nearby homes when it went off, the police spokeswoman said. The region is close to Sochi, which will host the 2014 Winter Olympics.

headline: T Fall Design Issue
text: In our latest issue, we explore distinct forms of design, whether they’re found in the asymmetrical forms of fashion, or in the ’70s-style curvilinear lines of furniture, or in the architecture of midcentury homes in the Beverly Hills neighborhood of Trousdale. Design, like all forms of art, can be very personal; members of one of England’s most celebrated families, Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant, draw inspiration from nature, namely from the bucolic surroundings in Scotland to create their sculptures and paintings. It can also be very pared down and minimal, like in the home of two fashion designers in Tokyo, or in the distilled, spacious Antwerp residence of the Belgian architect Vincent Van Duysen. On a larger scale, we discover designers and artisans determined to reinvent neighborhoods and cities around the world. In Sydney’s Rosebery neighborhood, three businesses celebrate the best of the city’s agriculture, craftsmanship and furniture design. Meanwhile, in Belgrade, locals are turning their city into a world-class destination, with the emergence of design hotels, art museums and adventurous restaurants. We embrace those who break with convention in art and design; Not Vital, a Swiss artist obsessed with habitats, is the Picasso, the Dali, the Andy Warhol of today, claims Andrew O’Hagan. Howard Slatkin’s Fifth Avenue apartment is filled with custom-made items, from floor to ceiling; each room has a combination of textiles, lighting, objets d’art from different eras and countries. Last but not least, we celebrate visionaries who are using technology to take design — and our imaginations — to the next level. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Mexico: Soda-Tax Bill Moves Forward
text: The lower house of Mexico’s Congress has approved a tax on soda and other sugary drinks as part of the government’s fight against the twin epidemics of obesity and diabetes. The legislators also added a junk food tax of 5 percent to most snacks and candy when they approved a broad overhaul of Mexico’s tax system late Thursday. The beverage industry, along with sugar producers and the owners of small stores, has led a fierce lobbying campaign against the tax, but public health advocates have fought back. The Senate will take up the tax bill next week.

headline: After Running Hot, Market for Used Cars Is Cooling
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — It was 9:30 on a recent Tuesday morning at Manheim Riverside, a wholesale auto auction, and more than a thousand used-car dealers were mulling in the desert heat. The bidders had gathered on the perimeters of Manheim’s 10 lanes of cars, watching the vehicles cycle through 10 different auction blocks, at no longer than 45 seconds a pop. Over a collective din that drowns out the auctioneers, the dealers wink, nod or, for the less stealthy, raise a hand to indicate their bid.

headline: The Quarterbacks’ Share
text: The Giants’ quarterbacks, primarily Eli Manning, consume a larger portion of their team’s salary cap than any other quarterbacks in the N.F.L. The chart shows the percentage of the $123 million cap used by each team for its quarterbacks.

headline: Reasoning May Be Wrong, but No. 2 Spot Is for Best
text: Sometimes it seems the rift between baseball’s traditionalists and its more statistically oriented enthusiasts will never be mended. Every time there is some progress, like players and pundits acknowledging the superiority of Mike Trout’s well-rounded game, a situation arises like David Price’s writing off questioning reporters as nerds.

headline: Wave of High-Profile Crimes Has Put Malaysians on the Defensive
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia’s population has tripled over the past four decades. Its largest city, Kuala Lumpur, a place once so sparsely populated that it looked like a botanical garden, has exploded into a cosmopolitan metropolis of shopping malls, luxury hotels and sprawling suburbs.

headline: Democrats Aim to Restore Immigration to Agenda
text: As the fiscal crisis subsided and the government went back to work this week, President Obama and other leading Democrats were quick to say that an immigration overhaul should be back on the agenda in Congress.

headline: Low-Cost B.A. Starting Slowly in Two States
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — With tuition, student loan debt and default rates all spiraling higher, what’s not to love about a $10,000 bachelor’s degree?

headline: Malaysia Confronts a Growing Crime Problem
text: Kuala Lumpur, the largest city in Malaysia, was once considered one of Asia’s safest cities. Now it’s fighting a rash of burglaries and other crimes.

headline: A Ted Cruz on Every Corner
text: Have you noticed how many lawmakers from Texas were doing crazy things during the government shutdown debacle?

headline: Shutdown to Cost U.S. Billions, Analysts Say, While Eroding Confidence
text: WASHINGTON — The government shutdown that ended this week will cost the United States economy several billion dollars, according to estimates by economic research firms.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: 5 FLORIDA STATE at 3 CLEMSON

headline: The High Cost of ‘Betrayal’
text: The new Broadway revival of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal” is setting box-office records at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, grossing $1,100,818 for the week ended Oct. 6 and $1,112,027 for the week ended Oct. 13. That’s roughly $45,000 more than the previous high mark set by Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman” in the spring of 2012.

headline: Canada and Europe Reach Tentative Trade Agreement
text: OTTAWA — Canada and the European Union tentatively agreed to a sweeping trade agreement on Friday. But while billed as a free-trade pact, the limited information released about its terms suggests that the details of any final deal may focus on adjusting import-export quotas and fine-tuning regulations as much as the easing of tariffs.

headline: Mets Said to Be Near Radio Deal
text: The Mets are nearing a multiyear agreement to make WOR-AM (710) the new home for their games, according to a person in baseball. Howie Rose, the voice of the Mets, is expected to remain. The Mets had been searching for a new home after WFAN announced it would carry the Yankees next season. The Mets had been on WFAN since its inception in 1987.

headline: A Sri Lankan Journalist Eagerly Toes the Line
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — He calls himself the Rush Limbaugh of Sri Lanka, “except I’m not as obnoxious.” His critics say he should be hanged from a lamppost.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Handling Medical Errors
text: Readers discuss apologies, disciplinary actions and lawsuits.

headline: N.S.A. Plan to Log Calls Is Renewed by Court
text: WASHINGTON — The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court released a new legal opinion on Friday that reauthorized the once-secret National Security Agency program that keeps records of every American’s phone calls. The opinion also sought to plug a hole in a similar ruling made public last month.

headline: As Iran Shifts, Hard-Liners See Threat to Battle Cry
text: TEHRAN — With the believers pouring out of the Friday Prayer site in Tehran, Ali Akbar and his friends sprang into action, hastily spreading posters of the American flag on the asphalt and switching on their megaphone.

headline: World Series Seems Rodriguez-Proof
text: Alex Rodriguez’s arbitration hearing recessed on Friday and will not resume until sometime in November, which apparently means this year’s World Series may be able to proceed without the Yankees’ third baseman creating a distinct distraction.

headline: Cardinals Take Beltran to World Series
text: ST. LOUIS — Carlos Beltran was used to the scent. Seven times before Friday, he had sniffed the World Series, playing a game with a chance to win the pennant. Every time, his team had lost. Once, Beltran struck out looking to end the season.

headline: Hit by Low Prices, Lobstermen Are at Odds in Maine and Canada
text: OTTAWA — Lobsters do not respect the lines on maps that define the Canada-United States border. They traverse the seabed contentedly munching on herring from New England to Newfoundland.

headline: Corruption in Peru Aids Cutting of Rain Forest
text: PUCALLPA, Peru — Afraid the police would tip off suspects, Francisco Berrospi kept local officers in the dark when he headed into the rain forest as a prosecutor to investigate illegal logging. Sometimes it hardly seemed to matter, though.

headline: White Sox Seek a Jolt of Power With a Cuban Slugger
text: CHICAGO — The White Sox finished 2013 with 99 losses, the most since they lost a franchise-worst 106 games in 1970. Less than three weeks after their season ended, they made the first big free-agent splash of the off-season by agreeing to a six-year, $68 million contract with the 26-year-old Cuban first baseman Jose Dariel Abreu.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: A deal is made to end the government shutdown, a Belgian company buys an American craft brewery and class-action lawsuits are filed against oil companies for burning off natural gas.

headline: Illegal Logging Thrives in Peru, Environmentalists Say
text: An investigator goes to remote areas at the western end of the Amazon rain forest.

headline: Texans Stick With Cruz Despite Defeat in Washington
text: HOUSTON — Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas and the face of the angry right, has been criticized, lambasted and lampooned for putting the nation through a 16-day government shutdown and the prospect of a financial default.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 19, 2013
text: “You see Republicans voting for immigration reform, you see Democrats voting for streamlining environmental regulations. You never would have seen that before.”

headline: Kentucky’s Case of the Missing Bourbon
text: FRANKFORT, Ky. — America’s decade-old romance with Kentucky bourbon, a drink formerly as plebeian as a Chevrolet, has come to this: high-end bar chefs and foodies everywhere have been abuzz since 65 cases of Pappy Van Winkle, one of the nation’s most expensive and sought-after bourbons, disappeared from a warehouse here.

headline: Policing the Amazon
text: With vast territory to cover across Peru, government authorities are working hard to fight the illegal timber trade that often goes on deep in the jungle.

headline: Continuing Salmonella Outbreaks
text: Months after salmonella-contaminated chicken distributed by a California company sickened people, the dangerous food is still being sold around the country. This disturbing situation is the result of weak federal regulatory powers and the company’s irresponsibility.

headline: Shortsighted Arms Deregulation
text: President Obama has rightly earned praise for signing the international Arms Trade Treaty, which seeks to keep many kinds of conventional weapons out of the hands of terrorists and other criminals who fuel conflicts around the globe. He now risks undercutting that treaty, as well as American laws and national security interests, by loosening regulatory controls on many of America’s own military exports.

headline: No Vacancies
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg said on the radio on Friday that New Yorkers are lucky to live in a city where apartments are so hard to find. “Somebody said that there’s not enough housing,” he said. “That’s a good sign. As fast as we build, more people want to live here.”

headline: Detectives Working on Police Tips Line Must Sift and Coax
text: Dozens of times each day, someone reaches for the phone and dials 1-800-577-TIPS, the anonymous tips line of the New York Police Department. Callers may be motivated by a guilty conscience, a desire for reward money, a keen sense of justice or some less classifiable impulse.

headline: Pirating Russia’s Hardwood
text: Hardwood timber from Russia’s Far East is being illegally cut and shipped to China to feed huge consumer demand for cheap wood products globally.

headline: Fordham Enjoying Renaissance, on a Smaller Scale
text: Once a week, Gabrielle Cremone, a sophomore at Fordham, volunteers to lead prospective students on tours through the serene campus in the Rose Hill neighborhood of the Bronx, walking past the Gothic-style buildings and 19th-century chapels. This semester, Cremone has added a new destination on her tour: the home of the emergent Fordham Rams football team.

headline: Long Island Man Faces Terrorism Charges After Failed Trip to Yemen
text: A Long Island man who the authorities say tried to fly to Yemen to join a branch of Al Qaeda was charged on Friday with conspiring to commit murder overseas and other terrorism counts.

headline: Final Race Will Test The Luck of Castroneves
text: Helio Castroneves was boarding a flight out of Houston last week, eager to clear his head of the weekend’s great disappointment: a broken gearbox scuttled what looked to be a clean shot at his first IndyCar Series championship.

headline: A Killing, a Puzzle: Self-Defense or Vigilantism
text: Nelson Acosta-Sanchez had proved surprisingly difficult to catch. Mr. Acosta-Sanchez, who was accused of the statutory rape of a 14-year-old girl, had already eluded capture, slipping out of the police’s grasp and later swimming across a reservoir before disappearing.

headline: Facebook’s New Rules
text: No sooner had the ink dried on my last column — about the new Dave Eggers’s novel “The Circle,” in which he imagines a world without privacy — than Facebook announced two changes to its privacy settings. In its short nine-year existence, Facebook has made many changes to its privacy policies, of course. More often than not, the changes have enabled the company to monetize the rich trove of data it collects from its users. When you get right down to it, that’s really all it has to sell.

headline: Juror in Tussle Over Taxi Is Taken Off Fraud Case
text: For two days, a defense lawyer sought to have a juror removed from a fraud case being tried in Federal District Court in Manhattan. And for two days the juror assured the judge that her impartiality had not been compromised and that she could carry on.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 18, 2013
Corrections: October 19, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: How’s It Goin’?
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t think I’ve had this much fun with a Saturday puzzle in a long time. There’s a certain amount of loin-girding that goes with solving the Saturday crossword puzzle. I love the challenge, but I know I’m going to have to really work for the answers. And work I do; I have always been honest about not being a speed solver or an expert, although I can tell you that my solving has certainly improved markedly with daily practice.

headline: More Laser Pointers Aimed at Airplanes, F.B.I. Reports
text: Reports of people aiming laser pointers at airplanes landing in the New York City area are up 17 percent compared with last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said on Friday as it sought information on a spate of recent incidents.

headline: States Are Focus of Effort to Foil Health Care Law
text: RICHMOND, Va. — The federal government is again open for business, and Republicans in Washington are licking their wounds from the failed Tea Party attempt to derail President Obama’s health care overhaul. But here in Virginia’s capital, conservative activists are pursuing a hardball campaign as they chart an alternative path to undoing “Obamacare” — through the states.

headline: Giants, the Stalwarts of a City, Suddenly Can’t Make It There
text: New York City is home to a noisy gaggle of professional sports teams shouting for attention.

headline: The President’s Pivot
text: “Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory.”

headline: Giants’ Losing Streak, by the Numbers
text: The Giants have lost their first six games, the team's worst start to a season since 1976 (and other unflattering facts about a team that won the Super Bowl two seasons ago).

headline: Lobbying Bonanza as Firms Try to Influence European Union
text: BRUSSELS — It was a show of force in keeping with the ambitions of American law firms that increasingly see the European Union’s vast apparatus as a vital lobbying opportunity for themselves and their multinational corporate clients.

headline: Against Jets, Patriots Can Do Without Thrills
text: BOSTON — Patriots and Red Sox fans are still celebrating Sunday’s back-to-back thrillers: a 30-27 victory with five seconds remaining against the previously undefeated New Orleans Saints and a series-changing 6-5 comeback victory against the Detroit Tigers in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series.

headline: Red Sox Will Stay With Drew, for His Glove if Not His Bat
text: BOSTON — The last time the Red Sox played in a Game 6 at Fenway Park was 2007, and J. D. Drew was one of the team’s heroes. Drew went 3 for 5 with a home run and 5 runs batted in, including a tone-setting, first-inning grand slam from which the Cleveland Indians never recovered.

headline: Roger Richman, 69, Dies; Lobbied for Stars’ Heirs
text: Roger Richman, a celebrity agent who is widely credited with helping to invent the dead-celebrity industry, a multimillion-dollar realm built on licensing the rights to images of the prominent posthumously, died on Oct. 9 in Los Angeles. He was 69.

headline: Cameras Found on L.I.R.R. Machines
text: Hidden cameras have been found attached to ticket vending machines on the Long Island Railroad, and the police are warning customers who have used the machines to check for any unauthorized activity on their credit or debit cards.

headline: Anthony Hinds, Who Scared British Moviegoers, Dies at 91
text: Anthony Hinds, the producer who put the horror in “Hammer horror,” in the process turning a puny British film studio into a Goliath of cinematic gore, died in Oxford, England on Sept. 30. He was 91.

headline: After Prison, Regret From Man Who Sold a Hoax to Try to Buy the Islanders
text: The man in the Islanders cap and sweatshirt partying with a dozen or so fans outside Nassau Coliseum last January was a specter from the team’s weirdest and maybe darkest days. It was John Spano, the businessman-turned-felon from Dallas who had nearly bought the team 16 years earlier, even though he never had the money to pay for it.

headline: Gloria Lynne, Singer of ‘I Wish You Love,’ Dies at 83
text: Gloria Lynne, a jazz diva who climbed onto the pop charts with her recording of “I Wish You Love” in 1964 and continued singing for more than half a century even in the face of poverty, died on Oct. 15 in Newark. She was 83.

headline: Giants Rush Hillis Onto Roster and Into Plans
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — If Peyton Hillis had reached the end of his professional football career, even at age 27, he was fine with that.

headline: Clustering Near the Seat of Power
text: Hundreds of businesses, organizations or lobbying firms that seek to influence the European government have outposts near the European Parliament in Brussels.

headline: Ralph Cook, a Pioneer of Off Off Broadway, Dies at 85
text: It was the kind of conversation that young restaurant employees in New York have surely had hundreds if not thousands of times since the early 1960s, when Ralph Cook was a waiter at the Village Gate, a nightclub in Greenwich Village.

headline: More Trouble for Rangers: Callahan Is Out With Broken Thumb
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers and the Devils are limping into their meeting in Newark on Saturday, looking to break out of their early-season misery.

headline: Outspoken Chinese Professor Says He Was Dismissed
text: HONG KONG — A politically outspoken Chinese economist, Xia Yeliang, will lose his professorship at Peking University, one of China’s most prestigious and internationally prominent schools, after a committee voted to dismiss him, Professor Xia said on Saturday. The decision came after months of contention over his future, which his supporters have said reflects the Communist Party’s efforts to deter liberal political views on campuses.

headline: Cardinals Win Pennant Once More, With Feeling
text: ST. LOUIS — By the end of the National League Championship Series, late Friday night, a cold, misty drizzle had settled over Busch Stadium. Nobody seemed to mind. The scoreboard read 9-0 in favor of the home team, just as it did last fall, when the Cardinals’ season slipped away in the San Francisco rain.

headline: Bum Phillips, Homespun Coach Behind Oilers’ Rise, Dies at 90
text: Bum Phillips, the homespun Texan who was caricatured as a cowboy but possessed a keen football mind that built the Houston Oilers into one of the National Football League’s leading teams of the late 1970s, died Friday at his ranch in Goliad, Tex. He was 90.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) MAMA (2013) In this modern fairy tale directed by Andy Muschietti, the uncle (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) of two feral sisters (Megan Charpentier, above, and Isabelle Nélisse), abandoned by their father in the woods, moves them into a home with his Goth girlfriend (Jessica Chastain). Then a grotesque figure the girls call Mama appears in the shadows and begins to wreak havoc on their lives. But is the monster simply a coping mechanism for dealing with tragedy? Or is Mama the essence of the girls’ dead mother? “Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that don’t often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you don’t want anyone to take an ax to them,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while the director, Guillermo del Toro, “the reigning godfather of motion picture horror,” took only an executive producing credit on the film, “it fits with the more successful movies he’s signed onto. Mr. del Toro understands that nothing says terror like a home that’s become a rattling cage.”

headline: Read!
text: The coolest library I’ve ever been to is in a book. It’s a literal labyrinth, made that way to scare off medieval monks from pursuing forbidden knowledge. There are 50-some seven-sided rooms and a few more square ones, and all of them have varying numbers of doors to the other rooms, and each is named after a Latin verse from the Apocalypse of John. Additional features include distorting mirrors, psychotropic herbs to induce visions and a ventilation system that whistles and feels like ghosts breathing on your face.

headline: Swap Frees Lebanese Held by Syrian Rebels in Exchange for Turks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A flurry of back-room Middle East diplomacy led to an ambitious international prisoner swap on Saturday that freed Lebanese citizens held by Syrian rebels and Turkish pilots kidnapped by Lebanese gunmen.

headline: Life in the Swamp
text: In early September 1863, a young Union soldier wrote a letter to his former professor back at Oberlin College, where he had studied before the war. The soldier, who identified himself only as “G,” had been tasked with taking a census of the freedmen on Craney Island, near Norfolk, Va. The African-American population of the area had been swelling since the arrival of Union forces the previous May, and soldiers like G were to provide the first step toward, among other things, organizing and recruiting black soldiers for the war effort.

headline: Suicide Blast in Somalia Kills 15, Police Say
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — More than a dozen people, including at least four Ethiopian soldiers, were killed Saturday in a suicide attack on a cafe in western Somalia, near the border with Ethiopia. The Shabab, the militant Somali Islamist group, claimed responsibility.

headline: ZLB Denial
text: Yes — if back in 2007 you denied the existence of liquidity traps, that is, denied that the zero lower bound on short-term interest rates places limits on monetary policy, you should long since have acknowledged that you were very, very wrong:

headline: Invitation to Veterans, Their Friends and Families
text: The editors of Home Fires are requesting the participation of readers for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11, 2013. If you are a veteran, or friend or relative of someone who served in the military and would like to share a written message or recollection, or a photograph recalling a veteran or their service, you can send it to us via e-mail at opinionator@nytimes.com.

headline: Do Currency Regimes Matter?
text: Antonio Fatas, citing new work by Andy Rose (pdf), suggests that currency regimes don’t really matter — in particular that membership in the euro has not really been a special problem for peripheral countries.

headline: High School Sexual Assault Case Is Revisited, Haunting Missouri Town
text: MARYVILLE, Mo. — The mayor of this small manufacturing town in northwest Missouri hardly blinks an eye these days when he gets an e-mail that calls him an unflattering name in the subject line. Those tend to be the tame ones. Others cut much deeper.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Wordplay, and indeed almost every other form of communication, would not exist without the subject of today’s acrostic. Michel Eyquem de Montaigne was considered to be the creator of the written essay and, as such, we can count him as the first blogger.

headline: Cardinals’ Strategy Replaces Big Names With Ingenuity
text: ST. LOUIS — Through the first five games of the National League Championship Series, one run separated the St. Louis Cardinals and the Los Angeles Dodgers. By the end of the series, the teams seemed worlds apart.

headline: With Series Clincher, Red Sox Ensure Memories Are Lasting
text: BOSTON — The Game 2 home run by David Ortiz that turned around the American League Championship Series was indelibly memorable as soon as it was hit. But now the image of Detroit’s Torii Hunter going headfirst into the Boston bullpen has become absolutely symbolic after the Red Sox, by winning the American League pennant on Saturday night at Fenway Park with a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers, reached their third World Series in 10 years.

headline: Seeing Things in Red and Blue After All
text: WASHINGTON — THE great irony of Barack Obama’s political rise is that it depended on what turned out to be his single biggest political miscalculation. From the moment he appeared on a national stage — in his 2004 “there is not a liberal America and a conservative America” speech — he held himself out as the leader who could transcend the partisan divide and win over Republicans.

headline: Val DiFebo of Deutsch NY, on Being Direct
text: This interview with  Val DiFebo,  chief executive of Deutsch NY, the advertising agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Lies, Damned Lies, and Fox News
text: The other day Sean Hannity featured some Real Americans telling tales of how they have been hurt by Obamacare. So Eric Stern, who used to work for Brian Schweitzer, had a bright idea: he actually called Hannity’s guests, to get the details.

headline: Vows | Mr. Duckett and Dr. Jones
text: Together 46 years, Lewis Duckett and Billy Jones wrote coded letters to each other during Dr. Jones’s deployment in Vietnam. They adopted a baby, became grandfathers and then, finally, got married.

headline: Cosmos Are Right Where They Want to Be
text: Around the North American Soccer League, a lament that rang true in the heyday of the league more than 30 years ago — the Cosmos are using their vast resources (Warner Communications then; an international group backed by the Saudi-based Sela Sports now) to buy championships — is again being heard from some less well-heeled clubs.

headline: Policing Village Moral Codes as Women Stream to India’s Cities
text: ROHTAK, India — Meena, 20, was a village girl herself, so she can recognize the changes that come when girls from the village arrive in this city as students and take their first gulps of freedom.

headline: How to Pay Millions and Lag Behind the Market
text: Today’s low-interest-rate environment has made the hunt for investment income tougher than ever. Many overseers of public pension funds, desperate to bolster returns and meet ballooning retiree obligations, have turned from traditional investments like stocks and bonds to hedge funds and private equity.

text: TO THE EDITOR:

text: CONCORD, N.C. — The cheating scandal at Richmond International Raceway that rocked Nascar more than a month ago continues to be felt in a sport whose credibility has been questioned by fans, the news media and even its drivers.

headline: Foreign Aid, Refined
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: In St. Louis, Celebrating a Team Long Gone
text: In the corridor of a St. Louis-area hotel last month, Sam Cash waited in line for autographs from members of the long-departed major league team known as the Browns. The signatures secured, he then sat at an adjacent table with his own Browns display that featured team trivia, a team time line and photographs of his favorite Browns player, Bud Thomas. Fans and several former Browns took a look.

headline: Driving a New Bargain on Health Care
text: The Affordable Care Act has gotten off to a rocky start. Federal and state online health insurance exchanges, which opened for business at the beginning of the month, have been bedeviled by technical snags. And opposition to the law from some House Republicans blocked funding for the entire federal government, leading to its partial shutdown.

headline: CMJ: Arcade Fire Takes the Stage. No, Not That One.
text: It was not a secret for long. Last week posters, looking like advertisements for a cheesy lounge promotion from the 1970s, appeared in Brooklyn announcing: “The Reflektors, 10/18 Brooklyn 10/19, Formal attire or costume mandatory. Prizes for best costumes!”

headline: Robert Shiller: A Skeptic and a Nobel Winner
text: Robert J. Shiller, a professor at Yale, learned on Monday that he had won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, along with Lars Peter Hansen and Eugene F. Fama of the University of Chicago. The Nobel committee described Professor Shiller as a founder of the field of behavioral finance, an innovator in incorporating psychology into economics and a pioneering analyst of speculative bubbles in the stock and real estate markets.
