text: The renowned chef and restauranteur discusses his cooking career and his ideas about food.

headline: From a Bitter End to a Fresh Chance for Freeman
text: Josh Freeman may one day thank Greg Schiano for chasing him out of Tampa Bay. That concept might be difficult for Freeman to imagine today, while the hurtful emotions of the sudden end of their quarterback-coach relationship are fresh.

headline: Alarming Abuses of Medical Credit Cards
text: Patients around the nation are being victimized by medical credit cards that can lead to financial calamity. These cards, issued by specialty finance companies as well as commercial banks, carry exorbitant interest rates after an initial period of zero interest expires — with heavy penalties for late payments. They are often pushed on patients with modest incomes by health care providers who want to make sure that they get paid, even if some of their patients end up with huge credit card bills they can’t afford. Unless strong regulatory action is taken to curb the abuses, financial companies will continue to gouge consumers at their most vulnerable moments, when they are in pain and need medical attention.

headline: World to Washington: ‘Really?’
text: PARIS — Not many Americans traveling abroad over the past three weeks could escape some fairly unpleasant reactions to the government shutdown in the United States.

headline: The Writing on the Wall
text: Art will abide. Artists will be with us always. And the news will surely live on, as long as humans remain curious and communicative.

headline: Europe’s Slow Progress on Banking Reform
text: The European Union last week moved one step closer to establishing a banking union that could help address problems in its financial system. But the Continent’s leaders need to act faster and do much more to end the long-running crisis.

headline: The High Cost of Low Politics
text: Early this year, it was widely acknowledged that the economy was in for a tough patch. The “fiscal cliff” showdown at the end of 2012 had led to higher payroll taxes and had locked in earlier cuts to jobless benefits, while “the sequester” — deep and arbitrary federal spending cuts enacted to end a previous debt standoff — kicked in on March 1. The only consolation at the time was that several economic forecasters expected conditions to improve later in the year.

headline: A Diaspora of 11 Million
text: Estimates of Roma populations vary. Figures on this map are from the Council of Europe, a human rights organization.

headline: Dina Katabi
text: Syrian-born Dina Katabi is a professor of electrical engineering and computer science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was awarded a MacArthur “genius grant” last month for her work on improving the speed, reliability and security of data networks.

headline: Here Comes the Neighborhood
text: SUBURBIA beckons many poor and working-class families with the promise of better schools, access to non-dead-end jobs and sanctuary from the looming threat of urban violence. But many suburbanites balk at the prospect of affordable housing in their midst.

headline: The Lessons of Japan’s Economy
text: BY many measures, Japan’s economic fortunes have turned up. The Tokyo stock market has surged about 65 percent since last fall. In the second quarter, the economy expanded by 3.8 percent, which is faster than other developed economies. At last, prices are edging upward, a good thing for Japan. Yet, the mood in Tokyo among businessmen and economists remains precariously balanced between enthusiasm for the monetary and fiscal stimulus unleashed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and worry that promised structural reforms might not be implemented.

headline: Cat on a Hot Stove
text: WASHINGTON — PRESIDENT OBAMA won big.

headline: Are Chicks Brighter Than Babies?
text: SOME Americans are wondering whether to eat chicken in the aftermath of the latest salmonella outbreak.

headline: Obamacare, Failing Ahead of Schedule
text: THIS is not the column about the Obamacare rollout I expected to write.

headline: Color Me Blue
text: “BLOOMBERG, love him or hate him?” a friend asked.

headline: Are the Roma Primitive, or Just Poor?
text: PARIS — THE cluster of Roma, handcuffed and caged-in behind glass walls, listened in silence as prosecutors accused them in court of selling child brides for up to about $270,000 in cash, valuing them based on their ability to steal. In a case that has riveted France, the prosecutors accused three family clans from Croatia of grooming girls and boys as young as 11 to steal as part of a gang that committed 100 robberies in France, Belgium and Germany in 2011.

headline: The Middle Class Gets Wise
text: Perhaps we underestimate ourselves. Five years after the Lehman collapse triggered the deepest recession in eight decades, the middle class may be solving the vexing problems of income inequality and stalled wages on its own.

headline: The Good Men of India
text: BANGALORE, India — IN India today, the rapes of women, from children to grandmothers, are daily news. Frothy television programs on sentimentalized family values are interrupted by advertisements for a new smartphone app: VithU, which allows women in danger, at a double press of a power button, to send an S O S alert with their location to predesignated friends and family members.

headline: Ma’am, Your Burger Has Been Paid For
text: IF you place an order at the Chick-fil-A drive-through off Highway 46 in New Braunfels, Tex., it’s not unusual for the driver of the car in front of you to pay for your meal in the time it took you to holler into the intercom and pull around for pickup.

headline: My Selfie, Myself
text: RECENTLY, I came across a great find in a Vermont antiques store: an old black-and-white photograph of a female pilot on a mountaintop, her aviator glasses pushed up on her forehead, revealing a satisfied, wind-burned face, the wings of her plane just visible behind her. But the best part of the discovery was the slow realization that she was holding the camera herself. It was, for lack of a better word, a “selfie.”

headline: Why We Make Bad Decisions
text: LONDON — SIX years ago I was struck down with a mystery illness. My weight dropped by 30 pounds in three months. I experienced searing stomach pain, felt utterly exhausted and no matter how much I ate, I couldn’t gain an ounce.

headline: Hearing an Irresistible Beat
A Washington Football Fan Breaks With Tradition
text: I am a third-generation fan of the professional football team in Washington. When my family sat down for pancakes last weekend, with a big game against Washington’s archrival, Dallas, looming on the eve of Columbus Day, I had to tell my children why we were not going to use the team’s nickname anymore.

headline: An Invention That Marinated for 19 Years
text: Mary Hunter has always been happy to cook for her congregation at the Yes Lord Church in Gary, Ind. Her recipes, she told me, come directly from God. “I don’t have a cookbook,” she said. “God gives me my own.” Prayer is “where I get 99 percent of my recipes.”

headline: When the Bosses Are Whispering
text: I’ve been in a new role at my company for three months, and I’ve felt rather left out of my new “team.” There’s a new department head, and I’ve been conveniently, or not so conveniently, forgotten in two meeting invitations when I should have been included.

headline: To Jets’ Ryan, the Passer Rating Really Does Mean Something
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Before Rex Ryan addresses his players after games, he is handed an index card loaded with the numbers that matter most to him. He glances at each team’s turnovers and combined total of runs and completions, and also a statistic that has long been derided and disparaged, mocked for its shortcomings in measuring the quarterback’s performance.

headline: Starting the Wine
text: In the predawn chill of a September morning, Mario Bazán, his wife, Gloria, and their crew of about 10 workers arrived to harvest sauvignon blanc grapes grown on a plot near their Napa Valley home. Helping them in their work was a generator with bright lights attached, pulled by a tractor. On this morning, they harvested enough grapes to produce 220 cases of Mario Bazán Cellars wine. Picking the grapes in the early morning means that they are cooler when they go into the collection bins, which helps keep the sugars in ideal condition.

headline: Tentative Deal Hands JPMorgan Chase a Record Penalty
text: Updated, 8:06 p.m. |

headline: A Harvest Before Dawn
text: The first steps toward producing this year’s sauvignon blanc at Mario Bazán Cellars are taken under a night sky in the Napa Valley of California.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 20
text: Congress reached a deal late Wednesday to end the 16-day government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling before the nation ran out of money to pay its bills. On Sunday lawmakers will weigh in on that agreement and what comes next as Congress faces another set of deadlines early next year.

headline: A Boy Who Played With Trains
text: My first job that mattered was on the Missouri Pacific Railroad, in 1963. I hired out — railroad lingo — as a locomotive fireman, working the switchyards in Little Rock, Ark. I was 19, and knew almost nothing about anything — certainly not about real work, and not about how work almost always affiliates you significantly with the lives of others.

headline: France Says Deportation of Roma Girl Was Legal
text: PARIS — A 15-year-old girl who was ordered off a school bus by French police officers so that she and her family could be sent back to Kosovo was legally deported, but the operation could have been conducted with more sensitivity, the French government said Saturday after an investigation.

headline: Seeking Online Refuge From Spying Eyes
text: Consider this scene in “The Circle,” Dave Eggers’s new novel that imagines a dystopian future dominated by an omnipotent social networking company: Mae, the young protagonist, tries to unplug from her hypernetworked life to go on a covert, solitary kayaking trip. But when she returns to shore, she is greeted by police officers who have been alerted to her excursion by several hidden cameras. She quickly realizes that very little in her life isn’t recorded, tracked and analyzed.

headline: Aid to Pakistan to Resume as Tension With U.S. Eases
text: WASHINGTON — The United States plans to give more than $1.5 billion in assistance to Pakistan for programs that had been blocked because of tension between the two nations over events including the Navy SEAL raid that killed Osama bin Laden inside Pakistan, American officials said Saturday.

headline: This Is War (for a Game Industry’s Soul)
text: The Swedish Army drafted Patrick Bach in the early 1990s and tried to make a soldier out of him. No such luck. Mr. Bach couldn’t see the point of pretending to protect a country at peace since the Napoleonic wars. The only part he liked was the shooting.

headline: Betting on Battlefield
text: Despite shifts in gaming platforms and public relations issues, Sweden’s Digital Illusions CE is betting millions on the latest version of its first person shooter franchise, Battlefield.

headline: In Sweden, a Breeding Ground for Video Games
text: The Scandinavian country has become a hotbed of video game development in recent years, and is home to the makers of several of the industry’s most recognized titles, including Battlefield and Minecraft.

headline: Hold the Drumstick! That’s an Intellectual You’re Eating!
text: My Sunday column looks at the ethical reasons to be wary of eating chicken, geese and other poultry produced in factory farms. My colleague Mark Bittman had an excellent column a few days ago about the health reasons to be wary, and in particular the salmonella risk. I agree with everything Mark said but want to go a step further. Even aside from the health issues, I think there are particular issues with the way poultry are raised, jammed in pens. Part of that is economics: it’s cheap to raise hens in cages, while cows and calves typically get pasture because that’s cheaper. And part of it is, I think, that we have some natural sympathy and regard for fellow mammals like cattle or hogs, but we dismiss birds as lower animals less deserving of our moral concern.

headline: Country Road
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — You might think that the solemn visage that looks down at us from the seated statue of Abraham Lincoln in Washington is the only memorial that exists for our SIXTEENTH U.S. PRESIDENT. And you’d be wrong.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, October 20

headline: The Sun Sets on a Symbol of Western-Themed Dining
text: SAUGUS, Mass. — The six-person booths in the Hilltop Steak House here were packed on a recent afternoon, and a line of customers stretched out the door. The wait for a table was two hours; by evening, it had grown to four.

headline: To Catch Up, Walmart Moves to Amazon Turf
text: SAN BRUNO, Calif. — A plucky Silicon Valley company, forced to compete for talented engineers, is trying it all — recruiting billboards on Highway 101; workplace perks like treadmill workstations and foosball tables; and conference rooms named after celebrities like Rihanna and Justin Bieber.

headline: Authors Accept Censors’ Rules to Sell in China
text: BEIJING — Chinese readers of Ezra F. Vogel’s sprawling biography of China’s reformist leader Deng Xiaoping may have missed a few details that appeared in the original English edition.

headline: Gun Sentiments and Guns on Display at Alamo Rally
text: SAN ANTONIO — Angela L. Pena brought her family to the Alamo on Saturday. She also brought her black assault rifle, a .223-caliber LWRC M4, and had it strapped across her back. Her daughter brought her M&P rifle; her son-in-law carried his .308-caliber Remington R-25; and her 8-year-old grandson, Sebastian Gonzalez, had his Ruger 10/22 rifle.

headline: Poised for ‘I Do’ as Soon as New Jersey Allows
text: Romance and bureaucracy are rarely a good match. But this weekend, gay couples in New Jersey are hurrying to overcome administrative hurdles, and plan weddings, before a court ruling that allows same-sex marriage in the state officially takes effect early on Monday.

headline: Six Killings in New York End a Lull in Murders
text: After a seven-day stretch in which no homicides were recorded in New York City, five occurred in 10 hours on Friday and Saturday, and another person was killed on Sunday morning.

headline: With Its Flashy League Gaining Buzz, Stanford Relies on Brawn
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Stanford resides out West, out in the Pacific-12 Conference, where sunshine and technology and an abundance of speed beget offenses that play football on fast forward. Where the scores often match the temperature, 50s and 60s posted deep into the fall.

headline: Two Russian Champions Capitalize on Mistakes
text: Peter Svidler won the national championship in Moscow last week by beating Ian Nepomniachtchi in a playoff. It was Svidler’s seventh Russian title in 20 years — an unmatched record.

headline: Lobbyists Ready for a New Fight on U.S. Spending

headline: After Misuse, a Push for Tutoring
text: A decade after it became law as a part of the federal No Child Left Behind Act, a tutoring program heralded as an academic safety net for children from low-income families in struggling schools has earned few champions — and lost many supporters.

headline: For Her Next Piece, a Performance Artist Will Build an Institute
text: In the name of art, she has hung naked on a wall and carved into her own stomach with a razor. She has masturbated in a museum; scrubbed at a pile of bloody, maggoty bones in a fetid basement; stood still while strangers put a gun to her head and stabbed her with thorns; and, in her best-known work, sat silently for seven hours a day, six days a week, as a succession of people lined up to bask in her aura at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Oct. 18, 2013
text: The federal government is up and running again after a last-minute deal that ended the shutdown and raised the debt ceiling so the government can pay its bills—for now. This week on Money Talking, WNYC contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine review the economic damage from the 16-day shutdown, what happens next, and how business leaders are considering getting involved in Republican primaries. Plus, what’s in store at Apple after the company hired the C.E.O. of Burberry to run its stores.

headline: Slow Ticket Sales for ‘The Fifth Estate’ and ‘Escape Plan’
text: Anything positive at the weekend box office was obscured by the smoking wreckage of two movies that bombed. “The Fifth Estate,” an Oscar hopeful centered on the WikiLeaks organization and produced for about $26 million by DreamWorks Studios, took in $1.7 million in wide release, for eighth place at North American theaters. “Escape Plan” (Lionsgate), starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone, arrived in fifth place, selling about $9.8 million in tickets. The Los Angeles Times reported that “Escape Plan” cost about $70 million to make, but a person who worked on it, speaking on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss financial information, insisted that the final budget was closer to $50 million.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE REUNION: 10 YEARS LATER The Fab Five of “Queer Eye for the Straight Guy” — clockwise from top left, Kyan Douglas, Carson Kressley, Thom Filicia, Jai Rodriguez and Ted Allen — reminisce about the effect of the series on their lives and those of viewers. Andy Cohen moderates the discussion, which includes their favorite “make-betters,” their most challenging subjects and who came out as a result of the show.

headline: An Echo of Rachmaninoff
text: For lovers of 20th-century Russian music in New York, the still-young season has offered a veritable banquet: great dollops of Shostakovich and savory side dishes of Stravinsky and Rachmaninoff. Amid this feast, alert listeners have undoubtedly turned up delicious little surprises and juxtapositions.

headline: An Opera Fights Hungary’s Rising Anti-Semitism
text: BUDAPEST — Ivan Fischer is best known as a first-class conductor whose Budapest Festival Orchestra has entranced audiences worldwide. Last week, Mr. Fischer took on a new role — social critic — when the orchestra gave the premiere of an opera he had composed as a rebuke to what he and others see as growing tolerance for anti-Semitism in today’s Hungary.

headline: A Subway Car With Fewer Doors, but More Ways Out
text: For decades, the New York City subway car has been a predictable space. Some have seats; some have benches. Graspable pole options vary only slightly. Mariachi bands play, and self-appointed preachers preach.

headline: Rice Approaches New Role With Diplomacy
text: STANFORD, Calif. — John Wesley Rice played football and coached football. He loved football. He was an offensive tackle, and he taught his daughter to appreciate line play and games called on the radio, and they religiously followed the Alabama Crimson Tide and the Cleveland Browns.

headline: After Losing Rangers Spot, Biron Says He Will Retire
text: Goalie Martin Biron, who delighted teammates, fans and reporters during a 16-season N.H.L. career, announced his retirement Sunday, less than a week after being waived by the Rangers and assigned to their American Hockey League affiliate.

headline: Humans Can Be Irrational, and Other Economic Insights
text: Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, writes in his new book, “The Map and the Territory,” that he has been thinking about bubbles since the financial crisis of 2008. Specifically, he has been trying to understand why he and so many other economic forecasters failed to see the housing bubble that caused the crisis.

headline: After Nearly 90 Years, Ford Wants China to Give It a Second Chance
text: HONG KONG — General Motors now sells far more Buicks in China than in the United States, partly by playing on its history as the brand in which Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founder of modern China, was chauffeured around.

headline: Cloudy Forecast for Holiday Spending Prompts More Promotion
text: THE 2013 holiday season was already challenging for retailers and marketers, with fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas and continued uncertainty over the economy. Now, after the government shutdown, as some analysts predict that consumers will trim holiday budgets by about 2 percent, efforts are being redoubled to woo reluctant shoppers.

text: Accounts

headline: Questions for Free-Market Moralists
text: In 1971 John Rawls published “A Theory of Justice,” the most significant articulation and defense of political liberalism of the 20th century. Rawls proposed that the structure of a just society was the one that a group of rational actors would come up with if they were operating behind a “veil of ignorance” — that is, provided they had no prior knowledge what their gender, age, wealth, talents, ethnicity and education would be in the imagined society. Since no one would know in advance where in society they would end up, rational agents would select a society in which everyone was guaranteed basic rights, including equality of opportunity. Since genuine (rather than “on paper”) equality of opportunity requires substantial access to resources — shelter, medical care, education — Rawls’s rational actors would also make their society a redistributive one, ensuring a decent standard of life for everyone.

headline: Lawyer’s Graphic Novels, Anything but Brief
text: LOS ANGELES — “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?” Philip K. Dick asked in the title of a novel that became the basis of the movie “Blade Runner.”

headline: China’s Mountains of Construction Rubble
text: The demolition of old structures to clear way for urban development in China has some well-known consequences, notably the violence associated with forcibly removing people from their homes. But in recent years, the country has been increasingly faced with another unwelcome byproduct of the drive to tear down and rebuild: mountains of construction debris.

headline: Spinning Horror Into Gold
text: LOS ANGELES — At first glance, there is nothing particularly special about Jason Blum. He makes low-cost horror films that sell a lot of tickets. Producers have been getting rich from that formula for decades: rinse (the fake blood) and repeat.

headline: Horror’s Head Honcho
text: The Hollywood producer Jason Blum has turned a decade of horror into more than a billion dollars at the box office.

headline: Artwork on Foot Attracts New Vantage Points
text: At the Museum of Modern Art on Friday, I turned a corner and ran into a man well over six feet tall dressed as Martha Graham. This was the dancer Richard Move, celebrated for his impersonations of that modernist choreographer. For a while, he wandered like any other visitor, looking at the art. But Mr. Move also was the art. The Graham choreography he performed was an exhibit, yet so was he: a dancer as a living archive of dance.

headline: Redemption, and It’s Good, as Jets Foil Patriots
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When it was over, the Jets scurried off the field. They dashed through the tunnel, slapping hands with jubilant fans above, toward their locker room, toward relevance and respect and the promise of excitement still to come.

headline: Standing Up for Muslims in India’s Courts
text: “Shahid,” a Hindi film directed by Hansal Mehta, is the story of a hero, though not in the typical Bollywood sense. Based on the life and death of Shahid Azmi, a Mumbai lawyer known for defending Muslims accused of terrorist acts, Mr. Mehta’s movie is about one man’s moral response to injustice.

headline: Behind the Facade of a Carefree Hip-Hop Girl Group
text: In 1997, VH1 introduced “Behind the Music,” a docu-series that turned pop star biography into telenovela. The formula congealed quickly: bright spark, rapid ascendance, limitless potential, tragic flaw, rapid collapse, mild but needed redemption. Whether it was Judas Priest or Dr. Dre or Goo Goo Dolls, the message was clear: Drama doesn’t discriminate.

headline: Playing to the Classical Set and to the YouTube Crowd
text: The dynamic Ukrainian-born pianist Valentina Lisitsa fully acknowledges there was savvy reinvention in the way she jump-started her stalled career to become a YouTube sensation and a touring artist with a prestigious Decca recording contract. The combination of her fluid, impetuous playing and her glamorous persona proved ideal for the Internet. She has over 100,000 YouTube subscribers and has had more than 60 million views.

headline: AT&T in $4.85 Billion Tower Deal With Crown Castle
text: AT&T agreed on Sunday to lease or sell 9,700 cellphone towers to Crown Castle International, a big wireless tower operator, for $4.85 billion in cash.

headline: On Brooklyn Stoops, Artist Cultivates Debate
text: Suzanne Lacy has a long history of creating political performances that encourage dialogue. And on Saturday night her first major New York work, “Between the Door and the Street,” brought together close to 400 women — “and a few good men,” as Ms. Lacy likes to say — on the stoops and courtyards of a block in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, to discuss gender-related aspects of issues like poverty, violence and immigration.

headline: Online Retailers Fear a Dreary Holiday Shopping Season
text: The government might be reopened, but online retailers are worried about whether the uncertainty the shutdown created, along with broader economic woes, could mean a dreary holiday season for online shoppers.

headline: Vigilantes Defeat Boko Haram in Its Nigerian Base
text: BENISHEIK, Nigeria — The men from Boko Haram came tearing through this rural town, setting fire to houses, looting, shooting and yelling, “God is great!” residents and officials said. The gunmen shot motorists point-blank on the road, dragged young men out of homes for execution and ordered citizens to lie down for a fatal bullet.

headline: As Downloads Dip, Music Executives Cast a Wary Eye on Streaming Services
text: As sales of CDs plunged over the last decade, the music industry clung to one comfort: downloads continued to sell briskly as people filled their computers and iPods with songs by the billions.

headline: Just Before Going Airborne
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — You know, there is only so much commentary that one can take before one starts to get a bit paranoid about what the constructors are trying to say. Take the latest from Gary Cee, for example. In case you missed the mini theme that opens and closes the puzzle, Mr. Cee feels that we are both CATTY and SEEDY and he is trying to RUN AWAY, BREAK OUT, ESCAPE and TAKE OFF.

headline: Writer Brings in the World While She Keeps It at Bay

headline: Mayoral Race Threatens to Shake Up Tradition Where Jesus Grew Up

The local party slate he heads, the Nazareth Democratic Front, a coalition of the Communist Party and other groups, has been running the city since 1975.

headline: Restoring Brooklyn’s Pastoral Heart
text: For years, the Kate Wollman Memorial Rink in Prospect Park was a fenced-off, decrepit relic of the take-no-prisoners approach that New York’s planning czar Robert Moses brought to urban renewal during the 1950s. Skaters suffered its musty lockers and dubious hot dogs until a couple of years ago, when the wrecking ball mercifully arrived to make room for a new skating and entertainment complex.

headline: Marathon of the Formulaic and Eclectic
text: In 2004, Arcade Fire was the new band everyone wanted to see at the CMJ Music Marathon, the annual New York showcase that packs more than 1,300 club sets into five days. Arcade Fire became the decade’s quintessential CMJ success story, as glowing reviews and word of mouth from the band’s independent-label debut album and small Lower East Side club shows propelled it onto radio and, eventually, to arena shows and an Album of the Year Grammy Award for its 2010 release, “The Suburbs.”

headline: Dozens Killed by Bombers at Baghdad Cafe
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber blew himself up inside a crowded cafe on Sunday, and moments later, as bystanders rushed to help the wounded, another suicide attacker detonated a car bomb at the scene, the Iraqi police said. Together, the explosions killed 54 people and wounded more than 70.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 21
text: EUROPEAN PRIVACY One of the most heavily lobbied pieces of European Union legislation in years, the Data Protection Regulation, could inch another step forward Monday evening when the justice committee of the European Parliament is expected to vote on whether to begin negotiating a final draft with bloc governments. Recent amendments to the law, which is aimed at expanding privacy rights, include a measure that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking to collect private data.

A glut of lobsters during the previous summer had pushed lobster prices to a 40-year low, while the cost of bait, fuel and complying with state and federal regulations seemed to creep ever upward.

headline: Contractors See Weeks of Work on Health Site
text: Federal contractors have identified most of the main problems crippling President Obama’s online health insurance marketplace, but the administration has been slow to issue orders for fixing those flaws, and some contractors worry that the system may be weeks away from operating smoothly, people close to the project say.

headline: Questions Surround Death of 2 Bay Area Transit Workers as Strike Continues
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Federal authorities on Sunday said they were investigating an accident that killed two workers for the Bay Area Rapid Transit system on Saturday, less than 48 hours after employees of the commuter railroad went on strike.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 20, 2013
The National Guard’s Defiance on Civil Rights
text: In August, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel announced that the Defense Department would begin offering full spousal and family benefits, including health care coverage, housing allowances and survivor benefits, to the same-sex spouses of military personnel. In doing so he swiftly aligned the military with the Supreme Court’s ruling in June striking down the Defense of Marriage Act’s denial of federal marriage benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples.

headline: A Way to Salvage Global Trade Talks
text: After more than a decade of fruitless talks to lower trade barriers, officials from more than 150 countries are back at the negotiating table. This time, they are hoping to reach a much more modest agreement by the end of the year that could provide a needed economic boost to the global economy.

headline: An Exit Strategy From Afghanistan
text: As it winds down its 12-year-old military commitment in Afghanistan, the United States is still looking for a face-saving way out of a conflict that seems headed, at best, for a stalemate. The new bilateral security agreement between the two nations is part of that exit strategy. So is a hoped-for political settlement with the Taliban, on which there has been no progress, and a 2014 presidential election process that is also having problems.

headline: Lousy Medicaid Arguments
text: For now, the big news about Obamacare is the debacle of HealthCare.gov, the Web portal through which Americans are supposed to buy insurance on the new health care exchanges. For now, at least, HealthCare.gov isn’t working for many users.

headline: Another Backside Debacle, This Time at Patriots’ Expense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — About 11 months ago, the Jets lost a game against the New England Patriots, at least in part because of a butt fumble. On Sunday, they won a game against the Patriots, at least in part because of a butt push.

headline: 0-6 Giants Will Be Tested at the One Thing They’ve Done Well
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There are not many things the winless Giants have done well this season. There is probably only one significant, measurable category in which they have had modest success: stopping the opposing team’s featured running back.

headline: The Doomed Queen of France, Stripped Bare
text: One of history’s most fabled material girls is having to do without these days. Her wardrobe has been reduced to one red strapless number — kind of divine, but not all-occasion wear — and, for her final days, a stained chemise. As for all those towering wigs, they have been shrunk to the dimensions of a Park Avenue bouffant.

headline: Grisham’s Tale Retold Onstage
text: The ceiling fans keep twirling away up there on the stage of the John Golden Theater on Broadway, as if to dispel all the heat and tension gathering in the courtroom where much of “A Time to Kill,” a stage adaptation of the John Grisham novel, takes place. But the producers might have saved a little on the electricity bill.

headline: Manning Receives a Warm Welcome Back, but Luck Gets the Victory
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Sunday evening at Lucas Oil Stadium was like a bobblehead doll promotion in reverse. The occasion was Peyton Manning’s first game here since he was let go by the Colts and found the Fountain of Youth in Denver. Instead of Colts fans receiving a ceramic reproduction of Manning, they gave Manning roughly 60,000 flesh-and-blood facsimiles of himself.

headline: Writing a Budget to Prevent Another Shutdown
text: The G.O.P. ended its standoff last week, but the deals were temporary. Can Congress and the White House negotiate a budget early next year?

headline: For the Vikings’ Peterson, the Death of a Young Son Is Another Devastating Turn
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — Several of Adrian Peterson’s teammates created such a commotion Thursday, whooping and laughing as they entered the Minnesota Vikings’ locker room, that Peterson had to repeat his explanation for missing practice the day before.

headline: U.S. Deal With JPMorgan Followed a Crucial Call
text: At a museum on Fifth Avenue, in a sparkling reception hall overlooking Central Park, Jamie Dimon convened his top executives and their spouses last month for the Wall Street equivalent of a pep rally.

headline: Crash Course on Speaking in Tongues, All 22 of Them

headline: Jets Close-Up
text: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Antonio Allen played linebacker at South Carolina before moving to safety in the N.F.L., and the Jets are fond of his physical style. That is why they put him on the Patriots’ hulking tight end, Rob Gronkowski, who caught eight passes for 117 yards in his season debut but was also stymied a number of times. This happened most notably on the Patriots’ opening drive of the second half, when Allen slipped underneath Gronkowski and returned Tom Brady’s pass 23 yards for a touchdown.

headline: At 12:01, Same-Sex Couples in New Jersey Say ‘I Do’
text: In Lambertville, N.J., the marriage certificate of Beth Asaro and Joanne Schailey allowed only for a “bride” and a “groom,” so Ms. Asaro — in a pink suit — was listed as the groom, and Ms. Schailey — in a black suit — as the bride.

headline: Red Sox and Cardinals Meet Again
text: The Boston Red Sox have made it to the World Series seven times since World War II and, often enough, when they arrive, the St. Louis Cardinals are waiting for them.

headline: Clashing Views of China’s Human Rights Record at U.N. Hearing
text: Examining the hundreds of pages of submissions to the latest United Nations hearing on human rights in China, a reader might almost think that two very different countries face scrutiny in Geneva on Tuesday.

headline: Scoliosis Can Hit Well Past Adolescence
text: On a family trip to the Grand Canyon three summers ago, my son Erik, who was hiking behind me, remarked, “Mom, your right hip is higher than your left.”

headline: Breast Milk Donated or Sold Online Is Often Tainted, Study Says
text: A cottage industry has sprung up facilitating the sale and donation of human breast milk on the Internet, but a study published Monday in the journal Pediatrics confirms the concerns of health professionals over this unregulated marketplace.

headline: Letter from Dr. Sun Yat-sen to Henry Ford and Ford’s response
text: Dr. Sun, a medical doctor and revolutionary who briefly became the first president of China in 1912, wrote to Henry Ford in 1924, in an exchange of letters released in Hong Kong by Ford Motor on Sunday night.

headline: A Broadway Run for ‘Bronx Bombers’
text: “Bronx Bombers,” a play centered around the Yankees and some their biggest stars from the last century, completed a short Off Broadway run on Saturday. But the producers are to announce on Monday that a move to Broadway is set for January with the actors Peter Scolari (“Lucky Guy”) and his wife, Tracy Shayne (“Chicago”), taking over the roles of Yogi and Carmen Berra from Richard Topol and Wendy Makkena. The rest of the cast from the Off Broadway production — which included Christopher Jackson as Derek Jeter, Francois Battiste as Reggie Jackson, and Chris Henry Coffey as Joe DiMaggio — will return. Previews of the play, written and directed by Eric Simonson, are set to begin on Jan. 10 at Circle in the Square Theater, with an opening night on Feb. 6.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 7
text: Action from the Jets’ 30-27 win over the Patriots at MetLife Stadium, a victory against a fierce rival for the Jets to savor.

headline: Spanking’s Link to Bad Behavior
text: Spare the rod and spoil the child? A new study suggests that the opposite may be true: spanking could increase the risk of bad behavior.

headline: Word of the Day | onomatopoeia

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) LIFE ACCORDING TO SAM (2013) In 1998, Dr. Leslie Gordon and Dr. Scott Berns discovered that their 2-year-old son, Sam, above, had progeria, a rare and untreatable progressive aging disorder that leads the children afflicted with it — at the time, fewer than 250 in the world — eventually to die of a heart attack or stroke at an average age of 13. But the couple weren’t about to give up on finding a cure, or empowering their son to enjoy life. Sam is now 17, a high school junior and an avid sports fan who excels at his studies, music and friendships. “I didn’t put myself in front of you to have you feel bad for me,” Sam says at the beginning of this documentary, directed by Sean Fine and Andrea Nix Fine. “I put myself in front of you to let you know you don’t need to feel bad for me.” His mother responds: “You are handed something, and what you do with it is what matters, and that’s what Sam is doing. I’m impressed continually by him.”

headline: Globalfest Acts Are Announced
text: Globalfest, an annual festival designed to showcase a variety of international musicians, has announced the lineup that will perform at Webster Hall in January. The one-night event is to feature a dozen acts, including Fanfare Ciocarlia, a Romanian brass band; Hassan Hakmoun,  a Moroccan artist who focuses on Gnawa trance music; and Wu-Force, a folk group that features Abigail Washburn, Kai Welch and Wu Fei. Now in its 11th year, Globalfest is scheduled for Jan. 12 and will take place on three separate stages. Among the other artists to perform are Baloji, an Afropop rapper, and Como Mamas, a gospel a cappella trio from Mississippi.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday October 21, 2013
text: “If you get milk from an unscreened sharer, you put your child at risk. I hate to say this to an informal sharer, because they are trying to do good. But they are playing a game of Russian roulette.”

headline: Beijing Marathoners Offend With ‘Wetting the Red Walls’
text: “Wetting the red walls,” it’s being dubbed. After participants in the Beijing Marathon on Sunday stood in rows to urinate against some of the high vermilion walls of the imperial palaces and gardens of the Forbidden City complex in the center of the city, people are asking: Has public peeing become an unfortunate and unhygienic tradition of the event?

headline: State Media Call Starbucks Too Pricey
text: The Chinese state news media have begun an attack on Starbucks, calling the coffee chain wildly expensive. Chinese consumers so far have responded with a yawn, and perhaps another latte.

headline: ‘Airpocalypse’ Hits Harbin, Closing Schools
text: Updated, 8:22 a.m. | School was canceled, traffic was nearly paralyzed and the airport was shut down in the northeast Chinese city of Harbin on Monday as off-the-charts pollution dropped visibility to less than 10 meters in parts of the provincial capital.

headline: A Conversation With: Historian Ramachandra Guha
text: Ramachandra Guha is one of India’s foremost public intellectuals and historians. “Gandhi Before India,” his first volume of a two-part biography of Mohandas K. Gandhi, was published in India earlier this month. India Ink spoke to Mr. Guha about his decision to work on a biography of Mr. Gandhi, his choice to make Mr. Gandhi’s years in South Africa as the first volume of the biography, and Mr. Gandhi’s journey from a boy in the western state of Gujarat to his return to India as a major political figure.

headline: China Arrests Prominent Businessman Who Backed Rights Causes
text: HONG KONG — The police in Beijing have formally arrested a prominent Chinese businessman who turned his energies and wealth to supporting human rights causes, his lawyer said on Monday. The arrest of the businessman, Wang Gongquan, was another step in the Communist Party’s drive to deter dissent, supporters said. Notice of the decision comes a day before China is scheduled to defend its human rights record at a United Nations hearing.

headline: Chinese Billionaire May Privatize Hong Kong Developer
text: HONG KONG – Zhang Zhirong, a mainland Chinese billionaire who was involved in an insider trading case in the United States last year, may make a privatization bid for his property development company in Hong Kong.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Oct. 21, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Deal to Build a British Nuclear Plant Assumes a Role for Government
text: LONDON — In a back-to-the-future bet on its energy policy, the British government announced a long-elusive $26 billion deal on Monday to build the first new nuclear power station in Britain since 1995.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | World Series Matchup Set
text: In “Victorino’s Slam Sends Red Sox to World Series,” David Waldstein writes about the baseball teams that will face one another in this year’s World Series.

headline: High in Nepal, a Lowly Status for Women
text: A woman crouches in a doorway, hay at her sandaled feet and a cow to her left. She looks ahead, a pained stare on her face. This is where she lives, for now.

headline: When Is the Last Time You Did Something Nice for a Stranger?
text: Doing nice things for strangers isn’t something that just came about, but in recent years, “paying it forward” has become a trend.

headline: New York Today: Gay Marriage Crosses the River
text: Updated 1:10 p.m. | On the day that gay marriages were first performed in New York in 2011, supporters in New Jersey gathered on a pier in Hoboken.

headline: Chasing Cars: It’s Ultimately About the Bottom Line
text: “The Car Chasers,” an auto-themed reality show on CNBC, comes back for a second season of wheeling and dealing on Tuesday. Jeff Allen, the owner of Flat 12 Gallery in Lubbock, Tex., roams the countryside looking for bargains that he and his team — including his bottom-line-oriented wife, Meg Bailey; his fixer, Perry Brandt; and a master mechanic, Eric Ables — can flip for a profit.

headline: The Umbilical Link of Man to Robot
text: WORCESTER, Mass. — Atlas doesn’t shrug. But he teeters, loses his grip, stutters and staggers.

headline: In Russia, Even Good News Is Bad
text: MOSCOW — I was about to turn off my computer late Friday night when a letter arrived saying that the bill that would take parental rights away from Russia’s gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender parents had been recalled from the Duma. And then I could not sleep.

headline: Fear vs. Radiation: The Mismatch
text: CAMBRIDGE, Massachusetts — It has been more than two and a half years since the Fukushima nuclear disaster began to unfold, and still the world watches events closely, fearfully. The drumbeat of danger seems never ending: Earlier this month, to take just one example, international news reports spread word that six workers at the plant had been accidentally doused with radioactive water.

headline: A Woman for All Seasons
text: BERLIN — When an 8-year-old girl on the Berlin subway asks her mother if it’s possible to have a male chancellor, you know something profound has changed in Germany. A woman ruling the country is not just the new normal; for millions of German children — including my daughters, ages 7 and 10 — it is the only normal they have ever known.

headline: Scalded by Coffee, Then News Media
text: In 1992, Stella Liebeck spilled scalding McDonald’s coffee in her lap and later sued the company, attracting a flood of negative attention. It turns out there was more to the story.

headline: Not Just a Hot Cup Anymore
text: More than 20 years ago, 79-year-old Stella Liebeck ordered coffee at a McDonald’s drive-through in Albuquerque, N.M. She spilled the coffee, was burned, and one year later, sued McDonald’s. The jury awarded her $2.9 million. Her story became a media sensation and fodder for talk-show hosts, late-night comedians, sitcom writers and even political pundits. But cleverness may have come at the expense of context, as this Retro Report video illustrates. And below, a consumer affairs reporter for The Times reflects on how the world has changed since the lawsuit.

headline: A Start-Up’s Documentary Series Tells Stories of Start-Ups
text: Gary Bredow has always been curious about how the businesses he patronizes started, whether it’s a local bakery, a pizza place or a hardware store. “I always wondered about how they got their inventory, how they leased the store or where they got the idea in the first place,” Mr. Bredow said.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 21, 2013
text: Updated: Oct. 22, 2013

headline: Daily Report: New Bids for Dominating the Tablet Market
text: The race for the tablet market has become a full-blown sprint, and the intense competition will be highlighted on Tuesday, as Apple, Nokia and Microsoft each introduce new tablets, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Week 7 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Inexcusable Broncos Blunder
text: Andy Benoit takes a quick tour through Week 7, from the Chiefs’ 7-0 start to a scary neck injury for the Packers’ Jermichael Finley.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Starts Spending His Billion-Dollar Charitable Fund
text: Last December, Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, and his wife, Priscilla Chan, donated 18 million shares of the company’s stock to the Silicon Valley Community Foundation. At the time, the billionaire couple said they would direct money from their foundation fund, then valued at nearly $500 million, to unspecified education and health causes.

headline: A Crucial Call From JPMorgan’s Chief
text: In late September, four hours before the Justice Department planned to hold a news conference to announce civil charges against JPMorgan Chase over its sale of troubled mortgage securities, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, personally called one of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s top lieutenants to reopen settlement talks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The call scuttled the news conference and set in motion weeks of negotiations that have led to a tentative $13 billion deal, people briefed on the talks said.

headline: History in Jewels
text: A Parisian house marks 400 years of work with sparkling stones.

headline: The Lackluster Reviews That Lawyers Love to Hate
text: WASHINGTON — “Would you want The New England Journal of Medicine to be edited by medical students?” asked Richard A. Wise, who teaches psychology at the University of North Dakota.

headline: Ruling on Katyn Killings Highlights Russia-Poland Rift
text: LONDON — In the long-simmering and emotional debate over a notorious mass killing during World War II, the European Court of Human Rights ruled Monday that Russia had failed to comply with its obligations to adequately investigate the massacre of more than 20,000 Polish prisoners of war by the Soviet secret police in 1940.

headline: Madame Tussaud’s and an Energy Company Seek to Go Public
text: The parent of Madame Tussaud’s and a clean energy business backed by the financier Guy Hands each said on Monday that they planned to go public on the London Stock Exchange, as their private equity owners seek to begin cashing out of their investments.

headline: Gaming the Future With EA’s Frank Gibeau
text: Frank Gibeau is a veteran gaming executive who until recently was in charge of console and PC game development at Electronic Arts, a gaming colossus that has had some misfires and queasy moments in recent years.

headline: Chinese Court Says It Will Rule on Bo Xilai’s Appeal
text: HONG KONG — A provincial court in eastern China said Monday that it would deliver its decision on Friday on an appeal against the prison sentence for the former politician Bo Xilai.

headline: U.S. Exchanges Set to Compete for Alibaba I.P.O.
text: The two big stock exchanges in the United States are ready to fight for the right to host the initial public offering of the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant.

headline: European Court Rules Spain Must Free Terrorist
text: MADRID — The European Court of Human Rights ruled Monday against a Spanish law that has allowed the Madrid government to extend the imprisonment of convicted terrorists and members of ETA, the Basque separatist group.

headline: For Star Athlete I.P.O., a Stumble on the Field
text: The “road show” for the Arian Foster initial public offering has gotten off to a disappointing start.

headline: Today in Small Business: Drywall Contractors
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: As Gays Wed in New Jersey, Christie Ends Court Fight
text: As couples across New Jersey began marrying on Monday after the stroke of midnight, Gov. Chris Christie abandoned his long fight against same-sex marriage, concluding that signals from the court and the march of history were against him.

headline: In Performance: Frances Barber
text: Frances Barber performs a scene as the title character in the Donmar Warehouse production of Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar,” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.

headline: In Performance: Frances Barber
text: The Donmar Warehouse’s all-female production of “Julius Caesar,” directed by Phyllida Lloyd, is set in a high-security women’s prison. In this scene, Caesar, played by the actress Frances Barber, addresses the senate right before he is assasinated by conspirators (or in the case of this version, fellow prisoners), including his close friend Brutus.

headline: Carol Burnett Cracks Up Washington
text: Decades after Carol Burnett made a place for women in sketch comedy with her namesake variety show, she stood onstage at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Sunday night to be recognized for her contributions to American society and to accept the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor.

headline: French Condemn Surveillance by N.S.A.
text: PARIS — The French government castigated the United States on Monday for carrying out extensive electronic eavesdropping within France, the latest diplomatic backlash against the National Security Agency’s wide surveillance net and another example of how disclosures about the program have strained relations — at least temporarily — with even the closest of Washington’s allies.

headline: Matchups Set for Europe’s Last Cup Spots
text: Portugal will play Sweden and France will face a tough November home-and-home against Ukraine when eight teams from Europe square off for the continent’s final four places in next summer’s World Cup in Brazil.

headline: Potential Silver Lining for S.E.C. in the Cuban Case
text: No one likes to lose, so the Securities and Exchange Commission is surely smarting from a jury’s decision absolving Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, of insider trading charges. Although the case garnered headlines, it is unlikely to have much effect on other investigations, and even has a potential silver lining for the S.E.C.

headline: A Landmark Building With a Fraught History
text: The Belnord is a powerfully built limestone rental building that occupies an entire city block on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Many windows are the width of a grown woman’s wingspan. The outer walls, as if built for a fortress, are nearly a foot thick. And the building has a 22,000-square-foot interior courtyard sprouting with well-manicured trees. Some of its apartments ask for $35,000, even $45,000, a month.

headline: Biopic on Life of Lawyer Murdered in Mumbai
text: On Feb. 11, 2010, I returned to Mumbai after a reporting assignment in Hyderabad. A rare weekend off with family, it was also my niece’s birthday. I switched my phone to silent mode to avoid work-related phone calls and tried to play host to a bunch of kids who were home.

headline: By Design | Paul Smith Reintroduces Himself
text: Known for bringing a warm, whimsical touch to classic men’s wear, Paul Smith may be one of fashion’s savviest eccentrics. Beginning next month, the Design Museum in London honors his nearly 45 years as a designer with “Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith,” a landmark retrospective of his smartly tailored, impeccably British ensembles for men and women, his charming collaborations — everything from Mini Coopers to Leica cameras — and his voluminous collection of oddball curios from around the world, quirky bits of inspiration that helped the designer bring his trademark twist to the venerable pinstripe. “Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith,” at the Design Museum in London, Nov. 15 to March 9; designmuseum.org.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: October 18-20, 2013
text: The severely mentally ill have easy access to guns in Oklahoma, The Oklahoman reported yesterday. Gerald David Hume, a diagnosed schizophrenic, was able to purchase rifles and a handgun at Walmart and Gun World in Oklahoma City in November, which he used to shoot his 77-year-old mother to death. He then dismembered her body.

headline: Cahill’s Goal: It’s the ‘Fizz’
text: There are no photographs of Tim Cahill’s lightning fast goal at Houston on Sunday, probably because the photographers assigned to cover the game were as stunned and surprised as the Dynamo and Cahill’s Red Bulls teammates.

headline: After Storm, Toxic Water Overflows in Japan
text: TOKYO — The operator of Japan’s wrecked nuclear plant said Monday that rainwater from a weekend storm became contaminated as it collected behind barriers meant to stop radiation leaks. The toxic water overflowed those barriers at several locations, with some of it possibly spilling into the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Tim Griffin of Arkansas Will Not Seek Third Congressional Term
text: Representative Tim Griffin, a two-term Republican who represents a politically competitive district in Arkansas, said Monday that he will not seek a third term.

headline: Rihanna Asked to Leave Mosque in Abu Dhabi
text: Rihanna was asked to leave the site of the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi after posing for photographs there over the weekend that the shrine’s overseers said had violated the “sanctity” of the site.

headline: Suicide Bomber Strikes Bus in Southern Russia
text: MOSCOW — It was impossible not to notice her, one witness said. The young Muslim woman, her head covered by a light green scarf, boarded the No. 29 bus in the city of Volgograd and took a seat near the back. She rode for two stops, quietly looking out the window as the bus zipped along Azure Street. Then she blew herself up.

headline: A Colorado Hotel With Plenty of Paleontology
text: Visitors to the Denver area can now spend a night in the museum –or at least at a dinosaur-themed hotel that is also part natural history museum.

headline: Martin Gardner’s Big Surprise
text: This week we’ll be continuing our celebration of the life and many interests of the popular math and science writer Martin Gardner with a special birthday post — the third in our four-week series featuring Mr. Gardner, who was born on Oct. 21, 1914. Mr. Gardner was a prolific and attentive correspondent; he devoted a day each week to maintaining an ongoing written conversation with mathematicians and readers worldwide.

headline: A Chain of Real Estate Envy From Across the Pond
text: Wishing a friend’s house or apartment were yours isn’t only an American trait.

headline: Obama Admits Web Site Flaws on Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama offered an impassioned defense of the Affordable Care Act on Monday, acknowledging the technical failures of the HealthCare.gov Web site, but providing little new information about the problems with the online portal or the efforts by government contractors to fix it.

headline: Image of the Day: October 21
text: Police personnel during a parade on the occasion of Police Commemoration Day in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: The Forgotten Preacher
text: Henry McNeal Turner, the first black chaplain in the Union Army and one of the most prominent religious and political leaders of Civil War era black America, was born a free black on Feb. 1, 1834, in New Berry Court House, S.C. Turner was the oldest child of Hardy Turner and Sarah Greer Turner, and while we do not know much about Turner’s other siblings, we do know that Turner’s father died while he was still young.

headline: In Our Pages: October 22
text: 1913 Crystal Palace Goes to the Dogs

headline: Championship Slipped Away, but Leyland Recalls the Thrills as He Retires
text: DETROIT — Jim Leyland said he thought he would know when it was time to step down as manager of the Detroit Tigers, to finally retire after more than two decades of calling the shots in major league dugouts.

headline: Saoirse Ronan’s Plum Benefits
text: The Girl: The actress contrasted the masculine silhouette of a plum pantsuit with a feminine lace top in a complementary berry hue at the 57th BFI London Film Festival Awards on Saturday night.The Details: The Kooples suit and shirt, Nicholas Kirkwood shoes.

headline: Is Breast Still ‘Best’ When It’s Another Mother’s Milk?
text: When parents cannot breast-feed an infant (when a child is adopted, when a mother’s health or medical history precludes nursing or when a mother can’t produce enough milk), most parents turn to formula. Donated breast milk — milk pumped by another mother and then donated personally, via a milk bank, or through informal sharing network — is still an option pursued by a relatively small group of parents, although many neonatal intensive-care units are increasingly seeking donor milk for premature infants to reduce the risk of a potentially fatal condition called necrotizing enterocolitis.

headline: Greek Abduction Case Highlights Roma Tensions
text: ATHENS — A Roma couple were ordered jailed on Monday over the alleged abduction of a child who was found during a police raid on an encampment in central Greece last week. The case has fueled speculation about human trafficking and illegal adoption rackets, and heightened scrutiny of Roma populations across Europe.

headline: Pogue, Times Technology Columnist, Is Leaving for Yahoo
text: David Pogue, the technology writer for The New York Times, whose columns were among the most popular at the paper, said on Monday that he was leaving for Yahoo to start a consumer-focused technology site.

headline: A Closer Look at Factors Curbing China’s Appetite for Shark Fins
text: Over the weekend, the Washington Post published an invaluable story offering a deeper look at the factors contributing to declining demand for shark fins in China. The piece adds some fascinating context on how the WildAid shark campaign that I posted on last week created social and governmental ripples.

headline: 22 Under Investigation in Libor Case in Britain
text: Updated, 1:56 p.m. |

headline: In Small-Business Lending, the Devil Is Often in the Lien
text: When small-business owners consider a loan, their primary concerns are generally what you would expect: What is the interest rate? How big is the loan? What will the monthly payments be?

headline: Longtime Goldman Executive Is Departing
text: J. Michael Evans, a Goldman Sachs executive once seen as a possible candidate to succeed Lloyd C. Blankfein as chief executive, is leaving the Wall Street firm.

headline: Bowlesonomics Versus Abenomics
text: As some readers may have guessed, a number of my recent blog posts have in effect been notes on the way toward my paper and presentation here. I have gotten somewhat obsessed with the question of whether a Greek-style crisis is possible for a country like the United States, and with the amazing way that the conviction that it is has taken root among policy elites without, as far as I can tell, any attempt to explain the actual mechanism.

headline: Anti-Doping Agency Exposed Armstrong, but What About Others?
text: Some were cyclists who injected themselves with banned endurance boosters and popped testosterone pills. Some lay side by side with teammates while blood dripped from chilled IV bags and into their swelling veins. Others were doctors who helped cyclists dope or middlemen who ferried drugs for Lance Armstrong’s United States Postal Service team.

headline: Alan Greenspan Sees Inflation
text: Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has largely avoided public comment on the Fed’s efforts to stimulate the economy, but he has said enough to make it clear that he is not a fan.

headline: Obama on Health Site Glitches
text: President Obama said the technical problems on HealthCare.gov did not indicate a failure of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Justices Return to a Death Penalty Issue
text: WASHINGTON — More than a decade after the Supreme Court banned the execution of the “mentally retarded” in 2002 in Atkins v. Virginia, the justices agreed on Monday to clarify how states should determine who qualifies.

headline: New Technique Holds Promise for Hair Growth
text: Scientists have found a new way to grow hair, one that they say may lead to better treatments for baldness.

headline: Ratmansky, Eliasson and  Iñárritu Among Rolex Mentors
text: VENICE — At a presentation at La Fenice opera house here on Monday, the Rolex Mentor and Protégé Arts Initiative announced the artists who will serve as the 2014-15 mentors in dance, visual arts, film, theater, literature, music and architecture. The lineup comprises illustrious international names: the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the artist Olafur Eliasson, the film director Alejandro González Iñárritu, the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, the author Michael Ondaatje, the composer Kaija Saariaho and the architect Peter Zumthor.

headline: A New Hotel in L.A. Celebrates its Koreatown Surroundings
text: A stately yet unstuffy hotel injects style into the vibrant Los Angeles neighborhood.

headline: Maybe Economics Is A Science, But Many Economists Are Not Scientists
text: Raj Chetty stands up valiantly for the honor of his and my profession, arguing that economics is too a science in which careful research is used to falsify some hypotheses and lend credibility to others. And in many ways I agree: there is a lot of good research in economics, maybe more than ever as the focus has shifted somewhat from theoretical models loosely inspired by observation — which, as he suggests, was my forte — to nitty-gritty empirical work.

headline: Walkabout: Record Numbers for American Tourism in Cuba; TripAdvisor Plans Expansion
text: Bienvenidos Americans are visiting Cuba in record numbers despite strict travel restrictions, joining the hundreds of thousands of Cuban-Americans who travel there each year. (Reuters)

headline: Better (and More) Congressional Member Information
text: Over the summer, as lawmakers in Washington, D.C., haggled about the budget, energy, immigration and other issues, we’ve been at work upgrading the information about members contained in the Congress API.

headline: Soaring to the Stratosphere
text: The Perlan Project is building a carbon-fiber glider to carry two pilots to 90,000 feet. Its mission is to set an altitude record and to explore the high reaches of atmosphere.

headline: Student Kills Math Teacher, Then Himself, at a Middle School in Nevada
text: A Nevada middle school student shot and killed a math teacher on Monday, then fatally shot himself in front of children who were gathering for class at the beginning of the school day, the authorities said.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Hayley Berlent joined Siegelvision, New York, in a new post, managing director and chief strategy officer. She had been senior strategy director at Siegel & Gale, New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Sorting Out the New Yahoo Mail
text: Sorting Out

headline: Hong Kong Tycoon Still Has Options for Supermarket Chain
text: Li Ka-shing’s sale of the Hong Kong supermarket chain ParknShop has flopped, but he still has other options.

headline: Some Republicans Change Course on Health Care
text: Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, never misses a chance to accuse President Obama of being a terrible leader. So it was inevitable that he would pronounce Mr. Obama’s Rose Garden speech today about problems with the federal health insurance Web site a sign of a “fundamental breakdown in leadership.”

headline: Qaeda-Linked Group Is Seen Complicating the Drive for Peace in Syria
text: PARIS — Even as planning intensifies for a Geneva peace conference on the war in Syria, the emergence of a group affiliated with Al Qaeda has undermined the chances of negotiating an end to the conflict, a senior State Department official said on Monday.

headline: The Scale of the Budget Divide
text: How the vastly different budgets passed by the House and Senate earlier this year as a share of the economy compare to the one proposed by President Obama in April and to historical averages.

headline: Carve the Turkey and Pass the Latkes, as Holidays Converge
text: This year, in an extremely unusual coincidence of the calendar, the chants of “Gobble, gobble, gobble” for Thanksgiving will be interspersed with the singing of “Dreidel, dreidel, dreidel” for Hanukkah. The Manischewitz Company, the nation’s leading maker of kosher foods, is hoping to have fun — and sell its mainstay products like broth — by combining the holidays.

headline: A Quiet Trip to the Ozone Hole
text: BEND, Ore. — It might be the weirdest part of the atmosphere, 15 miles above the polar regions, where vast stratospheric clouds of nitric acid and water vapor shimmer in iridescent pink while human-made chemicals play havoc with the ozone layer.

headline: Economic Data Starts Flowing Again
text: The government economic data train is getting back on track.

headline: Serena Williams Leads WTA Championships Field
text: ISTANBUL — Wearing a gray tank top and leather skirt that made her look every bit the conqueror she has become in women’s tennis, Serena Williams took to the podium for the media day at the year-end WTA Championships with an air of caution.

headline: Museum of Modern Art to Add Dave Kehr as a Curator
text: Dave Kehr, a columnist and critic whose writings about film and filmmakers have appeared in The New York Times since 1999, will become an adjunct curator in the film department of the Museum of Modern Art. Glenn D. Lowry, the museum’s director, announced the appointment on Monday.

headline: BuzzFeed Hires Pulitzer Winner to Head Investigative Unit
text: BuzzFeed, the media Web site focused on viral content, announced on Monday that it was again expanding its reporting staff, this time to introduce an investigative unit. A new team of about half a dozen reporters will be led by Mark Schoofs, who was hired away from the nonprofit investigative service ProPublica.

headline: A Look Toward the Future at National Design Awards
text: At the fourteenth annual National Design Awards event last Thursday, which drew more than 600 people to Chelsea Piers in Manhattan (including Al Gore), the talk was of recent dark days in Washington and a brighter future for design.

headline: The Allergen-Free Cake That Wasn’t
text: Nearly one-third of food-allergic children are bullied because of their allergies, according to a study published earlier this year in Pediatrics. Rather than blame the bully, what if we spun the discussion and asked: What does it take to create truly inclusive environments?

headline: Visiting China, Pentagon Officers Step Up Dialogue
text: WASHINGTON – Senior Defense Department officials have been accelerating a dialogue with China, carried out through personal visits with Chinese counterparts to establish and strengthen military-to-military relationships.

headline: A Start to Saving Lives: Treating Sore Throats
The Sweet Life
text: Q. WHY DON’T SUGAR, MOLASSES AND HONEY EVER ROT?

headline: In Video, Student Describes Nevada School Shooting
text: A student at Sparks Middle School in Reno, Nev., described witnessing a shooting that police said left two people dead and two others critically injured around 7:15 a.m. on Monday.

headline: A Worldwide Fight Against Street Harassment
text: THE reality of street harassment against women who are traveling dawned on me some years ago in Rabat, Morocco, when my wife rushed back into our hotel room looking uncharacteristically shaken. She had ventured out alone on an errand, and had been accosted on a street near the Kasbah by a group of men, several of whom barked and made lewd comments, one of whom exposed himself. In broad daylight.

headline: Pace-Setting Cells Linked to Slower Heartbeat
text: Getting older means getting slower, and the heart is no exception. A decreased maximum heart rate later in life reduces our capacity for strenuous work and can make it difficult to live alone. But why, exactly, does the heart slow down?

headline: Answer to the Old Teeth-and-Scales Question
text: It’s not quite a chicken-and-egg paradox, but scientists have long wondered which came first, teeth or scales. A new analysis of some toothlike fossils suggests the answer may be scales, contradicting decades of conventional wisdom.

headline: How Safe Is Cycling? It’s Hard to Say
text: Until his bike slid out of control while he was going 35 miles an hour downhill around a sharp turn, Dr. Harold Schwartz thought cycling accidents were something that happened to other people. Now, after recovering from a fractured pelvis, Dr. Schwartz, 65, the vice president for behavioral health at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut, has changed his mind.

headline: Megan Cunningham of Magnet Media, on Judging Other Travelers
text: AS C.E.O. of a fast-growing company, Magnet Media, I’m really committed to maintaining close relationships with clients. I think that’s key to quality service. Even though we are proponents about the power of digital marketing, there’s still nothing like being in a face-to-face meeting with a client and developing a relationship.

headline: Gliders, Syria’s Doctors and Bicycle Safety
text: A team of is hoping to send a glider 17 miles high for a closer look at what ails the atmosphere; how safe is your bicycle?

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 16-21, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Mullally and Offerman to Star Off Broadway
text: The real-life husband and wife duo Megan Mullally (“Will & Grace”) and Nick Offerman (“Parks and Recreation”) will play a long-separated couple reunited by the husband’s illness in “Annapurna,” which the New Group added to its season on Monday.

headline: Rules Shielding Online Data From N.S.A. and Other Prying Eyes Advance in Europe
text: BRUSSELS — A panel of European Union lawmakers on Monday night backed a measure that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking private data.

headline: Awareness Grows of Online Insurance Exchanges, and Their Problems, Survey Finds
text: Public awareness of the new health insurance exchanges has risen substantially in the weeks since they opened, but only a small percentage of consumers have visited the sites. Most of those already have insurance and are simply trying to learn more about the program, according to a survey released on Monday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Bud Adams, Founding Owner of N.F.L.’s Titans, Dies at 90
text: Bud Adams, a pro football presence for more than half a century as a founder of the American Football League and the owner of the Houston Oilers and their successors, the Tennessee Titans, died on Monday at his home in Houston. He was 90.

headline: An Eye for Bargains Can Be Bigger Than the Stomach
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

headline: Keystone Pipeline Opponents Plan Widespread Civil Disobedience
text: PITTSBURGH – Opponents of the Keystone XL oil pipeline outlined new plans for persuading President Obama to reject the project at a conference for young climate activists here over the weekend. And while most organizers continued to express optimism that the administration would not allow TransCanada to complete the 1,700-mile pipeline from Alberta’s oil sands to Gulf Coast refineries, they are preparing for the likelihood that the project will win approval.

headline: Poll Shows de Blasio Maintaining Huge Lead
text: Time is running out for Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor of New York City.

headline: Twitter to End Its Music App, Which Never Made Much Noise
text: Twitter will close its music app, which was introduced with great fanfare six months ago but has failed to gain traction in the marketplace. The company is expected to rethink its music strategy, according to a person with knowledge of its plans.

headline: Clinton Defender Takes On Fox News Over Benghazi Attack
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton says she has not decided whether she will run for president in 2016, but the battle over her public record is already being fought on television.

headline: The Collections
text: Designers introduced shorter hems and jewel-toned gowns as whimsical options alongside timeless,white silhouettes.

headline: Lawrence R. Klein, Economic Theorist, Dies at 93
text: Lawrence R. Klein, who predicted America’s economic boom after World War II and was awarded the 1980 Nobel in economic science for developing statistical models that are used to analyze and predict global economic trends, died on Sunday at his home in Gladwyne, Pa. He was 93.

headline: The Improbable French Buddies
text: These days, science and philosophy don’t seem to be the best of friends. Some prominent scientists dismiss philosophers as chasing vague concepts into “murky and inconsequential” rabbit holes, as the physicist Steven Weinberg once put it. And philosophers accuse scientists of imperial overreach in their attempts to claim ultimate authority on questions like consciousness, free will and the existence of God.

headline: How the Right’s Responding to the JP Morgan Deal
text: A few hours before the Justice Department was to announce civil charges against JP Morgan Chase over its sale of troubled mortgage-backed securities, the company’s C.E.O., Jamie Dimon, made a phone call. He got one of Attorney General Eric Holder’s top lieutenants on the line, according to a report in Deal Book, and reopened negotiations.  That happened in September. Weeks later, on Friday, the Justice Department and the bank tentatively agreed to a record $13 billion settlement.

headline: Scientists Go Back to Work and a Skull Changes Some Minds
text: “I brought some muffins!” proclaimed Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as he greeted workers returning to the Environmental Protection Agency headquarters in Washington on Thursday. Seventeen days after the government shutdown began, scientists around the country — and as far away as the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station — resumed the work they were forced to halt during the standoff. The full extent of the damage on abandoned labs and frozen studies will take time to assess. But now is the time to appreciate small things, like the return of the Panda Cam, and muffins.

headline: Panama Says It Will Release Most From Ship to North Korea
text: The authorities in Panama said Monday that they would release 33 of the 35 North Korean crew members of a rusting freighter impounded more than three months ago for carrying a secret stash of Soviet-era Cuban military gear hidden under bags of brown sugar.

headline: What Does ‘Terminal’ Mean? (3 Letters)
