text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Tests for Newborns (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Molina Helps Cardinals Pitch Beyond Their Years
text: Michael Wacha wore a wide smile and a National League champions T-shirt as he held his crystal Most Valuable Player trophy on a podium at Busch Stadium late Friday night. Yadier Molina stood a few feet away, beaming.

headline: Rangers’ Biron Is Comfortable With Decision to Retire
text: On Monday morning, the Rangers were skating at their Westchester County practice rink. At the same time, about 350 miles away, at his home in East Aurora, N.Y., Martin Biron felt no pangs of regret that he was not with them.

headline: The Collections | The Top 5 Bridal Looks for Fall 2014
text: At the Fall 2014 edition of New York Bridal Fashion Week, some designers presented timeless wedding dress silhouettes in traditional shades of white. But others offered more whimsical options that were less recognizable as bridal gowns. There were both long trains and shorter, calf-length hems. Creams and ivories shared the stage with brighter shades that ranged from light peach to dark berry. Whether future brides opt for the fanciful (a colorful frock with lace flowers embroidered onto the skirt) or the classic (a sleek sheath with a pop of detail), they’re sure to make a statement.

headline: Plundering Science, Bone by Bone
text: It is the dinosaur version of grave robbing: fossil poachers plundering a paleontological dig, frequently smashing ancient skulls and stealing valuable teeth, claws and feet.

headline: Sounds Like a Haven for Troubled Students. It’s Not.
text: “And Miles to Go,” Chad Beckim’s new play about a failing New York City public school, doesn’t shy away from the tough questions. Well, at least not until the last third.

headline: Netflix Hits Milestone and Raises Its Sights
text: Content is the new black.

headline: Doctors Without Fear
text: Amid the crisis in Syria, medical professionals have taken up a herculean effort to provide needed care, and played a critical role in exposing the use of chemical weapons to the world.

headline: Black History Across Five Centuries: A Journey of Many Dimensions
text: It always seemed pretty straightforward. And horrifying. Early African-American history was the story of thousands of Africans who were captured, shipped like cargo to the New World and sold into slavery, mostly to work and die on Southern plantations.

headline: In Syria, Doctors Risk Life and Juggle Ethics
text: WASHINGTON — Months before a chemical weapons attack killed hundreds of Syrians and prompted threats of an American military strike, an anesthesiologist named Majid heard an explosion near his home in a Damascus suburb. He rushed to the makeshift hospital where he works and found patients with itching skin, burning eyes and shortness of breath.

headline: Special PACs Spent Money at Resorts, Book Says
text: WASHINGTON — A new book from a conservative advocate of tighter campaign finance regulations seeks to draw attention to a number of questionable but legal fund-raising activities — some potentially damaging, others certainly embarrassing — that could prove uncomfortable for some on Capitol Hill.

headline: Figuring Out Who Really Had the Last Word in the Bush White House
text: How different would the world be if George W. Bush had picked John Danforth instead of Dick Cheney to be his vice president? Mr. Danforth, a moderate three-term senator from Missouri and an ordained Episcopal minister nicknamed St. Jack, met for more than three hours with Mr. Bush. Karl Rove favored him over Mr. Cheney, as did Joshua Bolten, the campaign policy director. And only at Mr. Cheney’s insistence did Mr. Bush interview Mr. Danforth.

headline: All the World’s a Bar at Channel From Esquire
text: During Prohibition, people desperate for a drink needed a password to enter a speakeasy.

headline: A Late Arrival in Boston, Greeted With Hopeful Relief
text: BOSTON — The health of the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s music director has caused it quite a few headaches over the past few years. The tenure of James Levine, who held the position for seven years, beginning in 2004, was characterized toward the end by a demoralizing string of injury-induced cancellations. In the 2009-10 season, Mr. Levine was forced to abandon 60 percent of his scheduled appearances with the orchestra. His resignation in 2011 was followed by a period of uncertainty and drift.

headline: ScienceTake: Flight of the Bumblebee
text: Harvard researchers have discovered that the bumblebee is a much more tactful navigator than its name implies.

headline: Shakespeare in Rep Sells on Broadway
text: The new Broadway double bill of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III,” running in repertory and starring the two-time Tony Award winner Mark Rylance as Olivia and Richard, had a solid first week of ticket sales, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The shows grossed $468,429 for a total of six preview performances — 73 percent of the maximum possible amount, a high level of plays. The gross is notable partly because the shows are setting aside 250 tickets at every performance for an unusually low $25, which would theoretically lower the amount of money in ticket sales somewhat. The new musical “After Midnight,” a revue recreating the Cotton Club nightclub scene, also had a good first week, grossing $235,823 for three previews (or 64 percent of the maximum possible amount). Over all, Broadway musicals and plays grossed $24 million last week, compared to $24.6 million the previous week, which fell over the Columbus Day holiday weekend. Attendance at shows totaled 233,682 last week, compared to 232,400 the previous week.

headline: Out of Darkness Comes Light, Movement and Music
text: Plagues, war, the eclipse of the classical tradition: there are reasons that people used to refer to 14th-century Europe as belonging to the Dark Ages. And yet the period produced some beautiful music, at once spare and complex, ascetic and sensual.

headline: $50,000 Awards Go to 10 Writers
text: The Whiting Writers’ Awards, given annually to 10 writers who have “exceptional talent and promise in early career,” were announced on Monday. Each writer receives $50,000 from the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, established in 1963 by Flora E. Whiting. The awards honor fiction, nonfiction, poetry and plays and are intended to identify writers, the foundation says, “who have yet to make their mark on the literary culture.” The 2013 winners are Hannah Dela Cruz Abrams (“The Man Who Danced With Dolls”), Amanda Coplin (“The Orchardist”), Jennifer duBois (“Cartwheel”), Virginia Grise (“Making Myth”), Ishion Hutchinson (“Far District: Poems”), Morgan Meis (“Ruins”), C. E. Morgan (“All the Living”), Rowan Ricardo Phillips (“The Ground”), Clifford Thompson (“Signifying Nothing”) and Stephanie Powell Watts (“We Are Taking Only What We Need”).

headline: A Storyteller Who Can’t Be Pigeonholed
text: Judy Collins, that ageless wild angel of pop, has many faces, all of them magnificently on display at the Café Carlyle, where she has opened her annual fall engagement.

headline: In His Hands, Bach Meets Bluegrass
text: On a cool Monday night in late September, Chris Thile came to Rockwood Music Hall to play for a devoted audience that hung on his every note. The scene was nothing new. Mr. Thile, a singer, mandolinist and composer who regularly appears at prestigious concert halls and festivals with the progressive-bluegrass quintet Punch Brothers, routinely works up material for his concert tours at Rockwood, an intimate nightclub complex on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Deep Fried and Good for You
text: Fried food is probably not on anyone’s lists of healthy eats, but you have to start with this: Fat is good for you.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Kenya, Egypt, China and Pakistan.

headline: An Odd Alliance in Patagonia
text: NEUQUÉN, Argentina — On the windswept Patagonian steppe, crews of roughnecks are drilling around the clock in pursuit of a vast shale oil reservoir that might be the world’s next great oil field.

headline: Recipe Lab | Chocolate Caramels
text: Julia Moskin makes chocolate caramels with sea salt from “Mast Brothers Chocolate: A Family Cookbook.”

headline: Discussing Chocolate With the Mast Brothers
text: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to talk about cooking with the Dining section. This month, join Julia Moskin and Rick and Michael Mast, of Mast Brothers chocolate, for a live video chat about chocolate — how it is made, and how to cook with it — on Thursday, Oct. 24, 2 p.m. Eastern time, right here on this page.

text: The Whiting Writers’ Awards, given annually to 10 writers who have “exceptional talent and promise in early career,” were announced on Monday.

headline: A Vagabond Troupe Gets Its First Home
text: Life as an itinerant company was not easy for Theater for a New Audience, which spent 34 years producing Shakespeare and other classical dramas in leased spaces, shuttling among Off Off Broadway theaters, school gymnasiums and even, once, a Y.M.C.A.

text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,273 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Shades of Oedipus for Hip-Hop Titans
text: SEATTLE — Four years ago, Drake played his first New York show, at S.O.B.’s. Huddled up in a private area at the rear of the club was Kanye West, presumably curious as to how secure his own future was. Drake had been making noise as the first demonstrably viable post-Kanye rapper, one for whom emotional excavation was a virtue, one who’d mainlined Mr. West’s middle-class sensibilities and created a new sound on that foundation.

headline: Medicaid and the Incentive to Work
text: The Affordable Care Act is — to state the obvious — aimed at bolstering insurance coverage in the United States. But the law is so big that it will necessarily have widespread economic ramifications, economists think, including an effect on the labor market.

headline: Nets' Turn to Be Talk of the Town
text: After decades of playing second fiddle in New York, the Nets, according to William C. Rhoden, are in position to capture the city's imagination. And the franchise in Manhattan is feeling the pressure.

text: After decades of playing second fiddle in New York, the Nets are in a position to capture the city’s imagination. And the franchise in Manhattan is feeling the pressure.

text: Dee Dee Bridgewater sings the number “A Foggy Day in London Town” from the Billie Holiday musical “Lady Day,” which had a run at the Little Shubert Theater in 2013.

headline: Scott Dixon Wins Third IndyCar Title
text: Will Power won the race, but by finishing fifth in Saturday’s 500-mile IndyCar season finale at Fontana, Calif., Scott Dixon clinched his third title in the series. Dixon, who also won the title in 2003 and 2008, had trailed Helio Castroneves in points much of this season. But a sixth-place finish in the race by Castroneves fell short of overcoming the 25-point lead Dixon held since the Houston double-header races earlier in the month.

headline: Remembering, and Forgetting, the Flying Tigers
text: The decrepit state of a graveyard that is connected to one of the most famous World War II fighting forces in China has revived questions about the country’s ability to honor its veterans.

headline: Politicians’ Extortion Racket
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — WE have long assumed that the infestation of special interest money in Washington is at the root of so much that ails our politics. But what if we’ve had it wrong? What if instead of being bribed by wealthy interests, politicians are engaged in a form of legal extortion designed to extract campaign contributions?

Arkansas: G.O.P. Congressman Won’t Seek Re-election
text: Representative Tim Griffin, a two-term Republican from a competitive district, said Monday that he would not seek a third term. Mr. Griffin, a former aide to Karl Rove and one of the Republican Party’s rising stars, said he wanted to spend more time with his wife and children. His announcement was unexpected. The district, which includes Little Rock and several surrounding counties, was represented until 2011 by a Democrat for more than a decade.

headline: Mario Cuomo, Vocal Foe of Italian Stereotyping, Finally Sees ‘The Godfather’
text: Mario M. Cuomo’s hate-hate relationship with “The Godfather” has been well documented. For four decades, he refused even to see any of the movies or, presumably, to read Mario Puzo’s book. He all but denied that the Mafia existed. And who could forget that unfortunate slip of the tongue during the 1992 presidential campaign, when Bill Clinton suggested that Mr. Cuomo, then the governor of New York, acted like a Mafioso?

headline: Critics Wage Quiet Fight Against Ballot Measure on Adding Casinos
text: ROCK HILL, N.Y. — The Coalition Against Gambling in New York has no office, no paid staff and basically no money. Its Web site features a Goya print and a graphic depicting something called the “Iceberg of Misery.” The group’s spokesman is a “recovering technologist” and an avid bowhunter with barely enough backing to make it to debates.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Silicon Valley’s Secessionists, and the Motorola Money Pit
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Language-Gap Study Bolsters a Push for Pre-K
text: Nearly two decades ago, a landmark study found that by age 3, the children of wealthier professionals have heard words millions more times than those of less educated parents, giving them a distinct advantage in school and suggesting the need for increased investment in prekindergarten programs.

headline: Tracking the Vocabulary Gap
text: A Stanford University study tracked how children recognize simple words.

headline: Brazil: Consortium Wins Oil Rights
text: The Brazilian authorities on Monday awarded a license to develop oil production in a coveted deep-sea area to a consortium of five companies: Petrobras, Brazil’s national oil company; the Western oil giants Shell and Total; and two Chinese state-controlled oil companies. The group, the only consortium to submit a bid in the auction, will pay a signing fee of about $7 billion to start work on the 35-year concession. The deep-sea field, called Libra, is believed to be one of Brazil’s most promising exploration areas. Legislation requires the Brazilian company to take control of the new operation, but doubts persist among energy analysts as to whether Petrobras, which has soaring debt and is trying to reverse a decline in Brazil’s oil production, is overstretched with an array of offshore projects. The auction was carried out in Rio de Janeiro amid protests by oil workers and other groups that oppose the participation of foreign companies in Brazil’s oil industry.

headline: On Subway, Tourism Push Promotes Upstate Stops
text: On the 42nd Street shuttle, long the province of the subway system’s least subtle advertising, riders have been encouraged to drink orange juice, watch the Yankees and join Papa Smurf at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: Medicaid Expansion Is Set for Ohioans
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As a Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee in the 1990s, John R. Kasich wielded a ferocious budget ax. On Monday, as Ohio’s governor, Mr. Kasich defied his party’s majorities in the state legislature to push through a multibillion dollar expansion of Medicaid under President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Plan Aims to Fix Sewers, but Its Cost to Residents Leaves a Bad Taste
text: LONDON — On a particularly hot summer day in 1858, the smell of raw sewage from the River Thames became so unbearable that legislators had the curtains of the Houses of Parliament soaked in chloride of lime. When that failed to repel the odors, members of Parliament simply abandoned the place.

headline: Judge Hears Arguments on Legality of Detroit Bankruptcy Filing
text: DETROIT — It is hard to picture a city in worse financial shape than Detroit, where decades of mismanagement and misfortune led to the nation’s largest municipal bankruptcy filing.

headline: Mattingly Gives Dodgers An Earful Over His Status
text: LOS ANGELES — Through all the turbulent years in New York, Don Mattingly carved a reputation as an elegant player who carried himself with an earnestness that did not betray his small-town Indiana roots. That portrait, like the nickname that accompanied it, Donnie Baseball, seemed apt.

headline: The Real Story Behind the City’s Deliverance From a Blood-Soaked Era
text: The Republican mayoral nominee, Joseph J. Lhota, went all retro on us last week, offering a commercial that had a 1970s “Escape From New York,” “Panic in Needle Park” jolt.

headline: Ex-Patients Police Mexico’s Mental Health System
text: MEXICO CITY — On a recent morning, a collection of people grappling with mental illness roamed the grounds of a psychiatric hospital here, stepping into dirty, dilapidated rooms; exchanging tales of anguish; and peppering administrators with questions.

headline: Texas A&M Pursues a Campus in Israel
text: HOUSTON — When Gov. Rick Perry visits Israel this week, he will leave a surprising piece of Texas behind: his alma mater, Texas A&M University.

headline: The 3 Roles of Michael J. Fox
text: On Thursday, NBC will air the sixth episode of its new comedy series, “The Michael J. Fox Show.” In it, Fox plays a popular television anchorman who returns to work after having retired years earlier because of his Parkinson’s disease. This, of course, closely tracks Fox’s own story. An extremely well-liked actor, he last starred in a television series in 2000, which is when the tremors, stiffness and involuntary body movements that are associated with Parkinson’s forced him to retire from “Spin City.”

headline: Economic Theory, via YouTube and Cartoon
text: Forget Econ 101. Take a look at the lessons in Dalio 101.

headline: Tradition of Not Voting Keeps Palestinians Politically Powerless in Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — Mayor Nir Barkat proudly trumpets the investments he has made over the past five years in the Arab neighborhoods of East Jerusalem: about $141 million for roads and infrastructure, $113 million to build 500 classrooms, more than $1 million for a single soccer field in Beit Safafa.

headline: Start-Up Reinvents the Bicycle Wheel
text: It’s rare that a company comes along and reinvents the wheel, but it looks like that is about to happen.

headline: Confessions of a Serial Memoirist
text: I am a serial memoirist — words I never imagined uttering or for that matter stringing together to describe any writer 25 years ago, back when I wrote my first book, “Riding in Cars With Boys.” I sold the book in 1988 on a five-page proposal, using my agent’s advice: “Pretend you have five minutes to tell a garden party why in the world they should be interested in the story of your life.”

headline: California: BART Trainee Was Running Train in Fatal Crash
text: The operator of a Bay Area Rapid Transit train involved in a fatal accident on Saturday was a trainee who was not yet certified to drive the train, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board said on Monday. The train, which killed two workers who were inspecting a section of track, was on a run “for training and maintenance purposes” during a strike by railroad workers, said the investigator, Jim Southworth. BART had said it would train managers to operate trains in order to provide a limited shuttle service during the walkout. Unions for the striking workers had warned that it would be dangerous to allow inexperienced operators to drive the trains.

headline: R.O.T.C. Making Cuts to Expand Recruiting
text: COOKEVILLE, Tenn. — When Sarah Short arrived at Tennessee Technological University this summer, she had mapped out her four years of undergraduate study and well beyond: an affordable nursing degree and a commission as an Army officer.

headline: Angry at Prague, Artist Ensures He’s Understood
text: PARIS — “The finger,” said the Czech sculptor David Cerny, “speaks for itself.” On that point, at least, everyone could agree.

headline: Clock Ticking, Bloomberg Seeks Council Approval of East Midtown Rezoning Plan
text: The Bloomberg administration is scrambling to gather enough City Council votes to enact the mayor’s final plan for reshaping New York City’s skyline with a new generation of ever-taller skyscrapers.

headline: Ruling Near, J.C. Penney Capitulates to Macy’s
text: Days before a judge was expected to rule in the long-running legal dispute between Macy’s and J. C. Penney over the right to sell branded Martha Stewart housewares, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and J. C. Penney scaled back the merchandising agreement at the center of the battle.

headline: In Belated Jobs Report, a Search for Clues
text: Will it be worth the wait?

headline: Sales Are Colossal, Shares Are Soaring. All Amazon Is Missing Is a Profit
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Nearly every day, Amazon announces a new venture.

headline: Security Check Now Starts Long Before You Fly
text: The Transportation Security Administration is expanding its screening of passengers before they arrive at the airport by searching a wide array of government and private databases that can include records like car registrations and employment information.

headline: Don’t Like the Video? Tell It What to Do Next
text: TELEVISION viewers have been talking to characters in commercials for decades, even if those conversations have been one-sided and consist mostly of demands to pipe down. In an online initiative to help promote the 2014 Infiniti Q50 sport sedan, the characters talk back.

headline: CeeLo Green, Star of NBC’s ‘The Voice,’ Faces Drug Charge
text: CeeLo Green, the singer and judge on NBC’s hit talent show “The Voice,” was charged on Monday in Los Angeles with giving the drug ecstasy to a woman, the district attorney of Los Angeles County announced.

headline: The Health Site’s Chaotic Debut
text: President Obama rightly acknowledged on Monday that there is “no excuse” for the horrendously botched opening of the federal Web site consumers are supposed to use to sign up for health insurance policies under the Affordable Care Act. Unless the problems can be fixed soon, they threaten to undermine the ability of the health care exchanges to help enroll some seven million uninsured Americans in 2014.

headline: Beijing’s Assault on Academic Freedom
text: Peking University’s decision last week to dismiss Professor Xia Yeliang, an economist and advocate of the free market, is making news around the world. The dismissal could hurt Peking University’s connections with American and European universities, and tarnish its reputation. In the spirit of academic freedom, universities that have collaborative relations with Peking University — Stanford, Cornell, Yale, the London School of Economics and many others — should be putting pressure on China’s leading university to reinstate Mr. Xia.

headline: How to Disarm the Debt-Ceiling Threat for Good
text: After Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, emerged from hiding last week to help negotiate an end to the debt crisis, he announced that Republicans would no longer use the same kind of extortion to get their way. “We’re not going to do this again in connection with the debt ceiling or with a government shutdown,” he told The National Review.

headline: Salmon Fishermen Battle Walmart on Certification
text: Early last year, Alaska’s wild salmon fishing industry decided to end its partnership with the seafood world’s most prominent sustainability certification group in favor of its own labeling efforts. But the move quickly set drew a reaction from customers, as WalMart and others said they would no longer buy Alaskan salmon without the independent check.

headline: A New Day in New Jersey
text: Gov. Chris Christie has repeatedly fought legislative and legal attempts to allow same-sex marriage in New Jersey. On Monday, he finally decided to drop his appeal of a state court decision issued in September that allowed gay and lesbian couples to marry.

headline: Lou Scheimer, Whose Cartoon Studio Entertained Generation X, Dies at 84
text: Lou Scheimer, an Emmy-winning producer of television cartoons whose company, Filmation, was once the largest animation studio in the United States, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Gannett Links Drop in Profit to a Less Eventful Year
text: The Gannett Company reported a sharp decline in third-quarter profit on Monday, attributing the drop to a deep dip in advertising revenue from a year ago, when the Olympics and the presidential campaign provided a financial lift.

headline: In Clinton Fund-Raising, Expect a Full Embrace
text: When a recent Manhattan fund-raiser for the Virginia candidate for governor Terry McAuliffe wound down and most of the donors had left the host’s swanky meatpacking district loft, President Bill Clinton stuck around.

headline: Asia, Where Mobile Games Flowered, Extends Its Reach
text: TOKYO — When SoftBank, the Japanese telecommunications provider, announced last week that it had agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in a Finnish mobile game company for $1.5 billion, many people in both industries reacted with disbelief.

headline: Considering the Fairness of JPMorgan’s Deal
text: Some on Wall Street have portrayed JPMorgan Chase as a victim of government zealotry.

headline: Gamesmanship Continues to Color Jets-Patriots Rivalry
text: Rex Ryan conducted his standard day-after-game interview session on Monday via conference call, so we are left to imagine his body language as he responded to questions about his role in illuminating his new favorite obscure penalty, the call that boosted his Jets to a 30-27 overtime victory against New England.

The Rules of the Road

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Once Their Son, Now a Riddle
text: Star student, sociopath or a little of each? That is the troublesome question raised in “Luce,” a thoughtful, well-acted new play by J C Lee that opened on Monday night at Lincoln Center’s Claire Tow Theater. The title character, winningly played by Okieriete Onaodowan, is a 17-year-old charter school student in an unnamed American suburb whose teacher, Harriet (Sharon Washington), becomes alarmed at the choice Luce makes when he’s given an assignment to write about a historical figure.

headline: Thingamajig
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — You know that thing, that … what is it called? That DOOHICKEY where you put words in a square box and cross them? Oh, right, crossword puzzles. Constructing them is a nice combination of LINEAR and non-LINEAR THINKING. So is solving them, I think.

headline: In Area Already Filled With Bars, a Proposal to Add One More Draws Opposition
text: Manhattan has its squares — Times, Herald, Union, Pershing, Sherman, Verdi and, ever since a blogger christened it, Hell.

headline: 2 Officers Convicted of Harassing Latinos
text: HARTFORD — Two police officers from East Haven, Conn., were convicted on Monday of violating the civil rights of Latino residents in a monthlong trial that exposed tensions in a town with a growing number of immigrants and led to a leadership change at its Police Department.

headline: Injured ‘Spider-Man’ Actor Makes First Appearance Since Performance Accident
text: With a dazzlingly wide smile and dancing bright eyes, the Broadway performer Daniel Curry greeted 200 friends and cast members from his show, “Spider-Man: Turn Off The Dark,” at a benefit concert on Monday night that raised $10,000 for his medical bills after a midperformance accident in August.

headline: Protests as City College Closes a Student Center
text: It was just a small room, one of hundreds in City College’s North Academic Center, but over the years the Guillermo Morales/Assata Shakur Student and Community Center had taken on a significance beyond its square footage. To student organizers who used it as their meeting space, it was a place for lesbian and gay activists, women’s rights groups, community organizations and others to make common cause.

headline: Maker of Animated GIFs Waits for Offbeat Moments
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — At 2:44 p.m. on a recent Sunday, Tim Burke took a moment from monitoring numerous N.F.L. games for the sports Web site Deadspin to post something that had nothing to do with football: a smidgen of a clip from an English rugby match he also happened to be following.

headline: Flo: Portrait of a Street Photographer
text: This short documentary profiles the photographer Flo Fox who, in spite of near-blindness and multiple sclerosis, continues her work in the streets of New York.

headline: ‘Flo: Portrait of a Street Photographer’
text: As a young, self-described “hot chick” in the ’70s and ’80s, Flo Fox hung out at Studio 54 and Area, in the same social circle as Andy Warhol and photographers like Andre Kertesz and Lisette Model. Today, worlds away from those underground art parties, she lives in an apartment building for disabled people, surviving with the help of Medicaid and Social Security.

headline: Yanks, With Much to Address in Off-Season, Start by Cutting Some Ticket Prices

headline: Giants Fans Are Blue but Not Angry

It was several hours before kickoff between the Giants and the Minnesota Vikings, and the lots were quickly filling up. Boresen said he had no doubt that they would.

headline: What’s on Tuesday

(ABC Family) PRETTY LITTLE LIARS In a Halloween episode, Emily (Shay Mitchell, above left, with Lucy Hale, center, and Ashley Benson); Aria (Ms. Hale); Hanna (Ms. Benson); and Spencer (Troian Bellisario) don their finest Edwardian costumes to crash the Ravenswood Founders Day Celebration after discovering a clue indicating that Ali (Sasha Pieterse) might be alive. Meanwhile, Caleb (Tyler Blackburn) travels to the town to help the girls — a move he comes to regret in the premiere of “Ravenswood,” at 9. There he meets the long-lost Uncle Raymond (Steven Cabral) of his new friend, Miranda (Nicole Gale Anderson), a feisty foster child, as well as the scandal-mired Luke (Brett Dier) and his twin, Olivia (Merritt Patterson). Only Remy (Britne Oldford) can help Caleb and Miranda connect the dots in this “Pretty Little Liars” spinoff.

headline: I Am Woman, Watch Me Hack

As a teenager, she liked studying science in school, and she thought forensics offered a way to give back to her neighborhood. Not insignificant, the job also looked pretty cool — at least based on the many hours of “CSI” Allen had watched on TV with her aunt.

headline: Robert Capa: Finding a Fearless Photographer’s Voice
text: Robert Capa — born a hundred years ago today — was famous as a dashing, brave photojournalist who often put himself in danger. He was a pivotal figure in the history of photography and helped found Magnum before his death covering the French Indochina War in 1954.

headline: Soaring Prices of New Homes Defy Beijing’s Attempts to Cool Market
text: HONG KONG — Prices of new homes in China continued to soar in September, defying government efforts to cool the market and highlighting some of the challenges Beijing faces as it seeks to rebalance growth and rein in risks that have built up in the economy during the past five years.

headline: Beijing Plans to Trim English Portion of College Entrance Exam
text: Beijing has announced a proposal to reduce the importance of English on the college entrance examination taken by high school students. The two- or three-day exam, known as the gaokao, has a critical role in deciding if and where students will attend college, so any change in the scoring will have a significant impact on what students study beginning in elementary school.

headline: A New Book Portrays Amazon as Bully

The large publishers traditionally did not know much about their customers, and did not really care. Amazon knew a lot about customers and made the most of it.

headline: Impasses May Slice Into Profits on Wall Street

text: Amazon.com announces a new venture nearly every day: the purchase of an online education company, the development of a payment mechanism to compete with PayPal, updates to its tablet line, a fashion design competition, three new comedy pilots. headline: India’s Press Faces an Online Future
text: Two years ago, Samir Patil surveyed his publishing floor in Mumbai, one of 10 he owned, and saw death. It was not for a lack of lively activity. His company, ACK Media, shipped roughly six million books, magazines and DVDs across India every month. In 2007, he had bought the children’s comic book Amar Chitra Katha, eventually merged it with two other titles and set lofty goals, described here, to revitalize the once popular comics industry.

headline: The Numbers Behind the JPMorgan Deal

The bank’s defenders say JPMorgan is paying for the sins of two firms it bought in the financial crisis, Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual. “But as details emerge, Wall Street’s fears of a largely punitive settlement may not add up,” Peter Eavis and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

headline: China Tries to Clean Up Toxic Legacy of Its Rare Earth Riches
text: TIANJIN, China — In northern China, near the Mongolian border, radioactively contaminated leaks from two decades of rare earth refining have been slowly trickling underground toward the Yellow River, a crucial water source for 150 million people.

headline: Why Can Neil Patrick Harris Say That’s ‘Too Gay’ and Straights Can’t?

headline: Two Charged in School Lunch Poisoning Case in India

headline: Weak Job Gains May Cause Delay in Action by Fed

headline: Investigators Raid Agency of Military in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Military investigators raided South Korea’s Cyberwarfare Command on Tuesday after four of its officials were found to have posted political messages online last year, in what opposition lawmakers have called a smear campaign against President Park Geun-hye’s opponents before her election in December.

headline: In Store | Azzedine Alaïa’s New Paris Boutique Is All Curves
text: Azzedine Alaïa, the cult-status fashion designer beloved by women like Franca Sozzani, Stephanie Seymour and Naomi Campbell since skyrocketing to fame in the 1980s with beautifully made, body-hugging dresses, has a breathtaking new boutique perfectly suited to showcasing his designs. As a landmark retrospective of his greatest gowns at the Palais Galliera was drawing crowds during Paris Fashion Week (a ritual the enigmatic designer has long shunned), Alaïa unveiled his new shop, housed in an 18th-century mansion just off the Avenue Montaigne. The space is adorned with impressive furnishings by Marc Newson, Kris Ruhs, Pierre Paulin and Charlotte Perriand, and a vertical garden by Patrick Blanc towers over the interior courtyard cafe. But the real stars are the dresses, coats, shoes and bags — stunning, elegant and unlike anything else around.

headline: New York Sets Work Rules for Young Models
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed legislation on Monday night that will recognize fashion models under the age of 18 as child performers. The new law, which is expected to go into effect in 30 days, will have a significant impact on the casting of models for the next New York Fashion Week, in February.

headline: Dry Whites for Creamy Chowders
text: A conventional creamy chowder is a pleasure with wine. The richness of the broth and the brininess of the clams enhance all sorts of dry whites. Adding spinach requires a slightly more discerning selection to avoid clashing with the mild, pleasing bitterness of the green. I might steer clear of Muscadet or sauvignon blanc for that reason, but it still leaves many fine choices. A Chablis, for instance, a Mâconnais or a California or Oregon chardonnay in a steely style would all be delicious. So would a good dry albariño, an assyrtiko from Santorini or almost any of the myriad variations on dry or lightly sweet rieslings now produced around the world. Of course, you could do a lot worse than a pilsner, a dry stout or a good English ale.

text: The verdict from President Obama’s economic advisers: Better than nothing, not good enough, likely to get worse.

headline: The Gun Report: October 22, 2013
text: Yesterday morning, a student at Sparks Middle School in Nevada took his parents’ handgun to class and opened fire, wounding two 12-year-old boys and killing a beloved math teacher before killing himself. A student told CNN that she believes the shooter was a nice kid who’d been bullied. That afternoon, in remarks he made to to the nation’s police chiefs, Attorney General Eric Holder noted that the number of active-shooter incidents in the country has soared over the past five years.

headline: From Barber Shops to Rooftops, Watching the Game

headline: From Barber Shops to Rooftops, the Game’s On
text: The Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals will open the World Series on Wednesday night at Fenway Park, the tight little ballpark in Boston that had sold out for 820 consecutive games before the record streak ended in April. In this age of high-definition broadcasts and ubiquitous gadgets, baseball fans have any number of ways to follow postseason games. But fans once had to be resourceful when a championship was at stake.

headline: Holding the Line in Maryland
text: On Oct. 21, 1863, an indignant delegation of slaveholders from St. Mary’s County, Md., on the western shore of Chesapeake Bay just across the Potomac River from Virginia, confronted President Abraham Lincoln at the White House. They demanded that he suspend recruiting efforts aimed at their slaves. The presence of “armed colored troops” was “frightening quiet people, and producing great confusion,” they told him. Lincoln listened sympathetically to the grievances voiced by these alleged Union supporters; he did not, he told them, want the Army behaving in “any rude or ungentlemanly manner.”

headline: How the Furloughed Will Be Counted
text: There has been a lot of speculation about how the federal government shutdown will affect numbers for the October jobs report, due out Nov. 8. The jobs report is based on two different surveys — one of households, and one of employers — and it turns out that furloughed federal government workers will be treated as unemployed in the first survey but employed in the second. In other words, the temporary layoff of federal workers will probably increase the unemployment rate, but not (at least directly) depress the payroll job growth numbers.

headline: A Brazilian-Style Meal in New York
text: Alex Atala, the acclaimed chef from Brazil, prepared dinner for about 70 people in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: In Manhattan, Alex Atala Offers a Sense of São Paulo

headline: Why a Stock Sale Could Be the Right Program for Netflix

headline: Tax on Medical Devices Becomes Recurring Theme in Budget Debate

headline: Major Owens, 77, Education Advocate in Congress, Dies
text: Major R. Owens, a former librarian who went to Congress from Brooklyn and remained there for 24 years, fighting for more federal aid for education and other liberal causes, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

text: Last Thursday I spent a half hour onstage in San Francisco discussing energy trends and choices with the energy analyst Amory B. Lovins and green business maven Joel Makower. headline: U.S. Officer Says Taliban Will Fight This Winter

Singing “I Dreamed a Dream” as Fantine — the role that won Anne Hathaway an Academy Award in the recent film version — will be Caissie Levy, who starred in the Broadway productions of “Ghost” and “Hair” (and was also in “Murder Ballad” this year with Mr. Swenson).

headline: Reflections, Intimate and Layered
text: Over a 27-year period, from 1947, just weeks before he turned 34, until 1974, two years before his death, when he was already ill with debilitating heart disease, Benjamin Britten wrote five Canticles, unusual and extraordinary vocal works. In earlier times, a canticle was an extended vocal piece on a spiritual subject. Britten took this old genre and made it his own.

headline: As Third Point Does Well, Loeb to Return Money to Investors

headline: The Debate Over Judge Posner’s Unforced Error

headline: Flu Shots Tied to Heart Benefits

headline: Nia Vardalos, Not So ‘Instant’ Mom
text: The thing about Nia Vardalos’s book, “Instant Mom,” is that I want to push it onto people. Lots of people. People who have looked at my family and said, “Oh, we’ve thought about adoption.” People who I kind of suspect might, for one reason or another, be thinking about adoption. People who I, in my status as she-who-knows-best-about everything, think should maybe be thinking about adoption. (I would never really do that.)

headline: For Starters, Unmasking Subtleties in Verdi

In 2011, Michele Wiles left her principal position at American Ballet Theater to found Ballet Next with the former New York City Ballet principal Charles Askegard. In 2010, Troy Schumacher, a corps dancer with City Ballet, helped to jump-start BalletCollective, which encourages multimedia collaboration.

headline: Germany’s Culinary Stars
text: FRANKFURT — When young lovers dream of a romantic European dinner in a back-street hideaway packed with locals, those back streets tend to be in Paris or Florence, not Düsseldorf or Nuremberg. When thrill-seeking diners book long-distance travel to taste some pathbreaking chef’s strange new inventions, their planes land in places like Barcelona or Copenhagen, not Leipzig or Dresden.

headline: Line by Line, the Artist Luo Ying Alters Chinese Tradition
text: In her studio in Wuhan, a giant city in central China known more for heavy industry than for art, Luo Ying picks up a fine-tipped brush, dips it in ink and begins delicately painting bamboo leaves on rice paper.

headline: An Exploration of the Curious Case of Benjamin Britten
text: Benjamin Britten, whose centennial is being celebrated this year, wrote some of his finest works for the tenor Peter Pears, his lifelong partner and muse. Britten also composed works for friends like the guitarist Julian Bream, who met the couple at a party during the 1952 Aldeburgh Festival.

text: IF THE UNSPEAKABLE ever happens to newspapers, the colors of my parachute are clear: morning talk-show producer, artisanal goat-cheese farmer, garbage-truck driver (presuming the “depth perception” issue can be addressed).

text: Photos from Indonesia, the West Bank, England and Pakistan.

headline: Sharing Tragedy and Grief Over Dinner
text: It is nice to imagine that on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, everyone who went off to work at the World Trade Center said a picture-perfect loving goodbye to the spouse and children before the towers were destroyed. Alec, a ghost in Jack Canfora’s consistently clever “Jericho,” did not. “Jericho” is also painfully significant, an intelligent intertwining of the nature of grief, cultural identity, fraught relationships and shared tragedy.

headline: Sebelius Names Administration Veteran to Lead Tech Repair Efforts
text: WASHINGTON – The Obama administration did not look far for someone to lead the so-called tech surge to fix its troubled health insurance Web site: Jeffrey D. Zients, a management trouble-shooter already in line to take over as the chief White House economic adviser on Jan. 1, until then will manage the effort to resolve the technical failures.

headline: Living In Valley Cottage, N.Y.
text: A more affordable neighbor to the Nyacks and Congers, with an interesting connection to Czarist-era Russia.

headline: Rockwell and Tolstoy Collide in Valley Cottage, N.Y.
text: Valley Cottage, a small rectangle of green set amid the three Nyacks and Congers about 30 miles from New York in Rockland County, is a quiet suburb with a woodsy setting and an unexpected connection with Czarist-era Russia: Leo Tolstoy’s youngest daughter and secretary, Alexandra, who arrived in the area in the late 1930s, spent four decades establishing and nurturing a community for political exiles — a flourishing organization called the Tolstoy Foundation, through which the author’s legacy lives on in the hamlet today.

headline: Why Not Medicaid For All?
text: My Sunday column on the potential consequences of Obamacare’s botched rollout ended by sketching a scenario in which the program’s Medicaid expansion is deemed a success while its reform of the individual market leads to much-higher-than-expected costs and much-lower-than-expected participation rates. This combination would no doubt be politically helpful to the Republican Party in the short run, but (I argued) it would actually leave liberals with a fairly clear path forward: Keep pressing the Medicaid expansion on states that haven’t taken it (and look for John Kasich-style Republicans to partner with), return to the Joe Lieberman-killed idea of expanding Medicare to 55-and-overs, and basically try to further shrink the percentage of Americans who aren’t eligible for one or both of those single-payer programs. This wouldn’t amount to the full-on push for single payer that some people expect from the left if Obamacare fails or gets repealed, but it would move the U.S. toward the closest thing to single payer that we’re ever likely to get: A system in which both the late middle-aged and the lower middle class gradually get folded into government-run insurance alongside the poor, the disabled, and the aged; the individual market survives as a kind of de facto high risk pool (overpriced but technically accessible); and the employer mandate helps prop up employer-based health insurance for a shrunken but still substantial share of the population.

headline: Lawsuit at Worcester Paper Delays Times’s Sale of The Globe
text: A Massachusetts judge has temporarily blocked The New York Times Company’s planned sale of The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette to the investor John W. Henry, citing a lawsuit involving the Worcester newspaper and its delivery workers.

headline: Citing Shutdown, I.R.S. Says Tax Season Will Start Late
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service plans to delay the start of tax-filing season by a week or two because of the government shutdown, the agency said on Tuesday. But taxpayers will still have to turn in their 2013 returns by April 15 as usual.

headline: Families, and Money, With More Than One Complication
text: The evil forces in “Bastards,” the new, grimly beautiful and somewhat unhinged film from the French director Claire Denis, enter wearing masks. These are not the usual monsters that slink through the shadows, growling and prowling while baring sharp teeth and talons. The evil here slips into the back seat of chauffeured cars and smiles a dazzling white smile before grasping a child’s hand, patting a woman’s arm or slipping in a metaphoric knife. Evil like this only needs metaphoric weapons: power makes its bearers dirty but also keeps them clean.

headline: Keeping a Foot in the Office Door Can Ease Mothers’ Anxiety
text: In her practice as a divorce lawyer, Margy Klaw sees many highly educated, middle-aged women who wish they hadn’t left full-time work after having children. Faced with the prospect of failed marriages, she said, they are terrified that they won’t be able to support themselves.

headline: Another Liquor License Approved in Lower East Side Area
text: Manhattan’s so-called Hell Square, a three-by-three-block section of the Lower East Side that already has about 50 bars and restaurants, is getting another establishment that will serve liquor. State regulators approved a license on Tuesday for a planned private club that had drawn complaints from residents concerned that it would bring more traffic and noise.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 8: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
text: Doug Martin. Reggie Wayne. Jay Cutler. Those were just three of the big-name players who were injured during Week 7 as the bad news kept coming for fantasy owners. Football is a cruel sport, but as we talked about last week, a large part of fantasy football is finding opportunity among others’ misfortune.

headline: The Numbers Behind the Job Numbers
text: A look at how Janet Yellen, President Obama’s pick to lead the Federal Reserve, may interpret the latest jobs report, and what those numbers say about how how the economy is really doing.

headline: Morrissey on Pitching the Glamour of a Plain Life
text: Steven Patrick Morrissey of Manchester, England, a place “more brittle and less courteous than anywhere else on earth,” former singer for the Smiths, once and future hero for the misunderstood, and champion for powerless humans and animals, is also an inspired adman. The concept for the Smiths’ record covers, he explains in his new book, “Autobiography,” was “to take images that were the opposite of glamour and to pump enough heart and desire into them to show ordinariness as an instrument of power — or possibly, glamour.”

headline: A Would-Be Diva From Suburbia Spends a Night in the Big-City Spotlight
text: Imagine “Gypsy“Mama Rose as a ferociously needy nightclub performer of the sort occasionally glimpsed on public access television belting Broadway showstoppers like “Before the Parade Passes By.” One such would-be diva, Miriam Passman, appeared at 54 Below on Thursday evening in the person of Charles Busch in his sidesplitting show, “Ridin’ High.”

headline: Hearing Starts for Dancer Accused in Bolshoi Attack
text: A Moscow court on Tuesday opened and then quickly rescheduled the first public hearing in the case of an acid attack against the artistic director of the Bolshoi Theater, which seems set to look into personal grievances in one of the world’s premier ballet troupes. Pavel Dmitrichenko, above, the former principal dancer accused of paying two co-defendants to ambush the artistic director, Sergei Filin, with a mixture of sulfuric acid and urine in January, entered the courtroom in handcuffs and wore a slight smile as he stated his name and place of birth before the judge. Prosecutors were expected to read charges against Mr. Dmitrichenko on Tuesday but the case was rescheduled to next week because a lawyer for another of the accused did not attend the hearing. While the Bolshoi had been known for its atmosphere of extreme, and sometimes destructive, competition, the acid attack sent shock waves through Russia’s theater community and further exposed animosities among some of the troupe’s most gifted dancers.

He has released five albums, counting his 2009 soundtrack to “The Reader.” (He also scored the new Beat Generation biopic, “Kill Your Darlings.”) He has also repeatedly teamed up with another singular young talent who is pushing a traditional discipline forward, the choreographer Benjamin Milliepied, most recently on “Two Hearts” for the New York City Ballet.

headline: The Shanghai Secret
text: SHANGHAI — Whenever I visit China, I am struck by the sharply divergent predictions of its future one hears. Lately, a number of global investors have been “shorting” China, betting that someday soon its powerful economic engine will sputter, as the real estate boom here turns to a bust. Frankly, if I were shorting China today, it would not be because of the real estate bubble, but because of the pollution bubble that is increasingly enveloping some of its biggest cities. Optimists take another view: that, buckle in, China is just getting started, and that what we’re now about to see is the payoff from China’s 30 years of investment in infrastructure and education. I’m not a gambler, so I’ll just watch this from the sidelines. But if you’re looking for evidence as to why the optimistic bet isn’t totally crazy, you might want to visit a Shanghai elementary school.
