text: The race for Nassau County executive is one of the most important election battles in the New York region this year. The Democrat, Tom Suozzi, is trying to retake the seat from Edward Mangano, the Republican incumbent who won it four years ago by a mere 386 votes.

headline: Intellectual Disability and the Death Penalty
text: Eleven years ago, the Supreme Court banned the execution of intellectually disabled people in Atkins v. Virginia. Ever since, some states have worked to circumvent that ruling by defining intellectual disability using unscientific standards or by making it nearly impossible to prove. On Monday, the justices indicated that they may at last be ready to clarify the Atkins decision by agreeing to consider whether a Florida law defines intellectual disability too narrowly.

headline: The United States, Falling Behind
text: Researchers have been warning for more than a decade that the United States was losing ground to its economic competitors abroad and would eventually fall behind them unless it provided more of its citizens with the high-level math, science and literacy skills necessary for the new economy.

headline: Star Characters, Spun Anew, May Live Well More Than Twice
text: William Boyd’s new James Bond book, “Solo,” takes Britain’s best-known spy to the war-ravaged jungles of West Africa and the insalubrious streets of 1960s Washington, with interludes of sex, drinking, the suggestion of homoerotic torture and other familiar Bondian amusements. But in writing nearly 50 years after the death of Bond’s creator, Ian Fleming, Mr. Boyd faced some contemporary dangers.

headline: U.S. Asserts Terror Suspect Has Implicated Himself
text: A federal prosecutor in Manhattan told a judge on Tuesday that a Libyan man brought to the United States for prosecution on conspiracy charges after being held in military custody aboard a Navy ship made an incriminating statement to the authorities after being advised of his Miranda rights.

headline: Sebelius Thrust Into Firestorm on Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — The first, and perhaps most painful, call for Kathleen Sebelius to resign as President Obama’s health secretary came this month from an old family friend: Senator Pat Roberts, Republican of Kansas, who once boasted of a “special relationship” with Ms. Sebelius, forged when he worked for her father-in-law.

headline: Harlem River, Cut Off From Public, Is Getting a Push Out of Isolation
text: One by one, the rivers around Manhattan have emerged from decades of industrial abuse. The Hudson River has its five-mile ribbon of parkland and active kayaking community; the Bronx River, the occasional beaver sighting; and the East River, a popular ferry service — all contributing to the sense that New York is, in fact, a river city.

headline: Boston’s Victorino Leans In, Gets Bruised and Gets on Base
text: BOSTON — Red Sox Manager John Farrell sat in the interview room in Detroit’s Comerica Park last week and explained why Shane Victorino had been hit by so many pitches, 24 in all. Victorino had been crowding the plate, Farrell said, ever since he stopped switch-hitting and started batting right-handed full time in August.

headline: Lottery Numbers for Oct. 22, 2013
If Police Encounters Were Filmed
text: Should police officers be required to wear cameras that record their interactions with the public?

headline: Trade for Beason Seemed Minor, but the Giants Get Big Results
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants sent a late-round draft pick to the Carolina Panthers for middle linebacker Jon Beason earlier this month, it hardly seemed like a significant transaction. While the Giants had not made an in-season trade since 1986, they had installed a revolving door at linebacker.

headline: Corrections: October 23, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Doubleheader
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — How meta: games within a game. Solving this puzzle took me back to my childhood, and that of my kids’, because the classic boardgames are always the most fun, aren’t they?

headline: Family as a Hall of Mirrors
text: At moments during “Fun Home,” the beautiful heartbreaker of a musical that opened on Tuesday night at the Public Theater, you may feel you’ve developed quadruple vision, and not just because your eyes are misted with tears. It’s also a matter of those three actresses playing the same character at different ages, a device that usually feels strained in theater, but here comes off as naturally as breathing.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 23, 2013
text: “I won’t postpone happiness until I die.”

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Four People Charged in Brawl at Jets and Patriots Game
text: Four people were charged with assault on Tuesday, two days after a brawl in which a male New York Jets fan hit a female New England Patriots fan in the face on the concourse at MetLife Stadium.

headline: Sleeping in Opponent’s Shorts? Chicken Before Games? Terry Has Rituals
text: Regimented rules dictate Jason Terry’s basketball life. One would strain to call them rational.

headline: Russia Putting a Strong Arm on Neighbors
text: CHISINAU, Moldova — It was not enough for Dmitri O. Rogozin, a deputy prime minister of Russia, to warn darkly that it would be “a grave mistake” for Moldova to seek closer ties with Europe.

headline: Wainwright Sees Beltran in Pinstripes, and Then Wakes Up
text: BOSTON — Adam Wainwright woke up sweating last week, terrified by a bad dream: his Cardinals had lost the National League Championship Series and had failed to get Carlos Beltran to his first World Series. Beltran then signed with the Yankees, won the pennant and sat on a podium saying, “I’m so happy to be a Yankee and in the World Series.”

headline: Ronald Shannon Jackson, Composer and Avant-Garde Drummer, Dies at 73
text: Ronald Shannon Jackson, an avant-garde drummer and composer who led an influential electric band and performed with many of the greatest names in jazz, died on Saturday at his home in Fort Worth. He was 73.

headline: A Rematch Red All Over (Except the Green Monster)
text: BOSTON — John Axford had been with the St. Louis Cardinals only a few weeks before they clinched a playoff spot. Axford, a veteran reliever, decided then that it was time to learn more about his new team. He searched YouTube and found old World Series clips, including Bob Gibson closing out the Boston Red Sox here in 1967.

headline: In a Harvest, Palestinians Cast a Light on Hardship
text: BURIN, West Bank — For most of his 58 years, Ahmad Najar has picked olives each autumn with his family, the women and girls cooking a hot meal in the fields as the men and boys topped ladders to fell the black and green fruit onto large tarps. On Tuesday, Mr. Najar earned about $21 for nine hours harvesting a neighbor’s grove, part of a new program that pays Palestinians whose trees have been destroyed by Jewish settlers to help farmers whose access to the land is limited to a few days by the Israeli authorities.

headline: Greece Suspends State Financing for Far-Right Party
text: ATHENS — Greece’s Parliament voted early Wednesday to suspend state financing for political parties whose leaders or elected officials are charged with serious crimes, part of a continuing effort to rein in the neo-fascist Golden Dawn, which is under investigation on charges involving murder, blackmail and other offenses.

headline: Canucks Beat Isles, but Tortorella Has Other Reasons to Smile
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — John Tortorella called the game a mess, but he was in a cheerful mood on Tuesday after his first visit to the New York area since being fired last spring by the Rangers.

headline: 16 Candidates Disqualified in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — More than half of the Afghan presidential hopefuls had their hopes dashed on Tuesday when the country’s election commission declared that their candidacies did not meet documentary or citizenship requirements.

headline: Lhota, in Acrid Second Debate, Turns Up the Heat on de Blasio
text: His mayoral ambitions slipping away, Joseph J. Lhota shed his sleepy style to unleash a ferocious attack against Bill de Blasio on Tuesday night in an acrid debate that descended into a free-for-all of interruptions, name-calling and indignant lecturing.

headline: Mets’ Harvey Has Tommy John Surgery
text: Matt Harvey had successful Tommy John surgery to repair a partial tear of the ulnar collateral ligament in his pitching elbow. Dr. James Andrews performed the operation in Gulf Breeze, Fla.

headline: Chinese Newspaper Asks Police to Free Detained Reporter
text: Updated, 3:19 a.m. EST| A newspaper based in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou has published a bold, front-page appeal for the release of a detained reporter, prompting an outpouring of support online and sympathetic statements from prominent media and business figures.

headline: Obama’s Uncertain Path Amid Syria Bloodshed
text: WASHINGTON — With rebel forces in Syria in retreat and the Obama administration’s policy toward the war-ravaged country in disarray, Secretary of State John Kerry arrived at the White House Situation Room one day in June with a document bearing a warning. President Bashar al-Assad of Syria had used chemical weapons against his people, the document said, and if the United States did not “impose consequences,” Mr. Assad would see it as a “green light for continued CW use.”

headline: Bill de Blasio and the New Urban Populism
text: In an era of Clintonesque caution, when Democrats typically mute any expression of their leftward leanings, Bill de Blasio, who will almost certainly be elected mayor of New York City two weeks from now, does not concede an inch to the right.

headline: Iran: Man Who Survived Hanging Might Not Be Hanged Again
text: The judicial authorities suggested they might not rehang a convicted drug felon who survived the first attempt to hang him and who has been convalescing in a hospital pending a second execution attempt. The semiofficial ISNA news agency quoted the justice minister, Mostafa Pur-Mohammadi, as saying, “I do not think there is any need for a rehanging of the convict,” although he said he would defer to the courts. The condemned man, identified only as Alireza M., 37, a father of two, was left for dead in the morgue this month after he had swung in a prison gallows for 12 minutes. His survival attracted worldwide attention and focused scrutiny on Iran’s heavy use of the death penalty.

headline: France: U.S. Wiretapped Envoys, Newspaper Reports, Citing Leaks
text: The National Security Agency wiretapped the offices of the French mission to the United Nations and the French Embassy in Washington, according to an article published Tuesday in the French newspaper Le Monde. The disclosure, as well as similar material published in the German magazine Der Spiegel in September, was based on secret documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, a former N.S.A. contractor. Both reports cited documents from September 2010 that showed that the Americans had singled out French diplomats for surveillance while they were working in the United States. The article in Le Monde quoted an internal communications from Susan E. Rice, then the American ambassador to the United Nations, saying that the intelligence on how the French were forming their position on Iran, in particular, was helpful in keeping the United States one step ahead in the negotiations.

headline: Deferral Sought for Kenya Trials
text: The African Union submitted a formal request to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday to defer, for at least a year, the trials of Kenya’s president and deputy president in the International Criminal Court at The Hague in order to allow them to deal with the aftermath of last month’s deadly terrorist attack at the Westgate mall in Nairobi. The African Union said the attack showed that “Kenya is a front-line state in the fight against terrorism” and that the trials would prevent President Uhuru Kenyatta and his deputy, William Ruto, from “fulfilling their constitutional responsibilities.” Both are accused of crimes against humanity related to violence that roiled Kenya after disputed 2007 elections.

headline: Rancor in Second Mayoral Debate
text: The second televised debate between Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio saw more acrimonious exchanges than in the first encounter. Mr. de Blasio was more defensive, but there were no killer blows.

headline: Impossibly Light, Totally Sleek Handmade Bikes Built by a Tokyo Shipwright
text: Sueshiro Sano, a ninth-generation shipwright, makes lightweight, bespoke wooden bicycles in his Tokyo workshop. His bikes, which take three months to assemble and can cost up to $20,000, use Honduras mahogany and are custom built for a 100-percent tailored fit. They’re also impossibly light — a result of Sano’s well-honed boat-building methods — and have become objects of worship, and in some cases, derision, for hipsters and bike experts everywhere. Case in point: at a handmade-bike convention in Denver earlier this year, several incredulous participants accused Sano of using carbon fiber in his designs. (He doesn’t.) But Sano, who built his first boat at 13 and subscribes to the Japanese principle of monozukuri (“making things”), shrugs off such accusations. “For me, it’s about pride,” he says. 011-81-3-5569-6567.

headline: The Power of the Individual Mandate
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Annual Rise in Cost of Public College Slows
text: Tuition and fees at public universities increased less than 3 percent this academic year, the smallest rise in three decades, according to the annual College Board reports on trends in pricing and aid.

headline: How Music Can Boost Our Workouts
text: Making music — and not just listening to it — while exercising makes the exercise easier, a remarkable new experiment finds, suggesting that the human love of music may have evolved, in part, to ease physical effort.

headline: Word of the Day | libel
text: libel •\ˈli-bəl\• noun and verb

headline: Filing Ties Slain Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect to 2011 Case
text: BOSTON — A government court filing links the deceased suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, to a triple murder in Waltham, Mass., in September 2011, attributing the information to his now-dead friend.

headline: Scientists’ Ties to Food Industry Raise Questions in Europe
text: LONDON — One scientist who advised Europe’s food safety regulators about animal feed additives sits on the board of a foundation backed by the dairy industry.

headline: Big Lead Aside, de Blasio Holds Less Tightly to Line
text: Bill de Blasio, the toast of Haute Liberal New York, is on quite the golden roll. He attends tête-à-têtes with titans and was feted by a former secretary of state at a million-dollar fund-raising gala on Monday.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (Sundance) LAUREL CANYON (2003) Jane (Frances McDormand, above), an aging, hard-partying Los Angeles record producer, opens her California dwelling to her snobbish son (Christian Bale) and his fiancée (Kate Beckinsale), both Harvard Medical School graduates. Alessandro Nivola plays the lead singer of the rock band whose album is being overseen by Jane, who has a history of sleeping with the musicians she produces. This situation is no exception, and soon the entire family is led into temptation. “Having set up its domestic conflicts, the movie doesn’t know exactly where to go or how far, but when the inevitable emotional explosions erupt, the mutual recriminations carry a sharp sting,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film, written and directed by Lisa Cholodenko, who said she was partly inspired by Joni Mitchell’s album “Ladies of the Canyon.”

headline: News Quiz | October 23, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: India-Pakistan Hostility Kills Trade on Kashmir Border
text: On Oct. 21, 2008, a caravan of trucks decorated with garlands crossed a tiny bridge over a stream in Kashmir and made history. Aman Setu, or Peace Bridge, is on the Line of Control, the volatile, disputed border dividing the Indian and Pakistani-controlled parts of Kashmir. The last time a civilian vehicle had crossed that bridge was before India and Pakistan fought their first war over Kashmir in October 1947, before the lines of control were drawn.

headline: E.C.B. Vows Thorough Review of Banks at Risk
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank on Wednesday outlined the parameters for a wide-ranging review of commercial banks that is designed to expose and fix any problems and ultimately allow credit to begin flowing normally again, a prerequisite for faster economic growth.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 23, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Creating Animated GIFs From Sports Absurdities
text: In “Maker of Animated GIFs Waits for Offbeat Moments,” Sarah Lyall writes about Tim Burke, an editor at Deadspin, who monitors several sports events to catch unusual moments, which he captures as images, video or animated clips.

headline: Do Not Fear a Beet Without Goat Cheese
text: A dozen less familiar recipes for the notorious root.

headline: Could New York City Subways Survive Another Hurricane?
text: A good place to see how and why the Metropolitan Transportation Authority just barely survived Sandy last fall is the entrance to a tunnel at 148th Street and Lenox Avenue, in Central Harlem, where, just before the storm hit, a crew of carpenters built a plywood dam 8½ feet tall by about 55 feet wide. That ad hoc, low-tech, last-minute construction held the New York Harbor at bay and not only saved the city hundreds of millions of dollars, but also made it possible for the subway to come back to life as quickly as it did.

headline: Street Art From the South Bronx to Soweto
text: Who suspected royalty lurked in East New York back in the 1970s? Certainly not Martha Cooper, then a photographer for The New York Post, when she befriended a young graffiti artist who tagged HE3 on the walls of the Lower East Side.

headline: Why Do We Take Selfies?
text: How often do you take selfies — pictures of yourself, with your cellphone camera — and send them to someone, or post them on social media? What kind do you take, and what reactions do you usually get? Why do you think there has been such an increase in this kind of picture-taking in recent years?

headline: New York Today: When Cold Cases Heat Up
text: Updated 12:02 p.m. | How does it feel to close a 22-year-old murder?

headline: The Conservative Who Hates Slush Funds
text: A new book, sure to wind up on the nightstands of all campaign finance geeks, documents the many ways in which a torrent of cash is corrupting members of Congress and providing benefits for the wealthy. The issue cannot get enough publicity, but the best news of all is that the book was written by a conservative.

headline: The Faces of Balthazar
text: One of the more striking things about Balthazar, which I wrote about in this past Sunday’s Food & Drink issue, is how many workers have stayed there for several years. For waiters, it makes perfect sense — this is among the best service jobs you can find in New York because the tips are so good. (One server I spoke to is an architect who works only part time at his craft, because he makes more money at the restaurant.) But the management earns no tips, and neither does the back-of-house — still, those employees come in and peel potatoes, tenderize steaks, make stocks and generally make the place function. Below are portraits by Marvin Orellana of some of the people who have served Balthazar the longest, behind the scenes. (And one of a busboy, widely rumored to be a real estate magnate.)

headline: Life With Boko Haram
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — In December 2010, Nigeria experienced its first wave of terrorist bombings at Christian churches. In 2011, we had our first-ever suicide car bombing, at the United Nations headquarters here. The explosion rattled my nearby office building. Flinging myself on the floor, I assumed it was an earthquake. A bomb was still the last thing on my mind.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Challenges Microsoft, Offering Free Apps
text: At an event in San Francisco meant to feature its latest iPad tablet computing devices, Apple took aim on Tuesday at one of the biggest and seemingly unassailable businesses of its rival Microsoft, its Office software for tasks like word processing and spreadsheets, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Trying to Explain Complicated Ideas Online
text: Conventional wisdom suggests that a Web site has 10 seconds to convince a visitor to stay. That makes things especially difficult for businesses that hope to convey complicated thoughts through their sites.

headline: Spain Emerges From Two-Year Recession
text: MADRID — Spain pulled out of a two-year recession in the third quarter, with its economy growing 0.1 percent from the previous quarter, according to preliminary data released Wednesday by the Spanish central bank.

headline: America's Latest Foreign Adventure
text: PARIS — When people ask what I’m working on these days, I tell them about my new book, “How French People Take Out the Garbage.” It’s all about the elegant, common-sense Gallic approach to trash, which I, of course, refer to as les poubelles.

headline: Gambling With Civilization
text: The 50th anniversary issue of the New York Review of Books is out. My review of Bill Nordhaus is one of the pieces.

headline: Anger Growing Among Allies on U.S. Spying
text: BERLIN — The diplomatic fallout from the documents harvested by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden intensified on Wednesday, with one of the United States’ closest allies, Germany, announcing that its leader had angrily called President Obama seeking reassurance that her cellphone was not the target of an American intelligence tap.

headline: Don't Arm Thy Neighbor
text: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — I am not one of those who believe the United States’ days of world leadership are behind us. All my life I have been an admirer of our northern neighbor. I believe its strengths — its democracy, its founders’ wisdom, its people’s ingenuity and diversity — give it unique authority in the world. But many of its citizens and their leaders seem to take such authority for granted now, as if it were American property. The truth is, it must be earned, and today the United States is passing up opportunities to earn it.

headline: 2 Commercial Property Giants to Combine in $7.2 Billion Deal
text: Updated, 10:01 a.m. | American Realty Capital Properties and Cole Real Estate Investments, two of the largest commercial property owners in the country, are finally seeing eye to eye.

headline: Carrie, Love Your Work!
text: How the years fly! Only four decades ago, Carrie White was a misunderstood 17-year-old, flinging her mother across the room, dousing her mean schoolmates with blood. Now she is a successful entrepreneur of 55, with yet another box office hit about her life. Her business ventures over the years have been many: interior designer (conflict-of-interest disclosure, I once hired Carrie to move the furniture around my house); crane operator; transplant surgeon (The sight of a donor heart hovering over the operating table, which can be found on YouTube, is mesmerizing).

headline: Turkey Adrift
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s announcement last month that it would buy a long-range defense system from a Chinese company is the latest sign that Ankara’s attempts to strike an independent foreign policy have gone wrong.

headline: Thanks for Your Great Driving
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 2 Real Estate Firms to Join Forces
text: Two real estate investment trusts — American Realty Capital Properties and Cole Real Estate Investments — agreed to a $7.2 billion deal on Wednesday in which American Realty will buy Cole with a mix of cash and stock, bringing an end to tensions between the companies that have simmered much of the last year. Under the terms of the deal, Cole stockholders can choose either 1.0929 shares of American Realty stock, valued at $14.59, or $13.82 cash for each Cole share.

headline: T LUXURY
text: If you’re lucky enough to have some, let them make a brilliant statement against stark black and white dresses.

headline: Advice About Assisted Living for Aging Relatives, Part 2
text: Readers have sent more than 100  questions and suggestions to Debra Drelich, a specialist in geriatric care, about assisted living and other special living arrangements for aging relatives. Part 1 of her answers can be read here.

headline: Objects | Diamonds Are for Now
text: If you’re lucky enough to have some, let them make a brilliant statement against stark black and white dresses.

headline: Social TV Ads (Sort of) Come to Facebook
text: As Facebook and Twitter duke it out to be the town square for people nattering about their favorite television shows, Twitter has had a big advantage on the advertising side: it offers an ad targeting option that can help brands hit the same viewer twice, once on TV and once on Twitter.

headline: Chemical Giant to Close Scottish Plant After Talks Fail
text: LONDON — One of the largest manufacturing plants in Scotland will be closed with the loss of hundreds of jobs, the chemical giant Ineos said on Wednesday, after employees there declined to accept an ownership plan involving pension and job cuts.

headline: Muzaffarnagar Gang Rape Cases Languish in Police Files
text: NEW DELHI– About a month after the first report of a gang rape was registered in the Muzaffarnagar district of Uttar Pradesh, the police acknowledged they have yet to question anyone named in the six gang rape complaints filed in the aftermath of last month’s sectarian riots.

headline: Boeing Outlines Progress on 787s and Raises Forecast
text: Boeing’s chief executive said on Wednesday that the company was pushing hard to fix reliability problems with its early 787 Dreamliners that have frustrated several airlines.

headline: One, Two, Three, Boo!
text: There’s so much that’s predictable in the structure of counting books; even preschoolers can enjoy anticipating the numbers’ ascent or descent. But that format still leaves a lot of room for surprises. “Ghost in the House,” by Ammi-Joan Paquette, with illustrations by Adam Record, and “Ten Orange Pumpkins,” written and illustrated by Stephen Savage, bring the fun to spooky tales of ghosts, witches and mummies.

headline: The Gun Report: October 23, 2013
text: In January, 13-year-old Michael Graham killed himself with his father’s gun at his home in Brewster, N.Y. On October 14, his mother, Sheila Kearney Graham, overdosed on pain medication. She was 52. Yesterday would have been Michael’s 14th birthday.

headline: Inside the Sugar Factory
text: Artifacts, and sugar, are everywhere in the Domino refinery, which has been shuttered since 2004.

headline: Relics of the Domino Sugar Refinery, Frozen in Time and Syrup
text: They called it refined sugar. The process was anything but.

headline: Vatican Suspends German Bishop Accused of Lavish Spending on Himself
text: BERLIN — Pope Francis, who has made humility and modesty his hallmarks, sent a swift and clear message to Roman Catholics around the world on Wednesday, suspending a German bishop accused of spending millions on lavish renovations to his residence and forcing the chief administrator of the bishop’s diocese into early retirement.

headline: Rabobank Nears Settlement on Interest Rate Inquiry
text: LONDON — The Dutch lender Rabobank said on Wednesday that it was close to reaching settlements with American, British and other authorities over its role in setting global benchmark interest rates.

headline: Criticism of United States’ Mideast Policy Increasingly Comes From Allies
text: ROME — As the United States grapples with some of the most intractable problems in the Middle East, it has run into a buzz saw of criticism, not from traditional enemies but from two of its strongest allies.

headline: 1968: Black Power Protest at the Olympics
text: The black-gloved fists of the athletes Tommie Smith and John Carlos rose above the fold of the International Herald Tribune’s edition of October 18, 1968, as the newspaper covered one of the most iconic statements in the history of the civil rights movement.

headline: When the Listening Trumps the Tale
text: In Lower Manhattan, Foley Square is humming with potential tales. Lawyers are entering the courthouses nearby, federal workers are finishing up lunch on the park benches, commuters are catching the 6 p.m. train. Mundane? Perhaps, but to Dave Isay and the organization he founded, StoryCorps, each one of these lives could make for a fascinating story.

headline: Laid to Rest in the Front Yard
text: James Davis has been involved in a dispute with the town of Stevenson, Ala., for burying his wife on his property.

headline: 10 New York Stories That Might Make You Laugh, or Cry
text: It used to be a common sight near the Lexington Avenue passageway of Grand Central Terminal: a couple emerging from a back-lit booth, wiping away tears from reddened eyes, before collecting themselves and reluctantly rejoining the masses.

headline: In ‘Flipped’ Classrooms, a Method for Mastery
text: In traditional schooling, time is a constant and understanding is a variable. A fifth-grade class will spend a set number of days on prime factorization and then move on to study greatest common factors — whether or not every student is ready.

headline: Homes in Warsaw
text: Poland’s market boom started in 2004, when the country joined the European Union, and ended in 2009, after the American mortgage crisis.

text: A  CONTEMPORARY HOUSE IN WARSAW

text: 1888 Uncle Sam’s Ledger

headline: White House Official on National Security Is Fired After Twitter Posts Are Unmasked
text: WASHINGTON — In his day job at the White House, Jofi Joseph was known as a generally collegial guy, a junior but experienced staff member working on some of the nation’s most serious business — specifically arms proliferation, and especially involving Iran.

headline: A Hotel Chain Drops Pornography Channels
text: Pornography is off the pay-per-view menu at all 171 Nordic Choice Hotels, Scandinavia’s largest hotel group. In a statement, Petter Storalen, owner of Nordic Choice, said the decision was prompted by the company’s charity work with Unicef to combat child trafficking and sexual exploitation.

headline: A Moot Effort to Burnish the Reputation of Goldman Sachs
text: I hate to be the bearer of good news for Jamie Dimon, but everything is going to work out O.K.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Loans Are So Hard to Get
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: At 24-0, Ace Is an Inspiration in Japan’s Series
text: Unless the typhoon season disrupts the schedule of the Nippon Series, Masahiro Tanaka will take the ball for the Pacific League’s Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles in Game 1 on Saturday night, looking to continue one of the most remarkable runs by a pitcher in professional baseball, and doing it in a region desperate for positive events in the years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Image of the Day: October 23
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is on a three-day state visit to China.

headline: Whatever Happened to Freedom of the Press?
text: Stung by criticism of the Obama administration’s heavy-handed tactics in dealing with the media, Attorney General Eric Holder announced new guidelines in July for protecting reporters from overly zealous prosecutors. He advertised the guidelines as a better way of shielding reporters in federal leak investigations, which sounded promising. But if he cares about this problem at all, Mr. Holder should now withdraw his demand that James Risen of The New York Times reveal a source for his 2006 book on the C.I.A.

headline: ‘Damage Control’ at the Hirshhorn
text: The new exhibition, opening Thursday at the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, is built around works that document destruction.

headline: Arranging an Encore in Manhattan
text: Jim Stake and Liam Harvey, partners in business and in life, live in a four-story lakeside town-house condominium with 2,600 square feet of space in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

headline: Bang! Kaboom! Art!
text: WASHINGTON — The rubble from a “concert” in which a piano gets smashed; a sculpture that slowly pushes apart its gallery; a drawing by a modern master completely erased by a rival — all are masterworks from a neglected trend in which artists have been more into breaking than making. “Damage Control: Art and Destruction Since 1950,” a show that opens on Thursday at the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum here, is built around such harm-full works.

headline: Gliding High: Designing Paper Airplanes Based on the Physics of Flight
text: Overview | How do gliders fly? In this lesson, students design, build, test and modify paper airplanes based on the physics of flight and inspired by a Times article about the Perlan Project. Then, they test their planes in a contest and evaluate the forces of flight behind each design.

headline: Fracking Fight Focuses on a New York Town’s Ban
text: DRYDEN, N.Y. — This town in the Finger Lakes region is not the kind of place where one would expect a grass-roots uprising. Even its promotional brochure makes it sound sleepy, listing the main attractions as “a few large dairy farms, some crop farms and several horse ranches.”

headline: A Business Owner Who Backed Off Tries to Step Back In
text: PARTIES THAT COOK is a 14-year-old event business founded in San Francisco by Bibby Gignilliat, a former marketing manager at Williams-Sonoma who followed her muse — first by going to cooking school and then by starting a business that offers cooking classes as employee-appreciation and corporate team-building events. It now handles events for as many as 300 in San Francisco as well as in Chicago, Seattle and Portland, Ore., where it maintains satellite offices. The company employs 11 full-time workers at its headquarters, and about 65 chefs, servers and dishwashers on a contract basis. Last year, revenue reached $2.2 million.

headline: European Parliament Rejects New Subsidies for Fishing Fleets
text: PARIS — The European Parliament voted Wednesday to reject most new subsidies for the saltwater fishing industry and provide financial support for new ecologically friendly measures meant to prevent overfishing. But in a nod to commercial fishing fleets, the lawmakers did maintain some handouts to the industry.

headline: Call It the Theater of Contrition
text: In the years since his affair with Monica Lewinsky, has Bill Clinton struggled to remain faithful to Hillary Rodham Clinton? Did Eliot Spitzer turn to a prostitute because his marriage to Silda Wall Spitzer had lost its spark? What need was Anthony Weiner satisfying when he sent explicit photos to female admirers and humiliated his wife, Huma Abedin?

headline: How Does an Owner Who Stepped Away Reassert Control?
text: We just published a case study about the chief executive of an event company based in San Francisco who is in the process of reasserting control of her business. Several years ago, approaching her 50th birthday, Bibby Gignilliat, the founder of Parties That Cook, a company that offers cooking classes as employee-appreciation and corporate-team-building events, realized that she needed to resuscitate her long-ignored private life.

headline: Showtime Renews ‘Homeland’ and ‘Masters of Sex’
text: Showtime announced Tuesday that it was renewing its biggest current hit, “Homeland,” for a fourth season, as well as the new drama “Masters of Sex” for a second season.

headline: Nissan and Suzuki Issue Recalls for Braking Problems
text: Brake problems have prompted Nissan to recall about 153,000 sport utility vehicles from the 2013-14 model years and Suzuki to recall 210,000 motorcycles, the manufacturers have informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Caterpillar’s Stock Drops, and 2 Big Deals May Be to Blame
text: Two of Caterpillar‘s biggest-ever deals may have played a role in the $3 billion of market value that the company’s stock shed on Wednesday morning.

headline: Homes for $1,250,000
text: A federal-style house in Minneapolis; a Tudor in Denver; and a 19th-century brownstone condo in Boston.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,250,000
text: MINNEAPOLIS

headline: Our Last Name Meant ‘Bad Luck.’ So We Changed It.
text: “What is your name?” the judge asked my 3-year-old daughter who sat quietly, her feet dangling from her chair. She looked up, her big brown eyes barely visible over the imposing wood table in front of the judge’s bench. “Go ahead and say your name,” I said, shifting in the seat next to her, trying to fit my pregnant belly below the table. “Lena,” she answered almost inaudibly. I glanced at my husband, Russ, and wondered if he, too, thought this judicial inquisition was going to scar her for life.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Red Sox Take Game 1 From Bumbling Cardinals
text: BOSTON — Errors, missed pop-ups and fat pitches hardly seemed like the Cardinal Way. The St. Louis Cardinals had stormed into the World Series while priding themselves on their ideal of professionalism and strong fundamentals.

headline: Feeding Fliers With Local Fare
text: Wolfgang Puck now has company: a number of airports across the country are opening restaurants from high-profile hometown chefs, offering local flavor to fliers.

headline: Food Matters | For L.A.’s Thoughtful Young Eaters, a New Breed of Catering Company
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: T-Mobile US Tries to Lure Tablet Customers With Some Free Data
text: T-Mobile US, one of the largest American mobile carriers, says it wants to change the way people use tablets. The carrier on Wednesday said it would give customers a small amount of free cellular data to use on their tablets each month.

headline: Looking for a Bus or Train? New Sites Aim to Help
text: IF YOU WANT to search a single Web site for fares across multiple airlines, there are plenty of options — Priceline, Orbitz, Expedia — that allow you to do just that. But the same cannot be said if you’re planning to travel long distance by bus or train. Typically you have to know the name of the company you plan to use and make a reservation through its Web site.

headline: Hotel Review: Copacabana Palace in Rio de Janeiro
text: Rates

headline: After ‘There’s a Kid With a Gun’ Came ‘Teacher Down’
text: In a trembling voice, the student called 911 to ask for help as a shooting unfolded at a Nevada elementary school this week. The student said: “This is a student from Sparks Middle School. Can you please send police out here? There is a kid with a gun.”

headline: Longing for the ‘Wow’ at Apple’s Product Showcases
text: Apple’s much-hyped product demonstrations used to end with an emphatic “wow!”

headline: ‘The Simpsons’: Springfield to Brazil
text: D’oh. Homer Simpson a referee at next year’s World Cup?

headline: Glaxo Sales Fall in China as Inquiry Continues
text: The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline reported Wednesday that its third-quarter earnings were badly battered by slumping product sales in China, a country where it faces a continuing bribery investigation.

headline: Wheelies: The Here’s Looking at You Kid Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Alan S. Blinder on Janet Yellen
text: Alan S. Blinder, an economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, talks about Janet Yellen’s handling of policy disagreements at the Fed.

headline: Russia Reduces Charges in Greenpeace Case
text: MOSCOW — Russian investigators on Wednesday dropped piracy charges against the crew members of a Greenpeace International ship who staged a protest against oil exploration in the Arctic Ocean last month, but said they would still face lesser charges of hooliganism.

headline: New York Public Library Postpones Release of Revised Renovation Plan
text: The New York Public Library will not release revised plans for its 42nd Street flagship renovation — or independent cost estimates of alternative options — this fall as expected, the library said on Wednesday.

headline: Boston and St. Louis Orchestra Musicians Play Up the World Series
text: A World Series just isn’t a World Series if there isn’t a certain amount of trash-talking between the two teams’ supporters, but the world of high culture used to stand apart from it all.

headline: 8 Questions for 3 Buffetts
text: Warren E. Buffett’s son Howard Graham Buffett and his grandson Howard Warren Buffett have written a new book, “Forty Chances: Finding Hope in a Hungry World,” which chronicles their philanthropic work on hunger, farming and poverty around the world. This is an edited transcript of a discussion with Warren Buffett, his son and grandson.

headline: An Afghan Interpreter Seeks a Visa That Is Unlikely to Come
text: Recently, a photo of a young Afghan man lying in a position that would usually be described as “face down in the dirt” was posted on the Facebook page for applicants to a special American visa program. In this case, however, the man in the photograph couldn’t be described that way because his head had been cut off and placed on the small of his back so that his lifeless eyes stared at the camera. He had been an interpreter for United States Marines advising the Afghan Border Police in 2010, which is presumably why insurgents made an example of him. I don’t know his story, but I can tell you Amin’s.

headline: Theater Will Ignore NC-17 Rating for ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color’
text: Abdellatif Kechiche’s “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” which won the Palme d’Or in Cannes earlier this year, has received a lot of attention — some salacious, some censorious — for its extended and explicit lesbian sex scenes. The film, about a French teenager’s relationship with a slightly older woman, is opening in New York and Los Angeles on Friday (and in other cities soon after) with an unsurprising NC-17 rating.

headline: Tea Party Group Begins Anti-Health Care Law Blitz in Four House Districts
text: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity, the Tea Party group that has made rolling back the health care law one of its priorities, is starting a $2 million campaign of television, radio and Internet advertisements aimed at lawmakers facing tough re-election battles in four House swing districts.

headline: Lobbying Heats Up Before Farm Talks
text: WASHINGTON — As the House and Senate prepare to meet next week to work out differences in their farm bills, lobbying efforts are intensifying to get last-minute changes to the 1,000-page legislation that sets the nation’s farm and nutrition policies.

headline: Among the Ruins, Education Is Also Lost
text: Children in Haiti are languishing in camps or working in menial jobs because thousands of schools in and around the devastated capital of the country could remain closed for months or never reopen.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Fight Nukes With Nukes
text: Via Philip Weiss

headline: Keeping Score: Statistics to Watch at the World Series
text: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championships characteristics in our book, “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.” In particular, our work relates key statistical factors to concepts of sports psychology like leadership, consistency and minimizing errors. Based on this research, we focused on factors that might help predict the winner of the World Series between the Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals, which begins Wednesday night.

headline: Scene City: Fashion Stars Take a Bow
text: Miley Cyrus, Marc Jacobs and Aretha Franklin celebrate Fashion Group International’s 30th annual awards.

headline: Roundup slide show
text: Roundup Slide Show

headline: Appeals Court Throws Out Confidential Arbitration in Delaware
text: A decision by a federal appeals court has ended Delaware’s experiment with confidential arbitration.

headline: Bill Mazer, Sports Fixture in New York, Dies at 92
text: Bill Mazer, who was a voice and face of sports coverage in New York for decades, pioneering sports-talk radio and becoming a television fixture while earning the nickname the Amazin’ for his encyclopedic recall of sports facts and figures, died on Wednesday in Danbury, Conn. He was 92.

headline: A Wife Committed to Cruz’s Ideals, but a Study in Contrasts to Him
text: WASHINGTON — At first glance, Senator Ted Cruz’s wife, Heidi Nelson Cruz, seems to be just the sort of person the Tea Party supporters who celebrate her husband’s anti-establishment positions love to hate.

headline: Middle East Peace Talks Go On, Under the Radar
text: JERUSALEM — A recent Israeli editorial cartoon depicted the lead Israeli and Palestinian peace negotiators beleaguered on treadmills, with Secretary of State John Kerry between them. Hands on the controls, Mr. Kerry was shown saying, “I’m upping the tempo a bit more.”

headline: The Benefits of Having Your Own Moving Truck
text: After living here and there for a few years, the time finally came for me to consolidate my things and move them all to one place. The problem? All of my things had ended up in Boulder, Colo., and I live in Brooklyn. That meant I needed a moving truck, and moving trucks can be pretty pricey to rent for a cross-country move.

headline: A Royal Christening in Britain Amid a Refrain of Coos
text: LONDON — Some spent the night in the English rain, huddling under tarpaulins and keeping warm with flasks of tea outside St. James’s Palace. It was all to secure a good view of Prince George of Cambridge on his christening day Wednesday. The prince had not been seen in public since he was born three months ago.

headline: Lorde and Eminem Battle at the Top of the Singles Chart
text: Here’s a contest that few could have predicted even a couple of months ago: Lorde vs. Eminem. But the two — a megastar rapper who has sold tens of millions of albums, and a 16-year-old rookie from New Zealand — are currently contending for dominance of Billboard’s singles chart.

headline: Nina Arianda Returning to New York Stage in ‘Red Vienna’
text: Nina Arianda, who who won the 2012 Best Actress Tony award for her turn as a dominatrix in “Venus in Fur,” is returning to the stage and staying on the dark side. She will star in the world premiere of “Tales From Red Vienna,” by David Grimm, which begins previews on Feb. 26 and opens March 18 at Manhattan Theater Club’s Off Broadway home at City Center.

headline: An Evening of Mark Morris ... and Some Other People
text: There is Mark Morris, and then there are all the other choreographers who are deprived of possessing even a sliver of his art. At least that’s what it felt like on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where Houston Ballet unveiled its opening-night program of four repertory ballets beginning with Mr. Morris’s enchanting and sophisticated “Pacific.”

headline: Following the Stars in a Rush to Riches
text: This year’s winner of the Man Booker Prize, “The Luminaries” by Eleanor Catton, is long and demanding, as Booker winners often are. In the past five years, two Bookers have gone to Hilary Mantel, whose “Wolf Hall” is at first a grueling read, since Ms. Mantel artfully complicated her Tudor tableau by eschewing names for pronouns. But “Wolf Hall” rewards the effort it demands, and in the end everything is fully, triumphantly clear. The same cannot be said for “The Luminaries,” nor is it Ms. Catton’s intent.

headline: A Night to Pay Homage With Their Wardrobes
text: When you are the recipient of a Fashion Group International superstar award, lots of people show up wearing your clothes.

headline: Three Men Lean in for Mutual Support
text: The bassist Christian McBride’s new trio is constant sleek fun, organized and coordinated. It’s connected to a line in small-group jazz going back to the 1950s that made elegance and continuity and affability a priority, one that includes Hank Jones, Dr. Billy Taylor and, more recently, Mulgrew Miller. Its solos run hot when it’s time for them to do so, and within formatted spaces; then they subside and lead into the next solo, or two-way conversation, or three-way themes.

headline: A Guitar Opens Up Some Musical Spaces That Only a Voice Can Fill
text: Fiona Apple has found a way to let her moods swing even more widely. She has always thrived on a precarious blend of the meticulous and the impulsive, and her current tour, which is billed as a duo with the guitarist, songwriter and producer Blake Mills, opens up new extremes for her to toy with. On Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, she was skittish and stubborn, baleful and whimsical, giggly between songs and, when she sang, cathartically serious. With the seeming casualness of a club show (despite a set list that has been consistent throughout the tour), the concert held a sold-out theater audience rapt.

headline: Student Ensemble’s Sound Belies Its Origin
text: There are experts — I’m not one of them — who can identify an orchestra by its sound. During Monday evening’s concert of the Juilliard Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, I found myself wondering what these people would have heard if they had sat blindfolded through this program of works by Bartok and Bruckner, conducted by Alan Gilbert. As powerful waves of rich brass chords rolled out during the last movement of Bruckner’s Symphony No. 7, would they have guessed that the players are students, most in their early 20s? When the sound of the violins intensified with the heat and gleam of molten metal, could they have known that the section was almost entirely made up of women?

headline: From the Wilderness to an Electric Role
text: Diane Davis was 12 hours from New York last June, vacationing in the Canadian wilderness without electricity or running water — but, luckily, with cellphone service — when her agent called her about an audition for the Primary Stages revival of “The Model Apartment,” Donald Margulies’s surreal, darkly comic 1988 play. “So I got in a canoe, with an iPad in a dry bag, and I paddled over to my friend’s house,” Ms. Davis said.

headline: Lundqvist’s Backup to Make N.H.L. Debut
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist’s nightmarish season took another bad turn Wednesday when the Rangers confirmed he had a lingering injury that would keep him out of Thursday’s game at Philadelphia.

headline: Bach in a String Concert, Sharing a Program With Bluegrass
text: The most impressive musicians are often versatile, but few match the breadth of the brilliant mandolinist Chris Thile. Even in an era when eclecticism is the prevailing aesthetic, Mr. Thile, a member of the progressive-bluegrass quintet Punch Brothers, stands out for his novel artistic juxtapositions.

headline: Q. and A.: Tom Byer on Soccer in China
text: In recent years Chinese athletes have won international competitions in sports ranging from archery to weightlifting. But their performances in soccer, one of the country’s most popular spectator sports, have long stagnated.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the West Bank, Gaza, Pakistan and China.

headline: Anatomy: ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color’
text: In this Anatomy of a Scene, Abdellatif Kechiche narrates a sequence from “Blue Is the Warmest Color.”

headline: A Seattle Theater’s Broadway Credentials
text: SEATTLE — By the fall of 2008, Louis Hobson had starred in enough Seattle productions of Broadway musicals — “Hair,” “Evita,” “West Side Story” — that he decided to shoot for Broadway itself. Within weeks, the dream came true: He was cast as the two doctors in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal,” supporting roles that earned him good notices and better money during the show’s 22-month run.

headline: Could Obamacare Discredit Neoliberalism?
text: As a kind of companion piece to my last post on the liberal and conservative visions for health insurance, I strongly recommend reading this post by Mike Konczal, which strikes a note that you can expect to hear sounded more often on the left if the Obamacare rollout continues to go badly. Contra conservatives suggesting that HealthCare.gov represents some kind of discrediting moment for liberalism, Konczal argues that the potential policy problems associated with a nonfunctional web portal really just point to the problems with neoliberalism — a much-debated term of art, but defined for his purposes as the post-1970s idea that social insurance should be “heavy on private provisioning and means-testing,” that it should preserve as much “choice and competition” as possible, and that it should be delivered at the state level or through state-and-federal coordination rather than by the federal government alone.

headline: Sparse Competition and Higher Premiums
text: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color’
text: In the French coming-of-age drama “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” a high school student named Adèle (Adèle Exarchopoulos), finds romance with an art student, Emma (Léa Seydoux). In this video, the director Abdellatif Kechiche discusses a scene that takes place before Adèle meets Emma, and involves a conversation she has with a girl at her school, Béatrice (Alma Jodorowsky). Their exchange becomes an important moment in Adèle’s self-discovery.

headline: $45 for a Premium Hockney Viewing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Think of it as the art-world equivalent of extra leg room — a museum’s resourceful way to turn a customer perk into a profit. Along with selling its regular timed tickets, priced up to $25, for “David Hockney: A Bigger Exhibition,” which opens on Saturday, the de Young Museum here is also offering a premium ticket online for up to $45. This ticket allows visitors entry at any time on the day of their choosing.

headline: London’s Tech City Takes Root
text: The British capital’s growing credibility in the tech scene has attracted companies to East London — or Tech City, as some local politicians call the area.

headline: Technology on the Thames
text: LONDON — Parts of this city have the outward signs of a budding high-tech scene. Run-down warehouses have been remodeled into gleaming office spaces. Some greasy diners have been transformed into trendy restaurants. And many wood-paneled pubs have become wine bars.

headline: A Liberal Parts Ways With Fox
text: Sally Kohn, one of the Fox News Channel’s most visible liberal pundits, parted ways with the network this week and turned up almost immediately on one of its rivals — MSNBC.

headline: Music History at Caffè Lena
text: Since 1960, this venue in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been an important outpost of the folk music revival.

headline: Everyone Except Mozart
text: The Amore Opera is in many ways recognizable as an outgrowth of the old seat-of-the-pants Amato Opera, now defunct. But the Amato knew its limitations and made itself lovable by tweaking pretension, starting with its miniature theater, fitted out with retractable chandeliers à la the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Folk Music Heaven, Upstairs
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The first sign that Caffè Lena is different from other joints where guitars are strummed and coffee is sipped comes before you even enter the place. Next to it, off a picturesque side street here, runs Lena Lane, an alleyway commemorating the club and the woman who ran it and became a local legend.

headline: Blurring Lines Between People and Other Creatures
text: At first glance, Melanie Maar’s dances are subtle creations, but by the final blackout, it’s hard to shake the feeling that you’ve traveled to a mystical land where nothing is what it seems. In “Our Other,” performed Friday at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church, Ms. Maar weaves an intricate tapestry pairing ideas related to nature and religion, humans and animals, sexuality and restraint. It’s earthy, but refined. Sound emanates both from people and from nature, so that once you’re good and settled inside Ms. Maar’s imagination, you’re rarely sure where you are. A factory? A dewy forest?

headline: Hollywood Stars Ask N.S.A. to Stop Mass Surveillance
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The debate over National Security Agency spying has gone Hollywood.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Pumpkins
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Jury Finds Bank of America Liable in Mortgage Case
text: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | Bank of America, one of the nation’s largest banks, was found liable on Wednesday of having sold defective mortgages, a jury decision that will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.

headline: A Sport Coat Meets a Topcoat
text: There’s a spirited new entry on the men’s wear scene.

headline: Sophie Calle Mounts an Exhibition of Missing Art
text: When the French artist Sophie Calle’s exhibition “Last Seen” opens tomorrow at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, it will mark an ironic homecoming of sorts for her.

headline: A Roundup of Worthy Apps for the New iPads
text: Tablets have altered the barriers of the computer world, shattering the belief that a personal computer must have a keyboard. And while laptops have become associated with boring Excel documents and the other digital trappings of work, tablets are making computing fun again.

headline: Joel Grey, M.C. in ‘Cabaret,’ to Publish Memoir
text: Joel Grey, the actor best known for his role as the M.C. in “Cabaret,” for which he won a Tony Award and an Oscar, will publish a memoir with Flatiron Books, a new imprint of Macmillan.

headline: Art You Can Live With
text: Josh Ingmire, whose Hundred Mile showroom opened last weekend in Rhinebeck, N.Y., thinks that the shop, which offers rugs, Carl Hansen classic furniture, fresh design from Established & Sons and other tasteful things, is perfectly located. “The riffraff goes to Poughkeepsie,” he said. (Rhinebeck, a historic village 18 miles north of Poughkeepsie, is, significantly, beyond the Metro-North commuter line.)

headline: Designer Theremin
text: Dorit Chrysler plays a theremin designed by François Chambard at the Judith Charles Gallery, where a dozen one-of-a-kind theremins are on display in the show “Odd Harmonics.”

headline: What Would They Do with Axl Rose?
text: “Wild Art” (Phaidon, $39.95), a new bricklike illustrated tome by David Carrier and Joachim Pissarro, aims to cover art that doesn’t find its way to the galleries, at least for a while. The expected subjects are represented, like graffiti and street art, two forms that don’t lack for attention, but so are plenty of weirder examples. Like Jason Mercier’s portraits of Kevin Bacon and Condoleezza Rice, made from the materials their surnames suggest. Or Kyle Bean’s sculpture constructed from eggshells, left. Or Carol Hummel’s crocheted sweater for a tree, above.

headline: Eating in a Most Peculiar Way
text: For her “Itinerant Gastronomy” project, the artist Mary Ellen Carroll stages intimate dinners in non-culinary-oriented settings. On Sunday, she will host the heart surgeons Dr. Bud Frazier and Dr. Billy Cohn, the chef Hugo Ortega and several other formidable figures in a vacant office at the top of the Pennzoil Place building in Houston.

headline: The Cavendish Invitational in Monaco
text: Look at the South hand. The dealer on your left opens one heart, your partner passes, and responder raises to two hearts. What would you do?

headline: Discounts at Flor, Maine Cottage Furniture, Blue Dot and Luceplan
text: All regularly priced Flor carpet design squares are 25 percent off, in stores and online, through Tuesday (Fedora, originally $9 per square, is about $7 per square); (866) 281-3567, flor.com. Seating is 20 percent off at Maine Cottage Furniture, through Oct. 31 (the Margaret bench in mango, usually $520, is $416); (866) 366-3505, mainecottage.com. Blu Dot is discounting all its furniture 20 percent, through Nov. 10, at stores nationwide (the Shale credenza, regularly $2,699, is about $2,159; the Perimeter floor lamp, regularly $399, is about $319): (612) 782-1844, bludot.com. Luceplan is discounting in-stock lighting by up to 80 percent, through Nov. 17 (the Curl table lamp by Sebastian Bergne, originally $435, is $261; the Otto Watt task lamp by Paolo Rizzatto and Alberto Meda, shown, originally $530, is $318); 49 Greene Street (Grand Street), (212) 966-1399, luceplan.com

headline: A Wave of Strange Creatures
text: Two years ago, François Chambard had not heard of a theremin, one of the first electronic instruments, though chances are he had caught its sound on movie soundtracks. But when Allen Farmelo, a music producer friend, told him about the device, which is played by waving one’s hands around its two antennas, Mr. Chambard, the principal of UM Project, a furniture design company in Brooklyn, attempted to make one. Or 12.

headline: Yes, That’s Right: Sconces
text: Why do you need a sconce? Brian McCarthy can give you a list of reasons.

headline: A Blueprint for Misery
text: The Scandinavian artists Michael Elmgreen, 52, and Ingar Dragset, 44, like to place statues of imaginary unhappy inhabitants inside their sculpture installations. For the 2009 Venice Biennale, they floated a simulated corpse of a wealthy, balding art collector face down in a swimming pool. This fall, they turned decrepit galleries at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London into “Tomorrow,” the London apartment of Norman Swann, a mediocre modernist architect who has contracted H.I.V. and run out of inherited money. Along with about 100 objects from the museum’s collection, like an 18th-century Japanese ivory horse figurine and an 1850s plaster fig leaf used to make the museum’s male sculptures less shocking, evidence of Swann’s fictional life is strewn about, including a passport, cigarette butts, unpaid bills, models of unrealized buildings and a biographical script 100 pages long.

headline: Where Peace Comes Whizzing By
text: While making a movie, Carrie Schoenfeld built a fossil-fuel-free country house with her husband.

headline: For Her Next Production ...
text: GHENT, N.Y. — There’s the everyday juggling of work and chores that most of us do, and then there’s the amped-up kind that Carrie Schoenfeld — artist, writer, inventor — thrives on.

headline: Only Slightly Mad
text: If you’re looking for David Bromberg, the folk musician-turned-luthier-turned-recording artist (again), just follow the beads.

headline: David Bromberg and Nancy Josephson: Duet for Violin and Voodoo
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — On the kitchen counter of the Bromberg-Josephson household, a voluptuous cremation urn glitters with sequins, glass beads and one very gnarly molar. Nancy Josephson, who bedazzles not just reliquaries but taxidermy, furniture and automobiles, envisions it as both her final resting place and a shout-out to her great-great-grandchildren.

headline: Pension Alert Is Issued in Chicago Budget Talk
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Wednesday proposed a spending plan for his city next year that is full of nips and tucks: a 75-cent per pack increase in the cigarette tax, higher zoning permit fees for big developments, an end to some retirees’ health insurance subsidies and a rolling hiring freeze. Left alone, for now, were more controversial taxes, on property, sales and gasoline.

headline: The Devil Is in the Details, but Few Take Notice
text: Haunted house designers have a curious relationship with their finished work. They fill each haunt with meticulous, lifelike details, yet the disorientation and fear they aim to induce doesn’t encourage appreciation by the public.

headline: Face to Face With My Inner Mean Old Man
text: When it comes to noise, I am, to put it generously, a sensitive neighbor. So when the bloodcurdling screams started emanating from the Gateway’s Haunted Playhouse up the street from my weekend retreat in Bellport, Long Island, several years ago, it irked me. I had just spent the summer battling the teenagers in the house behind me for talking late into the night on a screened-in porch. And now, with summer barely over, I’d

headline: How to Haunt a House
text: For designers who specialize in haunted houses, it’s high season. What scares them is how little time there is to furnish the home of your nightmares.

headline: House Haunters
text: Pomona, Calif. — On a recent morning, Steve Kopelman stood inside a hangar-size building at the Fairplex event center here, drinking his third or fourth Diet Dr Pepper of the day and eyeing a giant inflatable goat skull. The skull had arrived by truck from Colorado two days earlier and had just been suspended above a plywood wall spray-painted black that had been hastily erected near the building’s main entrance.

headline: The Over-the-Topcoat
text: Among the popular ideas now in circulation about how our primeval cave-man brain influences modern behavior is the theory that when we go shopping, women “forage” and men “hunt.” You know, just as they did back in Paleolithic times, when women brought home mushrooms (and a new mink pelt), and men brought home a mastodon (and a high-definition wide-screen cave painting).

headline: Fall Fashion Trends: Jewelry, and Skirts that Flutter
text: Given the ubiquity of street photography, it can now be easier to trend-spot outside fashion shows than inside. Case in point: the big and bold retro skirts so many women were wearing at the shows last month. You almost expected Carmel Snow to pull up in a Cadillac Brougham. Zanita Morgan, a model turned blogger and photographer, was a latter-day Grace Kelly in a voluminous skirt and angora sweater; Eva Chen, the Lucky editor, was uptown chic in a brocade Tibi; and Eleanor Strauss, the style director of Shopbop, wore a shorter style with a fitted crop top and leather jacket. While the days are still mild, you can pull off a hint-of-skin top under a leather jacket or peacoat.

headline: Competition Rises for AT&T, as Does 3rd-Quarter Profit
text: SAN FRANCISCO — T-Mobile USA, the underdog among the four big American phone carriers, has made aggressive moves to shake up the wireless industry this year — and AT&T in particular. But AT&T’s results have not budged.

headline: How Winglets Work
text: Winglets help lessen the wind vortexes which normally form at the tip of an airplane wing during flight.

headline: Openings, Sales and Events for the Week of Oct. 24
text: Openings and Events

headline: Funding Circle, British Peer-to-Peer Lender, Expands to U.S.
text: When the soccer team F.C. Barcelona asked Nick Daffern whether his company could set up some merchandise kiosks at its legendary stadium, the Camp Nou, the British businessman knew he had to find some cash fast to fulfill the order.

headline: Makeup Trend: Matte Base Layers
text: “Modern” matte, a shine-free finish without any hint of chalkiness, was a big trend at New York Fashion Week. Here are three products that can help lay a base for the season’s velvety blushes and eye shadows.

headline: Prospect Park Closing on Friday for Obama Visit
text: A year ago, Prospect Park was closed for several days during and after Hurricane Sandy. In May, parts of the park were taken over by the Great GoogaMooga, a food and music festival. Now comes Marine One.

headline: New Mexico Justices to Rule on Gay Marriage
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — The New Mexico Supreme Court is poised to decide once and for all whether same-sex marriage is legal in this state, addressing an issue that the Legislature has for years failed to resolve and the governor has avoided — but that Democratic county clerks have embraced, under threats of legal action and at considerable political risk.

headline: The Biggest Economy Killer: Our Government
text: The government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis inflicted a toll on the American economy, but that cost is only a fraction of the total damage that the federal government has been causing to the American economy.

headline: New Clean Air Rules Would Do Little
text: STANFORD, Calif. — PRESIDENT OBAMA’S recently proposed regulations to limit carbon-dioxide emissions from new power plants have been much heralded by environmentalists because they would make new coal-fired power plants too costly to operate. In truth, they accomplish almost nothing.

headline: For Emily Ratajkowski, ‘Blurred Lines’ Brings a Career Path Into Focus
text: It was a few days after New York Fashion Week, and Emily Ratajkowski was at the Gemma restaurant on the Bowery, huddled over a pot of chamomile tea and nursing a cold.

headline: At the Bathroom Sink, Razors Face Off
text: The return of facial hair, whether in the form of artful scruff or hipster beard, has been a major trend in men’s grooming over the last decade. But it can’t last forever; at least, that is what the founders of several up-and-coming razor companies hope.

headline: Oil Spill in North Dakota Raises Detection Concerns
text: DENVER — For several days last month, Steven Jensen smelled the oil, wafting up over his rolling wheat farm near Tioga.

headline: Web Sites and Grave Sites
text: Republicans are apoplectic about Healthcare.gov, the official Web site for the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Butch Warren, 74, Prominent Jazz Bassist, Dies
text: Butch Warren, a bassist who performed and recorded with Thelonious Monk, Herbie Hancock and many others and seemed poised for a high profile in the jazz world before his career was permanently derailed by mental illness and substance abuse, died on Oct. 5 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 74.

headline: A Stylist’s Custom Fashion
text: TWENTY YEARS OF WRANGLING celebrities, dressing celebrities and styling celebrities has taught Mary Alice Haney that no designer dress on earth is right for everyone. Almost everything goes to the tailors at some point. So when Ms. Haney, a stylist and a former West Coast editor for magazines like GQ and Marie Claire, began to design her own collection, she wanted women to have options.

headline: Adelson Suggests U.S. Nuclear Strike on Iran Ahead of Negotiations
text: Updated, Saturday, 3:54 p.m. | Sheldon Adelson, a leading donor to conservative politicians who share his staunch support for Israel, said on Tuesday night that the United States should begin negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program by launching a nuclear strike on the Iranian desert.

headline: 2012 Leak Detection Study
text: A study found that emergency responders or members of the public were more likely to detect hazardous liquid pipeline spills than pipeline companies themselves.

headline: Lawmaker Says Iran Has Halted Enrichment
text: TEHRAN — An influential Iranian lawmaker says his country has halted the production of enriched uranium up to 20 percent, a level that experts say is only a few technical steps from what is needed to produce a nuclear weapon.

headline: Mickey Boardman: Keeping Up With His Followers
text: At a few minutes past 6 last Thursday night, Mickey Boardman arrived for Paper Magazine’s annual Nightlife Awards at Marquee. Mr. Boardman, the magazine’s editorial director, was wearing a black Lacoste shirt, Missoni for Converse sneakers, a Missoni for Target cardigan (“Someone tweeted that Cate Blanchett wore it in ‘Blue Jasmine’ ”) and oversize Prada women’s sunglasses converted to clear prescription lenses, and he was carrying a Stella McCartney bag. In his hand was his omnipresent iPhone.

headline: Nicola Formichetti Pays Tribute to Diesel
text: THE FULL IMPACT of Nicola Formichetti’s new role as artistic director of Diesel will not be felt until March, when he reveals his fall 2014 collection, but that is a long time to wait. Too long, Mr. Formichetti said.

headline: Noel Harrison, Actor and Singer of ‘Windmills of Your Mind,’ Dies at 79
text: Noel Harrison, the actor and folk troubadour best known for his role on the NBC spy drama “The Girl From U.N.C.L.E.” and his rendition of the Academy Award-winning song “The Windmills of Your Mind,” died on Oct. 20 in Exeter, England. He was 79.

headline: Boy, 14, Is Arraigned as Adult in Killing of a Teacher Near Boston
text: DANVERS, Mass. — Christian Snyder, a high school freshman here, never liked math much, until he had Colleen Ritzer as a teacher.

headline: The Rancor Against Roma in Europe
Lights! Camera! Inaction! It’s Performance Art
text: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter’s Scary Names and Facebook’s Machines
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Bargaining With the Censors to Get Published in China
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn Academy of Music Announces Winter/Spring 2014 Season
text: A new stage collaboration among Willem Dafoe, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Robert Wilson; a Matthew Barney film adaptation of a Norman Mailer novel; and a live presentation of Isabella Rossellini’s explorations into the sex lives of squirmy animals are among the works that will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the first half of 2014.

headline: Honor Killings in India
text: To the Editor:

headline: Assessing Chemical Risks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pinterest Raises $225 Million, as Valuation Jumps to $3.8 Billion
text: The tech world may be abuzz about Twitter, but a big new social network is showing that it’s no slouch.

headline: Better News in New Study That Assesses U.S. Students
text: Amid growing alarm over the slipping international competitiveness of American students, a report comparing math and science test scores of eighth graders in individual states to those in other countries has found that a majority outperformed the international average.

headline: Young Women, Drinking and Rape
text: With studies finding an association between binge drinking and rape on college campuses, is there anything wrong with telling women not to get blind drunk?

headline: In a Major Departure, Google Shows Banner Ads in Search Results
text: Google’s search engine was once characterized by its simplicity — both its search results and ads were blue links against a white background. No longer.

headline: Case Explores Rights of Fetus Versus Mother
text: JACKSON, Wis. — Alicia Beltran cried with fear and disbelief when county sheriffs surrounded her home on July 18 and took her in handcuffs to a holding cell.

headline: Twitter, Women and Power
text: Twitter is on schedule to go public as a company next month, a sparkling symbol of innovation, technology — and stale, old thinking reflected in a board of seven white men.

headline: Ad-Sponsored Editorial Content Draws Regulator’s Notice
text: THE practice of native advertising, or the use of editorial content for promotional or marketing purposes, is beginning to capture the attention of advertising regulators who are concerned that some content could be considered deceptive to consumers.

headline: A More Nuanced de Blasio Emerges
text: Bill de Blasio’s runaway success in the polls as a candidate for mayor of New York City was built on crystal-clear convictions, uncompromising stands and black-and-white promises unburdened by the messiness of governing.

headline: Some Iranians Seek to Renew an Old Chant
text: TEHRAN — Born during the hostage crisis days after the 1979 Islamic Revolution, the chant “Death to America” has enjoyed a long run on the Iranian stage. But it has been getting a little threadbare in recent times, and has even come under threat, with no less a person than the newly elected president, Hassan Rouhani, suggesting that the country no longer needed slogans.

headline: Signs of Life in Euro Zone Could Point to Recovery
text: FRANKFURT — All the usual caveats still apply, but there is consistent evidence that the worst may be over for Europe’s economy.

headline: Boy, 13, Carrying Toy Guns Is Shot Dead by Deputies
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Sheriff’s deputies shot and killed a 13-year-old boy who was carrying a replica assault rifle they mistook for the real thing. The shooting occurred Tuesday afternoon in Santa Rosa, Calif., about 60 miles north of here, the police said.

headline: Extravagant Wedding Raises Awkward Questions for a Beijing Official
text: If you thought marrying in Manhattan was expensive, try Beijing. A village official in the city’s outskirts recently spent more than 1.6 million renminbi, about $260,000, on his son’s wedding, local media reported. But such extravagance by a government employee who is not highly paid has drawn suspicion: Where did he get the money?

headline: Heated Start in the Trial on Detroit’s Fiscal Future
text: DETROIT — The trial over Detroit’s eligibility for bankruptcy started Wednesday with starkly different interpretations of the events leading up to the city’s historic Chapter 9 filing in July.

headline: Year After Hurricane Sandy, Victims Contest Christie’s Status as a Savior
text: Hurricane Sandy turned Chris Christie into something akin to America’s governor, as the nation watched him express his state’s pain on the devastated shoreline the morning after the storm, then triumphantly cut the ribbons on reopened boardwalks on Memorial Day. “We’re stronger than the storm,” he proclaimed in television commercials that ran in other states all summer.

headline: LinkedIn Gets the Message: More Mobile, Please
text: LinkedIn is finally embarking on its mobile makeover.

headline: Eye-Catching Wingtips, but They Aren’t for Show
text: United Airlines is testing the latest innovation in airplane design that may prompt passengers to do a double take. Called a split scimitar, it’s reminiscent of a medieval sword and is a variation on those doodads, known as winglets, that extend up from the tips of wings.

headline: Veteran Reliever Knows About Facing Heat
text: BOSTON — Imagine the feeling of standing in the batter’s box in the World Series and staring down Randy Johnson. Only one player on the St. Louis Cardinals or the Boston Red Sox experienced this form of bone-chilling autumn pressure.

headline: Republicans, Sensing Weakness in Health Law Rollout, Switch Tactics
text: WASHINGTON — Emboldened by the intense public criticism surrounding the rollout of the online insurance exchange, Republicans in Congress are refocusing their efforts from denying funds for the health care law to investigating it.

headline: Boehner on Shutdown’s Fallout
text: Speaker John Boehner admits that Republicans failed, but that there are still problems to solve and that it is time for Washington to deal with them.

headline: Skakel Gets New Trial in ’75 Killing of Teenager in Connecticut
