text: A Connecticut judge on Wednesday ordered a new trial for Michael C. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy who was convicted in 2002 of bludgeoning a neighbor with a golf club in 1975, saying his original lawyer had not represented him effectively.

headline: Contractors Assign Blame, but Admit No Faults of Their Own, in Health Site
text: WASHINGTON — Contractors that built President Obama’s health insurance marketplace point fingers at one another and at the government, but each insists that it is not responsible for the problems that infuriated millions of Americans trying to buy insurance on the Web site, according to testimony prepared for a Congressional hearing on Thursday.

headline: Amid Rising Discord Over Indian Images, F.S.U. Has Harmony
text: Before every kickoff at Doak Campbell Stadium in Tallahassee, Fla., a Florida State student in facial war paint and an American Indian costume steers a spotted Appaloosa to midfield. As the horse rises on its hind legs, the rider, who is not an Indian, thrusts a flaming spear into the turf to the crazed accompaniment of the crowd’s droning chant and an arm gesture called the tomahawk chop.

headline: The Judge’s Decision on Skakel
text: The judge’s decision setting aside the murder conviction of Michael C. Skakel amounted to an attack on the way the lawyer who represented Mr. Skakel before he was convicted had handled his defense.

headline: Cardinals Are Sending Their Hot Rookie Pitcher to the Mound for Game 2
text: The St. Louis Cardinals will send the rookie sensation Michael Wacha to the mound for Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday, hoping he can continue his postseason success.

headline: No Husband, No Friends
text: Thanks to Noah, the world is made up of people in twosomes. I never thought much about the ark until my husband died one bright, sunny November morning almost one year ago.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 8 Matchup Breakdown
text: Injuries have been wreaking havoc on football rosters (both real and fake) in 2013. Week 7 wiped several more big names off the football map, including Doug Martin, Reggie Wayne, Jermichael Finley and Jay Cutler. But as always, one player’s injury is another’s opportunity.

headline: Left to Languish, Costly Fire Trucks Present a Reminder of Thai Dysfunction
text: SAI NOI, Thailand — In a weed-covered parking lot on the outskirts of Bangkok, tens of millions of dollars of never-used firefighting equipment sits decaying, punished by bouts of searing heat, monsoon rains and a flood that swamped the area two years ago.

headline: Twitter Illiterate? Mastering the @BC’s
text: Using Twitter sounds so simple. Type out no more than 140 characters — the maximum allowed in a single tweet — and hit send. That’s all, right?

headline: Ted Cruz Takes On the F.C.C.
text: Senator Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican who helped engineer the recent government shutdown, has a new target for his obstructionism: the Federal Communications Commission. Last week, Mr. Cruz blocked the Senate from considering the nomination of Tom Wheeler to lead the commission — a candidate who leaders from both parties had agreed would be put up for a vote without delay.

headline: The Deaths of Innocents
text: One of the arguments for America’s heavy reliance on drone strikes against suspected extremists has been surgical precision. The weapons are so finely calibrated and precisely targeted, officials argue, that only militants are killed, and that collateral damage to innocent civilians is rare. These claims were always hard to accept, especially given the government’s refusal to provide corroborating data. Now two human rights groups, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, have marshaled impressive new evidence challenging them.

headline: For District Attorney in Brooklyn
text: After losing the Democratic primary for Brooklyn district attorney by a wide margin and saying he was ending his bid for a seventh four-year term, Charles Hynes reversed himself. He is now waging an active campaign in the general election on the Republican Party line against the man who defeated him for the Democratic nomination, Kenneth Thompson.

headline: Waiting for What Comes Next
text: The sky to the west is kettle-gray. The last leaves on the sugar maple in front of the house are flickering but hanging tight for now. Most of the hickory nuts have fallen, but sometimes I still hear one clatter onto the chicken-house roof. Another couple of months and Orion will be visible when the dogs and I go out for the last walk at night.

headline: Outspoken Weir Will Be Quiet on Russian Law
text: It was just after 8 on Wednesday morning, and Johnny Weir looked — by his own assessment — “gorgeous.”

headline: Confession in ‘Baby Hope’ Killing Was Taped, but the Interrogation Was Not
text: It was a long interrogation. But after 22 years, the cold-case detectives could afford to be patient.

headline: Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Oct. 23, 2013
Nicks Struggles as Free Agency Looms
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — This was going to be the year when Hakeem Nicks ran under dozens of Eli Manning passes, snatched them out of the air with his sure hands and ran all the way to the bank.

headline: Corrections: October 24, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Wonder May Fade, but Lessons Linger
text: It’s just a simple ditty, with a jaunty lilt. Its rudimentary lyrics have something to do with a boat and rope, and you can imagine its being sung mindlessly by sailors or perhaps by a little boy, as it is here. But listen to it again, and then again, and it starts to sound melancholy, and maybe even sinister. By the last time you hear it, it has acquired a voice of chilling, mortal finality.

headline: Unwelcome Reversal
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this is a spiffy Thursday puzzle. It took a while for the theme to unfold, but that’s the way I like it. No sense giving up all of one’s secrets at once, right? Preserve a little mystery, that’s the way to keep a relationship between constructor and solver fresh.

headline: A Homely Relic on Wheels Awakens Nostalgia in Iran
text: TEHRAN — On a recent Friday afternoon, in the upscale Shahrak-e Gharb neighborhood in West Tehran, Porsches, Toyota Land Cruisers and Mercedes-Benz two-seaters drove up and down the street, music blaring from high-powered speakers that were quickly turned down for passing police cars.

headline: JPMorgan Faces Possible Penalty in Madoff Case
text: Federal authorities are preparing to take action in a criminal investigation of JPMorgan Chase, suspecting that the bank turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: Every Game Brings an Extra-Large Challenge for Jets’ Allen
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It had been a long and hectic week for Antonio Allen, a stretch encompassing the birth of his son, Blake, on Oct. 15; his preparation for defending Rob Gronkowski, the Patriots’ behemoth tight end; and his 23-yard interception return for a touchdown, which started the Jets’ comeback in their 30-27 overtime victory. And so on Sunday evening, when he left MetLife Stadium, Allen celebrated the best game of his brief N.F.L. career by doing ... absolutely nothing.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 24, 2013
text: “I didn’t know unborn children had lawyers. I said, ‘Where’s my lawyer?’”

headline: J&R Alters the Blocklong Layout It’s Known For
text: A stroll south of City Hall toward Park Row can inspire a wish list — guitars, computers, cameras, stereos, CDs, even vinyl records — in anticipation of the emporium, stretching from Beekman Street to Ann Street, that had long been J&R Music and Computer World.

headline: 7-Year Low Reported in Piracy Off Somalia
text: Piracy off the coast of Somalia, once regarded the most dangerous sea passage, has dropped to the lowest level in seven years, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations said in a report submitted Wednesday to the Security Council.

headline:
Health Care
Law Fails to
Lower Prices
for Rural Areas
text: As technical failures bedevil the rollout of President Obama’s health care law, evidence is emerging that one of the program’s loftiest goals — to encourage competition among insurers in an effort to keep costs low — is falling short for many rural Americans.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Panthers (3-3) at Buccaneers (0-6)
text: 8:25 p.m. Eastern

headline: Tunisian Protests, by Islamist and Secular Groups, Delay Talks on Constitution
text: CAIRO — Deadly violence and street protests in Tunisia on Wednesday postponed talks intended to end a political standoff that had thwarted completion of a new constitution in the birthplace of, and a relative bright spot in, the Arab Spring revolts.

headline: Sued Over Pay, Condé Nast Ends Internship Program
text: For Lauren Indvik, a business editor and soon-to-be co-editor in chief at Fashionista, the 2008 internship at Vogue was worth every sacrifice.

headline: From Small Fire, a Great Fried-Knish Famine
text: Before halal chicken and rice, or egg-and-cheese sandwiches, the street carts of New York sold knishes — many of them of the square, fried variety, a hefty, gut-warming pillow of fried dough filled with seasoned mashed potato.

headline: Pierce, Ex-Celtic and Current Net, Straddling Two Cities
text: BOSTON — Paul Pierce kept a low profile here Wednesday, but the two pictures he posted to his Instagram account during the day told a story.

headline: Pakistani Premier Meets Obama to Mend Ties
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama welcomed Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan to the White House on Wednesday, seeking to bolster his new civilian government and mend perennially frayed ties between the countries.

headline: Wise Dan’s Success Also Boosts Trainer
text: In horse racing, there is a belief that a horse’s talent cannot be determined by pedigree or auction price; it is the racetrack that is the judge of good horses, and they can come from anywhere. The reigning horse of the year, Wise Dan, is one of those horses.

headline: Drownings Put Migration at Fore of European Meeting
text: BRUSSELS — In the aftermath of the drowning deaths of more than 360 migrants in a packed boat off an Italian island this month, the question of how to share the burden of the refugees and asylum seekers crossing the Mediterranean Sea is dividing the European Union ahead of a meeting of national leaders starting Thursday.

headline: Sebelius Finds a Friendly Crowd in Boston
text: BOSTON — For Kathleen Sebelius, the Obama administration official who has become the focus of bipartisan anger over the bungled rollout of the online health insurance exchanges, a night out in Boston appeared to be a much-needed respite from scrutiny and criticism.

headline: White House to Tweak Tax-Penalty Deadline
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that people who obtained health insurance by March 31 would not face any tax penalties for being uninsured in the first three months of 2014.

headline: Allan Stanley, 87, Dies; Helped Maple Leafs Win 4 N.H.L. Titles
text: Allan Stanley, a Hall of Fame defenseman who helped the Toronto Maple Leafs win four Stanley Cups in the 1960s, died on Oct. 18 in Bobcaygeon, Ontario. He was 87.

headline: China Data Shows Uptick in Output at Factories
text: HONG KONG — An important gauge of manufacturing activity in China showed a larger-than-expected uptick for October, suggesting that the economy may have picked up some steam.

headline: The Demise of the Fashion Eccentric
text: The meaning of a true eccentric isn’t in the costume — it’s in the soul.

headline: A Very Expensive Tea Party
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Word of the Day | nomenclature
text: nomenclature •\ˈno-mən-ˌkla-chər also no-ˈmen-klə-ˌchu̇r\• noun

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Indicted in Corruption Case
text: Italy’s former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, was indicted on Wednesday in a corruption case linked to the collapse of Romano Prodi’s government in 2008, one of his lawyers said. Naples prosecutors accused Mr. Berlusconi of paying a senator 3 million euros to leave Mr. Prodi’s coalition. Mr. Berlusconi is already facing probable expulsion from Parliament and possible house arrest for a tax fraud conviction, and he is appealing a seven-year prison sentence on a conviction of paying for sex with a minor. He has denied wrongdoing in all the cases.

headline: Fall for St. Louis; Classic for Boston
text: BOSTON — Getting to this, baseball’s biggest stage, had never been the Boston Red Sox’ strong suit. Generations passed without World Series appearances. Seasons were too often marred by misfortune, blunders, collapses; promise was unfulfilled, and hopes were annually dashed.

headline: Time Warner Cable Reaches Agreement to Distribute Al Jazeera America
text: Time Warner Cable, one of the country’s biggest cable operators, has agreed to carry Al Jazeera America, giving the Qatar-owned broadcaster exposure to millions more households as it seeks to build an audience in the United States.

headline: Mali: Suicide Bombing Kills 2 U.N. Peacekeepers
text: A suicide bombing believed to have been carried out by Islamists linked to Al Qaeda killed two United Nations peacekeeping soldiers from Chad on Wednesday at a checkpoint in Mali, officials reported. The United Nations peacekeeping force was established in April to assume security operations from France.

headline: An Even Tougher Start for the Cardinals Than in 2004
text: BOSTON — Mike Matheny was behind the plate at Fenway Park in the bottom of the first inning of the opening game of the 2004 World Series. By the time he returned to the St. Louis Cardinals’ dugout, Boston had a 4-0 lead.

headline: Dominicans of Haitian Descent Cast Into Legal Limbo by Court
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — For generations, people of Haitian descent have been an inextricable part of life here, often looked at with suspicion and dismay, but largely relied on all the same to clean rooms, build things cheaply and provide the backbreaking labor needed on the country’s vast sugar plantations.

headline: Syria: Government Releases Some Female Detainees
text: Antigovernment activists said Wednesday that the Syrian government had released at least 15 female detainees in what appeared to be part of an ambitious regional prisoner swap. Last week that deal, brokered by several countries, freed Lebanese captives held by Syrian rebels and two Turkish pilots held in Lebanon. Syrian rebels had reportedly also demanded the release of the female prisoners.

headline: Stripped of Statehood
text: The Dominican Republic’s top court has declared that the children of undocumented Haitian migrants are no longer entitled to citizenship.

headline: Week 8 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
text: The standard N.F.L. matchup is hard to predict. In terms of probabilities for the favorite and underdog, a game is typically about a 62-38 percentage affair. When the underdog wins almost 4 out of 10 games, it can make for an exciting Sunday afternoon. But this Sunday probably won’t be one of them.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 10:30 P.M. (MSG) THE GARDEN TRANSFORMED: SPECIAL EDITION This program chronicles the three-year, $1 billion renovation of Madison Square Garden, with glimpses of the Chase Square entranceway, Chase Bridges, the Defining Moments display of the arena’s history and the Gardenvision scoreboard, above. It also features excerpts from a Thursday news conference; a question-and-answer session with Willis Reed, the former Knicks player and coach, and Mark Messier, the former Rangers player; and glimpses of 50 Cent, Mike D of the Beastie Boys, Chazz Palminteri, Al Roker, Tony Sirico and Robert Klein on the red carpet. At 7, the Rangers will meet the Flyers at the Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia.

headline: News Quiz | October 24, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: The Last Jews of Kolkata
text: KOLKATA — On bustling Brabourne Road in central Kolkata, vendors line sidewalks packed with pedestrians, while cars, motorbikes and rickshaw pullers fill the street. Amid the urban din, the Magen David Synagogue sits silent and empty. A Muslim guard stands watch outside. With an estimated 25 Jews remaining in this city of 14 million people, the synagogue is rarely used.

headline: Credit Suisse to Streamline and Shrink
text: Updated, 12:15 p.m. |Credit Suisse said on Thursday that it planned to shrink its investment bank and other businesses as it grappled with stricter regulatory requirements and a challenging fixed-income market.

headline: Challenging the Chinese Government to Disclose Its Aid to North Korea
text: Nearly deaf and close to blind, a veteran Beijing protester who was sentenced to re-education through labor in her late 70s, Wang Xiuying, now in her 80s, seems an unlikely threat to China’s secretive bond with North Korea. But she wants to know how much aid the Chinese government gives its neighbor, and she went to court to demand an answer.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 24, 2013
text: Use context clues and your knowledge of word roots to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

headline: French Contemporary Art Fair Opens In Paris
text: PARIS — Mona Lisa’s smile may still draw throngs of tourists to Paris, but the city’s contemporary art scene also has its own allure. This week collectors and art fans are invading Paris fresh from London’s Frieze for  the International Contemporary Art Fair, also known here by its French acronym, FIAC.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | StoryCorps Turns 10
text: After Sarah Littman recorded an interview with her son, Josh, who has Asperger syndrome, and the interview was broadcast on National Public Radio, she received hundreds of letters of support. She put all the letters in a notebook, and whenever Josh had a rough day, they would read the letters together. PBS turned the interview into the animated short, above. Read the related article to learn more.

headline: McKesson in $8.3 Billion Deal With German Drug Wholesaler
text: LONDON – The San Francisco health care services firm McKesson Corporation said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire a controlling stake in Celesio of Germany and will start a tender offer for its remaining shares in a deal valued at $8.3 billion.

headline: Preview: “Running From Crazy”
text: In this clip from the coming documentary, Margaux and Mariel Hemingway revisit the home where their grandfather, Ernest, committed suicide.

headline: Picturing the Gowanus Above the Muck
text: One day last October, Yunghi Kim went to the edge of a dock along the notoriously polluted Gowanus Canal. She took off her sneakers, rolled up her pants legs and stepped into the toxic muck. As a high tide lapped over her ankles, Ms. Kim dunked a camera wrapped in clear plastic bags beneath the surface.

headline: The Importance of Not Being Ernest
text: Mariel Hemingway gets up early, perhaps as an unconscious homage to her famous grandfather, to watch the sun rise. Each morning, while still in bed, she and her live-in boyfriend, an erstwhile stuntman and actor named Bobby Williams, begin a series of predawn exercises that consist of breathing, stretching, contemplating the things they’re grateful for and visualizing the day ahead. Hemingway then makes the bed and a pot of jasmine green tea. She fills the hummingbird feeders with organic sugar water, feeds organic soy-free meal to the brood of egg-laying hens that live in her backyard and heads back to the kitchen to prepare a smoothie.

headline: Has Baseball Lost Its Cool?
text: The Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals are battling it out in the World Series this week and next, yet does America care as much as it used to? According to a recent Op-Ed article by Jonathan Mahler, the game that we affectionately call our national pastime seems to have lost its cultural relevance — at least compared to football and basketball.

headline:
U.S. Envoy Is
Summoned by
Germany Over
Spying Report
text: BERLIN — Leaders and citizens in Germany, one of America’s closest allies, simmered with barely contained fury on Thursday over reports that American intelligence had tapped into Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone, the latest diplomatic fallout from the documents harvested by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Increase in Activity Reported at North Korean Nuclear Test Site
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has increased activity at its main underground nuclear test site, digging new tunnel entrances in what could be preparations for another nuclear test, a Washington-based research institute reported Thursday.

headline: With Winter Ahead, Can China’s Smog Get Anything But Worse?
text: Following the “airpocalypse” in the city of Harbin this week, a question now hovers in the minds of many residents across northern China. It was summed up in a headline that ran on Thursday with a commentary in People’s Daily, the Communist Party mouthpiece: “In this season of central heating, will PM 2.5 drop?”

headline: New York Today: Send in the Ghouls
text: Updated 12:09 p.m. | Jeanne Fleming is planning a very, very big party.

headline: A Chinese Newspaper Restates its Call for a Reporter’s Release
text: Updated, 7:15 a.m. EST | A Chinese newspaper has not backed down from its bold public request that a reporter detained in a defamation investigation be released. On Thursday, one day after the Guangzhou-based New Express ran a front-page story under the huge headline, “Please Release Him,” the paper followed up with another front-page call: “Again, Please Release Him.”

headline: Small, Steady Growth for Europe’s Economy
text: PARIS — Europe’s fragile recovery remains alive, according to the results of a closely watched corporate survey released on Thursday.

headline: Santander Profit Rises as It Sets Aside Less to Cover Bad Loans
text: LONDON – The Spanish lender Banco Santander reported on Thursday a surge in profits to 1.1 billion euros in the third quarter as it continued to benefit from declines in charges for bad loans.

headline: Daily Report: London Works to Raise Profile as European Tech Hub
text: King.com, the maker of the popular Candy Crush game franchise, is trying to become the first London tech start-up to hit gold on the public market. And if the company is successful, it could help cement the city’s reputation as one of Europe’s top start-up communities, Mark Scott reports.

headline: Ford Maintains Earnings Streak and Raises Profit Forecast for the Year
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Ford Motor said on Thursday that its net income fell 22 percent in the third quarter, to $1.27 billion, as the company took charges related to revamping its European operations and its United States pension obligations.

headline: North Korea to Release 6 South Korean Detainees
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a surprise move that could help ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula, North Korea said Thursday that it would release six South Koreans it has been holding in detention, South Korean officials said.

headline: Ireland Vows to Review Cases of Roma Children Removed From Their Families
text: DUBLIN — In a case that has drawn scrutiny here, the Irish authorities on Thursday promised to review the circumstances under which two blond, blue-eyed Roma children were removed from their families in different parts of the country this week — only to be returned when DNA testing confirmed their parentage.

headline: The Handyüberwachung Disaster
text: BERLIN — Germany, of course, has already concocted a compound word for it: Handyüberwachung. That would be spying on cellphone calls.

headline: Christening the Earliest Members of Our Genus
text: Around 1.8 million years ago, human evolution passed a milestone. Our ancestors before then were little more than bipedal apes. Those so-called hominids had chimpanzee-size bodies and brains, and they still had adaptations in their limbs for climbing trees. But the fossils of hominids from 1.8 to 1.5 million years ago are different. They had bigger brains, flatter faces and upright bodies better suited to walking.

headline: Jerusalem, Saved
text: JERUSALEM — The slang word “combina” entered the Hebrew language from Ladino, the tongue of Jews of Spanish origin. A combina is a clever dirty deal — a word at times used in admiration, at times used in disdain. When it was announced Wednesday morning that the mayor of Jerusalem, Nir Barkat, was re-elected to a second five-year term by a small majority, the response of Israelis was nearly unanimous: his victory came from a combina that failed.

headline: Anthony Caro, British Sculptor, Dies at 89
text: LONDON — The British sculptor Anthony Caro, widely known for his monumental works using industrial metal, died on Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 89.

headline: Ericsson Sales Slip, and So Does Its Stock
text: Shares of Ericsson, the maker of mobile telecommunications equipment, fell on Thursday after the company reported a decline in third-quarter sales. The Swedish company is grappling with a slowdown in investment by large cellphone carriers.

headline: Madoff Case Looms Over JPMorgan
text: Federal authorities, suspecting that JPMorgan Chase turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme, are preparing to take action in a criminal investigation of the bank, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. Coming on the heels of a tentative $13 billion settlement over JPMorgan’s mortgage practices, the case poses another major threat to the bank’s reputation.

headline: Subway Turnstile Haiku
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Permira to Buy Maker of Dr. Martens
text: LONDON – Adding to its stable of consumer brands, the private equity firm Permira agreed on Thursday to acquire the British firm that owns the Dr. Martens footwear and clothing brand in a deal valued at £300 million, or $485.3 million.

headline: At a Steakhouse Bar, Less Volume Can’t Be Ordered
text: The bar behind the steak side of Harry’s Cafe and Steak is a nice little lounge with some serious music problems. On one recent night, the playlist included, at pulverizing volume, Lady Gaga’s “Applause,” the inescapable “Blurred Lines” by Robin Thicke (at this point, no, we don’t want it), Nicki Minaj’s “Starships,” and somewhere in there what sure sounded like a commercial for a Nissan “Drive and Save” sale.

headline: ‘White Girls,’ The Controversy-Courting New Volume From Hilton Als
text: What do Truman Capote and Michael Jackson have in common? They’re “White Girls,” according to Hilton Als, the New Yorker writer whose incendiary new book — his first major work since “The Women” in 1996 — brings up race and gender identity in modern America while blurring the lines between memoir, cultural critique and fiction. “It’s a pejorative term, similar to the use of ‘black girl’ to describe a model of color in the fashion world,” Als says. “The white girls in this book are marginalized by the status quo because of their race and gender,” or because they are trying to “pass” as a member of the world responsible for their disenfranchisement. Here, passages excerpted from “White Girls” (out Nov. 12 from McSweeney’s; $24), which Als describes as a kind of “philosophical whodunit.”

headline: Lazard Earnings Rise 75% on Deals and Cost-Cutting
text: An improving market for deals and cost-cutting bolstered Lazard’s third-quarter earnings, as the investment bank reported on Thursday a 75 percent increase in profit from the period a year earlier.

headline: Football App, a German Start-Up, Gets U.S. Investment
text: BERLIN – Lucas von Cranach has come a long way since starting his professional career at a German machinery production company in the mid-2000s.

headline: A Quick Trip From Playwright to Player
text: It was dinner break at the Public Theater for the cast and crew of the new musical “Fun Home.” They had spent the late afternoon fine-tuning small bits — some new underscoring here, a less-than-crystal-clear snippet of French there. And with just three hours before that night’s preview performance, the time had come to relax.

headline: It’s Getting Warm in the Tap Studio
text: Every so often, you hear someone bemoan the state of the American theater, perhaps even proclaiming that it is dying or dead. But thankfully there are companies out there like Richard Maxwell’s New York City Players, that understand the need to generate and support new work and thus keep the naysayers at bay. Like Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, which recently produced a festival devoted to the work of the playwright Lucy Thurber, the New York City Players are also nurturers. The company’s American Playwrights Division presents full productions of works by emerging writers who also direct.

headline: After a Concussion, Returning to School
text: The usual protocol here at the Parent-Teacher Conference is that you ask me questions about parenting and education, and I answer in 800 words or fewer. Today, however, I am asking the question, and in order to follow my own advice, will answer in fewer than 800 words.

headline: Michelle Obama to Support Women Running for Office
text: Michelle Obama, a first lady who is often resists the stump, may be spotted next year helping women running for office. Next month in New York, Mrs. Obama will be a guest speaker at a lunch at the Democratic Women’s Senate Network policy conference in New York.

headline: Icahn Amps Up Pressure on Apple, but His Stake Limits His Leverage
text: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | When Carl C. Icahn starts making noises about a company, executives usually listen. But his campaign for Apple to return more money to shareholders might be falling on deaf ears.

headline: The Comics That Refuse to Die
text: The popularity of EC Comics’s horror and humor still flourishes.

headline: Neil Blumenthal of Warby Parker on a Culture of Communication
text: This interview with Neil Blumenthal, co-chief executive of Warby Parker, the online seller of eyeglasses, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: They’re ... They’re Still Alive!
text: This is a chilling and improbable tale of the living dead: Even though they were savaged by the politeness police and left lifeless some 60 years ago, EC comic books, which spawned notorious titles like Tales From the Crypt, Shock SuspenStories and Mad, have become the comics that refused to die.

headline: Indignation in Europe Over Claims That U.S. Spied on Merkel’s Phone
text: The revelation that the United States may have monitored the mobile phone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was greeted in Europe with a mix of righteous indignation and questions as to which leader’s cellphone could be next.

headline: 36 Hours in Milwaukee
text: Milwaukee is a city that evolves slowly. Its roots as a blue-collar town — as the German Athens, as Brew City — are still evident in the names of local landmarks (Pabst Theater, Pfister Hotel, Miller Park, where the Milwaukee Brewers play); the neatly demarcated enclaves that still retain strong traces of their ethnic origins; the countless cozy neighborhood taps; and the locals’ love of sausage, cheese and beer, not to mention the array of festivals (German Fest, Irish Fest, Polish Fest) that overtake the lakefront every summer. Yet this city — Wisconsin’s largest, population 600,000 — is hardly a backward-looking place. Following a few decades of diminishing population, numbers have risen slightly in the years since the 2010 census, much of the increase due to young people moving into a few revived downtown neighborhoods like Walker’s Point and the southerly, suddenly hip Bay View, with its bars and galleries. The result is a city that possesses a renewed vitality while still holding on to an Old World character.

headline: India’s Battle Against Nutrition Data Deficiency
text: NEW DELHI- Paharganj is an area populated with decrepit, low-budget hotels, about two miles from the Indian Parliament in central Delhi. Thousands of poor Indians live in a labyrinth of claustrophobic, dirty lanes that veer away from the hotel-lined main street. Kusum Kumar, 37, a day care worker for the Integrated Child Development Scheme, the Indian government’s social welfare program for children under 6, works out of a one-room tenement in an inner lane.

headline: A Journeyman Catcher Has Reasons to Shout
text: BOSTON — David Ross came bounding into the Boston Red Sox clubhouse late Wednesday night, fresh off the field, his jersey untucked, shouting as loud as he could. He could have passed for a rookie, if only the gray-streaked beard had not given him away. He kept shouting as he went to his locker, giving high-fives and hugs along the way.

headline: Former Detainee’s Right to Speedy Trial Wasn’t Violated, Appeals Panel Rules
text: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan ruled on Thursday that the government’s long detention of a valuable terrorist, first at a secret site run by the Central Intelligence Agency and then at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, did not deprive the suspect of his right to a speedy trial.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ and the Wall Street ‘Witch Hunt’
text: “It’s a shakedown, witch hunt, scalping jihad,” Jon Stewart of ‘The Daily Show’ said, mocking financial television’s coverage of a $13 billion settlement over JPMorgan Chase‘s mortgage practices.

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave’ Leads the Gotham Nominations
text: The movie awards season begins in earnest with the Gotham Independent Film Awards, which announced its nominees on Thursday.

headline: The Gun Report: October 24, 2013
text: Because online gun classifieds are under increasing scrutiny and Craiglist has a policy against selling guns, people are now unloading their firearms on the photo-sharing site Instagram. Yes, Instagram.

headline: Anthony Caro, Who Followed Sculpture on a ‘Path to Abstraction,’ Dies at 89
text: Sir Anthony Caro, a pre-eminent artist of the postwar era who created a new language for abstract sculpture in the 1960s with brightly colored, horizontal assemblages of welded steel that seemed choreographed as much as constructed, died on Wednesday in London. He was 89.

headline: 10 Questions for Matt Bevin
text: Mr. Bevin, a 46-year-old investment executive, spoke with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC about his campaign to oust Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Monsters’
text: With Halloween coming, this Poetry Pairing features “Monsters” by Dorothea Lasky and the 2008 This Land column “In the Wilds of New Jersey, a Legend Inspires a Hunt” by Dan Barry.

headline: 10 Questions for Matt Bevin, Mitch McConnell’s Tea Party Challenger
text: Before Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky can face off against Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Democrat and Kentucky’s secretary of state, he must turn back a primary challenge from Matt Bevin, a 46-year-old investment executive who has Tea Party support.

headline: Appellate Ruling in New York Progress and Protection PAC v. Walsh, et al.
text: Read the full decision allowing a group supporting Joseph J. Lhota to accept unlimited contributions.

headline: New Year’s Baby? You May Pay More
text: Traditionally, much hoopla surrounds the birth of the first baby of the New Year. But it turns out that can be an expensive bit of good luck.

headline: Contractors Describe Limited Testing of Insurance Web Site
text: WASHINGTON — Federal officials did not fully test the online health insurance marketplace until two weeks before it opened to the public on Oct. 1, contractors told Congress on Thursday.

headline: MTV Will Explore Youth and Revolution in ‘Rebel Music’
text: MTV is returning to its roots, sort of, with a new series that promises to highlight social change via slamming beats. “Rebel Music,” which begins Nov. 18 on mtvU, is a documentary-style look at six hotspots around the world – including Egypt, Afghanistan, Mali and Mexico – whose conflicts and culture are examined through the eyes of local artists and activists. The episode in Egypt was shot during the Arab Spring and focuses on the use of protest songs and social media; in Afghanistan, producers follow a young female rapper and a heavy metal band.

headline: Today in Small Business: Crowdfunding Rules Released
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: British Tech Start-Ups Take a Financial Bent
text: LONDON – A vibrant tech community is in full swing here in the British capital, with social gaming apps and e-fashion start-ups vying to attract venture capital investment.

headline: For a While, Her Life Is Yours
text: “Blue Is the Warmest Color” is a feverish, generous, exhausting love story, the chronicle of a young woman’s passage from curiosity to heartbreak by way of a wrenching and blissful attachment to another, slightly older woman. Although there is plenty of weeping and sighing, the methods of the director, Abdellatif Kechiche, are less melodramatic than meteorological. He studies the radar and scans the horizon in search of emotional weather patterns and then rushes out into the gale, dragging the audience through fierce winds and soul-battering squalls.

headline: YouTube Said to Introduce Paid Service for Music
text: The competitive world of digital music is about to become even more crowded with the arrival of one of the most formidable forces on the Internet: YouTube.

headline: 8 States Teaming Up to Support Electric Cars
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to spur lackluster sales of electric cars, California, New York and six other states said on Thursday that they would work jointly to adopt a range of measures, including encouraging more charging stations and changing building codes, to make it easier to own an electric car.

headline: K.K.R. Profit Buoyed by Rising Markets

headline: From Orbitz, a New Loyalty Program

headline: Poetry Profiles: Copper Canyon Press
text: Small presses are the lifeblood of poetry. Whether tucked behind the nurturing skirts of a university press, or weathering (mostly) harsh cultural indifference on their own, small presses are often the first to ferret out new and vital voices, to exhume lost masterpieces or to translate essential work from other languages.

headline: With Sales Falling, an Owner Struggles With Pricing Strategies
text: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about their biggest concerns. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, started the discussion — and had the group’s rapt attention for most of the meeting. She said last year, when annual sales were about $8.5 million, was the company’s best since she and her sister took over in 2008. But this year, sales have been extremely disappointing.

headline: Co-Sleeping, Reluctantly, With a (Wiggly) 3-Year-Old
text: At 10:45 on a recent evening, my wife and I are just falling asleep when our 3-year-old son, Jacob, cries out. Seconds later, we hear the pitter-patter of his feet in the hallway. My wife gets out of bed, picks him up and places him, half-asleep, between us.

headline: All-Women ‘I Remember Mama’ to Highlight Transport Group Theater Season

headline: Lester’s Game 1 Gem Comes Under Scrutiny

headline: The Night a ‘Halloween Special’ Went Terribly Wrong
text: In 1967, Paul and Linda Webber were brutally murdered by their son, Donald, in their suburban home in a crime that shocked the small town of River Hill. Twenty years later, WNUF, a local television station, enlisted a pair of occult researchers to participate in a live special from that home in hopes of speaking to whatever evil spirits may have lingered there.

headline: J. J. Abrams: By the Book
text: The Hollywood writer, director and producer, and creator of the novel “S.” is inspired by Chris Ware’s work. “His graphic novels have the emotional wallop of a Philip Roth or Thomas Pynchon.”

headline: The Union’s Most Undervalued General
text: Despite his brilliant victory at Vicksburg in July, some lingering doubts remained about Gen. Ulysses S. Grant when he took command of the besieged Union forces at Chattanooga, Tenn., on Oct. 23, 1863. Earlier, when his army was taken by surprise at Shiloh, he had amplified the misgivings of critics by denying the attack was unexpected and falsely claiming he was outnumbered two-to-one. More recently, a limp resulting from a horseback-riding accident during post-Vicksburg victory celebrations in occupied New Orleans fed persistent rumors of alcoholism.

headline: Cross-Country Run in 1930 Ford Cut Short by Engine Failure
text: Some of the most marvelous success stories began with embarrassing failures. Thomas Edison, Soichiro Honda, even Henry Ford – they all faced defeat, but went on to become great.

headline: Living With Cancer: Brains on Chemo

headline: Highlights and Analysis: World Series Game 2 — Cardinals 4, Red Sox 2
text: BOSTON — It appeared the Red Sox had done it again. They had bested another top pitcher, and David Ortiz had saved the day. But it was Boston this time, in Game 2 of the World Series, and not the St. Louis Cardinals, that made a game-turning mental mistake. The Cardinals went on to win, 4-2, to even the series at 1-1.

headline: Pirates Abduct Two Americans on Oil Ship Off Nigerian Coast
text: Pirates attacked an American-flagged oil industry vessel off the Nigerian coast early Thursday and abducted the captain and the chief engineer, both United States citizens, the Nigerian Navy and a private security firm reported. The abductions appeared to be the first involving American hostages in that region in at least two years.

headline: Your Experiences in New York’s Work World
text: Updated, Dec. 2 | I write a weekly column for The Times’s Metro section called “The Working Life,” which focuses on work, the workplace and the evolving economy in New York City. My reporting will highlight your stories and experiences, and I want to hear about the biggest changes that have taken place in your working life over the last few years as the city has struggled its way out of a historic recession.

headline: For Heidi Cruz, Grapefruit Juice Was Key to Political Career
text: Heidi Nelson Cruz, the wife of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and a managing director at Goldman Sachs, has one piece of advice she often gives to the young graduates she mentors: Be the person willing to do whatever it takes to get the job done, no matter how small the task may seem.

headline: Activist Bet on Evercore Would Have Beaten One on Lazard

We were eating off paper plates, our hands in plastic gloves and our faces bathed in fluorescence, in a former bodega still anchored by a counter selling lottery tickets and Alka-Seltzer.

headline: Perspectives on Painting: Investigating Early Italian Renaissance Art

headline: Cats Are Works of Art (but You Knew That)
text: THE video reel opens with a big cat squeezing itself into a narrow-mouthed urn, a miniature comedy that ends with the cat’s tail poking sinuously out the top. Later, there is a poignant encounter between a hair dryer and a blind kitten, which flails its paws at the heat, wind and noise. Elsewhere, a black cat plays the villain, rudely swatting a pill bottle off a dresser, then turning to the camera to deliver a contemptuous yawn.

headline: Despite Everything: Francis Spufford Talks About ‘Unapologetic’
text: Francis Spufford’s books cover a wide variety of subjects, from polar exploration to his childhood reading to a blend of fiction and nonfiction about Soviet Russia in “Red Plenty,” which Dwight Garner named one of his 10 favorite books of 2012. In “Unapologetic,” Mr. Spufford adds to the diversity of his bibliography, this time mounting an impassioned argument for, as the subtitle puts it, “Why, Despite Everything, Christianity Can Still Make Surprising Emotional Sense.” In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Spufford discussed his path back to religion from atheism, the low moments in Christian history, why Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens are “not even wrong” and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Martin Klimas Show at Foley Gallery
text: The Miser has long suspected that he has a mild case of synesthesia. While strumming a guitar, he experiences different colors according to the key he happens to be playing in: C is yellow, E is blue, D is green, and so on.

headline: Tibetans Call China’s Policies at Tourist Spot Tacit but Stifling
text: XIAHE, China — Buddhist monks in flowing burgundy robes hurried along the dirt paths of the Labrang Monastery, trying their best to ignore the scrum of Chinese tourists following their every move, many with cameras fit for paparazzi.

headline: Vivian Schiller to Leave NBC News for Twitter
text: In a bid to reinforce Twitter’s mutually beneficial relationships with the news industry, the social networking giant on Thursday appointed Vivian Schiller to a newly created position, head of news and journalism partnerships.

headline: All-Out Hustle
text: Everyone loves the hustle and drama of a playoff game, and Wednesday night’s World Series opener between St. Louis and Boston provided new moments that fans will remember. The second inning, in particular, stood out for Carlos Beltran’s catch against the bullpen wall and the moment when Adam Wainwright and Yadier Molina let a pop-up drop between them.

headline: Accounting World, Still Resisting Sunlight
text: The accounting business has sometimes had an attitude of — how shall I put it? — contempt for those who would regulate it. The people who run the major firms know best, and regulators should yield to their superior judgment.

headline: Celebrating Dylan From Coast to Coast
text: The Best Fest, a production company that presents charity tribute concerts built around the music of great rock songwriters – most notably, Bob Dylan, Tom Petty, Neil Young and the Rolling Stones – said on Thursday that this year’s Dylan Fest would be bicoastal, with concerts in New York on Nov. 11 and 12, and San Francisco on Nov. 20.

headline: A Risotto of Late-Season Tomatoes
text: The last of the season’s tomatoes are not to be ignored. The best ones at this time of year are usually the meaty, late-ripening plum or Roma varieties. And their flavor is helped by slow-roasting. I folded them into a risotto to serve with our Chiantis. Though the risotto is fine with the darker, richer examples we tasted, it is especially felicitous alongside the more graceful, lighter ones.

headline: New York Philharmonic to Stream Video Performances Next Week
text: The New York Philharmonic is revisiting a few highlights of its recent history, and inviting its fans to tune in and relive those events as well, by way of a five-day “I ♥ New York Philharmonic Festival,” to be streamed on the classical music video Web site medici.tv.

headline: Greenspan: No Saving Grace
text: Sorry about radio silence — family stuff and textbook deadlines fell in on me. But I would like to get in something about Greenspan’s new book.

headline: Exploring Plan B
text: My wife’s family and close friends are planning a surprise party to celebrate her 70th birthday. The planners have asked me to arrange for her to be at a certain locale at a certain time, and they have insisted on my secrecy. My wife told me that she hopes nothing is being planned for the occasion. She would like to celebrate her birthday with a quiet dinner for two at a fine restaurant. I am convinced that she is not being coy and would detest this surprise party. Should I blow the conspirators’ cover?

headline: R.L. Stine to Revive ‘Fear Street’ Series
text: R.L. Stine, whose “Goosebumps” books are a children’s publishing phenomenon, is reviving another beloved series: “Fear Street,” a best-selling line of young-adult horror books set in the fictional town of Shadyside.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: tainted breast milk, scoliosis and biking accidents. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: F.D.A. Urging a Tighter Rein on Painkillers
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday recommended tighter controls on how doctors prescribe the most commonly used narcotic painkillers, changes that are expected to take place as early as next year.

headline: Adding Rauschenberg and Richter at MoMA
text: Fifty years ago, when Robert Rauschenberg was experimenting with the relationship between photography and painting in New York, Gerhard Richter was doing the same thing in Düsseldorf, Germany. This week, the Museum of Modern Art announced two acquisitions by these artists — both paintings from 1963 — that illustrate their similar explorations. “They were specific paintings we had our eyes on for years,” said Ann Temkin, MoMA’s chief curator of painting and sculpture.

headline: Chucky, Now Part of the Family
text: The fearsome Chucky is now beloved in many ways.

headline: Abrams and Kasdan Take Over Writing of New ‘Star Wars’ Movie
text: There has been a (minor) disturbance in the force: Lucasfilm on Thursday said that Michael Arndt would be replaced as the screenwriter of “Star Wars: Episode VII,” which is scheduled to begin filming in the spring, for a planned 2015 release.

headline: Recalling Painful Lessons in Forgiveness
text: My mother started screaming, and I whipped around fast enough to see her staggering from my car, hunched over, hugging her arm to her belly.

headline: Force of Evil Becomes Cute and Collectible
text: It’s been 25 years since an evil plaything terrorized moviegoers and forced parents to reassure their children that their toys wouldn’t turn on them. Chucky, as the overalls-wearing miscreant was called, started his rampage in “Child’s Play,” Tom Holland’s darkly comic 1988 horror film about a little boy whose redheaded Good Guy doll is inhabited by the spirit of a foul-mouthed killer. With its depiction of a child in danger, the film was controversial “to the degree that sometimes parents and parents groups get up in arms about having kids watch horror movies,” said Don Mancini, the creator of Chucky and a writer of the film.

headline: French Fault Banks Over Tax Evasion
text: PARIS — French lawmakers proposed measures on Thursday to combat tax evasion and faulted a chain of financial players, including banks, that enable a flight of tax revenue estimated at 80 billion euros, or $110 billion, a year.

headline: Giants’ Pierre-Paul Says He Won’t Be Fully Healthy Till Next Year
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul conceded Thursday what has been fairly obvious to those watching him play this year: he is not 100 percent healthy after off-season back surgery. But Pierre-Paul now believes he will not be completely healthy until next season.

headline: Should Medical School Last Just 3 Years?
text: Sandwiched between three mind-numbing years of basic science courses and hospital rotations and the lockdown years of residency training, the fourth year of medical school has long been a welcome respite for future doctors. It is the only time in their medical education when students have few requirements and a plethora of elective course offerings – and the time to go on vacation and spend time with friends and family.

headline: Agency Initiative Will Focus on Advancing Deep Brain Stimulation
text: Worldwide, 100,000 people have electrical implants in their brains to treat the involuntary movements associated with Parkinson’s disease, and scientists are experimenting with the technique for depression and other disorders.

headline: Ice-Skating Archive Seeks a New Home
text: The most comprehensive collection of equipment and souvenirs from ice-skating shows sits in an unprepossessing brick photo studio in Minneapolis. Costumes, skates, props, dolls, jewelry, spoons, posters, programs, tickets and even popcorn containers are neatly packed into boxes and binders. They date to the 1910s, when nightclubs started installing minirinks and appreciative audiences would carry star skaters through the streets after shows.

headline: A Neighborhood Prowl Through the City of Chianti
text: I’m in love with the sangiovese grape. This is no new infatuation. I’ve always loved Chiantis, the wines of Montalcino and the various other expressions of Tuscan sangiovese. But this year the affair has intensified.

headline: Ackman to Sell Part of His Stake in Canadian Pacific
text: More than a year after the activist investor William A. Ackman won a bitter battle for control of the Canadian Pacific Railway, he is cashing in part of his investment at a substantial profit.

headline: ‘John Ashbery Collects’: ‘Poet Among Things’
text: Loretta Howard Gallery

headline: A New Ethiopian Lodge With a Focus on Conservation
text: The first resort in Ethiopia’s wildlife-rich Bale Mountains National Park, Bale Mountain Lodge, opening Nov. 1, is poised to expand the African safari checklist beyond the Big Five.

headline: Donald Judd: ‘Stacks’
text: Mnuchin Gallery

headline: Kenya Assails Coverage of an Attack on a Mall
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan journalists came under threat this week from the authorities over their coverage of last month’s Westgate mall attack, after video suggesting possible looting by Kenyan forces was broadcast on national television.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Australia, South Africa and Bangladesh.

headline: Amazon’s Revenue Soars, but No Profit Is in Sight
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon’s third quarter followed a familiar script: it sold vast quantities of things, lost money while doing so, and investors were delighted.

headline: ‘Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections’
text: An exhibition at the National Gallery of Art takes a processional sweep through Byzantine iconography, with about 170 items for many centuries.

headline: William Anastasi: ‘Sound Works, 1963-2013’
text: Hunter College Art Galleries

headline: France Begins New Anti-Islamist Sweep in Mali
text: PARIS — French soldiers in Mali have begun a major anti-insurgent sweep with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers, the Defense Ministry said on Thursday, calling it the largest operation to counteract a revival of Islamist militant activity since France intervened early this year.

headline: Annette Kelm
text: Andrew Kreps

headline: Christoph Ruckhäberle: ‘Frühstück im Freien’
text: ZieherSmith

headline: G.O.P. Roots for Failure
text: In theory, lawmakers hope that government programs work well, and if they don’t, try to fix them. In theory, our representatives hope that government agencies carry out their missions smoothly, and if something goes wrong, try to figure out what happened to avoid making the same mistake in the future.

headline: Fantasy Precedes Melancholy Darkness
text: At first glance, it seemed the height of timidity for the excellent and adventurous conductor Pablo Heras-Casado to open the Orchestra of St. Luke’s program on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall with a frequently heard staple: Mendelssohn’s Overture to “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” Big things are expected of this exuberant Spanish artist, 35, who was appointed principal conductor of St. Luke’s in December 2011.

headline: Lots of Dim Sum Feeds a Starry Career
text: First love dies hard.

headline: Brisk Sales to Business at Microsoft; Devices Lag
text: SEATTLE — The person named to be Microsoft’s new chief executive will inherit two companies. One is thriving, the other is sluggish.

headline: Ruling Lets Times Co. Complete Globe Sale
text: The New York Times Company completed the sale of the New England Media Group, which includes The Boston Globe, to John W. Henry on Thursday, after a Massachusetts judge lifted an injunction that had temporarily halted the sale.

headline: ‘My West Coast Martha’s Vineyard’
text: That first time I walked through the grassy dunes of Point Reyes National Seashore, back in 1997, it felt familiar. On this stretch of California sand, I’d found the West Coast doppelgänger of Gay Head, on the southwestern point of Martha’s Vineyard, from where I’d recently moved. Though it was summer, I was wearing a fleece, and the sandstone cliffs of Limantour Beach were shrouded in fog. But the echoes of the Vineyard in Point Reyes were immediately clear: a rugged, relatively remote refuge with salty air, fresh fish and a strong sense of place.

headline: Part Ostentatious, Part Intimate
text: If you like old clocks — and who doesn’t like old clocks? — there’s one you must see in the International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show at the Park Avenue Armory. Displayed by Richard Redding Antiques, one of the show’s 67 vendors, it’s called “The Hartmann Exhibition Clock,” and it’s spectacular. A gleaming, complicated assemblage of gilt bronze, it has a neo-classical base from which columns resembling minarets made of basket-woven metal bands rise. These flank a roughly pyramidal tower of eight different clocks with enameled faces keeping time according to as many different systems. At the summit a little figure of Victory blows a trumpet. It also has a variety of automata, including small silver rods whose revolutions suggest streams of falling water.

headline: Exploring Point Reyes
text: Sun and fog, oysters and organic produce in this area north of San Francisco.

headline: A Fairy Tale Heroine Finds Her Magic Tree
text: In his ambitious “Cinderella,” performed by San Francisco Ballet on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater, the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon discards the magic pumpkin. Instead of a fairy godmother, Cinderella has four male Fates, who have the aura of the Blue Man Group, even though their faces are painted gold. Among other duties, they tidy the kitchen.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Snow Geese'
text: Mary-Louise Parker and Danny Burstein in a scene from Sharr White's new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Christopher Wool at the Guggenheim
text: The museum is featuring paintings and works on paper.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 8 Tiered Player Rankings
text: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Fed Proposes a Rule to Help Big Banks Stay Liquid in Times of Crisis
text: During the financial crisis of 2008, the big banks fell dangerously short of cash, forcing them to take out enormous government loans to survive the tumult.

headline: Samsung Electronics Fined for Fake Online Comments
text: A Taiwanese trade agency has punished Samsung Electronics for paying people to post fake online comments that mocked a competitor.

headline: She’s Glad to Be Onstage and Turning Back the Clock
text: “I’m glad to be anywhere,” said Marilyn Maye, the inexhaustibly sunny 85-year-old trouper — who has every reason to be joyful — at 54 Below on Monday evening. In the opening-night performance of her new show, in which she jazzed up nearly 30 vintage show tunes, with a special emphasis on songs from “Guys and Dolls,” she exhibited no signs of the kind of faltering stamina that would seem almost inevitable for someone her age.

headline: Their Names Are Legion
text: When Hu Yinan meets someone new, say, in a meeting or at a party, she prefers to introduce herself by her English name: Number.

headline: Filling in the Blanks in the Tale of a Death
text: When “Strike Back,” Cinemax’s post-Sept. 11, globe-hopping counterterrorism series, began in 2011, something felt missing. In the premiere, a British special-forces soldier was kidnapped in Pakistan and executed, and people back in London were very upset, which made sense. But viewers were left wondering: Who was that guy? Why were we supposed to care so much about him?

headline: Fangs Follow the Fairy Tales
text: During its short life so far, NBC’s splendid fairy tale action-adventure “Grimm” — one of the network’s few nonfootball successes — has been stranded on Friday nights. For company, the network has given it a motley crew of “Dateline,” a few disposable reality shows and the last months of “Chuck.”

headline: Focused Effort to Narrow the Gender Gap on Corporate Boards
text: The dearth of women on corporate boards has been a persistent issue for decades. Yet little has changed over the years, despite much public hand-wringing over the stubborn gender gap.

headline: After Muddy Waters Report, NQ Mobile Falls by Half
text: When the stock market opened on Thursday, NQ Mobile, a Chinese mobile security company, had a valuation of $1.1 billion. Just hours later, half of its value was erased.

headline: Murder, Mayhem and Cross-Dressing Zombies
text: Don’t be fooled by the unwieldy title: “Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings” is nothing if not narratively succinct. Hailing from the genre-loving Philippines, this batty horror-comedy, directed by Jade Castro (who was also one of the film’s three writers), knows exactly what it is and where it’s going.

headline: Viewing for Your Inner Michael Myers
text: LET’S say you’re more “Halloween” than Halloween. You love scary movies, but the actual holiday makes you want to punch a drunken Dracula in the plastic fangs. You’d much rather turn off the lights, ignore the trick-or-treaters at the door, dig your nails into the couch and enjoy a good (or bad-good) horror movie at home. But first you must sort through the fright-flick detritus.

headline: Internet Archive Will Shield Visitors
text: Reading, once the most private of acts, is going public. The simple act of buying a book can be automatically publicized through social media. The makers of reading devices know who skipped chapter three and how many people made a note of that lovely passage in chapter four.

headline: Tripping All the Way to the Gates of Hell
text: If you enter “Toad Road” expecting a conventional horror movie, you will be sorely disappointed. But if you’re looking for an uncomfortably authentic drama about the horrors of dedicated drug use, then this strange little number from Jason Banker (who also wrote the screenplay and wielded the camera) might just do the trick.

headline: Social Media, the Spiritual Version
text: WASHINGTON — After arriving with no particular buzz, then being kept on ice by the government shutdown, “Heaven and Earth: Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections” has finally opened at the National Gallery of Art here, and it’s ambushingly resplendent, like a somber cloud with a fire inside.

headline: Excursions in a Digitally Fabricated Landscape
text: If you haven’t quite wrapped your head around the concept of 3-D printing, or haven’t yet had a digital scanner wrap itself around you, now you can do both in “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital,” at the Museum of Arts and Design. The technologies in this survey of computer-assisted art, architecture and design may not be entirely new; the Museum of Modern Art’s 2008 exhibition “Design and the Elastic Mind” covered much the same territory and included some of the same artists and projects. But these tools are becoming more pervasive in both art and life, making this a good time for the uninitiated to get up to speed.

headline: On the Road With the Vienna Boys Choir
text: In the opening of “Bridging the Gap,” members of the Vienna Boys Choir, clad in its traditional sailor suits, arrive in a rowboat on what is apparently the shore of New Zealand and plunges into welcome rituals with Maori people. The situation almost recalls a memorable scene from “Lord of the Flies,” in which a storm-tossed choir sings “Kyrie eleison” in procession on a beach, but the photography here has the color cranked way up, and a plummy, National Geographic-style voice-over pours forth platitudes and edifying narration.

headline: Painting’s Endgame, Rendered Graphically
text: Christopher Wool is one of many painters who have experimented with bringing their medium to extinction. They strip it of familiar attributes like imagery, brushwork or flatness, often ending up with some kind of monochrome that suggests the last painting that could possibly be made.

headline: Stop by These Subway Stops
text: The best locations in New York’s sprawling train system.

headline: Wildlife Is Tame; Not the Humans
text: “The Counselor,” Ridley Scott’s terrifying, implacable new movie, opens on a seductive scene. The setting is a softly lighted bedroom in which two people are murmuring sweet, dirty nothings under a white sheet. You don’t see who they are until there’s a cut to under the sheet, bringing you close enough to Michael Fassbender and Penélope Cruz to feel like an interloper.

headline: TV Talk: Comedy Comebacks
text: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the surprise hits among this year’s new comedies.

headline: Comedy Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Return Engagements

headline: ‘You’re Fired,’ in Terms Only a Boss Could Love
text: Through booms and busts, profits and losses, the vacuous jargon and happy euphemisms of the business world endure. In fact, they flourish. At a time when the nation’s economy is plodding and job growth is sluggish, corporations are coming up with new ways to sugarcoat words no employee wants to hear: You’re fired.

headline: Movie Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: In Jil Sander’s Exit, Echoes of the Past
text: EVER SINCE she sold her company to Prada, in 1999, Jil Sander has not been sure she wanted to stay. She has left three times. The third occurred on Thursday with the announcement that she is leaving for unspecified personal reasons.

headline: Response to a City’s Smog Points to a Change in Chinese Attitude
text: BEIJING — Emergency measures came swiftly in Harbin, the northeastern city blanketed with hazardous smog this week: Schools were shut down, buses ordered off the roads, the airport closed, police roadblocks set up to check tailpipe emissions from cars. City officials even fanned out in the surrounding countryside, ordering farmers to stop burning the cornstalks left in their fields after the harvest.

headline: Brave Optimism of Tahrir Square Meets Other Fierce Forces
text: In the language of politics, “the people” is a great abstraction, an idea that can be invoked to justify noble projects and terrible crimes. “The Square,” Jehane Noujaim’s stunning new documentary, is partly about the contested status of the Egyptian people between the winter of 2011, when crowds of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square to demand the removal of President Hosni Mubarak, and the summer of 2013, when the army ousted his successor, Mohamed Morsi, and began a violent campaign against his followers in the Muslim Brotherhood. Mr. Morsi, the military and the demonstrators — and, for that matter, Mr. Mubarak himself — all claimed to be true agents and loyal servants of the popular will.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: What I Love | Dani Shapiro
text: The author and her husband left the city for Connecticut and found a more spiritual life.

headline: Dance Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dani Shapiro’s Provident Move to the Country
text: Dani Shapiro, the novelist and memoirist, has awesome real estate karma. In the 1980s and 1990s, she lived in three of the Upper West Side’s most storied landmark buildings: the Ansonia, the Dakota and the Hotel des Artistes. When she and her husband, the screenwriter and director Michael Maren, decided to move to Brooklyn in the late 1990s, they bought a town house in gentrifying Prospect Heights right before yoga studios arrived and prices escalated.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 25-31
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Man Beneath the Hairspray
text: Before Boy George, before RuPaul, there was Divine, the zaftig drag diva and provocateur of early John Waters films who, once glimpsed, was hard to forget. Facetiously dubbed “the filthiest person alive” for a notorious scene in the 1972 film “Pink Flamingos,” in which he ate dog feces, Divine expanded the concept of the drag queen from brash female impersonator into something much larger, more subversive and less gender specific.

headline: Learning From Rejection
text: A rejection from a mortgage lender is no cause for shame. Instead, think of it as a call to action.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 25-31
text: ‘Hollow’

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: Understanding ‘Preferential Rent’

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 25-31
text: Village Halloween Parade and Costume Ball (Thursday) Barring any disastrous weather — last year’s hurricane put an end to many holiday plans — Halloween celebrations will be in full swing. Billed as the “Hallelujah Halloween Revival,” the Village Halloween Parade will proceed up Avenue of the Americas, from Spring Street to 16th Street, at 7 p.m.

headline: Palaces-in-the-Making
text: A run-down parking garage is for sale on the corner of Perry and Greenwich Streets in the West Village, and at least one of the bidders wants to tear it down to its bones and replace it with a 40,000-square-foot mansion — creating what would be the largest single-family home in New York City.

headline: So Evil, They Cackle at Strategy Meetings
text: Who doesn’t hate, at least a little bit, the high-flying wheeler-dealers who recently brought the world to the brink of economic collapse and were never held accountable? As you watch the Costa-Gavras financial thriller “Capital,” it may rekindle some of the rage and fear that people felt when the pillars trembled.

headline: About Last Night | Old and Young New York Collide at a Gala for the Whitney
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Being Gay in Lebanon
text: Samer Daboul’s “Out Loud” bills itself as the first gay film from Lebanon. Six rebellious young idealists break all the social and religious rules and decide to live communally. In hot pursuit are the relatives of the two who are gay, Rami (Ali Rhayem) and Ziad (Jean Kobrously), closeted lovers who were caught kissing and are marked for death for having brought shame to their families.

headline: ‘You’re Demised!’ Getting Fired Evolves
text: The Times’s David Gillen explains how companies like HSBC, AOL and Hewlett-Packard are getting creative with the jargon behind major layoffs, from “downsizing” to “right-sizing.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: New Debate About Sexism, and Battle for Power of the Internet
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: A Geriatric Biker Gang
text: There is undeniable exhilaration in the aerial shots of “Go Grandriders,” as a gang of motor-scooter-riding 70- and 80-somethings in matching helmets, shirts and jackets rides along majestic Taiwanese coastal roads. There is mystery, too, in this documentary about their cross-country ride, but mostly from omission in the sometimes inept storytelling.

headline: Fishing as Therapy
text: Like a documentary antidote to the adrenaline flow of “The Hurt Locker,” the modest, becalmed “Not Yet Begun to Fight” shows veterans of combat in Iraq and Afghanistan undergoing an unusual but apt form of therapy. These warriors, hobbled by injuries and psychologically fragile, enter a program that treats the guy’s-guy pastime of fly-fishing as regenerative meditation. The directors, Shasta Grenier and Sabrina Lee, delicately find moments of openness in casual, lapidary interviews with five men at different points in recovery.

headline: Troubles in the Kitchen
text: Joseph Levy’s ordinary documentary “Spinning Plates” rotates among the challenges faced by the proprietors of three restaurants: the 150-year-old Breitbach’s Country Dining, in Balltown, Iowa; a struggling roadside Mexican joint in Tucson; and the chef Grant Achatz’s Alinea in Chicago, which has three Michelin stars. While a lot could be said about each, and about food and culture generally, this dully structured film makes its points early and often, treading water before a purposely delayed big finish.

headline: Crudely Closing a Generation Gap
text: Attending “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,” Johnny Knoxville’s new prankfest, could be life-changing. It may cause you never to use another vending machine, never to enter another bingo parlor, never to put your child on one of those coin-operated rides, never to eat in another diner.

headline: Finding Love in a Cruel Time
text: One man and one woman against the world is a familiar story, among the oldest, told from Genesis to “The Blue Lagoon.” “The Pin,” a Canadian film about two young Eastern Europeans hiding in a barn during World War II, is a variation in which the couple are enclosed in menace. Here their island is an underground hiding place and the Yiddish they speak to each other.

headline: Incalculable Loss, Inconsolable Mother
text: We have seen J-horror from Japan, K-horror from South Korea, and now, with Le-Van Kiet’s “House in the Alley,” V-horror from Vietnam. Postpartum depression takes a murderous turn in this slight exercise, which, for all its modesty, generates a measure of dread.

headline: Filmmaker Chronicles His Battle With Illness
text: The title is “When I Walk,” but Jason DaSilva’s hard-hitting record of his daily battle with primary-progressive multiple sclerosis is really an exploration of creeping immobility. From the moment his legs gave way during a 2006 Caribbean vacation, to the film’s improbably upbeat 2012 conclusion, Mr. DaSilva, a successful documentary filmmaker and just 25 when he received his diagnosis, ruthlessly chronicled his dismayingly rapid decline.

headline: A Game of Shark and Minnow
text: In a remote corner of the South China Sea, 105 nautical miles from the Philippines, lies a submerged reef that the Filipinos call Ayungin. There’s little to commend the spot, apart from its plentiful fish and safe harbor. In most ways it resembles the hundreds of other desolate reefs, islands, rock clusters and cays that collectively are called the Spratly Islands. But Ayungin is different. It sits on the southwestern edge of Reed Bank, an area rumored to contain vast reserves of oil and natural gas. And its shallows are home to a World War II-era ship called the Sierra Madre, which the Philippine government ran aground on the reef in 1999 and has since maintained as a kind of post-apocalyptic military garrison, manned by eight Filipino troops struggling to survive extreme mental and physical desolation. Of all places, the scorched shell of the Sierra Madre has become an unlikely battleground in a geopolitical struggle that will shape the future of the South China Sea and, to some extent, the rest of the world.

headline: DuPont to Split Into 2 as It Plans to Spin Off a Major Segment
text: The industrial conglomerate DuPont is splitting in two.

headline: Group Linked to Kochs Admits to Campaign Finance Violations
text: A secretive nonprofit group with ties to the billionaire conservative businessmen Charles and David Koch admitted to improperly failing to disclose more than $15 million in contributions it funneled into state referendum battles in California, state officials there announced Thursday.

headline: A Portal to the Old World
text: A G.P.S. comes in handy on the way to Dubrovnik, an exciting, handsome restaurant on an unprepossessing block on Main Street in New Rochelle. This authentic Croatian spot — my Croatian-American guests thought the only thing missing was the Adriatic lapping at limestone cliffs — is polished but not fussy, just like the dishes created by its Croatian owner and chef, Zeljko Tomic, known as Jerry.

headline: To Combat Elder Abuse, Doormen Are Enlisted to Keep a Watchful Eye
text: Michael Marlow, a doorman at the Gracie Mews apartment building on the Upper East Side, does a lot more than just open doors for residents. He unscrews their jar lids, runs to the store for apple juice, listens to their complaints about spouses and children, and even reaches into his own pocket to lend a couple of dollars for cab fare.

headline: American Comfort Food From Asia
text: It’s interesting to recall how exotic Thai food once seemed, now that pad Thai is almost as American as spaghetti. My newest Thai favorite is Sweet Chilli on Park Road in West Hartford, a restaurant with a casually sumptuous look and soothing feel. It is often full but never loud. (And yes, the extra “l” in the restaurant’s name is intentional — meant to help distinguish its fare from Tex-Mex chili.)

headline: Despite Rising Sticker Prices, Actual College Costs Stable Over Decade, Study Says
text: Every year, price increases at private colleges prompt a round of appalled responses and calls for corrective action. But even as some sticker prices approach $60,000 a year, the amount that students actually pay — because of increased discounts, grants and tax benefits — has barely changed over the last decade, according to a major analysis of college costs published this week.

headline: Where Soul Food Is a Family Affair
text: “There are no good restaurants in Valley Stream” was a complaint I heard recently from friends who live there. I begged to differ and proved my point by taking them to Pretty Toni’s Cafe. This very good restaurant, which opened in January 2009, seems to have been overlooked by some of the local residents.

headline: City Says Principal Didn’t Tell of Abuse Claim
text: In May, a student at a Bronx elementary school told his principal he saw a teacher kissing a 10-year-old girl in the back of a dark, empty classroom. Another student told the principal, Angelyn Donald, that the man and the girl had exchanged a sexually explicit note during class.

headline: To Expand Offshore Power, Japan Builds Floating Windmills
text: OFF THE COAST OF FUKUSHIMA, Japan — Twelve miles out to sea from the severely damaged and leaking nuclear reactors at Fukushima, a giant floating wind turbine signals the start of Japan’s most ambitious bet yet on clean energy.
