headline: LinkedIn’s New Mobile App Called ‘a Dream for Attackers’
text: Security researchers are calling LinkedIn’s new mobile app, Intro, a dream come true for hackers or intelligence agencies.

headline: Contribution Solicitation Form Offers a Choice
text: A donation to the efforts of Americans for Job Security would be “nonreportable,” while one to the Small Business Action Committee PAC would be, the form says.

headline: Recalling the Republicans of Yesteryear
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ukraine: Boxing Champion Throws His Hat in a New Ring
text: Vitali Klitschko, who is the reigning World Boxing Council heavyweight champion and leads an opposition political party in Ukraine, on Thursday declared his candidacy for president of Ukraine in an election scheduled for 2015. His decision to challenge the incumbent, Viktor F. Yanukovich, came in response to an effort in the Ukrainian Parliament to pass a bill that would prohibit him from running because he holds permanent resident status in Germany, where he has trained.

headline: Those Bright Blue Bikes, to Love and to Hate
Anti-Semitism in Hungary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ellis Island Is Reopening With Damaged Museum
text: A year ago next week, Hurricane Sandy swamped Ellis Island and its immigration museum, ruining its electrical and air-conditioning systems and prompting the removal of most of its collection of artifacts.

headline: Eagles’ Frustrations at Home and With Quarterbacks Have Persisted
text: PHILADELPHIA — The City of Brotherly Love is hardly imbued with that spirit when it comes to the Eagles these days.

headline: Republican Consultant’s Interview With Investigators
text: An August report on Anthony Russo’s interview with representatives of the Fair Political Practices Commission and the California state attorney general’s office.

headline: New York City Amends Fee Policy for a Visit to the Met
text: Clarifying four decades of legal vagueness, the Bloomberg administration has amended New York City’s lease with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, spelling out that the Met is allowed to charge a suggested admission fee, as the museum has done since 1971 under an agreement with the city. The amendment adds that fees for special exhibitions may also be charged, a widespread practice in the art world but something the museum decided against in the 1980s.

headline: Tailgate Parties Far Beyond Burgers and Dogs
text: For Robert Burzichelli, getting to High Point Solutions Stadium by 7 a.m. to set up his tailgate party before Rutgers football games offers the kind of restorative tranquillity often associated with yoga.

headline: Winning Sports Fans’ Hearts by Giving Them Somewhere to Go
text: PROVIDING product samples is a relatively simple affair for many products, whether it’s fragrance brand representatives spritzing consumers in department stores or snack brand representatives handing out tortilla chips in supermarkets. For toilet paper brands, getting consumers to try the product on the spot is decidedly more complicated.

headline: In White House Pitches, Rosy View of Health Care Site
text: WASHINGTON — Just days before HealthCare.gov went live with disastrous results, top White House officials were excitedly briefing lawmakers, reporters, Capitol Hill staff members and Washington pundits on their expectations for the government’s new health care Web site.

headline: Excitement Before Health Site Went Live
text: Before HealthCare.gov made its debut, President Obama and his advisers predicted how user-friendly and beneficial it would be.

headline: Prospect Park’s Closing Is Scaled Back
text: Parts of Prospect Park in Brooklyn will remain open on Friday, despite a presidential visit, the Prospect Park Alliance said on Thursday, contradicting earlier information that it would be closed from noon to 6 p.m.

headline: Freedom of Speech Online
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Fatal Rape in India
No. But I Play One on TV.
text: For 15 seasons, “Law & Order: SVU” has recreated a vision of New York’s streets by casting extras who can be seamlessly woven into scenes.

headline: Why the Government Never Gets Tech Right
text: MILLIONS of Americans negotiating America’s health care system know all too well what the waiting room of a doctor’s office looks like. Now, thanks to HealthCare.gov, they know what a “virtual waiting room” looks like, too. Nearly 20 million Americans, in fact, have visited the Web site since it opened three weeks ago, but only about 500,000 managed to complete applications for insurance coverage. And an even smaller subset of those applicants actually obtained coverage.

headline: Anthony Caro, Sculptor, Dies at 89
text: Anthony Caro followed sculpture from the monumental to the abstract.

headline: Would-Be Virginia Governors Spar, Continuing Bitter Tone
text: BLACKSBURG, Va. — Trailing in polls and outspent on the airwaves, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, who has sought to capture the swing state of Virginia by building on his Tea Party base, faced his last, best chance to reboot the race for governor in a debate here Thursday.

headline: Fighting for a Hallowed and Grueling Ground
text: There are many who dread Cemetery Hill.

headline: The Bad News for Local Job Markets
text: DURHAM, N.C. — THE September jobs numbers, finally released this week after the government reopened, indicate that the job market remains on a painfully slow upward trajectory. Unemployment has fallen a full percentage point since early 2012, but at this pace, our economy could still be years away from its prerecession level. To make faster progress, many analysts are banking on job growth from two key sectors, education and health care.

headline: Hitting the Wall: For Marathon Charities, Numbers Are Slowing
text: By this time of year, the height of fall marathon season, the e-mails have long piled up: marathon aspirants seeking charitable donations from family and friends to help them secure a spot in a particular race. On race days, charity logos on runners’ gear have become as ubiquitous as mile markers, an integral part of an event’s feel-good message of fitness and philanthropy.

headline: Timeline of the Skakel Case
text: More than a decade after the conviction of Michael Skakel in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley in Greenwich, Conn., a judge has ordered that Mr. Skakel be released on bail. Here is a look at how the case unfolded through the years.

headline: Upstart in Miami Lures Luxury Stores From a Chic Citadel
text: MIAMI — For decades, the wealthy tourists and transplants who flock to South Florida bought their Chanels, Cartiers, Diors and the like at one place: Bal Harbour Shops, an open-air mall housing many of the highest-end retailers in the world around a courtyard of palm trees and koi ponds at the northern end of Miami Beach.

headline: After Baby Hope Confession, Assessing the Value of Taped Interrogations
text: Q. The police commissioner announced more than a year ago that detectives would videotape their interrogations of suspects in serious cases like murder. That’s what they did in the Baby Hope case, right?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 24, 2013
Addicted to the Apocalypse
text: Once upon a time, walking around shouting “The end is nigh” got you labeled a kook, someone not to be taken seriously. These days, however, all the best people go around warning of looming disaster. In fact, you more or less have to subscribe to fantasies of fiscal apocalypse to be considered respectable.

headline: City to Fit All Streetlights With Energy-Saving LED Bulbs
text: The amber glow of the New York City streetlight is going away. In an energy-saving effort, the city plans to replace all of its 250,000 streetlights with brighter, whiter, energy-saving, light-emitting diode fixtures in one of the nation’s largest retrofitting projects, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, said in a news conference on Thursday.

headline: In the Skakel Case, 2 Women on 2 Sides in an Endless Vigil
text: For more than a decade, they have driven themselves to court hearings, sat a few feet apart through countless hours of harrowing testimony, and exchanged cordial greetings, if not quite warm ones.

headline: The Ghosts of October
text: As I push my 4-year-old daughter on the swing, I wonder when the day will come when she will not need me to supply the power. My children remind me that time is marching on even when the frenetic pace of a parenting day convinces us that we don’t have time to age.

headline: French to Strike, but This Time Owners Call It
text: PARIS — The labor strike being something of a national sport in France, it should come as no surprise that its practitioners occasionally include professional athletes.

headline: No to More Casinos in New York State
text: New York State is home to five casinos run by Indian tribes and nine casinos that are called “racinos” because they are large slot machine parlors near racetracks. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the Legislature now want to expand gambling by putting a constitutional amendment on the Nov. 5 ballot that would add seven full-blown casinos. The answer from voters should be no.

headline: Seeking a New Relationship With Pakistan
text: After so many years of animosity between Pakistan and the United States, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and President Obama used their first meeting at the White House this week to begin to set the relationship on a more constructive path.

headline: White House Official’s Career Twitters Out
text: WASHINGTON — Until his Twitter adventures under the handle @NatSecWonk ended his career this week, Jofi Joseph embodied all the elements of a Washington cliché, down to the security card around his neck. His degree in foreign service was earned at Georgetown, which propelled him to his first job as an analyst in the Congressional Budget Office, the ultimately anonymous D.C. gig.

headline: @NatSecWonk Snark
text: A selection of Twitter posts about top administration officials written by Jofi Joseph, the National Security Council staff member who was fired for using an anonymous Twitter handle to knock public figures, reporters and colleagues.

headline: In Search of Republican Grown-Ups
text: The leaders of the Republican Party, in full flight from their disastrous and juvenile shutdown stunt, now want to restock their ranks with grown-ups. “Let’s face it: it was not a good maneuver,” Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah told The Times recently. “You’ve got to have the adults running the thing.”

headline: Allegation of U.S. Spying on Merkel Puts Obama at Crossroads
text: WASHINGTON — The angry allegation by the German government that the National Security Agency monitored the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel may force President Obama into making a choice he has avoided for years: whether to continue the age-old game of spying on America’s friends and risk undercutting cooperation with important partners in tracking terrorists, managing the global economy and slowing Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: The Assistants: The Mensa Member
text: The first name on Urban Meyer’s list of assistant candidates: Tom Herman, he of the documented high I.Q. Herman, now Ohio State’s co-offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach, would prefer not to be known as the Mensa assistant, but he did list his membership in the group on his first résumé at his mother’s suggestion, between his team captaincy and all-conference accolades. He asked various universities to remove that from his biography, but it trailed him like a blinking neon sign: I’m smart. Really, really smart.

headline: National Guardsman Accused of Shooting and Wounding 2 in Tennessee
text: ATLANTA — A Tennessee National Guard recruiter wounded two of his superiors on Thursday when he opened fire with a handgun at a military facility near Memphis, the authorities said.

headline: The Assistants: The Roommates
text: Luke Fickell wanted to be a wrestler. He idolized Dan Gable, the godfather of grappling. His family’s vacations revolved around wrestling tournaments. He won three high school state championships in Ohio and went undefeated. Yet Fickell ended up on the football team at Ohio State, where he made 50 straight starts at nose guard.

headline: North Carolina Prosecutor Takes Shots at the Laws He’s Obliged to Enforce
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The criticism could not have been much harsher: North Carolina’s Republican-led legislature had set out to undo 50 years of progress with a Tea Party-inspired “playground of extremist fantasies” that include tax giveaways to its richest residents and election law changes that make it harder for residents to register and vote.

headline: The Assistants: The Traditionalist
text: Ed Warinner, who grew up near Canton, Ohio, and played for Mount Union, embodied the background Urban Meyer sought.

headline: A Matriarch’s Cold Realities Pile Up
text: As a service to readers and copy editors, I feel the need to point out that “The Snow Geese” and “The Snow Goose” are not the same thing. “The Snow Geese” (plural), a new play by Sharr White that opened on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, is a sentimental tale set during World War I. “The Snow Goose” (singular), a novella from the early 1940s by Paul Gallico, is a sentimental tale set during World War II.

headline: Cause of a Class Struggle
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Stacking entries one on top of the next in a crossword puzzle is the metaphorical equivalent of the “clean and jerk” in weightlifting. It’s an impressive feat, difficult to do elegantly, and can throw your back out if you’re not careful. I’m sorry, I drifted. What I meant to say was that it should not be tried at home.

headline: Rape Case of Prosecutor’s Friend Spins Into County Feud
text: CARMEL, N.Y. — Had it come into her courtroom, the domestic dust-up might have raised Judge Judy’s eyebrows: A sitting district attorney gives advice and money for legal expenses to a criminal suspect — his personal trainer — who is charged with the rape of an underage girl in the district attorney’s jurisdiction. Then he sits back while his brother-in-law takes over as the suspect’s lawyer.

headline: The Assistants: The Motivator
text: The voice that echoes across the practice field, that seems to be coming from a megaphone, belongs to Kerry Coombs, the special teams coordinator and cornerbacks coach.

headline: Republicans Name 23-Year-Old to Head Youth Outreach
text: Seven months after a report described the Republican Party’s image as “old and detached from pop culture,” it has hired Elliott Echols, 23, to serve as its first national youth director.

headline: This Week's Movies: Oct. 24, 2013
text: The New York Times film critics on "Blue is the Warmest Color," "The Counselor" and "The Square."

headline: Corrections: October 25, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Visiting Nurse Service Cuts 500 Workers
text: The Visiting Nurse Service of New York laid off 500 employees on Wednesday, part of the fallout from state scrutiny of enrollment practices that drew fit elderly people into programs meant for frail and disabled patients.

headline: Political Nonprofit Groups Skirt Disclosure Rules
text: A Republican political consultant raised money to oppose California’s Proposition 30, which would raise taxes on the wealthy, and to support Proposition 32, which would prohibit unions from using automatic payroll deductions to contribute to political campaigns.

headline: Ohio State’s Staff Offers a Mix That’s Unmatched
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Urban Meyer started with a notepad, the first page blank. He scribbled “OC” and drew a line underneath. Same with “DC.” And “OL.”

headline: Soliciting Millions From a Koch
text: A donor working with Anthony Russo called and e-mailed Charles Koch several times, seeking a contribution of “several million” in the effort on Proposition 32, according to an e-mail obtained by investigators.

headline: Returner, Receiver, Rusher. Anything Else You Need?
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Josh Cribbs can be unpredictable on the field, where defenders are uncertain of how he will attempt to elude them and of where he will line up for the next play. The Jets hope to put Cribbs in several situations where he has space to use his legs. Those legs once made him one of the most dynamic players in the N.F.L.

headline: Disturbing Aliens, Some From Space
text: It was all Nelson Eddy’s fault. Seventy-five years ago, at 8 o’clock on the evening of Oct. 30, 1938, millions of Americans tuned in their radios to listen to NBC’s “Chase and Sanborn Hour,” a popular variety show starring the ventriloquist Edgar Bergen and his dummy Charlie McCarthy. When Bergen and McCarthy finished their first sketch — a routine about trick-or-treating — the announcer passed the microphone to Eddy, a booming baritone then starring with Jeanette MacDonald in a series of MGM operettas.

headline: Garden Renovations Come With a Tug of War
text: The $1 billion renovation of Madison Square Garden was unveiled Thursday, and there is much to admire about it, from the shiny lobby with its innovative 600-foot ceiling video screens to the steel-and-concrete bridges built high over the playing surface.

headline: Drone Issue Hovers More Than Ever, Even as Strikes Ebb
text: LONDON — For years, American drone strikes in Pakistan’s tribal belt have been the subject of what might be termed a wink-and-keep-moving approach between the leaders of both countries.

headline: Indignation Over U.S. Spying Spreads in Europe
text: BERLIN — Fury over reports that American intelligence had monitored the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel spread from Germany to much of Europe on Thursday, plunging trans-Atlantic relations to a low and threatening to recast the United States and President Obama from friend and ally to cyberbully.

headline: The Toll of War
text: Millions inside Syria are struggling to find adequate food as government-run bakeries that provide bread have closed during the conflict.

headline: Rethinking the Oklahoma Border (This Time It’s About Water)
text: LAKE TEXOMA — Inside a dimly lit water-pumping station that juts over choppy waters, Denise Hickey toes an imaginary line that has fueled real disputes over water, oil and property taxes, dating back to the Louisiana Purchase.

headline: Hardships Mounting for Refugees Inside Syria
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Some five million Syrians are now refugees in their own country, many living hand-to-mouth in vacant buildings, schools, mosques, parks and the cramped homes of relatives. Others are trapped in neighborhoods isolated by military blockades, beyond the reach of aid groups. Already desperately short of food and medicine as winter closes in, they could begin to succumb in greater numbers to hunger and exposure, aid workers say.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 25, 2013
text: “It is as if we are living on Jupiter or Mars. Everyone is looking at us from the window and we are in a separate world. Everyone left us alone, every single person on this planet.”

headline: Beltran, Sore but Eager, Returns as Fans Exhale
text: BOSTON — For Cardinals fans, it was a depressing sight: with their team already trailing the Red Sox in the second inning of Game 1, Carlos Beltran, St. Louis’s switch-hitting star, was clutching his ribs in pain. He had just crashed into the short bullpen wall while saving his team the indignity of allowing a grand slam to Boston’s David Ortiz.

headline: Money Plays a Critical Role in Texas State Races
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: If You Build It on Public University Campuses, 1 Percent Must Be Public Art
text: Like giant Mardi Gras masks, four seven-foot-tall faces of woven bronze peer westward from a lawn outside Talkington Hall, a recently opened student residence building on the Lubbock campus of Texas Tech University.

headline: With a Plant’s Tainted Water Still Flowing, No End to Environmental Fears
text: TOKYO — For months now, it has been hard to escape the continuing deluge of bad news from the devastated Fukushima nuclear power plant.

headline: Instagram Will Begin Showing Ads in the Photo Stream
text: You knew it had to happen eventually: Instagram is getting ads.

headline: Few Clues to the Spot Seen Round the World
text: BOSTON — Tyler Melling is a Class A pitcher who was 3-4 this season with a 4.93 earned run average. Because he is employed by the St. Louis Cardinals, who turn prospects of all pedigrees into stars, there is a strong chance Melling will somehow win 15 games in the majors next season. For now, his position is whistle-blower.

headline: Court Upholds Life Sentence for Bo Xilai
text: Updated, 11:55 p.m. EST | The black van entered the courthouse compound around 9:40 a.m. on Friday. It was one in a line of other police vans. Journalists armed with telephoto lenses outside the courthouse in Jinan, Shandong Province, took photographs. Those pictures, once posted online, ignited the speculation: Was Bo Xilai in the van?

headline: On Twitter, Eavesdropper Reveals Former N.S.A. Head’s Train Chat
text: WASHINGTON — It was just a background conversation on the Acela train ride north on Thursday.

headline: Dispute Over Canadian Senators’ Expenses Balloons Into Larger Political Scandal
text: OTTAWA — It began as a seemingly mundane dispute over expense claims from four members of Canada’s Senate, an appointed body rife with patronage and long a source of minor scandals. And while the amount of money involved is not vast, it has become a major political scandal for Canada’s prime minister and his government.

headline: Bob Greene, Jazz Pianist, Dies at 91
text: Bob Greene, a pianist who was so besotted by the controlled yet fevered jazz of Jelly Roll Morton that he abandoned a writing career to perform the Jelly Roll canon and spread the Jelly Roll gospel, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Amagansett, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: In Quake-Prone Israel, Public Is Advised to Take Cover, This Time Outside
text: JERUSALEM — For years, Israel has worked to educate its citizens to rush off the streets and take cover inside buildings during rocket attacks. But this week, the Home Front Command, the military department responsible for civil defense in times of war or national emergency, began a new public awareness campaign instructing people to run outdoors.

headline: A Marionette Production of ‘Sleeping Beauty,’ Created With Centuries-Old Techniques
text: The Milanese artisans of Carlo Colla & Sons Marionette Company who create sets, bodies and tiny costumes will also serve as puppeteers in a performance at the New Victory Theater in Times Square, beginning Nov. 1.

headline: The Midterm Grade for HealthCare.gov
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: A Warning on Chemical Peels
text: In the late 19th century, German scientists discovered that an easy-to-make acid could rather neatly peel off a layer of skin cells. They promptly marketed it for “skin rejuvenation.” Today, that compound, trichloroacetic acid, or TCA, is widely used by dermatologists both to brighten up aging faces and to remove damaged skin cells, including precancerous ones.

headline: Word of the Day | cohort
text: cohort •\ˈko-ˌhȯrt\• noun

headline: Portugal: Investigators Reopen Case of Missing British Child
text: Portuguese prosecutors on Thursday reopened an investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann from her British parents’ hotel room six years ago, when she was 3. The case, one of the most notorious recent child-abduction cases in Europe, was formally closed in 2008. But after a campaign by the girl’s parents, Kate and Gerry McCann, British and Portuguese investigators began reviewing the evidence two years ago and independently uncovered new leads. In July, British officials opened a formal investigation, and now Portugal has followed suit. Portuguese investigators did not specify what the new leads were, but according to the police in London they are separate from the ones being followed in Britain. Teams from both countries met a week ago to compare notes and to brief the McCanns on the progress. Madeleine disappeared on May 3, 2007, from an apartment in a resort in Praia da Luz, Portugal, while her parents were having dinner at a nearby restaurant.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: This Time, Error Benefits Cardinals
text: BOSTON — The St. Louis Cardinals returned to playing the brand of baseball they cherish: clean and crisp, coolheaded and clutch. And it still was not working.

headline: If We're Spying, Are We Still 'Allies'?
text: After surveillance revelations, Brazil, France and Germany may be having second thoughts about the U.S.: In what sense are they "allies"?

headline: ‘Trottergate’ Raises Questions of Reckless Consumption
text: Just how many pig trotters can a Communist Party official devour?

headline: Iraq: U.S. Pledges $1 Million to Help Relocate Iranian Exiles
text: The United States announced Thursday that it would contribute $1 million to a United Nations trust fund to help resettle Iranian exiles in Iraq who have been housed in Camp Hurriya, a former American military base near Baghdad. In a statement on the State Department’s Web site, Marie Harf, a spokeswoman, said resettling the exiles in other countries was “the only lasting means of guaranteeing the safety and well-being of those residing in Camp Hurriya.”

headline: Mr. Ortiz, a Modern Version of Mr. October
text: BOSTON — They are all scattered now, the legends of the fall of 2004. All except David Ortiz, who welcomed back seven of his former teammates before Game 2 of another World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals on Thursday at Fenway Park. Then he reprised what he did that October.

headline: Video Shows Violent Demolition Standoff
text: A video circulating widely on Chinese Web sites shows the police clashing with people attempting to block the demolition of a hotel in the southern city of Nanning. The police said Thursday that they had fired tear gas and rubber bullets after coming under assault from people throwing Molotov cocktails, according to a report in the Beijing Times.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 8 P.M. (Bravo) STYLED TO ROCK Twelve burgeoning designers compete to become the newest member of Rihanna’s team as they undertake weekly challenges to imagine looks for celebrity guests. The music producer Pharrell Williams, the model Erin Wasson and Mel Ottenberg, Rihanna’s stylist (above left with Ms. Wasson, center, and Rihanna) serve as the mentors. But only half the contestants will be selected to display their designs for the client. In addition to a job with Rihanna, the winner will be awarded $100,000 and a fashion feature in Glamour magazine.

headline: Week 8 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Cowboys (4-3) at Lions (4-3)

headline: Amid New Storm in U.S.-Europe Relationship, a Call for Talks on Spying
text: BERLIN — While President Obama has tried to soften the blow, this week’s disclosures about the extent of America’s spying on its European allies have added to a series of issues that have sharply eroded confidence in the United States’ leadership at a particularly difficult moment.

headline: News Quiz | October 25, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Iraqi Athletes Find a Haven in Beijing
text: For Iraqi athletes, dreams of competing at the highest levels of their sport can be thwarted by the simplest of hurdles, like being able to reach the gym.

headline: Scenes From the International Contemporary Art Fair in Paris
text: PARIS — “Has anything struck you?” an interviewer with a video camera asked an elegant woman in a sea of galleries at FIAC, the French international contemporary art fair, which runs through Sunday. “A few objects here and there,” she said matter-of-factly in French. “They manage to make poésie du rien,” poetry out of nothing.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Oct. 25, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | How to Haunt a House
text: In “House Haunters,” Steven Kurutz visits some haunted houses and talks to their creators.

headline: A Conversation With: Human Rights Activist Sima Samar
text: Sima Samar, 56, is a well-known human rights activist from Afghanistan. A doctor by training, she founded the nonprofit Shuhada Organization, which has provided health care and education to Afghan women and girls since 1989. After the fall of the Taliban, Ms. Samar entered politics and became the country’s first minister of women’s affairs.   She heads the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission, which monitors human rights abuses across the war-torn country and also looks at educational programs, especially for women. She is also the United Nations special rapporteur on human rights for Sudan.

headline: Spectacle Within an Argentine Limousine
text: Myriam Meloni didn’t plan to use a chauffeured limousine to whisk her around Buenos Aires to photograph all stripes of Argentine limo-dweller.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Restaurant?
text: Is there a restaurant you love to visit, whether because the food is fantastic, or because it’s just a familiar and pleasant place to go with friends or family? What is unique about it?

headline: Samsung’s Turn to Apologize to Chinese Consumers
text: While many consumers are debating the price of a latte after Chinese state television accused the coffee chain Starbucks of grossly overpricing its products in China, another global brand has been dealt a similar blow.

headline: New York Today: Obama’s Here
text: Updated 12:20 p.m. | All week long, one Brooklyn high school has been buzzing.

headline: Kenyan Deputy Leader Dealt Blow at Hague
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court on Friday told Kenya’s deputy president, William Ruto, that he must attend most of his trial at The Hague, overturning a ruling that let him be present only on key occasions.

headline: A Woman, Her Dog and a British Sports Car Dream Fulfilled
text: On a recent autumn day, Sue Howard, a sculptor from New Jersey, sat in the driver’s seat of her fully restored 1963 Type 14 Lotus Elite Series-2. Her 6-month-old black miniature poodle, Draper, sat next to her, his tongue lapping at the wind. The day’s drive would be an hourlong journey on country roads to the Performance Garage Club in Frenchtown, N.J., where Ms. Howard houses a neat collection of British sports cars.

headline: North Korea Hands Over Six South Korean Detainees
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Six South Koreans who had been held in North Korea on charges of illegal entry returned to their home country on Friday, after the North released them in a gesture that could help ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Norway Rejects U.S. Request to Help Destroy Syrian Chemical Weapons
text: LONDON — Citing regulatory constraints and time pressures, Norway said Friday that it had turned down an American request to help destroy chemical weapons as part of the effort to dismantle Syria’s arsenal of toxic munitions.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Sets a Price for Its I.P.O.
text: Twitter took the first steps in the pricing of its eagerly awaited initial public offering on Thursday, setting a price range for its shares that was below what some analysts had expected, Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Two Stabbed to Death in Forbidden City
text: Two people were stabbed to death on Friday in the Forbidden City, a vast complex in Beijing of vermilion-painted imperial halls and stone courtyards that is now one of the capital’s biggest tourist attractions.

headline: Raising The Medicare Age, Revisited
text: Back in 2011, we almost had a “grand bargain” whose centerpiece would have been a rise in the Medicare eligibility age. Liberals were horrified, but it actually would have happened if Republicans hadn’t balked at the idea of any revenue increases at all.

headline: A Bronx Start, Then a Life in Israel
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Twitter Aims for $10 Billion Valuation
text: TWITTER AIMS FOR $10 BILLION VALUATION  |  Twitter on Thursday set an expected price range for shares in its initial public offering that was below what some analysts had expected, Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel report in DealBook. The social media company said it planned to sell 70 million shares at $17 to $20 each. At the midpoint of the range, the I.P.O. would raise about $1.3 billion and value Twitter at about $10 billion, excluding options. Including options and restricted stock units, Twitter would be valued at more than $12 billion.

headline: Folding a Neighbor’s Laundry
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Anxious Parent Daily
text: When I was pregnant with my first son, I spasmodically clicked through to every parenting/pregnancy newsletter that landed in my in-box and obsessed over its contents until I was a twisted skein of parental anxiety. These days, I reflexively delete those same newsletters without reading, but that doesn’t stop me from internalizing their frequently fear-mongering headlines and prognosticating doomsday contents:

headline: Editing Microsoft Word Files on an Android Tablet
text: Q. I don’t have a subscription to the Office 365 site, so what’s the easiest way to read and edit Microsoft Word documents on an Android tablet?

headline: How an Indian Stranger’s Blood Saved a Young Pakistani in Delhi
text: I ended up in India, oddly, because I could not get to Pakistan. I had lived half my life in Pakistan. Both of my parents are Pakistani, with family roots in and around the city of Lahore as far as either one could see. But I am a citizen of America. I was born in the United States and had spent the other half of my life living in this country. I was a few hours’ drive from New York when the planes struck in September 2001.

headline: The Tweets That Roared
text: MEXICO CITY — We’ll call it tweet diplomacy.

headline: F.D.A. Bids to Regulate Animal Food, Acting After Recall and Deaths
text: The Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that would govern the production of pet food and farm animal feed for the first time.

headline: In Store | Waris Ahluwalia Opens an Old-World Market in Venice
text: Think of Waris Ahluwalia, the jeweler, actor and man-about-every-town, as a modern-day Marco Polo, bringing back implements of leisure from foreign ports of call: Morocco, Bali, India, Sweden, Lebanon. Next month, he opens his House of Waris Rare shop inside the library of Venice’s lavish Gritti Palace hotel. “I’m not just interested in well-designed trophies,” he says. “Whatever we stock should serve an actual purpose.” He steers away from comparisons to Paris’s Deyrolle or any upscale curiosity boutique, talking instead about revisiting ancient trade routes. In some ways this project is the culmination of a three-year expedition he began with the Luxury Collection, which owns the hotel and commissioned Ahluwalia as its global explorer. Everything sold at the shop — engraved tumblers hand-blown in Murano, vintage Fortuny fabrics fashioned into stuffed animals — is the type of affectionate object one might imagine, say, Ernest Hemingway gifting his mistress. Ahluwalia has stocked the shop with unique goods from artisans both emerging and established, including his own fine jewelry. “You can’t just ogle and awe,” he says about these collectibles. “You must engage as a patron. It’s not just the items that are unique — so too are the people who make them.”

headline: Off the Charts: The Long and Short of Unemployment
text: Long-term unemployment — defined as people who have been out of work for at least a year — remains elevated in the United States, and is also a problem internationally.

headline: For Some, Joblessness Is Not a Temporary Problem
text: MOST Americans who lose their jobs these days are able to find new ones quickly. But those who do not are likely to remain unemployed for a long time.

headline: In Our Pages: October 26
text: 1913 Spanish Cabinet Resigns Office

headline: The Light Touch of Sure Hands
text: It was a few years back that Richard Curtis — the writer behind such artfully accented guilty pleasures as “Four Weddings and a Funeral” and “Notting Hill” — began to mull the Meaning of It All.

headline: Why So Few Women in the Panthéon?
text: HOUSTON — In the politics of national identity, as with the politics of real estate, there are three cardinal rules: location, location, location. Few events better illustrate this truth than the current debate in France over whose earthly remains best belong in the basement of a hulking neo-Classical pile with a fissuring dome and bricked-up windows that looms over Paris — otherwise known as the Panthéon.

headline: Ridley Scott: ‘Most Novelists Are Desperate to Do What I Do’
text: Your new film, “The Counselor,” stars Michael Fassbender as a lawyer who gets in over his head on a huge drug deal. It’s pretty harrowing.  There’s a deep sense of stress that starts about halfway through, and you can’t put your finger on why. When you’re reading the script, it’s like there’s a series of cogs in a very clever clock. The cogs start to engage and — a good word is dread. And the dread sets in, and it stays there.

headline: Ty Tojo's Juggling Act
text: The 15-year-old became the world-record holder in the seven-ball backcross this year. He is headlining Big Apple Circus’s “Luminocity,” opening Friday.

headline: 'Transforming Still Life'
text: Kate Bryan, Head of Contemporary at The Fine Art Society Contemporary on Rob and Nick Carter's painting on exhibit at the Frick Collection, "Transforming Still Life."

headline: Listening to the Roar of 1920s New York
text: In 1929, New York’s Noise Abatement Commission outfitted a truck with microphones and sound recording devices to measure the city’s din.

headline: The 10.13.13 Issue
The Lobbying Lobby Fights Back
text: Batali perfects the martini; Rihanna’s grade-school grammarian.

headline: The Harvard Doctor Who Accidentally Unleashed a Zombie Invasion
text: Roughly two years ago, one of the most popular radio programs in America finally alerted the country to the coming zombie apocalypse. The weekend host of the radio program, Ian Punnett, was interviewing me, a Harvard Medical School physician and national expert on the compelling world of zombie neuroscience. Punnett asked me to help make sense of a new and terrifying threat to our planet, and I told him what I had learned from a discovered manuscript penned by a doctor from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who had succumbed to a zombie plague while studying its origins. The newly uncovered disease was called Ataxic Neurodegenerative Satiety Deficiency syndrome (A.N.S.D.), I explained, and the C.D.C. expert worried that the disease had been engineered by nefarious hedge-fund managers, in hopes that the stock market would plunge and become vulnerable to manipulations as the chaos spread.

headline: Who Made That Coffee Lid?
text: In the late 1970s, when you ordered coffee to go, you usually had to tear a hole in the plastic lid if you wanted to drink through it. This maneuver was so awkward that you risked burning your hand. So in the 1980s, a number of food-packaging engineers tried to fix the problem. William and Kenneth Dart, of the Dart Container Corporation, created one of the first of a new breed of coffee-cup lids, filing a patent in 1981 for a plastic disc with a press-down tab that acted like a valve. The inventors called this feature a “lip-engaging buttress”; you pushed on it with your upper lip to release a gulp of coffee. Once you finished drinking, the tab snapped back into place to prevent spills. (Kenneth Dart, who made a fortune in this and other business ventures, later renounced his citizenship and moved to Belize, where he was exempt from U.S. taxes.)

headline: Does the Golden Rule Hold Up in Modern Society?
text: The Golden Rule (usually defined as “One should treat others as one would like to be treated”) is attractive to people as a guiding principle for ethical conduct. However I feel that in our diverse, modern world, it is less than ideal. By assuming other people should be treated the way I want to be treated, it imposes my preferences and values on those around me. Wouldn’t a better rule be “One should treat others as they want to be treated”? GARRETT FRY, MONROVIA, CALIF.

headline: Hunting a Chimp on a Killing Spree
text: I raised the gun as the chimpanzee inspected a bunch of bananas, close enough that I could hear him softly grunting. Taking aim, I leaned back against a tree to control my trembling. My weight made the giant banana leaves rustle overhead, and he turned to face the noise. He walked unsteadily a few feet in my direction at first, clutching a bunch of bananas to his broad chest. Then he dropped the fruit and broke into a four-limbed run straight at me.

headline: The Past Can Hold a Horrible Power
text: A man returns to his hometown after 20 years abroad. Something is clearly amiss. Neighbors are unaccountably hostile. The family farm is seemingly under siege. His estranged brother greets him with an ax in hand for a reunion rendered all the more tense by a rock crashing through the window.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Involuntary Entrepreneurship’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Israel's Duel on the Sun
text: TEL AVIV — Israel goes off daylight saving time on Sunday, like countries in Europe do. The clock will take a small step backward, but Israel will take a giant leap forward.

headline: Think Back: America's Immigration Debate
text: The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains government efforts to keep immigrants out of the country and links President Reagan’s amnesty for Latino Americans to today’s debate.

headline: Before Malala
text: NEW DELHI — Ever since Malala Yousafzai recovered from her shooting by the Taliban last year, she has been universally honored: As well as a nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize, she has been given everything from the Mother Teresa Award to a place in Time Magazine’s “100 Most Influential People in the World.”

headline: Clearing the Air in China
text: CAMBRIDGE, Massachusetts — IN the northeast Chinese city of Harbin last week, the air pollution was so thick that schools were closed, traffic became gridlocked and flights in and out of the metropolis were canceled. For years, severe air pollution and rising carbon emissions have been downsides to China’s economic growth, even as that growth has lifted more than 600 million people out of poverty.

headline: Seeing You Seeing Me
text: It was her derrière that first caught my eye. Specifically, it was the way the camera captured the pretty teenager’s rear end in “Blue Is the Warmest Color” so that it was centered and foregrounded in the frame. It is a lovely derrière, no question, round, compact and firm, and I became well acquainted with how it looked whether tucked into snug jeans or perched prettily in the air when Adèle, who’s 15 when the movie opens, lies splayed sleeping face down in bed, as young children often do. The director, Abdellatif Kechiche, I realized fairly quickly, likes a tight end.

headline: Dear Mr. President
text: “The Letters of John F. Kennedy,” to be published on Tuesday, includes correspondence to and from Harry Truman, Winston Churchill and Nikita Khrushchev, about nuclear weapons, the Cuban missile crisis and other momentous subjects. It also contains responses like the one Kennedy wrote to a young girl in 1961, which begins, “I was glad to get your letter about trying to stop the Russians from bombing the North Pole and risking the life of Santa Claus.” Martin W. Sandler, the book’s editor, estimates that two million letters came in and out of the White House during Kennedy’s presidency. “Of course I didn’t read two million letters,” he told me in a telephone interview, “but I went blind reading a hell of a lot of them.”

headline: How Did It All Happen?
text: President John F. Kennedy once remarked that “in 1914, with most of the world already plunged in war, Prince Bulow, the former German chancellor, said to the then-chancellor Bethmann-Hollweg: ‘How did it all happen?’ And Bethmann-Hollweg replied: ‘Ah, if only one knew.’ If this planet is ever ravaged by nuclear war,” Kennedy went on, “if the survivors of that devastation can then endure the fire, poison, chaos and catastrophe, I do not want one of those survivors to ask another, ‘How did it all happen?’ and to receive the incredible reply, ‘Ah, if only one knew.’ ”

headline: If Only One Knew
text: World War I continues to exert a powerful pull on the popular imagination, especially in Britain, France and Australia, which, although victorious, suffered much more heavily in the trenches than did the late-arriving Americans. (There is less appetite for remembrance in the states that lost — Germany, Austria, Russia, Turkey.) Its ravages formed a backdrop to the television series “Downton Abbey” and to the movie and play “War Horse,” and they are being recounted anew in a profusion of books tied to the war’s centenary next year.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE OLD WAYS: A Journey on Foot,  by Robert Macfarlane. (Penguin, $18.) Macfarlane’s expansive travelogue takes him from the British Isles to the West Bank and the pilgrims’ paths of Spain and the Himalayas. With a command of natural history, cartography, geology and literature, he tries “to read landscapes back into being” — sailing in the Atlantic and matching strides with footprints made 5,000 years ago.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ROTH UNBOUND: A Writer and His Books,  by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) This clever account is an authorized critical life of the old school, but invaluably topped up with reported comments from the Roth of today.

headline: Inside the List
text: People Person: Brandon Stanton, the man behind the documentary photo blog Humans of New York, has just released his first book — also called “Humans of New York” — and it makes its debut on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. Stanton, a 29-year-old Georgia native, started photographing strangers in 2010 after finding his way to New York from Chicago, where he had recently lost his job as a bond trader. “My mom basically thought this was my glorified way of not working,” he told ABC’s “Nightline” last month. “Like, oh, Brandon’s in New York taking pictures of people on the street and putting them on Facebook, you know what I mean?” That description isn’t far off the mark, actually. But it misses the primal voyeuristic appeal of Stanton’s blog, which only increased after he started interviewing his subjects and including short quotations or anecdotes with their portraits. (“Q. Where are you from? A. Russia. If you see a doctor smoking, he’s from Russia.”)

headline: Twitter Visits Wall St. to Preview I.P.O. Roadshow
text: Twitter’s roadshow may not get under way until next week, but on Friday, bankers and the public got a taste of how the company plans to pitch itself to investors.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color,’ ‘The Counselor’ and ‘The Square’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics discuss the coming-of-age drama “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” the thriller “The Counselor” and the documentary “The Square.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: On Beauty | Two-Tone Eye Shadow, Double the Effect
text: This season opposites attract, as eyes are dusted with complementary colors for a moody two-tone effect.

headline: Morrissey on Morrissey
text: Slate’s Jessica Winter and The Times’s Ben Ratliff discuss “Autobiography,” the new memoir by the polarizing British pop star.

headline: Traveling Players
text: The young performer at the center of Daniel Alarcón’s wise and engaging new novel, “At Night We Walk in Circles,” isn’t the only one acting. The book is full of players and posers, among them a widow who writes to the newspapers in her dead husband’s name and mourners who “performed their sadness flamboyantly, pushing the very limits of realism.” Even the elusive narrator, a magazine writer, is playacting, pursuing a story that is unlikely ever to see print.

headline: Restless Romantic
text: Surprise is the keynote of the best travel writing. The travel writer should be knowledgeable but not an expert, open in mind and body to the unforeseen twists of serendipity. But what we most require from travel writing, as opposed to mere guidebooks, is that elusive quality Nick Carraway defined as “romantic readiness.” Few 20th-century figures combined these traits in a more appealing package than the English writer Patrick Leigh Fermor, Paddy to his many friends, who died in 2011 at the age of 96. One of these was Diana Cooper, a famous beauty who turned up in the fiction of Evelyn Waugh. Now Artemis Cooper, her granddaughter, has written an affectionately intimate, informative and forgiving biography of Diana’s complicated friend.

headline: Her Dynasty
text: For historians, there is no more powerful aphrodisiac than an exciting topic buoyed by a raft of unexploited sources, raising the prospect of a revisionist look at an important figure or even an entire era. There are few leaders in modern Chinese history more layered with prejudice begging to be stripped away than Cixi, the dowager empress who ruled China for almost half a century until her death in 1908. For decades, she was condescendingly referred to in the West as “the Old Buddha,” the “She Dragon,” the usurper of a throne “over whose disintegration she presided.”

headline: Root Notes
text: In Tony Palmer’s film “A Time There Was . . . ,” Leonard Bernstein describes Benjamin Britten’s music as seemingly “decorative, positive and charming, and it’s so much more than that. You become aware of something very dark. He was a man at odds with the world in many ways. And he didn’t show it.”

headline: The Governess and the Ghost
text: Upon the death of her father, bookish, dowdy Eliza Caine answers an ad for a governess position at Gaudlin Hall, a rambling pile in the outer darkness of Victorian-era Norfolk. Eliza — totally alone in the world, her sole companions the protagonists of Dickens, her recent dreams filled with “dark graveyards and irregular vistas” — seems primed for a richly horrifying experience. Arriving soaked to the bone and in the dead of night, the new governess of Gaudlin finds not the greeting of a warm fire and a noble family at its ease, but two eerily well-mannered children alone in an otherwise empty house.

headline: The Reawakening
text: Just give in — I finally did — to the rough-edged charms of Sara Wheeler’s latest hybrid of historical narrative and travelogue. Never mind that Wheeler, a British author whose previous book, “Terra Incognita,” chronicled her adventures in Antarctica, commits the same sin as at least two of the six women writers she profiles: Fanny Trollope, whose withering account of life along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers, “Domestic Manners of the Americans,” infuriated American readers; and Fanny Kemble Butler, whose reflexively judgmental “Journal of a Residence in America” provoked a breach with her American husband. Wheeler seems not to have calculated the effects of her own gratuitous insults, whether aimed at the “agreeable Fatty­towns” of the Midwest or the “crap of contemporary America” she encounters at a once-grand seaside resort community in Massachusetts. Even her praise can be faintly damning: “On the whole Americans are a friendly, polite lot.”

headline: It All Adds Up
text: Recovering from an illness, I sat in my hospital bed reading Edward Frenkel’s book “Love and Math.” I was following along, scrawling equations on scratch paper when my doctor walked in and gazed at my work. “Looks interesting,” he said cheerfully. But when he came closer, he grimaced. “Oh, yuck, it’s math,” he said. “Never was any good at math. I hate it!” Then his smile reappeared. “How’s your bowel?” he asked.

headline: On Guard
text: There are few jobs more toothless than those of museum guards. Their cautions are irksome, their inattention worrying, their reflexes dulled by the uneventful hours between bursts of activity. And yet, although poorly conditioned and compensated, they are called upon to protect rooms full of fragile, invaluable objects. Of those to whom little is given, much, apparently, is required.

headline: Blithe Spirits
text: Metafiction is often more fun to write than it is to read. Everything on the page is the result of a series of strenuous choices, none inevitable, and reminding the reader just who made these choices (whether conscious or not) can be amusing, aesthetically useful and a great relief from the constraints of the traditional conventions of fiction. But intelligent readers may not need reminding, may even take it as an insult. They know who the puppets are and who the puppeteer. They have sought out fiction for a reason: quite often they simply wish the puppeteer would shut up, back away and get on with the storytelling.

headline: Jamie Dornan Named as New Lead in ‘Fifty Shades’
text: The author of “Fifty Shades of Grey,” E.L. James, confirmed early reports that Jamie Dornan, an Irish actor and underwear model, has been selected as the new choice for the male lead in the movie adaptation of her erotic novel.

headline: For 25 Days, Transsexual to the Core
text: Fans of the band Thirty Seconds to Mars, accustomed to the long hair, scruffy cheeks, dark sunglasses and rocker’s rasp of its frontman, Jared Leto, may find him unrecognizable as Rayon, an AIDS patient and transsexual with a drug problem in the film “Dallas Buyers Club.” The waxed eyebrows and concave belly are just the beginning.

headline: 1996 Grand Jury Indictments for JonBenet Ramsey’s Parents
text: Grand jurors who reviewed evidence in the death of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey indicted both of her parents for child abuse resulting in death and being an accessory to a crime.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A one-bedroom in Greenwich Village with a pair of fireplaces; a two-bedroom in Tudor City with a spacious kitchen; and a two-bedroom in a prewar building in Brooklyn.

headline: Martinez, This One a Cardinal, Sets Them Down at Fenway
text: BOSTON — He looked so familiar here, on this mound, this lithe, 6-foot-nothing right-hander from the Dominican Republic, rocking back and hurling his whole self into every pitch, unleashing something fast and nasty toward home plate.

headline: A First-Person Defense of Writing in Jesus’ Voice
text: Sarah Young may be hard to find, but her books are everywhere.

headline: Popcast: Morrissey on Morrissey
text: This week: a paper trail into the heart of Morrissey.

headline: Deal With Union Prevents Closing of Scottish Plant
text: LONDON — One of Scotland’s largest manufacturing sites will remain open following a settlement of a dispute between the plant’s owners and the Unite trade union that preserves hundreds of jobs and provides the facility with millions of pounds in government support.

headline: Developers Return to the Fray
text: They waited out the crash, dialed back their dreams and scrambled back to serve an inventory starved market.

headline: Return to the Fray
text: In a bear market, most developers are not inclined to hibernate like bears as a strategy for self-preservation. Be they a Macklowe, Zeckendorf, Trump or Barnett, their modus operandi borrows from feline superstition: if they have nine lives, they’re going to spend them all building or go bankrupt trying.

headline: France Begins New Anti-Islamist Sweep in Mali
text: PARIS — French soldiers in Mali have begun a major anti-insurgent sweep with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers, the Defense Ministry said on Thursday, calling it the largest operation to counteract a revival of Islamist militant activity since France intervened early this year.

headline: Snowden-Inspired Play to Be Part of Donmar Warehouse Spring Season
text: LONDON — The Donmar Warehouse, which is currently presenting Phyllida Lloyd’s all-female production of “Julius Caesar” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, on Friday announced the theater’s spring season program. It includes two new plays, “Versailles,” by Peter Gill and “Privacy” by James Graham, as well as Brian Friel’s stage adaptation of Turgenev’s “Fathers and Sons,” directed by Lyndsey Turner.

headline: After a Stroke, Running a Half-Marathon
text: Six years ago I suffered a stroke that forced me to relearn how to walk. The other day I ran a half-marathon.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jung Chang Reconsiders Cixi
text: This week, Jung Chang discusses “Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Sara Wheeler talks about “O My America!”; and John Williams has best-seller news. Parul Sehgal is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review
text: This week, Jung Chang and Sara Wheeler.

headline: Dropping a Name (Or, Goodbye, John Wesley Harding)
text: There’s a rich tradition of fake names in rock music. Assuming them is easy: “I’m Elton John now!” “I’m Ringo Starr!” Getting rid of them is much harder: ask John Cougar (who had to ease into being John Mellencamp by slow degrees) or The Artist Formerly Known as Prince about the irreproducible hieroglyph that never caught on.

headline: Speaking to Young Latinos, in English
text: MIAMI — Since 1986, Jorge Ramos has anchored the Univision network’s 6:30 p.m. news broadcast, a vital source of information for the nation’s 50 million-plus Spanish speakers. But this week, his routine will change in a way that could have profound consequences not just for him but also for the American media landscape.

headline: Women on the Verge of a Moral Crisis, as Set to Song
text: Brandy Clark 12 STORIES

headline: Such Stuff as Dance Is Made On
text: Shakespeare, who turns 450 in April, doesn’t seem to have lost any power to inspire creators in every art form. Dance is no excaption. Choreographers have been turning to his plays at least since Jean-George Noverre created “Antony and Cleopatra” in the 1760s, and there’s barely a midlevel ballet company today that doesn’t perform a version of “Romeo and Juliet.”

headline: An Eternal Youth, Now 90
text: “Like everybody else, I think I’m never going to die,” the composer and diarist Ned Rorem said, warming instantly to the subject of a recent interview: his 90th birthday. “That’s sort of an unrealistic answer, and 90 is realistic,” he continued. “Everyone else can be 90, but not me.”

headline: Immigration Poses Threat of Another Republican Rift
text: WASHINGTON — A push to bring immigration legislation to the House floor, led by an unusual coalition of business executives, prominent conservatives and evangelical leaders, threatens to create another schism in the Republican Party and could have a noticeable effect on campaign contributions before the midterm elections.

headline: Image of the Day: October 25
text: A house on the outskirts of Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir, with shell marks allegedly caused by firing from the Pakistani side.

headline: Updates on America’s Persistent Air and Water Pollution Challenges
text: A look at ways to clean up America’s lingering air and water pollution problems.

headline: Can't Go Without: Gabrielle Hamilton
text: Packing for visits to Rome with the chef and restaurant owner.

headline: For Sebastian Vettel, the Coronation Awaits
text: Officially, Sunday’s Formula One race just outside New Delhi is the Indian Grand Prix, the 16th event of the season counting for the series’ World Drivers Championship.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: An 1882 Victorian in Larchmont that’s fully renovated but retains original details; and a waterfront house in Fairfield that includes three fireplaces, two terraces, and a private dock.

headline: BMW Releases Its New 2 Series Coupe
text: BMW announced Thursday details of its new 2 Series coupe models, the successors to the 1 Series cars introduced in 2004. The official debut of the 2 Series will be in January, at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

headline: End of a Line Reflects a Weakened Peugeot
text: PARIS — The last car rolled off the assembly line at PSA Peugeot Citroën’s factory in Aulnay-sous-Bois on Friday, marking the end of four decades of production at the auto plant on the outskirts of the French capital.

headline: Feeling For
text: From a Wednesday Addams-style Peter Pan collar to glitzy jewels fit for a Disney princess, here are some costume staples that will remain highly wearable parts of your wardrobe long past Oct. 31.

headline: Bale Could Start for Real Madrid in Clásico
text: BARCELONA, Spain — The attention will understandably be on the newcomers Saturday, as the Brazilian star Neymar and the Welsh wing Gareth Bale are set to play key roles in their first Barcelona-Real Madrid Clásico game. But while Neymar works his way into the Barcelona attack and Bale eases into the Madrid midfield, the long-running comparison between their top teammates, Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo, continues unabated.

headline: 5 Signs That It’s Time to Seek Outside Help for a Struggling Child
text: The current open question in the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming brought forth some of the most helpful advice I’ve ever seen from a “crowdsource.” I asked, “How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond her years?”

headline: WQXR to Celebrate Polish Music With Online Festival
text: If you’ve been eager to brush up on your expertise in contemporary Polish concert music – a repertory that is plentiful and varied – now is your chance: Q2, the Web station run by WQXR, is presenting “Celebrating Poland: Lutoslawski, Penderecki and New Music Now,” an online festival that includes three 24-hour marathons between now (the first is on Friday) and Nov. 12, to be followed by a concert Webcast on Dec. 13.

headline: Grand Jury Urged Charges in JonBenet Ramsey Case
text: DENVER — Nearly a decade before DNA evidence cleared the parents of JonBenet Ramsey in the killing of their 6-year-old daughter, a grand jury pursuing the case decided to indict the couple on charges of child abuse leading to the girl’s death, according to documents unsealed on Friday.

headline: CommScope, Backed by Carlyle, Has a Rocky Debut
text: Private equity firms have been eager to sell companies to public investors this year, with the stock market on a tear. But on Friday, one company sold by the Carlyle Group had a rocky start.

headline: Big Ticket | A Nascar Star Sells for $25 Million
text: An elegant apartment at 15 Central Park West with treetop vistas of Central Park just outside and a host of sophisticated customizations inside — like a built-in sushi bar in the great room overlooking the park — sold for $25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price for the 3,454-square-foot unit when it entered the market in May was $30 million, and the monthly carrying charges are $7,221.80.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jung Chang Reconsiders Cixi
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Orville Schell reviews Jung Chang’s “Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China.” Mr. Schell writes:

headline: Skills Practice | Making a Presentation on Health Topics, Using the PechaKucha Method
text: Feeling stressed? Can’t sleep? Too much homework? Students the world over complain of these problems, and this week we’ve suggested an exercise that can help them both research some solutions and learn a new presentation skill in the bargain.

headline: Rituals and Restaurants in Rome
text: “On the back of a motorcycle with my soon-to-be husband, who at the time was my secret Italian lover in New York,” is how Gabrielle Hamilton, chef of the New York restaurant Prune, said she discovered Rome.

headline: Inside the Walls of Fez
text: We spotted the craftsman first, alone in his workshop, a cubby barely larger than a closet. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of such stalls in the medina in Fez, an ancient city within a city of winding paths and centuries-old artisanship, where vendors tout their leather and oils on every corner. But this stall stood out. It was nearly bare, not crammed as most of the others were with doodads to be fussed and negotiated over. A few tools hung on the wall, alongside the red Moroccan flag with its green pentagram, and some old photos of the craftsman, now white-haired and wearing a traditional long robe.

headline: Off Ireland, a Rugged Journey to Remote Ruins
text: If anyone can explain why 10,000 people each year make the stomach-churning passage to Skellig Michael, a desolate rock pinnacle eight miles off Ireland’s southwest coast, John O’Shea can.

headline: The Gun Report: October 25, 2013
text: Because the Gun Report is a daily accounting, the details of the shootings we cover aren’t always filled in by the time we publish. So the report is rife with phrases such as “unidentified victim” and “police have no suspects.” In the days that follow, the identities of the victims and perpetrators, and the circumstances behind the violence, are revealed, but by then we’re covering a slew of new shootings.

headline: Competing to Tell Jack the Ripper’s Story
text: Just before 9 p.m. on a recent Thursday in London, five guided tour groups, about 150 people in all, converged on a nondescript courtyard on the eastern edge of the central financial district. Some tour guides wore 19th-century top hats and long, dark cloaks. Others grasped photographs of mortuary corpses. And each guide jostled for the best spot: near the tiny flower bed in the far corner where, in 1888, Jack the Ripper murdered a prostitute named Catherine Eddowes — slitting her throat, slashing her face, pulling out her innards and walking off with her uterus.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘Tell Her I’m Not Here’
text: Obama gets an earful from Merkel on American surveillance.

headline: The Long Trip Into a Dark Season
text: I told myself I wasn’t going to write about any more memoirs, at least not for a while. The act of honoring thy aging father or mother has already generated so many magazine articles and op-eds and blogs and books, including Katie Hafner’s account of moving her mother into her home and Katy Butler’s story of her family’s struggle to deactivate the pacemaker that kept her father’s heart beating while his brain and the rest of his body failed.

headline: When ‘Eat It’ Isn’t the Answer: The Halloween Candy Dilemma
text: I have long been an advocate of a relaxed approach to what some parents term the “problem” of Halloween candy. It’s Halloween, I wrote for Slate in 2011:

headline: Storm Still Brews Over Scalding Coffee
text: Even 21 years later, it’s clear that the case of Liebeck v. McDonald’s hasn’t lost its power to provoke. The Retro Report video about the lawsuit featured here this week has been watched more than a million times on several websites and attracted hundreds of comments, many vehement.

headline: For Cool Autumn Days, Warm Red-Cooked Flavors
text: The Chinese technique red cooking involves simmering meat with soy sauce, sugar and sweet aromatics like star anise and cinnamon. It happens in a wok, but instead of a quick high-heat stir-fry, it is a slow braise, more like a savory stew.

headline: Eat Your Broccoli
text: When my son was younger he was happy to eat broccoli every day, as so many children are. I would steam it and drizzle vinaigrette over it; that was the way he liked it best. But by the time he was a teenager he grew tired of broccoli; he never wanted it, so I stopped buying it. He has always been a good vegetable eater, so I didn’t mind; I didn’t really miss broccoli either.

headline: Plan to Tax the Rich Could Aim Higher
text: Bill de Blasio has made New York’s “Tale of Two Cities” a centerpiece of his Democratic campaign for mayor. “One New Yorker is rushing past an attended desk in the lobby of a majestic skyscraper,” Mr. de Blasio said in a speech at the New School earlier this year, while “a few miles away, a single mother is also rushing, holding her two young children by the hands as they hurry down the steps of the subway entrance.”

headline: Feeling For | Halloween-Inspired Finds You Can Wear Year-Round
text: Halloween is the one time a year when character dressing is O.K. for everyone, no matter what your age. But most style icons are better left to adults than pint-size trick-or-treaters. Wear these modern pieces to pay tribute to Edie Sedgwick, Andy Warhol’s legendary Factory girl; Wednesday Addams, the gothic adolescent with the braided pigtails immortalized by Christina Ricci in the 1991 film “The Addams Family”; and Disney princesses like Cinderella, Aurora and Ariel, those prim leading ladies who always get their happily-ever-afters. As an added bonus, all of these items are perfectly wearable the other 364 days of the year, long after the ghosts and goblins have been put to rest.

headline: The Latest Getaway Holiday? Halloween
text: Halloween is no longer just one night of dressing up and eating too much candy on a school night. Like most holidays, it’s been amplified with a monthlong roster of events aimed at kids both young and old. For travelers, that means sweet deals from hotels and attractions looking to capitalize on those who want to celebrate all things darkly hallowed.

headline: It’s Time to Parse Pole-Dancing
text: Pole-dancing may be a recent fitness fad, right up there with aerial aerobics. But for the Filipina performance artist Eisa Jocson, it’s the politically complex subject at the heart of her one-woman show “Macho Dancer.” The title refers to a form of nightclub entertainment in the Philippines performed by young men for both male and female clients. Ms. Jocson, who has a background in visual arts and exotic dancing, intends to raise questions about gender, seduction and the economics of performance.

headline: From Catchy Jolts to Minimalist Buzz
text: How do you want your jolts? Steady state, like a finger stuck in a socket? Or frantic, angular and quick changing, like a haywire carnival ride? Both kinds are available this week from experienced administrators of their chosen thrills: Thee Oh Sees, from San Francisco, and Melt-Banana, from Tokyo.

headline: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Pink Pompon
text: The pitch reads: “What’s worse than mean girl cheerleaders? How about resurrected mean-girl cheerleaders with supernatural powers?” Find out more at Thursday’s United States premiere of the horror film “All Cheerleaders Die” at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center at Lincoln Center. In this satire of high school horror movies, witchcraft is employed to resurrect the vengeance-seeking cheerleaders who died in a car accident caused by the football players.

headline: Bach’s in His Blood. Beethoven, Too.
text: The masterly pianist Andras Schiff, admired for his elegant and intelligent artistry, is also an insightful lecturer, as he demonstrated some years ago in a series of lecture-recitals on the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas at Wigmore Hall in London. (Audio recordings of those talks are available at Wigmore Hall’s Web site.) New Yorkers will have a chance to hear Mr. Schiff’s engaging commentaries on music when he gives a lecture-recital on Tuesday at the 92nd Street Y. Mr. Schiff will discuss Bach’s influence on Beethoven by comparing Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations and Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations, playing excerpts from both. (8:15 p.m., Tuesday, Kaufmann Concert Hall, 212-415-5500, 92y.org; $62, $25 for people 35 and under.)

headline: Recalling the Wave of Water and Panic
text: As the first anniversary of Hurricane Sandy’s onslaught of the New York region arrives, the Museum of the City of New York, with help from the International Center of Photography, is opening an exhibition of photographs whose size and scope seem intended to rival that of the storm itself. “Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy,” which began with an open call for images, draws on work submitted by more than 900 photographers, “many of whom,” as the museum says, “were personally and profoundly impacted by the storm.”

headline: A Grand Old Name With a Gory Past
text: Investigation Discovery, the true-crime network, has made theme packaging of mayhem an art form, with shows grouping murdered beauty queens, dates that turned deadly or bad behavior involving twins. Its midnight offering to close out Halloween night on Thursday is a classic example: “Bloody Marys,” about murders linked only by the coincidence that they were committed by women named Mary.

headline: The Great Republican Makeover
text: Big news from the Great Republican Makeover: The Grand Old Party has hired a 23-year-old to “reach out” to young people.

headline: No More a Slave
text: Most people who study the Civil War are familiar with the classic autobiographical narratives, written by such luminaries as Frederick Douglass and Booker T. Washington. But there are countless other unpublished works, written by lesser-known men and women who successfully navigated the treacherous path from slavery to freedom. One of these, “Come On, Children: The Autobiography of George Washington Fields, Born a Slave in Hanover County, Virginia,” recently rediscovered in museum archives in Hampton, Va., is a particularly stirring and valuable account of a slave’s path to freedom.

headline: A Menagerie of Music Lives in a Box
text: In the annals of American music in the 20th century, no record label had a more unlikely origin or trajectory than Paramount Records. Founded in 1917 as a subsidiary of the Wisconsin Chair Company, which was eager to supply content for the phonographs it had begun to manufacture, Paramount took a scattershot approach to its business, recording more than 10,000 tracks of blues, gospel, hot jazz, treacly pop, and hillbilly and ethnic music before going bust during the Depression.

headline: Hockney Returns
text: A look at works in a David Hockney exhibition in San Francisco.

headline: Mariel Hemingway’s Smoothie Therapy
text: The first morning I visited Mariel Hemingway — actor, author, activist, granddaughter of Ernest — I watched as she and her partner, Bobby Williams, prepared a smoothie. This is part of her daily routine: because she comes from a family with a history of mental illness, addiction and suicide (a legacy explored in “Running From Crazy,” a new documentary directed by Barbara Kopple), health and wellness and the preventive measures that promote both are at the center of her life — and thus at the center of my article about her in this Sunday’s magazine.

headline: Promised Fix for Health Site Could Squeeze Some Users
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would fix problems in the federal health insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, just two weeks before the deadline to sign up for coverage to replace health insurance policies being canceled because they do not meet new federal standards.

headline: He’s Back, in a Defiant Blaze of Color
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Although it would be hard to tell from the volume of his work, David Hockney, now 76, has had a rough year. Last October, this celebrated British artist had a stroke, which left him unable to complete his sentences for a time. In March, one of his studio assistants in East Yorkshire, part of a tight-knit circle of aides, collaborators and former lovers, died in Mr. Hockney’s home after drinking drain cleaner on the heels of a drug binge. And slowly but surely, Mr. Hockney’s hereditary deafness has progressed to the point that he depends heavily on two hearing aids and still needs to lean in for conversations.

headline: Scene City: Giorgio Armani Day in New York
text: A fashion extravaganza for Giorgio Armani at the SuperPier, with a marathon show, exhibition and celebrity-filled nightclub.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: The Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that would govern the production of pet food and farm animal feed for the first time. Related: Nearly 600 dogs and cats have died and more than 3,600 have been sickened after eating tainted jerky treats made in China since 2007.

headline: For Better and for Worse, Long Before the Wedding
text: Jay Nickerson spent 20 years listening to a friend, the comedian and actress Suzanne Whang, talk about her relationships, silently thinking that she could do so much better than this guy, whoever the guy happened to be at the time. During those conversations, Mr. Nickerson, an actor turned special-education teacher, kept pushing away the nagging feeling that maybe he was the right guy.

headline: Twitter Tantalizes, but Beware the I.P.O.
text: PERHAPS you’ve heard that Twitter is planning an initial public offering.

headline: Giorgio Armani Runway Show Is an Extravaganza of Extremes
text: Fifteen years ago, Giorgio Armani brought a fashion show to New York City with a set and dinner so dazzling that fashion people with long memories still talk about it giddily. And that only happened after the police in Paris, where he had originally planned to show his Emporio Armani collection that year, shut down his production (with a reported cost of $1 million, two black tents and 1,200 guests waiting outside) at the last moment, citing security concerns. Mr. Armani retaliated by bringing the whole shebang to Wall Street, barely flinching at the expense.

headline: How No-Strings Aid Affects the Poor
text: GiveDirectly is an unusual charity. Donors give money. GiveDirectly, well, gives it directly to the poor. It does not tell them how to spend it or when to spend it. And it does not give money to a specific group, like mothers or farmers or the elderly.

headline: When ‘Frankenstorm’ First Caught Our Eye
text: From time to time, the weather-forecasting authorities issue warnings of some type.

headline: A Bachelorette’s Night (or Four) to Remember
text: When Tracy S., a 33-year-old creative agency account director, began thinking about her bachelorette party, she knew getting out of town was a must.

headline: Even More Money Coming to an Election Near You
text: After the 2010 Citizens United ruling, which allowed corporations and unions to overwhelm federal elections with unlimited “independent” expenditures, the courts began overturning reasonable state-specific campaign finance rules — in Montana, for instance. Now it is New York’s turn.

headline: Review: 2014 Acura RLX P-AWS Advance
text: Steering with the front wheels has worked well since the day automobiles were invented. Is 4-wheel steering better? Tom Voelk drives the P-AWS equipped 2014 Acura RLX to find out.

headline: Publishing Executive at Amazon to Depart
text: Laurence J. Kirshbaum, a stalwart of New York publishing who joined Amazon in 2011 to lead its New York publishing imprint, will leave the company in January, Amazon said on Friday.

headline: The Un-Facebook I.P.O.
