text: Normally, the Federal Reserve would work to keep inflation from rising significantly. But during the financial crisis, the Fed has been fighting to increase inflation because falling prices help slow the economy.

headline: In Fed and Out, Many Now Think Inflation Helps
text: WASHINGTON — Inflation is widely reviled as a kind of tax on modern life, but as Federal Reserve policy makers prepare to meet this week, there is growing concern inside and outside the Fed that inflation is not rising fast enough.

headline: Who’s Left?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I never thought I would hear myself say this, but thank the universe for the circles in this puzzle by Brendan Emmett Quigley. Otherwise, I would have been hard-pressed to spot the theme.

headline: Vision of Prairie Paradise Troubles Some Montana Ranchers
text: MALTA, Mont. — On fields where cattle graze and wheat grows, a group of conservationists and millionaire donors are stitching together their dreams of an American Serengeti. Acre by acre, they are trying to build a new kind of national park, buying up old ranches to create a grassland reserve where 10,000 bison roam and fences are few.

headline: The Arguments for Early Childhood Education
text: My Sunday column argues that the United States has a chance to establish a nationwide early childhood education program that would do more than anything to broaden opportunity and break cycles of poverty – but it’s frustrating that the issue barely registers on the public agenda. And President Obama, who proposed the nationwide program early this year and who privately seems committed to it, hasn’t championed it very much in public.

headline: Milestones in U.S. Marijuana Laws
text: Over the last century, the laws relating to marijuana have gone through an evolution.

headline: Man Checking Guns Is Arrested at J.F.K., Authorities Say
text: A Tennessee man was arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday as he was checking in and officers discovered two pistols and two rifles, painted silver and purple, the authorities said.

headline: Bill de Blasio for Mayor
text: The rise of Bill de Blasio, New York City’s public advocate, has been remarkable. In a clamorous primary campaign against better known, more seasoned candidates, he won the Democratic nomination without a runoff, by appealing directly and doggedly to struggling New Yorkers who see a city of lofty wealth rising out of their reach. With the election only 10 days away, Mr. de Blasio is polling so far ahead of the Republican, Joseph Lhota, that commentators have already anointed him leader of a national rebirth of left-wing populism.

headline: A Library of Classics, Edited for the Teething Set
text: The humble board book, with its cardboard-thick pages, gently rounded corners and simple concepts for babies, was once designed to be chewed as much as read.

headline: Gang Rape in India, Routine and Invisible
text: MUMBAI, India — At 5:30 p.m. on that Thursday, four young men were playing cards, as usual, when Mohammed Kasim Sheikh’s cellphone rang and he announced that it was time to go hunting. Prey had been spotted, he told a friend. When the host asked what they were going to hunt, he said, “A beautiful deer.”

headline: Going to the Fair
text: Thousands of spectators assembled to watch a grand procession winding three miles long through Chicago on Oct. 27, 1863. They cheered as columns of police, military companies, civic clubs and religious organizations streamed past. One hundred wagons brimming with farm produce rolled along the unpaved streets. Army musicians played military airs, and marching groups of flag-waving children sang patriotic songs. Spectators jostled to catch glimpses of a carriage draped with tattered Confederate army flags captured by federal troops.

headline: A Champion of the Past Wins a Contest on the Rails
text: One reason chess is so popular is that it can be played anywhere. There is no need for a special field or court, and the equipment is rudimentary and easy to carry.

headline: Serena Williams Pushes Her Limits in WTA Semifinal Win
text: ISTANBUL — For a disorienting hour at the WTA Championships on Saturday, the longest season of Serena Williams’s career appeared to be catching up with her.

headline: In the Funeral Industry, Too Few Spanish Speakers
text: The mariachi band filed onstage, stopping beside the ceremony’s centerpiece: a candle-flanked coffin on display before an audience of funeral experts.

headline: For Both Sides, Time Takes a Heavy Toll on Evidence
text: Christine Greer remembers spending afternoons playing in the West Texas sandhills with her grandmother, who would slide down the hills for hours despite the persistent aching in her arthritis-ridden hands.

headline: Ethics at Fore of Secret Talks on State’s Laws
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Love Affair Between One Artist and Texas
text: The morning before the opening of “The Color Inside” at the University of Texas, Austin, last week, James Turrell, the artist, was pushing melon around his fruit plate and holding forth on the psychology of perception.

headline: College Football Around the Country
text: TYLER LOCKETT The Kansas State receiver, right, caught three touchdown passes in a 35-12 home victory over West Virginia.

headline: Rice Offers a More Modest Strategy for Mideast
text: WASHINGTON — Each Saturday morning in July and August, Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s new national security adviser, gathered half a dozen aides in her corner office in the White House to plot America’s future in the Middle East. The policy review, a kind of midcourse correction, has set the United States on a new heading in the world’s most turbulent region.

headline: Few Problems With Cannabis for California
text: LOS ANGELES — In the heart of Northern California’s marijuana growing region, the sheriff’s office is inundated each fall with complaints about the stench of marijuana plots or the latest expropriation of public land by growers. Its tranquil communities have been altered by the emergence of a wealthy class of marijuana entrepreneurs, while nearly 500 miles away in Los Angeles, officials have struggled to regulate an explosion of medical marijuana shops.

headline: In Response to Storm, New York Will Create a Gas Reserve
text: New York is creating a gasoline reserve to prevent shortages during disasters, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s office announced in a news release on Saturday.

headline: Corrections: October 27, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 27, 2013
text: “If we’re going to play classical music to our babies in the womb and teach them foreign languages at an early age, then we’re going to want to expose babies to fine art and literature.”

headline: Momentum Shifts in Congo’s Battle Against Rebels
text: Until last summer, rebels had the upper hand in their battle against the Congolese government. But the government, backed by the United Nations, has brought new leadership and vigor to the fight.

headline: A Reason for Hope in Congo’s Perpetual War
text: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Rocket after rocket ripped across the sky. By Saturday evening, after two straight days of pitched battle with artillery, tanks and mortars, the Congolese Army had driven the M23 rebels out of the strategic town of Kibumba.

headline: Rodriguez Inquiry Defended by Selig
text: Commissioner Bud Selig said he was satisfied baseball’s investigators did nothing wrong in obtaining evidence against Alex Rodriguez in the Biogenesis case.

headline: Gamecocks Change Passer, and Fortune
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — It seemed like a desperate move. South Carolina was trailing in the third quarter, 17-0, and quarterback Dylan Thompson had looked lost and claustrophobic against Missouri’s swarming defense. So the Gamecocks turned to Connor Shaw, usually the team’s starter, who had sprained his knee a week earlier.

headline: In a Bizarre Finish, the Cardinals Stumble Into a Victory
text: ST. LOUIS — Of all the teams participating in this sloppy World Series, only the one in blue seems at the top of its game.

headline: 3 Dead in Reported Brooklyn Stabbing
text: Three people were killed and three others were wounded in a reported stabbing in Brooklyn on Saturday night, officials said.

headline: 1975 Redux for Red Sox: Do You Agree With Obstruction Call?
text: The Red Sox win Game 1 of the World Series at home, by a lopsided score.

headline: Before Carnage, Frantic Warnings of Relative’s Odd Behavior
text: The phone calls came in rapid succession, each call more frantic than the last, made by a woman intent on warning her relatives that her husband’s 25-year-old cousin, who had been staying with their family only a few days, was not acting right.

headline: Momentum Shifts in Congo’s Battle Against Rebels
text: Until last summer, rebels had the upper hand in their battle against the Congolese government. But the government, backed by the United Nations, has brought new leadership and vigor to the fight.

headline: Chinese Newspaper Apologizes for Articles by Detained Reporter
text: Days after it used its front page to campaign for the release of a detained reporter, a Chinese newspaper has again taken to its front page, this time to admit that the reporter had been paid off to write a series attacking a prominent company. “To all walks of society we hereby express our profound apology,” The New Express, a tabloid based in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, said Sunday in a notice at the bottom of its front page.

headline: Wave of Car Bombs Kills Dozens in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Ten car bombs struck Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, on Sunday morning, all exploding within 40 minutes.

headline: Blasts Fail to Deter a Rally in India
text: NEW DELHI — A series of low-intensity bombs exploded on Sunday in the northeastern city of Patna, apparently targeting a vast rally featuring the opposition leader Narendra Modi, whose Bharatiya Janata Party hopes to unseat the long-dominant Congress Party in national elections next spring.

headline: The Food Writer and Her Picky Eater
text: Some children are omnivorous, equally enthusiastic for broccoli and brownies. Mine, on the other hand, is non-nivorous. For almost five years now, since he turned 2, Harry’s will-eat list has allowed fruit, snacky things, plain pasta with olive oil, yogurt and mozzarella (shredded only, thank you very much), and sometimes chicken. Oh, and hot dogs. His favorite “vegetables”: olives and capers.

headline: A Year of Recovery After Hurricane Sandy
text: Times Documentaries presents “Coming Back: A Year of Recovery After Hurricane Sandy.” A video portrait of four neighborhoods struggling in the aftermath of the 2012 storm.

headline: Coming Back: A Year of Recovery
text: For all the heightened alarm and panicky warnings that a monstrous storm was heading New York City’s way, no one was quite prepared for the deadly lashing that Hurricane Sandy delivered one year ago, on Oct. 29, 2012, to the coastline stretching from Connecticut to New Jersey.

headline: The Choices That Haunt Boston’s Manager
text: ST. LOUIS — If the Boston Red Sox win this World Series, they will not do it here, as they did nine years ago, when they broke an ancient curse and forged a bold new identity. If they lose, the twists and turns of Game 3 will be dissected and debated until the moment they win their next championship.

headline: PPP and Japanese Inflation Expectations (Extremely Wonkish)
text: I’m doing a bit of work on Abenomics, which will surface in a week or so. One thing I discovered along the way is that nobody much likes any of the existing measures of inflation expectations, as this New York Fed post by Mandel and Barnes explains. In particular, the Japanese market in inflation-protected securities is considered too thin to rely on.

headline: Disruptions: Are Eager Investors Overvaluing Tech Start-Ups?
text: Pinterest is a kind of Internet message board where people post their favorite images of clothes or furniture. It’s a three-year-old company and though it has an estimated 50 million unique monthly users, it doesn’t have any revenue yet.

headline: Concussions and the Classroom
text: Because of heightened awareness about the hazards of sports-related concussions, many states have implemented standards determining when an injured student may resume playing contact sports. But only a few states have begun to address how and when a student should resume classwork.

headline: Vows: The Anti-Bachelorette
text: Tequila shots and strip clubs make way for apple picking and pie baking at Katie Dickens's summer camp-themed alternative bachelorette party.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (A&E) THE GOVERNOR’S WIFE Edwin Edwards, now 86 and popularly known as the King of Louisiana for his four terms as governor, and Trina Grimes Scott, now 35, both above, became pen pals when he was serving an eight-and-a-half-year prison sentence for extortion. They married after his release, to the chagrin of his 60-something daughters, Anna and Victoria. This series follows Ms. Edwards, already a mother of two teenage sons, as she tries to get pregnant using sperm Mr. Edwards froze a decade earlier; get along with stepdaughters nearly twice her age; and disarm skeptics who think she’s a gold digger. (Her desire to jump out of a cake at her husband’s 85th birthday party doesn’t help.) “The family feuding is played for laughs,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, “but there is some pathos peeking out of the margins.”

headline: Syria Meets Deadline for Submitting Destruction Plan for Chemical Weapons
text: GENEVA — Syria submitted a formal declaration of its chemical weapons program and its plans for destroying its arsenal three days ahead of the deadline, the international chemical weapons watchdog said Sunday.

headline: In Our Pages: October 28
text: 1963 Buddhist Burns Self To Death at Cathedral

headline: Johnny Knoxville and Latest ‘Jackass’ Movie Are No. 1 at Theaters
text: The vulgarity-loving masses returned to North American multiplexes over the weekend, powering “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa” and its star, Johnny Knoxville, to $32 million in ticket sales, easily enough for first place. This R-rated comedy cost $15 million to make and ended a dry spell for Paramount Pictures, which last released a movie in June. “Bad Grandpa,” the fourth film in a franchise that started 13 years ago on MTV, did not deliver the same kind of box-office euphoria as its series predecessor: “Jackass 3D” took in $50.4 million over its first three days in October 2010.

headline: Of Fact, Fiction and Cheney’s Defibrillator
text: In a chilling episode of “Homeland” last year, a terrorist killed the vice president with a fiendishly clever weapon: a remote-control device that attacked the computerized defibrillator implanted in his chest.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Oct. 25, 2013
text: President Obama was in Brooklyn this weekend to visit P-Tech, a technical high school where students earn a diploma and associate’s degree in six years. WNYC’s Money Talking examines this new model of schooling, which promises to prepare students for jobs in our changing economy.

headline: Lawmaker Offers Strong Defense of U.S. Surveillance Efforts in Europe
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Mike Rogers, on Sunday offered one of the most vigorous defenses of American surveillance activities in Europe, saying that much of the anger and resentment they have engendered were the result of misunderstandings.

headline: Outsider Whose Dark, Lyrical Vision Helped Shape Rock ’n’ Roll
text: Lou Reed, the singer, songwriter and guitarist whose work with the Velvet Underground in the 1960s had a major influence on generations of rock musicians, and who remained a powerful if polarizing force for the rest of his life, died on Sunday at his home in Amagansett, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 71.

headline: Colombia Rebels Free American Hostage
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Colombia’s largest rebel group has released a United States citizen it held hostage for more than four months, Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday in a statement from Washington.

headline: Second Win Has Giants ‘Humble’ but Hopeful
text: PHILADELPHIA — The unforeseen bliss of a two-game winning streak has not exactly gone to the Giants’ heads. On Sunday, in the waning moments of their second victory in seven days, their sideline was not a party zone. The sting of six losses to start the season remained.

headline: The Economics of Rip Van Winkle
text: Binyamin Applebaum’s piece on the growing acknowledgment that moderate inflation can help, especially under current circumstances. But I can’t help thinking, only now they notice? I mean, this was all worked out and carefully explained fifteen years ago.

headline: Growing Giants of the Sea
text: Cruise ships have grown bigger and bigger in recent years as cruising has become ever more popular.

headline: A Lion of the Left Wing Celebrates Six Decades
text: When Irving Howe and Lewis Coser started Dissent in 1954 as a quarterly magazine of independent left-wing thought, they imagined they would be lucky to last a year. Their budget was too small, and the forces against them — both the McCarthyism of national politics and the sectarian dogmatism of the broader American left — were too strong.

headline: The Crusader Leaps Back Into the Past
text: Video games and comic book superheroes ought to be an irresistible combination, like chocolate and peanut butter, pancakes and maple syrup, anger and Dr. Bruce Banner. Instead, comics and games have gotten along about as well as Superman and Kryptonite.

headline: Compositions Created to Be Seen ... as Well as Heard
text: “In the solo concerto musical interest is aroused and sustained on the basis of an opposition between one instrument and many,” Abraham Veinus wrote in “The Concerto,” a 1944 study. “In this sense it has been described as a musical reflection of the everyday and ever-engrossing human drama of the individual lost in, emerging from, and pitted against the multitude.” From Vivaldi’s groundbreaking “Estro Armonico” of 1711 to today, attributes of theater have adhered to the genre.

headline: A Festival That’s Rich in Music but Puzzling in Name
text: The White Light Festival is back at Lincoln Center for a fourth season: another opportunity for music lovers to try to puzzle out the exact meaning of the title. Not that the first classical program — Handel’s little-known dramatic cantata “Aci, Galatea e Polifemo,” performed by Le Concert d’Astrée on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall — was much help.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 28.
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Levée des Conflits Extended’
text: Dancers performed the work by the French choreographer Boris Charmatz, in the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: When the Numbers Don’t Add Up, a Movement Has to Be Left Out
text: Several times this past weekend, 24 people sat in the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art and scrubbed the floor with circling hands. Sometimes they did this in near unison. Sometimes one person did the scrubbing, while the other 23 did 23 other actions: rocking, rolling, running, spinning, leaping. Sometimes 24 actions were happening, and scrubbing wasn’t one of them.

headline: A Long Time Ago, in a Universe More Analog
text: In August, the director-producer J. J. Abrams released a video teaser for his latest mystery project, “S.” Shot in inky black and white, the video featured a strange man staggering out of the ocean, as a narrator intoned, “Who is he?”

headline: Straight From Baden-Baden, It’s Opera-Opera-Opera-Opera
text: “Is reality TV art?” asked the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Rivera, dressed as a Kim Kardashian look-alike in heels and a leopard-print dress, tossing a long black mane while flouncing around the Gerald W. Lynch Theater on Wednesday evening.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 28
text: APPLE EARNINGS Apple has become one of the most valuable companies in the world largely because of the success of iPhones and iPads. But over the last year, the growth of its profit has slowed as fewer people have been upgrading their smartphones each year, and as more competitors have produced low-cost tablets. In response, Apple in September introduced not one, but two new iPhones. When the company announces its third-quarter earnings on Monday, investors and analysts will watch closely to determine whether the new iPhones have given Apple’s profit a much-needed lift.

headline: Cavendish Open Pairs in Monaco Won by Bulgarian Team
text: The winners of the Cavendish Open Pairs in Monaco last week were Rossen Gunev and Ivan Nanev of Bulgaria. In the auction, they went for 14,000 euros ($19,300), and the purchasers received 185,000 euros ($255,400) in return: a 13-for-1 increase. Almost as good was the payoff for the second-place pair of Krzysztof Martens and Dominic Filipowicz of Poland: 110,000 euros ($152,000) for 10,000 ($13,800) paid. Third place was not nearly so profitable. To buy Tor Helness and Geir Helgemo of Monaco cost 52,000 euros ($72,000) and brought in 75,000 euros ($103,500).

headline: Chris Brown Is Charged Again
text: Chris Brown was arrested early Sunday in Washington after a fight broke out near the W Hotel, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Joyce Theater Plans
text: The New York City Ballet principal Wendy Whelan, DanceBrazil and Pilobolus are among those slated to perform on the Joyce Theater stage in 2014. Joyce officials are to announce on Monday that the spring and summer season will kick off Feb. 19 to 23 with Jessica Lang Dance, followed by Brazil Festival from Feb. 26 to March 16. The festival is to feature four contemporary companies, including DanceBrazil, a group founded in 1977 and specializing in Afro-Brazilian movement, contemporary dance and capoeira. From April 1 to 6, the Joyce will host the New York City premiere of Ms. Whelan’s “Restless Creature,” a suite of four duets. The summer season will wrap up with an annual appearance from Pilobolus, based in Connecticut, from July 15 through Aug. 10. The company is to perform two programs, including a New York premiere of a collaboration with Etgar Keret, an Israeli author.

headline: Too Big to Sail? Cruise Ships Face Scrutiny
text: One of the largest cruise ships in 1985 was the 46,000-ton Carnival Holiday. Ten years ago, the biggest, the Queen Mary 2, was three times as large. Today’s record holders are two 225,000-ton ships whose displacement, a measure of a ship’s weight, is about the same as that of a Nimitz-class aircraft carrier.

headline: Celebrity Apologizes for Blackface Costume
text: Julianne Hough (“Dancing With the Stars,” “Safe Haven”) was criticized over the weekend after donning blackface at a Halloween party in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Hiding Within His Own Words
text: “You see, I still don’t really know quite what I want to do,” Leonard Bernstein wrote to a friend in 1939, when he was 20. “Conduct, compose, piano, produce, arrange, etc. I’m all of these and none of them.”

text: Updated, 12:44 a.m. |

headline: Verbal Feedback
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Evolution is inevitable, and perhaps the puzzles are evolving. Last Monday we had a relatively smooth puzzle except for an entry that I would categorize as a non-Monday word (FUMET), and today we have another: PLENA, which has appeared before, but only once on a Monday, and that was back in 1996.

headline: Better Than a Tweet? In Four Characters, a New World of Meaning
text: There is a Chinese idiom that might be used to describe the place of idioms in Chinese literary tradition: jianding buyi (坚定不移), meaning “firm and unchanging.” The use of such expressions, especially the classical set phrases known as chengyu (成语), has long been seen as a mark of erudition in China. Most chengyu consist of only four characters, but they don’t follow the grammar and syntax of modern Chinese, and as many frustrated Mandarin students can tell you, they are often indecipherable without some knowledge of their origins, often in ancient Chinese literature that preceded the birth of Christ.

headline: Lou Reed, 1942-2013
text: Mr. Reed, a disciple of Andy Warhol and of the poet Delmore Schwartz, claimed his niche as music’s eternal New York bohemian.

headline: NATO Reduces Scope of Its Afghanistan Plans
text: BRUSSELS — After months of tense negotiations over the size and role of a postwar presence in Afghanistan, senior North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials say they are planning a more minimalist mission, with a force consisting of fewer combat trainers and more military managers to ensure that billions of dollars in security aid are not squandered or pilfered.

headline: Obama Eases Pakistan’s Worries Over Drones
text: Obama finds a solution to the drone problem.

headline: Marathon as Melting Pot
text: On a recent foggy Sunday in Central Park, a group of runners lingered near the finish line of a half-marathon, recounting their efforts in Spanish. They had finished the 13.1-mile course before many entrants reached the halfway point.

headline: Is the ‘Dumb Jock’ Really a Nerd?
text: In the frequent debates over the merits of science and philosophy, or the humanities in general, it is often assumed that the factual grounding and systematic methodology of the sciences serve as a corrective to the less rigorous wanderings of the humanities. And while many take the position that the humanities can provide their own important path to enlightenment, few argue that considerations from philosophy can or should correct the considered judgment of scientists. Even most defenders of the humanities hold that the sciences are directed at truth, whereas the humanities have an alternate goal, perhaps the molding of ideal citizens.

headline: Georgia Elects New President, but Real Power Will Rest With Next Premier

headline: Blast Kills at Least 17 in Restive Afghan Province

headline: Wikipedia China Becomes Front Line for Views on Language and Culture
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese-language version of Wikipedia has become more than an online encyclopedia: it is a battlefield for editors from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong in a region charged with political, ideological and cultural differences.

headline: NFL Network’s 10-Year Gains: 13 Games and 72 Million Homes

headline: Jets’ Up-and-Down Pattern Holds, and Crumples Them
text: CINCINNATI — It was not the Bengals’ first touchdown that epitomized their domination of the Jets on Sunday. Or their second. Or their third. Or even their fourth, though all were worthy candidates.

headline: The Big Kludge
text: The good news about HealthCare.gov, the portal to Obamacare’s health exchange, is that the administration is no longer minimizing its problems. That’s the first step toward fixing the mess — and it will get fixed, although it’s anyone’s guess whether the new promise of a smoothly functioning system by the end of November will be met. We know, after all, that Obamacare is workable, since many states that chose to run their own exchanges are doing quite well.

headline: Ruling Doubles Paycheck for 1,375 Employees at High-Grossing Queens Slot Parlor
text: Jeannine Nixon looked as if she had hit the jackpot. Ms. Nixon, a customer relations representative at Resorts World Casino in Queens, had just learned that she would be making $40,000 a year, up from $22,300.

headline: South Carolina’s Clowney Savors a Rare Moment of Joy
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Jadeveon Clowney hobbled down the hill leading from the visitors’ locker room here, headphones around his neck, a pizza box in his left hand, a smile on his face. At the bottom of the hill was his family. And beyond them, a few dozen South Carolina fans were waiting behind metal fences, calling his name.

headline: Twitter Prepares to Feed New Hunger for I.P.O.’s
text: When it was preparing to go public in 2012, Facebook kindled hopes that the broad interest in the company would accelerate a slow rise in new stock offerings.

headline: On Way to Wild Final Act, Three Protagonists Have Faced Rough Spots
text: ST. LOUIS — Allen Craig, Will Middlebrooks and Jim Joyce will be long connected by what happened at third base Saturday night at Busch Stadium, by their roles in one of the wildest endings to a World Series game.

headline: Shelter From the Storms
text: WHEN the floodwaters rose around New Orleans hospitals after Hurricane Katrina in 2005, doctors wondered whom to rescue first. Sick babies? Critically ill adults? The elderly?

headline: Data Suggests Push to Spy on Merkel Dates to ’02
text: BERLIN — New details about the monitoring of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone by the National Security Agency further stoked the German government’s anger on Sunday and raised two questions: Why did the United States target her as early as 2002, and why did it take five years for the Obama administration to put a halt to the surveillance?

headline: The Costumes We Choose
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — SALES of President Obama masks at Party City in Augusta, Me., are down this Halloween season, way down. “It’s not that popular an item,” said a sales clerk when I visited a few weeks ago. You’d think this would be a bad sign for the Democrats, but on the other hand, there weren’t any John Boehner or Mitch McConnell masks in the store. The public has spoken: no one fantasizes about being a politician anymore. The most popular costume at that Party City? The minions from “Despicable Me.”

headline: ‘Octonauts’ Series Adds Federal Partner in Ocean Awareness
text: “Octonauts,” the animated preschool series about a crew of eight undersea adventurers whose motto is “explore, rescue and protect,” is getting a seal of approval of sorts from a unit of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: ‘Not One More’
text: President Obama urged Congress on Thursday to revive immigration reform, which is not dead but not moving, either. He was talking mostly to House Republicans, though he also urged business, labor and religious groups to “keep putting the pressure on all of us to get this done.”

headline: Disney Show Will Appear First on App for Tablets
text: LOS ANGELES — A cat in a pink cowboy hat is leading Disney’s television operation deeper into the Wild West of mobile viewing, where it hopes to connect with the company’s core audience.

headline: Why Prisons Are Shrinking
text: The mandatory sentencing movement that swept the United States beginning in the 1970s drove the state prison population up from less than 200,000 to about 1.4 million today and made corrections the second-fastest-growing state expense after Medicaid. But bipartisan sentencing reforms in a growing number of states are starting to reverse that trend — causing the prison population to decline by about 3.8 percent since 2009.

headline: Health Site’s Woes Could Dissuade Vital Enrollee: the Young and Healthy
text: WASHINGTON — Sean Jackson, like tens of thousands of other Americans, has had trouble signing up for medical coverage using the HealthCare.gov insurance marketplace, despite several attempts.

headline: For Extending New York’s Judicial Terms
text: The judicial retirement ages embedded in New York State’s Constitution are a relic of a time when average life expectancy was much shorter than it is today. A sensible proposal on the Nov. 5 ballot, Proposition 6, would modestly extend the age limits for certain state judges and help ease court system backlogs by allowing seasoned judges to stay on past age 70. We urge voters to approve the change.

headline: Game 3’s Decisive Play: Why Call Was Obstruction
text: You think baseball is not intricate? Consider the difference between “interference” and “obstruction.” The dictionary says that in some cases, the words are interchangeable.

headline: A Real Job in Make-Believe
text: It’s called “faking New York” — making a movie or television show in some other city with locales ginned up to resemble the one and only. “A lot of people were faking New York,” says Katherine Oliver, the commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment, looking back over the last 11 years. “They were making a movie about Rudy Giuliani in Montreal! Ridiculous.”

headline: F.D.A. Shift on Painkillers Was Years in the Making
text: When Heather Dougherty heard the news last week that the Food and Drug Administration had recommended tightening how doctors prescribed the most commonly used narcotic painkillers, she was overjoyed. Fourteen years earlier, her father, Dr. Ronald J. Dougherty, had filed a formal petition urging federal officials to crack down on the drugs.

headline: Forging an Art Market in China
text: BEIJING — When the hammer came down at an evening auction during China Guardian’s spring sale in May 2011, “Eagle Standing on a Pine Tree,” a 1946 ink painting by Qi Baishi, one of China’s 20th-century masters, had drawn a startling price: $65.4 million.

headline: Corrections: October 28, 2013
text: NEW YORK

headline: Strong Finish by Williams in Capping a Dominant Year
text: ISTANBUL — Pushing past the lingering lethargy from her grueling season, Serena Williams finished her 2-6, 6-3, 6-0 victory against Li Na in the final of the WTA Championships with a backhand down-the-line winner into the open court, then fell to her knees in relief.

headline: Media Outlets Embrace Conferences as Profits Rise
text: Financially struggling media companies are racing to add conferences, festivals and other live events to their business strategy, convinced they can provide a reliable revenue stream and expand the reach of their brands.

headline: Caught Between Sudans, Region Tries to Pick Side
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Residents of the disputed Abyei region, on the border of Sudan and South Sudan, began voting in a referendum Sunday on which country to be part of. Though the voting was largely symbolic, and likely to be heavily one-sided, it could have very real consequences if it raises tensions and prompts further conflict in an area plagued with violence.

headline: Is Glenn Greenwald the Future of News?
text: Much of the speculation about the future of news focuses on the business model: How will we generate the revenues to pay the people who gather and disseminate the news? But the disruptive power of the Internet raises other profound questions about what journalism is becoming, about its essential character and values. This week’s column is a conversation — a (mostly) civil argument — between two very different views of how journalism fulfills its mission.

headline: Threesome to Tantalize and Behold
text: So just how sexy is it? Oh, admit it. That’s the biggest question on your mind. You didn’t pay all that money for tickets to “Betrayal” because it was written by the Nobel Prize-winning playwright Harold Pinter, the great master of existential dread and the vagaries of memory.

headline: A Tap-Dancer in Training With Hopes as High as Falling Stars
text: “Dancing With the Stars” it most definitely is not. And that’s part of what makes Tina Satter’s “House of Dance,” at the Abrons Arts Center, so very refreshing.

headline: Video Offered to Back Claim of Cairo Attack
text: CAIRO — A little-known Islamic extremist group released a video over the weekend providing evidence that it orchestrated a deadly car bombing here last month, while seeking to enlist others in a violent revolt against the military-backed government that ousted President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: For Many, Free Subway Rides on Anniversary of Hurricane
text: It was conceived as a good-will gesture from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to the subway riders whose lines had been disrupted by Hurricane Sandy: Let R train riders in Brooklyn and A train riders from Howard Beach and the Rockaways in Queens travel without paying on Tuesday, the anniversary of the storm.

headline: Arthur C. Danto, a Philosopher of Art, Is Dead at 89
text: Arthur C. Danto, a philosopher who became one of the most widely read art critics of the Postmodern era, championing avant-garde artists like Andy Warhol and proclaiming the end of art history, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Robinson Risner, Ace Fighter Pilot, Dies at 88
text: Brig. Gen. Robinson Risner, one of the nation’s most decorated pilots in the Korean and Vietnam Wars, who spent seven and a half years in the infamous “Hanoi Hilton” prison after being shot down, died on Tuesday at his home in Bridgewater, Va. He was 88.

headline: Marcia Wallace, Comic Actress on ‘The Simpsons,’ Dies at 70
text: Marcia Wallace, the bubbly comic actress who greeted doctors and group-therapy patients on “The Bob Newhart Show” in the 1970s and burnished the image of jaded, substance-abusing fourth-grade teachers as the Emmy Award-winning voice of Edna Krabappel for more than two decades on Fox’s animated hit “The Simpsons,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: Rare Giants Takeaway Alters Game
text: PHILADELPHIA — Giants defensive back Terrell Thomas saw the football dangling there, like an apple hanging from a limb — said limb being Matt Barkley’s extended right arm.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 27, 2013
Harvard and Harvey Mudd: Both Best Value Colleges, Depending on the List
text: Top ten lists that ranked colleges based on the best value for students vary widely.

headline: If Jews Skip Synagogue and Christians Skip Church
text: How can congregations recapture the many “lost sheep” who identify with a religious tradition but no longer engage with it?

headline: This Time, a Nascar Breakthrough Remains in Full View
text: It took 65 years for a black driver to make it to victory lane in Nascar. On Saturday, it finally happened.

headline: Lists That Rank Colleges’ Value Are on the Rise
text: Looking out over the quadrangle before him as students dashed from one class to the next, James Muyskens was feeling proud one recent afternoon, and why not?

headline: Popular Demand
text: There were 16.1 million desktop and laptop computers sold in the United States in the third quarter — the back-to-school shopping season — up 3.5 percent compared to the same period in 2012.

headline: Skakel Lawyer, in a TV Twist, Is Talk Fodder
text: For two decades, when the tribulations of the famous and the notorious have aired on television, Mickey Sherman has been there to talk and talk: about O. J. Simpson, Martha Stewart, Michael Vick, Casey Anthony, Michael Jackson, just to name a few whose legal cases he analyzed for the camera. When Nancy Grace needed help explaining how a man accused of murder had walked free even after the victims’ bodies were found in his backyard, Mr. Sherman was there, making the CNN studio peal with laughter.

headline: City Drops Bid to Ban Display of Cigarettes
text: A highly contested bill to require stores to keep cigarettes out of sight has been quietly dropped from a package of anti-tobacco measures that would make New York the first city to raise the legal smoking age to 21.

headline: Clarkson’s Homecoming for the Maple Leafs Is Delayed but Hard-Hitting
text: TORONTO — David Clarkson was supposed to be the feel-good story of the summer: hometown boy signs with the Toronto Maple Leafs, the team he grew up idolizing, and hopes to make his mark right away.

headline: Debate Postponed a Day, Out of Respect for Storm Victims
text: Officials have postponed by one day the final televised debate between the mayoral candidates Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota, originally set for Tuesday, after they both unexpectedly requested that the debate not be held on the first anniversary of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Budgets Challenge Libraries, a ‘Point of Integration’ for Immigrants
text: You can always tell what time of year it is by the array of books that greet visitors to the Sheepshead Bay branch of the Brooklyn Public Library. These days, volumes on women’s suffrage, the Constitution and democracy occupy a place of honor in anticipation of Election Day.

headline: Atop Thoroughbred Racing and Remaining Positive, Despite a Painful Setback
text: NICHOLASVILLE, Ky. — Ken Ramsey, whose father was a mechanic and did not advance beyond a sixth-grade education, is joyful and proud as he details his rise to becoming one of thoroughbred racing’s most successful owners and breeders.

headline: Red Bulls Savor Being No. 1 ... for a Night
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls have won nothing. The Red Bulls finished No. 1 over all in Major League Soccer, but the Red Bulls have won nothing. The Red Bulls won the league’s Supporters Shield on Sunday night at Red Bull Arena.

headline: Children, Too, Need Flu Shots
text: Seasonal flu killed 830 children from 2004 to 2012, and 43 percent of them had no high-risk medical conditions. The rest of the children had neurological, pulmonary, cardiac and other serious disorders.

headline: Commuting’s Hidden Cost
text: My twin grandsons, now 13, walk nearly a mile to and from school and play basketball in the schoolyard for an hour or more most afternoons, when weather and music lessons permit.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) SEDUCED AND ABANDONED (2013) In May 2012, James Toback and Alec Baldwin (from left above) spent 10 days schmoozing their way through the Cannes Film Festival as they tried to secure financing for a proposed movie project: a political-erotic Middle Eastern adventure inspired by Bernardo Bertolucci’s “Last Tango in Paris” and starring Mr. Baldwin and Neve Campbell as the characters played by Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider. The men filmed the proceedings — from pitches to billionaires and studio moguls to encounters with movie stars and directors — then turned it into a cinematic romp about Hollywood deal making. “ ‘Seduced and Abandoned,’ which uses split screens much of the time, rambles entertainingly from topic to topic,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “It begins with a complaint ascribed to Orson Welles that he spent 95 percent of his life running around trying to raise money for movies and 5 percent making them. There is hardly a dull moment.” It may be, he added, “the year’s most entertaining put-on.”

headline: Red Sox Top Cardinals to Even Series
text: ST. LOUIS — With the Cardinals down, 4-2, and with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning Sunday, Carlos Beltran, a hitting star who represented the tying run, came to bat. The way St. Louis won the night before, he would surely hit the next pitch to the outfield seats.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/Siena College Poll of New York City consists of telephone interviews with 1,215 adult residents throughout the city conducted Oct. 21 through Oct. 26. Of these, 701 were judged to be likely voters.

headline: De Blasio in Position to Win Mayor’s Race by Historic Margin, Poll Shows
text: Bill de Blasio is poised to win the race for mayor of New York City by a historically large margin, powered by optimism that he will bring about change and by overwhelming voter disapproval of the Republican Party.

text: The New York Times and Siena College interviewed voters throughout New York City about their views on the candidates for mayor and their expectations for the next administration.

headline: New Guidelines on Punishing Child Rape Win Praise, and Criticism
text: A string of cases this year of adults raping or sexually assaulting children has sickened the Chinese public. Last week the Supreme People’s Court reacted, issuing a legal opinion mandating heavier punishments for sex offenders — especially state employees, including teachers, who figured in many of the cases.

headline: Singapore Showcase
text: FIDé Fashion Week, one of the increasing number of style events in this increasingly wealthy city, presented collections by Asian and French designers.

text: 小肯尼·欧文将他父亲位于加州棕榈泉的家变成灵感迸发、异想天开的雕塑公园。

headline: Hopes of Market Reforms in China Tempered by Political Realities

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | War Criminals and the World Series of 1946
text: In the This Land column “A World Away, the Seventh Game; Close at Hand, Condemned Nazis,” Dan Barry writes about the World Series of 1946 and the chaplains who were counseling Nazis awaiting their fate at Nuremberg prison in Germany at the time.

text: It was one celebrated photographer’s salute to another. With war photography in the news, wrote Bob Gomel of Life magazine, how about some recognition for Max Desfor of The Associated Press?

headline: Will You Be Wearing a Halloween Costume This Year?
text: Halloween, a favorite holiday of many, will be here on Thursday.

headline: South Koreans Say They Fled to North Korea for Better Life
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Six South Koreans repatriated from North Korea over the weekend said that they had fled to the North through China in recent years to escape bankruptcies and family troubles in the South and in search of a better life in the North, the South Korean news media and government officials said on Monday.

headline: Spain Summons American Ambassador on New Reports of N.S.A. Spying
text: MADRID — The Spanish government on Monday summoned the American ambassador to address allegations that the National Security Agency had recently collected data on 60 million telephone calls in Spain.

headline: Narendra Modi and the Calculus of Tea
text: PATNA, Bihar — Arun Pathak, a social worker, and his friends have been meeting at a tea stall near Patna University’s College of Arts & Crafts for years. “We’re all regulars here,” Mr. Pathak said, taking a sip of strongly brewed masala chai.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jeff Himmelman on Rickety Boats and Threatening Ships in the South China Sea
text: Jeff Himmelman, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the South China Sea, where a Filipino crew on a forsaken boat is trying to hold ground as Chinese ships close in (the disputed region is home to oil and natural-gas reserves, major shipping lanes and fisheries). His last article for the magazine was on the singer Frank Ocean.

headline: New York Today: Hurricane Sandy, One Year Later
text: Updated 12:14 p.m. | A human chain, wiggly and windswept, formed on Rockaway Beach in Queens on Sunday.

headline: 5 People Killed After Vehicle Crashes at Tiananmen Square
text: Updated, 10:29 a.m. ET | A sport-utility vehicle crashed into pedestrians and caught fire on Monday alongside Tiananmen gate in Beijing, killing five people, including the driver and two passengers, and wounding 38 others, according to the Beijing police and the state-run Xinhua News Agency.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Readies to Meet Growing Interest in I.P.O.’s
text: As Twitter begins an eight-city road show this week to pitch its stock sale to big institutional shareholders like Fidelity, BlackRock and Legg Mason, it will be entering one of the strongest markets for I.P.O.’s in three years, especially in the United States. Despite Facebook’s initial stumble in its market debut in May 2012, investors have shown a growing appetite for initial offerings, eager to take risks in hopes of big rewards when shares of newly public companies rise, Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles report.

headline: In the Shadow of Katrina
text: Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast in 2005, and Louisiana's troubled housing recovery has shaped the response to every major disaster since, including Hurricane Sandy.

headline: After Hurricanes, the ‘Road Home,’ the Long Way
text: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina in 2005 — not the levee failures, FEMA’s infamous trailers or the legal battles with insurers, but the long process of rebuilding homes.

headline: Sheiks and Princelings and Beeznessmen, Oh My
text: Joe Weisenthal tells us who’s buying all those incredibly expensive London residences. It’s not the locals:

headline: Security Firm G4S Rejects $2.5 Billion Offer for Cash Transport Unit
text: LONDON — The security company G4S says it has rejected a 1.55 billion pound ($2.51 billion) nonbinding offer from the British private equity firm Charterhouse Capital Partners for its business that provides armed car and other cash transport services.

headline: A Year Late, S.E.C. Weighs in With 585 Pages of Crowdfunding Rules
text: The day before the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last week to propose rules to implement the crowdfunding section of last year’s JOBS Act, advocates on both sides of the issue — those favoring investor protection and those eager to make it easier for companies to raise capital — appeared to fear the worst. “You’ve waited so long for the shoe to drop that you think it’s never going to,” said D.J. Paul, vice chairman of Crowdfund Intermediary Regulatory Advocates, a trade association for the new industry. “Now I’m just afraid that the shoe might drop on our head.”

headline: AMC Networks to Acquire Chellomedia From Liberty Global
text: LONDON — AMC Networks said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire substantially all of Chellomedia, an international content division of Liberty Global, the media company controlled by John C. Malone, in a deal valued at 750 million euros, or $1.04 billion.

headline: Kasparov Faces Obstacles to Leading Chess Federation
text: Garry Kasparov, the former world chess champion who retired in 2005, is preparing to re-enter the chess arena, and his next opponent may be the most formidable, and strangest, he has faced.

headline: Researchers Draw Romantic Insights From Maps of Facebook Networks
text: It’s not in the stars after all. Instead, it seems, the shape of a person’s social network is a powerful signal that can identify one’s spouse or romantic partner — and even if a relationship is likely to break up.

headline: Goldman’s Charitable Efforts Stoke Tensions
text: Goldman Sachs “wants the world to know it has a charitable side,” DealBook’s Susanne Craig reports. “With the same calculation that earned it a reputation as the savviest trading house on Wall Street, it has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists, giving away more than $1.6 billion since 2008.” As John F.W. Rogers, Goldman Sachs’s chief of staff, put it: “Engaging wasn’t just the right thing, it was necessary, especially in the wake of the financial crisis when people said we weren’t doing enough.”

headline: LG and Samsung Throw a Curve
text: TOKYO — Remember when telephone handsets were curved to bring the microphone closer to your mouth? That began back in the days of rotary dials. The smartphones of today are flat, to accommodate touch screens. But that may be starting to change.

headline: BY THE NUMBERS
text: Giorgio Armani is breezily and busily approaching his fifth decade of design under his namesake label.

headline: By Design | High Season for High Jewels
text: Diamonds may be a girl’s best friend, but next month is all about men designing and collecting some of the world’s greatest gems. The Paris-based Joel Arthur Rosenthal, known professionally as JAR — an acronym synonymous for more than 35 years with ne plus ultra jewels fashioned into spirals, flowers and butterflies — will unveil his first American retrospective, “Jewels by JAR,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. Meanwhile, Sotheby’s will showcase the rarest pieces made by the retired Alexandre Reza, in addition to designs by his son Olivier, with an exhibition, “The Extraordinary Jewelry of Alexandre Reza.” Finally, Sheikh Hamad bin Abdullah Al Thani of Qatar boasts an unparalleled private collection of Indian jewels spanning the past 400 years — from handcrafted jade daggers of the Mughal courts to emerald turban ornaments favored by 19th-century maharajahs — which have been bound into a beautiful tome.

headline: Confronting the Legacies of Slavery
text: DURHAM, North Carolina — Late one afternoon in March, officials unveiled a new monument at the University of the West Indies, in Cave Hill, Barbados. The ceremony featured African drumming, a historian’s lecture, a bishop’s prayer and a song performed by a school choir with the chorus, “We cry for the ancestors!”

headline: The Curious Case of India and China
text: During his recent visit to China, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India said that when the two Asian giants shake hands, the world takes notice. Although the statement stands true, the real question to ask is whether the media and the security and diplomatic community in the two countries make much of this handshake. It can be argued India-China relations comprise a slew of missed opportunities, and these two have added yet another chapter to this narrative.

headline: The Confidence Gnomes
text: It’s kind of sad, but I suspect that half a century from now the main thing people will remember me for — if they remember anything — is the confidence fairy. So maybe I can somewhat package my attempts to debunk the Hellenization of our discourse (pdf) by pointing out that the scare stories seem to involve invoking a related set of characters, the confidence gnomes. (They’re also related to these guys.)

headline: Sounds of Continued Rebuilding
text: After Hurricane Sandy, Kim Spinella and her family spent four and a half months in a motor home parked in the driveway of their Babylon, N.Y., house. A year later, the construction goes on.

headline: The Loss of Accessibility
text: When her one-story Union Beach, N.J., home flooded during Hurricane Sandy, Millie Gonzalez, who uses a wheelchair, moved in with her sister and is now in a home that does not meet her physical needs.

headline: Creepy Uncle Sam Is Back, With More Bad Advice
text: The conservative group Generation Opportunity is back with another creepy Uncle Sam ad attacking the Affordable Care Act. When we last saw the health-insurance-is-evil mascot, in September, he was performing gynecological exams on young women and prostate exams on young men, in an effort to make Americans believe that the government is “playing doctor.”

headline: Japanese Bank’s Inquiry Finds Details of Shady Loans
text: Updated, 7:03 p.m. | TOKYO – The used-car dealers that dot the outskirts of Tokyo and other Japanese cities are an unlikely link between one of Japan’s biggest banks and the country’s yakuza gangsters.

headline: Cardinals’ Roster Feels Two Players Short
text: ST. LOUIS — The Boston Red Sox are one win away from a World Series championship while hitting .205. The St. Louis Cardinals are one game from elimination while hitting .218. No team has allowed more than four earned runs in a game.

headline: Brown Rice Bowl With Oven-Baked Miso-Glazed Tofu, Red Peppers and Kimchi
text: I use the same marinade for the peppers as I do for the tofu in this sweet and spicy mix of toppings. The kimchi is the main vegetable, but if you only want it as a condiment add another vegetable of your choice – steamed or blanched broccoli or greens, for example, or roasted squash, or anything else that catches your eye in the Recipes for Health archives.

headline: Farro or Bulgur With Black-Eyed Peas, Chard and Feta
text: Black-eyed peas cooked with greens is a classic Greek preparation. I decided to add a chile pepper to the beans, just to spice things up a little. I like to serve the beans with bulgur, but you can also serve them with farro.

headline: Israel Agrees to U.N. Human Rights Review
text: GENEVA — Israel will participate in a review of its human rights record at the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva on Tuesday, a decision announced after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ended the country’s 18-month boycott of the council.

headline: Red Rice or Farro With Miso-Roasted Squash, Leeks, Red Pepper and Tofu
text: Tofu, red peppers, leeks and winter squash all benefit from the same sweet/salty marinade in this dish. The squash sweetens as it roasts and is irresistible. I recommend that you roast more than the recipe calls for because it makes a delicious snack. The vegetables look pretty against a tawny grain like red rice or farro.

headline: Millet Polenta With Tomato Sauce, Eggplant and Chickpeas
text: Millet polenta is as comforting as it gets. In season you can use fresh tomatoes in the topping, but canned will work just fine. You could also make this dish with cornmeal polenta.

headline: Millet Polenta With Mushrooms and Broccoli or Broccoli Raab
text: I had envisioned serving this savory mix of mushrooms over a bowl of farro, and farro – or brown rice or barley, for that matter – would certainly work well. But I made the mushrooms on the same day that I made the polenta in Millet Polenta With Tomato Sauce, Eggplant and Chickpeas and ended up spooning them over the millet, which was so delicious and comforting that I voted on the polenta as the accompanying grain. Cornmeal polenta would also work well.

text: Readers who had been affected by Hurricane Sandy shared stories of frustrations and silver linings, offering glimpses at the physical, financial and emotional impact that remains.

headline: Indian Officials Say Outlawed Militant Group Is Behind Patna Blasts
text: NEW DELHI — Investigators believe that Indian Mujahedeen, an outlawed Islamic group, was behind a series of explosions on Sunday that killed at least six people and disrupted a huge political rally in Patna, a senior official said Monday.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Prankvertising’

headline: Calculus Made Easy
text: Updated, 8:56 a.m. | In addition to covering our weekly brain benders, we’d like to open Numberplay to students or teachers who might be learning certain math concepts for the first time, or who might be looking for inspiration when teaching them. We’d also like to hear from those who have questions about “numbers in the news.” Please send your math questions or questions about how to understand math-based articles in The New York Times to gary.antonick@nytimes.com, with the subject heading “Numberplay question”. Selected concepts and suggestions will be covered at a future date.

headline: Fleetwood Mac Cancels Tour as John McVie Undergoes Cancer Treatment
text: Fleetwood Mac announced on its Facebook page on Sunday that it was canceling a monthlong, 14-concert tour of New Zealand and Australia, set to start Nov. 10, because its bassist, John McVie, was scheduled to undergo cancer treatment during that period. The statement did not say what form of cancer the 67-year-old Mr. McVie had, and Liz Rosenberg, the group’s spokeswoman, said she had no further information.

headline: A Trophy Thief Goes for the Gold
text: As far as heists go, the disguise was cartoonish — the thief was swaddled like a ninja from head to toe. His method was neither high-tech nor elegant — he kicked in doors and smashed glass cases. But his taste was impeccable, and sporting: his haul included the 1903 Belmont Stakes trophy, a silver Fabergé soup tureen and ladle given by Czar Nicholas II of Russia to an American harness horse impresario and the United States Amateur Championship trophy that completed golfer Bobby Jones’s Grand Slam in 1930.

headline: The Wicked War in the West
text: At reunions held years after the Civil War ended, Confederate veterans of the Trans-Mississippi Theater liked to tease their Eastern comrades about one of their most treasured expeditions. “Jeb Stuart’s ride around McClellan?” they roared, “Hell, brother, Jo Shelby rode around Missouri!”

headline: In Fashion | Minimalist Dressing Made Simple

headline: Weekend Gun Report: October 25-27, 2013
text: Keenan A. Draughon, 23, of Clarksville, Tenn., was arrested at Kennedy International Airport in New York on Saturday when officers discovered a shotgun, two pistols and two rifles as he was checking in for his flight to Charlotte, N.C. Draughon approached a United Airlines counter and told an attendant that he had two cases containing firearms—two 9-millimeter pistols, two magazines capable of holding 15 rounds of 9-millimeter ammunition, and two .22-caliber rifles. The rifles had been painted purple and silver, and one of them had a round in the chamber. Both were missing serial numbers.

headline: Prisoner Release Stirs Anger in Israeli Coalition
text: JERUSALEM — The fractured politics of Israel’s governing coalition were spotlighted on Monday ahead of a second release of Palestinian prisoners that was agreed to as part of peace talks brokered by the United States.

headline: Walkabout: A Dubai Airport’s Outsize Ambition; Ellis Island, Still Wounded, Reopens
text: Sizing Up Though it’s still years away from completion, Al Maktoum International Airport in Dubai expects to become world’s largest airport. Currently operating just one runway, Al Maktoum plans to ultimately operate five runways with an annual capacity of 160 million passengers. (CNN)

headline: Another Way Samsung Can Copy Apple
text: Here’s one idea that Samsung could safely copy from Apple: As a proportion of its $221 billion market capitalization, the South Korean giant’s near $40 billion cash pile is almost as big as that of its American archrival. With its reserves accumulating quickly, it can afford to mimic Apple by giving more to investors.

headline: As Landlord of Brooklyn Duplex, de Blasio Gets High Approval Ratings
text: Many labels have been hauled out in the parlor game of pigeonholing Bill de Blasio, New York City’s potential mayor-to-be.

headline: Conquering Fears, Without Drinking the Samples
text: I LOVE airports, hotels and anything involving getting from Point A to Point B. But it wasn’t always like that. When I first started out with Belvedere Vodka more than 10 years ago, business travel involved jumping on a train and going to places like Cambridge, Bristol or Exeter to talk to anyone who would listen to me talk about Belvedere. After two years, I guess you could say I graduated from only traveling by train in Britain to traveling by plane throughout Europe and eventually to the Americas, and every place else in the world.

headline: Mitsubishi, Audi and Ford to Recall Vehicles for Various Problems
text: Mitsubishi, Audi and Ford will recall vehicles for a variety of problems, according to reports posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s website. The agency is also investigating fires in Jeep Liberty models and sunroofs that shatter on Kia Sorentos.

headline: A Dubai Hotel With Villas Over the Water
text: Anantara Hotels, Resorts & Spas, the upscale Bangkok-based chain, opened its first location in Dubai last month, the Anantara Dubai The Palm Resort & Spa.

headline: Goldman, Feeling Robbed, Still Has to Pay for Accused’s Defense
text: A victim of a crime would never be expected to pay for the perpetrator’s lawyer to defend the case. But corporate law can be counterintuitive, and Goldman Sachs found itself on the wrong side of a court decision that found that the bank’s bylaws require it to advance the legal fees of a former employee who has been accused of stealing its computer code.

headline: It’s Hunting Time in France
text: Autumn signifies the opening of the six-month season, when chefs compete to transform quarry into gastronomic bliss.

headline: Consol to Sell 5 Coal Mines to Murray
text: Consol Energy, the largest coal producer in the eastern United States, said on Monday that it was selling five highly automated mines — about half of its production capacity — to focus instead on natural gas and on mines that produce coal for export.

headline: Turning the Hunt Into a Trip to the Market
text: PARIS — The chef Alain Dutournier was so excited about the first game meat of the season that he transformed the reception area of Carré des Feuillants, his two-Michelin-star restaurant, into a still life.

headline: Speeding Up Gmail Delivery
text: Q. My Gmail on Firefox has gotten really slow lately and sometimes I can’t see attachments. I don’t think it’s my network connection and I still have plenty of space left in my mailbox, so what might be causing the pokiness?

headline: Will Sandy’s Lessons Fade as a Sleepy Atlantic Storm Season Ends?
text: With the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy’s coastal assault here, The New York Times and other media have run a batch of helpful articles tracking how coastal communities are, and are not, responding to the lessons from the extraordinary surge raised by that storm — a 1-in-700-year event, by some calculations.

headline: Germaine Greer’s Archives Are Sold to the University of Melbourne
text: Dead trees will help subsidize live ones, thanks to a deal recently reached by the feminist author Germaine Greer to sell her archives to the University of Melbourne, with proceeds donated to rainforest rehabilitation efforts in Australia.

headline: A.D.H.D. Medication Is a Hit for Red Sox Hero
text: Shane Victorino has it all. He is a member of a Boston Red Sox team that is two victories away from a World Series title. He has a championship ring (won with the Philadelphia Phillies in 2008), three Gold Glove awards, and a yearly income of over $6 million. He has a beautiful wife and two insanely adorable children. He has the undying love of Boston sports fans, after hitting a pennant-clinching grand slam that sent the Red Sox to the World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: Judicial Neglect
text: MURMANSK, RUSSIA — The 30 Greenpeace activists who are in jail here and the large group of volunteers who are organizing their legal and humanitarian aid got their first ray of hope in a month on Oct. 21 when the Netherlands filed a claim in the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea. The Dutch government demanded that Russia release the Greenpeace ship, “Arctic Sunrise,” which had flown the Dutch flag. The ship was seized in international waters and escorted to the port of Murmansk, where the crew and passengers from 18 different countries have been held since Sept. 24. And now, their supporters hoped, the tribunal would order them released.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Florida; Turkey; and Wisconsin
text: Sarasota Chalk Festival, Florida More than 500 artists will contribute works to a street gallery in Sarasota that will eventually vanish. This year, participants will use pastel chalk to create images along the pavement on a patriotic “Legacy of Valor” theme (above, chalk work by Valentina Sforzini). The free event, from Nov. 13 to 18, also features musical performers, an area devoted to children’s works and a vertical gallery of street art on approved walls and other surfaces.

headline: Student Uncovers Baby Dinosaur Specimen
text: At first, the bone didn’t look like much. “But when we walked around to the other side, we saw the skull,” Kevin Terris said. “We figured the whole skeleton must be there, or at least a good portion of it.”

headline: Lawyers Challenge Judges’ Authority in Trial of Chinese Activists
text: HONG KONG — A court in eastern China adjourned the trial of three human rights activists on Monday after their lawyers unsuccessfully challenged the authority of the judges to hear the case, according to two of the lawyers and a daughter of one of the defendants.

headline: Penn State to Pay Nearly $60 Million to 26 Abuse Victims
text: Penn State has agreed to pay $59.7 million to 26 sexual abuse victims of the former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky in exchange for an end to their claims against the university, Penn State announced Monday.

headline: Uganda’s Neglected Epidemic of Breast Cancer
text: KAMPALA, UGANDA — Dr. Henry Ddungu held the hand of a thin, frail-looking woman as he led her into the outpatient clinic at the Uganda Cancer Institute. Scowling, he said, “we are having an epidemic of breast cancer and pain.”

headline: A Premium Brand Reaches Out to the Discerning Vodka Fan
text: Belvedere Vodka, the Polish premium brand, has introduced its largest global ad campaign, with new television spots that stress its knowledgeable fans, composition and distillation process.

headline: Giorgio Armani’s Dolce Vita
text: It is one of the fashion industry’s more epic feats of longevity that Giorgio Armani is breezily approaching his fifth decade of design under his namesake label. But you don’t create a multibillion dollar empire that spans clothes, home décor, hotels, restaurants and even the silver screen without raising a few eyebrows. After all, this is the man responsible for shifting the boundaries of permissible images of male eroticism with Richard Gere’s wardrobe in “American Gigolo,” and for helping to define the prowess of grab-and-greed 1980s power-suit dressing for women — which, by extension, has become the uniform of choice for Hollywood honchos, Wall Street bigwigs and red-carpet mainstays to this day. But as is the Armani M.O., all epoch-making moments appear as effortless as his signature bronzed physique and glowing white smile.

headline: Netflix to Add ‘Dexter’ in Deal With CBS Corp.
text: Netflix continues to sweep up high-profile television shows for its online subscription service, completing a deal Monday for “Dexter,” which has been the biggest hit series so far for the Showtime network.

headline: The Perils of Ascribing Meaning to a Random Event
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

headline: Robotic Crowd Pleasers of the Past
text: They could talk, sing, smoke, shoot guns — early humanoid robots were created in our image, but without anything close to the technology needed to be truly autonomous.

headline: The Automatons of Yesteryear
text: The metallic monster had slanted, yellow eyes, skin like a suit of armor, and the halting, unsteady movements of one of Frankenstein’s creations. On a bright September day in 1928, a curious crowd of onlookers got their first glimpse of Eric the Robot. The mechanical man rose from his chair, stretched out an arm for silence, and made a speech, of which few people understood more than a few words. In a special cable to The New York Times, one reporter remarked on the event, held at the exhibition of the Model Engineer’s Society of London: “Of all orators, Eric seemed the coldest and most lacking in magnetism.”

headline: Star Withdraws From Lyric Opera’s ‘Otello’
text: The South African tenor Johan Botha has withdrawn from the Lyric Opera of Chicago’s production of Verdi’s “Otello” because of what the company described as “severe back pain caused by a previous injury.” He has gone to Vienna for treatment.

headline: Humanoid Robots
text: Fully programmable robots were on display at the Humanoids 2013 conference in Atlanta. The goal is to enable them to work effectively and even autonomously in emergency situations.

headline: Entering a New Era of Robots
text: In a shift away from strictly industrial use, they are being designed to collaborate with, and even look like, human beings.

headline: For Lou Reed’s Chefs, a Walk on the Mild Side
text: For a handful of chefs and restaurateurs in downtown Manhattan, Lou Reed, the iconic New Yorker and rock pioneer who died of liver disease on Sunday at age 71, was more than just the man associated with songs like “Heroin,” “Sweet Jane” and “Satellite of Love.” He was a devoted customer, and they spent years trying to keep him in good health.

headline: Making Robots More Like Us
text: On a recent morning Natanel Dukan walked into the Paris offices of the French robot maker Aldebaran and noticed one of the company’s humanoid NAO robots sitting on a chair. Mr. Dukan, an electrical engineer, could not resist. Bending over, he kissed the robot on the cheek. In response the NAO tilted its head, touched his cheek and let out an audible smack.

headline: Danny Bowien’s Mission Cantina Opens Soon
text: During four days in Mexico City last summer, Danny Bowien and his chefs, Angela Dimayuga and Zach Swemle, ate in 35 restaurants. Call it homework for Mission Cantina, the Mexican restaurant they’re opening in three weeks on the Lower East Side.

headline: Chamber Music Society Will Summer in Saratoga Springs
text: Saratoga Springs has long drawn summer visitors with the promise of thoroughbred racing, and, more recently, performances by the Philadelphia Orchestra and New York City Ballet at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center. This summer it will add a new attraction: the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center announced Monday that it would become the resident chamber music ensemble at the performing arts center, with a three-week chamber music festival planned for August.

headline: Japanese Autos Lose Ground in Consumer Reports’ Reliability Ratings
text: After results of Consumer Reports Annual Auto Reliability ratings were released on Monday, there appeared to be a crack in the dominance of Japanese brands over automotive reliability. Two of America’s most popular cars, the V-6-equipped Honda Accord and the Nissan Altima, no longer have the consumer advocacy publication’s coveted “Recommended” rating, according to the report.

headline: Wynton Marsalis to Lead Jazz Studies at Juilliard
text: The Juilliard School has appointed the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis director of its jazz studies program. Mr. Marsalis, who is the managing and artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center — and a Juilliard alumnus — officially takes up the appointment on July 1, but will actually start a few months earlier, overseeing spring auditions for the school’s fall 2014 class. He succeeds Carl Allen, the program’s director since 2008.

headline: Ex-Prison Chief Guilty Amid Cases Against Georgian Officials
text: TBILISI, Georgia — In the first major conviction to result from a string of prosecutions of former high-level officials in the Georgian government, a judge on Monday found a former head of the country’s prison system guilty of abuse of power in connection with the deaths of seven inmates in a prison riot.

headline: Neglected Diseases Still Are, Well, Neglected
text: Despite much progress in the last 35 years, a new study has found that major gaps persist in the effort to prevent and treat the “neglected diseases” of the poor.

headline: Judge in Texas Partly Rejects Abortion Law
text: A federal judge in Texas on Monday blocked an important part of the state’s restrictive new abortion law, which would have required doctors performing the procedure to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.

text: A computer algorithm used to identify songs can also identify the signature whistles of bottlenose dolphins, a new study reports.

headline: Powerful Storm Lashes Northern Europe, Paralyzing Travel in Much of Britain
text: LONDON — One of the most powerful storms in Europe in years left at least 13 people dead, hundreds of thousands without power and many stranded on Monday when trains, planes and ferries were canceled after high winds battered the northern part of the Continent.

headline: Charges of Racial Profiling in Manhattan Stores Deserve Attention in The Times
text: Reports about racial profiling at Barneys New York, the upscale store, have appeared in The Detroit News, The Las Vegas Review-Journal, USA Today and other newspapers throughout the nation and world, but not in the pages of The Times – despite the store’s location in Manhattan.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Richard Meier and Tavi Gevinson
text: Richard Meier, the Pritzker Prize-winning architect who created the Getty Center in Los Angeles and the Jubilee Church in Rome, and Tavi Gevinson, the Chicago-based fashion blogger and actress, take on Ari Seth Cohen’s new book, David Chipperfield’s design for Museo Jumex and diamond earphone covers.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Wins His Fourth Consecutive World Championship
text: Sebastian Vettel, the Red Bull Infiniti driver, clinched his fourth consecutive Formula One championship with a victory Sunday in the Indian Grand Prix at the Buddh International Circuit near New Delhi. Vettel now joins Juan Manuel Fangio and Michael Schumacher as the only drivers to win four titles in a row. (Alain Prost won four, although not consecutively.) Fangio ultimately won five titles, while Schumacher went on to collect an unparalleled seven.

headline: An Insect? For Me? You Shouldn’t Have
text: When mating, some male nursery-web spiders offer their female companions a nuptial gift: an insect wrapped in white silk. Now researchers in Europe and South America have found an evolutionary basis for the practice: females were more likely to store sperm from gift-giving males, and their eggs were more likely to hatch. No wonder the spider, Pisaura mirabilis, has evolved in favor of generosity: more presents seem to mean more spiders.

headline: Now, a Kiss Isn’t Just a Kiss
text: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives with a helpful tip for Smarter Living.

headline: Search for Atypical Yields Diverse Program
text: The American Composers Orchestra started its Orchestra Underground series a decade ago to showcase works incorporating eclectic influences, unusual instruments and multimedia components. The lineup on Friday evening at Zankel Hall honored that mission with four recent, diverse pieces.

headline: Apple’s Profit Falls Despite Higher Sales of iPhones
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple now has more product offerings. And Apple now sells its products in more places. But for the third consecutive quarter, Apple does not have more profit.

headline: Picasso Museum Makeover Drags On
text: PARIS — Metal scaffolding laces across a regal 17th-century building in the historic Marais district here. Home to the world’s largest collection of works by Pablo Picasso, the building has been closed because of renovations for the last four years.

headline: Seeking Inspiration, to Be Served Well Chilled
text: Dancing on ice skates isn’t easy. At the Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers on Friday, the distinguished Canadian ballerina Sonia Rodriguez performed at a gala in her honor. Wearing ballet slippers, she had to be carried by three male skaters, who passed her around as she danced through the air with prettily pointed feet. Then they left her stranded on a bench.

text: BUENOS AIRES — After a decade of family rule in Argentina, the political tenor has begun to change.

text: Hidden in Tumblr’s bottomless trove of illustrated quotations, posts debunking falsely attributed illustrated quotations, pornography and obsessively composed photos of huckleberry muffins, is a blog written by a twelve-year-old from the Bronx named Aaron Philip.
