headline: BP Increases Its Dividend as Earnings Beat Forecasts
text: LONDON — The British oil company BP said on Tuesday that its profit for the third quarter, adjusted for one-time items, was $3.7 billion. That was down 26 percent from the period a year earlier, but exceeded analysts’ forecast.

headline: Business Owners Weigh Their (Often Frustrating) Software Options
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about the pros and cons of various software solutions.

headline: Intersection: The Warsaw Way
text: In Poland’s Savior Square, Martina Matwiejczuk, a singer, displays her elegant nonchalant style through mixing simple and avant-garde pieces.

headline: ‘Dancing in the Moonlight,’ Three Ways:  Thin Lizzy, King Harvest and the Tallest Man on Earth
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Obama May Ban Spying on Heads of Allied States
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is poised to order the National Security Agency to stop eavesdropping on the leaders of American allies, administration and congressional officials said Monday, responding to a deepening diplomatic crisis over reports that the agency had for years targeted the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.

headline: Matthew Barney Film in the Lineup at Australia Arts Festival
text: Isabella Rossellini, John Zorn and Matthew Barney are among the artists on the program at the 2014 Adelaide Festival, Australia’s biggest culture event, which will run from Feb. 28 to Mar. 16 next year. The festival, founded in 1960, was a biennial event until last year, when David Sefton, the British-born former director of UCLA Live performing arts series, became its artistic director.

headline: Transforming an Island House, and Ourselves
text: It started a few years back during my ill-fated 50th birthday getaway to Vieques Island, just off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico. When the puddle jumper touched down on the island’s minuscule runway and my partner, Michael, and I emerged from the plane into the fragrant heat, several months of winter dreariness melted away.

headline: Are You Competent? Prove It.
text: IN 1893, Charles Eliot, president of Harvard, introduced to the National Education Association a novel concept: the credit hour. Roughly equivalent to one hour of lecture time a week for a 12- to 14-week semester, it became the basic unit of a college education, and the standard measure for transferring work between institutions. To be accredited, universities have had to base curriculums on credit hours and years of study. The seat-time system — one based on the hours spent in the classroom — is further reinforced by Title IV student aid: to receive need-based Pell grants or federal loans, students have had to carry a certain load of credits each semester.

headline: In Performance: Kristen Sieh and Libby King of ‘RoosevElvis’
text: In the surreal new dramedy “RoosevElvis,” Ann (Libby King), a lesbian factory worker in South Dakota, channels the spirit of Elvis Presley to help her work up the courage to ask out Brenda (Kristen Sieh), a woman she meets online. But when their first date doesn’t go well, Ann imagines Brenda as Theodore Roosevelt as a way to keep her spirit close. In this scene, Elvis and Roosevelt introduce themselves. The show, directed by Rachel Chavkin and mounted by the theater collective the TEAM, is at the Bushwick Starr through Nov. 3.

headline: The Latest Style
text: This week, we’ve introduced a number of updates and revisions to our in-house stylebook, The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage. The changes are mostly modest and don’t alter our goal of publishing clear, literate prose that is largely free of jargon, journalese, slang and sloppiness. But a lot has changed since 1999, when the stylebook was published. While we have updated many entries over the years, we thought it was time for a more systematic look. (For now, the updated style guide is available only to Times writers and editors. But we hope that the revised version may be published for general readers in the foreseeable future.)

headline: Reining in the N.S.A.
text: America has created a surveillance monster.

headline: India Raises Interest Rate to Battle Inflation
text: MUMBAI — India’s central bank announced on Tuesday a number of changes to its interest rate policies, continuing efforts to contain inflation while rolling back currency stabilization measures put in place in July to prop up the weakening Indian rupee. The bank also warned that inflationary pressures were unlikely to abate in the near future.

headline: Cellphone-Hater in the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Wide Open Era in 3-D Printing
text: SINGAPORE — For a 15-person start-up in 3-D printing — a nascent industry at best — Pirate3D has the hallmarks of a much bigger tech company. These include big funding, large expectations, unforeseen price increases, expanded distribution and serious trash talking.

headline: For Once-Mighty Sears, Pictures of Decay
text: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | When Brian Sozzi, the chief executive of Belus Capital Advisors, visited Sears locations in New York and New Jersey this month, he said, he found barren shelves, haphazard displays and badly stained carpets.

headline: Amid Debate, Turkey Unveils Rail Tunnel Under Bosporus
text: ISTANBUL — With its skyline stitched by minarets and its soul straddling the Bosporus waterway, this city has long defined itself as geography’s junction between East and West, where the European landmass meets the Anatolian steppe and cultures intertwine.

headline: In Smartphone Sales, the Big Get Bigger
text: TOKYO — The two biggest smartphone rivals, Samsung Electronics and Apple, can each find reasons to cheer about industry sales numbers reported this week.

headline: Dutch Bank Settles Case Over Libor Deceptions
text: Updated, 8:37 p.m. | The Dutch lender Rabobank admitted on Tuesday to criminal wrongdoing by its employees and agreed to pay more than $1 billion in criminal and civil penalties to settle investigations by United States, British and other authorities into its role in setting global benchmark interest rates. Its chief executive stepped down immediately.

headline: Home/Work | In Belgium, a Housewares Designer Finds Transcendence in Simplicity
text: Using basic geometries and the most elemental of materials, the Belgian designer Michael Verheyden creates objects of sublime beauty and remarkable spiritual power.

headline: Nextdoor, a Start-Up, Raises $60 Million
text: Nextdoor, a social network for neighbors, is moving into elite territory.

headline: Responding to an Insurgent Attack on an Afghan Base
text: At around 10 p.m. on Sept. 14, 2012, 15 heavily armed insurgents penetrated the perimeter of Camp Bastion, a base in the Helmand Province of Afghanistan. Slipping through a hole in the wire, heavily armed and outfitted in American military uniforms, they wreaked havoc across the northeast flight line, killing two American Marines, wounding nine others, destroying six AV-8B Harrier jets and causing hundreds of millions of dollars in damage. One of the dead was the Harrier squadron’s commanding officer, Lt. Col. Christopher Raible, who died using only his 9mm handgun against five insurgents.

headline: Mount Vernon Blaze Kills 4 Relatives Inside Home
text: Raymundo Ureña, 17, was the first to realize that his family was in danger.

headline: Keanu Reeves Bowed to Chinese Censors to Make ‘Man of Tai Chi’
text: The movie “Man of Tai Chi” would seem like a perfect fit for the booming Chinese film market: a lowly courier with upwardly mobile ambitions gains wealth and renown by lethally leveraging his skills in the ancient meditative practice to vanquish a series of bloodthirsty rivals. Think “Kung Fu Panda” meets “Fight Club.” Then throw in Keanu Reeves, who often has taken the role of the stoic underdog hero, as both the kung fu-fighting villain — and the director.

headline: Life to Go On, But Jonas Brothers Call It Quits
text: Sic transit gloria mundi; a flower blooms and then wilts; a great empire flourishes and then fades away. And so, too, must time eventually take its toll on the Jonas Brothers, the pop-rock act that announced its breakup on Tuesday after the abrupt cancellation of a planned tour.

headline: U.N. Confirms an Outbreak of Polio in Syria
text: GENEVA — United Nations officials confirmed an outbreak of polio among children in Syria on Tuesday, lending urgency to plans for vaccination campaigns there and in nearby countries to try to halt the spread of the disease.

headline: ‘Have You Ever Thought of Adopting?’
text: No one wants to hear about fertility problems. My single friends are caught up in dating, my child-free friends wonder why I am putting myself through this, and my mom friends feel guilty and sorry for me and relieved for themselves at the same time.

headline: As Microsoft Looks On, Nokia Reports a Rise in Smartphone Sales
text: BERLIN – Microsoft has yet to get its hands on Nokia’s handset business, but the American technology giant got some good news Tuesday.

headline: Debating Bribes and Rewards
text: On Room for Debate, it’s me versus Bruce Feiler applying our most powerful argumentative skills to the question: Should You Bribe Your Kids?

headline: Health Site Chief Expects Low Initial Enrollment Number
text: WASHINGTON — Marilyn B. Tavenner, the official in charge of President Obama’s health insurance marketplace, apologized on Tuesday to millions of Americans who have been frustrated in trying to buy insurance under the new health care law.

headline: How Has Twitter Changed the Role of the Literary Critic?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Anna Holmes discuss social media’s effect on criticism.

headline: China Focuses on an Ethnic Minority in a Car Explosion
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities investigating a deadly episode near Tiananmen Square appeared Tuesday to focus on suspects from Xinjiang, the region in China’s far west that has been the scene of increasingly violent resistance to Beijing’s hard-line policies.

headline: Have Patience With Us
text: BAGHDAD — Imagine how Americans would react if you had a terrorist organization operating on your own soil that killed dozens and maimed hundreds every week. For Iraqis, that isn’t a hypothetical question; Al Qaeda in Iraq and its affiliates are conducting a terrorist campaign against our people.

headline: The Worlds of Dayanita Singh
text: During a recent visit to the Hayward Gallery in London, two vendors’ carts were parked against a wall, and a row of visitors stood with their backs to them as they read the introduction to “Go Away Closer,” unaware that the carts were part of the exhibition featuring the works of the photographer Dayanita Singh.

headline: T WINTER LUXURY
text: Doodles and selfies from the likes of Johnny Depp, Karl Lagerfeld and Conan O’Brien crowd the pages of the guest book of Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc in Cannes.

headline: A Concert of Sad Songs, Delivered Anywhere in the World
text: Ragnar Kjartansson, the Icelandic artist, has agreed to travel anywhere in the world to perform a two-hour concert for the highest bidder.

headline: Lester Again Makes World Series His Moment
text: ST. LOUIS — There is a photograph of Jon Lester from the 2007 World Series that symbolizes so much of the good in sports and life.

headline: Beck to Release New Album After Signing With Capitol Records
text: Beck may work in strange and mysterious ways, but when he will release his next album and who will release it are mysteries no more. This eclectic singer-songwriter, whose wide-ranging work includes the electronic funk of “Midnite Vultures” and the melancholy ballads of “Sea Change,” has signed with Capitol Records, and he will put out a new album, “Morning Phase,” on that label in February.

headline: Today in Small Business: Losing Money Can Be a Good Thing!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Nokia, Despite Loss, Shows Progress in Shift to Networks
text: BERLIN — Nokia announced a third-quarter loss on Tuesday as the company continued with a makeover that includes selling its handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion.

headline: Peyton Manning Halfway to Another M.V.P. Season
text: No quarterback has led the league in passing yards and won the Super Bowl in the same season.

headline: Morrissey Autobiography to Be Published in U.S.
text: The autobiography of the pop star Morrissey, which has become a quick sensation in Britain, has found an American publisher. G. P. Putnam’s Sons, an imprint of Penguin Random House, acquired the memoir, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: At Miami Beach Hotel, Design by Banksy
text: A new hotel in Miami Beach is using the work of Banksy, the British street artist known for his pop-up works of social commentary, to put a gritty edge on its otherwise glamorous design.

headline: Centrist Party in Israel Introduces Civil Union Measure
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s centrist Yesh Atid Party introduced civil union legislation on Tuesday that would give same-sex couples access to the rights of marriage and free heterosexual ones from the religious strictures imposed on marriage.

headline: The Things Traders Say, Dutch Bank Edition
text: Rabobank, which began life as an agriculture cooperative in the Netherlands in the late 19th century, has become the largest Dutch lender and a modest player on the stage of world finance.

headline: Deal Reached in Inquiry Into Visa Fraud at Tech Giant
text: Infosys, the giant Indian technology outsourcing company, has agreed to pay $34 million in a civil settlement after federal prosecutors in Texas found it had committed “systemic visa fraud and abuse” when bringing temporary workers from India for jobs in American businesses, according to court documents and officials familiar with the case. The payment is the largest ever in a visa case.

headline: Two Kinds of Hospital Patients: Admitted, and Not
text: Judith Stein got a call from her mother recently, reporting that a friend was in the hospital. “Be sure she’s admitted,” Ms. Stein said.

headline: Document | In the Guest Book of the Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc, Celebrity Signatures Galore
text: Situated just down the beach from Cannes, the storied Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc was originally conceived in the 19th century as a writers’ retreat before helping to transform the French Riviera from a sleepy, if well-appointed, backwater into the summertime playpen of the international jet set. Hemingway, Chagall and Picasso were all guests. Winston Churchill turned up, as did Marlene Dietrich, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, and a honeymooning Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton. The palatial Cap d’Antibes hostelry even had something of a star turn itself, checking in under a pseudonym, as it were — the Hôtel des Étrangers — in “Tender Is the Night,” the work of F. Scott Fitzgerald, another guest.

headline: When Tempers Flare
text: In a series of photographs from the Times archives, we take a look at the tense moments after disputed calls by baseball umpires.

headline: My Morning Jacket Plans a Resort Rock Festival, Yoga Included
text: Remember when going to a rock show meant packing into a crowded, grungy club, where the music was loud and the air was filled with smoke (various kinds), sweat and the aroma of beer? If you’re happy to have all that well behind you, but still have a yen to rock out — perhaps with some ritzy conveniences — the Southern rock band My Morning Jacket has a deal for you.

headline: Consultant to Democrats Faces Corruption Charges
text: An influential political consultant whose clients include the New York Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee and leading real estate developers, including Forest City Ratner, was arrested on federal corruption charges on Tuesday.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Trading Pain
text: Deutsche Bank’s third-quarter hit in fixed-income trading could presage a painful loss in market share. The German bank suffered a 48 percent fall in third-quarter debt sales and trading revenue — as bad as any peer. And things could get tougher still.

headline: When Tempers Flare
text: The wild finish Saturday night to Game 3 of the World Series — the winning run scored on an obstruction call — probably felt familiar to Red Sox fans who were around nearly 40 years ago when another incident on the basepaths figured prominently in a World Series defeat.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Obama’s Political Style
Whose Feet Are Those? Negotiating Air-Travel Etiquette
text: Forget paying extra for more legroom seats. These days I’d pay to sit next to someone who keeps his socks on. On recent flights I’ve had bare feet beside me, on the back of my armrest, on the bulkhead in front of me. Once, upon feeling something push through the sliver of space where the seat back and bottom meet, I reached behind me and grabbed a stranger’s toes.

headline: An Apology for the Health Care Rollout
text: Marilyn B. Tavenner, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, made her opening statement in front of the House Ways and Means Committee.

headline: In the San Francisco Bay, a Mysterious Google Barge
text: There is a mysterious barge floating in San Francisco Bay with Google’s fingerprints all over it. The question is what Google wants to do with it, and Google won’t say.

headline: Image of the Day: October 29
text: A lotus pond on the outskirts of Bhubaneshwar, Odisha.

headline: For Red-Cooked Beef, a Softly Fruity Wine
text: The spike of heat from the red chiles and the vivid, electric tingle of the Sichuan peppercorns make this red-cooked beef dish one of the more difficult to pair with wine. A softly fruity wine like a well-balanced zinfandel or Russian River Valley pinot noir may go surprisingly well, cushioning the jagged flavors and complementing the harmony of spices, provided they are not extravagantly alcoholic and are served slightly cool. As a sherry fanatic, I think oloroso, even with its high level of alcohol, around 20 percent, would pair beautifully. You might also try sweet wines, like a demi-sec Vouvray or an auslese riesling from the Mosel. These wines will be even better with 10 or 15 years of age.

headline: Bolshoi Dancer Pleads Not Guilty in Attack on Artistic Director
text: MOSCOW — Pavel Dmitrichenko, a soloist with the Bolshoi Ballet, pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to ordering an acid attack that nearly blinded the troupe’s artistic director. The man accused of carrying out the attack admitted his guilt but said he had been acting alone.

headline: The Beginning of the End of the Financial Crisis
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: In Our Pages: October 30
text: 1938 Fate of 120,000 Jews Debated

headline: Kentucky’s Senators Versus Kentuckians
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky hates the Affordable Care Act. So does Kentucky’s senior senator, Mitch McConnell — though apparently not quite enough to stave off a primary fight. The Senate Conservatives Fund has endorsed Mr. McConnell’s Tea Party challenger, Matt Bevin, who charged in a television spot that “McConnell helped Barack Obama and Harry Reid fund Obamacare.” By that he meant that Mr. McConnell worked to end the government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling to avoid default.

headline: U.N. Agency and Iran Cite Progress in Settling Questions on Nuclear Program
text: PARIS — Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency said Tuesday that they had held a “very productive” two-day meeting in Vienna aimed at resolving questions on the disputed Iranian nuclear program and would reconvene their discussions on Nov. 11 in Tehran.

headline: Rookie’s Bruising Running Helps Open Up Packers’ Attack
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Teams never defended the Green Bay Packers like this, because it invited quarterback Aaron Rodgers to shred them. That is why T. J. Lang, the right guard of the Packers, was so surprised the last two Sundays to see the Cleveland Browns and the Minnesota Vikings bring both safeties closer to the line of scrimmage at times to protect against the run.

headline: Skin Deep: Neo-Goth Makeup
text: Follow these easy steps to create the neo-goth look at home.

headline: The Obamacare Rollout’s Toll
text: As the promoters of a sweeping education referendum in Colorado look to Election Day next Tuesday, they worry about many factors, including what kind of voter turnout they can expect in an off year and whether Americans in an anti-tax era will choose to pay more, as the referendum calls on them to do, even if the money is guaranteed for kids and schools.

headline: Goth Is Dead, Long Live Goth
text: A style guide for the look that’s hard to kill.

headline: Dancin’ in the Aisles: Virgin Gives Its Safety Message Some Song and Dance
text: Singing. Dancing. Life vests.

headline: Sale of Dell Closes, Moving Company Into Private Ownership
text: After months of wrangling and tough negotiating, Dell Inc. is finally going private.

headline: Halloween or Not, a Softer Shade of Goth Makeup
text: They appear at the front of drugstores every year: the Halloween makeup displays, bearing inky black nail polishes and blood-red lip shades. “Go goth,” they whisper, “Channel your inner Wednesday Addams.”

headline: Dutch Website Catalogs Art Looted in Nazi Era
text: A four-year review by more than 400 Dutch museums and galleries has turned up a list of 139 artworks that may have been forcibly taken from Jewish families during the Nazis’ reign, the BBC reported on Tuesday. The works, which include a Matisse and several by Dutch artists, are listed on a special website. (An English version of the site won’t be available until 2014.)

headline: Seeking Students’ Short ‘Hamlet’ Videos
text: “Brevity is the soul of wit,” declares Polonius in William Shakespeare’s “Hamlet.” And perhaps short videos of lines from one of the Bard’s most-loved plays will expose the souls of their performers, too. So The New York Times invites student actors and actresses to submit their performances of lines from “Hamlet” using Instagram.

headline: Revenue Slides at Martha Stewart Living, Partly From Curbing Ties to J.C. Penney
text: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia posted troubling third-quarter results on Tuesday, largely because of losses in its publishing and broadcasting divisions. That was not surprising. What was unexpected was the company’s acknowledgment that its curtailed relationship with retailer J. C. Penney had significantly hurt advertising revenue of its magazines.

headline: French Interest Rates in the 1920s
text: Jeremie Cohen-Setton raises questions about the NBER series I used in the draft of my IMF Mundell-Fleming lecture. Fair enough; I’ve actually referenced the study he mentions in earlier work. I wish I understood it better. Still, that’s why I put the draft out there — comments, especially on historical data, are always welcome.

headline: How a Burned Out Owner Got Back Into the Game
text: Last week, we published a case study about a business owner who sought a better work/life balance in her early fifties by downshifting — cutting back on her hours and working two to three days a week from home. But then, two years closer to 60, Bibby Gignilliat, founder of Parties That Cook, a San Francisco company that offers cooking classes as employee-appreciation and corporate team-building events, had a change of heart. She had spent 14 years building her business to $2.2 million in revenue, but she knew she had more work to do if she ever wanted to sell the business.

headline: Syrians Flee What Some Called the ‘City of Death’
text: New video images show hundreds of civilians, balancing belongings on their heads, carrying children and assisting people using canes or wheelchairs, streaming out of the Damascus suburb of Moadhamiya, which had been blockaded for months by the government.

headline: College Painters to Face Off Onstage
text: The gladiatorial side of the art world is usually kept under wraps, in the jockeying for prominence among artists, gallery owners and curators. But ArtBattles U wants to get the sparring out in the open. The company, which specializes in finding opportunities for student artists to show their work, is presenting what it is calling a Live Art Battle — painters create works while audiences watch — on Nov. 14 in the Marlin Room at Webster Hall, the rock club on East 11th Street.

headline: Valium for Obamacare Worriers
text: Suppose that healthcare.gov isn’t fixed by the end of next month. How bad is it for Obamacare? Would the program be doomed?

headline: N.S.A. Head Says European Data Was Collected by Allies
text: WASHINGTON — The head of the National Security Agency on Tuesday vigorously challenged recent reports that the United States had been gathering the phone records of millions of Europeans, saying that the records had in fact been turned over by allied spy services.

headline: Garlicky Chicken
text: Elevate pan-seared chicken thighs by adding anchovies, capers, garlic and plenty of lemon. Melissa Clark shows how.

headline: Business-Conservative Alliance Presses for Immigration Action
text: WASHINGTON — For the business group from Utah, the lobbying blitz started well before their plane touched down in the nation’s capital.

headline: The Gun Report: October 29, 2013
text: * Every year in America, 500 children and teenagers die, and an estimated 7,500 kids are hospitalized, from gun violence, according to findings presented at an American Academy of Pediatrics conference held in Orlando, Fla., last weekend. The study found that handguns account for the majority of childhood gunshot wounds, and states with higher percentages of household firearm ownership have higher proportions of firearm injuries among children.

headline: Mariel Hemingway, Beyond ‘Manhattan’
text: Many know Mariel Hemingway from her role in Woody Allen’s 1979 movie, “Manhattan,” in which she played Allen’s sensitive and precocious 17-year-old girlfriend. Some of her other work in films and TV seems to be less familiar. One online commenter, responding to Amanda Fortini’s article in this past weekend’s magazine, wondered how Hemingway could afford her lifestyle, which includes a home in Malibu on a 1.5-acre ranch with organic vegetable beds, a climbing wall and at least one horse: “The math doesn’t add up. She hasn’t had a real film career in thirty years.” In fact, she has appeared in quite a few films and TV shows, including one of the ”Superman” sequels and an episode of the sitcom “Roseanne.” Here are some of the highlights.

headline: Street Style: Blazer
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Oct. 21.

headline: Anchovies Elevate a Pan-Seared Chicken Dish
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Pan de Muerto Is Bread That Gets Into the Spirit
text: Over the next few days, space will grow increasingly tight at the Guadalupana Bakery in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. The counters are piled high with displays of colorful breads in the shapes of skulls or figures in repose, and customers are coming in droves to buy special pan de muerto, or bread of the dead, some of them 10 loaves at a time.

headline: Documentary Association Announces Awards Nominations
text: LOS ANGELES — Issues and politics mostly ruled, as the International Documentary Association on Tuesday announced its nominees for its annual documentary awards. In the feature film category, nominations went to “The Act of Killing,” about Indonesian genocide; “Blackfish,” about orca whales in captivity; “Let the Fire Burn,” about a 1985 standoff between police and activists in Philadelphia; and “The Square,” about Egyptians struggling for social change. Those were joined by one very personal story, Sarah Polley’s “Stories We Tell,” about her discovery of a family secret that surrounded her own birth. The association also announced nominees for short films, television documentaries, and entries in other categories. The awards are to be presented at a ceremony in Los Angeles on Dec. 6.

headline: Egyptian Jihadists Cite Zawahiri in Video Claiming Responsibility for Cairo Attack
text: As our colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh reported from Cairo, a little-known Islamist militant group claimed responsibility for a failed attempt to assassinate Egypt’s interior minister last month, in a slickly produced video message posted online Saturday.

headline: Target Bans the Box
text: Sanctions that make it more difficult for ex-offenders to obtain jobs, housing and even basic documents like drivers’ licenses only serve to drive them back to jail. With that in mind, a growing number of states and municipalities now prohibit public agencies — and in some cases private employers — from asking about a job applicant’s criminal history until the applicant reaches the interview stage or gets a conditional job offer. These eminently sensible “ban the box” laws are intended to let ex-offenders prove their qualifications before criminal history issues enter the equation.

headline: Top British Official in Ulster Is Target of a Letter Bomb
text: DUBLIN — A letter bomb was sent to Britain’s top official in Northern Ireland on Tuesday, forcing an evacuation at the sprawling estate near Belfast that houses the offices of the province’s political leaders until the parcel was defused by the British Army. It was the fourth letter bomb mailed to a high-profile figure in Northern Ireland over the past week.

headline: Reese Accepts Some Blame and Expresses Some Hope
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants General Manager Jerry Reese has customarily waited until the team’s bye week to speak with reporters, a policy that went unchallenged for years because the team typically did not start seasons with mortifying losing streaks.

headline: The New Sushi Chef
text: At various spots in New York City, fish-and-rice specialists in their 20s and 30s have been making their own mark.

headline: Sushi’s New Vanguard
text: If you’re expecting all the whispery delicacy of a haiku at New York Sushi Ko on the Lower East Side, you may be a tad taken aback when John Daley grabs the blowtorch.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Twitter Alters Feed to Add Images
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter has gone visual.

headline: Vertical Living: Exploring Identity, Social Class and Global Change Through the Highrise
text: Overview | How can thinking about where and how people live be a window into issues of identity, social class and global change? In this lesson, students explore the interactive Op-Doc “A Short History of the Highrise” to learn 2,500 years of history through images, verse and graphics and use it as a jumping-off point for inquiry and discussion. Finally, they can choose to take the project further by focusing on a range of related ideas, from Chinese urbanization to New York City affordable housing to students’ own neighborhoods.Materials | Computers with Internet connection (high-speed Internet is necessary for some of the interactive features mentioned in this lesson)

headline: It’s Autumn, Time to Check Flexible Spending Accounts
text: AS the end of the year approaches, it’s a good time to check if you have a balance remaining in your health care flexible spending account.

headline: On Monday Night, World Series Tops N.F.L.
text: Baseball, which often plays second fiddle to football in television ratings, found something to smile about Monday night when Game 5 of the Boston Red Sox-St. Louis Cardinals World Series faced off against the Seattle Seahawks-St. Louis Rams N.F.L. game.

headline: Fairfield Beach: Buildings Rise; Values Stay Put
text: If it’s dangerous for a house to be close to the water, plenty of places in Fairfield Beach seem to be asking for trouble.

headline: AMC Orders a Fifth Season of ‘The Walking Dead’
text: “The Walking Dead,” the zombie apocalypse drama that is more popular than anything else on AMC (and most other channels, for that matter), will continue for at least a fifth season, the channel said on Tuesday.

headline: Listen Up | Cass McCombs and His Vagabond World
text: Aeon of Aquarius Blues (Alternate Take)

headline: New Confections, Coconut Chips and More
text: To Indulge: The Next Sweet Treat, From Paris to New York

headline: ‘Sightseeing at 26.2 Miles at a Time’
text: Among the throngs of runners crossing the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Sunday for the New York City Marathon, a fair number of them will travel not to Boston for their next race, but to lesser-known, far-flung destinations like Napa Valley, Mont-St.-Michel, France, even the savanna of South Africa.

headline: Hotel Review: The Marker Hotel in Dublin
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Lievito Madre al Mare in Naples, Italy
text: Pizza-making runs deep in the Sorbillo family DNA: dozens of members of this Neapolitan clan have become renowned pizzaioli in their home city and beyond. Perhaps the best known is Gino Sorbillo, a 39-year-old business school graduate whose father was one of 21 pizza-baking siblings.

headline: Syria Fires Official Who Tried to Broker Peace
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government on Tuesday fired a deputy prime minister who has lately been its most outspoken voice in favor of reform and who recently held meetings with American and Russian officials about peace talks that world leaders are trying to arrange to end Syria’s civil war.

headline: King Cole Bar & Salon Opening
text: Headliner

headline: Built With a Loudspeaker in Mind
text: Primarily known for making hi-fi speakers for audio studios and luxury hotels, the British company Bowers & Wilkins recently turned its expertise to headphones. The company quickly built a high-quality lineup, and rounding out the roster is the P7, its first over-ear headphones.

headline: A Hobbyist Plants Seeds of Bluegrass on 7th Ave.
text: The pop star quest for seriousness has checkpoints: Make an album in a well-aged, roots-oriented genre that’s miles away from your native sound. Collaborate with people far more gifted but far less renowned. Play a room that confers authority on the cheap. Be humble while never getting off the mount.

headline: Hearth
text: Inside the restaurant that, approaching its 10th anniversary, has remained true to its vision.

headline: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
text: Photos from China, Malta, Afghanistan and New York.

headline: With Season at Hand, Knicks’ Defense Remains a Work in Progress
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Metta World Peace went through a series of majors when he was a student at St. John’s. He initially wanted to study architecture so he could learn to build community centers, but he was disappointed to discover that too many of his classes clashed with basketball practice.

headline: A Chef Remains True to His Vision
text: Reading the opening lines of Hearth’s last review in The Times, published in 2004, is like strolling among the headstones in New York’s vast restaurant graveyard. The critic at the time, Amanda Hesser, observed that one-word names had become fashionable, and gave recent examples:

headline: Trying to Outrun the Cardinals’ Long Reach
text: ST. LOUIS — About 7 p.m. Central on Wednesday, a voice will declare on a radio wave transmitted at 1120 kilohertz, “This is KMOX, the voice of St. Louis,” and millions of homes from Denver to Alabama and Louisiana to North Dakota will be able to hear Game 6 of the World Series come to life on an AM radio.

headline: Trepidation and Restrictions Leave Crowdfunding Rules Weak
text: Crowdfunding is becoming a reality, but the question is whether it will thrive or become largely a vehicle for fraud.

headline: Ensconced in Luxury, as Terror Pays a Visit
text: On the evening of Nov. 26, 2008, as heavily armed Pakistani terrorists raced to infiltrate the five-star Taj Mahal Palace Hotel and other tourist sites in Mumbai in a spectacular coordinated attack, the hotel’s executive chef, Hemant Oberoi, feared he was falling behind.

headline: Share Your Views for Veterans Day
text: Our colleagues at Home Fires invite veterans, or friends or relatives of someone who served in the military, to share recollections, photographs and messages for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11, 2013.

headline: Yearning for Tenderness, and More, in a Vale of Cynicism
text: Bathing everyday cruelties in an ethereal, golden light, Malgoska Szumowska’s “In the Name Of” maximizes the tension between harsh content and softly seductive presentation. This dissonance between sight and sound is only one of the many contrasts that define this contemplative study of a young priest whose repressed desires threaten to derail his chosen vocation.
Sounds Like Somewhere
Devil We Know
Nothing But Time

headline: Does It Say ‘Arrgh’ When You Make a Kill?
text: The pirate adventure Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag is nearly as long and almost as beautiful as an actual vacation to the tropics.

headline: Ackman Sees Expansion of Activist Investing to Europe
text: Updated, 11:40 a.m. |

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: How Glass Magnifies Desire, and Motorola Channels Pixar
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 9: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
text: After two weeks of injury decimation, fantasy owners somehow managed to escape relatively unscathed in Week 8. As we start moving toward the tail end of bye weeks, waiver wires are getting barren, so you have to dig deep to find those waiver gems.

headline: Artists on Artists | Will Cotton on the Elegant Iraq War Watercolors of Steve Mumford
text: The name Will Cotton immediately brings to mind images of gorgeous nudes cavorting in fantasy landscapes made of sugarplums and candy canes. The painter’s current show at New York’s Pace Prints (through Nov. 16) is a case in point: it features prints of women wearing garments bedazzled with sweets and petit fours (in some cases hand-painted over lithographs), as well as crazily towering stacks of cakes built from pastel-colored paper pulp. In December, the French patissière Ladurée will introduce a limited-edition ginger whipped cream macaroon that Cotton dreamed up, housed in a box decorated with his painting of a woman wearing only whipped cream.

headline: Like a Blizzard of Dance Fragments
text: It was an ordinary Christmas and an ordinary gift. A few years ago, the French choreographer Boris Charmatz unwrapped a hardcover book about Merce Cunningham, a present from his father. His heart sank. A book about Cunningham might have excited him when he was 13, but now?

headline: Beijing Police Strive to Save Women From Driving ‘Mistakes’
text: The Beijing police have helpfully offered women an online lecture on driving. Under the rubric “Women Drivers Please Take Care to Avoid These Mistakes,” the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau generously listed tips on its official Sina Weibo page on Tuesday for confused women who somehow find themselves behind the wheel.

headline: Making Silly Showdowns for YouTube
text: LOS ANGELES — On a recent evening, Peter Shukoff and Lloyd Ahlquist, two breakout stars of the YouTube era, were trying, very seriously, to look like teenage girls from 2006: long hair, pink headbands, embroidered jeans.

headline: A Choreographer Wrestles With Wartime Tragedies
text: During the same two days in October 1967, an American battalion, ambushed in Vietnam, lost some 60 men, and an antiwar protest at the University of Wisconsin-Madison was met with violent police force. This juxtaposition of events is the subject and structure of “They Marched Into Sunlight,” an acclaimed 2003 book by David Maraniss. That book, in turn, has inspired “Into Sunlight,” a dance by Robin Becker that had its New York debut this weekend at Gould Hall at the French Institute Alliance Française.

headline: For ‘SNL’ Cast, Being Diverse May Be Better Than Being ‘Ready’
text: One decade after “Saturday Night Live” began in 1975, it added the first black woman to its primary cast. Danitra Vance, a gifted downtown actress and Second City veteran, lasted just one season.

headline: Ghoulish Mirror Images, Young and Older, Live and on Screen
text: No matter how closely images on screen might reflect a score and vice versa, sound, live performers and film are invariably separate entities in most multimedia works. But a remarkable intertwining occurs in the chilling “Up-close,” a film-noir cello concerto by the Dutch composer and filmmaker Michel van der Aa. On Monday evening in the Manhattan Center’s ornate Grand Ballroom, Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival presented the American premiere of this 2010 work, which won the prestigious Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition for 2013.

headline: Delayed Gratification for Maker of Grand Theft Auto
text: When your company has one of the best-selling products in the history of your industry, it must be mildly annoying to delay the booking of the sales bonanza because of an accounting quirk.

headline: Faces of Foster Care
text: Students at U.C.L.A. and Los Angeles City College who have beaten the odds.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are (at Home)
text: While photographing pagan beasts, “Star Wars” characters, knights and aliens, Klaus Pichler plumbed his subjects’ imaginations to make portraits of them sitting around at home.

headline: Good-for-You Motorcycles That Can Move You
text: HOW can you sell motorcycles when people are more worried about losing their jobs than how they will look on the latest Harley? How do you keep assembly lines humming when the baby boomers who have sustained the motorcycle business since the ’70s are now pushing 70?

headline: From China to Los Angeles, Taking the Electric Bus
text: LOS ANGELES — THERE’S a newcomer to this city’s auto row. Compared to the shiny showrooms displaying the latest Mercedeses and Toyotas, the Chinese carmaker BYD’s outpost in the shadow of downtown skyscrapers looks rather forlorn.

headline: Image of Hindenburg Haunts Hydrogen Technology
text: WHEN Rebecca Markillie of ITM Power  in Sheffield, England, attends trade shows to promote her company’s ambitious plan to build hydrogen fueling stations for cars in Britain, she sometimes must calm skittish consumers. “You get people saying, ‘Oh, no: hydrogen. That is dangerous,’ ” she said. “And you go, ‘Well, why do you say that?’ And straightaway, the only knowledge of hydrogen would be the Hindenburg.”

headline: A Woman’s Touch, Still a Rarity in Car Design
text: FOR Monika Zych and Sandy McGill, becoming car designers for BMW started with Matchbox toy cars, racing the tiny replicas around the living room as little girls.

headline: A Concept Goes From Paper Sketch to Metal Reality
text: “YOU can lie to yourself quite easily in a sketch,” said Niki Smart, a designer at the General Motors Advanced Design studio in North Hollywood, Calif., who makes dozens of sketches a day.

headline: 100 Years Down the Line
text: DETROIT — THE moving assembly line was the simplest of inventions, born of necessity to meet the exploding demand for automobiles in America in the early 20th century.

headline: Natural Gas Waits for Its Moment
text: CARS and trucks powered by natural gas make up a significant portion of the vehicle fleet in many parts of the world. Iran has more than two million natural gas vehicles on the road. As of 2009, Argentina had more than 1.8 million in operation and almost 2,000 natural gas filling stations. Brazil was not far behind. Italy and Germany have substantial natural gas vehicle fleets. Is America next?

headline: 18 and Talented, a Racecar Driver Is Open to Logos
text: NAZARETH, PA. — JODY AND KAREN KARAM built a home on a lot that sits on a hill next to a cornfield in a subdivision outside this town. But before that, Jody raked out a track on the land for his 4-year-old son, Sage, to learn how to race a go-cart. That was many laps and many trophies ago.

headline: Hail to the Minivan, Dowdy but Not Out
text: THE minivan was a cliché almost from the moment the first Dodge Caravan rolled off Chrysler’s assembly line in 1983. It was the boxy family hauler aimed at harried soccer moms, a symbol of the soul-crushing conformity that was the price Americans paid for suburban comfort.

headline: Dreamworks Animation Profit Falls, Though Shares Stay Strong
text: LOS ANGELES — Despite suffering a 59 percent drop in quarterly profit after the disappointing box-office performance of “Turbo,” DreamWorks Animation on Tuesday sought to convince investors that its film operation is healthy.

headline: James Clapper's Testimony in 2 Minutes
text: Top intelligence officials defended their operations before a House committee on Tuesday as they faced growing criticism and calls for a congressional review of the nation’s surveillance efforts.

headline: The Superman Building in Providence, Now Dark, Is in Need of a Savior
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — This city’s skyline has long been defined by the Superman building, so named by most everybody in Rhode Island because the 26-story skyscraper closely resembles the Daily Planet building that Superman leapt over in the 1950s television series.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Improving Adult Literacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ballot Measure on Judicial Retirement Age Is Said to Divide Cuomo and Top Judge
text: Of the six ballot proposals in New York’s general election, much of the attention, lobbying and debate have centered on the first referendum, which tackles the issue of allowing casino gambling. But deeper in the ballot, another proposition has quietly become the focus of a behind-the-scenes conflict between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the state’s top judge.

headline: A Departed  ‘21’ Club Fixture, Known for His Stories, Inspires a Few
text: As soon as Tip O’Neill came back from the men’s room at the “21” Club, Nicholas Verbitsky knew that Mr. O’Neill had fallen under the charms of the Rev.

headline: Company Hopes to Change Small Electric Vehicles With Cheaper Magnetic Technology
text: DESERT HOT SPRINGS, Calif. — If only electric propulsion could operate at low voltage, maximize the motor’s performance and do without the cumbersome array of batteries. That’s the proposition advanced by KLD Energy Technologies of Austin, Tex., which suggests that it has come up with the next great innovation in electric-vehicle powertrains.

headline: Chocolate Factory, Trade War Victim
text: KIEV, Ukraine — From the Baltic to the Black Sea, a chocolate wall has descended across the continent of Europe.

headline: Staten Island Property Puts a Nascar Failure Behind It
text: A windswept corner of the industrial northwest coast of Staten Island is infamous as a dumping ground for toxic waste, a home to Mafia-related crime and perhaps even more notoriously, the location for an ill-fated attempt to build New York City’s first Nascar racetrack.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Shortened Battery Life Found in Some New iPhones
text: The Apple iPhone 5S is supposed to have significantly longer battery life than its predecessors. But for a small number of the new models, a manufacturing defect has caused the battery to drain quickly, according to the company.

headline: People Who Buy Own Health Policies Face Big Changes
text: As Washington and much of the rest of the nation debate whether President Obama misled Americans when he said that people who like their health plans may keep them, tens of millions of people are finding that their insurance is largely unchanged by the new health care law.

headline: ScienceTake: What Makes Ticks Stick
text: Scientists studying ticks that carry Lyme bacteria wanted to know how these arachnids are able to stick so well to skin. The answer is a mouth that works like a ratchet.

headline: How Does a Tick Do Its Dirty Work? Research Video Offers a Clue
text: Chain saws, hockey masks and the undead are all classic symbols of horror. But for a true shiver of dread, take a look at a tick.

headline: New Chief of the F.C.C. Is Confirmed
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted unanimously on Tuesday to confirm President Obama’s two nominations to the Federal Communications Commission, overcoming obstacles by Republican lawmakers.

headline: Meet the Makers
text: TENGCHONG, China — I never thought I’d have to come to China for a breath of fresh air.

headline: Between Democrats and a Push for Filibuster Change, One Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats plan to force a vote this week to fill a vacancy on the court widely considered the country’s second highest, threatening to reopen the bitter fight over limiting the filibuster if Republicans follow through on their pledge to block the nomination.

headline: Homecoming at Howard
text: MY son is 13 and already cultivating an eclectic sense of himself. His friends span the American rainbow, and taken together, look like an ad for Gap Kids. I once heard him tell a group of giggling teenage girls, “You’re the first girls from Georgia” — the country, not the state — “I’ve ever met.” His music taste vacillates between hip-hop and something the kids call dubstep. Ask him what he wants to be when he grows up, and he’ll sketch an arc that begins at Google, pit-stops in a German embassy, returns home for a stint in Hollywood, then decamps again to some “football club” in Central Europe. This is not so much a career plan as a plot for that “Buckaroo Banzai” sequel that somehow never got made.

headline: Uber and Cheezburger Offer Kittens for Rent, for a While
text: Need to cuddle with a kitten for 15 minutes but don’t have a fluffy friend? Not to worry, Silicon Valley has an app for that — at least temporarily.

headline: Greeks Question Media, and New Voices Pipe Up
text: ATHENS — Late on a recent evening, crowds gathered at the Radio Bubble cafe in downtown Athens, drinking beer and talking politics. The cafe, in the trendy yet rough-around-the-edges Exarchia neighborhood, funds a small leftist online radio station of the same name, which broadcasts from inside.

headline: Do People Want to Build Their Own Customizable Smartphone?
text: Motorola’s idea for the ultimate smartphone looks more like a set of Legos that make up a smartphone.

headline: 18 Years Sober and Running for Mayor
text: Martin J. Walsh, a candidate for mayor of Boston who is a recovering alcoholic, has attracted the support of people in recovery.

headline: In Race for Boston Mayor, Former Addicts Back Candidate With a Past
text: BOSTON — Tom White, who says he used to swig two six-packs of beer while driving home from work, has been sober for 25 years. Now, his Toyota Corolla has a vanity plate that reads “ONEDAY,” a reference to the Alcoholics Anonymous slogan “one day at a time.” On the rear windshield is a sticker for Martin J. Walsh, a candidate for mayor of Boston.

headline: Jeffrey I. Brodsky
text: Mr. Brodsky, 56, is the president of Related Management, a division of the Related Companies that manages the developer’s 45,000 rental units, from affordable to work force to luxury, and more than six million square feet of commercial and retail space in 19 states.

headline: As Buffalo Sabres Rebuild, Fans Say Team Should Also Reform
text: BUFFALO — The Buffalo Sabres have the worst record in the N.H.L. at 2-11-1, and that is bad enough for their fans. But the Sabres have also become pariahs, so widely criticized for a handful of violent incidents that fans in Buffalo and commentators across the continent are calling for their coach’s ouster.

headline: Greenwich Village Zombies Rise From a Grave of Debt
text: BARRYTOWN, N.Y. — When the upper barn door creaked open, bones crashed, teeth clacked and a moth-eaten bridal veil floated to the ground.

headline: At Fenway, Looking for a Replay of 1918
text: The 1918 baseball season is back again, but this time as a curiosity rather than a taunt.

headline: A Dynasty to Duck
text: Dick Cheney and Mike Enzi are in a tiff over whether they’re fishing buddies or not.

headline: State Court Deems Law Wide Attack on Abortion
text: WASHINGTON — Responding to questions from the United States Supreme Court, the Oklahoma Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that a 2011 state law violated the Constitution by effectively banning all medicinal, nonsurgical abortions. The case, already accepted for review by the United States Supreme Court, may be decided this term.

headline: A Parade Is Back From the Financial Dead
text: Greenwich Village’s Halloween Parade was canceled last year because of Hurricane Sandy. Much of its budget was wiped out, too. But after a fund-raising drive, ghouls, zombies and puppets are preparing to strut this year.

headline: Adobe Hacking Attack Was Bigger Than Previously Thought
text: An online attack at Adobe compromised personal data for tens of millions more customers than was previously reported, the company acknowledged on Tuesday.

headline: Cardinals Give the Ball to Wacha With Confidence
text: BOSTON — Adam Wainwright had just lost for the second time in five games in this World Series, leaving the St. Louis Cardinals in a desperate situation. They will need to win two games in Boston, if they are going to beat the surging Red Sox. But Wainwright appeared calm after he and the Cardinals lost Game 5 on Monday, seemingly unconcerned about what lay ahead.

headline: Climate Pact Is Signed by 3 States and a Partner
text: The leaders of three Pacific Coast states and British Columbia have announced a broad alliance to combat climate change, including new joint steps to raise the cost of greenhouse gas pollution, promote zero-emission vehicles and push for the use of cleaner-burning fuels in transportation.

headline: Lighter and Faster, It’s iPad Air
text: The iPad Air is noticeably lighter than its predecessors.

headline: As It Denounces U.S. Spying, Europe Delays Privacy Protection at Home
text: BRUSSELS — Even with Europe in an uproar over intrusive United States surveillance, its leaders are looking for ways to slow down legislation aimed at preventing violations of privacy at home.

headline: Should High School Last Six Years?
text: President Obama recently visited a six-year high school, highlighting it as a model for the rest of the U.S. Should it be replicated?

headline: U.S. Says It Won’t Back New International Coal-Fired Power Plants
text: WASHINGTON — In an aggressive move to impose President Obama’s environmental policies overseas, the Treasury Department on Tuesday largely declared an end to United States support for new coal-fired power plants around the world. The decision means that Mr. Obama’s administration will no longer contribute to coal projects financed by the World Bank and other international development banks.

headline: Christie Embraces Budget Strategies He Scorned as a Candidate
text: Running for New Jersey governor in 2009, Chris Christie hammered the Democratic incumbent, Jon S. Corzine, for using “one-shot gimmicks” to balance the budget, called it “unconscionable” to take away property tax rebates and railed against issuing more debt for transportation projects, promising to “start saying no to spending.”

headline: Allies in Revolt
text: It is not every day that America finds itself facing open rebellion from its allies, yet that is what is happening with Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Israel. The Obama administration has denied there are serious problems. But there are clearly differences, some perhaps irreconcilable.

headline: New York Police Detective Is Accused of Perjury
text: A narcotics detective with the New York Police Department was arrested on Tuesday and accused of changing his testimony about a drug arrest, causing the case to be dismissed.

headline: Putting More Controls on Painkillers
text: The Food and Drug Administration took an important step last week to curb an epidemic of overdose deaths from misuse of prescription painkillers that contain hydrocodone, such as Vicodin, Lortab and their generic equivalents, in combination with another painkilling drug. The only regret is that it took so long for the agency to make up its mind.

headline: Where the Buck Stops, Some See a Bystander
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama finds himself under fire on two disparate fronts these days, both for the botched rollout of his signature health care program and for the secret spying on allied heads of state. In both instances, his explanation roughly boils down to this: I didn’t know.

headline: A Mixed Decision on the Texas Abortion Law
text: Under a phony guise of protecting the health and safety of women, states with Republican governors and state legislatures have been keeping busy enacting one burdensome scheme after another designed to radically curtail access to safe and legal abortion care.

headline: Google Plus Aims to Become a Photo Storage and Editing Hub
text: Google Plus has not come close to rivaling Facebook for social networking. But it is trying to carve out its own niche, as the place to go for photo storage, editing and sharing.

headline: 3 Things to Watch in Sebelius Testimony
text: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, will testify before Congress on Wednesday about issues with the rollout of the Affordable Care Act. Here are three subjects to focus on.

headline: Jackie Robinson’s Legacy Recedes on Baseball Rosters
text: When Boston and St. Louis first faced each other in the World Series, in 1946, there wasn’t a single African-American in either dugout. As the Red Sox and the Cardinals meet again 67 years later, there is one.

headline: Stand Clear of Closing Doors! Protect Your Manicure
text: REMEMBER the vending machines in New York City subway stations, even on platforms? (O.K., maybe not, as it was decades ago.) Among the products straphangers could buy were cigarettes, candy and gum; there were also scales proclaiming, “Horoscope and weight 1¢.”

headline: Spying Known at Top Levels, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top spymaster said on Tuesday that the White House had long been aware in general terms of the National Security Agency’s overseas eavesdropping, stoutly defending the agency’s intelligence-gathering methods and suggesting possible divisions within the Obama administration.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 30, 2013
text: “They give me the emotional strength to keep moving.”

headline: Cancellation of Health Care Plans Replaces Website Problems as Prime Target
text: WASHINGTON — After focusing for weeks on the technical failures of President Obama’s health insurance website, Republicans on Tuesday broadened their criticism of the health care law, pointing to Americans whose health plans have been terminated because they do not meet the law’s new coverage requirements.

headline: Protests Halt Kelly’s Speech at Brown University
text: A speech by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly at Brown University planned for Tuesday was canceled after protesters against the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactics disrupted the event with shouting and chants.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 29, 2013
The Republicans’ Shift on Health Care
text: With the Obama administration saying HealthCare.gov will fixed by Nov. 30, Republicans are looking to attack other aspects of the Affordable Care Act besides the troubled website.

headline: As Power Line Grows, So Does Fight Between Ancient and Modern Korea
text: MIRYANG, South Korea — The traditional farming villages within Miryang city, like so many in South Korea, are nestled against forested mountains. Rice paddies spill out into the valley, and persimmon and apple orchards line the roads.

headline: CBS Said to Be Developing Streaming News Channel
text: The CBS Corporation is developing a 24-hour news channel that would be streamed online and would mainly repurpose video and reporting already produced by CBS News, according to executives involved in the planning.

headline: Errors Rife in New York State’s List of Health Insurance Assistance Sites
text: Computer issues are not the only problem plaguing the rollout of the Affordable Care Act. A 228-page list of navigators — businesses and organizations that help people sign up for coverage — on New York State’s health exchange website has turned out to be littered with places whose owners and employees have no clue how to offer health insurance advice.

headline: On Road to Fed Cup Final, Top Russians Jump Off
text: Bud Collins, a tennis commentator and gadfly, once wrote that the Fed Cup was “a splendid idea with a lame name.”

headline: At Foley’s Memorial, a Rare Show of Bipartisanship
text: The Capitol Hill memorial service for Thomas S. Foley, the former House speaker, brought together Republicans and Democrats who just two weeks ago were fighting about the government shutdown, but who were united in praise on Tuesday of a man who himself was a victim of partisan rancor two decades ago.

headline: Mayor’s Race Intrudes on Stop-and-Frisk Case, Judges Say
text: A panel of federal judges on Tuesday questioned New York City’s efforts to fight court-ordered changes to the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policies, suggesting that should Bill de Blasio be elected as the city’s next mayor, such efforts could be rendered moot.

headline: Corrections: October 30, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Among the Huddled Masses, Doing Good Can Come With a High Price
text: Some shows are just too good to go away for good. And no, I’m not referring to the mechanical juggernauts that are parked on Broadway like so many hyper-expensive theme park rides. I’m talking about the Foundry Theater’s sublime production of Bertolt Brecht’s “Good Person of Szechwan,” which was a highlight of the last theater season, when it opened in February at La MaMa, and now becomes a highlight of the current one, having reopened Tuesday night at the Public Theater.

headline: Bob and Others
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I hope you’ve all brought your toothbrushes and toothpaste. We’re going to need a good brushing after this one.

headline: The Sex Therapist’s Story, From Calamity to Cliché
text: “People don’t look at the elderly as sexual beings,” says Debra Jo Rupp as the title character in “Becoming Dr. Ruth,” a solo play about the celebrity sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer that opened on Tuesday at the Westside Theater. “Worse, some older people don’t see themselves that way.”

headline: Emotional Gulf Renewed as Israel Frees Palestinian Prisoners
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — For the family of Sharif Abu Duheileh, one of 26 long-serving Palestinian prisoners released by Israel late Tuesday, this was a day of celebration.

headline: Calder’s Heirs Accuse Trusted Dealer of Fraud
text: The bond between dealer and artist can be a kind of love affair, with its attendant passions and confidences, interests and intrigues.

headline: What Hurricane Sandy Destroyed, a Man Rebuilds by Hand
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — Pat Dixon wiped his hands on his basketball sweatshirt and looked around at his house-in-progress.

headline: Nets Head Into Opener With Assortment of Aches
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The multitude of positive traits the revamped Nets are supposed to possess — savvy and spirit and a high basketball I.Q. — will be undermined if their stars succumb to injury.

headline: Alabama: Deal Reached Over Immigration Crackdown
text: Civil rights groups announced an agreement with state officials to permanently block major portions of a law passed in 2011, the toughest of recent state laws to crack down on illegal immigration. The accord resolved lawsuits challenging the statute, H.B. 56, by groups including the Southern Poverty Law Center and the National Immigration Law Center, and by the Justice Department. It strikes down provisions that required schoolchildren to declare their parents’ immigration status and barred signing contracts with illegal immigrants. Most of the law was already temporarily halted by federal courts. The agreement is subject to approval by a federal judge.

headline: Profiling Complaints by Black Shoppers Followed Changes to Stores’ Security Policies
text: Several months ago, a meeting was convened at Barneys New York to discuss a growing problem: A significant amount of inventory was being lost to theft. Something had to be done.

headline: Public Housing Residents Relying on Agency Still Recovering From Storm
text: The midday food giveaways at Gravesend Houses in Coney Island began soon after Hurricane Sandy, and are still going strong.

headline: Bulls Star Returns, but Heat Own Stage
text: MIAMI — In what is considered to be a renaissance era for exceptional point guards, the two-time defending N.B.A. champion Heat — who, in effect, play without one — welcomed the most intriguing of the little-man lot back to the regular-season grind Tuesday night.

headline: Lawrence G. Foster Dies at 88; Helped Lead Tylenol Out of Cyanide Crisis
text: Lawrence G. Foster, a former journalist who started the public relations department at Johnson & Johnson and helped lead the company out of a crisis when seven people died after taking Tylenol, the company’s signature pain reliever, died on Oct. 17 at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 88.

headline: Shifting to Higher Gear, Rangers Rally to Beat Isles
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Benoit Pouliot wore a wide smile of relief after his wrist shot late in the third period lifted the goal-starved Rangers past the Islanders, 3-2, Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Senators’ Letter to President Obama on Iraq
text: An influential group of senators sent a strongly worded letter to President Obama warning that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s “mismanagement” of Iraqi politics had contributed to the surge of violence there.

headline: To Save Money, Beijing Couples Divorce in Soaring Numbers
text: Around the world, divorce can make people poorer, as they sell their property. In Beijing, couples are divorcing — to become richer, by selling their property.

headline: William Harrison, 79, Novelist and ‘Rollerball’ Writer, Dies
text: William Harrison, who adapted his fiction into the films “Rollerball” in 1975 and “Mountains of the Moon” in 1990, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Fayetteville, Ark. He was 79.

headline: When Class Trumps Identity
text: Last week, I wrote about Bill de Blasio’s victory in the Democratic mayoral primary in New York, and mentioned that exit polls showed that his support was “consistently high among all income groups.”

headline: Senators Warn Obama Before Iraq Leader’s Visit
text: WASHINGTON — As Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq headed to Washington on Tuesday, an influential group of senators sent a strongly worded letter to President Obama warning that Mr. Maliki’s “mismanagement” of Iraqi politics had contributed to the surge of violence there.

headline: Higher Powers
text: An oceanic allusion in Maureen McLane’s reflection on desire and enlightenment reminds the artist Daniel Arsham of a Neptune statue he once saw on the French island of Bendor.

headline: Morocco in a Bottle
text: Pure argan oil, responsibly sourced from Morocco, is the key ingredient in all of the products made by the New York organic skin care line Kahina Giving Beauty, founded five years ago by Katharine L’Heureux. The brand’s signature product, a bottle of 100 percent organic argan oil, works as well on the face and body as it does on hair, soothing dryness and replenishing moisture. But for Kahina’s first body serum, L’Heureux combined a lightweight argan oil base with 16 other oils, from watermelon and coconut to cumin and clove, to “create this more luxurious spreadable texture,” she said. It’s also the brand’s first scented product. The aroma is called Fez. Putting it on is a warm, sensory experience meant to transport the wearer to the Moroccan city, one of L’Heureux’s favorite places. “I wanted something evocative of that multilayered city that combines spirituality with all the scents of the spice market and the souk and the floral notes that happen in the spring, when the orange flower blossoms are just spilling through the streets,” L’Heureux explained. “I’ve never personally been a big scent person, but I love the idea of evoking places.” She plans to introduce additional products with the same spicy scent. $98; givingbeauty.com.

headline: China’s Fashion Matchmaker
text: As luxury brands try to crack the exploding Chinese market and the Chinese seek to export their own fashion stars to the West, Melvin Chua — bon vivant, image maker and cross-cultural connector — is the man in the middle.

headline: Work Now, and Let Uncle Sam Pay You Later
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: The Marathon Runner as Couch Potato
text: Someone can train for a marathon and simultaneously qualify as a couch potato, recent research shows, raising provocative questions about how sedentary most of us really are.

headline: Ousted General in Egypt Is Back, as Islamists’ Foe
text: CAIRO — A year after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, the man responsible for rooting out government corruption, Gen. Mohamed Farid el-Tohamy, faced a very public barrage of allegations that he had deliberately covered up years of cronyism and self-dealing.

headline: Word of the Day | pitfall
text: pitfall •\ˈpit-ˌfȯl\• noun

headline: Barnes & Noble to Release New Version of the Nook
text: Barnes & Noble is set to release a new black-and-white e-reader with a glowing backlit screen on Wednesday, as the bookseller enters the holiday season with declining sales and a cloudy digital future.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 1:15 A.M. (TCM) THE CONVERSATION (1974) Gene Hackman, above, plays Harry Caul, a surveillance expert and paranoid loner who has been hired to eavesdrop on a married woman (Cindy Williams) and her lover (Frederic Forrest) by her suspicious husband, known as the Director (Robert Duvall). (A young Harrison Ford portrays the Director’s assistant.) But three people have already died because of Harry’s work, and now he’s worried that two more may soon lose their lives. The movie, written and directed by Francis Ford Coppola, received three Oscar nominations, including for best picture and best original screenplay. In the same awards season, his film “The Godfather: Part II” won for best director, best picture and best adapted screenplay. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called “The Conversation” haunting and bothersome: “Haunting because its suggestion that technology has gotten out of hand, though not exactly new, is so convincingly and fastidiously detailed. It’s bothersome because Mr. Coppola, the writer as well as the director, has nearly succeeded in making a great film but has, instead, made one that is merely very good.” Worth a listen: David Shire’s evocative score for solo piano.

headline: Kenya: Soldiers Punished Over Looting
text: The Kenyan military said Tuesday that it dismissed and jailed two soldiers for looting from the Westgate mall in Nairobi last month, as security forces fought off armed militants. A spokesman said that allegations of looting by forces had prompted an internal investigation, and that two soldiers had been identified with cellphones and cameras that the army said had been stolen from the mall as security forces secured the building. Another soldier is under investigation. The Westgate mall was attacked by militants claiming to be from the Shabab, an Islamic extremist group in Somalia, on Sept. 21. Security forces spent four days securing the mall. Shop owners said that myriad merchandise was looted from the mall between the day of the attack and when shop owners were allowed back, one week later.

headline: Superfund Status Sought for Queens Industrial Site
text: City, state and federal agencies have long known that an industrial site in Ridgewood, Queens, contained radioactive material. The location, currently home to an auto repair shop, a construction firm, a warehouse and a deli, was once used by the Wolff-Alport Chemical Company, which sold thorium to the federal government for research on atomic bombs.

headline: News Quiz | October 30, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: North Korea: Work Seen at Missile Site
text: Commercial satellite imagery taken a few weeks ago suggests that North Korea is upgrading its main launch facility with the possible intention of handling both larger and more mobile missiles, a Washington-based research institute that monitors the country said Tuesday. In a report posted on its website, 38 North, the U.S.-Korea Institute at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies said the new construction at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in North Korea suggested it may become “the main, and perhaps sole, test facility in the future.” The report was the institute’s second in less than a week that utilized satellite imagery to suggest North Korea is proceeding with proliferation activities that have been banned by the United Nations Security Council, which has imposed severe sanctions on the country in response.

headline: Egypt: Inquiry Opened Into Satirist
text: The country’s general prosecutor on Tuesday opened an investigation into Bassem Youssef, an Egyptian satirist, stemming from citizen complaints including that Mr. Youssef had insulted the military on his popular weekly television show, state news media reported. On Friday, the program returned to the air for the first time since the military ousted President Mohamed Morsi in July, in a test of the boundaries of free speech under the new military-backed government. The new complaints, which include broadcasting false statements and “portraying Egypt as a promiscuous woman,” have yet to result in any formal charges.

headline: France: Hostages in Niger Are Freed
text: The four French hostages who were kidnapped three years ago in Niger by Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb have been released, President François Hollande of France said Tuesday. Mr. Hollande did not describe the conditions of the release of the hostages — Daniel Larribe, Pierre Legrand, Thierry Dol and Marc Féret — who were working for the French nuclear giant Areva, and Sogea-Satom, a subsidiary of the French construction group Vinci in Arlit, in northern Niger, when they were kidnapped in September 2010. Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility and later posted videos showing that the men were alive. They were believed to have been kidnapped by Abu Zeid, the militant group’s deputy commander, who was killed in an airstrike in Mali this year.

headline: Russia: New Indictment for Navalny
text: Russia’s Investigative Committee said Tuesday that it had completed a new indictment of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s most prominent opposition leader. The indictment charged him and his brother with embezzlement and money laundering, this time involving a commercial cosmetics contract worth nearly $1 million. The new charges came only two weeks after a judge suspended a five-year sentence in a previous conviction that had widely been denounced as politically motivated, allowing him to remain free though with his political future in doubt. Mr. Navalny denounced the indictment as an expected, though baseless effort to maintain pressure on him after his strong showing in the Moscow mayoral election in September.

headline: In Doctored Photo, Chinese Officials Loom Large Online
text: Efforts to promote a visit by local government officials to an elderly pensioner in the eastern province of Anhui took an awkward turn after a poorly doctored photo spread rapidly on Chinese websites. By Wednesday morning, hours after it had begun to go viral, the photo had landed on the front page of The Beijing News.

headline: From Today’s Paper: After Storm, a Time to Plant
text: Volunteers in Breezy Point, Queens, reintroduced beach grass to dunes on Tuesday, a year after Hurricane Sandy hit the region.

headline: Argentina: Court Loss for Media Group
text: After four years of combat between the government and Argentina’s biggest media conglomerate, the Clarín group, Supreme Court judges declared constitutional on Tuesday a law that forces media companies to shrink their broadcast divisions. The law, which was passed in 2009, has not been fully put in effect because of Clarín’s challenges in the courts. But the ruling means the group must immediately start the process to divest itself of assets, according to Martín Sabbatella, president of the government agency enforcing the law. The ruling concluded that the law “favors freedom of speech by limiting market concentration.”

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 30, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Schools Watch Students on the Internet
text: In “Warily, Schools Watch Students on the Internet,” Somini Sengupta writes about how new ways to monitor students around the clock are raising questions.

headline: The President Wants You to Get Rich on Obamacare
text: Tom Scully bolted through the doors and up the stairs to a private dining room on the third floor of the “21” Club. Scully, 56, is slightly taller than average and has tousled graying hair, an athletic build and a lopsided smile. He typically projects a combination of confidence and bemusement, but on this rainy September afternoon, he was frenzied. Scully was scheduled to deliver the keynote address at an event hosted by the Potomac Research Group, a Beltway firm that advises large investors on government policy (tag line: “Washington to Wall Street”). Today’s discussion centered on the most significant change in decades to the nation’s health care policy, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare. As Scully walked to the front of the room, some 50 managers from hedge funds, mutual funds and private equity firms tucked into the round tables. Others gathered in the hallway. A hush of anticipation hung in the air.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are (at Home)
text: A plump teddy bear perches on the edge of a sofa, surrounded by floral wallpaper. A monk in a dimly lit room hangs his head, his shadow projecting menacingly onto the wall. Meanwhile, a skeleton tucks itself into bed, where a painting of Mary and Jesus watches over its slumber.

headline: What Kind of Robot Would You Want?
text: More and more, robots are beginning to imitate — and look like — humans. And the idea that someday they will be partners of humans, rather than stand-ins or servants, is now driving research at universities and industrial laboratories.

headline: Barclays Rebounds to Profit, Despite Fixed-Income Slump
text: Updated, 8:22 p.m. | The British bank Barclays reported a better-than-expected third-quarter profit on Wednesday but said that income in its investment bank declined, driven primarily by a 44 percent drop in its fixed-income business.

headline: New York Today: Fall Colors
