headline: Held 3 Years, French Hostages Return Home
text: PARIS — Free after years being held hostage in the deserts of West Africa, four Frenchmen, two with eyes downcast, two appearing joyous, stepped out of a plane and into a fine autumn morning south of Paris on Wednesday. Their families had gathered on the empty tarmac with President François Hollande. It had been three years, six weeks and three days since their kidnapping by Islamist fighters in Niger, and just hours since their release.

headline: Corrections: October 31, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Howard Be Thy Name
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Halloween! Let’s start off with a comment from puzzle master Will Shortz: “This is probably my favorite daily puzzle of the week. The trick at 65A is downright mean!”

headline: No U.S. Action, So States Move on Privacy Law
text: State legislatures around the country, facing growing public concern about the collection and trade of personal data, have rushed to propose a series of privacy laws, from limiting how schools can collect student data to deciding whether the police need a warrant to track cellphone locations.

headline: Tennessee: Guardsman Is Indicted in Armory Attack
text: A National Guard soldier was indicted Wednesday in connection with a shooting in West Tennessee last week that wounded three of his superiors. A federal grand jury in Memphis charged the soldier, Sgt. First Class Amos Patton, with nine counts, including assault with a deadly weapon and unlawfully attempting to kill four soldiers. Sergeant Patton, 42, is accused of opening fire at an armory in Millington after officials told him that he was likely to face severe penalties, including dismissal from active service as a National Guard recruiter, for previous misconduct. The soldiers who were hurt in the shooting last Thursday were treated and released.

headline: When Mac Retired Yaz to Stun the Red Sox
text: BOSTON — The final stop of the baseball season is the oldest address in the game: 4 Yawkey Way, Boston, Mass. Fenway Park. Green walls and red bricks. One hundred and one years of history.

headline: South Carolina: Five Are Killed in Custody Dispute
text: A gunman in Greenwood County killed five people, including two children, because of a custody dispute, the authorities said Wednesday. Sheriff Tony Davis said that the man, Bryan E. Sweatt, 27, had fatally shot Chandra Marie Fields, with whom he had a 7-month-old daughter, along with her parents and two of her young nephews, and then killed himself. Ms. Fields had clashed with Mr. Sweatt about visiting privileges for their baby, who was unhurt, Sheriff Davis said. Three other children were also unharmed. The other victims were identified as Richard Fields, 51; his wife, Melissa Fields, 49; William Robinson, 9; and Tariq Robinson, 11. Sheriff Davis said Mr. Sweatt had an “extensive” criminal history.

headline: American Candy Makers, Pinched by Inflated Sugar Prices, Look Abroad
text: READING, Mass. — Inside the Chocolate Truffle candy shop in this Boston suburb are chocolate pizzas, chocolate buffalo wings, even a chocolate wingtip shoe. The owner, Erin Calvo-Bacci, would like to expand her business close to home, but is instead thinking of moving her operations to Canada, where the sugar essential for her products costs far less.

headline: Cilic’s Return Raises Questions About Antidoping Protocols
text: PARIS — Marin Cilic lost to Juan Martín del Potro in the second round of the ATP Masters event in Paris on Wednesday, but his overall feeling was one of relief.

headline: Boston Fans Set for Party After Years of Buildup
text: BOSTON — Boston’s four principal sports teams have had an unusually impressive stretch of success, a run of seven championships that began when the New England Patriots won their first Super Bowl, after the 2001 season. (An eighth title was within reach Wednesday night.)

headline: Chamblee Resigns From Golf Magazine After Critical Remarks on Woods
text: Brandel Chamblee, the Golf Channel commentator who suggested on Golf magazine’s website that Tiger Woods was a cheater, resigned from the publication on Wednesday but will stay at the television network. His assessment earlier this month was part of Chamblee’s season-ending PGA Tour report cards for various golfers. Chamblee gave Woods an “F.”

headline: Bitcoin Pursues the Mainstream
text: The currency known as bitcoin — a much-hyped and much-doubted type of digital cash that can be bought with traditional money — has mostly attracted attention for its popularity in the black market, and for its wildly gyrating valuation.

headline: An Abridged History of Bitcoin
text: What started as an idea in 2008 has since become a currency found in automated teller machines, used by black markets and put in portfolios that some investors want to trade like stocks.

headline: Closing of Live Poultry Markets Is Called Effective in Flu Fight
text: Shutting down live poultry markets is extremely effective in preventing human cases of avian flu and should be considered if the disease reappears this winter, researchers in China reported Wednesday.

headline: China: Brother of Tibet Religious Leader Details Circumstances of Sibling’s Death
text: The brother of a prominent Tibetan religious leader, Choje Akong Rinpoche, who was stabbed to death in China on Oct. 8, has said Mr. Akong had not been “assassinated.” The brother, Lama Yeshe Losal Rinpoche, the abbot of Samye Ling Monastery in Scotland, released a statement that said: “Unfortunately I used the word ‘assassination’ in respect of the killing of my brother Akong Rinpoche. English is not my first language and I did not appreciate that the word means killing with a religious or political motive. I never intended to imply that there was such a motive.” State news media reported three suspects had been detained and had had an “economic dispute” with Mr. Akong.

headline: In Final New York Mayoral Debate, Rivals Mock Each Other’s Résumés
text: Bill de Blasio said he needed no backup plan: Skeptics aside, Albany would approve his plan to raise taxes on the rich.

headline: United Nations Proposes to Bolster Force in Somalia
text: Four months after a deadly attack on the United Nations compound in Mogadishu, a senior United Nations official on Wednesday called for an expansion of an international security force. Jan Eliasson, the deputy United Nations secretary general, pressed the Security Council to bolster the international force, specifically with guards to protect United Nations staff members.

headline: On Council, de Blasio Blended Idealism With Push for Power

headline: Knicks Show Promise, and Flaws, in Debut

It was bold talk given the strong competition in the Eastern Conference and their own mishmash of aging parts, so Coach Mike Woodson always made certain to couch his optimism. His team, he said, was a work in progress.

headline: Rebuilt Nets Still Need Fine-Tuning
text: CLEVELAND — Kevin Garnett lacked the precise word to describe the prodigious anxiety and eagerness he and his teammates felt walking onto the court here Wednesday night, so he contorted his face into an exaggerated snarl and let out a comical growl.

headline: Canadian Cyclist Admits ‘Short-Lived’ Drug Use

text: At their Milan atelier, one of the last truly Old World interiors firms, Studio Peregalli, is making history — mining everything from the high Renaissance to the Victorian era — to create deeply poetic spaces that transcend the bounds of time.

headline: Countess Marina Cicogna, a Woman of the World

text: This article appears in the Nov. 3, 2013 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: A Fat Dad Halloween (Hide the Candy)
text: Every year after trick-or-treating for Halloween, I used to hide my candy in a little paisley suitcase under my bed. Just to be safe, I even locked it so my dad would not devour the contents in one night.

text: witticism •\ˈwi-tə-ˌsi-zəm\• noun

headline: The Perils of a Free Trade Pact With Europe
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Red Sox Rout Cardinals to Win World Series
text: BOSTON — For much of the 20th century, the Boston Red Sox were a symbol of frustration and pain for an entire region. As popular as they were in their corner of the nation, either they were good enough to lose in agonizing fashion on baseball’s grandest stage, or they were just plain bad.

headline: Boston Leaves Worries Behind and Learns to Be Happy
text: BOSTON — They don’t even worry about the Red Sox here anymore. Why would they? With another championship, their third in 10 years, the Red Sox have the finances, the farm system and the fan base to succeed for years to come.

headline: Iran: Official Says Arrested Men Were Thieves, Not ‘Nuclear Saboteurs’
text: The minister of intelligence, Mahmoud Alavi, said Wednesday that recent claims that four “nuclear saboteurs” had tried to steal secrets from a power plant were inaccurate. The accusations had been made by Ali Akbar Salehi, Iran’s top nuclear official. Mr. Alavi said the four suspects had been seeking scrap metal, according to the semiofficial Islamic Students’ News Agency. The men, who were arrested, had dug a hole under a fence around the power plant in order to sneak the purloined scrap metal out and sell it, he said. “These people were thieves, not nuclear saboteurs,” the minister said. “They were from a village close to the power plant, and they had done such things before.”

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (Sundance) THE RETURNED In an idyllic French mountain town, a random collection of people — a boy killed during a robbery, a teenager who died in a bus wreck, a bridegroom who committed suicide, a serial killer buried alive by his brother — find themselves in a state of confusion as they try to return to their homes. What they don’t realize is that they’ve been dead for several years, and no one is expecting them back. Worse, their arrival coincides with a series of gruesome murders bearing a chilling resemblance to the work of a serial killer from the past. Above, Clotilde Hesme and Pierre Perrier. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called this series, adapted by Fabrice Gobert from Robin Campillo’s film “Les Revenants,” “strange and strangely suspenseful” and compared it to “The Walking Dead” — “only the zombies are sentient, and hungry for cassoulet, not human flesh.”

headline: N.F.L. Week 9 Game Probabilities: Patriots’ Passing Decline
text: First, fifth, second, second, fourth and 31st. Those are the league rankings of the Patriots’ net passing efficiency with Tom Brady at the helm since New England’s record-breaking 2007 season. The Patriots currently rank second to last in the most important and most consistent of all facets of team performance.

headline: News Quiz | October 31, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Mayor 2013: The Final Debate
text: Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota repeatedly challenged each other over experience and values in the final televised debate, which was also heavy on detailed policy proposals.

headline: Scenes From a Series
text: In a World Series notable for strong pitching and strange blunders, the Red Sox earned the third jewel in their championship crown over the last 10 years, and their eighth over all.

headline: A Conversation With: Jazz Pianist Vijay Iyer
text: Vijay Iyer, 42, is an Indian-American jazz pianist and composer. His albums incorporate a mixture of traditional jazz, Indian classical fusion, and various other eclectic musical styles. Apart from producing music, Mr. Iyer also has a Ph.D in cognitive science of music and has written extensively on the relationship between music and society. Mr. Iyer was recently awarded the MacArthur Genius grant and appointed a professor in the department of music at Harvard University.

headline: Manila’s Mayor to Address Tensions With Hong Kong
text: MANILA — A former Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, now the mayor of Manila, hopes to accomplish in the next few weeks what the national government has failed to do in three years: mend strained ties with Hong Kong over a botched hostage rescue attempt in 2010 in which eight tourists from there were killed.

headline: Revenue Slumps at BNP Paribas, but Profit Rises on Cost-Cutting
text: LONDON — The French bank BNP Paribas reported better-than-expected earnings in the third quarter despite lower overall revenue and a nearly 11 percent decline in its investment-banking business resulting from a “lackluster” economic environment.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 31, 2013
text: Use context clues and your knowledge of word roots to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

headline: Movie’s Flop Contributes to a Loss for Sony
text: TOKYO — After tantalizing investors with signs of a financial turnaround in the spring, Sony said on Thursday that it swung back to a loss in its summer quarter as strong sales of smartphones were not enough to overcome a dismal performance by the company’s Hollywood arm.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | How a Tick Sticks
text: In the article “How Does a Tick Do Its Dirty Work? Research Video Offers a Clue” and related video, James Gorman explains what scientists have learned about how ticks latch onto skin.

headline: Should We Rethink How Long Students Spend in High School?
text: High school in the United States traditionally lasts four years. But should it?

headline: Duane Michals: Heart of the Question
text: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: The Pills of Last Resort
text: It was shortly after the breadbasket arrived last year at the Temple Bar near Harvard Square that Sarah Broom first told me about the last-ditch plan to save her own life.

headline: Syria Destroys Chemical Sites, Inspectors Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s ability to produce chemical weapons has been destroyed and its remaining toxic armaments secured, weapons inspectors said Thursday, as President Bashar al-Assad has offered unexpectedly robust cooperation, at least so far, with a Russian-United States accord to dismantle his arsenal.

headline: Q. & A.: Philip Potter on the Growing Risk of Terrorism in China
text: The Beijing police say that the vehicle crash and explosion near Tiananmen Square on Monday, which killed five people and injured 40, was a terrorist attack and have arrested five members of the Uighur ethnic minority group whom they have labeled as Islamic extremists.

headline: New York Today: Li’l Lhota vs. de Blasio Jr.
text: Updated 11:09 a.m. | We wanted to cover Halloween today. And mayoral politics.

headline: Wheelies: The Cash for Clunkers Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

headline: Daily Report: States Take Lead in Online Privacy Legislation
text: State legislatures around the country, facing growing public concern about the collection and trade of personal data, have rushed to propose a series of privacy laws, from limiting how schools can collect student data to deciding whether the police need a warrant to tap cellphones, Somini Sengupta reports.

headline: Jobless Rate in Euro Zone Stays at Record
text: FRANKFURT — The economic recovery in the euro zone is feeble. Employment continues to suffer. And the patient is likely to be getting around on crutches for months if not years to come. That was essentially the prognosis from two key economic indicators published Thursday and from economists assessing the latest conditions.

headline: Profit Margins Squeeze Shell and Exxon Mobil
text: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell, Europe’s largest company by market capitalization, reported sharply lower earnings for its third quarter as weak profit margins in refining, and disruption in Nigeria, one of Shell’s leading production areas, hurt results.

headline: Chegg Seeks to Raise Up to $172.5 Million in I.P.O.
text: Chegg, a start-up focused on textbook rental and academic services, said on Thursday that it hoped to raise up to $172.5 million in its initial public offering.

headline: The Royal Family on Twitter: Approved Disclosure, in Short Bursts
text: LONDON — To follow Britain’s royal family on its Twitter accounts is to enter a universe that Shakespeare, with his battle-scarred kings and anguished princes, would not recognize.

headline: Seeing a Turning Point for China’s Thinking on Terrorism
text: One of China’s leading experts on counterterrorism and foreign policy predicted on Thursday that the fiery crash of a vehicle three days earlier near the Chinese leadership’s compound at the edge of Tiananmen Square would lead to a broad reassessment of domestic security and China’s diplomacy.

headline: 3 Star Deal Makers Form London Advisory Boutique
text: LONDON – They could call themselves the three Simons of investment banking.

headline: Digging Into Deep Pockets at Auction
text: It’s strange to think that just a decade ago, Christie’s entire evening sale of postwar and contemporary art totaled $62 million. On Nov. 12, during the second of the two big auction weeks that start in New York on Monday night, Christie’s is offering one painting — a Francis Bacon triptych — that is expected to bring $85 million. Its archrival, Sotheby’s, has a 1963 Warhol that it anticipates will sell for $60 million to $80 million.

headline: Afraid of Snakes? Your Pulvinar May Be to Blame
text: Multiple Walter Whites will walk the streets on Thursday in search of candy. But some frights endure the fashion cycle and never go out of style.

headline: Black and White and in the Red
text: WITHIN a month of taking over as editor of The Hatchet, George Washington University’s student newspaper, Cory Weinberg knew that something had to change. Advertising dollars had been steadily declining. Printing costs continued to rise. At the same time, visits to the website were up. The number of students reading articles on their mobile devices had doubled. Traffic from Twitter had increased 300 percent in the last year.

headline: 1961: Rue des Mauvais Garçons to Keep Name
text: PARIS —The City of Paris came to the defense of its rowdy past today when Prefect Jean Benedetti refused to change the name of the Rue des Mauvais-Garçons (Street of Bad Boys—or hoodlums in French slang).

headline: Trick-or-Treating, Honestly
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Times Co. Posts a Loss, Hurt by Sale of The Globe
text: The New York Times Company reported a quarterly loss on Thursday, attributable in large part, the company said, to expenses related to the sale of the New England Media Group, which included The Boston Globe, and some pension expenses.

headline: Time Warner Left Bruised in Fee Battle With CBS
text: The CBS blackout in homes with Time Warner Cable ended in early September. But the damage from the feud is still being tallied up — and it may be lasting.

headline: Some Essential Reading (and Viewing) on Government Surveillance and the Press
text: On the endlessly fascinating subject of journalists, press rights and government surveillance, in what might be called the Snowden era, a few recently published articles (and a television interview) may be of interest.

headline: Acrostic
text: Acrostic puzzle for November 3, 2013

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for November 3, 2013

headline: Young, Restless and Indian
text: MUMBAI, India — Back in 2003, when I lived in a small, liberal California town near Berkeley, the prospect of George W. Bush’s re-election filled my neighbors and me with palpable dread. At our annual block party some of us facetiously repeated things he’d said, Bushisms like “I know the human being and fish can coexist peacefully.” What we really meant was that we could not coexist with Bush, peacefully or otherwise.

headline: In Shadows, Hints of a Life and Even a Job for Snowden
text: MOSCOW — On very rare occasions, almost always at night, Edward J. Snowden leaves his secret, guarded residence here, somewhere, in Russia. He is always under close protection. He spends his days learning the language and reading. He recently finished “Crime and Punishment.”

headline: After a Run of Growth, Concern Over Japan’s Next Moves
text: HONG KONG — Nearly a year after the Japanese began to hope that their economy could turn around under new leadership, a sense of realism is replacing the euphoria.

headline: A Doggie Bag for Your Jeep
text: Just about anyone with a large dog can appreciate a vehicle with a large rear compartment. The trouble is, with all that space back there it can be difficult to keep things secured in one spot — particularly an animal with a mind of its own. Many dog owners buy those cagelike steel partitions that mount just behind the rear seats of a sport utility vehicle, crossover or wagon, but what if you want to drive a car that doesn’t look like a mobile animal control unit?

headline: Loud and Colorful, With Total Recall
text: In 1967, the same year that the playwright Tennessee Williams found himself in the depths of substance abuse, depression and critical failure, a short, busty, outspoken 17-year-old named Susana Ventura completed her tenure in reform school and ran away from working-class New Britain, Conn. She moved to downtown Manhattan, was sheltered by drag queens and fell under the tutelage of gay artists including Andy Warhol; the filmmaker and performance artist Jack Smith; and John Vaccaro, founder of the avant-garde Play-House of the Ridiculous theater group.

headline: And a Child Shall Lead Them Into Space Battle
text: At one point in “Ender’s Game,” the boy brainiac Ender Wiggin stands on a podium waving his arms. A vast, immersive image of outer space is spread out before him, and if you didn’t know better, you might think he was playing Wii on an Imax screen. It’s an amusingly self-reflexive moment in a humorless movie about children who play war games as part of their very grown-up military training. As he furiously moves spaceships and troops across computer screens, he looks, by turns, like a superexcited kid, an orchestra conductor, Mickey Mouse as the Sorcerer’s Apprentice and even a Christ figure. Childhood can be tough in movies, but rarely do screen children suffer for our sins as they do here.

headline: Free Speech, for the Loudest
text: Even those who oppose New York City’s “stop and frisk” policy should be chagrined about the way noisy protesters at Brown University on Tuesday greeted the city’s police commissioner, Raymond Kelly.

headline: Filling Cavities Can Be a Laugh, but Dentists Still Suggest Limiting Gummies at Halloween
text: No Sour Patch Kids, no Skittles, no Swedish Fish. Same goes for Starbursts, gummi bears and Nerds.

headline: A Journalist With a Mission
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A young American lawyer comes to Brazil in 2005, falls in love, finds that his gay relationship confers greater legal rights than back home, starts a blog called Unclaimed Territory focusing on illegal warrantless eavesdropping by the National Security Agency, takes a place in the hills of Rio with a bunch of rescue dogs, denounces the cozy compromises of “establishment journalists,” gets hired to write a column by Britain’s Guardian newspaper, is sought out by the N.S.A. whistle-blower Edward J. Snowden, becomes the main chronicler of Snowden’s revelations of global American surveillance, is lionized for work that prompts a far-reaching debate on security and freedom, files repeated thunderbolts from his leafy Brazilian perch, and ends up, in just eight years, as perhaps the most famous journalist of his generation.

headline: Another Delay for Small-Business Health Exchanges? Depends on Whom You Ask.
text: If you thought that the small business health insurance exchange would be fully working Friday, prepare for some disappointment. On Tuesday, while testifying at a House hearing, Marilyn Tavenner, the head of the Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services, the government agency implementing the federally run health insurance exchanges, said that the Small Business Health Options exchanges would be functional “at the end of November.”

headline: On the Trail of a Nuisance
text: Dusty Kennedy and Clint Watson head out with their dogs to hunt feral hogs.

headline: Slower Growth: It’s Not Just Government
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: F.A.A. Approves Use of Devices on Flights
text: It’s game on, quite literally, for airline passengers who want to use their cellphones and other portable electronics during flights. The Federal Aviation Administration announced Thursday morning that it has approved the use of electronic devices during all phases of a flight, with a few exceptions, according to a release from the agency.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Fisherman’
text: Two well-known Irish poets are remembered in this Poetry Pairing, which features the nearly 100-year-old poem “The Fisherman” by William Butler Yeats, and the August 2013 obituary “Seamus Heaney, Irish Poet of Soil and Strife, Dies at 74” by Margalit Fox.

headline: F.A.A. Moves to Ease Electronics Ban, Opening the Runways to Angry Birds
text: WASHINGTON — The days of airline passengers being hounded to turn off their tablets or e-readers for takeoff and landing are coming to an end.

headline: Baby Book as Battleground
text: At first glance, you might mistake this little book for one of those slightly old-fashioned illustrated stories grandparents give preschoolers as holiday gifts. It could be a Golden Book, say, illustrated by Garth Williams. This one is already inscribed: “To my little birthday bunny on his special day. Love, Gran Gran.” The note appears to have been written in ballpoint by someone who studied penmanship. But below that inscription, the book’s title has been defaced: What was once “Birthday Bunny” has been scrawled over, with a marker and in a far less steady hand. It now reads, “Battle Bunny.”

headline: The Gun Report: October 31, 2013
text: The police chief in Sanford, Fla., where George Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch volunteer, shot and killed 17-year-old Trayvon Martin last year, is set to unveil rules stressing that volunteers are not to carry guns or follow suspects. In a community meeting next week, Police Chief Cecil Smith, who took over the department in April and quickly and suspended the neighborhood watch program, will emphasize that members are to call police when they see a suspicious person or activity. Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder in July.

headline: The Less-Skilled Surgeon
text: Video from a study in The New England Journal of medicine demonstrating a less-skilled surgeon. Warning: Graphic content.

headline: The Highly-Ranked Surgeon
text: Video from a study in The New England Journal of medicine demonstrating a good surgeon. Warning: Graphic content.

headline: Reshuffling at Time Inc. to Set Table for Spinoff
text: Seeking to increase revenue by building a closer partnership between business and the newsroom, Time Inc. said on Thursday that the editors of its individual magazines would report directly to the company’s business side for the first time in its history, instead of the editor in chief of Time Inc.

headline: James Blake Wins Britain’s Mercury Prize
text: James Blake, a pianist and singer whose music is a blend of gentle, soulful ballad structures with beats and electronic textures, was awarded this year’s Barclaycard Mercury Prize for his second album, “Overgrown,” at a ceremony at the Roundhouse in London on Wednesday. The $32,000 prize, which was established in 1992 by the British Phonographic Industry and British Association of Record Dealers, is for the best British or Irish album of the year, selected by an anonymous jury.

headline: A Property Fight in the Adirondacks, Brewing for a Century, Is on the Ballot
text: TOWNSHIP 40, N.Y. — There are no road signs leading to this place, a square swath of Adirondack Park greenery in Hamilton County. There is no “Welcome to...” or “Thanks for visiting...” sign. Indeed, visitors would have to be a cartographer, or maybe an environmental lawyer, to know they were there.

headline: M.V.P. Goes to a Most Valuable Papi
text: BOSTON — David Ortiz had done everything else right in this World Series. He had hit just about every pitch. He had said the right things, at the right moments. Now, he could make one more memory. He held the World Series Most Valuable Player trophy high, in his right hand, looked out at his people, and shouted, “This is for you, Boston!”

headline: T WINTER LUXURY
text: At their Milan atelier, one of the last truly Old World interiors firms, Studio Peregalli, is making history — mining everything from the high Renaissance to the Victorian era — to create deeply poetic spaces that transcend the bounds of time.

headline: Performing Global Warming
text: You may have already heard Daniel Crawford perform his cello composition “A Song for Our Warming Planet,” built with notes representing each year’s global average surface temperature:

headline: Intimidating Pakistan’s Press
text: LONDON — The Shura-e-Mujahedeen, a group affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban, recently reissued a year-old fatwa describing Pakistani journalists and media outlets as “enemies of the mujahedeen.” The decree threatened several radio stations and included photographs of the popular political talk show hosts Hamid Mir and Hasan Nisar, accusing them of promoting secular and Western values and spreading anti-Muslim propaganda. The fatwa was first issued following widespread condemnation by Pakistani journalists of the Taliban’s attempt to kill the teenage education activist Malala Yousafzai in October 2012. The announcement raises concerns about journalists’ safety in a country that is already among the deadliest in the world for reporters.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 9 Matchup Breakdown
text: In a season in which Knowshon Moreno, who was undrafted in some leagues, is fantasy football’s No. 2 running back and Doug Martin, who was supposed to be fantasy’s No. 2 running back (based on average draft position), is probably available on your league’s waiver wire, nobody should be surprised that the rookie Marvin Jones (CIN) is suddenly a top-15 wide receiver.

headline: Scores of Migrants From Niger Found Dead in Sahara
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The decomposing bodies of 87 migrants from the impoverished West African nation of Niger were discovered in the Sahara this week just a few miles from a well, apparently stranded after a desperate search for water, said the head of a local humanitarian organization who helped bury many of the bodies.

headline: The Dreams of War
text: The Civil War placed new and unique strains on Americans, and their dreams reflected those hardships. Sometimes the war intruded on people’s slumber, vividly bringing to life the horrors of the conflict; for others, nighttime was an escape from the hard realities of life and death in wartime. When Americans recorded their dreams in their diaries, letters and memoirs, they sought to make sense of the changing world around them, and to cope with the confusion, despair, and loneliness of life amid the turmoil of a gigantic civil war.

headline: Former Premier Can Be Charged, Czech Court Rules
text: PARIS — The Czech Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that former Prime Minister Petr Necas was not entitled to immunity from prosecution for the period when he was head of government, clearing the way for prosecutors who have been seeking to charge him with corruption.

headline: U.S. Teams Up With Operator of Online Courses to Plan a Global Network
text: Coursera, a California-based venture that has enrolled five million students in its free online courses, announced on Thursday a partnership with the United States government to create “learning hubs” around the world where students can go to get Internet access to free courses supplemented by weekly in-person class discussions with local teachers or facilitators.

headline: A Play That’s Sure to Make You Sweat
text: THE Russian and Turkish Baths on 10th Street in the East Village is a place where people (including, legend has it, Frank Sinatra, Timothy Leary and John Belushi) have gone for escape for more than a century. But the baths could easily pass for a place you would want to escape from, under different circumstances. Inside, they are dark and dank and sweaty, packed with masses of hot, sagging flesh, a spa version of Dante’s City of Dis, where the heretics are punished in burning stone coffins.

headline: Are Caregivers Healthier?
text: The idea that caring for a chronically ailing or disabled family member might be good for you is so startling, so counterintuitive, that it sends researchers rummaging through their data to see where they went wrong.

headline: What to Do When Your Child Asks About Your Income
text: Of all the money questions that our kids will eventually ask, the inquiry about our income may be the toughest one of all to answer. Why, exactly, do they want to know how much money we make? And what are they going to do with the information?!

headline: A Grim Aftermath
text: Residents of Centro do Meio, Brazil, are still dealing with an attack on a soccer field that left two men dead. It began with a yellow card.

headline: Cirque du Soleil Facing Fines in Death of Performer
text: After a four-month investigation the Nevada Occupational Safety and Health Administration has fined Cirque du Soleil and the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas for safety violations that the agency said led to the death of a 31-year-old French acrobat, Sarah Guillot-Guyard, in a fall during a performance of “KA” on June 29.

headline: In Our Pages: November 1
text: 1888 Zola Condemned

headline: Best Illustrated Books
text: The New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2013, with sample artwork from each.

headline: Walker Tower Penthouse Under Contract
text: A full-floor penthouse atop Walker Tower, a newly converted luxury condominium in Chelsea, has gone into contract for more than $50 million, a new high for a condo sale in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Image of the Day: October 31
text: Thursday marked the 29th anniversary of the death of former Indian prime minister Indira Gandhi.

headline: Kerry to Visit Saudi Arabia to Smooth Relations
text: Secretary of State John Kerry will begin a nine-day trip to the Middle East, Europe and North Africa on Sunday by stopping in Saudi Arabia for talks with King Abdullah, a major ally who is angered over what he sees as Obama administration failures on Syria, Egypt, the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and relations with Iran.

headline: One Complicated Life, Illustrated
text: In her engaging and ultimately sad biography of Norman Rockwell, Deborah Solomon fills in the partly known life of one of America’s most famous and popular illustrator-artists. Because Rockwell has been well documented — from his own autobiography in 1960 to periodic monographs from art-book publishers in later decades — a skeptic might ask if a new accounting is needed. Well, no and yes.

headline: If Your Child Was Bullied, When Did You Intervene and When Did You Stay Out?
text: It is a very painful and scary thing for parents to learn that their child is being bullied. Though my four — now young adults — were relatively popular and athletic kids, I watched them go through bullying several times. It was one of the the harder problems I faced as a dad, and it’s the topic we are asking our readers to discuss this week: Do I intervene on behalf of my children or hold back and let them work out the problem themselves?

headline: A Vital Measure: Your Surgeon’s Skill
text: To those of us in training, the hospital was cursed. At least when it came to a certain operation.

headline: Ann Patchett: By the Book
text: After the novelist, memoirist and author of “This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage” read “Charlotte’s Web” at age 9, she became so obsessed, she got a pet pig: “That’s impact.”

headline: Changes on In-Flight Electronic Devices
text: Michael P. Huerta, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, explained the relaxed rules on using electronic devices during flights.

headline: Planned Obsolescence, as Myth or Reality
text: The new iPhone is out. That means, as I wrote in a column for the coming issue of The New York Times Magazine, that conspiracy theories again abound about ways that older models start to become more unattractive and dysfunctional around the time that a shiny new upgrade is available.

headline: MARKET REPORT
text: From cocktail dresses to jewelry, blue feathers are marking their territory as a timeless wardrobe addition.

headline: A Second N.F.L. Player Signs Public Offering Deal
text: Fantex, the company that introduced the first initial public offering for an athlete, has signed its second client.

headline: Air France-KLM Writes Off Alitalia Stake
text: PARIS — Air France-KLM, the French-Dutch airline, said Thursday that it had written off the entire value of its 25 percent holding in its partner Alitalia, raising doubts that it will take part in a plan to inject 300 million euros into the struggling Italian flag carrier.

headline: Booker Joins the Senate and Casts His First Vote
text: WASHINGTON — Cory A. Booker, who gained celebrity as a danger-defying, super-tweeting mayor of Newark, was sworn in as New Jersey’s junior United States senator on Thursday. He is the first African-American to be elected to the chamber since Barack Obama in 2004.

headline: Jane Austen Portrait Intrigue Deepens
text: Jane Austen may have been dead for nearly 200 years, but she continues to make waves in Britain.

headline: G.O.P. Filibuster of 2 Obama Picks Sets Up Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday thwarted the confirmation of two of President Obama’s nominees, one to a powerful appeals court and another to a home-lending oversight post, setting up a confrontation with Democrats that could escalate into a larger fight over limiting the filibuster and restrict how far the minority party can go to block a president’s agenda.

headline: A Landmark Turn in India’s Medical Negligence Law
text: Anuradha Saha died painfully in May 1998 at the age of 36, her skin sloughed off all over her body, except for her skull. She was encased in bandages meant to prevent infections that had already lodged in her system. Her immunity had been compromised after receiving a high dosage of steroids from some of the top doctors in Kolkata.

headline: Love Trouble
text: It should not be strange to encounter any of Shakespeare’s plays at any time of the year, so firmly ensconced are they in the canon. And yet there’s something a little startling in the arrival of a production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” opening in November, as Julie Taymor’s upcoming production at Theater for a New Audience will. The play is among Shakespeare’s most beloved and most frequently produced, but it has mostly become a rite of summer, often performed outdoors, with picnickers sharing bottles of wine and children romping on grass.

headline: As Security Deteriorates at Home, Iraqi Leader Arrives in U.S. Seeking Aid
text: WASHINGTON — When Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq last visited the White House, he and his host painted a glowing picture of the situation in Iraq after the withdrawal of American forces.

headline: Australia Said to Play Part in N.S.A. Effort
text: BEIJING — Australia, a close ally of the United States, has used its embassies in Asia to collect intelligence as part of the National Security Agency’s global surveillance efforts, according to a document leaked by the former agency contractor Edward J. Snowden and published this week in the German newsmagazine Der Spiegel.

headline: When Joy Storms the Field
text: Crowds of emotional fans have often created a memorable pandemonium after the winning of a pennant or a World Series.

headline: Profit Margins Squeeze Exxon Mobil and Shell
text: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings on Thursday because of weaker profit margins in refining and a sluggish global economy.

headline: Starting Windows 8.1 in Desktop Mode
text: Q. I read that you can make Windows 8.1 start directly in desktop mode instead of going to the Start Screen apps, but how?

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 9 Tiered Rankings Overview
text: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Today in Small Business: Drones That Deliver Pizza
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Tablets on a Plane
text: It took a while, but common sense has finally prevailed when it comes to the rules governing travelers’ use of electronic devices on planes. The Federal Aviation Administration announced on Thursday that passengers could soon be allowed to use tablet computers, e-books, music players and other devices in planes at almost all times as long as their wireless functions are disabled by putting the device in “airplane mode.” (The editorial board backed changing F.A.A.’s policies earlier this month.)

headline: A Call for ‘Scrooge McDucks’ to Pinch Fewer Pennies
text: The billionaire bond analyst Bill Gross is calling on “the Scrooge McDucks” of the world to share a little more of their wealth.

headline: Booker Is Sworn In as Senator
text: Cory A. Booker, the former mayor of Newark, became the newest member of the Senate after he was sworn in by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: On-Screen Frights
text: Select offereings in the Scary Movies series at the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Dwight Merriman of MongoDB on Leading by Enthusiasm
text: This interview with Dwight Merriman, chairman and co-founder of MongoDB, an open-source document database, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: In Saudi Arabia, Even Writing About Female Drivers Can Mean Trouble
text: A columnist in Saudi Arabia who published a commentary on women’s rights has been detained by the authorities as they cracked down on a campaign by the kingdom’s women this month to defy a ban on driving.

headline: Toronto Police Chief Says Mayor Appears in Video Uncovered in Criminal Investigation
text: Updated, 3:09 p.m. | Toronto’s police chief, Bill Blair, revealed at a news conference on Thursday that Mayor Rob Ford “does appear” in a digital video file uncovered in the course of a criminal investigation into his friend and sometime driver.

headline: Batista’s Bravado, Even After His Company’s Bankruptcy
text: Even bankruptcy can’t subdue Eike Batista’s bombast.

headline: In Amish Country, on the Train to Paradise
text: The double hoot of a steam train jolted me awake. I peeked out the window above my bed. A wispy gray tuft billowed behind a massive coal-burning locomotive as it chuffed across fields of Amish farmland toward Paradise, Pa.

headline: In Stockholm, ABBA, Alcohol and Animals
text: Buzzy new gastropubs and drinking salons have been proliferating throughout Stockholm’s urban islands, from pockets of the tourist-heavy Gamla Stan to hip Sodermalm, which today is a virtual Little Brooklyn with its bars, body art and beards. But Djurgarden, the tranquil two-mile-long island in the middle of the capital, had largely been a stalwart against these waves of change. Dense with meadows, an aging amusement park and staid museums, Djurgarden lacked the dynamic appeal that pulses in nearby areas. But recent openings on the western edge are infusing new life into this oft-overlooked island.

headline: After Fraud, the Fog Around Libor Hasn’t Lifted
text: The Libor market, we now know, was a fraud. There were few — if any — real trades backing the indicator.

headline: Student Contest | 15-Second Vocabulary Videos
text: Update, Dec. 20: Winners have been announced!

headline: In Namibia, Conservation and Tourism Intersect
text: Uamunikaije Tjivinda squatted in the sand and threw a few strips of dried giraffe meat into a pot of boiling water. Like many Himba women in the arid, northwestern part of Namibia called Kaokoland, she wore sandals, a goatskin skirt and little else. Her skin and long, plaited hair were a striking rust-red, rubbed with ocher dug from the earth.

headline: A Mood Change at Security Checkpoints
text: Mood lighting and upbeat music aren’t revolutionary ideas for romancing a date, but they may be for wooing travelers at airport security checkpoints. At least that’s the hope of the creators of a new security experience being tested at the Charlotte-Douglas and Dallas-Fort Worth International Airports over the next few months.

headline: Jos. A. Bank Says It May Raise Bid for Men’s Wearhouse
text: Jos. A. Bank said on Thursday that it was willing to raise its takeover bid for Men’s Wearhouse, but only if its target was willing to begin merger talks.

headline: Parents’ Group Challenges Theater’s Policy on ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color’
text: Soon after church groups denounced Monty Python’s “Life of Brian” as blasphemous, John Cleese was asked, in a television interview, what he thought of the ruckus. “These people have made me,” he said, calmly, and with a dramatic pause, “a very rich man.”

headline: 10,000-Year Study Finds Oceans Warming Fast, But From a Cool Baseline
text: I had a fascinating and fruitful chat with Yair Rosenthal of Rutgers and Braddock Linsley of Columbia University — two authors of an important new Science paper extracting 10,000 years of temperature changes in fairly deep Pacific Ocean waters from fossil plankton buried in the seabed off Indonesia.

headline: When Joy Storms the Field
text: On Wednesday night, after the Red Sox took a 6-0 lead against the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 6 of the World Series, the Boston police were getting ready for an onslaught of emotional fans, announcing on Twitter, “Anyone who is not in a bar and does not have a ticket to the game must leave the permitter area around #Fenway.”

headline: Recovered Video of Mayor Roils Toronto
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s largest city, Toronto, was in political turmoil on Thursday after the police said they had recovered a video apparently showing Mayor Rob Ford smoking crack cocaine.

headline: Work by Britten Resurfaces at American Ballet Theater
text: A Benjamin Britten orchestration of Chopin piano music that was believed to be lost will re-enter the repertory on Friday night when American Ballet Theater uses it for its performance of Michel Fokine’s “Les Sylphides” at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Google Announces New Phone and Updates Operating System
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Every day, Google crawls and indexes the entire Internet to help deliver the best search results on its website. Now the company wants to apply the same firepower to dig through applications on smartphones that run the Android operating system.

headline: A Southwest Orientation
text: With the opening in June of Palomino, Rafael Palomino added to his “nuevo Latino” restaurant holdings, which include the perennially popular Sonora, in Port Chester, N.Y.; Bistro Latino and Pacifico, both in Connecticut; and Mesa, Pacifico and Tapas on Main, all in Pennsylvania. (There has been some shuffling: this Palomino is not to be confused with Palomino in Old Greenwich, Conn., which became Greenwich Tavern and then Bistro Latino; Bistro Latino in Tuckahoe and Pacifico in Port Chester have closed). The author of several books, he also runs a consulting company, Latino Chef, and a catering company, Pasión. With his jazzy branding and meticulously built dishes, Mr. Palomino has made a name for himself.

headline: Set for Marathon, Ex-Addicts Find Their Way
text: CORIANO, Italy — It is still dark when Sara Floriddia laces her shoes and goes running on the hilltop roads near the Adriatic coast of Italy. With every mile, she leaves her past further behind.

headline: Timetable for Opening of Small Business Exchanges May Not Represent a Delay
text: Another Delay for Small-Business Health Exchanges? Depends on Whom You Ask.

headline: Gastronomia Culinaria
text: Inside the Upper West Side restaurant that evokes a small Roman trattoria.

headline: Ewan McGregor to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Real Thing’
text: Updated, 6:13 p.m. | Ewan McGregor will follow in the footsteps of Roger Rees, Jeremy Irons and Stephen Dillane when he stars in “The Real Thing,” the 1982 play that many theatergoers consider Tom Stoppard’s best.

headline: A Modest Reminder of Rome
text: The bread lay on a notched wooden board, anchored by a saucer of something creamy and wildly green that evoked pesto but tasted like ocean floor. When asked about the ingredients, the waiter looked startled. “I do not know the name for this in English,” he said. “Rucola? Also a small fish.” Arugula and anchovy, a woman at my table suggested. He smiled, shrugged and vanished.

headline: A Yellow Card, Then Unfathomable Violence, in Brazil
text: PIO XII, Brazil — It was midafternoon that Sunday when Otávio Jordão da Silva Cantanhede left on his bike to play pickup soccer. His father said he did not see him tuck a knife into his shorts or slide a blade into his backpack.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Italy, the West Bank, the Philippines and India.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: tainted spices, commuting’s costs and smoking’s quit day. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: To Boldly Go, but Not to Blog
text: Busy day, not sure if I will manage to get anything up. But for your surreal pleasure: the US Navy has a brand-new super-high-tech ship, the Elmo Zumwalt — stealth, incredibly long-range weapons, etc.. And who is the new vessel’s captain?

headline: Decision From the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
text: Read the full decision from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

headline: Social Network for Opinions Gets a Dose of New Money
text: It’s not hard to find people who express strong opinions about politics, social issues and their favorite movies on Facebook and Twitter. In fact, there’s a whole cottage industry of researchers and entrepreneurs dedicated to mining social networks using language analysis tools to measure sentiments.

headline: Court Blocks Stop-and-Frisk Changes for New York Police
text: A federal appeals court on Thursday halted a sweeping set of changes to the New York Police Department’s practice of stopping and frisking people on the street, and, in strikingly personal terms, criticized the trial judge’s conduct and removed her from the case.

headline: Activism Is Going Global, Citi Warns Clients
text: Citigroup has a message for the international companies it advises: Watch out for the activists.

headline: Writing Bytes
text: The Internet has changed (and keeps changing) how we live today — how we find love, make money, communicate with and mislead one another. Writers in a variety of genres tell us what these new technologies mean for storytelling.

headline: Russian Diamond Firm Closes Higher After Offering
text: MOSCOW — Shares of the Russian diamond-mining company Alrosa closed slightly higher on Thursday in their first day of trading, indicating some investor enthusiasm for a stock that offers a way to place a market bet on the price of diamonds.

headline: Market Report | Timeless, Feathery Finds
text: The plume briefly disappeared from the fashion scene after last year’s Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge-inspired fascinator craze died down. But now it’s back, this time on clothes and accessories and in varying shades of blue, from deep sapphire to a bluish gray. Feathers complement satin as a shapely detail on a Christopher Kane cocktail dress, a dangling tassel on a Roger Vivier heel and on the diamond-encrusted face on a Harry Winston watch; and take center stage as the main material of a Louis Vuitton handbag. Fanned around a white gold and diamond cuff from Wilfredo Rosado, sapphire feathers add interest to any evening look. And unlike the fascinator, Stephen Russell’s archival feather brooch, made entirely of actual sapphires and diamonds, will never go out of style.

headline: An Abundance of Asian Flavors
text: If you’re trying to find Aja, a pan-Asian spot on Route 1 North in New Brunswick, look for the multicolored lights swooping across a lumber framework that hides the building’s origins as a Fuddruckers. (The Aja sign is illegible at highway speed.)

headline: Hydrangea Hyperbole at New York Botanical Garden
text: Seed catalogs can tell tales, and not just about shifting tastes in flower-bed palettes. In 19th-century America, these promotional booklets tried to convince customers that gardens could change the world.

headline: 'Promises'
text: The most recent ad from the Lhota campaign features the candidate speaking directly to the camera.

headline: Oracle Shareholders Oppose Compensation for Ellison
text: A majority of Oracle shareholders demonstrated their opposition to the compensation of the software giant’s chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, on Thursday, voting against a nonbinding resolution on the company’s pay practices.

headline: Sophie Calle: ‘Absence’
text: Paula Cooper Gallery

headline: Richard Hollis
text: Artists Space: Books & Talks

headline: Worker’s TB Investigated at Hospital
text: An employee who worked in the maternity ward of a Manhattan hospital tested positive for tuberculosis, setting off a search for anyone who might have come in contact with the infected worker, including dozens of newborn babies.

headline: Michaela Eichwald: ‘Ergriffenes Dasein: Artist, Writer, Mentalist’
text: Reena Spaulings Fine Art

headline: David Shaw: ‘Eat Out’
text: Feature Inc.

headline: Farrell Brought Consistency to a Franchise in Chaos
text: BOSTON — A year ago, the Boston Red Sox opened Fenway Park for Halloween. Children paraded around the warning track in costumes. There were face painters, magicians and balloon artists. Will Middlebrooks, Rich Gedman and Wally the Green Monster greeted fans.

headline: What You Can’t See Is Even Cooler
text: Mordecai-Mark Mac Low, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, was showing off an exhibit about the history of the universe outside the Hayden Planetarium there eight years ago, he says, when a schoolteacher approached him and said, “You don’t really believe all this Big Bang stuff, do you?”

headline: Daniel Lopatin Music at MoMA PS1, and Drama at Theater 167
text: The composer Daniel Lopatin has attracted a lot of attention over the last few years for someone working in the avant-garde of electronic dance music under the almost farcically unwieldy name Oneohtrix Point Never.

headline: A Bluesy Voice for Country, Heavy on Experience
text: If there was ever a time to be young and female and blond in country music, it was the mid-2000s: the era of Taylor, of Carrie, of Miranda. All of a sudden, the genre’s innovation was coming from its female stars, leaving their male counterparts to atrophy on the vine.

headline: American Davis Cup Team Warms to Clay Courts
text: PARIS — To beat back the British, the United States Davis Cup team is prepared to get dirty.

headline: A Floating Historian’s Hot-Air Adventure
text: Richard Holmes, author of “Falling Upwards,” takes a ride in a balloon.

headline: Salonen Meets Sibelius
text: During his adventurous 17-year tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen was so preoccupied with his work there, and with carving out time to compose, his top priority, that he had limited occasions for guest appearances with American orchestras, including the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Where Horses Wet Their Whistles
text: So, with both main mayoral candidates opposed to allowing horse-drawn carriages in the streets, a major chapter in the history of New York may be about to close. The first horses served man here no later than the 1620s, and since then they have pulled, plodded, trotted and galloped in our service.

headline: Imagining the First Strains Wafting, When the Ink Was Scarcely Dry
text: The handwritten score on display at the Morgan Library & Museum is open to a passage near the end of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony: As the orchestra and chorus are ecstatically hailing Joy, the “bright spark of divinity,” the music’s reins are suddenly pulled back, the meter shifts, and exuberance gives way to majesty.

headline: Conservative Group Tests New Attack on Health Law
text: A promise President Obama may come to regret — “If you like your health care plan, you can keep it” — is the centerpiece of the latest web video attacking the Affordable Care Act, released Thursday by Americans for Prosperity, the conservative advocacy group that is working to undo the health law.

headline: The Philanderer Reconsiders
text: “A Perfect Man” is a platitude-packed romance that might never have seen the light of day had its star, Liev Schreiber, not hit a career high with the success of Showtime’s “Ray Donovan.” As it is, this feature debut from Kees Van Oostrum, set in Amsterdam among the members of an unpleasant clique of upper-middle-class malcontents, is one of those projects whose very existence should baffle anyone hardy enough to endure all 94 minutes.

headline: A Dog’s Tail Wag Says a Lot, to Other Dogs
text: When dogs wag their tails, they can convey not just happiness but a wide array of emotions. As Italian researchers reported in 2007, a wag to the left indicates negative emotions; a wag to the right indicates positive ones.

headline: Oh, to Slip the Bonds of Earth
text: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y. — “The first rule of ballooning,” Richard Holmes said, “is to forget all your troubles and let the world fall away.” Almost as soon as he spoke, the wicker basket in which he was standing, attached to a 100-foot-tall hot-air balloon, began to rise, goosed by a blast of flame from its propane burner, and before long, he was skimming over the treetops here in Orange County. As the balloon slowly ascended, the landscape underneath increasingly resembled a train set. Startled, a buck down below began crashing through bushes. A moment later, the balloon drifted over a quiet country road, and a tractor-trailer gave a three-honk salute.

headline: Renaissance Prayer Book Is Set for Auction
text: HIGH-PRICED PRAYER BOOK

headline: Making a Home for Pakistani Runaways
text: Asad, a kind young van driver in Karachi, Pakistan, carries two kinds of passengers: lost children and corpses. He takes the children to a home for runaways or back to their parents; he is paid (usually) for the corpses.

headline: Strident Video by Chinese Military Casts U.S. as Menace
text: A conspiracy-minded 100-minute film produced by the Chinese military that was circulating widely on the Internet Thursday accuses the United States of trying to undermine the Communist Party’s control of the People’s Liberation Army and impose American values on China.

headline: Book Details Obama Aides’ Talks About Replacing Biden on 2012 Ticket
text: President Obama’s top aides secretly considered replacing Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. with Hillary Rodham Clinton on the 2012 ticket, undertaking extensive focus-group sessions and polling in late 2011 when Mr. Obama’s re-election outlook appeared uncertain.

headline: The Politics of Acoustic Guitars
text: Even if you can’t tell the difference between a soundboard and a fretboard, “Musicwood” will hold your attention. Merging the sustainability worries of guitar enthusiasts and environmentalists with the hard-cash concerns of logging corporations and Native American land developers, Maxine Trump’s thoughtful documentary wrests clarity from complexity.

headline: A Harmonic Marriage
text: “Children and Art,” John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey’s wonderful new show at the Café Carlyle, isn’t just the title of a Stephen Sondheim song from “Sunday in the Park With George.” This reflection on what matters most is paired with “Children Will Listen,” from “Into the Woods,” to make a sweeping reflection on the rewards and stresses of balancing the roles of parent and artist by musicians who are married with two children. Both songs address personal responsibility for that which we create and leave behind: “Careful the things you say/Children will listen.”

headline: Pairings for Tasting Menus: A 30-Piece Puzzle
text: Setting out on the madcap journey through a chef’s imagination that is otherwise known as a tasting menu can be a delight. It requires a commitment of time, attention and money, and the right mood and the company, but the results can be dazzling.

headline: Shaping the Future, in the Kitchen and Beyond
text: Shoehorned into half the Museum of Modern Art’s design department, “Designing Modern Women 1890-1990” is a confusing exhibition but an excellent conversation starter.

headline: A Little Shop of Possibilities
text: “Sweet Dreams,” a documentary about efforts by the Brooklyn-based Blue Marble Ice Cream company to help a group of Rwandan women open their own shop, could have come off as insensitive or twee. And in the first 10 minutes, I worried that it was, indeed, about how artisanal food could save Africa.

headline: Q. & A.: Jung Chang on Censors, Bound Feet and the Chances of a Woman Leading China
text: It was first thing Thursday morning, and the author Jung Chang, in a dramatic emerald cloak, was already holding court in a suite overlooking Hong Kong’s skyline. She was in town to promote her latest book, “Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China,” which she wrote after gaining access to historical documents in Beijing that she says “have not been seen or used outside the Chinese-speaking world.”

headline: Leaping Into a New Home, With Poetry and Storms
text: The David H. Koch Theater is fast becoming New York’s prime year-round dance house. With its large upstairs foyer, it’s also a happy home for galas, and on Wednesday, American Ballet Theater opened its first season there in 37 years with a night that was seriously glamorous. That foyer was transformed into a spectacular alternative set for “The Tempest” — the evening’s main event — with vast pillars and successive thunderclaps.

headline: ‘Rituals of Rented Island’
text: A new show at the Whitney takes a look at performance art’s beginnings.

headline: Nothing to Spend, Nothing to Lose
text: With the end of daylight saving time this weekend, we’ll set our clocks back an hour. But already in New York this fall, American art has been set back 40 years. It’s the early 1970s again, with abstract painting and performance art the fashionable modes.

headline: TV Talk: Midseason Renewals
text: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss this week’s TV cancellations and renewals.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Lhota Issues Warnings and Makes Promises
text: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor, released his latest television ad on Thursday. Titled “Promises,” it is airing on broadcast channels across New York City.

headline: Shrimp, Grits and Everything in Between
text: Jonathan Harris has a talent for grits. A native of North Carolina, Mr. Harris is the executive chef at J. Christian’s in Wallingford, where he has been offering his version of the Southern specialty since the restaurant opened in 2010. Cooked in a mixture that is equal parts chicken stock and milk, the grits are made lusciously creamy and gooey with Asiago cheese. Why Asiago? “Wallingford is an Italian town,” Mr. Harris explained on the phone after my visits. “I figured if I threw Italian cheese into the Southern grits, they would catch on faster.”

headline: Taking On Broncos and a Plague
text: Skinny as a whippet and fierce as a snapping turtle, Matthew McConaughey brings a jolt of unpredictable energy to “Dallas Buyers Club,” an affecting if conventional real-life story of medical activism. The film, directed by Jean-Marc Vallée from a script by Craig Borten and Melisa Wallack, tells the story of Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician and rodeo rider who, after receiving a diagnosis of H.I.V. in 1985, took his treatment into his own hands and helped others with the disease obtain medication not legally available in the United States at the time.

headline: Where Photography Alone Wasn’t Enough
text: A new show of portrait photography at the Rubin Museum of Art, “Allegory and Illusion” is a fascinating little piece of a very complicated puzzle. Ostensibly a focused, regional exhibition, it has much to say about the larger relationship between photography and colonialism (a subject big enough to fill several museums).

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 1-7
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Michael Arrington’s Conflicts, and Rewarding Amazon Reviewers
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: A Veteran Wave Rider Tells His Life Story in Art
text: “Surfing to me is metaphysical yoga,” the surf icon-turned-art world fixture Herbie Fletcher said. “When you’re in big waves and you take a drop, you lose your mind. It’s being in the void. There’s no thought. It’s bliss for a moment. That’s the state of mind these paintings are in,” he said about the work on view in “Path of the Wave Warrior,” a massive exhibition of his paintings, collages and sculptures on view at Known Gallery on North Fairfax Avenue in Los Angeles, through Nov. 9.

headline: Manly? Yes, in That Present-Day British Way
text: It is about time we addressed the crisis of British manhood. The once proud nation that in the last century gave us such vital and varied paragons of masculinity as Winston Churchill, Laurence Olivier, Mick Jagger and Morrissey is now represented in the popular imagination mainly by rabbity, passive-aggressive stammerers. With all due respect — or maybe just, sort of, well, just the tiniest smidgen of due respect, if you see what I mean — to Hugh Grant, it all seems to be his fault. When he sweet-talked Julia Roberts in “Notting Hill,” the whole world swooned, and the sun slid further below the horizon of John Bull’s manly old empire.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Poland, Wedded to Coal, Spurns Europe on Clean Energy Targets
text: BELCHATOW, Poland — They call it Poland’s biggest hole in the ground.

headline: Former American Embassy in Iran Attracts Pride and Dust
text: TEHRAN — Dusty and dilapidated, dwarfed by the modern high-rises of the Iranian capital, the former United States Embassy building stands in a vast compound in the center of Tehran, a forlorn symbol of what increasingly seems like a bygone era here.

headline: Help for Some Sandy Victims
text: A temporary change in a federal loan program for the rehabilitation and repair of houses may provide a new option for financing repairs to homes damaged a year ago by Hurricane Sandy.

text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: What I Love | Christian Siriano
text: A look inside the Chelsea home of the “Project Runway” winner and his partner.

headline: Christian Siriano’s Walk-Up World
text: It’s been an arduous journey for the fashion designer Christian Siriano: winning Season 4 of the reality show “Project Runway,” a triumph that his publicist asked not be mentioned here (sorry); collecting a group of celebrity clients (Taylor Swift, Christina Hendricks, Sarah Jessica Parker and Victoria Beckham among them); and finally establishing himself as a credible — and fierce — brand.

headline: App Lets Riders Forgo Cabs and Ignites Debate on Dallas’ Code
text: When Uber, the San Francisco-based company that allows customers to order rides with a cellphone app, expanded its operations to Texas, it chose Dallas as its starting point.

headline: A River in Trouble, a Question of Who Has to Sacrifice
text: Like nearly every other river in Texas, the 600-mile Colorado River — which flows from West Texas to the gulf coast — is under serious threat. Drought and surging population growth have taken their toll on the water’s flow and its wildlife and, by extension, on the farmers and fishermen who rely on it.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 1-7
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tussle in G.O.P. As Challengers Eye Primaries
text: This is not unusual: Candidates lining up to challenge incumbents in primary elections. That is a simple risk of political life.

headline: A Wave of Good Indicators
text: We lived in Boulder, Colo., in a townhouse along a narrow creek. My boyfriend, Brian, and I, along with my three children, our dogs and cat, were shoehorned into the three-level home, with the children’s bedrooms in the basement.

headline: Tipping Points
text: I recently moved to the mecca of small coffee shops. Many have tip jars on the counter. When I receive my change, I usually drop the coins into the jar. I figure this is better than no tip at all, and I don’t like carrying lots of change. But it occurs to me that this may come across as cheap and insulting. If I were a barista, I might not want a customer’s dimes and pennies. Should I tip? And if so, only with dollar bills?

headline: Bahrain Crackdown Extends to Exhibit on Crackdown
text: One day after the police in Bahrain raided the offices of an opposition party to confiscate materials being used in an exhibition on the security crackdown following the 2011 uprising, the authorities released a video statement in which a spokesman contended that the display of painting, spent tear-gas canisters and the belongings of dead protesters was being used to illegally “reinforce hatred.”

headline: British Tabloid Editors Charged in Hacking Scandal Had Affair, Prosecutors Say
text: LONDON — A high-profile phone hacking trial in Britain turned considerably seamier on Thursday when the prosecution revealed in court that the two most senior editors of the tabloid The News of the World had an affair lasting more than six years — during the period at issue in the trial, and also while both of them married other people.

headline: Buckyball Recall Stirs a Wider Legal Campaign
text: Over the last three weeks, more than 2,200 people have placed orders for $10-to-$40 sets of magnetic stacking balls, rising to the call of a saucy and irreverent social media campaign against a government regulatory agency.

headline: Building a Portfolio With a Focus on a Single Sector: Water
text: In the late 1990s, David Henderson and Khalil Maalouf bet big on young telecommunications companies, as industry landscape was changing drastically. Then the bubble burst, and the two investors got burned.

headline: Earthquake Shakes Remote Area of Taiwan
text: HONG KONG — A strong earthquake shook a remote, mountainous area of central Taiwan on Thursday evening, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

text: The New York Times film critics on "Ender's Game," "Dallas Buyers Club" and "About Time."

headline: Psyching Us Out: The Promises of ‘Priming’
text: Reports of psychological experiments are journalistic favorites.  This is especially true of experiments revealing the often surprising effects of “priming” on human behavior. Priming occurs when a seemingly trivial alteration in an experimental situation produces major changes in the behavior of the subjects.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 1-7
text: ‘Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy’

headline: Two Versions of a Dominican Tale
text: To the Editor:

headline: Old Hatreds Just Won’t Stay Buried
text: Virulent ethnic hatred doesn’t die; it lies dormant until it is suddenly prodded awake, at which point it can flare into a consuming wildfire. That is the ugly message of the Polish filmmaker Wladyslaw Pasikowski’s lurid “Aftermath,” which delivers its Holocaust-related story with the clunking force of a blunt instrument slammed into the skull.

headline: Boeing Says It Will Raise Production of the 737
text: Riding a surge in demand for new fuel-efficient planes, Boeing said on Thursday that it would increase production of its top-selling 737 jets to 47 a month by 2017, from 38 now.

headline: A Spicy Outlier of Pink Grapes
text: From a distance, the five bottles arrayed on my kitchen counter for a recent tasting — tall, with slender necks — looked Alsatian, but they were not. All contained dry Long Island gewürztraminers, which, broadly speaking, trace their style to Alsace, in northeastern France.

headline: A Writer Who’s Beat in Search of a Refuge
text: “Big Sur” cracks the code of how to adapt Jack Kerouac for the screen. The secret is deceptively simple: Go to the source and stay there. The hot-wired energy and spontaneity of the Beat mystique are embedded in writing that distills its feverish essence better than any hyped-up action. The hard part is melding readings with live action, but “Big Sur” makes it look so easy that you hardly notice the transitions.

headline: A Writer’s Lament: Working Without Pay
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Sin City, Men Will, Predictably, Be Boys
text: If you crossed “The Hangover” with “The Bucket List,” you might wind up with something like “Last Vegas.” For all I know, that may have been the exact pitch that brought a green light to this almost defiantly pointless film, competently directed by Jon Turteltaub. A mild geezer comedy full of jokes that might have sounded tired at a “Dean Martin Celebrity Roast,” the movie has no reason for existence and nothing much to recommend it.

headline: Tattoos and Bluegrass Music in the Wilds of Belgium
text: Much like the tattoos etched on the beautiful body of one character and the beard sprouting on the face of another, the narrative two-step performed in “The Broken Circle Breakdown” goes a long way toward distracting you from the familiarity of the story. The ink adorns Elise (Veerle Baetens), a tattoo artist, who lives with her bearded partner, Didier (Johan Heldenbergh), a bluegrass musician, and their young daughter, Maybelle (Nell Cattrysse), in the kind of picturesque country spread where a dog chases chickens that roost in a pickup truck. It looks like a slice of hillbilly heaven, except that this isn’t Kentucky but a pastoral corner near the Flemish city of Ghent in Belgium.

headline: Censorship in China
F.D.A. Lays Out Rule to Avoid Drug Shortages
text: The Food and Drug Administration detailed a plan on Thursday to prevent drug shortages. It fleshes out changes in a 2012 law that requires makers of important prescription drugs to notify the agency of interruptions in production that might disrupt supply. The rule, which is open to public comment for 60 days, applies for the first time to makers of “biological medicines,” which are produced in microorganisms, animal or plant cells. The agency said the number of new shortages fell to 117 last year, down from 251 in 2011.

headline: The Private Heartaches of a People’s Princess
text: Naomi Watts is one of those performers who seemingly can do no wrong, even in a waxworks like “Diana.” A slice of biographical conjecture about the Princess of Wales, this movie isn’t especially good, but it wins you over a little just because it succeeds where truckloads of sanctifying reminiscences have failed: Anchored by Ms. Watts’s sympathetic performance, it humanizes the woman behind the smile, the helmet hair and the myth. Part reheated gossip, part moony romance, it revisits an affair Diana had with a Pakistani heart surgeon, Hasnat Khan, a liaison she managed to keep from the ravenous media maw that she routinely fed and spectacularly failed to control.

headline: More Yang Than Yin? Better Fix Your Life Force
text: The fight is the thing in “Man of Tai Chi,” Keanu Reeves’s down-and-dirty and generally diverting directing debut. A story about the past and the future, the good and the bad, the strong and the weak, the movie finds a Januslike Mr. Reeves looking in two directions at once: toward the old-school kung fu movies of once upon a matinee time and the modern China emblemized by the high rises that slice through smog-swathed Beijing, where most of the story unwinds. It’s there that Tiger (Tiger Chen) logs hours between lessons with a tai chi master, Yang (Yu Hai).

headline: Malaria in United States Is at a 40-Year High
text: Malaria cases in the United States have reached a 40-year high, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Thursday, but virtually all were in travelers who were infected overseas. Of the 1,925 cases detected in 2011, almost 70 percent were in people who had visited Africa, particularly West Africa. Most others were from India. Five ended in death. Cases peaked in January and August after the Christmas and summer travel seasons. Only five cases occurred in the United States, said Dr. Paul M. Arguin, the agency’s chief of domestic malaria. One was a lab accident, another was from a blood transfusion, two were in babies born to mothers who had traveled and one occurred in winter in a patient whose travel history might not have been fully disclosed.

headline: Container Store Prices I.P.O. at Top of Heightened Range

headline: Drop in LSAT Takers Shows Legal Field’s Slump
text: Once again, fewer candidates are taking the Law School Admission Test, a sign that students recognize the continuing slump in the legal field. The latest figures released this week by the Law School Admissions Council show that nearly 11 percent fewer people took the LSAT in October than the year before. The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog calculated that this October’s 33,673 test takers represent a drop of 45 percent since the test-taking peak in 2009. Daniel M. Filler, a professor at the Earle Mack School of Law at Drexel University, blogged that some schools might see applications decline to the point that they could have to “radically restructure” to make ends meet.
